description:
The salsas here are OVER THE TOP good.

Just got a jar for my birthday (habanero)-and it is to die for.

I am drinking it right out of the jar-it is that good. ;)

Last time I had something this perfect, a woman from El Salvador made me a 1/2 gallon of it for my birthday-super secret recipe. I have missed it ever since, (they deported her-grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr).

Now I have found the clone in this jar for $7.

Life is worth living again! :)

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU V THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU, and may I have another?
author: Laurence T.

description:
The menu here is easy to follow and the portion sizes are great. The counter service was friendly and the wait time was nothing. I was able to find metered parking nearby on the same street...for a price. The tortilla chips were crispy--yum! I customized my burrito with a spinach tortilla and added avocado. 
The burrito itself was very salty..lots of salt and not much actual flavor of the ingredients. There was a significant amount of avocado in it, which I was thankful for..but it was difficult to keep going back to the same salty bites over and over. 
The salsa that many reviewers praise was some of the worst salsa I've EVER tasted. It is bland and almost tastes and smells Italian in some weird way..like pizza sauce.  I didn't like it at all and probably shouldn't have read the reviews ahead of time and gotten my hopes up. Yuck!!
author: Emily A.

description:
Came in last weekend after a long walk up and back from Twin Peaks, so I was famished and anything would have satisfied me. But the super pollo asado burrito in a spinach tortilla hit the spot and then some. The salsa is legitimately one of the best I've had (and I've been eating Mexican in the Bay Area for 30 years!) and the guacamole was outstanding. 

It's a little cramped at the counter where they take the orders, but seating is decent. Not a place to linger but that's not the point here. Since we arrived on foot, I can't speak for parking, but it's in the Mission neighborhood so it would be silly to expect easy parking.

Price wise it's comparable to any other burrito joint, but for the money, I'll be back for the 'sabores'!
author: Mi-Yung R.

description:
We were looking for a quick bite in the neighborhood. This place also accepts American Express which is a rare thing around here. We ordered takeout and our food took a long time because we didn't realize you had to stand in the front for takeout. They gave us a number and were delivering the rest of the foods --- we apparently missed the memo.

We ordered a chicken burrito supreme and carne Asad's quesadilla. When I got home, my burrito was supposed to have sour cream and guacamole and unfortunately all those things were missing. The flavors were still good, but it was really lacking those Ingredients. My husbands carne asada burrito was super salty.

I like that the food comes with free chips and salsa but that's pretty standard around the mission.

There are so many wonderful options for burritos in the area, try elsewhere. They seemed busy and had happy seeming customers, so maybe the dine in experience would have been better. 

$26.00 for a burrito and quesadilla - not crazy cheap but not crazy expensive either.
author: Alyssa A.

description: One of my favorite spots based almost entirely on the salsa. The food tends to skew a bit healthier than some of the nearby places, but is def tasty. The little dining area is ok but you're not going for the ambiance. The salsa. I've been trying to recreate it at home but its nuanced flavor profile eludes me. Luckily, you can buy it there. I just want to rub it all over my body and BE the burrito.
author: Matthew E.

description: This place sucks. Asked to sit after ordering to go. Wanted to buy beers for 10 ppl and sit. Said, no. No reason. Waited 40 minutes for a lukewarm burrito and stale gross chips. Don't go here there are so many far better places in the mission. Rude staff. Bad food. No reason to go here.
author: David B.

description:
So I was in the mission and decided to get my nachos that I so love from this place. I get home and they're like cheese less?!? Disappointing. I called the restaurant and I am now getting a credit for the new nachos next time. 
I actually did check them before I left just to make sure I got the right order but I should've looked a little bit longer.  
Bummed, I live like 20 minutes out.
*Oh yeah and look how messy I got them.
author: Tere C.

description: These guys recently added the Healthy SF tax to app their orders and increased their prices. Compared to their competition El Farolito, which is a block from this place, their burritos are overpriced and underwhelming in taste. Got the Tofu Mole.
author: Chris W.

description:
Absolutely love Papalote's food but I am writing a 1 star review for their delivery service Postmates.  Be aware if you order from Postmates, you will wait an hour for your food.

Just now, I submitted an order which was accepted at 7:09PM.  Estimated delivery time was 7:39PM which has now been pushed back to 8:18PM.  I called Papalote and my food has already been sitting there waiting for a courier to arrive.  FYI, I live 3 blocks from Papalote.

Papalote - PLEASE consider another delivery service.  I am sick and tired of receiving cold food.  Until then, I refuse to order from Papalote ever again.
author: Sandy T.

description: I love this place.  I always get the chicken mole burrito, with Spanish rice, and a spinach tortilla.  You can pick the rice, beans and tortilla.  Plus you get some of their amazing salsa (also available at Whole Foods) with the chips.  My friends liked the grilled chicken burrito as well with the sour cream, guacamole etc.  We often get the guacamole and chips, although we never finish.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Was driving around the mission last night trying to find a place to park, intending on going somewhere completely different. Rounded the corner on 24th and Papalote caught my eye. Parked a few blocks away (lucky at that!) and walked back down to restaurant. Had a vegan friend with me who was aware of their vegan mole, which he had read on line. 

Walked inside, smaller place with some family style seating on one side and a few single tables along walls. Very colorful and fun vibe, loved the large dragonflies suspended from ceiling. Waited in line for a bit and ordered at the counter. My friend ordered their veggie burrito, I ordered a chicken burrito. Was asked if I wanted guacamole and sour cream and I said sure, thinking I'd have a t least a scoop of each. 

Free chips and mole arrived at table, the mole was the best part of the dinner! If I were just there for the mole, then 4 stars. Burritos arrived, nothing on the side, everything wrapped up. The flavor was decent, ingredients fresh....but the price $14+ did not seem justified for what I got. Barely any chicken inside and the amount of guacamole and sour cream I paid the extra $1.99 for seemed like a rip off. 

In short, I feel good food but way overpriced. Would I go back again? No, sadly not.
author: Don K.

description:
3.5 stars. This was our first meal in San Francisco during this most recent trip. My fiancé and I each ordered a taco order since you get 2 of the same and we wanted to mix and match. We got the chicken mole and a chicken verde and the house salsa and chips. If they had a liquor license it would be the best place ever for a Mexican dinner night!! That being said, it was a perfect first lunch in San Francisco. The salsa is puréed and creamy like a mole and absolutely delicious! That was my favorite part of the meal. Nice kick of spice but not too spicy that you can't eat it all 
The food was all very fresh and I liked the mole but could have used a little spicy kick (I added hot sauce). I wasn't as keen on the verse sauce but it was all still good and that salsa is just awesome.
author: Heather B.

description: This is the best Mexican food in all of San Francisco. It's affordable tasty, and they make the most amazing salsa. I recommend Coming for lunch  And taking some of their salsa home for later.
author: Anne S.

description:
An incredible Mexican spot that's my second favorite the Mission (next to El Farolito)! 

Their burritos are delicious and the salsa to die for! I love their chips too. 

It was very small inside but we ordered and waited outside for it to come up. I got a huge burrito and we got tons of chips. 

I'm so grateful for all these awesome authentic Mexican spots in town!! 

Me and my friend Matt came here on an afternoon around 1pm and we were served right away. 

I'll certainly be back!
author: Bridgett W.

description: We chose Papalote to cater our wedding reception on the recommendation of our venue and we were not disappointed! Although they don't have a catering menu yet, Nancy (from the Fulton location) worked tirelessly with us to make sure we got exactly what we wanted. The price was very reasonable and the food was delicious. Our guests were raving about the taco bar for days after! Cecelia and Alma worked the taco bar during the reception and helped with the set-up and it was a fun feature at our cocktail style reception. I would definitely use Papalote again.
author: Kelly K.

description: Good After. Let me start off by saying the food is amazing. You get what you pay for. The only reason why I'm given this restaurant a 1 star is because the female cashier today around 2:3ish is not very welcoming. She was not smiling, 1 answer words, and seem over her job.
author: Deandre H.

description:
The food I got here was delicious. I ordered a burrito bowl with vegetables, no lettuce. It contained potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots... Perfectly cooked and perfectly seasoned. Pico de gallo, guacamole, beans,  and rice were all great. The sauce is tasty, though not very spicy. It's great mixed with the green hot sauce that they provide at the tables. Generous portions. 

My friend got a burrito with grilled vegetables... zucchini and eggplant. She liked the burrito... but upon trying my food, she wished she'd ordered the vegetables that I got instead. She said hers weren't as flavorful. 

The strawberry agua fresco was nice. Super refreshing.
author: Sarah W.

description: Fresh ingredients and a house salsa that is amazing on everything! I always get the burrito and it's outstanding. I took my bestie who is vegan and she loved loved loved the soyrizo! The location is small and the line will probably be out the door but it's worth the wait. If you aren't walking the city, pick up a jar (or 3) of the sauce because you will want to put it on everything!
author: Roma N.

description:
My favorite burrito location.  However, instead of getting a burrito i usually order a wet burrito (no tortilla but with salad) which i enjoy for the variety.
Of course, they have the best sauce in the world!!!
author: Michael H.

description: Decent taqueria fare, better than many. Range of offerings and options (spinach tortillas) and tasty housemade salsa you can buy. Veggie options. Friendly staff. Noise level is high -- all hard surfaces. Small, often crowded, dining area. Better to take out or delivery.
author: Kenneth O.

description: Delicious!! I got a veggie burrito and it was fantastic! The retired black beans, which are vegan, are some of the best I have ever tasted. The pico was slamming! The tomatoes in it tasted so fresh and juicy. Husband got nachos and he says they were great. This place has lots of vegetarian and vegan options and my meat eating husband was happy with his meal too. So glad we came here! Plus the place is easy to find street parking and it's in nice little spot. Only thing I hate is the bathroom as it gives me the creeps. But the seating area is great and they have these cool art pieces on the wall that change colors when you use flash photography on them. Plus free chips and their signature salsa when you dine in. What more can you ask?
author: Marley M.

description: Quaint little spot by the 24th bart with great mexican food. Iv been having a nacho craving and heard these maybe the best and they didn't disapoint. I ordered the chicken nachos and added guac and sour cream. They also come with beans, salsa, and cheese. The house chips are excellent and they also threw in an app of chips with papalote dipping sauce. I came hungry and barely finished it you can easily split it with 2 people and its delicious.
author: Sean G.

description: I came here today with my girlfriend and we ordered two burritos. After a long wait of about 20 minutes, we got our burritos. Unfortunately, there were quite a few issues... For some reason, one burrito was about 1.5x larger than the other burrito (one was single wrapped while the other was double wrapped, one was filled to the brim while the other one was half empty with fillings); there seems to be no quality control here. Secondly, though the option was given on what kind of tortilla you could have for your burrito, neither burrito we received had the tortilla that we requested. Lastly, the burritos were mislabeled. If it weren't for the delicious house salsa, Papalote would certainly be getting a 2 star. The burritos here certainly aren't cheap either (about $12 each after tax), so I'd expect a little bit more care in preparation. I would take my business to either La Taqueria or El Farolito in the future.
author: Austin W.

description: Good spot... too expensive. 2nd or 3rd choice for burritos in the mission. Good for a change once in awhile
author: Alfonso L.

description:
I've come here a few times after my friend insisted we go here over La Taqueria. Typically recommending anything over La Taquiera is blasphemy in my eyes, but I trusted her, and I'm so glad I did. 

The mole and salsa here are sooooo good! She told me they're like crack (aka super addictive), and she was right. I now always get a little extra to take home with me. (FYI, if you sit there and get food they have take away containers and they have the little containers for sauce.) 

The people working there are super friendly and patient when you're not sure what to do with their menu (which I appreciate). So far, I've gotten the veggie burrito and the quesadilla and have no complaints about either. Both are pretty big and easily last me 1.5 - 2 meals. 

Given that this place is pretty affordable and they have much better seating options than La Taqueria, I come here whenever I want to sit and eat somewhere (and generally deal with a shorter line, since they're off the main Mission streets). 

Definitely recommend this place. It will not disappoint.
author: Kavita P.

description: Amazing salsa. Great food. A little expensive. My only real complaint is they restrict how much salsa you can have. It's the only mexican restaurant I've been to where people dining in get charged by the ounce for salsa.
author: Garret R.

description:
I've been a longtime customer of Papalote; however, they're really going downhill.  Their food is just ok, but extremely overpriced.  I get it..that they supposedly use fresh ingredients and all that but, come on.  We hadn't been there for a while, but finally decided to order for pick-up a few weeks back.

My husband ordered his usual--a prawn and chicken quesadilla, and I ordered my usual--a veggie burrito.  Our total came out to be around $29! What's even worse is that my husband's quesadilla was so tiny (only two pieces) and barely any prawns in there.  They didn't even put his quesadilla in a box, they just wrapped it in foil, which caused the food to get all messed up and sloppy.  We typically don't mind paying extra for top quality food, but like I said, the quality is not even that great anymore. 

I really like the owners--Miguel and Judy (I think), so I feel bad writing this review.  But I feel really ripped off and I feel like they totally just jacked up their prices while diminishing their quality.  Also, this place is always filled with damn hipsters and techies (who are extremely annoying).
author: Cin W.

description: My carne asada burrito cost about $12 and was meh. Maybe this place is good if you don't eat meat since they have multiple veggie options. There are SO MANY taquerias in this area that do a great job of both, more affordably, so I'm confused. I'm personally sad they didn't have the mexican-filipino fusion burrito I had heard about :(
author: Hana S.

description:
As first-timers, the hubs and I shared a Triple Threat burrito - 3 proteins: chicken, beef, and shrimp. The shrimp was the star!

Tacos are mediocre. I expected more. I thought these would be like street tacos, but the tortillas weren't even warm/toasted. They were very dry and fell apart.

Lastly, I just want to point out that the housemade salsa is DELICIOUS. This is the fresh salsa they give to you when you order. But the jarred salsas they sell, are just... BLAND, for some reason. These are the same jars they sell at Safeway for like $8 a pop, I think. What a rip off.
author: Janis A.

description: Usually positive experiences here, not so much today.  Came in when things were relatively slow, ordered a burrito.  After 20 minutes I asked if someone could check on my order, no response other than a nod.  After 35 minutes and no explanation I asked for a refund with nothing more than a cursory "sorry bout that."  Unlikely to return again.
author: Steven G.

description: As expected, fire tacos with fire salsa. They are authentically making basic Mexican food with intricate flavors. As a dis hard taco connoisseur I give this place a whopping five stars for their originality and flare. The mole is a must try! Take a salsa to-go as a nice souvenir!
author: Karlos G.

description: I'll keep it short and sweet! Go here if you want a big, good, Cali-Mex meal. Get a burrito and pack it full of veggies and refried black beans, order it with sour cream, guacamole, and cheese. Devour it with the free side of salsa and the delicately crunch chips. Add hot sauce if you're into that. You'll be so happy and y'all want to come back every time you're in the Mission. If you're in a rush, order it to go because there is likely to be a wait for seating. Get even more salsa because it is so good!
author: Adam H.

description: I am a devout fan of really good Mexican food, and in the Mission that isn't hard to find, and Papalote delivered. The burritos are massive and incredibly tasty, and while not my favorite in the Mission, top 3 for sure. What sets them apart is the salsa they give you, out of this world, I would drink a bowl of it if I could. I poured it over my burrito and savored every bite. Though here is my problem, they sell salsas, and having fallen so madly in love with what they served, I bought 3 varieties, including what was supposed to be the one they served, and it wasn't. Not close. So a big disappointment on the salsa front, but the food was great and they do get extra credit for having a cool bathroom.
author: Josh M.

description:
Not quite sure why this place only has 3.5 stars, but I've learned to overlook Yelp ratings once in awhile. There are many Mexican restaurants in the area, so reviewers are probably just comparing to the classics like El Farolito and La Taqueria... but I personally loved Papalote because of its naked burrito with adobo chicken. 

I seriously would've never known of this place until a yoga friend of mine was eating it before class. It looked so tasty that I got it the next day before yoga class (slightly bad idea)... yes, it is on the pricier side and added up to $13 but it is a meal for 3 days. I had it for lunch yesterday, and then lunch today... and I still have a good amount of rice and beans left that I can pair with other protein for dinner tonight. 

Papalote was also featured on Bobby Flay's show, which is pretty cool. The food is flavorful and I enjoyed every bite. It even comes with a generous serving of guacamole! Bonus points for their amazing complimentary salsa for their chips!

When you get the chicken burrito or deconstructed bowl, be sure to ask for the adobo chicken, not the pollo asado... the adobo is shredded and so tender, while the pollo asado I believe is just diced roasted chicken. Luckily they were able to change my order last minute when I realized there was a difference. 

I'm going to yoga again on Tuesday and I'm planning on getting another naked burrito. It's that good!
author: Janet H.

description: Not "authentic", but always been damn tasty. One of my top 3 go to Mexican spots in SF
author: Christopher P.

description: If you like delicious, authentic Mexican food- this is a great place to try! I came  this past weekend while in town visiting. My fiance and I were craving Mexican food, so some friends of ours suggested we check this place out. We got the chorizo con queso which was amazing, and the carne asada which melted in our mouths. The vibe here super cool, chill... and down to earth. The service was great! If I lived in the bay area this place would definitely be one that I would regularly frequent! Highly recommend!
author: Chelsea V.

description:
Any friggin' taqueria on earth can give two tacos of differing variety, except beloved Papalote, where the customer is forced to get two of the same types of tacos. "House rules" said the inflexible cashier. Well you know what, I walked out. 
And I did try their famed fusion salsa on the way out which was very good-- so upping to two stars. Hopefully no msg hiding in that but I have my doubts. 
I won't be going back until you change your exclusive and stupid taco rule.
author: Brian J.

description: Worst experience ever. The bus boy asked me to leave while I was ordering food because other people had already got their food and wanted to sit down at the table I was at. I felt disrespected and felt uncomfortable here. It's really sad because I would have liked to enjoy their food. It's terrible this establishment treats people in this manner.
author: Zarina B.

description:
About six years ago, Flay challenged Papalote to a burrito contest and the triple threat burrito triumphed. I wish I knew what Papalote was like before it was featured on Throwdown. Was the triple threat always $20? Back then, $20 was a lot of cash for a burrito and it still is now, but at least that burrito hasn't been affected by inflation in these past few years. Also, the hype has calmed down compared to those crowds after the episode first aired. 

Triple Threat - chicken breast, carne asada, prawns:
It's loaded with 3 types of proteins, but I don't feel threatened. The taste and quality is on par with most burritos, so in comparison, the price tag sure is steep. The grilled prawns were the best part. They're tender and springy with a nice char. Plus, the prawns are left whole instead of chopped up beyond recognition. The chicken and carne asada are nicely seasoned, too. 
It is a very large burrito, so if you need a reason to justify spending $20, you can share it or split it between two meals. It's also a good decision if you have a tough time choosing between poultry, beef, & seafood, or if you're just curious to try it, but it is not a must have.

The Carne Asada & Pollo Asado burritos are pretty good too, sans shrimp. The single meat burritos are about $10, which is a little pricey. Adding cheese, guac, or sour cream are each $1. Kind of a bummer, since burritos usually include cheese. If you're going to add one, you might as well add all 3 for $2, resulting in a very creamy burrito. 

Of course the roasted tomato salsa is excellent. It is the true threat here. This thick & creamy, robust, orange sauce is like a flavor explosion of smokey, sweet, savory, spicy, and slightly tart. This salsa is excellent on their thin, warm chips, as well as on everything else. Jars of Papalote's various salsas are available for purchase in various local markets. 
Overall, I'm satisfied with the food, but the prices are high relative to other Mexican joints in the Mission, so I give it a 7.25/10.
author: Joy W.

description: Did you know Papalote scored a 74 food safety rating? Gross. Worse though, they try to hide this behind a gift card sign. Shady shady.
author: Chris G.

description: Amazing burritos and the salsa is made in house.  Totally a casual place.  But it is a must for mexican food in SFO
author: Mark D.

description:
"papalote" is just a fun word to say - that's at least 3 stars just for a dope name. BUT, the food is also amazing! Every meal you order comes with chips and salsa--but not just any salsa. Papalote (man, I love saying that..) has a special secret recipe home-made salsa that has a hint of chipotle who know what else. You just NEED to try it for yourself!

I ordered a carne asada quesadilla. You can supersize any meal and add sour cream and guac for just a $1.50. I can't eat anything without sour cream, so I did that and it was so worth it. Do it!

Papalote is a small space with tight seating, so get to know thy neighbors and bond over some good food! Highly recommended!
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Zane raves about Papalote. I know Papalote is popular for on demand food delivery. However, my burrito today was a big fail. I do not like paying .99 for some sour cream. I don't like beans, so those had to be left out(Zane wanted them on the side). The chef did not think about how he could fill up the burrito to fill the void of no beans. I guess I could have tried to ask for more pico, chicken, or rice. The was not enough chicken or pico de gallo in the burrito. It just seemed like a tortilla with Spanish rice, and a little of the other toppings. I have had many better burritos than this one. This one was overpriced at $11.50 or so. Nick's Crispy serves up good burritos. Chipotle even does the trick. El Castillito on Church is really good. I don't know what happened, but I am not the chef, so he can figure out how to whip up a satisfying burrito sans beans.
author: Denise C.

description:
if you can walk here, your experience is fine. The place is small. I would recommend take out. We were there to collect a large order so I can't even remember if there even was any seating to be had. The burritos are large and well made. Decent prices. They do have some good vegetarian/vegan choices for those. Honestly, not the best Mexican food I've had from the Mission (there are so many good ones), but I do recommend coming here for the bean dip and salsa alone. Seriously addicting. They give you a huge portion of the bean dip too and a huge bag of chips to go with it. 

I can see why this place is popular.
author: Nora S.

description:
My #1 taqueria in mission, which by extension means #1 taqueria in USA and world. 

They have veggie mole. Excellent.

Pro tip is to buy a jar of their awesome salsa to take home.
author: Joey M.

description: Our first time to San Francisco & this place was recommended to us.  Also reviews looked pretty good so it must be good.  Wrong!  Boy were we disappointed.  I can honestly say it's the worst Mexican restaurant I've ever eaten at.  Ordered a carne asada burrito and the meat was gross - fatty, tough, .... every bite.  Needless to say, I threw most of it away & never went back.  If you want great Mexican food, go to LaTaqueria at 2889 Mission St.
author: S P.

description: They no longer carry the legendary Mexipino burrito (Mexican-Filipino with garlic fried rice and chicken adobo). They have dethroned themselves! None of their other options are even remotely worth the prices they charge, try one of the many other shops in the area instead.
author: Derek R.

description:
I had written a negative review of Papalote a while back (price hikes, unfriendly staff) but I went back by recently and Paplote has restored the menu item I normally order to it's former price. Also, servers were again chill. Maybe I just went by on a bad day when I wrote the review before, maybe Papalote reads these reviews and responded. Either way I'm editing my review and I'm happy to say I can again whole hearted recommend this place! 
Healthy awesome Mexican food.
author: david w.

description:
Whoa whoa whoa...now I've been to most of the major burrito establishments claiming to be the best of the best, but Papalote Mexican Grill was still an amazing surprise. It certainly isn't the cheapest nor the quickest (so places like El Farlito will continue to have a place in my taco/burrito loving heart)...but the food is superb!

My friend and I shared the carne asade super burrito. The burrito was certainly substantial and I was very glad to find that it wasn't a squishy mess. The carne asada was tender and seasoned very well. Additionally, their famous salsa was also delicious - spicy, sweet, great flavor, and just a tad creamy...I could eat this all day!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Been eating here for 10+ years. Never been disappointed with salsa or their burritos. Great chili verde in Nov 2017. Keep it up!
author: A V.

description: Are you serious now? I been to a few taquerias and this one takes the cake in skimpy as fck in their portions. I had a shrimp burrito... which only had 4 pieces of shrimp. It was packed with rice and veggies and cost $12?! I thought I had ordered a veggie burrito with those portions...My friend had the steak burrito and there was barely any steak. Stop cheating your customers.
author: Ann L.

description:
I just have one word to describe this place: LEGIT. 

I love burritos and have heard countless times from friends that the Mission is the place to go. I was meeting a friend in SF for lunch and he asked what I wanted. I said I found this burrito place on a website that was named one of the best burrito joints so I was dying to try it out.

He confirmed that he had been papalote's before and said it was pretty damn good. 
That got me even more excited than I already was... The day came and I walk in the restaurant. I forgot to mention, I went to the Mission location. The place is pretty small and very casual. 
I ordered the Carne Asada burrito with whole wheat tortilla. The price is definitely not considered cheap but it's SF so I wasn't surprised... about $10+ for a burrito and chips/salsa.

I just have to say this first.. but the salsa was bomb!! It's not like any salsa I've ever had before... it's not chunky and does not have the consistency of your average salsa. It's very much like a sauce almost and is pretty oily. I can't describe it, but I just couldn't get enough of it.
Now on to the burrito... it was delicious and nicely grilled which was a nice touch. 

My only minor complaint is the size... it could've been a bit bigger for the price. 

Hint: They sell the salsa they serve in the restaurant. There are many different salsas they sell, but be sure to ask for the fresh one they sell. Unfortunately for me, they were sold out of that one so I got what they said was the next closest thing... At $7 a jar, it's the most expensive salsa I've ever bought, but damn it was worth every drop. 

I'll savor every last drop until the next time I visit Papalotes again.
author: Milton F.

description: With so many great Mexican restaurants in the mission, which do you choose?! Papa life is a solid choice, with a few standout items on the menu. The chicken mole is to die for, along with the salsa they bring out in the beginning. Not to mention that the burritos are as big as my forearm. This is one of the pricier taquerias in the mission, but still i the 10-17 dollar range. Definitely recommend checking Papalote out, and getting the chicken mole if that is your thing!
author: Ross S.

description: I ordered a carne asada burrito. To be honest, it tasted like Chipotle. It was also a bit salty. The salsa they have here is made in house. It tastes good on the burrito, especially since the burrito is kinda bland by itself. The burrito is humongous. It can last me two meals.
author: Shu T.

description:
When I told my friends I was driving up to SF and looking for some great food, they immediately recommended Papalote. I told them if it was as good as they're hyping it up to be, I'd buy them lunch here. 

Safe to say lunch will definitely be on me! 

This place is fantastic, the salsa they served with the chips was the best I've ever had. My buddy and I had a hard time properly describing its taste. Had a chipotle-like flavor to it, it was just great! 
I had one of their well-renowned Burritos (Asada for me), and it was phenomenal. The black beans were fantastic, tortilla was soft to the bite, tender, warm, and the carne asada was cooked perfectly. As soon as I took my first bite, I just had to stop and look at the Burrito for a moment - a standard for me anytime I taste something so delicious, I just have to take a moment to appreciate it. Also, staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was quite pleasant and relaxing.

No complaints on my end, this place definitely lived up to the hype for me, and I will certainly be returning VERY soon!
author: Alex S.

description: Excellent burritos and their salsa is also really great. Service is good. Location is not great, dining room was "mostly" clean and most tables are very close to the bathroom. Overall, worth trying.
author: David P.

description:
Really nice burritos in a relaxed environment. I have been to Papalote a few times and keep coming back as I know I am going to have a great meal. The burritos are large and full of good ingredients and the free chips come with an awesome side sauce.

A bit on the pricier side but I think I have been desensitized to high SF prices as I didn't realize until reading the reviews and thinking... yeah, I did just pay over $12 for a burrito. But I will be back....
author: Tristan L.

description:
Came here to celebrate cinco de mayo and the first thing you'll notice is they one out the door for pick up or delivery. Definitely a popular spot in the area and known for their hot sauces. 

As required by cinco de mayo I got a corona along with some free crazily chips that I used to eat with the amazing green sauce there. I got a veggie burrito which was good but nothing that wax amazing. I do agree they have some solid sauces. I imagine the meat options could be better but as a vegetarian it was okay. Definitely a hipsters stop for Mexican food.
author: Linda L.

description:
After wondering what my number was or why I didn't get a ticket w my order, I find out they gave my order to someone else, and had to remake mine. I'm very hungry I stopped here because it shouldn't take long to make. Then they can't tell me oh hey we made a mistake, I have to ask about my number to find out. 

This has me waiting like 30 minutes. I think it's cause they wanna take the order too fast & then they lose track of who's who.
author: THE F.

description:
I'm gonna say something really snobbish. Ready? Here goes.

I don't like Papalolte because it's a hipster-infested burrito place.

Oops i mean hipster-invested.

Oh you know it's hipster because: 

One, everything in the restaurant is spanking clean. 

Two, they have this signature creamy salsa that all silicon techies like to irrationally rave about in their work patios. 

Three, you always see these Postmates/Grubhub/UberEats/Eat24 people hanging around, waiting to pick up a Pork Chile Verde no sour cream extra guac spinach wrap for some techie who does the software programming for Postmates/Grubhub/Uber. 

Four, remember that delicious salsa mentioned above? Yeah they sell it separately in a jar. 

Five, and probably the most evident indicator of Papalolte's hipster affiliation, a burrito costs like $10 to $11 #damndaniel

My good friend, Salty P, swears by this place though. He loves pouring that creamy salsa on each bite of his carne asada while convincing us that Papalote is actually the best burrito place in Mission. But we can't trust this guy to give an unbiased opinion. Salty P. wears a beard, rocks an expensive vest, and has like, 5 hydroflask bottles ("i need it").

Although i might not like Papalote, i do recommend it to my vegetarian friends though. I know other burrito places offer vegetarian options, too, but Papalote takes their vegetarian menu seriously. Unlike other places, you can be sure that the oil used for the veggie options is kept separately from the meat. You can sleep easy knowing that a piece of meat may not have snuck its way into your Soyrizo Burrito. How can we be so sure? Because unlike other burrito places, Papalote actually has something to lose. They got a chain store down at Fulton.

So yeah, if you don't have any dietary restrictions and/or if you're not a hipster, then i would go Cancun and El Faro instead. But if you are a vegetarian and/or keeps a leather notebook in your butt pocket, then Papalote is the place for you :)
author: Ringo M.

description:
Holy. Guacamole. Papalote now has a "buy 10 burritos get 1 free" frequent rewards card.

This is new! As of a few weeks ago! I could have gotten so many free burritos by now!

Aside from free burritos, what makes this place great?

1) Convenient. I live a block from this location. And when my friends and I are feeling like lazy bums...sorry, since we ARE lazy bums, we call in bulk to-go orders, wait 15 minutes, and send over volunteer tributes to pick up our stash.

2) Quality. Their meat is GOOD. Tender. Moist. And they are so generous. One of my girls swears by two menu items: the mole and the chile verde. I've tried both, and I'm a much bigger fan of the CHILE VERDE because the pork makes my taste buds dance a happy dance. I get it as a salad to cut down on carbs and because the jicama and fresh salsa pair so well with the salty pork and the awesome green serrano sauce, which I drizzle errywhere. I've also tried their carne asada burrito and breakfast burrito, both of which are bomb. Oh, when they say scrambled eggs, they really mean pulverized eggs--it's pretty awesome.

3) Customizable. Tacos, burritos, naked burritos, quesadillas, salads--meat/tofu vehicles of all types. Last I checked, their "make it super" option, which adds sour cream, cheese, and guacamole was only $1. Seems like the prices now are more expensive per online source?

4) Crack sauce. When I first tried it, I wasn't a big fan because it's spicy. It's still spicy, but I've learned to better ignore my screaming pain receptors. There's something about eating crunchy tortilla chips with a creamy sauce that makes everything taste way better. I love this combination so much that I always save my leftover chips and sauce for future snacking. I even save my friends' leftover chips and sauce. My boyfriend thinks I'm crazy, squirreling away all of those mini sauce containers in our fridge. I think I'm GENIUS. They sell jars of this stuff, and I'm getting it FO' FREE.

5) REWARDS CARD. This perk deserves to be repeated. FYI: valid for burrito purchases only.

Downside: seating. It looks like a seat-yourself situation, but one of the waitstaff will usually be around the dining room entrance to keep an eye out for tables. The room holds about 20 people, so you might have to wait for a bit during rush hours.

But srsly, Papalote is dope-alote. Time to reap some free burritos.
author: Adele F.

description:
Cute place with a decent amount of seating for a food establishment in the city, and some REEEEEEEALLY amazing salsa. The 3 stars here are mostly for that salsa, which is made of pureed roasted tomato and chipotle peppers, blended until its creamy without dairy added in. IT IS AMAZING. You get a cup of the salsa and complimentary chips while waiting for your order, which was the highlight of the meal. They also sell the salsa at the cash register and I've actually seen it at some supermarkets on the peninsula. 

The actual food I ordered were the nachos with shrimp, and personally I wasn't blown away -- the nachos were topped with a lot of melted shredded cheese, tomatoes, and beans, but not much else and they were somewhat skimpy on the shrimp (i.e. I can get more shrimp for half the price from a cheapo taqueria in the same part of town, or in Redwood CIty where I live within a mile from about 5 Mexican restaurants). The overall effect was kind of bland, which was unfortunate since the salsa we got at the start was so good. 

Verdict: Come here for that damn salsa.
author: Anita T.

description: The "Triple Threat" burrito in the iconic Mission District.  It was so d*mn good.  The salsa is incredible.  Everything inside was cooked to moist, charred perfection!
author: Spencer J.

description: 4 star food, and an extra star on their hospitality. They are always polite, always get my order right, and it's always delicious. Everyone talks about the salsa, and the rumors are true. It's so flavorful and comforting. Thanks Papalote.
author: Adam K.

description: Came here to pick up a to go order, so don't know much about the service or environment but the food was very good. Had a really good breakfast burrito with a little too much oil in it. Very very big, I could only eat half of it and had the other half for lunch! There is seating inside, some noise/not totally quiet but not too loud either. Seems like the kind of place to have a long wait or a line if you don't call ahead. Don't think there's any convenient parking that I could see. Staff is friendly and helpful. Will definitely visit again!
author: Folasade A.

description:
Don't agree with the hype. 

Good for vegans (so I would come back if I had that eating preference), but so overrated otherwise. My pollo asado burrito was too soggy for my preference and also just lacked flavor. I found myself adding a lot of hot sauce just to add some taste. Not to mention the food is overpriced. Go to el farolito or as my coworker suggested, La Palma, for really good authentic Mexican food.
author: Liz C.

description: The grilled steak burrito is very good. Authentic Mexican food and I like how the chips and the salsa were free. I always wanted to eat here and I glad that I did. Only problem is that it is over priced.
author: Kangaroo K.

description:
I only came here to buy their homemade orange salsa since it was recommended as an alternative to La Victoria's orange sauce. As a former South Bay area resident, my burritos were feeling a little lonely without the special homemade sauce I would regularly pour on to add that extra layer of spicy goodness. 

However, the service I experienced over a simple transaction such as buying sauce was dismissive and not very friendly. I just expected a little less attitude when all I asked for was a small brown bag to carry my jar home as I waited patiently at the takeout window in the midst of the Friday evening rush. 

Overall, the salsa turned out to be good - not an exact replica of La Vic's orange sauce - but I'm not sure I would trek back to buy a bottle.
author: Miyishia S.

description:
Too salty. All the reviews say it and they don't care to try to change it. 

Decent sized tacos and burritos for the $.
author: Nina D.

description:
That SALSA. Let me drink it by the jar. Addictive. Buy in the store or order here- http://papalotesalsa.com/

The Mexipino burrito is good! Some garlic rice in that tortilla, mmm... The mole entree is tasty also, but go with dat burrito first. 

Inefficient service and long wait times (both for waiting in line to order and waiting for food to come). Only one person taking orders at the counter, and she's taking phone orders as well. Should be at least two people doing this task. So, order your food by phone and pick it up. A staff member is good at delegating table seating for those who ordered first. I dig that authoritative nature- people gotta sit to eat.
author: Joanna L.

description: Food was tasteful; however, very small tight spot.  Barely any room to stand and put your order in.  Place was extremely cramped.  Bathroom had graffiti all over,  even the toilet.  Got the tripple threat burrito, taste good, but don't believe the hype.  Only got 4 to 5 pieces of shrimp.  Paid extra for sour cream and guacamole, but barely tasted it.  Not worth $25.
author: M C.

description:
The Mission is packed with burrito places and all are super great yet my favorite burrito is at Papalote. I'm a longtime vegan of 16 years so Mexican food has always been a favorite.

I love Papalote for going the extra mile providing several vegan options including:
veggie with potato, carrot, and mushroom
grilled veggie with eggplant and zucchini
vegan soyrizo
marinated grilled tofu

All of these come with beans, rice, pico de gallo.

I went with the veggie burrito and had them add avocado. It came with chips and a yummy homemade salsa. I will be sure to visit here the next time in the Bay Area as was wonderful!
author: Shane S.

description:
Food: 3.0/5.0
Service: 2.5/5.0
Value: 3.0/5.0
Decor: 2.5/5.0
Overall: 3.0/5.0 

I'm going to sip on haterade and say that the mixed reviews for this place are totally understandable.  It's a Valencia-ed version of Mission proper but the quality (imho obviously) doesn't keep up with the price.  Don't get me wrong; the food is good, but just not a reasonable trade-off in the area.  It's telling that the salsa, which I found good but not amazing, gets such a ridiculous amount of play.  If you prefer this spot over some of the alternatives a few blocks away, let's just be honest and say that some of us don't want to squeeze in with the plebs.
author: Damian W.

description:
This is the best salsa in SF.
Of all the taquerias in town, authentic, hip, or trendy...this is the salsa.

Not like pico de gallo.  No no no.  Usually pico de gallo is way too chunky & bland for tortilla chip dipping or using as a topping for me.  This is smooth, creamy, rich, & deep.  It has perfect consistency.  And even in just their regular salsa, the heat is there.  If you don't pick up a jar, you can be confident that you're missing out.

It's fantastic w everything.  I've used it to make chilaquiles & no other salsa has been better.

Now, the food.

The super carne asada burrito was a bit of a let down for me.  The carne asada was chewy & dry.  And the only flavor punches were at the ends of the burrito, meaning the distribution was all whacked.  

No bueno.  

But I'll still be back.  I need to try the mexipino.  And of course, the triple threat.

The cashier was sweet.  Actually, all the staff was.

Their salsa is available all over town.  Bi-Rite, Safeway, Whole Foods, etc.

Lucky us.

It was a 3 star burrito.  But their salsas are totally 5 stars.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
This is one of those places where the rating does not match the restaurant.

If I could give this place 6 stars, I would. The food was amazing

Thank you
author: Nick O.

description:
So, I went here today with a friend.  Turned out it's like her hands-down favorite place.  Ordered catering for them for her wedding rehearsal.  Had her husband pick up burritos for her each time she'd delivered a baby (3x).  Begged him to take her here before they went to see Hamilton.  My friend's name is Kegan and I told her she should post a review!!!

I had the chicken mole burrito and lord was it succulent.  Held me the rest of the day and clearly delayed how quickly the post-work wine bar outing landed on me.  I'd go again :)
author: Anne G.

description: Carne asada is good because it's grilled and kinda crispy. Sauce is of course good, but they give you so little and you have to pay for extra. And $10.50 for a burrito is a little pricey.
author: Eddie E.

description:
Thank you, Food Network for leading me here!

Food: My boyfriend was so cool and decided to order the Triple Threat Burrito. Larger than my forearm, this creation included chunks of tender carne asada, smoked prawns, succulent achiote chicken, rice, beans and slightly piquant papalote salsa. He made it super by adding fresh guacamole, cheese and  sour cream. The marriage between all of the ingredients worked magically, I wouldn't change a single thing about this burrito. Though the price is fairly steep ($19.99), it can easily be shared among two people and the quality and taste alone are enough for me to pay the whooping fee each and every time. The papalote salsa is pretty epic, though not as spicy as I'd like it to be. The roasted tomatoes and chili provide a bit of a smokey flavor, the salsa is a full-bodied/robust work of art boasting in both flavor and aroma. I purchased one to take home and finished it in three days. I built my own burrito as well and the menu allows for optimal customization if you don't want one of their signature burritos. I was able to chose between the type of beans, rice, meat and tortilla I wanted. I basically built myself a super healthy burrito (brown rice, wheat tortilla, black beans, chicken), however it was still ridiculously delicious and better than anything Chiptole could ever manufacture for me. I highly recommend any of their burritos, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

Price: On the pricier end and they'll tack on more for adding any extra ingredients. However, the food here is certainly worth the price every time. 

Ambiance: Small, simple and clean. I saw a ton of people waiting outside to either get a table
or pick up carry-out orders.

Service: Quick and friendly servers, limited interaction with employees.

Overall: Authentic, fresh and ridiculously appetizing Mexican eats. I approve and can't wait
to come back for more!
author: Astrid Z.

description: One of my favorite places in the Mission. This restaurant goes above and beyond the typical tacos and burritos. I had an amazing steak salad with jicama. They have excellent fresh  ingredients which perfectly complement their unique sauces and dressings, which I've been meaning to buy by the bottle. You will not be disappointed.
author: May C.

description: We didn't know what to expect coming in, and we're blown away by how good the food was. It's not the cheapest on mission, but it's just so damn good. I had the chicken mole tacos and my friend had a bean and rice burrito and they both were great. They also had this insane sauce to eat with the nacho chips they give out for free and it was the most amazing sauce I've had. I'd buy it in a bottle if I could. Definitely a must try!
author: Raksha M.

description: Tried this place for the first time even though I live close to the place. Everyone was hyping it up, so I thought I'd give it a try. Got the vegetarian super burrito with retried beans and marinated tofu. Really good place for someone that's vegetarian or even vegan! I wasn't too fond of the sauce the chips came with. Over all the food was good.
author: Myleen R.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to go here after attempting to call to place an order at La Taqueria down the street on cinco de Mayo. I must say that I preferred this taqueria over my usual spot mostly because the wait time was way shorter and that sauce is the absolute best. I got a burrito de carne asada which was super bomb. I prefer the way the meat is prepared a little more at La Taqueria but their lack of rice in the burritos takes it down a peg. I don't like sloppy food and their burritos and tacos get pretty sloppy.

I'm over waiting in line with a bunch of yuppies at La Taqueria so it looks like Papalote will be my new go to :)
author: Janette M.

description:
Breakfast is the most important meal of the day, so it's important to treat yourself with Papalote's breakfast burrito. 

The Chorizo Breakfast Burrito is heaven on a plate - savory and authentic! I upgrade it to a Super Burrito to add sour cream, cheese, and guacamole for 99 cents AKA the best purchase I've made for 99 cents. 

The burrito is massive, so I cut it into two massive halves. Everything is perfectly warm inside the burrito and the scrambled eggs meshes well with the rest of the ingredients. I've never had a breakfast burrito like it! 

Each order comes with side of tortilla chips and orange sauce. Their orange sauce is highly addictive with just the right kick. I'm such a weak *sauce* to anything spicy, but when it comes to their orange sauce...I'm willing to sacrifice some sweat and tears. 

I've only tried the breakfast burritos, but I know Papalote Mexican Grill was voted as one of the best places to eat a burrito in San Francisco. I'd love to come back and try their other ones. 

Definitely worth it to grab a bite here!
author: Kristal D.

description:
Mexican restaurant on 24th & Valencia. On the 2014 and 2015 7x7 list for their chips and salsa.

Although you order at the counter your food gets brought to you. Limited meat selection. No chorizo or carnitas. 

Carne Asada quesadilla - 2/5 - Steak is rather bland and a bit too chewy.

Triple threat burrito - 3/5 - Massive. Shrimp/Steak/Chicken with rice/pico/avacado. Not really impressed.

Chips and salsa - 5/5 - WOW. I very much expected to be disappointed by another overhyped dish but this absolutely lived up to it's reputation. The salsa is so damn good. This is easily my favorite salsa in the city and I even bought an extra jar to take home. It is creamy, spicy and delicious. It certainly deserves the spot it has held on the 7x7 list for the past two years.

Overall, this is without a doubt my new go to option for salsa. Unfortunately the rest of their items are passable so I think I will likely be getting the salsa to go and getting my burrito/taco/quesadilla elsewhere in the future. Regardless, this salsa is absolutely "as good as it gets" and I will probably always have some on hand in my fridge.
author: Mark O.

description:
Man, for a place that's as famous as Papalote, I was pretty disappointed.  I guess if you're not ordering the $20 Triple Threat that's all over TV and in the papers, it's not worth the headache of trying to find a parking spot.

I can't think of any other way to describe this place other than, "meh".  You guys...there are so many STELLAR taquerias in the Bay Area and SF.  This isn't one of them.  Dude...even the CHIPS needed salt.
author: Tara S.

description:
Short version: SUPER overpriced for average-tasting food. 

I'm torn, because the burrito is pretty decent and the flavors are there. (It is way too wet for my personal taste- I would rather there be more rice or meat than all the sauce and juices, but eh.) The salsa is OK as well. Yes, it's good, but I don't get the hype. I wouldn't go out of my way for it. What kills me are the prices here. My pork burrito somehow turned out to be $15??? That's insane, you can get burritos across the street for half the price. I know the ingredients are supposed to be more fresh, but still not worth the price IMO. Even worse, my friend ordered the tacos and they looked and tasted very sad. Only one tortilla under them even though it was to-go, which left them soggy and completely falling apart. There was hardly any meat, and these two tiny tacos were $10. Come on.
author: Emily L.

description: best taqueria in san francisco. end of story. i will fight anyone who says otherwise.
author: Liron N.

description: Vegan mole tofu salad bowl is incredible. I orderit every time with avocado and am never disappointed. The hicima on it is a great crunch that cuts through the spice. Always leave with a fresh jar of salsa. It never lasts a day on our house.
author: Danielle P.

description: My carne asada burrito was really salty and the chips were a bit stale. I'm sad because this used to be one of my fave Mexican spots. The sauce used to be amazing and it's whatever now. Where has the quality gone???
author: Ryan C.

description: Nice food. I tried the grilled chicken burrito and the size was very decent aside from being delicious. Probably one one the best burritos I had in SF so far.
author: Arash E.

description:
This place has amazing food and amazing sauces. Papalote is clean and fast. They have many options for meat eaters and vegetarians. Portions are big! Parking can be tricky but it is 100% worth it. 

10/10 will come back
author: Oliver K.

description: The prawn burrito was excellent, I had every intention of eating half and taking home the remainder. Well let's just say that idea went out the window after the first bite. Did I forget to mention that I had Wolfed down more than my share of the delicious guacamole. My wife had the Carne asada burrito, it was good nothing to write home about. The dude next to me was eating the mole burrito and that will be my next item I try.  Parking can be a challenge and the seating area is tight during the lunch rush. Be patient it is worth it.
author: Manny G.

description:
Wow, their house salsa/sauce is awesome! I've never had anything like it. It's soo good! 

I really enjoyed my "naked" chicken burrito with sour cream, cheese, and guac on the side. They load it up! 

My man was not super impressed with his Mexipino burrito. It was good, just not what you'd expect a burrito to be. The flavors were more subtle and vinegar-based (hence the nod to Filipino food) and less about the spices of Mexican food. He will try a regular burrito the next time we go, and hopefully this will one day become a 5 star review. Looking forward to next time!
author: Sarah Z.

description: The veggie burrito is delicious here! It's all fresh ingredients in generous portions. I love the chips and salsa here too! It can get crowded sometimes so I like to just order ahead and pick up.
author: Jacqui C.

description: I normally avoid this place but I went on a whim cause Arizmendi was closed and I needed lunch quick.. big mistake. Their soyrizo gave me food poisoning, only after I ordered did I see their health score was 74. Disgusting. Barf. Never again!
author: Sloane F.

description:
I had a chicken burrito and it sucked.  The only thing worse was the woman behind the counter.  First of all, my burrito was cold, not warm...yes, cold.  Second, it also contained some beef, of which I did not order.  Finally, they were incapable of making my burrito spicy.  It was seriously too much to ask from Alma B. because she treated me like I was some total asshole disturbing her while she was at the spa...oh, yeah she was at work...my bad.  Finally, after I realized that my cold disgusting burrito had no heat, I asked the gentleman for spicy salsa.  His reply, you need to buy an entire jar at the register.  Really, I just want hot salsa for my cold overpriced burrito and I have to buy an entire jar...wtf?

There are much better places to go in the City and obviously within the immediate area.  This place has gone way down hill and I will not return to any location.

PS. Does management exist? Is there quality control?  Why does Alma B. work in customer service?  Really not jalapeños or spicy salsa? Why are there pieces of beef in my chicken?

Gross!
author: Kiki I.

description:
Atmosphere is nice. Presentation of the food was good. Friendly staff. But, for a Mexican restaurant.... Playing regae then some of Common's music.... Meh... Still, great music. 

When I ate my quesadilla, it was warm... Not what I was expecting being the only one waiting for his food here. You can tell the quesadilla was not heated up properly. I also had 2 tacos... Very cold and only on 1 corn tortilla each. Which immediately fell apart in my hand. If you're gonna load these lil tacos up, make sure to use 2 tortillas. The tortilla chips that they gave me was much warmer than anything else. 

Someone recommended this place to me who lives like 1 block away but did say she doesn't come here to often. I now know why. 

I'd say look else where if your looking for good Mexican food. Sorry....
author: Daniel C.

description: Literally my favorite burrito place in existence. I go out of my way to get here. I've even bought jars of the salsa. The burrito is amazing. The meat is like heaven. The salsa is life changing. I love the ambiance of this place and everything about it.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Best Mexican food I've ever had!! And the most affordable. The salsa is different, but tasty! I recommend going early, as the place fills up fast and there is minimal seating. Also, get the mandarin jarritos soda and an extra side of salsa! You won't regret it.
author: Jessica F.

description: Awesome,  mole is excellent. Ever Salsa has great taste,  my preference is the Habanero.
author: William M.

description:
SHOUT OUT!

Papalote was one of our food sponsors for our Concrete Runners event. After a run to get into shape, what do we do, get catered with BREAKFAST BURRITOS, SPICY JICAMA FRIES, and CHIPS. Nobody complained!!!

Breakfast Burrito - was on point. Never had a breakfast burrito like that before. Must add the addicting salsa. 

Jicama - shaped like fries paired well with the burrito. It had that juicy crisp crunch with a hint of spicy seasoning sprinkled on top. 

Chips & salsa - tortilla chips were just typical but the salsa.... Addictive. 

Thanks homies for sponsoring. Much appreciated.
author: Jane A.

description: Delicious, well-wrapped, and well-balanced. Their specials (e.g. the mexipino) and their breakfast burrito are wonderful as well. Be sure to try the salsa.
author: Joel V.

description:
They have avocados and soda in the front- seems like they've run out of room. Very cluttered ordering & waiting area.

I saw them on TV and decided to try their TRIPLE THREAT burrito $23.00!!! I didn't know it was priced so high for a BURRITO. 

Customer service was rushed and un-personal. They can at least balance out their customer service with their price! My goodness. Cashier didn't smile, did not feel welcomed- just "what would you like, a drink with that? for here or to go" STALE.

I like their colors and the table of community flyers- gives you reading material while you stand up and wait.

Most likely my first and last. Parking sucks as well, no lot what so ever.
author: Jasmine-Desiree L.

description: A local from the Mission neighborhood took a group of us (out of towners and a couple of friends) to this place. It's one of those hole in the wall type places, and you KNOW how good the food can be in these spots! My burrito was huge and really good. No complaints, even the vegetarian in the group was satisfied with her salad. We all loved the salsa(sauce/dip?) it was unlike any salsa I've ever had. It has a smoky flavor that is SOOOOO good. This place is really popular and the tables filled up quick, as well as the line to order. Good fresh food and definitely worth a visit.
author: Denise D.

description:
This place has to serve the worst tacos in San Francisco. Pretty much anywhere is better. 

As far as the burritos and the salsa, this place is great. Mole is excellent. The tacos though... why?
author: H K.

description: Great food. Colorfully decorated and very nice staff. The woman taking our order knew we were saving seats for 5 while we ordered and helped escort a squatter from our seats for us. So nice!
author: D S.

description: I am so sad to write this.. I always loved Papalote for your veggie options. I ordered a veggie burrito to go tonight and it turned out to be a carne asada burrito. Seriously not cool..
author: Elena K.

description:
I heard good things about Papalote Mexican Grill but I have a mixed feeling about it on my first visit... (This review about food is only for Mole tofu burrito with sour cream, cheese, and guacamole.)

Good:
- friendly stuff
- fast service
- reasonable price
- variety of choices for tortilla, beans, and ingredients
- tasty Papalote salsa that comes with chips! (I want to buy a bottle next time.)

Bad:
- Mole was super salty! (It was about 7 PM. So it might be cooked down and concentrated? (PLEASE TASTE IT FROM TIME TO TIME!!!)
- Horchata was thin and waterly... (Maybe it has been sitting there for a long time and diluted...?)

This place is extremely popular. People are constantly making a long line. It's supposed to be good. I should avoid mole next time.
author: Mariko H.

description: Great place for a very filling meal. Love that they have good vegan options. I got the Vegan Soyrizo burrito and it was delicious. Would highly recommend visiting!
author: Michelle H.

description: This is a great spot. Chill vibe, good seating, and cool staff. Not fancy enough for a first date (for me), but any other date after that, and anytime you're hanging with friends, or exploring on your own, this spot couldn't be better. Check it out and get their super burrito. Also, go while you're hungry. Their burrito is huge.
author: David S.

description:
Got the triple threat burrito and the quality of the ingredients is superb! The salsa is so good, you can clearly tell this is a step up from the other taquerias. And i easily split the burrito into two meals (its about 1.5x the size of a chipotle burrito) But also it costs $20. 

There's lots of seating but its a pretty busy place so turnover was pretty quick. Service is super friendly and self serve water.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Boring Nachos with very little cheese. 
I have guacamole and their sauce on the side. 
Won't order this again.
author: cheryl R.

description:
We came at about 9pm on a Friday; they were busy but not crowded. We did get the last 4 seats free. No line at the counter, and maybe 5-10 minutes later our food came out. 

* Fish Taco - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/papalote-mexican-grill-san-francisco?select=wjDWHeUEau0cj063ExVBdw#wjDWHeUEau0cj063ExVBdw
Large chunks of fish filet. Pretty fresh, good texture. They're not breaded or fried though. 

* Shrimp Taco - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/papalote-mexican-grill-san-francisco?select=wjDWHeUEau0cj063ExVBdw#z-j-9B6z9JdvI7LfEo_Cpw
The shrimp is a bit small, crunchy but not quite fresh-tasting. 

Overall on the tacos: a little too au-naturel, no salsas or sauces drizzled on top, but lots of chopped lettuce, tomatoes, onions. A little too much of these raw veggies, so much that it hides the meat at first and tends to overpower the tacos. You have to add their free salsa, which is creamy and pretty spicy. Makes a world of difference.

* Triple Threat Burrito - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/papalote-mexican-grill-san-francisco?select=wjDWHeUEau0cj063ExVBdw#_dyP1DyvOS9TPp_ljhC1lQ
Yes! So much good meat. Even better with their salsa drizzled on top.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Came here and ordered an overpriced quesadilla. I can probably get something with the same quality for a more affordable price at another spot in the Mission. All orders come with chips and salsa. Their salsa was delicious! It was my favorite part of the meal. It's probably a favorite of a lot of their customers since they sell it by the bottle. I'd probably come back to buy a bottle of salsa but I will pass on the food.
author: Michelle T.

description: Absolutely love the vegan options. Special trip to San Francisco just for these burritos. I was a little disappointed that they messed up my special order and the next day when I went back they didn't comp me for the extra money I spent nor did they offer to add the add ins for free. The girl was just like oh I remember sorry and rang me up like business as usual. With that said it may be a while between the next time I go there but the food is great and the sauce is amazing
author: Garrett V.

description:
By far the best burritos of SF. The salsa is what dreams are made of, and each burrito is 'solid' on how delicious it can be. This is not a Taqueria, this is a burrito shop, so be ready to enjoy amazing burritos. I recommend Mexipino and Breakfast Burrito Machaca con Huevo. Both are delicious options that can serve for 2 meals. Be sure to enjoy some Agua fresca, and be patient. The place can be really busy at night. 

I suggest to order on the phone for pick-up and in that way you can skip the waiting for the delicious burritos. 

Enjoy. You won't regret it.
author: Rodolfo C.

description: Really disappointing. Two of us went for lunch, I ordered 2 prawn tacos, and guess how many prawns were inside: two.  haha!  This place is GROSSLY OVER RATED!!  Maybe the ownership changed?  Dunno but I won't be back to find out.
author: Hoo.asked. U.

description:
I only went to Papalote during this visit mainly to try the Mexipino Burrito that all my friends have been raving about.  And it did not disappoint!

The Mexipino Burrito with Adobo Chicken and Garlic Rice --  http://bit.ly/Ud1cNi
Yeah, the Mexipino Burrito is really good.  So flavorful!  Takes one of my favorite Filipino comfort foods and wraps it all up in a Burrito.  And the Burrito is loaded with chicken as you can see in the pic.  It's awesome when taquerias don't skimp on the meat.  

Although Papalote wouldn't be my first choice to get a burrito in the mission, it still holds it own with their Famous Salsa and late hours.  I'll probably stop by again to get another Mexipino Burrito in the near future!
author: Rodney H.

description: This place was recommended to us as one of the best in the city. The food was good. It has a small eat-in area so we got politely booted out as soon as we were done because of the lineup outside.
author: Tash J.

description: One the best veggie burritos, the potato, mushroom, carrot, is my favorite the soyrizo can also be made vegan too. The papalote sauce is also crazy good ask them to put it in your burrito for extra flavor!
author: J.s. H.

description: To start with some chips and salsa u get two flavors roster to mates and roster habanero both off the hook and the famous triple threat award winning burrito u can't go wrong
author: Samuel N.

description:
Wow. What a major disappointment. Major.

USA Today ranked Papalote Mexican Grill as the #1 burrito in the country. I've eaten quite a few excellent burritos and a lot of "meh" burritos, but actually not a lot of terrible burritos. The one I had today would fall into that last category. I'm pretty sure I actually enjoy Chipotle's burritos more, and that's saying something.

I got the super "Triple Threat Burrito" -- chicken, steak, and shrimp. I should have known it was going to be a discombobulated flavor mess. First of all, among the three proteins, I only enjoyed the steak. The chicken, although obviously dusted in some spice mixture, was incredibly bland, and the shrimp was very fishy AND overcooked. I was burping up bad shrimp all night long.

As for the rest of the burrito, it could be that I just ordered wrong by getting the refried beans. They advertise the refried beans as being vegan, which should have been a red flag. Ask your abuela if she ever made vegan refried beans. She'd laugh at you. But aside from the poor taste, the texture was... saucy. Not goopy, not gloppy, not bean-y. Saucy. And these beans, which made up far too much of the burrito, melded together with the salsa, watery guacamole, and who knows what else to become a really drippy, nasty sauce. Burritos are meant to have all of the components stay separate while being wrapped together, not seem like they've gone through a blender together to become homogenized. It was really, really bad. I regretted buying this $22 burrito (Yes! $22!!!) two bites into it.

On another note, the salsa that comes with their chips is very unique. Very Romesco-y. The chips were stale.

Tips and tricks for if you go to Papalote:
1) Don't get the shrimp. Or chicken. 
2) Don't get the refried beans. Just trust me on this.
3) Park on the residential streets nearby.
4) Actually, nevermind all that. Skip this spot and go to La Taqueria instead.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Don't get the shrimp burrito. You won't be able to find the shrimp. What a disappointment.

This place is all hyped up. Please don't be fooled. The food was ok. The portions were a lot smaller than we expected for the price we paid. They don't have lengua or tripa here. This place is more like a Mexican fusion. 

I will have to say that this place is probably loved by vegetarians and frowned upon by the meat lovers. If you're looking for some real good Mexican food, just head to El Farolito. You'll get your meat fixing and authentic foods there.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Ok now I understand the craze that is Papalote.

For hipster Mission, it's reasonably priced (e.g., 2 people can eat for $20), but yeah it's just a burrito.  But it's a good one.  

People rave about the chips and salsa (yes the burritos come with it) and yeah the salsa is like crack.  The chips have been hit or miss.  Sometimes it feels hard and tasteless, but it's just a shovel to get the salsa in my mouth.

I made a big mistake...I ordered a steak naked bowl with no beans.  It was dry and tasteless.  The steak is meh.  Skip it.

But the chile verde burrito with refried beans. OH MY GOODNESS.  Flavorful and addictive.  Even the leftovers tasted wonderful.  It is really messy because the chile verde is really wet so I just dug right in with a fork and knife instead.

Frequent burrito card so why not come back more.

Order and pay at the cash register and then you sit with a number and they bring your food.  One of the cash registers is for phone orders only so if you're doing takeout, it's pretty easy.

Bathroom on the far side of the restaurant.

And head down the street to Arizemendi for a little after meal scone ;-)
author: Traci H.

description: $14 for a large heavy carne asada burrito with lots of rice, beans, guacamole but had to hunt for the meat. In fact, I had to unwrap the burrito to be sure there was even any meat in it. What I found were a few tiny diced squares of beef that looked like someone's skimpy night-before leftovers. At best maybe they ran out of beef and thought they could make it up with extra rice and beans. The place is way overrated. I feel ripped off. I took the food to go, and only realized it was all rice and beans after I arrived home, and did not feel like driving back to return it. Maybe they would have put some meat in the burrito if they knew I was eating there in the restaurant. Either way, El Papelote is obviously just looking to charge as much as they can for the lowest cost possible. I live in the neighborhood and will not be back.
author: Bob J.

description: I just moved to San Francisco and have been searching for a great veggie burrito. Been to all the regulars and "famous" ones in the mission. This place is by far the best!  So many options including the filling as well as the types of tortilla. Eggplant was the one I went with and I'll definitely be back. My only request is that they do enchiladas and not just burritos / quesasillas
author: Alex B.

description:
Orange salsa in the refrigerator cases, see photo. You've just read the most important part of this review. 

Somewhere in the last couple of years I developed an addiction to the Papalote orange salsa. I'm actually walking out of the restaurant having just bought two jars a moment ago and I am already thinking about how I can ask the sushi restaurant I'm going to for some chips to start demolishing my purchase. 

When you get to the register, don't be fooled by the extensive display of the shelf stable jars with over designed looking labels. Yes, the stuff in the fridge expires two weeks from purchase but it's definitely the product you want. Don't end up with the ugly stepsister!

The rest of the food is what I would call decidedly mediocre (hence the four stars). If you do end up eating at Papalote, you can make it a little less mediocre by dumping the orange salsa all over everything. 

#worthcrossingthemissionfor
author: Stephanie T.

description:
USA Today featured Papalote Mexican Grill as one of the 10 great places to bite into a big burrito, SF Weekly readers voted it, Best Burrito in '07, '08, '09, '10, SF Bay Guardian best burrito and best Mexican Restaurant, what are these people talking about, they need to have their taste buds checked.

I was born in Mexico and have had Mexican food all my life and I have to say what a disappointment Papalote Mexican Grill was. I don't know what makes it "Fresh And Healthy, From Scratch!" All Mexican taquerias use fresh and healthy ingredients when they make their food

I ordered a Prawn Burritos and added zucchini, eggplant, carrots and mushrooms, it cost over $16.00. Let tell you I was very it was bland, bland, bland as it had absolutely no flavor except a hint of garlic. My burrito had about five prawns, black beans, semi-raw vegetables, lots of rice and no mushrooms. The burrito was of an average size and if it wasn't for the rice, it would have much smaller. So this was my first and last time I will be purchase food at Papalote Mexican Grill. The Mission has less expensive Mexican Taqueria that offer better food like Pancho Villa.
author: D. B. M.

description:
What I got:
Triple threat burrito

What I thought:
So the Mission is known to have a bunch of great Mexican food spots to eat and to say that this is definitely top 3 is saying something!

The triple threat burrito is something else. I don't think I've ever had a burrito quite like it. Stuffed with steak, chicken, and shrimp -- what better combination could you ask for!?

Flavors were amazing and the meats were seasoned perfectly. The combination of everything blended very well. I ended up wanting more after I finished my half!

We arrived a little bit late before closing time so we didn't get to enjoy our burrito in the actual restaurant, but the employees were so kind and asked us if we wanted to cut our burrito is half since we were on the go. They even individually wrapped each one. Even by cutting it in half, it still looked like two regular burritos. That's how gigantic this puppy is.

One of the best places to eat in the Mission -- no doubt! Craving Mexican food? This is the place for you!
author: Tony V.

description: I organized Papalote to cater a lunch for a company event. We planned in advance but had last minute adjustments, which they happily accommodated. They were lovely to work with. The food arrived hot, clearly labeled, and well organized. I went with their build-your-own burrito option. The salsa was a hit! After the lunch, we left the chips and salsa out and people snacked all afternoon. I am looking forward to working with them again in the future.
author: Jana B.

description: Delicious and fresh food. Their portions are way bigger than I expected but it just means you get more bang for your buck. Their roasted tomato salsa is to die for and I really wish I had bought a jar.
author: Amara L.

description: Best salsa in the city and killer veggie options. A little more $$ than your average taqueria in the mission, but this place is on another level. Try the tofu mole.
author: Justin H.

description:
I really feel that this restaurant represents everything wrong with the world, gentrification, and taking advantage of the tech boom to just charge ourageous prices for trendiness, and under-deliver on service and product.
As a credit to their integrity, they were WAY overpriced before a lot of other mission restaurants followed suit, so I guess they started that trend instead of hopping on the bandwagon, and I do have to admit that at one point their burritos were pretty tasty and fairly unique, especially for vegetarians.  But just because they were thoughtful enough to want to make money off of vegetarians, doesn't mean they aren't douchebags.

It's been almost 5 years since I have been there, but my last experience left such a bad taste in my mouth, and I have heard it has gotten worse, that I felt morally compelled to write a bad review.  

Last time I went there I got charged about $10 for a "super" burrito, and it was TINY, and I had to pay extra for each of the tiniest thimbles of salsa I had ever seen (i went through three of them in the first few bites), even though I was eating IN HOUSE!
