I can kind of understand charging for salsa after the first few cups if its to go, but to charge $10 for a tiny burrito, AND charge for salsa to eat in house, and treat customers like trash, is just incomprehensible.
That's Donald Trump-like in its audacity, and I can't believe more people haven't called them out on their shit.
author: james b.

description: The burritos are pretty solid, but the salsa...the salsa is next level good. I eat here often simply to get the chips and salsa that come with every order. I believe you can also buy the salsa in grocery stores like Whole Foods. Yum!
author: Brandon G.

description: Confused as to why the ratings for this place are so low, but I guess Yelp isn't always on the mark... Anyway, I went to Papalote at least once a week when I was working in the Mission this summer. There are so many choices for vegetarians and the salsa is SO delicious, I haven't had anyone I've taken there to try it disagree. Obviously, there are lots of taquerias in the neighborhood, so it's easy to overlook Papalote, but you definitely don't want to miss it!
author: Wan Qi K.

description: They really seem to have jacked up the prices in recent years (e.g. burritos $2-3 more expensive that elsewhere in the Mission and $6.50 for a basic Mexican beer). Still decent food and the salsa is great. Seems less crowded than it used to be - you can get better burritos for less in the Mission.
author: Daniel N.

description: I love Papalote! I make sure I go there to eat if I am in SF (not often - hate the traffic!). I love their salsa. Always get the chicken burrito with everything (you pay extra $2 for sour cream, cheese and guac). My friend had shrimp nachos one time and they were awesome too. It's not cheap though. You can expect $12/person here. Small tight space inside.
author: Jatin M.

description:
I got the super chicken burrito and it was delicious and quite flavorful. My pallet was a fan of the orange sauce! However, I do have to gripe about the chips to sauce ratio ( more chips, less sauce). No Bueno. 

Living a non-domesticated (can't cook for sh%*) life in Eastside San Jose, with a significant portion spent in San Francisco and San Leandro, has lead me to consume large amounts of tacos and burritos. I would say this place is comparable to the awesome spots I've dined in the past. 

This place may be a hit or miss judging from the negative reviews. It was definitely a hit for me and I will be returning when I'm in the area for grad school bussiness.
author: Jezz P.

description:
I like the nachos. The guac never seems oxidized. The carne is always very flavorful.  

Their burrito won some award or something, but it has way too many ingredients and everything gets lost. 

Their hot sauce is excellent. They should bottle and sell it - oh wait they do.
author: Cecil C.

description: Most amazing Chili Verde in town. I love Chili Verde and I always look for new places for it. Papalote is go to place for me here on. Also love the service and their sauce. Bought a jar full of it to go.
author: Zeki O.

description: delicious salsa. the chili Verde burrito could have had more meat than sauce, but was still delicious.
author: Sam S.

description:
I didn't know I can really enjoy burritos until I came here... Thank you Papalote! 

Really like Mole burrito and seafood burrito. Highly recommend to make it super if you love creamy burritos.

The portion is huge. Can never finish in a meal.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
5 stars for the salsa.
Buy it and buy it in bulk! :)
I have seen the salsa at Bi-Rite Market if you can't go to the restaurant itself.

The carne asada here is BOMB. Get that and you will be a happy camper.

Wait is a bit unbearable at times for a seat but only because you come starving and all that chip and salsa smell makes you salivate and hangry. Yes, I lack patience.

On another note, the horchata I thought was horrible. It was chalky. I say AVOID and get a mexican soda or even better, a beer.
author: Angela D.

description:
Came here for a quick fix of the sudden Mexican food cravings... Friendly service and the food was delicious! The place itself is pretty small so I could see it on peak time getting crowded but we came here on a Sunday evening for dinner and found a spot to sit with no problem-- not crowded but most tables were occupied. They offer ordering to go ahead of time so that's a good alternative if you don't want to stay or want to do pick up. 

I really enjoyed their salsa! It's unique, creamy and has a load of taste to it-- I ended up stuffing myself with chips and the salsa (comes with every order) to the point where I got too full to finish the carne asada burrito I ordered, which by the way, was good too. I got the smaller of the two burrito sizes but found it too be a hefty amount. My friend had the chicken mole burrito and thought it was really great, granted, it was her first time trying mole. Only thing I didn't like was the Horchata. Personally, it was too grainy for me and had some floral aftertaste but maybe I'm not used to it? Despite that, I'll definitely be returning here!
author: Janelle S.

description: One of the best burritos I've had anywhere. The menu is limited, it's basically take out with some seating inside. The chips are also quite good they give you. Love this spot, and it's cheap and easy. You can also take it out and eat nearby on a bench or park.
author: Jonah K.

description:
Regular meat burritos 9.95
Tacos order of 2 meat $8.75

I ordered a grilled chicken burrito. It's was good but over priced considering there are a lot of other good burrito spots in the mission.
author: Frank A.

description:
I can't get enough of this place and their homemade hot sauce (purchased by the bottle of course). Always been out of horchata, so never tried it, but it's on my list. 

I haven't tried anything meaty here yet but I can't imagine it'd be anything less than delicious. I usually get the soyrizo burrito + potatoes. Rice, beans, pico de gallo on wheat tortilla noms.

Even when I'm full, I'm never too full. If I am, it's a bonus snack for tomorrow.

I could probably eat here everyday, forever.
author: Shereen A.

description:
Best salsa I've EVER HAD!!!

Man it's so good, I started buying it in stores to use for chips and salsa at home!

The burritos are pretty good here, too :) I tried the soyrizo one and LOVED IT. I'm sold!
author: Ezra B.

description:
Papalote drew much of its fame from winning the throwdown against Bobby Flay on Food Network. Their salsa was so famous that they decided to bottle and sell it; and I have to admit it was good and very unique because it's heavy on the creamy side, thick, and completely blended through.

The food was good.... depending on what you order. The carne asada quesadilla was OK, the cheese was a little too gritty for my taste. The prawn quesadilla was tasty but it was 25% prawns, 75% tortilla and cheese. 

I would recommend the carne asada burrito and douse that baby with their famous salsa (ask for easy on the beans). The rice-meat-beans proportion is perfect (unlike the heavy on the rice/beans at Cancun or Farrolito), and the serving size is generous. 

Note: Not a fan of the stale chips.
author: Jess C.

description: I've been coming to Papalote for over a decade because the food has always been tasty, but within the past few years, the quality and portions have completely deteriorated. The past handful of times I have left feeling ripped off, but given my history with this place, I didn't want to write it off just yet, thinking that they were maybe just having an off night. But this last experience was my last straw. My boyfriend and I ordered two chicken burritos, each being over $12. The amount of chicken in our "chicken" burritos was laughable. I thought they had forgotten the chicken completely but after opening my burrito, I counted three, yes three tiny pieces of chicken. This was also the case for my boyfriend. After paying over $12 for a burrito, you would expect some substance, not three tiny pea-sized pieces of chicken. What a joke. Sadly, I will not be returning after having frequented this spot for so many years. Not worth what you pay. If you want to pay over $12 for a stingy burrito, this is your spot, if not, go somewhere else to get your money's worth.
author: Claudette V.

description:
Got a naked carne asada "burrito" which is basically a chipotle bowl but not as flavorful. the meal was very chewy and even though I got a "super" which is an extra $2 for guac, sour cream, and cheese, it was somehow bland. 

Salsa is amazing. 

BF's chicken burrito on the tomato tortilla was good.
author: Emma M.

description:
This place is SOOOO overrated.  Had tacos there, first they are really expensive, two for about $9.  Taqueria tacos are usually about $2/ea.  Second they were terrible, the worst taqueria tacos I've every had. If a middle school was selling tacos at lunch, they would be just like these.  Lots of lettuce and tomatoes, very little meat.  The style wasn't even like a taqueria style taco, more like something Chipotle would sell, only not as good.  It is FAR from authentic, gringo tacos.

If you think Panda Express sells great Chinese food, then you may like this place.
author: Tim S.

description: My naked burrito with chicken mole - brown rice and super - was UNREAL. And the portion was huge. (SHARE!) That salsa is amazing. I'm older now. I love the cleaner environment. Worth the extra $.
author: Andrew K.

description: Looking for a restaurant that will satisfy Vegans, and non-Vegans alike? Along with a craving for Mexican? Then you've found the right place, and so did we! The food here is really well done, in a small environment that's reflective of a hidden gem that only San Francisco locals might know about. Order a burrito, a quesadilla or just some tacos. It's all great, and they're dipping sauces too! Yum.
author: Manny M.

description: This place is awesome. The salsa is amazing. We even took some home with us to LA give them a try!
author: Jillian G.

description:
If you get just one thing at Papalote, get the salsa. I mean, salsa isn't a food, but it goes so well with everything here! It's creamy, rich, and has just the right amount of kick.

Granted, everything else is great here too -- their burritos are large and fresh with no lard or anything. However, everything is real expensive here. $10 for a burrito? That's even more than The Little Chihuahua!
author: Casey S.

description: So very vegan friendly. Hubby is not vegan and enjoyed the meat. The soyrizo burrito and papalotes sauce...mucho way happy in my mouth.
author: Bethany P.

description:
MMM! Good food and friendly service.

Nachos were delicious with their special salsa. Very creamy.

Carne Asada burrito was also delicious, but I wish it was wrapped tighter; contents were loose in the tortilla.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
Maybe one of the best places in SF for vegans and vegetarians with richs flavors.
With a combination of Mexican and American Food this restaurante has a great options with soyrizo, f the best veggie food's invention or grilled vegetables!!
 Only bad thing us the noise. Is a very small restaurante and sometimes members of some groups (today next to me) were screaming all time!! But that is out control of the restaurante!!!!
author: Arturo R.

description: Not so much a fan of the food since there are so many options around the area but one thing they have that is amazing is the Fresh sauce option in the fridge not the jars that are out or in stores. Its orange and so good!!
author: Jay A.

description: 2 burritos $25. Wtf. Where do they get these exquisite beans? These regal tortillas? Shoulda walked up the block to Cancun
author: Jessica M.

description: This place is great!!! Everything is fantastic. My Personal favorite is the fish tacos. It comes with a medium tomato based hot sauce. It is so popular they are now selling it at the super markets. The burritos are also very good. Parking is difficult but worth it.
author: Kylie P.

description: How does this not have a higher review? Their salsa alone should be a 5 star. The place is small but the food is consistently delicious. I love everything here from the burritos, plates, or salad. I tend to get the fish salad with cilantro dressing and my husband gets the chicken burrito and both are super delicious.
author: Hello G.

description: They are now doing their own sauces and it's been so long since I made the trek up the taqueria, I had forgotten the lay out! The menu seemed slightly changed? But nevertheless was excellent... High quality fare... Had the chile verde super and was not disappointed... Drinking food! The chips with their own sauce at the start though mmmmm need more of that salsa... Worth a trip past the usually burrito joints for an altogether more relaxed experience in the mission
author: Reg B.

description: I've been coming to this place since the first week you opened...  the food remains great, but I'm deducting 4 stars for service...  maybe I'm slightly nostalgic for the old days when the owner / operator was behind the counter...  but I came in today at 11:30am to spend $44 for a few burritos and got treated like a 3rd class citizen.  It started with a 'don't bother me' vibe on the phone to call it in, culminating in a 'give me your f'ing money' vibe at the register.  I had a heightened awareness because my 3 year old son was with me and I don't want him to learn that it's OK to treat people in this way.  If you're charging a premium for food, it takes more than a good cook.  Tighten it up. #idontwritereviews #butyouwerethatbad
author: adam k.

description:
I was pretty disappointed with this place, given the great reviews. We ordered delivery. The food came pretty quickly. 

The food was alright, but definitely not worth 5 stars. I will definitely be searching around for other options the next time I am craving Mexican food. I got a burrito and it was just okay. It had beans, cheese and rice and the smallest amount of salsa. It tasted as boring as it sounds. My boyfriend got a chicken quesadilla and he felt very neutral about it and said he was not a fan of the spicing of the chicken. 

The biggest issue we had may or may not be the restaurant's fault. However, we ordered using Order Ahead and we did not have the options it seemed other customers had on the menu. For example, there was no option to get a "super burrito". If I wanted to add sour cream to the order it was $2.00 extra, etc. If you wanted extra chicken, it was something like  $6.50! Maybe there is a mistake with the menu within this app but this seems to be way too much for add ons.
author: Carissa B.

description: I obsessed with the super fish burrito here. For years now. I get one every time I'm in the lower mission. If you want a California-inspired uplift on the plentiful Mexican fare in the Mission, this is your place. The dinning room is small so you might want to take your food to go.
author: Jazmin H.

description: It's OK. Tastes more like chevy's Mexican food. There are so many places in the mission that are more authentic and taste better. I wanted to like this place but to me it's just hyped up.
author: Paola S.

description: I like this place a lot, their salsa is basically my favorite salsa ever. However, I feel like every time I'm there something happens and I can't just enjoy my food in peace. I won't stop going but every time I'm there, I remember why I don't go all the time:)
author: Roxi P.

description: A hearty burrito after a long week's work is exactly what I needed -- I have heard amazing things about papalote from friends and colleagues; it was true. I ordered 2 steak tacos and a triple threat burrito ( made super ) to share. Unfortunately they were closing soon so we had to get it to go -- although it was quite a long wait, it was so worth it. The meal came with nachos and their award winning papalote sauce. It was AMAZING! The triple threat burrito had all three meats -- chicken, steak, and garlic shrimp. The tacos were alright, a tad bit on the dry side but it is because we didn't get any guac or sour cream with it. Despite the wait and the fact we couldnt be seated, overall it was a good experience. I will be coming back again.
author: Peter W.

description: Huge fan of Papalote! The place has a casual, friendly vibe, decent burritos and AMAZING salsa. I mostly order takeout (I live down the block so it's hard not to!), but it's a nice place to sit and relax solo or with a small group, too. They have some unique flavor and protein combinations as well as a bunch of good vegetarian and vegan options. Nachos are really good too and a huge portion! A great spot in the Mission.
author: Christine G.

description: This place is the reason that The Mission is famed for burritos! We stopped in on a Sunday evening, a little before your typical dinner rush. We were able to order quickly and got a small table with no wait. Go here with an appetite b/c no matter how much you want to stop eating, you just can't! We had the house made salsa (OMG! So good!), chicken and grilled veggie nachos (Again... OMG!) to start. Our entrees were the fish tacos and carne asada super burrito. I'm more of a fried fish taco person, but these were really solid. Burrito can't be beat! Will definitely come back on our next visit to the city!
author: Suzanne P.

description:
Really good food, there is usually a line but worth the wait.

They have the garlic rice that can be added to your burrito.  

Definitely an underrated Mexican food location
author: Jad A.

description:
Not a place to get a shrimp burrito. They charge around $12 which is expected but in this huge burrito of just fillings, you'd be lucky to find 6 "medium sized" shrimps. I'm sure if you get chicken, beef, or whatever you see the meat everywhere. You take one bite and this guck just starts pouring out. I got sick for a from this place and that salsa is more like lard than anything. 

The only good thing I had was the chips but the overall experience wasn't good enough to come back. I emailed the restaurant about a refund after the poor meal and sickness but I got no response.
author: Daanyaal K.

description:
7x7 100 Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2012

#46 Chips and Salsa at Papalote

My first question to myself was how good can the chips and salsa really be or was this just another fill in item. Well I finally was able to have my answer this past week. 

After deliberating where to go, we decided to go to Papalote for their chips and salsa. While browsing their menu online I noticed something odd. Everyone on Yelp kept posting pictures of the Triple Threat Burrito however I saw it no where on the menu. Turns out it is their signature item that was featured on Bobby Flay's show Throwdown. 

Basically its a huge burrito stuffed with steak, chicken and shrimp however you do need to pay $1 extra to make it super. To me it is weird that isn't included in the price but ok. My friend and I agreed to split the burrito plus get chips, extra salsa and two beers. We both ended up paying $18 for just that so keep that in mind. 

For what its worth, the salsa is unlike any other salsa I have had. From color, consistency and all the way down to flavor there is a complexity to their salsa that is well worth trying. The chips did not appear to be anything out of the ordinary but I would recommend trying the salsa at least one time. 

The steak was sensational, the best I have had so far from any mexican restaurant. It was juicy, flavorful and fork tender. I would gladly go back for their carne asada burrito. 

Chicken was fine, good portion and seasoned adequately but no real highs or lows.

As for the shrimp, the addition of the 4 pieces felt a little underwhelming, and left me wondering why was it even in there to begin with. The quality was good and cooked well but didn't find it be a valid "threat".

Overall Thoughts

Salsa is delicious and well worth trying as well as the carne asada but be warned Papalote isn't a cheap grab and go burrito kind of place
author: Eddie W.

description:
One star for the fact that the salsa is available at Whole Foods. It is good salsa no doubt, but purchased with some sort of resignation because of an experience I'd had some years ago-

I had placed an order to go and waited patiently by the counter along with many other folks. The wait time ended up being about 30+ minutes, which I understand is just a reality sometimes and not worth complaining about. However when my order was ready I asked politely if I could get (and pay for) a bit more salsa, to which the woman at the counter replied in a patronizing tone, 'I'm sorry, we're closed.'  There were patrons still eating, and other folks still waiting to pick up their to go orders. It's not as if the register was closed, or anything was closed for that matter. Confounding.

As an aside, I had previously worked on a food magazine story about their great salsa, so this experience struck me as particularly distasteful on a personal level.

I do hope they've improved their service and attitude towards their customers since.
author: Snowballs Chance H.

description: Been wanting a burrito bowl so I decided to head here for a naked prawn burrito. The ingredients were quite yummy, loved the beans but there were only 4 prawns.  Mind u the prawns are not even that big, probably a bit bigger than a quarter.  Besides that it was quite filling.  I agree kinda pricey but everything tastes pretty fresh. People that work there are quite nice as well.
author: E S.

description:
Amazing home made salsa and tons of delicious vegetarian options. Huge portions and don't miss the pickle jar on the corner. 
I can probably just keep chips and salsa and end up eating my fingers. Would love to try other salsa options
author: Nikhil A.

description:
3 stars for the Triple Threat
4 stars for the carne asada tacos
5 stars for the salsa

Maybe the pictures got the best of me and it looked better than it tasted. The TT was a little overhyped in my opinion. The idea/concept is legit and the thing is enormous, but the flavors are a little muddled because there's just too much going on. I couldn't really taste the steak or the chicken although I know it's there. The carne asada taco had all the fixings and the steak was distinct and tasted great! The salsa...forget about it...it's hands down addicting like crack! 

I'll be back to try a normal carne asada burrito so that I can make a better comparison of the other taqueria spots I've already tried. I'll be back for sure!
author: Andrew S.

description: Really love the appetizer that's cheese and chorizo. A little greasy but it's delicious. I had a super vegetarian quesadilla that was really good as well. I don't agree with everyone about them having the best salsa , but I will say they pretty much make everything good .It's a solid place to get food
author: Lauren V.

description:
I am really confused on how to rate Papalote. 

I would give their bottled salsa 5 stars, best I have ever had, including in Mexico itself! I plan to stock up on the salsa for taco nights at home. Its delicious and everyone in my household loves it!

BUT, I got a chicken burrito and was disappointed with it. The high rating really got my expectations high, but the burrito lacked all the flavors I expect from a good burrito. I have had much better in several other places.

I might still go back to try their tacos (and to buy more salsa, ofcourse). But I'll pass on the burrito.
author: Hema R.

description: Been going here on and off for the last 8 years. That ends today after trying the Mexipino burrito. This is likely one of the most vile food products I have purchased and am seriously wondering if I'm making it to work tomorrow. No words can describe the sweaty combination of chicken and rice wit a sprinkle of "Filipino" seasoning that has likely been on the shelf since Duterte was born.
author: Walter M.

description:
Papalote was okay. I wouldn't return since the waitress said their best vegan tacos were the tofu ones, and I thought those were mediocre. Also, seating is extremely tight, and we had to play musical chairs at times during our meal, which I don't find to be an enjoyable experience. Also, the staff is constantly preparing and queue-ing up the next tables for the guests waiting so you never quite feel relaxed. I prefer a sit down meal where I'm not rushed personally. 

The taste of the vegan tofu tacos were good at first, but it was cloying after a while and hard to finish. My friend commented that his tacos were just okay as well. 

The infamous salsa was okay, I don't know what it was about it but it was not my favorite. My friend had another kind at home, and that was spicy and delicious. We wished it were served in-house.
author: Charlene N.

description:
I don't get it?
I came because of the reviews.

This was expensive. And lacked flavor entirely. 
They guac was probably the best part of this Americanized meal. I don't understand all the raves about this place. It's just "meh"
author: Twila J.

description:
I ordered Super Carne Asada Burrito Togo and it was delicious and friendly chef actually brought it out :)

Their jalapenos are really good too and it's not too  spicy. I think their unique selling point is definitely the salsa.
author: Daniel H.

description: One of the best places for burritos given the huge portions of flavorful meat and amazing special Papalote sauce.  Plus, the service is friendly, helpful, and prompt.  I'd come here whenever I get a chance.
author: Jenny L.

description: The utensils were modern and the interior decor was pleasing. It took them a while to make the burrito. For a super burrito, it was more expensive than your traditional popular burrito place in SF. The major downside with the food was that the burrito was quite dry. They serve the burrito on a plate which you can cut up with a knife and fork.
author: James S.

description: Definitely my favorite burrito place in San Francisco. I've been here so many times and was just let down once (my carne asada burrito with garlic rice was for some reason wayyyy too salty) but other than that, love this place!
author: Mauna T.

description:
I was not impressed. At all. My friend and I split the chicken mole burrito. Meh. Our kids got a cheese quesadilla ($5.15) and 4 chicken tacos ($19). The chicken was nicely seasoned but the taco tortillas were kinda stiff. 

The guacamole was good but $9.75??   The service was excellent.

I would give the food 3 stars cuz it wasn't "bad" but the prices were too high for what you got, so I gave it 2 stars.
author: R A.

description: We stopped in for lunch here; I told my homeboy about their award winning burritos and he ordered one. I had the chicken nachos. We left with a jar of salsa that we bought there. You can never go wrong at Papalote!
author: Mika D.

description:
Every time I'm in San Francisco I make my to this place for a burrito! Located in the mission area across from the 76 gas station. It goes get very busy and tends to be annoying when there's a lot of customers. On the other hand, the food is delicious however it is a little pricey but it's SF :) 

I always get the steak burrito with everything in it. I usually don't like guac in burritos but the put the right amount of it and it tastes perfect. The meat inside is extra crispy and tastes well cooked. 

After ordering they bring you salsa which is by far the best salsa you'll ever taste. Im not sure what's in it but maybe a tomato salsa? They don't have extra for free but it's a 1$ charge. 

Overall, I will continue getting my Mexican fix from here and recommend it to anyone that loves authentic Mexican food.
author: Hemza S.

description:
Very poor customer service- after 15-20 mins of wait for my fajitas, i got a buritto. And no apologies- apparently the cashier thought it was my fault that she took the wrong order . So she asked me to either pay 5 more dollars and wait 15 more minutes for the fajitas or eat the burrito .

I have always been a big fan of their delicious food- but totally disappointed by their unprofessional customer service.
author: Sherry B.

description:
Why in God's name would "Mexican" be included in the name of this establishment?  I've walked by this place for the past year on my way to work in Noe Valley & always wanted to get it.  Today I left work early & thought I would treat myself to some steak nachos. What a mistake that was.  $13+ for a bowl of chips with less than 1/2 cup of toppings combined.  What's that 1000% mark up? The guacamole was mashed up avocado w no favor, the pico de gallo was chopped tomatoes with no flavor, the cheese wasn't melted & the steak was super dry & tasted like Taco Bell steak (sorry Taco Bell).  The horchata was the worst!  It tasted like lemonade!  I was so disappointed.  

Gone are the days when you could go to the Mission for cheap burritos & nacho plates.  Considering who now lives in the Mission I'm not surprised.  I'm sure this place will continue to be packed by transplant hipsters that don't know any better.  As for me I'll stick to La Tapatia in SSF where you can get nachos for half the price that you can share w 2 or 3 friends.
author: Rosie D.

description:
Really delicious burrito and that salsa that comes with is both unique and out of this world! 

They don't serve ground  beef or pulled meats, however my friend had the pork and it was just about as close as you can get o pulled pork it was so nicely cooked, tender, moist and came apart easily.

I tried the veggie with carrot, potato, mushroom - it was fantastic!!! Loved the charred flavor of the veggies. 

Great place to stop for a filling, yummy bite!
author: Pamela M.

description:
I ordered the Mexipino that others were raving about and it cost around $10.
I'm sorry but I just don't understand what people are so amazed about? I actually thought it was a little too salty and not enough of a balance. 
My burrito was also a little too loose and just fell apart altogether which made it quite messy. 
Maybe it was all the juices inside that caused it but in the end, I threw away the last 1/3rd of it. 
I wouldn't say it was bad but certainly not an item worth 5 stars.

Will I return? Probably ......to try out other items. 

There's just so much competition in the area for Burritos that you have to be spectacular to get 5 stars and I feel like the Mexipino is more of a gimmick than a "have to have" item.
author: Chris L.

description: Pacifico is $7?!? Their burritos are passable, salsa is like crack, and chips are good but I cannot abide the $7 Pacifico.
author: Steve E.

description:
I finally got to try this place after hearing so much about it from friends and Bobby Flays throw down.

Overall this place has pretty decent burritos, chips, and quesadilla. However nothing special enough to warrant my return. I will stick with El Farolito from now on and NEVER stray again.

Chips and sauce were ok. Chips were a bit thick. Sauce was pretty good, albeit a bit on the heavy side.

Shrimp Burrito. SUPERRRR salty. I ended up forgoing half of it, and fishing out the shrimp to eat. I can tell ingredients are fresh. However it was a bit plain, and the bell peppers were in large chunks dispersed unevenly in the burrito.

Beef quesadilla. It's very small for how much your pay, but pretty good. 4 pieces of quesadilla and beef that was flavorful. However the beef was on the dry and chewy side. (El Farolito is 20000000% better. ARguably they have the best quesadillas in town.)

Breakfast Burrito.  SOOO salty and greasy, that I was honestly not even sure what I was eating. I would definitely stay far away from this.

All in all...not bad by any means. However it would be a disappointment if you are expecting it to live up to its hype.
author: Em F.

description: Best burrito I've had, ever. Had the grilled veggie burrito with guacamole. It had lots of veggies (usually veggie burrito's have loads of rice and beans, with some veggies ... this was the opposite, which I like). I came here because I heard about their amazing salsa. It's as good as everyone says it is, absolutely delicious. The place is quite far from where I am, but worth the 30min bus ride. Will definitely come back and get a jar of their homemade salsa.
author: Linda S.

description:
This place was great back in the day. Food and service has gone downhill. A bottle of beer is now $7! 

Salsa is still the best!
author: Neil M.

description: A quaint stop in Mission District. Casual atmosphere. They serve they most delicious salsa to start. The food came out quickly. The water is self serve. If the place would have been larger and they offered seconds of salsa, I would rate it a 5!!!
author: Karen R.

description: Parking is hard but the sauce was worth it and they have vegan options :) so that's super cool
author: Alice A.

description: Excellent carne asada tacos. The meat is high quality. The taco fixings are perfect and generous. OMG and that salsa though?!!?!!!! No wonder they bottle it... It's life changing :)
author: Lajuanda A.

description:
Let me start off this review with the fact that I do not go for Mexican food. It's not necessarily that I don't like it, it's just that I basically crave everything else before I go for something South-of-the-Border. So, when visiting a friend in SF, she pretty much had to drag me here.

Papalote is now the only Mexican place I will willingly go to. I had the greatest burritos and salsa of my life. My friend and I split a chili verde burrito and a mole burrito. Both were phenomenal. The mole burrito can only be described as a warm and a loving caress in my mouth; the chili verde was exciting and exquisitely spiced and danced on my taste buds. Both were amazing in different ways.
 
The salsa that the chips came with was also amazing. Bought a jar; taking it home and gonna eat it forever.
author: Riva L.

description:
The salsa was good - very creamy with a kick to it. 

However, my burrito was dry, dry, dry, with so much beans and rice filling. I ended up taking the whole thing apart and only eating the steak pieces.
author: Ashley Z.

description:
Holy crap, this might be the best burrito I've grabbed in the Mission.

It's not like El Farolito, El Castellito, Pancho Villa or Taqueria Cancun. It's clean and cute in here, menu items are $3-$5 more expensive, it's located far off Mission Street almost in Noe Valley and you won't be coming here drunk really late at night after you leave the bars. 

You know how you drink the nicer wine when you're sober and then switch to the cheaper wine? Papalote is like the burrito version of nice wine. 

Also, the salsa. My god, the salsa. It's the best salsa I've ever had. I get it, I'm on board. It's worth the hype.

Come here and get your day burrito on.
author: K M.

description: I am a fan of the burritos here.  A little disappointed the last time I got food here, but I'll keep coming back.  You guys get a pass because the food is good. :)  Please expand to the East Bay since I see Papalote salsa on sale at stores now.  They should give you at least two salsa cups when ordering to go.  The salsa is pretty awesome!  Chips are good too!  But, after careful research and study I have concluded there are better spots in the Mission for burritos.  But hey, the SF Mission is the best area for Burritos and Mexican food in general. So, no knock on you, Papalote.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Very underwhelmed. I ordered 2 marinated tofu tacos, which were pretty boring, taste-wise. (*Much* better tofu tacos across the Bay, at Cholita Linda.) 

The worst is that each taco had only *one* tortilla. Wtf? The tofu tacos were already very heavy and moist (given the tofu itself and lots of chopped tomatoes), and so the thin tortillas just disintegrated the moment I tried to lift them, spilling the contents all over the plate. 

On the plus side, the salsa that came with complimentary chips was pretty good. I put most of it on the disintegrated tacos to give the sad remains of my ruined tacos a modicum of flavor. 

Skip!
author: Rosalind C.

description:
Ordered the Chile Verde burrito. It was mushy flavorless mess, 'Pico de gallo' was a few tomatoes. This place does not stand up to the hype. The worst burrito I've had in the mission... probably because of the vegan beans. 

I heard that the salsa was the best in SF. It also has no flavor. A little spicy but that's it; the only thing that stood out was the unique consistency.

Oh and if you want extra of their horrible salsa it's 50 cents. Ridiculous.... i just paid $12 for a burrito, c'mon.
author: Jim W.

description: Based on other yelp reviews, I expected way better food.  The salsa wasn't what I expected, it was creamy, not chunky.  Adding sour cream, cheese and guacamole on my mexican /filipino burrito, the price came up quite a bit more compared to other mexican places.  Someone else had the fish burrito bowl and it was fine. The cashier didn't bother giving me a receipt and the restaurant has a very small seating area.  Overall, kinda disappointed.
author: K. G.

description:
I looove their orange sauce/salsa that comes with their chips. It makes anything you order from the menu even better!

My bf had the chicken adobo burrito with everything on it. It was both our first time trying it and it was pretty good and hefty, until he was finishing the first half...piece of hair. *gag* instantly looses appetite.

I immediately bring the plate back to one of the servers and show him what we found. Another worker came to us at our table to apologize for the incident and offered us the option of getting a refund or another one to-go, which I appreciated. But still disgusted...like why can't instances like that be avoided? I hate that ugh makes me cringe.

It's tough to not let my view of this spot to be tainted by that mishap. I really enjoyed their orange sauce and burritos...whyyyyy me?! I guess it'll just take some time to come back and give the place another chance without questioning if there's a piece of hair in my burrito =(
author: Georgina G.

description:
Hipstered burritos? In MY Mission?
It's more likely than you think.

Papalote gets points on fresh ingredients, a juicy carne asada (which should never be dry, dammit why is it always dry), and griddled burritos by default (think dorado style at La Taq).

They lose points, however, on the orange-colored salsa. It's more like an aioli honestly, and it had very little flavor. I'm surprised the Yelp literati raves about it because we were not impressed.

The chips and guac were fine, and pickled jalapeños you grab out of a jar were a nice touch. If a friend really wanted to come here, I wouldn't complain. But the SO and I both agree, we'll stick to the tried and true burrito corridor on Mission Street.
author: Zach M.

description:
Very good burritos, they are tasty and large. It is definitely enough for at least two meals for most people!

I like that this location has ample seating, which gives it a competitive edge over some of the other burrito places in the Mission with nowhere to sit.

The salsa is amazing, but you probably didn't need me to tell you that, right?

The staff are attentive, but not always the most friendly. Venue seems clean enough.

Thanks, I'll keep coming back :-)
author: Meaghan H.

description: This place was recommended to me by a friend who lives in the Mission. After seeing the 2000 reviews and 4 star rating I knew I was in. Definitely lives up to the reviews! The super nachos were HUGE, ended up getting a box to go. The salsa is a must have and so is the steak burrito. Taking off one star as I'm an avid fountain drink lover and this was lacking here. Other than that good neighborhood Mexican restaurant.
author: Katie C.

description: Second time here and both times the venue was selected by my dinner date as their respective favorite - so there is that. I am reasonably I had the super size buritto chicken mole the first time and I had it again on this visit. This is the best mole sauce I have ever had. BAM! Get it!!! Before digging into that bad boy, we shared a large chorizo con queso apetizer which comes with choice of hot tortilla or chips. If you use up the tortilla, they will give you chips - no losing there. On this visit, my date had the fish tacos and was thoroughly please with her selection as well. We will keep coming back. See ya!
author: Scott C.

description: THAT SALSA!!!!!! But also the food is amazing haha. The vegetarian options can't be beat for my wife, and I'm a meat-eater looking for their delicious steak. When we are tired and lazy after work and can't be bothered with deciding what to eat, Papalote is always the go-to... like twice a week. Awesome spot.
author: Jake K.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me this long to try Papalote!

My boyfriend & I were craving really good salsa so I checked on Yelp & saw that I had bookmarked Papalote for years - perfect!
It was a beautiful day in San Francisco. 
We found parking almost immediately & was welcomed with upbeat Mexican music when we walked in. 
I ordered the fish tacos & my boyfriend ordered the carne asada burrito.  
Each order comes with side of tortilla chips & salsa. 
This salsa was DELICIOUS - very unique, not too spicy, not bland & very creamy. 
My boyfriend wished it had a little more tomato-ness to it, but I thought it was great.

My fish tacos came out & they were amazing!
There were nicely cut chunks of fresh fish in there & they didn't skimp out at all. 
I think they might put a TEENY bit too much shredded cheese but I guess it just depends on your taste. 
I have to say these fish tacos are the best that I've tried in SF thus far!

My boyfriend really enjoyed his burrito. 
I tried it out & I thought it had a really good grilled flavor to it. 
The meat was tender - not dry at all (which surprised me because it looks dry at first glance).  
The one thing I would say is that I think they put too much rice. 

Overall great experience at Papalote. 
As other reviewers have mentioned, it IS a bit pricey - so don't go in there thinking you'll have a cheap meal. 
We paid $23 for the tacos (which comes in two), the burrito, & one horchata.
author: Sylvia N.

description: I am convinced that they use crack for their salsa because I am ADDICTED!  So good.  Love the food here....wish the dining area was bigger, but I just go early!
author: John C.

description: Great food and good price! There Carne asada is delicious and same goes for the salsa!
author: Karla V.

description: I appreciated all the veggie options. However, the veggie burrito was a little too greasy and salty for me. The roasted tomato salsa was delicious though. Overall, I'd recommend La Taqueria!
author: Joshua R.

description: The best (vegetarian) burrito in San Francisco! I absolutely love that they have multiple solid vegetarian options. My go-to is the marinated tofu burrito, and I'm obsessed with their signature roasted red pepper salsa.
author: Shilpa R.

description: So you like the generic Chipotle burrito?  Why not whilst in San Francisco try the real deal?  First order at the counter, ask for a table or to go.  Simple menu.  I ordered the carne asada regular.  They bring out chips and dip.  The chips are fine, but not my preference as they are thick.  The salsa has a nice flavor, but a bit different, not your normal red/green.  The blueprint for the burrito, carne asada, pintos, rice, wheat tortilla, and salsa.  Tortilla good, other ingredients standard flavors , but the carne asada is fantastic and they are generous with the helpings!  All of this comes together in a perfect mix.  Throw off the shackles of corporate greed and try an original in the Mission District.....
author: Paul V.

description:
An experience like never before. O.o

Dear Yelpers, 

Please proceed with caution when entering a despised Mexican joint like PapaShittay....

Today I ordered two Super Steak Burritos with everything. Me and my boy sit down, and in 5 minutes we get our burrito. I'm eating through my burrito and wtf..... there's no steak. No sour cream.  I told the lady about it and she gave me a plate with steak expecting me to stuff it in my burrito. But I ordered Steak Burrito... 

#ButIOrderedASteakBurrito 

Never again... This is how you treat a loyal customer?
author: Leo J.

description: Their burrito is unbelievable and the special house sauce is out of this world. great customer service as well
author: michael m.

description: This is my 10th time here and everytime has been equally consistent and delicious! Definitely the best burrito place in town and I especially recommend their mexipino burrito. Free nachos and pickles, can this place get any better!?
author: Eddie Z.

description: I ordered the prawn tacos (comes with 2 prawns in each with lettuce/tomatoes/jicama). Ingredients were made fresh with not a lot of fuss. We also ordered the chicken super nacho. Yummy!!! If you like fresh ingredients, this is the place for you. Not the best tacos/nachos I've ever had but decent. We were also served chips and their signature Papalote dip which was very good. Consistency of ranch but very flavorful.
author: Ya Y.

description:
All I can say about Papalote is I love the salsa!! Everytime I've gone, I've wanted to buy a bottle of it but I always resist. They have very interesting combinations for their entrees. You can choose between tacos, quesadillas, salads or burritos and then pick whatever protein you want. They have a bunch of different veggie options so it's exciting to keep coming here and try different things. 

I think my favorite would be the potato, carrot, mushroom. They put a lot of these veggies in there so you get some in every bite. If you get a burrito, make it super so you can get sour cream, guac and cheese! I've heard to tofu is very good as well so I'll be back to try that!

It gets kind of crowded at dinner time (6:30-8:30) and the place is pretty small so I would recommend pick up if you're going around that time.
author: Malika R.

description:
This place has the best fish burrito I've ever tasted! A friend suggested this place before and my other friends and I decided to give it a try because we were craving Mexican food, but wanted to try a new place. 

They're pretty pricey, but hey, it's good food! I crave the fish burrito sometimes because it's just THAT good.
author: Vanessa M.

description: Most overrated place in San Francisco.  People always say but the "salsa is so good" so it got one star for salsa.  My boyfriend loves it because Postmates delivers it for cheap (there's a reason it sucks).  Chicken was somehow burnt lacking in flavor and charred at the same time.  I always ask for no sour cream and extra cheese.  They never get either right.  This time got tomatoes and horrible chicken with no rice.  And beans that would could pass for beans in Nebraska, maybe.  Please please please please go to one of the hundred other burrito places in SF!!!!
author: William O.

description: yummy! I enjoyed their veggie burrito and salsa!  Wish they provided more salsa for free but whatever "not all salsa is free".  I think Jesus said that.
author: j. t.

description:
People always ask what my favorite burrito is, and I always answer that it depends on my mood.  If i absolutely could only choose one, regardless of my mood, it would be Papalote.  This place is especially dangerous because i live a couple short blocks away.

Ingredients are all A+.  The garlic rice is very good.  Chicken is some of the best in any burrito I have ever had.  The salsa is incredible (I always order 2 extra on top of the 1 they give you).  Its a Filipino style burrito which is a nice contrast to the traditional burritos you will find at a Mission spot like Farolito .  They sell beer too so its always good to enjoy a tall can while you eat your burrito.

I also recommend buying a couple of their salsa jars to go because it is so good on everything.
author: Tom F.

description:
HOMOPHOBIC WORKERS !
Today was my first time in that horrible place and there was a transgender woman who also ordered a burrito. People who was working behind the cashier and other workers were looking at her and laughed to each other. PLEASE DO NOT order your burrito from this HOMOPHOBIC place !
author: Arthur W.

description: Craving this burrito now and forever. Pulled up this page just to look at pictures of said burrito. Go here for the creamy salsa!
author: Nicole A.

description:
I had the carne asada burrito with refried beans and nachos. Both with guoc sour cream and cheese. The beef was really tender, surprisingly good. A friend of ours recc'd the place and had no idea it had so many reviews. Must be all the out of town yelpers like myself peeping it.
 
The food is good, jarritos is a plus and cant go wrong with a cerveza to chase it down.

  The bathroom is like a high school one, all tagged up but is clean. Too close to the dining area though.

Parking is tricky so good luck. We found meter street parking
author: TOY A.

description: Food is really good,very disappointed about the place being so tiny..very crowded with all the soda boxes and beer being all over the place they need to get rid of all those business cards move the water and empty chilies jar to that counter bar and add more stools to it will defenetly add more seating by declaring the place..and side to ooo expensive c'mon $1 for sour cream.
author: Lizbeth V.

description:
Super delicious burritos. We got the super burritos, one with steak, one with chicken and another rice and three kinds of beans (black, pinto and refried). They are all incredibly yummy. Now I believe burritos don't actually have to be spicy to be tasty. 

Btw, their salsa and chips are crazy good too. I am hooked.
author: Shou-cheng L.

description: I ordered the carne asada super burrito and it was one of the best burritos I've ever had! The meat was nice and juicy and very flavorful. It also comes with chips and this orange sauce which is a little bit spicy but bearable. I would definitely come again!
author: Bailey L.

description: Waaay Overpriced for average food. They must have spent too much on painting the bathroom--very disappointed with the food and the service. Go somewhere else!!!!!
author: A.K. S.

description:
The Burritos are great and they serve em up right. The chips are thick and lovely like they should be. The salsa is so good they bottle it, but you don't get to serve yourself so you've got to be sparing. And you drop a little more money than at most taquerias so its a little bit of a treat. 
The Tofu mole is one of the best burritos in the city though so its worth it.
author: Martin L.

description: I've eaten in almost all of the Mission's Mexican restaurants, having lived in the neighborhood for the past eight years. This is flat-out my favorite. They grill the meat fresh as you place your order - not ladling it out of some bin of mystery meat, like many of the other places - and all the ingredients are super top quality, fresh from the farm. The owner and staff are exceptionally friendly, and many of them greet me by name. My entire family loves the house specialty salsa/sauce they serve with your chips, which is available at a number of local supermarkets (and available freshly made in take-home jars, behind the front counter). Highly recommended!
author: Bill W.

description: Wow, I'm definitely coming back here!! Delicious food, great service, & didn't have to wait long for food. Delicious chips and dip too!
author: James D.

description:
The hype about this place is as high as ever. But there are so many great options in the area, does this one hold up to its reputation? I'm going to say no. It's getting a high rating from me because I generally love Mexican food, especially if it's in the Mission. If I say it's in my top ten, that's got to be a good thing right?

I had the carne asada burrito, it's my go to. The taste is definitely there. It's packed full of flavor, the vegetables were fresh, the meat tender and cooked to perfection, the service was blazing fast (which mexican place isn't?). However, the portions left me wanting more. Or maybe it's my huge appetite. Other places give you a giant burrito that can fill an ogre. The burritos here were moderate sized, not enough for your average (read: fat) american. 

I had a jamaica aka hibiscus drink as well, but found it too sugary.

Still, it's a good location, and the food was delicious. The portions were average size, but for the price, the value is missing. I'd also like to complain about the lack of seating, but I came in at a very busy time, so that's probably my own fault.
author: Phan H.

description: I went here twice. First time I didn't enjoy it but because it was close to my apartment I went back a second time. Just as bad as the first... Too expensive for what you get. They charge a dollar for sour cream, cheese or guac... Burrito was not good with crunchy undercooked rice. The salsa is awesome. Buy the salsa and leave. I'll buy the salsa in the jar but won't be back for the burrito.
author: Patrick P.

description:
Grabbed a veggie burrito (potatoes, mushrooms, carrots) with guacamole to go. The veggies are delicious and the vegan black refried beans are awesome! The papalote roasted tomato salsa is kind of amazing. 

I love that they have such a great vegetarian and vegan selection. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Yea this spot was alright i came from oakland cus the reviews and not only that but they're supposed to be one of the best in th i dont know how everything totaled out to $16 for a burrito and a drink but yea the best thing about the burrito was the steak it was perfect grilled chunks but im not sure if it was the rice or too much seasoning but it was pretty salty and i really wish the salsa was actually spicy but i feel like i can get a better burrito  back across the bridge
author: Antonio R.

description: When visitors come to SF, they're often familiar with mission-style burritos.  What they DON'T know is that different taquerias have different specialties.  For example, you go to El Farolito for their carne asada.  Personally, I love the chicken tikka masala burrito from Curry Up Now.  But you go to Papalote for their shrimp burrito.  It's huge and delightful.  Plus their creamy salsa?  Two thumbs up.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
This was such a great burrito! No line at 5:30pm on a Saturday. I got the super chicken burrito with refried black beans and no rice. We sat there and there was a ton of seating. I didn't even know what was coming with that amazing salsa. I knew it must be good since they sell it at the register, but wow is it good. I have considered going back just to buy some so I can put it on every future meal!
The burrito's are massive. I cut it in half and it made out to be two decent meals. I liked how the tortilla was grilled and that they put a lot of meat in there. Only drawback was that there were way too many beans. I hardly got any guacamole, hence the four stars. I would definitely go back to try something else here! I am sure they do breakfast burritos really well. They have one person dedicated just to phone orders, so they seem pretty efficient.
author: Alisha K.

description:
Chicken adobo burrito. Chicken adobo, garlic rice, egg, secret herbs and spices, all wrapped up in a tortilla. What red-blooded Filipino or ANY foodie worth their salt, for that matter, wouldn't want this? 

-1 star for being all the way up in the City and for me being all the way down here in LA. ;)
author: Jimmy N.

description: Got a mole burrito with guac and bottle of Modelo - $20. Food quality was good 4/5, value 3/5
author: Timur T.

description: Love this place! The homemade salsa is amzing! The best Burritos ever! The place has a fun vibe, also great for children. My son loves it.
author: Maxwell N.

description:
Bottom line at the top: really yummy!!
--
The sauce here is to die for. Had carne asada tacos and a side of achiote chicken. Service is great but they are weirdly stingy about extra sauce. 

La Taqueria is still my favorite joint in SF but this is still a great spot.
author: Dahlia S.

description: If it weren't for the salsa this place wouldn't be good. I got the fish burrito, very soggy and tasteless.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Come here if you like quality: My favorite steak burrito in town! That's pretty much all i get here. All meat, no chewy weird stuff you won't swallow. 3 types of tortillas, spinach, tomato and regular so you can switch it up here and there. They're also heated in the skillet, extra crispy please! They have mild and hot salsa. If you don't ask, you will get mild. 

If you like hip hop and reggae, that's all you will hear from the speakers. They owner is a DJ and bad ass favorite! 

You also love art. Hip hop culture and Mexican culture up on the walls and all art is for sale. 

Also, Papalote means kite. Find cool kites in here 

Don't come here: If you like cheap food don't eat here. If you're still used to the high fats, stringy meat, cloned veggies, guacamole from a bag and sugary hfcs gmo tortillas heated with a steamer, skip this place. 

Out of 100 burritos, 1 sucked. New cook I guess. "Even the best chef burns the beans" they say.
author: Fredo L.

description: I got Papalotes through postmates. At first I was pleasantly surprised. It was a good size burrito with some fresh chips. As I was eating, I was actually enjoying my chicken burrito... until I found not one, not two, but three strands of hair in the burrito. Had to throw most of the burrito away. Super big disappointment!
author: Rupa A.

description:
Some friends and I ventured to the mission and eat at one of the many great burrito places there. My friend chose this place because of the reviews.
The place will tend to get packed during peak hours (we went on a saturday) but good thing we stopped by a lil after that. The waitress cleared a table for us which was great so we can sit and chat. I was surprised that they did not have a carnitas burrito and the only pork they had was carne verde? Dont quite remember the name.

I thought it was alright, I will want to try the other places as well.
author: Jade L.

description: I live across the road and come here once per week (get a loyalty card). Legendary sauce. Better burritos than many nearby shops, but a little pricier. Get the spinach tortillas or naked bowl. Very fast take out (phone to pickup is under 10 min).
author: Brayden M.

description:
i always judge a burrito place on its vegetarian burritos. why?

a) it's cheaper. and if i eat a bad burrito, i don't want to spend a lot.

b) It makes sure i confirm that there is good tortillas, fresh vegetables, and a good cheese:bean:rice ratio without the meat seasoning distractions.

c) if i like it, it will be even better when i come back and get a meat burrito.

but papalote broke these rules and made my favorite vegetarian burrito- it has so many good vegetables and potatoes!! so good. 

also has A+ chips and salsa.
author: Kate T.

description: the location and dining room off Valencia invites all sorts of characters. I have my regular order and it's always good. Papalote is a nice mixed-crowd taqueria with killer orange salsa.
author: Matt J.

description:
Saw this place on the Food Network and yelped it and saw all the reviews and its rating. Usually Food Network places suck but this was a surprise.

Street parking.

I ordered the Chicken Adobo Burrito. This was one of the best burritos I ever ate. The chicken was moist and flavorful. Everything in the burrito worked well with the chicken. I ate the whole thing and I normally can never finish my food. It was that damn good.

Must eat again!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Super mega huge tacos made with fresh ingredients and delicious meat. 
The ambiance is great and the staff is awesome. Definitely a good value.
author: Olivier L.

description: Best. Salsa. Ever!!!    Ask for the house salsa, not the pre-canned stuff, when you order your food.   The triple threat is an evil burrito!!!  Chile Verde here is really good too!
author: Aaron C.

description:
I think Scott L. has the most accurate review of this place. There is a bunch of hype for this place and I was intrigued in trying this place. When we got there the restaurant was empty and the menu is a little hard to read. 

The service at the counter was okay. It was our first time there and there were two people behind us and we felt very rushed. The girl that was taking our order was very quick when we ordered one thing saying "okay anything else" as soon as we said one item. We didn't have a chance to ask questions or even take a good look at the drink options because we felt like she was trying to cut the line of two down as soon as possible.

After we got our drinks, we went and sat down. The place is very small but has enough seating for roughly 15-20 people. Our party of 8 sat comfortably. Within 5 minutes our guacamole came out with the house salsa. Roughly 5 minutes later our triple threat burrito came out. The guys that brought out the food were really nice.

The guacamole was absolutely fantastic. It is up there on par with Chipotle if not better and I didn't know if that was even possible. Chipotle's guacamole was one of the best I have ever had but this place takes the cake as far as guacamole is concerned. The $10 appetizer seemed expensive, but for the price you actually get a lot of guacamole.

The triple threat burrito is the size of a new born baby. It is large. I am glad I shared it because there is no way I would have been able to eat that by myself. The main event was the saddest part of our visit. As Scott L. mentioned, you can tell the meat is flavored and there are things working for it but as a whole it is underwhelming. I had better burritos at taco trucks. 

There wasn't enough good things to warrant a revisit. I won't be back unless I am in the city craving some delicious guacamole.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
2.5 stars

4 prawns in my $12+ burrito. Seriously.

Granted, I didn't necessarily have an issue with the way the perfectly grilled, plump, and juicy prawns were proportioned relative to the other ingredients in my burrito, and I'm sure the portion size would have done a better job filling me up if I didn't have the rice replaced with romaine to cut back on carbs. But my burrito was almost all tortilla: take your average Chipotle burrito (forgive the comparison), remove half of the contents, and charge twice the price. Oh and speaking of the contents, it was just prawns, romaine, and black beans..... For that kind of subpar value? Meh... I've definitely experienced better.

It's a shame because this is totally my kind of Mexican joint -- ultra fresh, high-quality ingredients simply and relatively healthily prepared but loaded with intricate layers of natural flavors. However, between the exorbitant prices and the unforgivably rude service (lady behind the counter served up more attitude than burrito), I'm not sure if I'll be back.
author: Cam Y.

description: Came here for a work event recently. I'm talking 15 of us crammed in to Papalote during prime dinner hour. While I ordered a fish burrito, my colleagues were ordering almost every thing off the menu along with a couple rounds of beer. The food here is relatively "clean," however c'mon if you're in the Mission you want a REAL Mission burrito... Btw, the salsa they provide is worth the visit and maybe can overlook the yuppie foods... I'd still come back.
author: Tracy C.

description: The food here is fantastic, in substantial part due to the fantastic sauce, which can also be purchased separately for take-home.  It's extremely crowded, with a huge take-out business.  I  prefer tacos over burritos, and their mole tofu tacos are delicious, but the serving size I feel is a bit small (compared to a burrito), and it always leaves me hungry, but getting two servings would be too much.  If it was three instead of two tacos I think that would be better, but then I don't eat chips, and if I ate even half the tortilla chips they are generally provide I'd certainly be enough.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Salsa!!!!! Oh my!!!! Soooooo good.

I was just watching on the travel channel the other day  a show about the best burritos in the country and Papalote was in it. I kept thinking about how bad I wanted to try their burritos. Well, it just so happen that we went up to the bay this weekend for my bf's DJ gigs and one of them was at the mission district. Since we were in the area, I couldn't pass up the chance. 

We got there around 8pm, an hour before closing time. It was nice to get free chips and salsa while waiting for our food. As I've already mentioned, the salsa is bomb!!! The chips, on the other hand, I didn't really care for. They were kinda stale. Then burritos came. I had the tofu mole burrito with refried black beans, wrapped in spinach tortilla and upgraded to super for just 99 cents! Super means they add sour cream, guacamole and cheese. I got mine without the sour cream. The burrito was delicious! That mole sauce was one of the best I've ever tried. Although, I wish I would've gotten whole black beans instead of refried because everything in my burrito was mushy. 

Burrito was devoured and I couldn't move for half an hour. Will definitely be back here next time I'm in SF.
author: Delani D.

description:
My boyfriend's coworker raves about the place so we decided to give it a try when we were in the neighborhood. The place was pretty happening and the cashier girl was super sweet. We were pretty excited to dig into the chicken mole (mine) and chicken asado burrito (the boyfriend's). 

Unfortunately, the place really fell flat. My boyfriend's burrito was pretty good, but my chicken mole was terrible. I am not the type of girl that leaves food on the plate, but I felt the dish was pretty much inedible. The rice was way under cooked -- totally raw in the middle. The chicken was overcooked -- stringy and tough. The mole sauce didn't taste all that multi-dimensional or complex. I did, however, love the small bit of jicama salad on the plate. 

The burrito here is worth a try and the rice is probably not normally that terrible. I'm willing to give the place another try, but will definitely get the burrito and avoid any of the entree plates.
author: Alice W.

description: Had the Super Carne Asda burrito and it was AMAZING!!!! Definitely coming back here when in SF..!!! Tortilla chips on point and there salsa is so amazing!! FYI you can buy the salsa
author: Shante G.

description: Always like visiting Papalote with their great soyrizo vegetarian option.  Orders come with chips + their famous salsa.  Burrito bowls are my go-to here and they make them great.  This restaurant is small, with limited seating, so be prepared to wait.
author: TZ J.

description:
This place is voted "best burrito in the Bay Area"? REALLY?? Mediocre, overpriced burritos that take 40 minutes to make while you wait in a poo-smelling environment, that's the best SF has to offer? My friend ordered guacamole and chips, which were unceremoniously placed at the bottom of the bag, beneath all the other "food". And I don't know who the hell they think they are fooling when they give you a side of "salsa" because that shit tastes like ass and it's not anything close to being salsa. 

There are so many better burritos to be had in the Bay Area, for much cheaper, where people actually know how to make Pico de Gallo. Avoid this place. Avoid it like the plague.
author: J J.

description:
Papalote is one of the best burrito places I have been to. I've been to this place a couple times and I have never been disappointed.
 
Here's why I gave them FIVE stars:

Plus one star for the portion size.  I was looking around the restaurant and the portions that they give patrons are pretty hefty.  I'm such a piggy that I love big portion sizes (but of course without sacrificing quality!) We got the Triple Threat Burrito which is so ginormous that Loverboy and I were full after splitting one. You can even split that burrito into three and still be full afterwards.  You can save some of it for the next day.  It tastes amazing just sitting in the fridge overnight.  It's like the flavors magnified while marinating in the fridge. $20 for one burrito is not expensive if you can split that into three or four meals.  

Plus one star for flavor. The beef, chicken and prawns were perfectly seasoned.  Everything inside that monstrous burrito is delicious. The meat pieces were so juicy and tender. The flavors of the three different kinds of meats really complemented each other.

Another star for beating that douche Bobby Flay. I just can't stand his show and how he goes around America telling people he can cook better.  Papalote really deserved that win and they were heroes for showing B. Flay that he ain't all that!

Another star for the sauce.  It is sooooogood!  I want to drink a whole jar of it. I am so happy that they sell jars of that yummy sauce. I just want to slather that sauce all over rice and you could even put that in a quesadilla or a sandwich.

The last star goes to the owners and the staff.  The cashiers were super nice and they had big smiles on their face when we ordered.  The owners are socially responsible and are good people. I went to a volunteer event for Project Pearls where we collected clothes and non-perishable goods for victims of Typhoon Sendong in the Philippines.  Around lunch time, one of the owners of Papalote came with a big box full of burritos which he donated to feed the volunteers. He brought us FREE chicken adobo burritos! They were so delicious! 

Check them out.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Shirleyanne A.

description: I love Mexican food and I might have just had the best burrito in my life.. It was delish and flavorful! I'm from MI and I usually feel a heaviness in my stomach after eating so much Mexican food but probably because Papalito uses fresh ingredients, although I got full the food didn't sit in my stomach very heavy which was great! Salsa is aweeeesome!
author: Sheereen S.

description:
Meh.  Not hatin', but I'm not sure I understand why people stand in line here for 30 minutes at 2 pm on a Wednesday... (but then again city people can be funny that way... )    Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing  (the chicken and garlic rice burrito with tomatoes) but there really wasn't anything special about it or any of the tacos the rest of the people in my party of 7 were having.   Yes, the salsa is very unique - creamy as though it is an emulsion of oil and tomato with chiles and a nice spicy kick. (almost like a spicy aioli).    The chicken nachos were very good - nice big serving with lots of grilled chicken and cheese.  But at the end of the day, there was nothing remarkable about this place other than the long line.

I will say this - the staff is super helpful. The seating is very limited, so they will time your order if you tell them that you are eating "in".  They make sure you have a table first, then they sit you down and THEN they bring your food.  They won't prepare the food until you have a spot to sit.  This means that you get hot food and a place to sit, but it also means that if you order your food for "dine-in" then you won't get your food until there is a spot to sit.  They are very good about monitoring the small dining area and making sure no one grabs your spot, however.  +1 star for the service.
author: Brent C.

description:
Went here for dinner and really loved it! I think it's hard to be creative / differentiated with Mexican food, and Papalote managed to be. It's a small place and I would not pick coming here for the ambiance / if you want an intimate setting. Also really difficult if you have a large group because it's so small, and usually pretty crowded. I got pretty lucky and got a table in under 10 minutes. 

Sat down after ordering food, and the waiter immediately came with chips and salsa. Chips were a bit stale, and while their salsa was good, I don't think it was as amazing as it's hyped up to be. Don't get me wrong - I did still really like it, just think it is as good as other salsas I've tried. 

The burritos are HUGE and super filling!! Portion size is great, and I thought the price was pretty good! I wasn't feeling adventurous enough to try the veggie burrito (has carrots, potatoes and mushroom), so I got the soyrizo burrito (rice and beans with soy chorizo) and made it a super (add guacamole, sour cream and cheese for just $0.99 more!) with a spinach tortilla. I'm not usually a fan of fake meat, but I loved the soyrizo!! Would get it again for sure. It's a little spicy, so difficult to eat with their salsa which also has a bit of a kick. I came with someone who got the same thing without the soyrizo, which was still really good but I like the soyrizo add-on more! The waiter was also really great; we didn't realize that water was self-serve (oops) and we asked him for water, and he still went to get it for us. 
One of my favorite burritos in the city for sure!
author: Pooja S.

description:
[Featured:  Throwdown with Bobby Flay, Food Network, http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gSciXC-jO8I]

Pop Quiz:  What SF burrito joint absolutely pwned Chef Bobby Flay in a salsa and burrito throwdown on national TV?  If you responded "Papalote" ... ding ding ding!

Seriously, as much as I like El Farolito (of which I am also a fan), Papalote will likely be in the mix for my go to spots for Mexican fare, even though I have mixed feelings.  As far as authenticity and value, Papalote is lacking, so I can see where others are coming from when they reduce Papalote as merely a fancy Chipotle, though I don't agree.  Also, Papalote's burritos are slightly smaller and pricier than its Mission counterparts.  

On the other hand.  It's hard to argue with the quality, especially the famed roasted tomato salsa. 

Overrated?  Nope, I don't think so.  Papalote's burrito and quesadilla were simply delicious, no exaggerated flavors.  In my view, Papalote deserves all the pub that comes with being named as SF Weekly's "best burrito" every year since 2007.  Now the Food Network has taken notice.

The carne asada burrito was off the chain, with tender beef and rich flavor and the burrito was not overly salted.  Plus it was just the right size that it wont leave you stuffed and bloated after the meal.

However, the highlight of my meal was the camarones quesadilla, which features shrimp sauteed in white wine and butter with delicious melted cheese...seriously, this is very very good stuff.  Add to that the flavor of the roasted peppers, with a dab of roasted tomato salsa and a bottle of coke on the side...I'd say that's a winning combo.

Unfortunately, the only damper was that the chips we got were too hard and they might have been a little stale.  It didn't matter too much in the end.  The roasted tomato salsa was so good that I could have dipped cardboard in it and I would have enjoyed the meal.

Thank you; Chef Escobedo.  I now have my sights set on the adobo buritto (off menu) and, maybe the triple threat.  Yet another reason to love the Mission District.
author: Angel S.

description:
I stopped by here before leaving for class because I was really curious about their Mexipino burrito.

Mexipino burrito is supposed to be a fusion of Mexican and Filipino food. Chicken adobo, garlic rice, and tomatoes in a burrito. I was very curious about this because I like that kind of food and I wanted to see if Papalote would be able to make it right.

The burrito itself was okay. The fillings were great. They made the chicken adobo really well and it was tasty with the garlic rice and everything (as it should be). I didn't see anything particularly dazzling about it though. You get exactly what you ordered. 

I found that eating it with their famous salsa made it taste way better. I regretted not asking for extra salsa. 

Overall, pretty good burrito. Make sure you eat it with the salsa!
author: Sofia R.

description:
The fish taco here is probably the best I've ever had.

maybe it's because they say they cook the fish in butter, but the flaky white fish is SO perfectly cooked, it just melts in your mouth.  My boyfriend and I ordered some other meat taco and it was also scrumptious, but paled in comparison to the fish.

Also, the SALSA here is the BOMB!!!  I almost bought a jar but I was scared I'd drink it on the way home.  It's so creamy that you think there's dairy in it, but it's just oil (no dairy!  so it might even be vegan..)

They could definitely charge boatloads more for their food.  Now I just need to find a way to sneak back on a taco gorge...
author: Kelsey H.

description: Overrated. The burrito was enjoyable, but I don't get the hype about the salsa. It wasn't bad, but not memorable in the slightest. Doesn't taste like much. Walk a block in any direction for a better burrito experience.
author: Kelly N.

description: EXCELLENT prawn burrito. The only reasons for 4 stars instead of 5 are long waits and tiny, stuffy dining area. The sidewalk is huge--it'd be awesome if they added outdoor seating.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Above solid meal to start our evening out... We stopped in for a quick bite last week and were completely satisfied....

Never been here before so we gave it a shot.

We ordered and in about ten minutes, two great meals showed up....

The burrito was tasty, flavorful, and hot... The tacos were really good.

Oh yeah, the salsa that came out with the chip was pretty addictive.

We will come back...
author: Joe B.

description: Amazing salsa. Get a jar of the homemade kind in the restaurant to take home - it's better than the grocery store kind! Naked burrito is my favorite!
author: Molly G.

description: Marinated tofu burrito was great. Salsa was phenomenal. Free chips were a nice touch.
author: Christian C.

description:
Well after the hype on tv.  I have to say I was very disappointed 
First the meat in my burrito was very very salty.  
As I watch on TV calling it the best burrito. I wonder who where the other burritos that were judged. Taco Bell, Del Taco and chipotle?  
Take your 23.00 and have real Mexican food.  
I should of read  the review from Jennifer B. 5 months ago.  

And the salsa had very little flavor.
author: Mike E.

description:
So, a classy burrito place is not an oxymoron! haha burritos here will set you a back a couple more bucks than your average mexican joint, but it is definitely delicious and worth it if you order right. That said, the chicken mole burrito was sensational. 
Chicken was tender to perfection, perfect blend of flavors in the mole sauce, and it was all wrapped and expertly melded together in such a way that every bite yielded ingredients in an appropriately proportional manner (i.e. you won't get a bite that's all rice/beans and no chicken). You don't even have to try! Get the guac! Get the cheese! 

The salsa that came with the chips (pretty sure it's free when you order, they just set it down on our table as we sat down after ordering) was unique and unlike any other salsa I've ever tasted. It looks and has the consistency of vodka sauce, but it is just the right amounts of creamy, spicy, tomato-y and tasty. amazing!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I'm a fan of any place that makes a great habanero sauce and Papalote fits the bill.  Their prices are a bit high but the quality of the food is well worth it.
