I always have reservations about eating Mexican food because I know what it's supposed to taste like and am tired of being disappointed or having to settle for good enough.  Papalote isn't one of those places; I ordered a chorizo burrito and coated it with their habanero sauce and had a grin that stretched from ear to ear. 

A party of 3 goes out to dinner at Papalote and leaves happy vowing to return the next time we're in SF.  If you're in SF I recommend you take advantage of the opportunity to be happy too.
author: Alberto O.

description:
Ahhhhhh!!! What's better than a jumbo burrito filled with the best flavored shrimps and black beans? Just the same one with a Pacifico beer.... of corse in this small delicious restaurant Mission's style. 

Perfect for eat there or snappy take away. You can of course order over the phone and pick up at the reserved counter. 

So much deliciousness in a tiny place. My preferred in the city. 

Short menu. Essential. Perfecto!!! Add an ever smiling lady at the counter and one of the very nice brother who own the place(s) and you might get to meet Bobby Flay for one of his food throw downs !!!
author: Gianguido G.

description: I came here for the first time and ordered the Triple Threat Burrito. It was HUGE and really tasty. We split it between three people, and were almost full, so I definitely would take at least one more person if you want to order this =).
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Oh, Papalote. We've had some good times together. Your tofu mole burrito is so hearty and delicious, but I'm afraid we must part ways for a little while. This isn't necessarily break-up, but I need a little break. I think we should see other people. 

The service is spot-on, but the execution of the food has been very hit or miss lately. 

Maybe one day our paths will cross again. That tofu mole burrito is the stuff dreams are made of. Your salsa is fabulous, as is the guacamole. Unfortunately, everything else that I've tried here just hasn't been that good. I didn't care for the soyrizo. Maybe you were just having an off day?

No hard feelings. I wish you nothing but the best in your future endeavors.
author: Brandi W.

description:
The prices are extremely high, the restaurant is a complete filthy dump and the food is just OK.  

On top of all that, there was a piece of glass in my food. I checked it with the person who I went with and we both agreed it was glass. The restaurant made me another portion after I complained, but then I noticed a cockroach crawling on the wall while I was thinking about the glass that had been in my food.

On top of that, later in the month I saw on my credit card statement the employees added an extra $4 charge that I hadn't authorized. 

Why so many people are clamoring to eat in a high priced, filthy, unsanitary, disgusting dump of a restaurant is beyond me.
author: Laurence S.

description: Pseudo-Mexican hipster "grill" where two beers and a guacamole dip cost over $25 with an extra $1 charged for more chips which were pretty stale in the first place. We were waiting for a friend to order more, but didn't bother and instead went down the road to La Santaneca on Mission with good, solid Salvadorean food at sensible prices. There are plenty of places within a stone's throw with better food, ambience and prices.
author: Joseph M.

description: Rip off. $12 for an order of shrimp tacos, take away. You get about 6 shrimp, slightly burned and some sad amount of salad. $6 per taco!!! Are you guys nuts?
author: James G.

description: One of my co-workers wanted to try this place after he heard they had the best burritos in town. Actually, Papalote Mexican Grill is known for its amazing super burritos. We arrived at 11:45am on a Friday and we had to wait about 10 minutes for our burritos. I had the Super Burrito and it was perfect!. The tortilla was toasted after it is made. It also had sour cream, guacamole and fresh cheese. It was the perfect amount of beans and other ingredients. Most burritos I have had before this one had rice, beans and a very small amount of chicken or beef. Papalote Mexican Grill's burrito was perfect and full of flavor.
author: Alicia R.

description:
After a two year break, I went back to Papalote and now I'm 0 for 3! 

I stopped by on impulse to get some guacamole to serve at a party I was hosting. According to the menu, a 4-oz serving was $3.75. I was shocked when they rang me up for $9.50! I pointed out the lower price on the menu, got some unintelligible rebuttal from the cashier, and decided not to fight it, since I was in a hurry.

For that price, the guac should've been amazing--but no; it was bland and completely unexceptional.

Back to avoiding Papalote.
author: Elinor A.

description: Haven't been here.
author: Matt L.

description:
First time here and maybe the food next time (never) will be better. Or maybe my standards for Mexican food have been set by the often amazing food available in Southern California. (Didn't mean for this to
turn into regional turf war, but this kind of mediocrity pisses me off.)

Don't get the pechuga en axiote, as the chicken is dry and what should be a complex blend of seasonings amounted to just salty and orange. 

The chicken was accompanied by rice that was also salty, dry and orange (oh, it's a theme!) This is the kind of rice one might get served on an airplane flying from Toledo (Ohio) to Salt Lake City.  Average beans.

My buddy ordered two burritos (he's an eater) and mid conversation, he said, "You know what? This food just isn't very good."

The guys who run the food to the tables were very nice.

This is also not a $ taqueria but a $$ restaurant that needs to better their food to make it worth their prices.
author: Ant C.

description: Best burrito I've had in the Bay Area. I got it with carne asada, refried beans, white rice, housemade salsa (bought an extra jar of the fresh-made stuff), sour cream, cheese. Just divine and cannot wait to return. I would take the BART into the City just for this burrito.
author: Sara R.

description:
Very hipsterish burrito. It's ok, but slightly overpriced compared to the nearby mission burritos...but not too bad. The orange sauce is okay as well..nothing too memorable. I like the rice that comes with it. I ordered no beans and the burrito came out looking a little flat.

They also have this weird door that makes you wanna "pull" but it says "push" on it. I was waiting outside and I saw a bunch of people pulling on the push door, including myself. Dohhhhhhhh....!!!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Most overrated burrito in town?
Their salsa is the best, and the service is great.
But the rice is mushy, the chile verde has a funky off taste and isn't particularly tangy or spicy. 
Come for the chips & salsa, but don't stay.
author: Lulu L.

description: The shrimp tacos were delicious but the fish tacos could have been better. The fish was a bit soggy. Other than that I enjoyed the complementary chips and salsa and horchata!
author: Aimee W.

description: Friendly service, casual atmosphere and very good food (and generous portions). Carne asada was well seasoned. Very good locally owned neighborhood place.
author: CS W.

description:
The vegan soyrizo burrito here is my absolute favorite! I crave it constantly and probably have it like 3x a week for dinner. The people who work there probably think I never cook (this is kind of true)

My favorite order is: soyrizo burrito with the black refried beans and add guacamole. 
My only frustration is that even though I always order and extra cup of salsa- because the salsa is AMAZING- they forget the 2nd salsa like 30% of the time- and I still get charged for it.  I also would love to have jalopenos in my burrito. They will add them if you ask- but they will seriously put like 50 in. I wish I could somehow convey I would just like a few : ) So now I just ask for them on the side or use my own at home : )

Yummiest burrito every. Expensive for a burrito- but definitely my favorite in SF.
author: Sky B.

description:
I love Papalote and always make sure to bring out-of-towners whenever friends come to visit.

The grilled prawn and lime tacos on soft corn tortillas, camarones (shrimp tacos cooked in butter and wine), chilaquiles and Papalote's incomparable salsa (I've gingerly transported jars of Papalote salsa, bubble wrapped for good measure, to the East Coast to distribute amongst lucky friends but nothing beats fresh salsa at the Mission location) are all killer. Add a strawberry agua fresca and I'm good to go.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
Great burritos!

This place is pretty delicious - and not TOO heavy! The "super" is a killer deal - cheese, guac and sour cream for just 99 cents - you can't go wrong! They also have burrito bowls to save on some carbs. 

Planning to make it my go to burrito spot.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
not a big burrito fan, coming here, i ordered the tacos. i shared two orders with a friend so we can each try different ones. 

prawn - not much prawn (maybe 3 in each taco?)  but the flavor on the prawn was all there. it didn't add much to the taco. can skip next time. 

fish - lots of fish in each taco and it adds to the taco when you take each bite. you don't have to search for where each piece of fish is cuz it's in your mouth every time you take a bite! will definitely order this again next time i am here! 

salsa - my friend comes here for salsa and make sure she gets extra. i can see why. the salsa is available for purchase by jar also. this salsa has enough kick in spiciness and it's more blended than chunks of tomatoes, etc. Maybe i'll buy a jar next time so i can enjoy it at home! 

Will definitely try other tacos next time around!
author: Kapo T.

description:
Really good, inventive burritos. I would not suggest coming here expecting a traditional mission-style burrito. This is more creative and expensive than your El Farolito or La Taqueria. You are also getting a different experience. 

I opted for the Mexipino Burrito-- adobo chicken, garlicky rice, and a tomato-ey pico salsa. There isn't any cheese or guacamole, but the burrito gets plenty of flavor from the adobo and garlic rice. The rice was really a nice changeup from your typical white or Mexican rice as it added a lot of flavor-- not just filler and texture. 

The spot is pretty trendy and attracts more of a hipster crowd but it is a cool spot. The service is slow but this is mainly due to the demand and also the care they take in putting everything together.
author: Neal C.

description: Overrated IMO. Salsa is as good as everyone claims, but everything else is just ok.
author: John V.

description:
Maybe they're losing their touch? Went in today and ordered a salad with the tofu mole. As a vegetarian, I get excited for veg mole dishes! Well...I got mole, all right. I really should've taken a picture, but suffice to say my salad was absolutely soupy with the sauce. I had to ask for another bowl to fish out the salad, which was of course still drenched. I could have drank the mole left in the old bowl. But I didn't. Because it wasn't particularly flavorful, unfortunately.

Of course the cashier knew why I'd asked for the new bowl, but I figured I'd just say something after. I ate it because I didn't want to waste, but I thought it would be worth letting them know that someone had a bit of a heavy sauce hand. All I got was kickback, even as I pointed to my bowl of mole soup that the busser walked by with. First, I was told what it was. Like telling me it's mole explains the mess. Then it was that nobody else had a problem with it. Like it might not have been an accident/new guy dumping the sauce on? Like they'd pour that much sauce in a burrito-??!!

I hate crappy service even more than I hate bland mole soup.
author: Jessica F.

description: I will agree the salsa is the best. My chicken tacos consisted of lettuce and dry  grilled chicken. I ate it but it was boring and I will not go back for tacos, that is for sure.
author: J A.

description: Tip: you can call, place an order and pick it up. That ways, you can save time since this place is very busy and popular.
author: Tejal D.

description:
Beyond being an incredibly fun name to say,* the fine folks at Papalote are churning out tasty fare that may not be 100% authentic but it's mighty tasty to gringo tongues throughout the Bay area. I ate my burrito whilst sitting on a couch and drinking wine. No, that's not their set up (although, it's a winning idea; give me some commission on it), I ate from (my friends' home). Take out is the way to avoid the crazy lines and unwashed masses.

You'll also need time to prepare for the order because there are many options available to you: meat, super or not, type of tortilla, beans... this ain't your average slop-it-together-burrito joint. As for me: chicken (the mole version is very nicely seasoned; oftentimes the meat of a burrito is an afterthought. Not here), of course, super (cheese and double guac, hold the sour cream), spinach tortilla, and refried black beans. First off, the burrito (super!) was huge. It took all my fatty power and a lot of time to finish it. Come here hungry. Secondly, it's all about the guac. Like I mentioned earlier, the meat tasted great alone but pair it up with that guacamole? Goodness gracious. Delicious. I could have eaten that guac with a spoon... and I did because we ordered sides of guac, chips and salsa. All were magically delicious. My spinach tortilla wasn't as pronounced in flavor as I expected/hoped for, but there was so much going on on my plate that it wasn't that big of a deal. In a city that hypes its burrito prowess, Papalote is legit. I'd, gladly, come here again. I just made myself hungry writing this review.

*You just said it, didn't you?
author: Johnny T.

description:
Charging for salsa?!? Are you kidding me?

The food is decent, but the prices are probably 50% more than what they should be. And charging for salsa is pretty ridiculous. there are plenty of other places that are just as good and charge half as much.
author: Mike S.

description: WHAT!?!?! No carnitas?!?!?!? And you call yourself a Mexican restaurant?!?! Sorry, but even Chipotle is better than this place... and I don't think very highly of Chipotle either. Just saying....
author: Stephen Y.

description: Triple threat is one of the best burritos I've had in a long time! It sounds silly to spend 20 bucks on a burrito but it was worth it! Their special sauce is lethal!!! My only complaint is that it took a while for them to make my burrito. Other than that, I am dying to come back!
author: Michelle L.

description: I really wanted to love this place but was disappointed.  Personally, I think this place is overhyped.  I'm a carnitas fan, which is not an option here.  What kind of taqueria doesn't have carnitas?  Anyway, after reading yelp reviews I ordered the chicken mole burrito.  The chicken was in huge hunks, rather than being properly shredded, and was BONE DRY.  We're talking difficult to chew dry.  The mole was bland.  The chips were stale.  All of that said, the salsa was delicious.  I think from now on I'll limit my purchases to the jars of salsa they sell at the cash register.
author: Becca F.

description:
Papalote is known for their amazing orange salsa! I'd like to confirm that the amazing orange salsa is truly amazing. It's savory, flavorful, and has a spicy kick to it! They sell their sauce in packaged jars, I will probably pick up a bottle during my next visit

Every order comes with complimentary tortilla chips and the yummy salsa.

I usually order the super burrito with chicken and it's always more food than I could handle. The super burrito comes with sour cream, cheese, and guacamole in addition to the regular burrito filling (meat, rice, beans). And it usually comes with a small side of radish salad. My bf orders 2 chicken tacos and that comes with heaps of lettuce and fresh tomatoes. I'll be sure to order tacos the next time I visit - it looked fresh and delicious!

The restaurant is quite small and has limited seating, but it is overall clean and welcoming. 

Papalote is located in the Mission District and is just 1 block away from the 24th St and Mission St BART station. 

Papalote's delicious orange salsa is reason enough to give this place a try. It's soo gooood... YOU NEED TO TRY THE SALSA!
author: Monica T.

description: Love this place for so many reasons. But ultimately it's consistency that keeps me and my brothers as repeat customers! Sometimes there is a line out the door but always worth the wait. Zero bad experiences!
author: Nicolas J.

description:
This review is for the service.  Awful, unfriendly, and rude.  We walked in and the staff did not say hello they just stared at us.  We ordered some guacamole and chips along with 2 beers.

Beers were nowhere near cold.  Quac was just ok.

Not going back really disappointing
author: Graham T.

description: We ordered a few burritos and nachos and everything was as promised. Good, hearty, and just the right nasty. Sometimes you want a little good nasty food. Nothing fancy, just what you would expect and want from an authentic burrito joint. The refried beans were surprisingly good!
author: Danny C.

description:
Really good carne asada. The horchata wasn't bad either. 

I got the carne asada tacos, which was two tacos with carne asada, salsa, and lettuce. Really simple but great-tasting. My order also came with complimentary chips. 

Kind of a small spot, but I was able to find a small table to sit at. Service was ok.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I honestly did not have a welcoming experience here. My boyfriend I were planning on meeting a friend here and were wanting to sit while we waited. The sign said "wait to be seated." We waited awkwardly for a while and finally asked some one. She said we had to order food before sitting down. We mentioned we were waiting for a friend and if she minded if we sat and waited for him. She said no. Strike one. 
We ordered an appetizer while we waited. It was a huge amount of chorizo queso but they only gave us three tiny corn tortillas. Strike two. 
I asked my boy friend to see if we can give us some chips to eat the rest if the queso. They charged us for them. Strike three. We left after we finished our food. 
The sad part was the food was AMAZING! But service is everything for me.
author: Danielle W.

description:
My experience at this place was so ridiculously annoying it's really comedic. The food is standard Mission Mexican hole in the wall fare, nothing amazing. The one star is for the complete lack of listening skills. I mean like talking to a wall, literally.

My wife and I were craving just a few plain ole bean and cheese burritos...nothing else. No rice, no meat, no fixins, just BEANS AND CHEESE. Mine with refried black, hers with pinto (per their choices). Easy, right? Wrong. Super wrong. We get our order, excited and hungry, go home and what do I find? Rice. Everywhere. Awesome.

My wife was too hungry to care so ate away, but I was annoyed so I called back and they graciously agreed to make me another. So I biked back there, get my order and come home and guess what...RICE AGAIN! And the wrong kind of beans. And this time after I explicitly explained JUST refried black BEANS AND CHEESE. I even watched her write it down. So, I called back AGAIN and what does the woman on the other end say? She repeats back "Oh, sorry, so you wanted rice, beans, and cheese??" I almost lost it. I said NO, just beans and cheese. I then just asked for a refund instead for the overpriced burritos I didn't even order. Hopefully that actually happens, but knowing what had just transpired, I'm not holding my breath.
author: A S.

description:
Five stars for the salsa, three stars for the burritos. My wife likes Papalote because the ingredients seem "fresher" than other taquerias, but I think that's actually what detracts a little from their flavor... they seem kind of bland to me. Not enough commingling of juices and so on, or something like that.

Love the variety of options for "meats" (e.g., soyrizo) and beans (very few places offer refried black beans), and the salsa really is to die for. They used to sell it fresh out of the refrigerator, and we used to take a jar home after every visit. Now they're selling it in a labeled, shelf-stable jar, and it's just not as good (must be preservatives or something). The stuff they serve with your dine-in order is the good (fresh) stuff.
author: Andrew M.

description: Very filling and tasty! Definitely one of the best burritos ive had. The jalapenos are great and nachos are fresh. If your in the mission, this is a must try!
author: Jeff G.

description:
The best Mexican in SF. I don't know why La Taquiera gets so much buzz. This place is so much better. 

I don't know what's in their "special sauce" but I literally want to put it on everything I eat from now on. 

I don't have "recommendations" because everything you order is good. I usually go with a super steak burrito or a shrimp quesadilla though WITH EXTRA SAUCE.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I saw this place on TV and decided to give it a try. Not gonna lie, the place itself was not the cleanest and there was not enough room to move around. I definitely felt a bit claustrophobic when it got full. 
The chips and salsa they serve prior to bringing your food were not that great. The chips were very hard (almost stale) so I just assume that they don't make their own chips but take them out of a bag. 
The food was really good, though. That's why I'm giving this place 4 stars despite the ambience. I had a veggie burrito and my boyfriend had carne asada nachos. We ate everything lol
author: Mihaela P.

description:
I will state this for the official record: this is far and away, hand down, no questions asked, the best burrito I have ever had.  It is also far and away, hands down, no questions asked the best salsa I have ever had in my life. I ordered two jars of the salsa online the moment I got home. Sprint, do not run, you dare not walk, sprint straight to Papalote if you are anywhere within a 100 mile area of San Francisco.  Mind-blowing! Epic! Epically mind-blowing!

The scary thing is that people of San Francisco will claim better burritos...which obviously peaks my interest...and my appetite
author: Albert M.

description:
GREAT FOOD AND YUMMY BURRITOS 

BUT HOLY CRAP THE HABANERO RED LABEL SALSA IS SPICY! 

I occasionally buy a bottle of this salsa at Whole Foods and it gets my every time! I must be a complete masochist because it burns my tongue, mouth and stomach every time and yet I go back for more! 

The flavors are so complex and good that despite the burn, I love it. 

Try the restaurant and try the salsas. You won't be disappointed. However, not for the faint of heart. If you are weakling when it comes to spice, get a chicken burrito and stick to the basic salsa they serve and you'll be fine.
author: Alanna R.

description:
Good, but I prefer other spots nearby. 

That salsa is great, you can buy it at Safeway now.
author: max m.

description:
I ordered two tacos to go, and instead of putting the tacos in separate sheets of tin foil sheets, or putting them side to side, they gave me a taco-sandwich with two pieces of tortilla as bread.  Kind of weird.

In any case, it was fine.  Not the best tacos, nor the cheapest, but it gets the job done.  And it comes with chips.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I come to Papalote's every single time I am in the Bay Area. It is the best burrito I have ever had!! Plan to come here before you head back home because you'll have leftovers you'll want to keep!
author: Nat N.

description: Great veggie burrito. Call ahead to pick up your order. So yummy and they have multiple options for vegans. Staff is awesome as well!
author: Madelyn T.

description: After an 8 year gap, we wandered back here today. Nice people, great burrito, cold beer, and value for money. YUMMY
author: Chris M.

description: Lunch today: Regular nachos, chile verde tacos, steak burrito, two diet cokes, free chips and their signature roasted chili salsa, $36. Two people. I took one taco home- a lot of food. My son raved about the food and he is picky. I liked that the pork in my chile verde was tender and NO GRISTLE. Hate gristle. Also really like the heat on the chile verde. Their roasted chile salsa is yummy, too. So, yes, go and enjoy!
author: Carol E.

description:
Burritos are good, but absolutely outrageous price for the "prawn" tacos. You get two for $9.25 but they won't even make it a block to my apartment. Tortilla gets completely soggy and falls apart (hint: in L.A., they put two or three tortillas on to-go tacos so they hold their shape.) Yeah, I'm a San Francisco native, but I know about good tacos. 
The kicker? FOUR EFFING "PRAWNS". TOTAL. Yes, two per taco. I dug and dug beneath mountains of lettuce. FOUR PRAWNS. Absurd.

I'm so angry I'm not ever going back, and I used to eat there 2-3 times a week.
author: Anna B.

description:
This is the first place I experienced eating my first burrito!! LOL I've heard so many people rave about the Adobo Burrito, I decided I have to try it out. I ended up loving the burrito!! People may think that adobo is saucy and may drip, but not this one. It is very filling and has a kick to it! 

I've also tried the Triple Threat burrito! The chicken is so tender!! I'm pretty sure everyone watched the challenge between Bobby Flay VS PAPALOTE, so that's enough said! The salsa dip to the chips is great!!
author: Kathy V.

description:
Solid burrito.
Brick...house.
Fresh.
Proper.
7/10 beef.
Niice salsa.
Niiice if they fry burrito in butter...
author: Burger B.

description: I met up with some friends here for dinner after work. It's small and cozy and based on the crowd that was there, very popular unbeknownst to me. I got a naked burrito (burrito bowl) and was expecting something similar to Chipotle's bowl in size, but what I got was a giant bowl filled with so much good stuff. I got the basics (no rice or beans), but it was really good and I was very pleased with the value. My two friends got burritos that were equally as giant and they seemed pretty pleased. I'd definitely recommend this place if you're looking for a spot in the Mission to grab some mexican food.
author: Candace R.

description:
Much respect to Team Papalote who represented SF well and handed Iron Chef Bobby Flay his ass on Food Network's "Throwdown - Burrito edition." 

I came here for lunch with some coworkers. The semi-long line moves fairly quickly, you place your order, take a seat, a person brings you chips with their signature orange salsa, and then your order. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jwb3vTh8rn3OsN9wlI56-Q?select=mhg77Sztnk2avL-lcA-sxg) 

Here's the breakdown for the champion "Triple Threat Burrito". 

- It's made to order since it took about 20 minutes to come out.
- 3 different types of meat, 
          - 4 grilled prawns - very juicy. 
          - marinated and grilled, white meat chicken - juicy 
          - carne asada - solid
- you get an extra side of their signature orange salsa
- it comes with this jicama? slaw
- you choose what type of beans you want (black, refried)
- then the kicker, it's $20 and it's the same size of a regular super burrito. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jwb3vTh8rn3OsN9wlI56-Q?select=eKBq5WSoQVZabdWyZf25qQ)

I did a doubletake on the $20 price tag but, it is, what it is and halved it with a coworker. This is what food history tastes like.

Overall, it's good, probably a 3 star burrito with 1 star value but I'll give them 4 stars because Bobby Flay is an arrogant SOB. Oh yeah, Iron Chef Flay always loses ethnic eats. 

Are you ready for a throwdown?
author: Earl G.

description: Toasted tomato salsa is worth the trip alone! Chicken was grilled to perfection, super juicy and not over cooked. Highly recommended
author: Chris K.

description:
SO I am going to say that this seemed to me to be a very eel put together and healthy tasting burrito. Not greasy, very fresh, great options. I had the carne asada burrito with whole black beans, and I appreciate their  mission of providing healthier burritos. 
That being said, I am a fan of the very large, unhealthy greasy burritos and so I am very biased.
Their location is awesome, and their dining room is lively and communal which is cool. Their was a pretty long wait for my food so as I wasn't really happy to stand there and wait 10 minutes, I know its because they ere cooking up or order fresh, so it was. 
I would for sure recommend to call in your order ahead of time if you want to get in and out quickly.
author: Jack W.

description: This restaurant is really good for its price. We had five dishes and all are pretty authentic. The plates are so big that we couldn't finish any one of them haha. The restaurant is very authentic and fills up really fast, I'd recommend people go in early and try them out!
author: Suzanna Z.

description:
I saw this place listed on 7X7 magazien's as being the # 1 burritio place winner a few years back and never really attempted to try it until I was doing a pet sit in the area last week. 

My husband was with me and we're both fans of thier salsa, which we buy at Whole Foods. Sadly, the two burritios we split (chicken and steak) where a bit underwhelming and just didn't have the flavor we were hoping it would. I mean, the steak one was still decent but it wasn't "wow" or "amazing" in anyway to me, not to mention a bit over priced for a burrito in the Mission. I think I still prefer El Farolito and so does my husband. 

I think we'll just stick with buying thier salsa but perhaps you might like them so do give them at least one try.
author: Petra S.

description:
*I would actually rate this place 3.5 stars if I could, but since I can't, I'm going to have to round down in this instance*

So, I've been wanting to try this place since it was featured and won on a Throwdown with Bobby Flay episode years ago... Then, I wanted to try it even more when I read an article recently that named this place the Best Burrito in America.... I can't tell you the excitement I had inside- it was overwhelming.

Of course, the place was packed inside. It's a very small, cozy place with only a few tables... The seating is somewhat communal style, where you may or may not have to share the same table with other parties... It has a cool, vibe to it- fits right in in the Mission neighborhood.

You order at the front counter and then are asked to wait outside until they are able to seat your party. 

Obviously I ordered the $19.95 Triple Threat Burrito (Don't worry- I shared this with one other person) as that's the very burrito that beat out Bobby Flay and was mentioned in the article... P.s. It's an extra $0.99 for guacamole ... Why wouldn't a $20 burrito already have guacamole in it? (That extra $0.99 is actually for cheese, sour cream and guacamole but I don't eat cheese or sour cream) 

Once seated, they will bring you chips and salsa (it more looks like a slightly thick, smooth orangey sauce)... The chips are mediocre, but the salsa is really unique tasting and really yummy! 

The burrito was served very shortly after. It's huge! Thank goodness we decided to share.  So the burrito was really good... Really, really good... Probably the best meat I've ever had in a burrito- the pieces of steak and chicken are lean and big and juicy and flavorful; very different from many Mexican food places where the meat is always greasy, minced to an oblivion and full of weird, chewy and fatty bites where you aren't quite sure what you just put in your mouth (icky)... The shrimp is grilled to perfection and also bursting with flavor... All the meats are cooked to order and you really could taste the freshness in the cooking- it keeps you excited for each and every bite that you take.

Overall, I really enjoyed my meal... The high quality of the meat is definitely the highlight of this place.... But to me, they really need to improve their chip recipe and the fact that this place isn't what you would consider to be typical "Mexican taqueria style" food threw me off a little from what I was expecting... Also, in my opinion, America's best burrito is definitely not going to have black beans inside it. 

Okay, so maybe it's not the best burrito in my book, but I would say this place is definitely worth a try if you're in the area. 

Note: This place has tons of vegetarian options which was really cool to me.
author: Gaby C.

description: $20 burrito so overrated. Man gave this place a chance a few years back, and honestly I can say that I have stayed away. The only thing good about this place were the chips and orange dip =). Their frescas were not that bad. But what was bad though was the triple threat. Not only did it threaten my pockets it threatened my tastebuds. The meat in the burrito was close to burnt, dry, and skimped. BOOM 3rd threat. There are other spots in the city for way better prices and actually taste good and not overcooked. Thanks for kicking Bobby Flay's butt in the throwdown, but now I feel like my butt's getting kicked for even getting suckered into the hype.
author: Mary Ann B.

description: Good space, pretty meh food. Got a breakfast burrito with steak, after two bites the whole thing fell apart. The eggs were soggy and the meat portion was super stingy. The eating space was small, but functional. The bathroom was completely destroyed with nonsensical graffiti.
author: Sean C.

description: Excellent location, very close to BART station. Large portions. Good tasting. Big enough dining area. Very affordable.
author: Ronald P.

description: This more than met my craving for an authentic California Burritto. I went with the carne asada super burrito in the spinach tortilla. Despite its size I finished the entire burrito because it was that delicious.
author: William C.

description:
Tastes alright. Really pricy for what me and my 7 other latino friends consider and rate as a "mediocre burrito". Just see who is sitting at the tables. Latinos? Nope.

Extremely limited meats for a mexican food place. look at the menu, the only worthwhile item is the Triple Threata burrito of steak, chicken adobo, and shrimp, for $20! Which is only missing their vegan items to be the whole menu. Bobby Flay should just stick to barbeques. Oh Papalote made a better burrito than Boby Flay on Throwdown? Have you seen the show? He never wins.

The jicama sample-size salad is ridiculous. The stale table chips a joke. The only thing ok is the salsa they sell and offer with the chips. Also the mexican coke and 7up.

Regardless, I wish this little restaurant well, I wont be coming back. But I hope they prosper in their own way.
author: Leo M.

description: Best salsa I've ever had! I ordered nachos - mushy black beans in gravy, and lots of cheese. Very tasty. Definitely coming back here another time.
author: Sandeep R.

description: I got the veggie burrito, which was tasty, but damn those hunks of carrot and potatoes are big! Pour a little of the heavenly red sauce on before each burrito bite and you can't go wrong. Yum!
author: Kendra B.

description:
I've been coming here for years and years and years and it's the best vegetarian burrito in the Bay Area. I'm certain of it. The mole is incredible. 

The space/ambiance leaves something to be desired... And I don't mean being fancy. The layout of the long tables just isn't all that great. 

What makes Papalote so exceptional, though, is its salsa. We buy it by the jar. I eat it with a spoon. This is why I'll always come back.
author: Lucy B.

description:
Our go to place for good mexican food.  We usually end up there at least a few times a month.  I love getting either the chicken burrito or the chicken tacos.  Food is always fresh and very good tasting.

Love the salsa and it is nice you can buy a jar of fresh salsa there.  The jarred stuff in the stores doesn't taste quite the same to me.

Also, they are convenient to pick-up from;  I recommend calling your order in so you don't have to wait because they can get quite busy at peak times.
author: Jax B.

description:
LATIN-AMERICAN FOOD CRAWL IN THE MISSION: Creamy salsa


Update: Came back here for dinner and have to say that garlic rice-chicken burrito special they have is the stuff of dreams. Pure deliciousness served in a way-too-big portion. Mmmm!

...............................................

We stopped by here only to try the famous "creamy" salsa, which Papalote thankfully sells in a nice little container with plenty of homemade chips for under $2. I know it's hip to hate on the popular thing, but I loved the salsa (guess this is why I can never be a hipster). It had a delicious tomato base reminiscent of tomato sauce, but with lots of thick, rich creaminess mixed in. The usual flavors of cilantro and onions were missing, but I hardly noticed. If marinara sauce and alfredo sauce ever had a baby and added garlic to it, I imagine this is what it would taste like.
author: Josephine L.

description: Hmmm,$48 for two steak tacos, two shrimp tacos, a steak burrito, and a couple of sodas. The place should really be listed as $$ or $$$ ...
author: Colleen M.

description:
Fact: Being a transplant from SoCal, I am a burrito snob. 
Fact: Since moving to SF, I've lived in the Mission and visited a plethora of burrito joints. 
Debatable fact: Yes, this place is good and has a lot of options for veggies. Is it the best in The Mission? Nope. The salsa is worth a trip but the burritos are meh. I prefer El Metate over Papalote and Taqueria Cancun over El Metate.
author: Katey W.

description:
Came here based on the '4 star rating' yelp reviews and I absolutely do not get it. 

Spent $30 dollars for 2 orders of tacos, one diet coke and one corona, for a taqueria is outrageous!!!!!!  an order of tacos should be $3.00 each! 

Flavors were bland, and tacos immediately fell apart on serving. 

Will not be back.
author: Best M.

description:
The Carne Asada and the Mexipino Burritos are 2 really good Burritos here. I can't explain on how good both are. The Mexipino combines a Filipino twist with a Mexican taste. TRY IT!! Also Try the Salsa!!! Too Good!!!!

As for the Carne Asada, I have had alot of Carne Asada burritos in my time and this place is on the top of my list. The meat wasn't dry or tough to eat. It was perfect. Somewhat tender yet still kept all the flavors. 

The place is pretty small, so good luck if you want to eat there. Really tight spaces so if you're claustrophobic of any means, than I would suggest taking your food to go and take a stroll to Dolores Park and eat there.

Parking isn't a problem too much, I would first look residential first then meter.
author: Aryan O.

description:
Let's get this out of the way. I've spent the majority of my life in Southern California, where we all know there is an overabundance of fantastic Mexican food. Yes, I'm sometimes snobby about it. That works in your favor, because I'll help you avoid eating at places like Papalote.

Let's start with the food, of course. It sucked. My girlfriend and I shared the carne asada plate. Let's talk for a moment about carne asada. Typically, but not always, made from skirt steak, prized for it's flavor, not it's tenderness. It's for this reason that they usually marinate the shit out of it to break it down a bit prior to searing it to impart some additional flavorful goodness and then cutting it across the grain to make it easy to eat. Did that make you hungry? Well then don't go to Papalote. The carne asada at this place is devoid of all of the qualities I've just described.

And I suppose I shouldn't have been surprised that all of the accompanying sides (with the exception of the refried black beans; those were surprisingly tasty) were mediocre at best. The worst thing you can ever say about Mexican food is that it tastes bland. And this was soul-suckingly bland trash, served piping hot to people who don't know any better. As of this writing, Papalote has 4 stars on Yelp... I'm actually angry.

To add insult to injury, this plate of junk cost 16 bucks, plus 3-something for a side of guac... So just over 21 bucks with tax for ONE plate of food... Fuck. That.
author: Brad T.

description:
$10 for a chicken burrito!  

I remember when this used to cost $6, so now feel like the owners are gouging their customers because of their current fame.

Also this place is 40% to 50% more expensive than other tacquerias 2 blocks away..

3.5 stars for the Burrito
Minus 1 star for jacking up their prices by 40%
Minus .5 stars for losing the original feel of a once great place. 

This Place is now for tourists and the Guy Fieri Food Network Types...
-------------------
2 Stars total
author: Zk K.

description: I have been disappointed the last 3-4 times.  The prices have gone up, the quality has gone down, and the size has gotten smaller.  Way too much money to pay for inconsistency - you don't know if you are going to get a burrito too salty or too small, or both.  The last burrito I bought hardly had any filling; it was mostly tortilla, and the filling that was there was not very flavorful. I will be looking for another neighborhood Mexican place.
author: Jessica W.

description: This place is the bomb. such good burritos. get the carne asada super burrito with a  whole wheat tortilla and you'll never regret it. super fast take out service, standard speed sit down service, frenziedly people and friendly atmosphere. i recommend this place to all incoming visitors and friends.
author: Kyle H.

description: (4.5) Came for a mole burrito, stayed for the salsa. By far my favorite salsa in the Mission.
author: Irina P.

description:
Cute little place with good food. My boyfriend and I aren't locals so we were surprised at how packed everywhere in the Mission was on a Wednesday night. There was a line spilling onto the street when we first passed by so we looked for another place we heard about. That place was also full so we walked back up to Papalote and the line was basically gone. We got a table right away and ordered marinated tofu tacos for me and mole chicken burrito for him.

I liked my tacos even though they fell apart. The marinade was tasty so I definitely recommend anything with that but I think I would have enjoyed a burrito a little more. My boyfriend destroyed his burrito in no time, so I take it that it was delicious too. The salsa was awesome and I wish we bought some jars of it but we rushed out of there when another long line formed. I'm kind of sad that I'm back home already, cause I really would have liked to have tried their other stuff, as they are very vegetarian friendly and had more interesting flavors, unlike most Mexican places near me.
author: Q D.

description: I'm giving two stars because the food is delicious but the service SUCKS. I called to make a pickup order, was asked to wait, got hung up on, and called back. When the woman who answered said, Can I put you on hold?, I stated that I got hung up on while on hold earlier. The phone clicked, and I thought I'd been hung up on again. But a few second later, the same person came back on the line and took my order. I know they're busy and probably stressed but geez.
author: Seghel Y.

description: Bummer. I ordered a burrito and beverage - $15-16. Ouch. I come home cradling my precious burrito and was so sad when I could barely eat it. The carne asada was so salty and cut into these large unappetizing chunks. The thing was overloaded in rice and barely any of the add-ons were detectable. It really needed the sour cream to neutralize the crazy amount of salt. I'll continue to buy the salsa because it's amazing but I'll get my burrito fix elsewhere. PS - cut back on the salt!
author: Kari F.

description:
DAT SAUCE!!!


A hip mission spot featuring ok food, and excellent EXCELLENT SALSA. The ingredients in my fish tacos seemed fresh and were delicious, the chips were - within acceptable parameters of crunchiness, thiness, and tastiness - but like myself and seemingly everyone else has already said - this place is all about the salsa.
author: Oleg H.

description: Food is only one part of the equation for success for a restaurant. Customer service is a necessity for any business. Consistency is another factor. Perhaps some places consider restaurant name/reputation to exceed the value of customers. Well, that is not the case. If in San Francisco spend your money in a place where you (and your family) will consistently be treated respectfully.
author: Antoine T.

description:
Another 3.5 rating - went for the 4 stars as the salsa deserves that extra 1/2 star.

- "Americanized" Mexican food (imo)
- Tastes good, but not authentic
- Salsa is unique, love that they give you chips/salsa with your order - worth trying this place for this only
- Pollo asado, carne asada are both "good", not amazing or authentic tasting
- I've only done takeout so never had to wait
author: Melody T.

description:
Supposedly the best burrito in San Francisco.  

I wouldn't necessarily say that.  It was good, and definitely gets props for vegan options (soyrizo, tofu as protein options).  They also have pretty comprehensive choices (whole wheat tortillas, mushrooms, black, pinto, or refried black beans).  The house made roasted tomato salsa was sorta special too.

I'd come here again if I was in the mood for burritos and in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here if chipotle was nearby.

UPDATE: Came here a second time.  Get Achiote Marinated Tofu, grilled vegetables(carrots, potatoes, mushrooms), and guacamole in a burrito.  Much better than the vegan soyrizo combo I got the first time.  It was a very satisfying burrito, better than chipotle.  I've come here like 15+ times over the past year.  Updated to 5 star.
author: Matt T.

description: Filipino friend said the Mexipino burrito was satisfying. Love that they griddle the tortilla, not just steam it. I loved my meaty nachos -- loads of food, crispy chips, generous on the meat side. Crowded, but quick turnover.
author: Nini M.

description: I'd say a solid 3.5 stars. The service was good (order at register, pay and have the food brought out to you). The food was solid, but nothing special. Overall, I'd say decent value with good service and decent food.
author: Sau y.

description: Had the nachos and a couple tacos. Food was great, salsa was amazing. The most important thing is the beer was ice cold!!
author: Nick W.

description: Big fan of the Mexipino burrito -- the garlic friend rice really ties the burrito together. And obviously, who's not a fan of the salsa?! Ask for a jar of the fresh salsa to take home.
author: Tyler D.

description:
Really great burritos! 
I'll settle for other taquerias if I can't get to Papalote but this place is the only burritos I really CRAVE. Great nice staff. I usually get my food to go because it is usually crowded seating area and hard to find a table. 

Their salsa is also amazing.
author: Kieran B.

description:
Delicious Authentic Mexican Burrito. 

My girlfriend and I visited this nice cozy place, and really enjoyed the Carne Asada Burrito.  The salsa has nice spice and tastes excellent.  

The prices are a bit on the higher end, but other than that it was an awesome place to grab delicious food.
author: A.J. T.

description:
Quick qualification, full disclosure: I worked the Food Network/Bobby Flay "Throwdown" production gig that featured the Triple Threat Burrito.

My rating really is closer to a 4.9 star rating buuuuut I still can't quite get passed the $20 price tag on the Triple Threat burrito, which happens to be my favorite thing here... that and their secret sauce salsa of course.

I, like a few others, without a doubt suggest you order 1 Triple Threat and split it with someone. It's large and awesome. It's always cooked just right and you really can taste each distinctive type of meat (carne asada, chicken, shrimp) inside the burrito... while they all somehow taste well together. Everything seems to be in just right the place.

I also usually order a quesadilla or something like that and spilt it with my fellow grubber.

P.S.- Totally nice staff, including the bros/owners that were featured on Bobby Flay's show.
author: Chris P.

description: This place is alright. It's not a true taqueria. It's more of a nice mexican place. It's a bit pricey to me for mission mexican food, but it is a bit nicer than most places. I wouldn't come back here as I prefer a real taqueria. This is like a nicer place that perhaps I could compare to a Rubios?
author: Julie L.

description: Suprisingly good veggie burrito here. I got the standard veggie one, with potatoes, carrots, and mushrooms. I love mushrooms and have never seen them in a burrito so I got this one. I'm often skeptical of potatoes in a burrito, but these were fresh cut, as were the carrots, and large chunks full of flavor. I love that you can pick what kind of rice, beans and wrap that you want. The papalote's salsa is amazing! I upgraded to get cheese/sour cream/guac and it was the perfect combo. Comes with a small bowl of chips and salsa on side.  I would definitely come back here next time I am in the Mission. Also, not at all crowded at 3pm on a Monday! Seems reasonably priced for what you are getting (granted bc it's SF, when you add tax tip and a beer the prices get high).
author: Kristi P.

description: This place has delicious Mexican food and they're known for their salsa which they also sell in stores ,its that good! I had the steak burrito and it was one of the best I've had in the mission. Nice little location with very friendly staff.
author: Nicholas F.

description:
I know what you're thinking...Come on, Joe.  Papalote was so last year.  Nah, man.  It's still hella good.  I hadn't been here since all the hype last year made the lines insanely long.  But I came here yesterday with my coworker around 1pm and the line was practically non-existent.  I remember that I really liked the carne asada burrito last year more than the chicken adobo burrito.  But my coworker said he really liked the adobo one better.  So my wily side came out and I convinced him to half his adobo burrito with me and I'll half my carne asada with him.  The best of both worlds!

I started my meal off with their nachos and signature salsa.  The spiciness of the salsa has a nice little kick to it that makes your mouth say, "Feed me another....and another.....one more......aw hell, just keep going."  I balanced it out with their freshly squeezed cantaloupe drink.  I frikkin' love freshly squeezed cantaloupe drinks! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jwb3vTh8rn3OsN9wlI56-Q?select=Tk-JVGQ-oTYVcHBMxuxG5Q)

The chicken adobo burrito came out first.  I remember the last time I had it, it was kinda dry.  That wasn't the case this time.  It was actually pretty juicy.  The adobo flavor is definitely not the typical Filipino adobo flavor.  There's something different about it.  Maybe a Mexican touch?  I'm no chef so I can't really say what it is.  Either way, it still tastes good.  I'd get it again.  On a side note, my coworker ordered it with no beans and I think this was a genius decision.  I think beans would have messed up the harmony of the burrito overall. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/jwb3vTh8rn3OsN9wlI56-Q?select=F-QEBmUZwDW3MJ-y1suNvg)

The carne asada was just like I remembered it.  Juicy and tasty all around.  You can really taste the grill flavor in the meat.  It was actually a little more saltier than before, but I'm going to overlook that cuz I still enjoyed it.  Overall, I was thoroughly full.  Afterwards, I felt like my stomach was bulging and wished I could lay down and take a fat-ass nap.  I think there must be a school close by because the younger gen started to filter in as we were finishing our meal.  And that meant it was time to go back to work.
author: Joe M.

description:
Woah! This place just replaced el Farolito as my go-to burrito place!

FYI they sell their amazing sauces and take phone orders.
author: Jenny W.

description:
So sorry I doubted you! Papalote is delicious! The salsa is yummy (could use some extra spice though) and the Mexipino burrito is damn good!! The only thing I would recommend is mixing more ingredients so I don't get full off of the first 4 bites of just rice =/ 

Loveee that they play DJ MR.E's mixes in the shop, such a great soundtrack to grub on!
author: Alyssa O.

description: Did takeout since there is no parking at all around this one!! I had prawn burrito and guacamole. They forgot my guac & wasn't easy to fix with the cashier when I had to come back (after driving away). A male employee came out and resolved quickly. The guacamole was warm & missed any flavor, probably in top 5 worst guacamole ever. The burrito was okay in the flavor area, but really mushy. The combination didnt offer any texture variety. Wouldn't eat here again.
author: Anna H.

description:
I'm doing it. I'm bucking the trend on this one. 

Papalote is good. Yes. But is the 8.33 out of 9 moustaches that Burrito Eater has deemed it? ...No. Sorry, folks. Their salsa is very good, their meat is tasty fresh, but there are just too many better places (San Jose or Taqueria) within a tortilla's throw of this place. Papalote is small by design, so lines can extend out the door during busy times, but feels too polished to have that family-owned charm. It's got a great reputation going for it, but at the ended of the day, I yearned for a burrito that earned its 8.33 moustaches. This...was not that burrito.
author: Kevin B.

description: My favorite modern-Mexican taqueria/burritoria in SF. Super fresh and healthy. Every order comes with chips and what is possibly the best salsa in all existence. They even offer brown rice as an option! - I wish every Mex restaurant would do that!
author: J J.

description:
Rated one of the best burritos in San Francisco, Papalote attracts many people each day. I decided to deviate from my normal taqueria choices and step inside. You'll be greeted with the menu and, most of the time, a line.

Price wise it's a step up from regular Mexican restaurants, but this isn't just any restaurant. This place has been featured on Bobby Flay's short run show, Throwdown. They also have the feature that similar with Chipotle where you sub the rice for lettuce.

I decided to opt for a steak burrito. After ordering and grabbing a seat, a server comes around and hands me a bowl of chips along with their amazing, amazing salsa. I could go on about the salsa, but the fact that they sell it by the jar speaks for itself.

The burrito was absolutely massive. You get what you paid for and then some. Luckily, they provide you a knife and fork seeing as I don't have NBA player sized hands. Everything seemed standard, but the refried beans were something else... Very savory and creamy, the perfect compliment to any great burrito. 

I'll be back again and again if I decide to pay a bit more for a burrito when I stop by. They should have a loyalty program here!
author: George Z.

description:
***500th review written by Maile N***

:)  YUM!!  I was in the area and asked my facialist for lunch recommendations nearby after my appointment.  She mentioned Papalote and I had heard it of it, plus she recommended the fish burrito - I was totally intrigued so I wandered over.  I decided to get one to eat there and one to go to take home for my bf to try.  I had a feeling he would totally love me for it!  

I got a Mexican Coke - love!!  The chips and that salsa they bring over (and they also pack it in your to-go order) ROCKS!!!   I'm not sure what's in it, tomatoes, other vegetables mixed in and spices all blended together.  They should bottle it and sell it because I want more!!  The burrito was big, and packed with black beans, tomatoes, fish, etc. - yum!!  I could only eat half of it so I went home with 1-1/2 fish burritos for me and my bf to share, plus more of those yummy chips and *salsa*!  We sure enjoyed our burrito, chips and salsa!!  

We live clear across town from the Mission location and really wish a Papalote was closer - maybe the other location is closer.  Either way, we are definitely going to go back to have more fish burritos and to try their other items.  Gracias!!
author: Maile N.

description:
13 bucks for a burrito?  That better be twice as good as every other burrito for that price, but that is by far not the case.  A few shrimp, tons of rice, just a poorly sculpted piece of art.  I live in that hood and there are so many better places. Great salsa, but that's really not enough. I prefer salsa bars with more variety and hotter.  I need hotter!  But that's just me.

 I can't get over the pricing, I feel a bit robbed, but never again!
author: Jon S.

description:
Been coming here for years because of the superior salsa and veggie options.  But now that I'm eating meat once again, I have to say the meat burritos are rather meh.

Carne asada is too salty and low quality cuts and the chili verde too dry.  And now that the prices have been raised sky high, what's with still charging for extra salsa?!  You can't just give one extra for fux sake?!

Still the best for veggie options, and yes...their precious salsa, but i'll hit up the plethora of better and cheaper options for my meat burritos from now on. Sigh....
author: Drew W.

description:
- Delicious americanized burritos
- salsa is awesome
- 10+ minute lines
- $$ not $
author: Joe D.

description: Absolutely delicious. 3 of 4 people in our family is vegetarian or vegan. This was a great option for all of us.  I had a veggie burrito and it ruled. The guacamole was awesome as well. They have a huge jar of pickled jalapeños that are addictive. And yes, the salsa is super tasty.  The only drawback would be the limited seating but I would never NOT recommend this place because of that.
author: Larry M.

description:
Very good, savory, and delicious food. I came here with a friend for lunch. There are many choices for Vegans and Vegetarians. I ended up ordering Super Soyrizo burrito (10+). There was a serving of complementary chips and home mad creamy salsa. The salsa was very good (50 cents for extra sauce). I would recommend ordering an additional side of chips and salsa (1.69) if you want more salsa.

The soyrizo burrito was good. It was very saucy/juicy and well structured (almost no dripping). You could taste all the flavors and it was full of it. I would try out other options (breakfast burrito :) when I am around. Try regular burrito if you don't want too many ingredients. It is little bit more pricey then other places in the neighborhood.  However, it is still worth a try.
author: Sid P.

description:
When I want the standard veggie burrito and we opt for Papalote, I get the bean and cheese and add the other toppings to build to my liking. Their version of the veggie has potatoes and carrots which I really don't care for. 

Definitely call in your order. We were in and out in two minutes flat which was great because we parked nearby which was not even a legit parking spot. Our first visit to Papalote we waited a good 20 minutes or so for take out as we were unaware how busy this place was. 

Prices are a bit higher than your average taqueria but the ingredients are also higher in quality. I say it's worth it. 

I've tried many taquerias in my days although far from a personal favorite, their claim to fame is their salsa. And for me, it's justified.
author: Esther A.

description: I'm from San Diego and we're very particular about our burrito. I've had Papalote's twice now, and both times have been pretty good. The Triple Threat is a solid burrito, but it's a little unwieldy and the last time I had it, the fillings weren't evenly distributed. All that said, it's still a delicious burrito and I can see why it's so well-regarded.
author: Alan T.

description:
Food is pretty decent however when I asked for salsa, it was like living in the "Soup Nazi" episode of Seinfeld. They immediately declined to give me an extra small container of salsa in an aggressive way. I would've paid extra for it.

No salsa for you!
author: Katie M.

description:
Completely over-hyped. I couldn't be more puzzled as to how this place has been able to achieve its status as some of the best burritos and salsa in the Mission. I found both to be very mediocre and expensive.

You have to order something before you can sit down here. I arrived a little earlier than her and they wouldn't let me sit at a table while I waited for her even though there was space. Not a big deal, but worth noting. Ordering was painless enough, but boy were the prices high! I ordered a super chicken burrito and a horchata. I had heard people rave about their salsa/secret sauce so I also got an extra cup of it for 50 cents extra. My total was $16! My friend ordered guacamole and a naked burrito and her total was over $20. 

The food came, and to their credit, they got it out to us incredibly fast! I tried some of my friend's guacamole and it was very good and fresh, but still not $8.50-good. The salsa was definitely not anything to write home about, but it was kind of unique compared to most salsas and tasted fine. The chips on the other hand were pretty bad. Not inedible, but bad enough to where I abandoned them after the first three or four. But they were also free, so I guess that's forgivable. 

Then came the burrito and honestly, there just wasn't whole lot going on flavor-wise. It had everything I usually like, but for some reason I just felt like it was missing something, like there was no depth to the flavor. On the other hand, they were generous with the chicken and the cheese was nicely melted. It was also pretty big so I was able to bring some home. 

+1 star for having extra pieces of tin foil out for the customers to wrap their leftover burrito up in. I think this should be a standard at burrito places, but not enough of them do it.
author: Shelly P.

description:
BUMMER.  This was formerly a 5-star rating, holding strong for years.  How could they fall so far so fast, you ask?  Has the food changed?  Nope, it's equally bomb.  Well then what the...?!  Well, having (had) Papalote on speed dial, I called in a burrito on my way to the park.  I arrived and got out my eleven bucks for the fish burrito I ordered.  Eleven bucks, I think, is a high-end burrito.  But I get it, good quality fish is expensive.  

Cashier:  "That'll be fourteen dollars please."  
Me:  "Oh, no I just ordered one burrito." 
Cashier:  "Our prices went up; it's fourteen dollars."

FOURTEEN DOLLARS FOR A BURRITO?!  

We've been in an open relationship for 6+ years, San Francisco, and I've grown beautifully with you. But fourteen dollaz for a burrito? Baby I feel like I don't know you anymore.  

Are you farming that fish in an urban aquacultural environment on the premises?  Because THAT would be badass.  That I would pay fourteen dollars for.  

Otherwise, you just lost a long-time customer, Papalote.  Dude, I didn't even get it super.
author: X-topher B.

description:
I wish I could turn back time and never have chosen to go to this place for lunch yesterday. With the plethora of amazing food in sf, scratch that- in the area, scratch tha-t ON THAT ONE DAMN STREET! whhhyyy oh why did I chose a place with mediocre food and insane prices? 

Ok so their confusing weird menu offers 79 types of burritos or tacos at sort of decent prices or if you don't want a burrito you can choose an egg dish or a plate. When I ordered the Chicken Mole plate the cashier asked me if I wanted to make it super. I asked what that entailed and she said, "sour cream salsa and guacamole for $.99" Uhhhhh como-what? For SIXTEEN GOD DAMN DOLLARS you guys aren't gonna slap some condiments on my plate? I should have turned around and left at that moment or at least changed my order but I just declined the super-cision and moved on. Next we sat at a table and were brought a sugar bowl of chips and a salad-dressing cup of salsa which held 3 tablespoons of their overly-salty-not-as-good-as-pancho-villa salsa. 

My husband and I inhaled the salsa on 2 chips each and waited about 30 mins, drank all of our drinks then finally received our skimpy lame-ass non-condiment-having plates. I asked the food runner "can we have more salsa with our food?" and she said "yes but that's 50 cents" UM COMO WHAT? Are you people insane? You give out 2 tsp of salsa and then charge if somebody consumes it in 5.2 seconds? There should be disclaimers galore on those little shot glasses of sauce! We paid the stupid 50 cents because we basically had to, for we had no condiments on our stupid, un-super plate. We were given either 4 or 6 tortillas for 2 plates, my man eats minimum 6 tortillas so I had 1 and he the rest and we just packaged our food up to-go since we knew we'd be in for another up-charge if god forbid we want more of their crappy hard chewy tortillas. Oh and if Papalote wants a lesson on how to make Mole I'd be happy to oblige. I mean, on Mondays you can get the nectar of the Gods at Los Compadre's in South City on Grand Ave, but not even comparing it to that, Paplote's sucked.  Lay off the crunched up bran flakes! Wtf is that about? 

Overall we spent almost $40 on 2 crappy skimpy plates, mine-bad mole his huevos (his huevos machaca was pretty good tho) mushy over-cooked, over-stirred, cheapy-bought rice, really good refried beans, an insulting scoop of jicama salad and no god-damn condiments.
author: Emma H.

description:
A much yuppier vibe than other Mission District taquerias, with a clientele that looks as if most of it wandered down from Noe Valley and Bernal Heights.

Burrito kind of mellow, if I can put it that way, with ingredients swapped around together rather than crisply highlighted in the usual taqueria way, and all wrapped up in a thick, heavy flour tortilla.

If that wasn't memorable, the salsa that comes with the chips is unbelievable.  Salsa should be either chunky or liquid or chunks in liquid, right?  This was none of the above.  It was smooth and creamy and resembled a tomato alfredo sauce more than anything else.  Good for eating the dull chips and the duller heavy tortilla with after I'd dug all the filling out of the burrito.
author: David B.

description: The salsa is AMAZING! It looks like a cream sauce but it's just wonderfully concentrated, bright orange healthy sauce. The food is great, not pricey and the salsa brings everything together. Yum!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Papalote uses good quality ingredients, so the food is delicious no matter what you get. It's pretty expensive, but it is really good. They open at 11am, and I prefer to get there early. It gets super busy, and sometimes it's impossible to get a table. 

The salsa is off the hook! They have a few different kinds, and they're all really good. Super complex taste, I know why everybody loves it.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Papolote has become a go-to for takeout Mexican. Tip top burritos and quesadillas with excellent house-made salsa/sauce and mediocre tortilla chips. My wife loves the Chicken Mole quesadilla (it's great). I tried the Chicken Mole burrito recently and felt like it was too runny/soupy for a burrito. It tastes great, but I prefer the more classic burrito offerings (from them and everyone else). 

If you haven't checked Papolote off your list of Mexican stops in the Mission, it's about time that you do.
author: Marcus C.

description:
My first burrito in the Mission District!  Papalote was the first recommendation given to me when venturing into this mecca of big burrito lovers.  I'm not going to just meekly accept the assumption that all burritos from this area are better than anywhere else without validating this myself though.    

Going on a picturesque Sunday evening in August, it was surprisingly not too packed.  I have had longer waits at Chipotle.  The clientele here included mainly tourists and hipsters, here because of their devotion to a good burrito.  

Papalote is REALLY proud of the fact that their "Triple Threat" (steak, chicken, shrimp) burrito beat Iron Chef Bobby Flay's.  It's prominently advertised and mentioned by Papalote groupies.  And they charge $20.  I asked a friend who is a Papalote devotee if she wanted to split it, but was told it's not really that big.  But still $20?  Yeah, no thanks.

So you order at Papalote by telling them what you want, getting a number, taking it to your table, and waiting for them to bring it out.  I ordered the chicken burrito and got a Horchata too.  On to the chips and salsa.  The salsa is pretty awesome.  It tasted like a fire-roasted tomato-based red salsa, but is a little creamy too.  The chips were standard.  The horchata was a tad sweet for my taste.

The burrito came out after roughly 10 minutes.  Time to dig in!  Wait . . . no foil and it's on a plate?  Surely I don't have to eat this burrito with knife and fork? That's a little too formal for me, so I used my hands and picked it up.  First bite and I liked the flavor of the burrito.  The chicken seemed shredded.  A little dry.  As I continued to eat it, it was good, but it did not wow me or fill me up at the end of the meal.  A good burrito.  Add a little salsa as you eat the burrito and it's better.  But this experience has inspired me to try other joints in the Mission for my next visit.  Maybe find some friends to go on a Mission burrito crawl.
author: Corey C.

description:
I begrudgingly bequeath 4 stars to this burrito joint.

It's about the best burrito west of Valencia and deserving of the praise it gets. It's just silly that the price of the triple threat burrito went up so high. It's a pretty damn good burrito but I shouldn't need to put out a loan to get it.

Definitely try the orange sauce but in my experience, buying the bottled sauce isn't really the same (tends to be too watery).
author: Baron C.

description: They give free nachos and jalepeno pickles. Burritos were filling and their salsa was delicious.
author: Ernest W.

description: The vegan soyrizo burrito is my favorite and I always make sure to have jars of Papalote hot salsa at home. At the restaurant, you can get the freshly made salsa to take home or the more familiar store version that you find at up scale supermarkets and both are excellent. Really good food and the best salsa on the planet!
author: Jan P.

description:
Lets pretend for a second that astoundoing and delicious had intercourse. Then you know what Papalote is- as-licious! 

The Super Fish Tacos are so fresh and tasty.

The staff is nice, and the food came out fast enough too. A pretty darn good spot.
author: Luis D.

description:
SUPER delish!!! Okay so I have a friend name Victor that said he had a restaurant in SF. Then I seen his clip on food network and still didn't go. HAHAAH Finally,
my besties and myself decided to go out and spend the weekend in SF for Cinco De Mayo! In Honor of Cinco De Mayo we ate mexican food of course!!!! SOOOO the sauce is sooo tasty!!! DELISH I must buy the jar when I go shopping next! I got the shrimp burrito it was pleasantly DELISH... Can I say that word again? DELISH!!!!! Next time on a cheat day I will go back and go big or go home and get the triple threat? It looks like death but I'm sure it's to die for!!!!!! I'll be paying for it at the gym!!! hahaha

SO the place is small but who doesn't like small places? If the food is good who cares right? I love the photography work on the wall. I am quite intrigued by the photoes!! I love ART!!! Very pretty! Good job EH!
author: Leah C.

description:
Epic chicken mole tacos and roasted pepper salsa!! Wish there was something that came close to the quality and deliciousness out here in NYC.

Tip: You can buy their salsa there, both fresh and bottled. I snagged a bottled jar and it made it through TSA just fine (in my checked luggage and wrapped up in clothes).
author: Diana S.

description:
This would probably be my favorite place to grab lunch if it weren't for the high end price attached to a traditionally reasonably priced food. Although I don't really mind paying a premium for their exceptional quality & service. 

Where else can I get a soyrizo or tofu mole burrito? The ingredients are always fresh and that salsa is killer! Just wish they would include more of it or have a salsa bar... The cute and sweet girls @ the counter are always helpful and nice when I call in my order, seriously, who doesn't if it's for take-out? Papalote gets extremely busy and isn't the biggest space in the world. #shoutout to Alma and the girls for always getting my order just right while greeting me with a beautiful smile when I pick it up. 

Yum! Can't stop thinking about my next visit...
author: John B.

description:
It's alright.

A bleach-blonde version of a Mexican resto (interpret that any way you want).

Definitely "feel" like you're eating healthier fare...but then, what's the point?

Salsa was tasty, guac was ok. 

If you want ebony with caramel highlights, walk a couple blocks towards Mission.
author: Moo C.

description:
I asked my friends. "What is this place known for?" And they said "the salsa". I laughed because I thought it was a joke, but they weren't kidding. I liked the salsa so much I bought myself a fresh bottle from the fridge (mason jar) and brought it home to put it on everything. 

I also order the Filipino burrito. That was good for the first few bites however it became too salty for my liking. I'm willing to come back and try other food to boost the stars.
author: Khanh L.

description: Love the food chips and salsa are great. Shrimp tacos are hands down the best sautéed in white wine sauce and butter.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Well I felt a little duped after eating here. 

I had located this little hole in the wall using yelps reviews and photos of the food. I ran across Dungeness crab enchiladas and was sold. Upon looking over the menu board there was no crab or enchiladas any where in sight. Oh well, must have been a special, no big deal. I had a carne asada super burrito which I thought was quite tasty. My girl on the other hand who ended up getting the prawn super burrito ($12.95), received only 4 small very over cooked prawns in her burrito, she was pissed. It was a lot of rice and beans for $13.
On the other hand I felt as though I received a healthy amount of carne asada and enjoyed my burrito well enough.
author: Pizzle D.

description:
Really tasty fish burrito with fresh grilled fish. 

Try the Mexipino burrito- Filipino-Mex burrito
author: Jingo Django J.

description: Their salsa is excellent and unique, but everything else I've tried is bad.  I've gotten tacos several times which have ranged from "would be subpar in the Midwest" to "undercooked pork".  I won't be ordering anything but chips and salsa going forward.  It's really a shame they don't bring the whole package; even mediocre Mexican with that salsa would make them a go-to spot for me.
author: Justin L.

description: Consistently reliable and delicious, but way to expensive. I usually go with the steak or chicken super burrito with black beans. The tacos are not good here.
author: Aaron L.

description: It's my second time here but I must say this experience was much better than the first time. The first time we took burritos to Dolores Park. Eating at the restaurant while you food is still piping hot is a much better option. We got the nachos which were delicious. Comes with Refried black beans and the cheese is melted perfectly. I ordered a chicken burrito and my husband got a carne asada burrito. They have whole wheat tortillas which is nice and the burrito has tons of flavor. Make sure you get their signature sauce to dip your burrito in. Don't get your food to go, doesn't do it justice.
author: Melissa S.

description: Would you like to wait 45 minutes for a takeout burrito?  If so, then Papalote is the Mexican Grill for you!
author: Leon K.

description: I just ate the best carne asada burrito I've ever had in my life. Kudos to the team at Papalote!
author: Chris C.

description:
In what turned out to be the last installment of The Mission Burrito Experiment, I visited Papalote Mexican Grill. I was new to the Mission burrito scene and needed to decide if I like Mission burritos or not by visiting a few of the burrito joints in the Mission.  Some may argue that Papalote's burritos aren't quite Mission burritos, but I decided to give them a chance as part of my experiment.

So, I got close to my standard burrito; carne asada, pinto beans, super, no rice. It was damn good.  It was very similar in flavor to the previous Mission burritos.

As mentioned, this was the last installment of The Mission Burrito Experiment.  This whole time, I was comparing each burrito to my favorite burrito of all time, the carne asada burrito at Mondo in Santa Clara.  And I decided that I'd rather have that burrito than a Mission burrito.  It was fun while it lasted, and I'm sure I'll be back for a Mission burrito again!
author: Nadeem A.

description:
Doooood!!! I can't believe I forgot to rate this place. Smh this spot is the bomb! 

Although I haven't been in a while, I do often catch myself thinking of your luscious burritos. Lol I've had their fish burrito and mmm mmm!!! 

If you're looking for a taqueria in the mission, you'll notice that they come dime a dozen. Unfortunately, not all of them are any good. 

Papalote is great for several reasons. For one- the owner is super cool. Papalote is one of the only businesses in the community, where the owners actually make appearances lol 
Two- they make amazing food. Prepared with some culinary pride.
Three- THEY ARE CLEAN! I can't tell you how many dirty taquerias their are in the mish. 

Papalote not only has great food, but an awesome ambiance and nice staff. Check em out! It's worth it. :)
author: Julia C.

description: so I was here in SF for the weekend with some homies and we decided to eat here because of this show called taco trips. the show itself is pretty freaking corny if you ask me but hey they do show some pretty good looking food. Anyways, DANK yo triple threat burrito for $19.99 i think $23 after tax. Definitely worth it. The burrito is pretty large in size. it has carne asada, chicken, prawns, Mexican rice, and of course sour cream and guacamole. To be real I don't even know if I went to the one from the show but cuuuh so dank. if you're in SF or just a tourist, I would definitely recommend coming here. Sure $19.99 is pretty pricy for food and it's probably a lot cheaper if you make it yourself but for the experience it's well worth it. With that being said, I'm sure their other burritos are pretty dank as well I think you could custom make your burritos too. Also their sauce is pretty dank too like it's not too spicy but not too mild. I don't even really know if that made sense but hey super good food! shout outs to taco trip
author: Jaspur P.

description:
This mexican grill is super yummy!! I forgot the name of what I got but i know it's what they recommend to their customers. The burrito was very good and the size was huge! I could have split it with 3 other people.

The chips and salsa was extremely good!! The best I've had so far!! 

The place is pretty small but very artsy!!

Great food!!
author: Arnieliz S.

description:
The Chilaquiles - enough said!

Okay - but actually, there's so much more. On top of the totally-killer, absolutely-supreme chilaquiles, Papalote has some bomb burritos. It's hard to find a good bean and cheese burrito, but they have perfected the art.
