Their in-house made salsa is also out of this world. Unique and creamy with a smokey base, I always ask for extra. Plus, you can buy it in-store for friends who may also be Papalote-fans. 

Tips: 
+ Looking to eat your burrito at home? Call ahead and pick it up. They're timely and have a register dedicated solely to phone orders. 
+ Only bummer is that they open late on weekends. Sometimes I need breakfast before 11am...
author: Tiffany K.

description:
2 stars for the salsa (which is good) and the service, which was fine.

The answer to the question that many of you are wondering after eating here and wondering how this place gets voted the best burrito in SF may lie somewhere in the clientele that frequents the place and the people who do things like vote for best burrito.
 
I have a general rule when eating in an ethnic eatery in SF: if there are not people of that ethnicity eating at the establishment, it most likely isn't authentic, is usually pricey, and is not typically good. 

I imagine (just my observation as a native Californian of Mexican decent) that Papalote is popular among people who are a) not from California/San Francisco or any state that borders Mexico b) have never had good Mexican food or c) lack taste buds.

My observation and 2 cents below: 

1. Papalote does one thing well: salsa.

2. The chips are store bought dry and stale.  Fried tortilla strips = not that hard to make. But hey they are free. (But are they really at $9 for a burrito?)

3. The pollo asada (chicken) burrito I had was bland and tasteless. Chicken had some sort of dry (emphasis on DRY) rub on it to give it "flavor." I ordered my burrito with no rice (because that's how you do it) so I had a chance to get some beans which were ok when drenched in the house salsa.

4. My girlfriend ordered a VEGETARIAN burrito which was MOSTLY RICE and even included some grill CHUNKS OF BURNED MEAT. Obviously, this Mission establishment caters to mostly non-Latinos, many of whom (just a stretch since this is San Francisco we are talking about) are vegetarian. However, they do not separate or clear their grill for vegetarian orders. Minor to me since I eat meat but the GF, not so happy.

To bring it back around to the "best burrito in SF," Papalote is what I call a "gentrification joint."  With the influx of non-Latinos into a traditionally Latino neighborhood, we see more and more places pop up that water down the "tradicional," you know, to keep the neighborhood "authentico" and "diverse" with its new inhabitants. In come things like "voting for best you fill in the blank."

I have no advice for Paplote because they have found a niche and have even expanded into--surprise!--the NoPa neighborhood. 

The best burrito in SF they are not. To get that, you now have to venture way past the "best of" signs further out in the Mission and find that little place where meat is still slow cooked, beans are painstakingly prepared for days, tortillas come fresh off the grill, peppers marinate forever, and the abuelita behind the counter has trouble understanding you when you make you order in English.
author: dude m.

description: How hard is it to get a super burrito without sour cream when you ask three times? Apparently for this place it's close to impossible. Second time it's happened. At least they were quick to refund the purchase!
author: Rafa D.

description:
I was looking forward to finally going to Papalote and I have to say the hype is not worth it. Is the salsa delicious? Absolutely. That's about all I can say.

My gripes:
1) You can't "mix and match" your tacos - meaning, if you want to try two kinds of meat, you have to end up with 4 tacos. See, typically I go to taquerias and get 2 or 3 tacos, each with a different protein so I can sample. Much to my dismay, when I asked about this the nice lady said I have to get the 2 tacos.  That's kind of crappy.

2) The chile verde was pretty bad.  Despite having some heat, it was otherwise bland from the flavor side.  The pork was fake-tender. By that I mean, you could break of pieces easiily with a fork, but it was still dry. Clearly it had been simmering for too long in too high of heat. Even I, the home cook, know this - poor technique in the kitchen.  The scary part? I asked the cashier if she recommended the chile verde or the chicken mole, and she said chile verde. I'm terrified of how crappy the mole might be.

3) The tacos come covered in lettuce and tomatoes. What?  Why? There's so much of it too. I appreciate wanting to promote eating veggies and all, but I came here to eat a taco - with meat.  Not ok.

4) Guacamole - was also bland. I had to add some salt. There was no limey zip, and I'm not even sure how but I didn't really get the flavor of avocado. 

5) Service - When the gentleman brought out my tacos, I asked about my side of guac. He looked at the ticket in his hand, which I also saw, and it clear said "Chile Verde, Guacamole." He seemed very confused. My friend also pointed out that on her (separate) order, she had asked and paid for 2 extra salsas and those were not brought out either. He seemed confused and flustered. Eventually we got everything we needed but it wasn't like he was bringing out multiple plates of food at once. He literally was only carrying my tacos in one hand and the ticket that clearly stated "Guacamole" in the other.  Also, on an unrelated note - flies in the air. Not ideal.

This place is probably great for vegetarians/vegans who otherwise can't get Mexican food, but for us meat eaters, don't bother.  

2 stars for the salsa. Good news is you can buy jars of that stuff and never eat anything else here. That's probably my go-to plan from now on.
author: Naoko M.

description: The breakfast burritos are awesome! Especially the mexicana (egg with tomatos)
author: Henry L.

description: The veggie breakfast burrito with soyrizo is heaven on a plate for any vegetarian. As is obvious, the salsa here is also out of this world and will make any Mexican food better. Also, the people behind the counter are super friendly and always have a smile on their faces, or that may just be because they recognize me from coming here all the time. Two thumbs up!
author: Isaac R.

description:
Why You Gotta RESPECT Papalote:

1)  The Salsa

It is one of my favorites.  Made with smoked tomatoes and with enough heat to make your nose sweat a little, this orangey sauce is great any which way.  Go ahead and buy a jar to take home ($7) because that itty bitty container of SALSA with your CHIPS ain't gonna cut it.   

2)  They kicked some Food Network challenge booty.

While I like a Bobby Flay schooling as much as the next person, I'm actually not a Papalote burrito fan.  The Grilled Chicken Burrito (with black beans, rice, and "salsa") is pretty bland.  Instead of their signature salsa, inexplicably you'll find a disappointing stand in of watery diced tomatoes and onions.  The Grilled Veggies Burrito is a misnomer as it barely had any zucchini.  Next time, I'll get my salsa at Papalote and my burrito at El Farolito.

With some Bobby Flay schadenfreude on the side.
author: Amy C.

description:
Solid burrito joint and fantastic place to get salsa. 

First- the salsa. That's why I mainly come here now. They have 3 kinds - Serrano (the mildest), habernero (the hottest), and the house salsa (also decently spicy, but so good!). I've tried all the salsa and it's fantastic. Now I make sure to always have a couple jets stocked at home to have whenever I get a takeaway burrito (from anywhere!). So yeah, definitely try their salsa, and then take some to go. 

As for the food, I came here first with some friends to get burritos for lunch. Let's face it, this place is small! And at lunch on a Saturday, it was busy. It definitely felt cramped as we are waiting in line and then being shuffled to a table. One of their workers was coordinating seating to for people at the right tables so everyone could sit. That being said, there was enough room, we didn't have to wait, and the tables were plenty spacious. 

The chips and salsa were great, and the burritos were really good. We all got super burritos, and I got the adobe super burrito. It was fresh and delicious. I'd have no hesitation recommending someone to cube here for the food.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Great organic Mexican food with gluten free and vegan options! Great pollo con mole! And they have tofu con mole for all you vegs!! Definitely going back!!
author: William H.

description:
Delicioso! Came here for lunch with my two gf's around 1:30 on Saturday. It was busy but not packed; we were able to get a seat right after we ordered. 
So this place you order at the front and then find a seat. They will bring you a little serving of chips (individualized) and this yummy yummy salsa-type thing. I'm not exactly sure what it is, but it was really good - and kind of spicy too, which I LOVED! They will also bring your food to the table.

I ordered the soyrizo tacos. They are like a mix between real Mexican style (not fried shells) and Cali-style (lettuce). I think the tortillas are homemade, and I loved that they were kind of thick. The soyrizo was perfectly seasoned, and the lettuce was super fresh. The whole package was very good.

My gf's ordered burritos and they looked amazing! The tortillas looked like legit mexican-style tortillas, and they were huge! So worth the like $10. I'll have to try a burrito next time.

All-in-all, I can say I will definitely recommend this place to friends, and I definitely would love to come back!
author: Courtney S.

description:
one if the best burritos I've be ever had! 


Except the breakfast burrito. Replacing meat w eggs doesn't make it breakfast and I don't understand why there's rice in a breakfast burrito. It tasted like a regular burrito but w chorizo. It was still good, just not a breakfast burrito. But OMG their salsa is to die for!

Overall great place, so glad my dad took me there. Just maybe make breakfast burritos different than regular burritos and offer more than one salsa cup as well as a spicy option.
author: Emely Z.

description: Papalote has awesome Mexican food! The portions are great and the ingredients could not be fresher. It's worth making the trip to Papalote if you are in the Bay Area.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Had my first burrito of Papalote in 2004 it was the soyrizo burrito and the flavors were great, left the west for a while came back and now in 2014 had the super chicken burrito. This place still has the consistently great flavor that it did 10 years ago. Salsa is really good and chips are crisp and fresh. 

Only downside to this place is that it is cramped with very little seating when its busy also the line can get overwhelming for my likes. 

Pop in give it a try and see WHY they beat Bobby Flay at Salsa Cook Off!
author: Marc R.

description: I used to work at the smoke shop on 24th and mission and this place is the best for a burrito! Their special sauce thing is amazing! I love it so much! Ask for extra sauce.
author: Nawaf T.

description:
I used to live across the street and would eat Papalote at least 2-3x times a week (super fish burrito with extra guacamole) and it was by far my favorite go-to burrito place. Recently however, it seems as though they've changed their recipes. Not sure if anyone else has noticed but their seasonings taste off and not as good as before and the ratio between beans, meat, and sauce is not quite right.

Scrolling through the recent Yelp reviews it looks like other long time customers have noticed the same drop in quality.
author: Jahan D.

description:
I don't get it...

This place is highly over-rated, especially since its a block away from El Farolito and Taqueria San Jose.

The salsa is good, hence the 2 star rating.

admittedly, I will stop by once in a while when I'm craving for beets and carrots in my burrito. 

In the immortal words of Chuck D, "Don't, don't don't...believe the hype"
author: mark q.

description:
I've been hearing about the Mexi-Pino burrito for quite some time now. This creation, made with Filipino style chicken adobo (meat simmered in vinegar and soy with garlic), garlic rice, and tomatoes, generously wrapped in a flour tortilla is deeelocious! At the recommendation of a friend/Papalote patron, I ordered the burrito "classic." You have to ask for "super" to get  the sour cream, cheese, and guac goodness. I'm usually a super burrito gal, so this plain version was new to me. The Mexi-Pino was still so tasty and I venture to say better as a "classic" because you can taste the flavor of the adobo. It was filling, yet not too heavy, and I walked out feeling muy feliz. 

Also, their salsa is pretty tasty with a little bite to it. I bought a jar of fresh made salsa and 2 extra burritos (for the husband and parentals) to bring home. The guy at the counter was really nice. He recommended the fresh salsa vs. the jars on the counter. He also hooked it up with a frequent customer card and marked off 3 burritos because he knew my sis and I had also just shared one in the dining area.
author: Tiffany E.

description: Dried out chicken molé with almost no flavor, undercooked black beans, and dried out brown rice that tasted like cigarettes. I threw most of it in the compost, complete waste of food, time, and money.
author: Matt O.

description: Great place for vegans! I got a pollo taco, he got a marinated tofu burrito, and we shared guacamole and chips. Thanks to Yelp reviews we made sure to try the house hot sauce, yum.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Would rate as 3.5 stars if yelp let me
now  why low rating, well burrito was delish.  Great taste.   Had the chile verde burrito. That salsa they give you on table more like a sauce is awesome.  Would hav bought a bottle if i wasnt flying home and knew damn tsa people would keep it.  But lets get real.  Despite great flavor, there was very little meat in it mostly rice and beans.  $11 for a burrito and can of coke come on now.  Get over being on tv.  Shave $3 off that price and you are 5 star material.  Crossed off my bucket list.
author: Jim G.

description: I'm very disappointed from this place they overcharge and nothing there tastes so good the only thing that I liked was the salsa the mole was disgusting not even with beef
author: Zohar I.

description: Favorite Mexican restaurant by far! I usually order either tacos or naked burrito with shrimp or Chile Verde. Consistent, fast, and delicious whether you're ordering out or eating there. Best salsa EVER!
author: Sophie S.

description:
Small, quick, delightful. Three words that sum up Papalote.

The decor is simple and eye-pleasing.

The menu is concise and easy to figure out. 

The service is quick despite its popularity.

The Triple Threat burrito price has indeed gone up, but is really worth having. Everything on the menu is good and the beans are vegan, and so is the rice.

The three sauces that Papalote are known for are divine and they really are "The secret weapon," as Bobby Flay so famously said. You can buy them after you visit at papalotesalsa.com
author: Rachel J.

description: Such good food. I have had two different burritos, and can't decide which is better! Easy, fast service too!
author: Joe F.

description: This was a fantastic spot with many solid offerings and great ambiance. I would recommend anything on their menu. They are a fairly busy place so show up early to get a seat.
author: Jim G.

description: Really delicious burritos! I got the veggie burrito with potatoes/carrots/mushrooms and whole black beans  and it was delicious. Really well balanced flavors. Adding guacamole and some sour cream makes for an awesome, filling meal.
author: Drini C.

description: Great salsa and chips. Watermelon juice is refreshing. Burrito is good.
author: Wayne Z.

description: Awesome hole in the wall. Long line but it moves quickly. If you order guacamole, be forewarned: it's HUGE.
author: Lucinda D.

description:
I came in on a Saturday night and got the naked burrito with pork verde (I think) and sour cream. I ordered the food to-go because there was a 20 minute wait for seating inside. The food came out in about 15 minutes, and I was pleasantly surprised at how tender the pork was, and with the heat in the house salsa.

The food here was not the typical street tacos that I'm used to in San Diego, and I have no idea if its authentic Mexican food, but it was still delicious. Only 4 stars because it is a bit pricey for what you get, especially compared to other Mexican restaurants in the Mission. Still, it was cool to have food prepared by a chef that has competed with Bobby Flay on Throwdown. I will be back for the friendly and quick service and the yummy food!
author: Malini K.

description: The Triple Threat Burrito Is By Far The Best Burrito Iv Ever Had Hands Down!!! Worth Every Penny! Wish It Was Only $15 bucks tho
author: Jacob D.

description: As everyone else says, the salsa is a must. It's kind of like a spicy creamy tomato/marinara sauce, which might sound odd but is actually really delicious on your burrito of choice. The carne asada is amongst the best I have ever had - ever. So flavorful and tender, clearly not the cheapest cut of meat. The servers, although a bit flustered during busy hours, are very friendly and helpful in getting you a table. My only complaint is that you definitely cannot eat this burrito with your hands - it's wrapped pretty loosely so everything starts leaking/falling out the bottom halfway through.
author: Amy Y.

description:
This restaurant has great vegetarian and vegan options.  The beans and rice are made vegan and they have 2 vegetable options and 3 tofu options.  The burritos are large and they do cross the $10 threshold but it is a lot of food.  

My boyfriend and I have a tradition of splitting a burrito once per week and earning a punch on our loyalty card for a free burrito.  Our favorites are grilled veggies (eggplant and zucchini) with whole black beans and marinated tofu (which has a perfectly firm texture) and whole pintos.  Make it a super with sour cream, guac, and cheese for only $1.  

The salsa is BOMB so we always get an extra side and sometimes a jar to take home!
author: Jessica L.

description:
First up, I am sure I am not the first to end up here because they were on Throwdown with Bobby Flay.

I had high expectations.  The place was super busy.  I ordered.  Time karma was with me and I was able to land a table.  Figuring there would be a wait, I had gotten a couple of beers.

And there was a wait.  It was about twenty minutes.  Not horrible but Mexican food is usually fast.

I ordered a carne asada platter.  It was a pretty good plate but it was nothing that would stand out.  I've had many other carne asada platters that were just as good and a fair number that were better.

If I was in the neighborhood, I would go back.  But I would not go out of my way to return.
author: Mark D.

description:
This is my favorite burrito spot in the Mission for 2 reasons:
1. The salsa is incredible! I think it's some kind of garlic emulsion or I don't know... I could eat it by the spoonful
2. The adobo chicken burrito, I think it's called the Mexipino. Really delicious chicken, plus garlic rice. It's perfect.
author: Marlena F.

description:
This is what I was most looking forward to, and it didn't disappoint. It was described as a notch above the traditional Mission burrito as far as ingredients and presentation, yet still classic and delicious.

That sauce is definitely fantastic. Really great on everything - I could drink it.

I had the carne asada, twice. Just amazing. If I moved to SF, I'd take Papalote into account when considering location. Seriously.
author: Eric B.

description:
Pros:
-If you have a friend that is vegetarian or vegan, this is a great place to take them to because there are a ton of vegan and veggie selections
-Their trademark salsa sauce is indeed very delicious

Cons:
-Expensive for a burrito
-Burritos are okay from a meat eater's perspective; I feel like there are better and cheaper options
author: Wendy S.

description:
I first heard of this place when my friend brought their salsa to a potluck, and I was hooked. If I could drink it, I would, but alas my waistline would not thank me for it. 

I came here with my husband and ordered the fish tacos. The place is small and seating is limited. Everything was fresh and well seasoned. I love that they give you chips and a side of salsa. But if you want more salsa, they do charge you extra.
author: Kim C.

description:
This place is pretty darn good. Tried it because of all the yelp reviews and was not disappointed. When I first walked in, I saw all these newspaper clippings and what not about their amazing food, so that was a big plus. Their burritos are even mentioned in being one of the best in CA. Shared the food, so I was able to try both the super nachos and super quesadilla. Both were very good! They also have some sort of special salsa (that they make I guess), it's pretty tastey and I haven't had any salsa like it before. They gave us a lot of chips too :).
I want to come back and try their burritos. They have one called the mexipino which has chicken adobo. Never heard of anything like that so, I want  to try it :].
The prices are good, service is normal, pretty small dining area, so the wait depends on how busy it is, but you can always take it to go.
author: Monica M.

description:
This review is specifically for the Papalote Roasted Tomato Habanero Salsa. 
OMG so good, gift worthy! Thank you for creating this heavenly spiced salsa!!
author: Josie C.

description:
*2.5 stars*

Papalote is really ALL about the salsa. When it comes to Mexican food, however, great salsa is awesome, but it's definitely not the make-or-break factor. Papalote has amazing salsa, but that's pretty much all it has going for it.

When you're a hole-in-the-wall Mexican restaurant in the Mission, then you've got to have some pretty incredible food to even be in the competition. Papalote is okay, but definitely not even close to what's available in the Mission.

I got the carne asada super burrito, and including being more expensive than El Farolito or La Taqueria, it was also much more subpar. The meat was tender, but it was lukewarm. In fact, everything was just lukewarm. The rice tasted strangely old. I mean, it was okay, but definitely nothing special.

The chips they provide are horrible. Overly crunchy and overly fried, they were pretty bad for a Mexican joint in the Mission. The guacamole was flavorless -- just a bowl of avocados mushed together.

I did get a jar of their salsa to go (yeah it's really THAT awesome) but the food itself was just lackluster all the way through. Unfortunate.
author: Roy C.

description: For a 15-minute wait, this burrito better be amazing, I thought. It was pretty delicious, but I probably won't wait for 15 minutes for it again. What set it apart from other burritos I've had is the meat. I got the carne asada burrito, and the meat was just amazing. There was a perfect balance of lean and fat, and the flavors were so embedded in the meat that I was taken aback. Next time I'll probably just get a quesadilla so I can taste more of the meat!
author: Sherry L.

description: Quite possibly THE BEST burritos in the Mission, with amazing homemade salsa. Get a jar to bring home, you won't be sorry.
author: Lala R.

description:
Healthier Mexican food?
Check.
Vegan and veggie options?
Check.
Tasty, thick salsa like you've never had before?
Check.
Making an ass out of myself in front of complete strangers. Knocking over condiments with my bag. Damn, those tables are small.
Priceless.

I would definitely go here again, especially for the salsa. My burrito had just the right amount of flavor and was the perfect size. Not too big, not too small. I dunno if I could eat a super which is only 99 cents more but that's just me.

I discovered the Mission library along the way. Score. Check them out. They're not like any other taqueria in the area.
author: Amy J.

description:
I came here for 2 reasons, 1) after reading about it on the paper (or was it yahoo, i forget), and 2) because my friend recommended it

I know this place is known for there salsa, and yes they get props for their salsa, it was quite delicious, though personally i'd still prefer the fresh stuff over the "processed" salsa (i dont know if its processed or if they just intentionally make it into a mush/mash consistency)

Yes this place makes solid burritos, but then again, i don't think i've ever eaten a bad burrito, actually, i dont think i've ever eaten bad mexican food, its just one thing that is hard to mess up

we order one carne asada burrito and one soyrizo burrito

the soyrizo tasted an awful lot like the frozen chorizo breakfast burrito you can buy at trader joes for 4 dollars, im being serious. the carne asada was good, the meat was fresh and probably one of the better carne asada meats i've seen in a burrito 

so why do they only get 3 stars?

1) 7.50 for a burrito, too expensive, i can see if they justified charging 7.50 for their chips and salsa, since that is what its known for, but burrito for almost 8 bucks, no way

2) got our order wrong, we made it clear, one carne and one soyrizo, said it twice. what the waiter brought us was two soyrizos, then had the audacity to show us the receipt, which clearly stated 2 soyrizo (but come on, are you telling me that the lady who punched it into the computer didnt make any mistake?) 

3) salsa and chip portion was alright, but when i asked for a bit more salsa for my burrito, and the waiter said an extra 50 cents, sorry, thats 50 cents im not willing to pay for something that other restaurants give out for free in unlimited portions

in summation, this is san francisco, where burrito joints and food trucks litter almost every street corner, i have definitely had better burritos elsewhere, dont know what the hype is all about
author: Long C.

description: Friend of mine told me to try the Mexipiño burrito and it's seriously worth every penny. I go back repeatedly for this and their tomato salsa. Amazing!
author: Rachel H.

description:
One of the best Mexican foods I have ever tried. I was shocked when there was a picture of Bobby Flay on the wall, b/c apparently he had a throwdown there, and apparently he lost, so had to go try that place. 

This place was kind of small, it's kind of packed, but it's packed because it was really good. I had the chicken burrito, I really liked it, I'm more of a chicken person than steak person. My sister tried the 'mexipino' it's mexican and filipino food mixed together in a burrito. All I know it had chicken, but adobo style. It was really good, trust me. That's a must try when you go there. 
Also the carne asada nachos was really delicious. That's a must try also.

Service was friendly. 
Parking was pretty tough.
And finding a seat for 6 people was pretty difficult.
Food was great though. 

Go here if you're ever in San Francisco.
author: Ivadine M.

description:
One burrito, two burrito, three burrito - floor?! Seriously filling, big, bad (in a good way) burritos to be found here. I had the grilled vegetables option, which was one of several vegetarian choices - great to see. Order at the front and take a seat, your bodacious burrito* is en route.

*Other food is available here from salads to grilled meats, but I recommend you go for a burrito, you won't regret it.
author: Ellen G.

description:
I found this place while just walking by it, something that's a little bit of a rarity for me to go in without checking yelp. The first thing I noticed was that the door only opens halfway since the sidewalk is on a slant, and for whatever reason that made me really excited to eat there.

LIke any good place, this place was full and had free water. Thank god for free water! It was nice and cold too. They take orders ridiculously fast and the cashier was very nice, so there wasn't much waiting in line time to decide what to get.

Thankfully this place was pretty standard Mexican so it wasn't too hard to go for the steak burrito to go. I don't live too far from here so I figured I'd rather eat it at home. The price point was pretty standard, although a lot of places like Taqueria Cancún are cheaper and (spoiler) better.

When I opened the bag and took out the well sized burrito I was pretty happy, but still nothing out of the ordinary so far. Underneath the burrito I realized that the nacho chips (which are complementary like many burrito places in SF) were just lying out at the bottom of the paper bag, which was kind of disappointing. After a struggle to tear the paper bag in a way that would make it a suitable plate for the chips, I was only disappointed to find their spicy rendition of nacho cheese dip to be... well, mediocre. But complaining about a complementary side, maybe I'm just spoilt.

The burrito, this is where my still to be four star rating for the place dropped to three. It wasn't bad by any regard, but since burritos are quite the large food to tackle, I like them to be good to the very last bite. Unfortunately the first of this one told me this was going to be a challenge, albeit not a hardest one. It was rolled somewhat loosely, I didn't how ridiculously thin the tortilla was, and the ingredients weren't causing the orgasm in my mouth that other burritos have caused me to expect. I actually even payed the extra dollar or two it takes to get a super burrito with the guac, something I usually love, but something was just missing.

Being in the mission, unless you're ridiculously hungry and right outside this place, I'd reccomend going to one of the many other burritos around.
author: Mayank G.

description: Far too Chipotle-esaue for my liking.  It's fresh, pretty tasty, and has some good salsa to put on top.  Amidst my mountains of rice and beans, though, I found maybe only a couple pieces of steak.  It was kinda small and, while tasty, was not exactly memorable.  A good burrito, and I wouldn't mind going to this place again.  I definitely won't be seeking it out, though...especially given how bad the parking situation is around it, even on Sunday...
author: Brian B.

description: $13.31 for a chicken burrito....No thanks, never again...Better places in the Mission that's half the price....
author: Captain C.

description: These guys make a mean burrito, facing off against the one and only -Bobby Flay- in one of his classical throw downs.  As Bobby Flay pointed out, their secret lies in their salsa.  You can put Papalote salsa on nearly everything - not just burritos.  Their 3 varieties are THAT GOOD.   I am happy to report that Papalote salsa can now be purchased at most Whole Foods.
author: earl w.

description:
They have the best salsa ever created, in my humble opinion.
I was able to get a low-carb entree, thanks to the helpful staff.  Food was excellent.  But I can sit and just eat their salsa all day.  I can't wait to go back again.
author: Stacey D.

description:
This place?  Did some juvenile youths from the Mission tag up this bathroom..wait it must be art.  Whaaat..I'm in the center of SF where good Mexican food is and I'm standing here, contemplating what to order when everything here is at LEAST $3 more each than other taquerias?  

A decent sized burrito ..for $10.  Chips with orange salsa okay. And I guess if you love the sauce, you can even buy it in jars.  Chunk of meat that's not so tender..but the refried black beans with guac, swirl of sour cream, and salsa fresca got me excited like how I preparty and drink.  But the difference is when I get to the party, it gets better and this burrito did not. On to the next one.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
46. Chips and salsa at Papalote on the Big Eat list.

I came with a friend and we were pretty hungry. I decided to get the carne asada entree that came with beans and rice. Also I got extra tortillas. All of it was really good. We did order the salsa and chips. That salsa is AWESOME! My friend decided to buy a jar of it. I could only eat half of my meal and got the rest to go because I was full, but I couldn't stop eating the salsa and chips.
author: Rhoda G.

description:
What can I say about this place that hasn't been said a million times already? First of all, the salsa is so delicious that I had to send a jar down to my mom and dad in LA (they loved it), and secondly, everything else I've had there has been equally amazing.

I am a vegan and they have plenty of vegan options. No lard in any of the beans, thank god. I used to get the tofu mole burrito until I had their soyrizo. Now I get that so often that they know my order as soon as I walk through the door.

The staff is super friendly and they are super fast, especially if you call in your order while you're on your way, which I usually do so I can go eat in the park.

The dining room is clean, if a bit too small at times, and the bathroom is... Crowdsourced artistic... But certainly clean.

So, they may be more expensive that other mission taquerias, but the quality makes it worth it. Pretty much the only bad thing about this place is that they're only open til 10pm.
author: Justin S.

description:
First burrito excursion in the Mission. I'd call it a success. Just like everyone else says, the salsa is FANTASTIC. It's by far the highlight of the meal.

I was with a group, and we all got different things. No one was the slightest bit disappointed with their meal. Guacamole was fresh, and all the meat was well seasoned. The burritos are huge, and was easily 2 meals for me. But it was still good after reheating.  And always get the SUPER. You will not be disappointed.

The restaurant is a bit small. I pass by it on my way to BART and it's super crowded on friday and saturday nights, so you may have to wait for a table. Most other nights of the week it's not as bad.
author: Michele T.

description:
Busy on a Wednesday, so I assume it is always busy! Beer only. 

We ordered the Chorizo con Queso to start! AMAZING...a must try! This dish comes with a lot of cheese melted on top of well marinated, spicy and juicy chorizo.  It was exceptional. 

The chips come salty, warm and crispy. It doesn't get better than that! 

I also ordered two fish tacos. They were massive! The flavor was subtle but fresh. 

Wished  I lived closer becuase I would come here more often!
author: Julie J.

description: Although El Farolito may have been my go-to, simply because it's cheaper, Papalote was my change of pace burrito treat. See the Mission is sprawled with great Taqueria spots, but if you're willing to pay ~$3 more you can get a quality carne asada burrito.. And you know what I mean by quality steak, not thin strips but tender juicy chunks. And to top it off, their orange sauce is amazing
author: Neil I.

description: I love Papalote because their menu so clearly defines their vegan options, and the fact that their beans and rice are vegan. Yay! :D
author: Stacey J.

description: Two complaints about the extremely expensive $12 carne asada burrito I just had: the whole thing is utterly flavorless, and the carne asada was chewy--a surefire indication that it was not cooked correctly. The salsa that came with the burrito looked like orange salsa but was so bland I couldn't even tell any difference in taste with- or without the sauce on the burrito. All in all I'd say there's nothing particularly horrible about the burrito, but it didn't even live up to the flavor expectations I'd have of a $5 burrito much less a $12 one. Papalote is a great demonstration that even with the freshest and best ingredients your food will still suck if you don't put any soul into it. Save your money and get a burrito somewhere else.
author: Max S.

description: You know it based on the probable line.  Plus, a vegan burrito?  With mole?  Hello. Yep.  You're going.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Seriously!  That salsa is sooo good.  Their pollo asado is marinated perfectly and works well in their super burrito.  Friendly service, generous guacamole portions, sweetly pickled jalapeños, just all around good food.

Keep up the good work!
author: Robby F.

description: This place is about as good as it gets.  I've loved the food here for almost 20 years.  One of the best places in the Mission to grab a burrito and that's saying a lot.
author: Tom J.

description: Three stars only. Simply because the carne asada burrito needed about 3-4x more meat. The flavors were excellent. The salsa was really good. Even the roasted tomato habanero salsa, which I bought too, was delicious. I will go back, but order a 3x meat, 1/2 portion beans, 1/2 portion rice burrito. Probably cost me $30 as the 'bean' burrito was $9. Soo disappointing. La Taqueria around the corner does supply 3x the carne at the $9 or better price.
author: Joe D.

description: I recommend this restaurant and my favorite dish is the fish Pescado  which is a fried fish I think the fried in butter and make fish tacos out of it a burrito and spectacular I would definitely recommend that and you have to try the hot sauce it's a tomato-based hot sauce that is unbelievable
author: Louise M.

description:
You can Papalome any day!

Ahem...moving on.  This place came highly recommended by many people.  So I went with high expectations.  The place already had a pretty good line at 6pm on a Thursday.  My friend and I waited patiently and ordered a Chile Verde Super Burrito (chicken simmered in chile verde with rice, black beans, guacamole, cheese and sour cream).

The burrito itself was fantastic, the guac tasted like it was whipped or something and the overall flavors of the burrito itself were delicious and filling, while using a minimal amount of oil so I didn't feel gross afterwards.

However - I did take away one star since my friend and I waited for 40 minutes and after we kept seeing others get their food, I went in to inquire about the burrito status since my hanger   pains were setting in. The guy at the counter laughed and was like "It looks like they lost your slip, no worries - ok?"

While it was not an issue per say, I was pissed because I was hungry and after all was said it done it took us 50 minutes to order and get our food. Not to mention the guy just laughed about it - not cool. Next time I will be calling ahead - since their burritos are too delicious to ignore.
author: Lauren B.

description: You must come here! Everything is good and Miguel and his brother have come a long way! I'm especially excited because now Papalote's salsa which is soo good it sold in stores! I believe it's certain Whole Foods in the SF Bay Area. Service is always great and beats while dining are always on hit.
author: Marie P.

description:
Finally had this yesterday, and it was definitely worth the Bart trip from Union City to the Mission district.

First off, their homemade salsa tops everything I've had in my Mexican dining experience. It's a must-have when you visit.

Next, being that I'm Filipino, I specifically came here for the "Mexipino" (chicken adobo burrito) and boy did it live up to the hype. Very light and flavorful.

AIso had some of my fiancee's "Triple Threat" (steak, shrimp, & chicken). A lil pricy at $20, but I think it's worth it. It's one of those "you gotta try it once" kinda things. Just as flavorful as the Mexipino, but I can't say better.

Have their horchata too!
author: Juno M.

description:
Please don't throw tomatoes at me, I'm just being honest.

There has been hype around Papalote for a really long time in my mind.  With the 7x7's best burritos in SF article to my coworker constantly dipping his broccoli in their salsa, I was just aching to eat here.

I tried both a Carne Asada and a Camarones burrito, super'ed.  The shrimp pieces were small and really fresh.  The carne asada was a hit or miss depending on the piece I got.  I had initially picked out a piece and that was dry but when eating it with the burrito, it tastes pretty tender and fresh.  I like that even though the pieces are big, they rip apart easily.  

Unfortunately, by super-ing it, you get grilled veggies (bell peppers?) in it and it doesn't really go.  Also, the flavor in the burrito was weak so the salsa is quite necessary.  Now the hype about the salsa is interesting because it is good and it is really spicy but the texture is weird.  It's very blended and not quite smooth but not quite chunky... a strange in between.

Salsa comes from two places:
1. Made in this restaurant - $5.99 
2. Made somewhere else but still the Papalote recipe - $6.99

I've had both and I would say #2 wins the initial taste test.  #1 still isn't bad though.

Similar to traditional Mexican restaurants, you can help yourself to pickled jalapenos but they have WHOLE pickled jalapenos here.  Total highlight for me.  I can see how this place can be frustrating if you're trying to dine in and it's packed.  There isn't much room to stand in line to order and there isn't much room to sit. All the tables are also close together but it's a clean joint at least.

The best part is that they give each person their own little basket of chips and cup of salsa!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Such a disappointment ;(

I was looking forward to this place because I saw that they had the chicken adobo burrito, but it was such a fail. You'd think since they were on the food network, they'd hold up to standards but there was no adobo flavor to it! My bf had the crane Asada burrito and honestly the two tasted the same. Meat was dry and they put too much rice. Nothing spectacular. 

I wouldn't go back here again, there are probably better Mexican joints around so save yourself the trip.
author: Camila A.

description:
Why is it so hard to get burritos like this in NYC? Totally reasonably priced, lots of meat, lots of flavor. Plus, the burritos come with chips and salsa. Yum. 

-1 star because they're a victim of their own success; it's annoying to have to wait 15 minutes for a burrito.
author: Pamela S.

description: I used to work around here and went there for lunch almost every day. Their burritos are quite tasty but one day I found a large piece of glass inside my burrito. Went back with my burrito to show them and complain and the lady behind the counter told me that they find glasses in the black beans all the time.!!!! she did at least offer me a refund.
author: Pamela F.

description:
The boy and I were craving a burrito, so we stopped at the first place that had parking nearby (can you blame us? Damn you, Mission!)

PAPALOTAY! I just like saying it. It means "kite," right? Awesome.

We sat down in the cramped joint (make friends with your table neighbors!) with our respective Mexican beers and were immediately served up with some chips and creamy salsa. We each got burritos in a whole wheat tortilla and it completely changed the dynamic of what I'm used to, but not in a bad way: it was delicious!

I got the prawn super burrito (with guacamole, cheese, sour cream) and rice, black beans, and salsa. Since I let it sit for a minute, the bottom got all soggy* (tee hee), so I had to fork-n-knife it; it felt so, so wrong. The boy got the standard carne asada burrito, but was able to pick it up and eat it the proper way; he said it was excellent. 

All in all, very pleased with the quality of the food, but not really with the prices; with tip, I think I dropped a little less than $20 for a burrito and a beer. Worth it though, since the service was great, too.


*Most people came in to pick-up since they had called in. With the soggy-bottom debacle, I'm not sure if I'd be comfortable doing that. Besides, the line moved pretty quickly.
author: Adena B.

description:
I miss the days when my friend lived in the Mission.  There were so many great places for Mexican food!  This was the first place I found and wow did it not disappoint at all!

The first burrito I had was at Papalote and I ordered the carne asada.  Wow is the only thought that crossed my mind.  I have since tried all the carne asada, pescado and pollo meals here.  They are fantastic!  The menu is limited to mainly burritos, quesadillas and tacos.  The ones I've tried are all amazing.  The appetizers I had were all good as well.

I can't wait to come back!
author: Coy W.

description:
This used to be my favorite Mexican place in the city. It is now my least favorite. My prawn burrito had 4 prawns. Not enormous lobster like jumbo prawns. Just medium to regular sized prawns. As if that weren't enough, three of the four shrimp were at the bottom of the burrito, leaving me to navigate through five shrimpless bites of burrito nothingness.

After this experience I feel like this guy was talking about Papalote: https://medium.com/comedy-corner/fd08c0babb57

I want my money back.
author: Brian W.

description: I had high expectations for Papalote given the 1800+ reviews. However, I was pretty underwhelmed with my burrito. I ordered the Carne Asada burrito with no beans and made it super. The rice was mushy and the filling was not evenly distributed throughout the burrito. Some bites were all rice, some bites were all steak, some were all guac. The burrito came with chips and salsa. The chips were a little bland and the salsa was too mild for this spice-loving girl. Given that Papalote is right down the street from me I will probably give it another try, but I can't say I'll be craving this burrito like I do the Carne Asada San Francisco style at Tacko.
author: Angela C.

description: Don't waste your time and money!  I eaten better tacos and burritos at Taco Bell and  their food is nasty! The food at Glide is more tastey than the mess I paid  $43. for today.  Bobby Flay would have won the "Throw Down "had the judges tasted the food we were served today! Yuk,  yuk, yuk! NEVER AGAIN!
author: Vicki D.

description:
Papalote,

It's not me, it's you.

After a 10 year love affair, I am afraid I am taking the kids and leaving you.  You see, you have just steadily let yourself go.  At first, I started to ignore the warning signs.  The declining food quality, the increasingly shabby dining room, the non hygienic bathroom.  I chose to let all of this go because of that delicious, delicious salsa!  But now I am afraid, my last visit was the final straw.  I don't know if the Bobby Flay throw down went to your head or what, but the Papalote experience is just not the same anymore.  

During my last few visits, I have become increasingly aware of the strange 'renovations' to your dining room.  Not only have you oddly mixed Ikea modern with Mission Shabby, but you have also managed to cut off the dining room making the lineup for takeout awkward and claustrophobic.  You have also managed to ruin the one thing that made your restaurant hip and eclectic, a naked, no-frills mason-jar filled lovingly with the best salsa this side of La Paz. This 'insiders experience has since been cheapened by adding a label and hawking it by the register (as well as Whole Foods)!

And so for these very reasons, I must move on Papalote.  We had a torrid love affair for many, many years, and had some great times, but the fact of the matter is that I am simply no longer in love with you.

La Cumbre and El Farolito, how you doin'?
author: Trent L.

description:
After hearing all the reviews about this place and seeing it on Bobby Flay's show, thought it was time to give this place a try. I might have hyped this place up too much and I was a little bit disappointed. One mistake I made was to order something that the reviews were suggesting. Papalote is known for their Triple Threat Burrito and have high reviews on the prawn burrito, but I went with the Marinated Tofu. Typical me for always doing something different from the general population. The burrito was good, but it wasn't as good as the regular chicken burritos that I have had elsewhere. It feels like it's missing some sauce. It was really nice that Papalote is so generous with their ingredients and packed the burrito with beans, rice, sour cream, gracamole, and meat, but it tasted a bit on the dry side.

Their chips and salsa is good. Their house salsa is definitely their specialty. They sell them in jars at the restaurant. If I were to return, I will stick with what people like and try the prawn burrito.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I've been to this establishment twice and I have not been disappointed by any means. The food is always fresh and cooked perfectly, the ambiance is that of a tex-mex style restaurant, but the food is clearly in spirit of traditional Mexican style.  I always get the shrimp super burrito and I have no idea why since I'm usually not a fan of them, but this place just makes one DAMN GOOD shrimp Burrito.

The only draw back is that the place is small and the seating is so closely packed together that you're practically eating on top of the people seated next to you!! 

Still though,  I would definitely recommend anyone in the Bay Area to try this place out!!!
author: Michael F.

description:
Can I say BEST BURRITO in san francisco? this place is so delicious i don't even know what to say about it. 

my go-to burrito here is the grilled veggie one - i just love the fresh vegetables that they use and it's good to always make it SUPER (guac, sour cream, and cheese) and i usually get black beans and throw it into a spinach tortilla. nomtastic. the other burritos that are good are soy riso and chicken. so so so safe and such a solid meal for about $8. if you're not a big eater, you can always save half of it for later, which makes an amazing meal or even better - amazing drunk food! (haha)

their special sauce is tasty and if you want more, i believe its $0.50 for each extra cup of it. i would get more - i usually have a cup for just the chips, and another cup just for my burrito.

thank you sf for the best burrito in the world!!!!!! love you.
author: Priya G.

description:
I've read the reviews, I've tried there food, honestly I don't even know how this spot got such a high star rating, I give this place a bare 3 stars only reason I didn't give it 2 stars was there sauce they offered, that orange spicy sauce you sprinkle or dip on everything.

Ok here is what we tried:
Ultimate Burrito also know as the Triple Threat i was told- grade D+ there is no taste, they got 3 types of meats carne asada which was tender and juicy, shredded chicken decent size cut not dry but no flavor, the shrimp I think there were like 4 or 5 in it but they pile them all on one side so when you whatever side you start on if you get the shrimp enjoy it you will probably get maybe 4-5 bites in then no more shrimp haha.

we also tried there shrimp quesidilla- super oily, dipping it in the orange sauce gives it some flavor eating it alone you will need salt

The Chorizo Nacho Plate - this plate had to say is kinda what saved face for the restuarant for me but there was some dislikes, shady on the guac, sourcream, and even cheese camon now folks you get lets just say it is about maybe 3tsp of each sourcream & guac if you ask for more it is $1 more, condiments $1 more horrible but taste wise of the nachos with the chorizo and beans all good.

next time your out there just get the chorizo nachos don't spend $20+ for a burrito, there are plenty other mexican restuarants in the bay area you can go to and get 2 of the meats added for about $5-$8 same price but not 3meats.

Only reason I visited this place was due to Bobby Flay and his throwdown sad to say folks been to Bobby Flay's resturant in Vegas food there is blah literally bland and expensive, there are several other spots you can get a decent burrito in the city, this unfortunately is not one of them, if you do go stick with the chorizo nachos and try to get some of that togo orange sauce

ultimate burrito/ triple threat - FAIL ** at best only 2 stars
quesidilla ** super oily no taste drench it in the orange sauce then it makes it *** 1/2
chorizo nachos **** only thing i liked that i tried but it does have its flaws
service *** they are kinda fast
price $ moderate all around the board all $8 except for the triple threat/ultimate burrito $20+
ambiance *** small but clean, tiles on everything
author: Clarence A.

description:
One of the best in SF.

Carne asada super tacos are amazing.

If you don't agree it's a 5 star (hole in the wall kind of place) meal, you just might be a communist born without a sense of taste.
author: Steve J.

description: Best burrito's in SF for vegetarians and vegans, though a few dollars extra. Their signature papalote sauce is what keeps me coming back. It's also easy to call ahead and pickup your food, unlike El Farolito or La Taqueria.
author: Drew M.

description: Hell of a good burrito. The beans were delish. The rice was delish. The steak was perfectly med cooked. It was like every time I took a bite. The burrito was giving me a hug. Didn't get that "oh shit I ate too much' feeling. Seems like their burrito was made with not so greasy ingredients. Really solid burrito. Seen most people share the burrito for lunch.
author: Sun Y.

description:
Working with Korean and Mexican fusion food really has taken a toll on my view on burritos, quesadillas and the like. Don't get me wrong I love Mexican food with a passion. 

It was refreshing to come to a place that had everything right going on with their food, but somewhat unexpected. Hello? Whoevers idea it was to put Chicken Adobo in a burrito is quite amazing in my book.

The Chicken Adobo Burrito is not on the menu but was recommended by friends who've been to Papalote before and boy I'm glad they did. I can seriously eat Chicken Adobo plain and having it in my burrito was perfect. The portions here kinda big for a small girl like myself so I split half a burrito- great advice for those sharing a meal. Plus you get chips and dip complimentary before your meal! Be careful the dip is a bit spicy, but addicting.

Pair your meal with a Jarritos or Pure Cane Sugar Cola!

Though the food was delicious, our service kinda sucked to be honest. Half of the table got their food and decided to wait for the other half to receive their food. Probably 10 minutes later we asked 2 waiters about our food and said they'd check the kitchen only to come back saying it was coming out. The other half the table was famished beyond words to wait longer and finished. Then our food finally came out ... with no apology either. Huh? I guess so ... 4 stars for the food itself, service that's another question.
author: Janet N.

description:
Quick review- overprice, bad mole, one tortilla tacos, better off going to many other places.

A group of friends and I did a taco crawl.  6 or 7 places along 24th st.  This was the worst.  The ingredients were good but it lacked flavor and was the most expensive of all the places we went.  Up to 2x more in price than every other place and small too.  Plus the worst of all the worst is only one small ass tortilla per taco. I am native and never gotten a taco with only one tortilla. The mole was bland.  I gave them 2 stars cause the ingredients were good and there are veggie and vegan options but if you want a good taco, look anywhere else.  Take your hunger to El Faralitos or the truck at 23rd and Treat.  You will save money fill your belly and in the end be happier.
author: Bucky W.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? Well, "I could drink a bathtub full of their trademark salsa" may not be original, but that doesn't make it less true.

Also, their fish is buttery and scrumptious and their burritos make me hate burritos less.
author: Christina S.

description: We were going over to my sister's place in SF for lunch and she picked up some food from here for us to try.  I've always heard this place was really good and I couldn't wait to try it.  My husband and I got carne asada super burritos and my sister got the mexipino super burrito.  She also brought back some chips and salsa.  The burritos have lots of good flavor with a good amount of meat.  The salsa is soooo good!  My sister said it was made with habanero peppers but it wasn't too too spicy for me.  Next time I'm definitely going to buy a jar.
author: Charlene P.

description: Way better than their NoPa location! The service is much better and their guacamole actually wasn't rotten. I love that their burritos aren't greasy. Their ingredients are very fresh and they have a variety of options. The downside is the price. It's pretty expensive IMO for a burrito. Regardless, it's good and a great place to stop by if you're hungry and in the mission.
author: Hana K.

description: Another hipster touristy taqueria. I got the mole plate. It was as if it was stored for weeks. It was so dry. Not tasty. The meat was nearly a "powder" when I chewed it. My friends got steak tacos. They said they were decent but not excellent. This is a great place for out of towners and hipsters. I wrote this review because I spent nearly $20 on a mole plate and felt it was a complete waste. Do the cooks even taste what they are serving? How can you serve that? I'm positive it is not what the intent of a mole dish is supposed to be.
author: Joseph W.

description: This place has delicious salsa and guacamole - although I wish both were spicier. I am from LA so I am use to flavorful, authentic Mexican food. I got the carne asada burrito after seeing the award for "best burrito in SF". I haven't had many other burritos in SF so it's hard for me to judge this. I will say I was a little disappointed by the lack of food in my burrito. It was a huge burrito but mostly tortilla and rice and not much meat. Luckily the salsa and guacamole made the whole meal more enjoyable. Maybe I'll try tacos next time.
author: Kim Le P.

description:
I'm giving 4 stars coz I'm hooked with their famous salsa (more like sauce) oh how I love it. I bought 2 jars. 

this place was featured on foodnetwork's show throwdown with Bobby flay and mr. Iron chef challenged their triple threat burrito.so, we ordered it. beware on this $20.00 burrito cos it's very huge. It's good for 4. We liked it too.

I'm just not comfortable eating here. The place is small and I hate that the tables were too close to each other. You can easily bump the person eating next to you.
This place is not very easy to find either. There is no sign outside when we went there. 

Overall, I liked it but still not the best burrito... I'm a fan of their salsa though.
author: Cryszilla G.

description:
Love their salsa, but let's be honest: the rice is bland bland bland. I also wish they would serve the habanero salsa in house instead of making me buy a jar. 

What a nit-picky review this is!
author: Brittany L.

description:
I can't tell what the excitement is about. Had the carne asada burrito - low on flavor, too much rice, not enough beans. I left full and unsatisfied - the worst :-(

One star for just burrito. Two stars because the salsa *is* really good.
author: Jack M.

description:
When I first heard about Papalote's $19.95 burrito, I was like, "we should be running them outta the Mission instead of blowin' them up with 1000's of reviews." I get it, we're in America & the owners are well within their rights to embrace a little American greed & capitalism, but not at my expense.

So, after a little internal struggle ("Don't patronize them, there's better two blocks away & they don't rape you with their prices! But it could be oh-so-good. Why would Bobby Flay challenge them if it wasn't? Don't do it! DO IT!") I finally went  *hangs head in shame*

The bf & I ordered: 2 prawn tacos, 2 carne asada tacos (.99 cents extra to make them "super), & two bottled drinks. Total: under $21--well that wasn't too painful at all! 

The salsa is definitely unique--it is creamy without chunks of tomato. I tasted a lot of heat but not a lot of real, tomatoey flavor. It's a nice change from regular salsa. When the tacos arrived, we were surprised (not to mention disappointed) at how it is Fresh Mex instead of authentic Mexican. Zero grease, zero salt. It's very similar to La Salsa (maybe the lack of Latino patrons should have tipped us off...) There was nothing wrong with the flavors but it's obvious that this place caters to a specific demographic who's palates are not ready for some dirty, real, greasy Mexican goodness. Papalote is definitely a non-offensive, very polished version of Mexican food & no me gusta.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Plusses: lots of vegan options, meat is made to order (not in buffet trays), house salsa is tasty, fresh guac, fresh ingredients

Wish they: were way way cheaper ($20 for the throw down winner, the triple threat?? For real? And $7 for guac?), had more spacious quarters, had bigger portions, gave more than one small plastic cup of house salsa

Definitely worth a try to experience the hype. But not affordable enough to warrant a frequent trip. I just can't understand paying on average $9 for a medium sized burrito, even if the vegan options are plentiful.
author: Debora L.

description:
That creamy smoky salsa is perfect.  There's almost nothing else like it. In fact, it's a closely guarded treasure. You only get one little cup of salsa and extra salsa will cost you.  The guacamole is average, the marinated chicken is fantastically tender.  Slightly more costly than your typical grullenese. 

I'm tempted to buy their prepacked salsa, however, I'm not sure if its the same stuff.  Overall, a great burrito.
author: Christian W.

description:
We came to this place when some friends from out of town came visiting and mentioned that they would like to eat at this place. Sure, always up for some Mexican!

There's a small counter where you order your meal and the rest is dedicated to seating. There's not much space so you may have to wait to find an open table as this place gets busy. It's a colorful interior.

I like carne asada anything probably, so plumped for the burrito. The tacos also looked extremely tasty. My burrito was pretty good and I finished it without issue.
I think the hold back for me is that you can get equally good food in the Mission without having to wait so long.

Perhaps due to it's popularity, it's also on the pricier side.
author: Nick L.

description:
The salsa is like crack! Seriously, the best salsa and burritos I have ever had.

I was in town from DC and was told to go to this place. I did on the way to the airport. I had half of the burrito for dinner and then the other half for breakfast right before my plane landed.

The service forgot my order, but, made-up for it by giving me a freebee on the next visit. The only problem I have is that they don't have one of these in DC :(

I'll be back...
author: Jason M.

description:
This restaurant & the review for this place is misleading. My bf and I decided to try this place out since it has a lot of good reviews. As soon as we got there and saw how the place looked we should've turned around and just went to another taqueria we always go. Once we ordered the girl wasn't even listening to what we were trying to order and looked lost. The girl didn't even know what carne asada was.. Fail. 

We ordered a carne asada burrito and  a coke, for two people it was $26.00. When we got our ordered we were surprised, we got chips w/ some type of sauce.. What happened to the salsa? And the burrito? Well it was big, not wrapped in a foil so it was hard to eat... And no I am not about to eat a burrito with a fork & a knife. The meat? Well it didn't taste anything, it was dry and hard to chew. I could only taste the avocado. The burrito tasted too bland, I had to put hot sauce and mix it with the sauce they gave me to have some flavor into the burrito, but still it didn't taste any good either. I wasn't even able to finish it. Honestly this place reminds me of Chipotle- Americanized Mexican food. I rather go to Chipotle since their meat has more flavor. Never am I going back to this place. It's truly a hipster place. So if you really want authentic Mexican food, go to La Taqueria or El Farolito.
author: Shay C.

description:
This is probably my favorite burrito place, due to their vegetarian friendliness.  (I wish that 90% of "vegetarian" burritos in this city weren't filled with lard and chicken stock.)  Sure, I liked it better before it was overflowing with Mission hipsters, but what can you do...

The salsa is awesome and those teeny tiny containers aren't nearly big enough.  I really hope I don't find out that its secret ingredient isn't beef or something, cause I do love it. 

The only downside is its priciness.  If only there was a way to get tofu/soyrizo AND veggies without it costing so much!  No matter what I order I end up overspending.  And if I'm getting really nit-picky, I have noticed the burritos have been pretty rice-heavy lately.

Tip: If you eat in, your burrito won't be wrapped in foil, so you'll be risking the always embarrassing burrito "spill-out" all over your plate.
author: J K.

description:
My sleep cycle is all messed up...I get more rest on the weekends sleeping for 3 hours than on the weeknights sleeping for 6 hours. Erm, must be the alkie? :X  

It's 1 AM on Thursday Morning and while I should be "attempting" to sleep, my eyes are glued to  an episode of "Throwdown w/ Bobby Flay". For 26 minutes, my mouth was salivating at the thought of meeting the "Triple Threat" one day; needless to say, it was another sleepless night. *sigh*

My friends and I came here yesterday at 12ish and luckily, we came at just the right time before it started getting busy.

FOOD:
*Chips & Salsa (#46 on the 7x7 list): The chips were slightly warm, thin, and crisp with just the right amount of salt. Ahhhhh, the salsa....the BEST freaking salsa EVER! The salsa was emulsified to perfect creamy consistency. As it hits your palette and moves around your mouth, you can taste all the fresh ingredients (the charred tomatoes, garlic, onion, chilies, and cilantro) sink into your taste buds. It had the perfect blend of savory, smokiness, acidity, and fiery kick to it! This is the ONLY thing that lives up to the HYPE!

*Triple Threat (super w/ sour cream & guac): HOLY MOLEY! $20 for a freaking burrito?!?!? The burrito was a regular size burrito that you would find from any taqueria. It was generously filled with rice, chicken, carne asada, and shrimp. The rice was al-dente and the chicken breast, carne asada, and shrimp were perfectly grilled, well-seasoned, and tender. The sour cream and guac are a must as it added a slight tartness and creaminess to balance out all the flavors.

*Ode to Poleng Adobe Burrito: FAIL! If you're expecting the garlicy, peppery soysauce vinegary taste that makes your lips pucker type of Adobo, you will be sadly disappointed. The chicken lacked all the components of what an adobo should be and was not well-seasoned. Errr, where was the garlic friend rice? The rice used was the standard burrito rice. The tortilla was the only thing that stood out. It was different from the typical tortilla used; it was crisp and flaky. All in all, the burrito lacked any real flavor and was quite dry b/c there was no sauce or salsa in it).

DRINKS:
Papalote has a selection of sodas, juices, and Mexican beer. I have to note that their refrigeration system was not working properly yesterday as our drinks were room temperature.

PRICES:
WAY OVERPRICED! A regular burrito is about $8 and an extra $1 to make it super (sour cream and guac). The size of their regular burritos are quite small (approx 7' and 2.5' in diameter) compared to other taquerias in The Mission.

Although the Triple Threat was good; it was NO where near a $20 good! To me, Mexican food is just like Chinese food; you shouldn't have to pay much to get good-tasting food. And, I really think the "hype" has allowed Papalote to capitalize on its customers by charging such ludicrous prices. 

SERVICE:
Order your food at the counter, grab a number, and the server will being you your order when it's ready. The chips and salsa came first and it took about 15 minutes to get our burritos.    

AMBIANCE: 
Very funky hipster type feel with the bright red walls with colorful panting and reggae music playing in the background. 

PARKING: 
Difficult street parking around Valencia and Mission streets. However, Guerrero street seemed to have some available non-metered spots. 

Would I return? I would only return for the chips and salsa. Other than that, Papalote is WAY OVERYHYPED and OVERPRICED. I say bottle the salsa and bring it with you to the other taquerias like Pancho Villa or El Toro where you can get a freshly grilled steak and shrimp burrito for 2/3 of the price.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
You try to make good decisions in life, you try to be a good person. But then you are caught in a moment of weakness, after having flown across the country, jetlagged and slightly hungover. You arrive at Papalote with the intention of eating "something light" and just to "try it and see what the fuss is about" and then head to a fancy, heavy dinner. You arrive soon after it opens, around 11:30am, full of optimism and good intentions.

Then your dining partner orders a super burrito and all hell breaks loose. Soon you are ordering the chorizo con queso and a breakfast special and extra beans and you get the complimentary chips (2 bowls of them!) with that special salsa. You inhale the chips and then the chorizo con queso comes and my god that's a lot of cheese and fresh tortillas. There is not much hope for you at that point. The food is good. The food is very, very good. You, oh reader, must know this because you have already come to this page and you have come this far. Just travel a bit further and arrive at Papalote and make your own bad (but so good) consumption choices.

Long story short, we canceled our dinner plans and, after several hours of digesting, am still wondering how Papalote got the best of me. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Annie M.

description: Love Papalote although the line can be a nightmare and sometimes I wonder she it became acceptable to pay $9 for a burrito.  Still their tofu burrito is very yummy and the salsa rocks.
author: maren n.

description: This place is a joke. The burritos they serve are an embarrassment to their Mission counterparts. I should have known when I saw soy chorizo on the menu that this dive is nothing but another HIPSTER hangout. Hated it!
author: R D.

description: Paid $14.68 for two Pacifico beers. A little over priced especially since the microbrew down the block charged $12 for 2 higher quality brews . $.50 each if you want any extra salsa. Other places are free! Chicken Burrito was ok but had better down the block. Got the other burrito wrong too. Nickel and dime customers. Lady behind the customer had attitude.
author: Fred O.

description: Great food, super tasty, it can get busy in the evening. So be prepared for a short queue.
author: Radoslaw D.

description:
From the "That's what she said" joke potential to the succulent flavor, I love [almost] everything about meat.

So you can imagine what I'm about to say is very difficult, but it's also a testimony to how skilled Papalote is at making a healthier alternative not taste like feet.

That being said, the best thing I've tried on this menu is actually the soyrizo (soy chorizo)!  I tried a piece of the soyrizo quesadilla, and was very pleasantly surprised.  It was well seasoned, and the texture was not weird.  I think this dish will be my go-to from now on!

OTHER DISHES I'VE TRIED:
1. Chips and salsa - this is on the 7x7 100 things to try list.  The salsa was really good and different than any other salsa I've tasted, but I still think the soyrizo was more stand-out.
2. Carne asada fajitas - huge portion, and came with lots of veggies including eggplant.  Awesome!
3. Carne asada burrito - 2 days later and reheated via microwave...and STILL tasty!
4. Jicama salad - usually comes on the side with your meal, and refreshingly delicious!  

LIKES:
1. Large portions 
2. Leftovers still tasty 2 days later
3. Lots of veggie alternatives
4. Seems more health conscious than the average taqueria

DISLIKES:
1. Dine in was crowded...you'd probably be annoyed/displeased if you're claustrophobic.  You can phone in orders though.
2. Prices are a bit higher than what you'd expect to find at other Mexican places in the Mission - the steak fajitas were $13.95!  (and I think the carne asada at both El Farolitos is tastier...but then you can just get the soyrizo!)
author: Alice C.

description:
Tried Papalote Mexican Grill for the first time It truly  was the Best Burrito I ever had! Amazing Flavors, with every bite each one kept getting more Delicious !!! Usually I could only eat half of a burrito and take the other half home. Not this time so Yummy!
I highly recommend this gem of a place I look forward for the next visit!
author: Sera O.

description:
Two words: Mexipino burrito. 

Quite possibly the best burrito I have ever had. The secret ingredient is Garlic Fried Rice. It is sticky and soft and SO flavorful. It combines magically with the Filipino style Adobo Chicken and guacomole. Absolutely, mouth wateringly delicious.
author: Serena Q.

description:
A MEXIPINO dish?

Thanks to a tip from the cuzzos and back by popular demand, the ever popular Adobo Burrito was available. It was only going to be available on Saturday, February 6th (Same as Giants Fan Fest Day) but it was so popular, they extended it another day. 

Worked out for me since we pretty much spent the whole day at the ballpark that Saturday. Come Sunday, after work, the wifey and my youngest picked me up from work and went straight here. Ordered three Adobo Burrito to go and was expecting something awesome. However, it fell kinda flat since it was missing the fat. 

Dude....you need to add the fat to get some flavor in here. The protein was on the lean and dry side too, and it was just OK. The saving grace was the Hot Sauce that came with the chips. I couldn't stop shoving them in my mouth.

But this review is for the Adobo Burrito and we will be back to try their regular menu.

But I give em props for thinking out of the box.
author: John G.

description:
I went here yesterday with my mom and aunt for the first time.  We all got burritos.  They had fish and I had veggie.  We all thought the food was fresh and excellent.  Amazing.  And no lard or animal fats in anything, I really trust them.  The place was super busy, but had a fun vibe to it.  

So why only 4 stars?  We all agreed that we thought the prices were too high.  but then again, if I was the owner of a place that was that popular I would raise the prices too.  So I will go back here anytime, food was great.  But only if I don't have to pay.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Came at the perfect time...2:30ish on a Tuesday. Found FREE parking right around the corner and it wasn't crowded at all. 

To put it simply, I am burrito-skeptic. I feel like there is no such thing as an AMAZING burrito. I've tried La Taqueria's but I still found it to be a "non-craving" burrito...so I usually stick to tacos or quesedillas. I decided to give Papalote's burrito a chance since I saw all these awards for it in the restaurant. I ordered the Mexipino since i LOOOOVE Filipino food. The adobo chicken in it was flavorful and moist and the burrito overall wasn't bland by any means. The garlic rice in it wasn't too garlicy either, but in a good way. 

Thank you Papalote for being my go to burrito spot! Finally!
author: Adlyn S.

description:
Oh man, that orange salsa.... SO GOOD! I buy it by the jarful at Whole Foods and dump it on everything at home. Sure it's expensive, but it's way better than Frontera or any of that other hoity-toity stuff that tries to pass for gourmet salsa. Based on the quality of their salsa, I was very excited to try the Papalote restaurant in the Mission today!

Papalote is a small restaurant on a largely residential block of 24th street. It's conveniently located a couple of blocks from the 24th & Mission BART stop and also a block away from a good friend's house. If I'd known it was this close, I would have gone numerous times already! Inside the restaurant are a handful of tables next to a large window which offers a good people watching view of the street outside. You order at the counter up front and then take a number and sit down.

I ordered a carne asada burrito with beans and rice. The burrito was about average in size, but that's ok because I don't like overeating these days. The contents were very tasty with plenty of grilled beef and flavorful rice and beans. I only had one funny bit of gristle in the burrito, so I would call that a rousing success for the Bay Area. They also give you tasty chips and a cup of their salsa before the meal. HOWEVER, if you want more salsa to go with your meal, it costs an additional fifty cents for each refill. WTF?! Most places load you up on salsa without an additional charge. This is something they really should consider since it seems a little chintzy of them.

My two lunch friends had the pork chile verde tacos and the fish burrito. The tacos looked good, but seemed to be piled high with garnish which seemed a little weird. If I order the tacos in future, I'll get them with just meat and tortilla. The fish burrito looked like a winner and my friend swears by it, so I'm either getting that next time or trying the machaca which is hard to find in the Bay Area!

Papalote is a very clean, stylish restaurant. Food gets delivered quickly and the staff are all super nice. I'll definitely come back again, but maybe I'll bring my own Papalote salsa from home if they're going to charge me for salsa!
author: Jason W.

description:
Order at front and get seated.  They'll bring you warm tortilla chips and "salsa" to your table.  The "salsa" isn't your typical chopped tomatoes and onion but very spicy roasted tomato dip.

We ordered the mole chicken tacos and chile verde with pork.  The tortillas were super soft and not dried out.  The tomatoes and lettuce on top were very fresh.  The chile verde was just YUMMY!  The mole was a bit over powering and thick.  This is the best taco in town!  Will come back again for sure!
author: Irene C.

description: Loved the soyriso. Just a cute little Mexican restaurant with yummy vegetarian options and amazing vegan salsa that is uber creamy.
author: J A.

description:
All I can say it Fish Tacos!!!

Wow they were amazing. The sauce is pretty good too. I am not one for big burritos and such but looking at peoples plates they looked like a handful. Unfortunately, I went on the day that they closed the street down, I think Sunday at 12. 

Great food. Go there.
author: Rondi J.

description:
A friend suggested Papalote to me, claiming they were some of the best tacos in the Mission.  Since I was meeting a friend for lunch, I decided we would check them out.  The place is cute, small, and very clean.  You walk in and are immediately in front of a large wall mounted menu and the registers. 

For lunch I decided to try the grilled tofu tacos.  I was surprised when they came out and there was only one tortilla underneath.  It was difficult to eat as a taco since they were loaded up with vegetables and tofu.   Overall they were good but the tofu was a bit odd (I've never had grilled tofu before).  My friend was happy with his carne asada tacos and promptly devoured them.

We ordered the guacamole appetizer which was far too large for two people.  If you have four it would be more appropriate.  We left about half of our guac in the bowl (I hate letting deliciousness go to waste).
