The price was appropriate for tacos ($6.25 for two).  We were fortunate to find a table with a nice family on the other end so the communal tables wasn't an issue  I'll probably return to Papalote, although I'll avoid the tofu and go for another of their meat selections.
author: Michelle K.

description: Papalote's is not my favorite burrito in San Francisco but I can't fault anyone who claims that it's theirs. They definitely know what they're doing here and offer a plethora of options for meat lovers and vegetarians alike. I'm of the pescetarian nature myself and flip flop through the various veggie options (grilled veggie, tofu mole, etc., etc.). Lots of points for customizability (beans, tortillas, tacos/quesadillas/burritos). When I have out of town guests visiting I often take them to Papalote's for a SF super mission burrito experience.
author: Stephen S.

description: Good burrito - great secret sauce! Small space - worth the wait. Doesn't beat Freebirds :(
author: Andy D.

description:
WOW Salsa owns.

Spicy, THICK, and SO delicious.

THICK, juicy, nicely charred, chunky pieces of prawns tighlty wrapped in my whole wheat tortilla burrito ... smothered in that amazing salsa = MM MM GOOOOOOD!!  We got there around 6ish and beat the crazy lines that started forming around 7.  Small but cozy restaurant with friendly and fast service.  They have the classic bottled cokes :) yay  

Don't sit at the table next to the bathroom.....everytime someone opened the door and it closed, the stanky air was forced in our faces.  Def had to hold my breath...boo.  Perhaps getting to-go is the best option for this place on busy nights.  Call in.  

STILL LOVE TLALOC'S SALSA, THO!  This place doesn't have a salsa bar...nor do they have pitchers of ice water like Tlaloc does...just tiny ass cups.....that you have to refill by going to the cash rep area....they charge for extra salsa, too....meh.  But dang good burrito's.
author: Kat C.

description: I would give this zero stars if I could. The horchata was gritty and warm. The chilsquiles were way too salty. What a waste of a meal.
author: Sandra C.

description: Average and expensive burrito, no flavorful nor traditional like La Taqueria on mission st. Found a whole side of avocado inside steak burrito, oddly enough it was not ripe and impossible to bite or cut with knife as it was very hard. Lots of rice and beans but not a fair amount of meat, which was also prepared in a way that it dry out, taking away flavor and texture. White fish tacos...will simply put; blend, no seasoned and not worthy the high pricey tag!  The only bright side is; they have great friendly customer service. Anyhow! I'm Walking to La Taqueria now to get the real deal! Yay
author: Sabrina B.

description: Love. Best burrito. Period. Best salsa. Fresh. The service is good. I love this place...
author: Astrid C.

description:
This ain't your run-of-the-mill taqueria ova here.

Papalote kicked Bobby Flay's ass on Throwdown and for good reason, their burritos are the bomb yo!

Everything is made to order. That's right, made to order. Grilled fresh in front of yo face! The steak and chicken isn't made in mass quantities and dumped into containers to be heated under a lamp or in hot water.  Everything is flame grilled when you order it and you can taste it.

To top everything off is Papalote's world famous salsa. The salsa is so good that it has it's own Twitter page (http://twitter.com/papalotesalsa) and it has more followers than me! The salsa is a taste of pure evilness with a side of quintessential bliss.

I heart burritos.
author: Ed C.

description:
Wow. Yippee. Delish. Yummers. As a vegetarian friendly gal, (I eat the fishes, cause, well you know, so I can't claim full veggie status) I am in LOVE with their soyrizo burrito. I buy soyrizo from TJs and make it at home, but the balance and the spiciness they achieve is just out of this world. 

Also, the creamy/saucey/spicey/what the HECK do they put in that saucy sauce is also mind blowing.

So for the record, that's 1--out of this world reference and 1--mind blowing reference...which if you haven't already garnered means this place is pretty flippin' good!
author: Shira O.

description:
I'm not going to say it was the best burrito I've had, but I ate the whole damn thing! 

That's an not only a sign of a great burrito, it's also accomplishment. I never eat a whole burrito, not even on my hungriest day. It was a Chicken Asada Burrito with Cheese and Guacamole, practically a super no less. 

So I was told to get an "extra"salsa, which they will change extra for. I wish I would have known that it was going to be that great - I would have doubled up that order.

The wait was not long at all. I'm not bothered to wait for a few minutes to get hot, freshly prepared food - after all, I'd like to think of this as a healthier alternative to fast food joints.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Soyrizo & egg burrito, all day every day.  

I crave it if I don't have once every couple of weeks.  It be callin me man that sh** just be callin me!
author: Von W.

description: First off, their sauce is aweeesome.. I was sweating. Free chips and salsa which is a plus in my book. I ordered the chicken salad with the cilantro sauce. Yummy! It is one of the hardiest salads I have ever eaten. You'll be full guaranteed. We ordered the shrimp and streak super burrrito. Delicious! Its large. Massive food coma afterwards no doubt. Last note, the triple threat is not made for 1!
author: Lauren H.

description: Pretty tasty though I'd say basically on par with any of the (more casual) taquerias in the area. It's pretty sweet that each person gets a bowl of chips and dip for themselves. The place is cute with original artwork for sale, but pretty small so arrive early for a table.
author: Elicia R.

description:
My bf was craving burritos ever since he moved to the east coast, so when we were visiting SF this past month, he wanted to check this place out. I ordered the Super (which is sour cream, cheese, guacamole for 99 cents extra) Pollo Burrito (grilled to order chicken breast) for about $8.50 plus tax. It was a hefty size. Not huge not small (maybe 6 or 7 in long, 4 in thick). The chicken wasn't too dry (which is good for me) and the extras were somewhat adequate, but for my personal taste I would've wanted more guacamole and cheese :p The tortilla itself was slightly crispy, not too soft at all which is what I'm used to. And the burrito was wrapped nicely, but if you aren't in the mood to pig out in public, they provide you with knife and fork to eat it more in a more domesticated fashion :p 

The ambiance: almost cramped. The ordering space is quite small. You walk in, and the registers are right there. There's a sign saying wait to be seated, but I don't think that should be there because you actually look for seating and seat yourself. It's cafeteria style seating. We went around 2-3pm ish and it was busy. We were lucky to find three spots open. 

When you sit, someone serves you and each of your party with yummy homemade? tortillas and spicy salsa. And if you don't feel like spending extra money on a soda, they offer "get it yourself" water and small washable cups in the corner. I can vouch that they're clean. And if you want your burrito to go, there's foil wrap next to the water. The service was nice. Friendly.

If I wasn't already full I would've devoured my burrito T_T
author: Geraldine T.

description: Talk about an overpriced mediocre burrito... confusing menu and storage items when walk into the place.
author: Lauren S.

description: Their burritos and pretty good, and their salsa is very good.   I live down the street and used to go here frequently, but after seeing a large rat (the size of a small cat) coming out the back door, I've stopped going here.
author: Reed M.

description: Went back a second time - ordered exactly the same thing, got something completely different.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Great place for some Tex Mex food! The food is decent and the prices are moderate. this was the first place I ever tried horchata, and I am still a fan.

The real bonus to this restaurant is being connected to a parking garage, for the area it is in, and to have guaranteed parking you can not beat that.

I personally have a couple other favorites, however if your in a hurry or with someone who HATES parking situation in SF, this may be the place to go.

XOXO
author: Noelle L.

description:
My friends and I were in the city early. We decided early on what we needed to eat for later so we wouldn't go super hungry. My friend wanted to try Papalote for their burritos. My other friend said that they were featured on a show by Bobby Flay on the Food Network and Papalote won the challenge....... Ok. Let's go! The food must be really good then.

Just a few weeks ago, I was walking up the hill on 24th. I remember seeing Papalote. There was no sign..... It looks like they are renovating... the only way to find this place if you had the address because there was a paper on the window with the address... The inside looked like it was being renovated as well.

When we entered, we ordered at front. One of my friends wanted In-N-Out instead, so we ordered to-go.... but one of my friend's burrito took 20 minutes to be finished, so my other friend had to order from here. We also decided to stay and eat at the restaurant because we were not going anywhere else for a while, and we were STARVING.

I ordered a rice and bean burrito on a whole wheat tortilla. I was super happy to see the have the whole wheat option. Not many places I go to have that option of tortillas. It was a pretty good size. Not too big or small. Well... it was actually too big for me. I ended up saving a third of it for later. I also got complementary chips and salsa with the order.

About the salsa.... OMG IT WAS SO GOOD! It wasn't too spicy, but it had enough of a kick for me to enjoy it. It was perfect.

By the way, my burrito was really good, but it wasn't super tasty. The pinto beans I had were kind of dry. I can see myself coming here for a burrito... but not anytime soon... Or at least when I come back to the city one day. I don't live here... :(

I was really satisfied with the burrito. I was happy after eating it. If that ever happens with my meal, I'm so coming back.

The dining area is SUPER small and crowded. There is a wait if you want to eat here. I'd rather take it to go, but for the experience, it is best if you stay here. I really liked the feel of the restaurant.

I totally recommend coming here for a burrito. Yummy! :)
author: Terri L.

description: Definitely a fan. Order for pickup at least twice per month. Tacos, burritos, burrito bowl, and quesadilla are all fantastic. And lets not forget the really great and distinct salsa.
author: Ryan P.

description: Wow that was delicious. Had a carne asada burrito with the works. The salsa is amazing too
author: Benny B.

description: So so so slow and marginal at best. Place is nearly empty and it took 30 min for a burrito. I had time to download the yelp app set up an account and wrote this review while waiting. Do yourself a favor and go down the street to El faralito for better burritos for 1/2 the price.
author: Morgan H.

description:
I like that Papalote is easy to get to from work, for a quick bite at lunchtime. Parking is usually pretty easy, both metered and residential. There is always a lot of people around, and it may take a while until you get your order placed. Always helps to know what you want when they're ready to take your order.

Last time I was there, I switched it up and got a Chile Verde (pork) burrito. It was humongous and very good, topped with guacamole, sour cream and the works.

I usually go for the prawn quesadillas, that is my usual menu go-to item at Papalote. All their items are well under $10, which makes me a fan!

TIP: must try the chips and homemade salsa, it's got a fiery, roasted taste to it. Delicious!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Dear Papalote,

Your chips suck. They're terrible. But your salsa is divine! How can you insult such magnificent salsa with such subpar chips?! It is an insult to the perfection of that salsa. 

Food is pretty damn good. Love that it is healthy and vegetarian-friendly. 

But how 'bout you look into improving those chips?
author: Joyce G.

description: An expensive $10 mediocre burrito in the mission and no salsa bar? And you have to pay more if you want sauce? Plus there is nowhere to sit because the place is so small. Go to El Farolito for a good true San Francisco Mission burrito.
author: James S.

description: As a burrito lover this place is the most mediocre of mediocre. Don't believe the hype and waste your time in this overpriced burrito. Grab yourself a deliciously marinated, grilled to perfection, carb ridden baby at El Farolito or Taqueria Guadalajara instead. Being raised in SF, I guess I'm spoiled with authentic taquerias. This place is almost comparable to chipotle. Mediocre and boring
author: Aundria G.

description: Pretty good, not worth the hype or price. Plenty of other places with much more reasonable prices. Food isnt bad
author: Rigo J.

description: Meals comes with free chips and a unique salsa. Sat by the window on  a hot day, let the cold breeze in, and sucked down a cold corona with my steak tacos. One meal is two tacos and they are bulky. I recommend paying the extra dollar for cheese, guac, and sour cream. Fast service, cool vibe and clean. Thanks, I'll be coming again.
author: Tim L.

description: As a vegetarian,  this place is awesome!!  I got the  tofu burrito and it was amazing.  The salsa was also to die for!   Can't wait to try the soy chorizo burrito!
author: Rosh S.

description:
My first excursion to Papalote today was pretty good.

This is actually 3.5 stars, rounded down because, well, 4 stars means it's got to be really solid, and Papalote's kind of there, but just not quite. 

Some observations, aite here we goes:

1. They take card.  Woot! For a moment, after I stepped in, I panicked because I thought I wouldn't be able to get a burrito since I hardly ever carry around cash.  But phew!  They do!  And then I said to myself, "Oh silly, of COURSE they take card!  Gringo burrito place, duh!"  

2. I got a chicken mole super burrito for $7.93.  The mole was pretty good, as was all the other fillings:
+ Cheese = MELTED, I approve.
+ Black Beans = Soft and flavorful, good job there!
+ Chicken = Shredded and tender perfect chompos for me to eats!  
+ Guac = Mush! Texture, flavor, aesthetically pleasing.  Who doesn't like avocados?
+ Rice = Soft, just right. 

3.  Good location, close to the 24th/Mission BART.  Even though I work in the FiDi, I can easily BART here and back during a lunch break and still have time to spare.  

4.  Hipster paradise indeed.  There were two very nice girls in front of me, with cute bags and flowy skirts and interesting hair.  Such a nice, appropriate place for the hipsters, hippies, and happy white people.  

5.  So, I tried their chips and salsa finally.  It's on that 7x7 "100 Things to Eat in SF" list.  There must be something wrong with my taste buds.  The chips were not that great, nothing special.  You want awesome chips?  Tropisueno's got awesome chips!  The salsa, however, was bangin'.  Unfortunately, I can't take the heat, and one tiny taste set my entire mouth on fire.  It was good, yes, but painful.  

So, why the 3.5 stars?  This review seems to suggest a solid 4, maybe more, right?  Well, I mean, I definitely LIKED my burrito, but it was just...not totally 100% there. . .  

You know what I mean?  Imagine meeting a person, or attending a class, and even though he/she/it is perfectly fine and nice and all, you're just not blown away.  

And you could go either way, go with it, or not.  That's kind of how I felt about Papalote after my meal.  Certainly a decent meal, but I'm not about to jump around recommending it to everyone I know.  

No, no, that shameless plugging is still reserved for my all-time favorite, El Farolito. 

But Papalote?  Eh, she's alright.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Pretty damn delicious  burritos and the salsa is as good as all the reviews say. We had no problems with service or anything taking too long, but maybe that was because we went at on off time?

I can't say definitively whether Papalote wins the Great SF Burrito-off (I'm pretty sure the victor will change based on your mood / current level of inebriation) but this is a damn good contender.
author: Irina Z.

description:
After some deep self-reflection, I've decided that I'm not really a fan of traditional burritos. 

The first inklings came when we tried the carne asada burrito at Papalote. This was one of the burrito-eater's top-rated burritos, consistently scoring over 8.5 mustaches on each review but I didn't think it was anything special. 

I had the same experience again at El Farolito and again at Taqueria Cancun, two of the other Mission burrito heavyweights. They were good burritos, but not something I'd actively covet.

Why wasn't I impressed by any of these burritos? It kind of bothered me. 

I started to think about burritos that I liked in the past: the chicken tinga and al pastor burritos from Maya's (RIP) and the burritos from La Vic's in San Jose and Los Morenos in San Mateo. I remembered that the Maya's burritos were special because they were juicy and had unique sweet and spicy flavor combinations. La Vic's and Los Morenos had average burritos but both places provided amazing orange sauce that you could slather on in between each bite. 

Then I understood why even the best traditional burritos don't offer enough to keep me interested: I like my burritos to be sweet, spicy, and moist and cheesy enough to keep everything together. 

Sorry, Papalote. You're good, but I think I'm in a place where I need a sauced up burrito.

If anyone has any recommendations, send them over!
author: James Y.

description:
Best Mexican I've had since I moved to San Francisco.  The chorizo quesadillas were so delicious and the homemade salsa, there are no words for.  

The place is tiny so make sure you aren't going during prime lunch hours.

Love this place!
author: Lauren P.

description:
The best (and only) Adobo Burrito I've ever had is from Papalote's secret menu!  I thought I was over Mexican food since Mexican food is so overexposed in the Mission, but Filipino fusion helps breath new vida into it.  The non-Filipino fusion food is good, but not by as large a margin.

Adobo Burrito: This was my reason for coming here and it did not disappoint.  The chicken was even more fall apart tender than the traditional Mexican options.  The adobo flavor was thankfully high on the garlic, soy and pepper while not getting overly vinegary.  No beans because that would have been weird.  The garlic rice was a nice touch to add an extra bit of zing.  What a great, portable way to enjoy Filipino food!  Now if only they'd do pork adobo...

Chicken Mole: Chocolatey and pasty, this is pretty decent mole.  The chicken was a tad firm, perhaps they should stew it longer?

Refried Beans: I liked the concept of refried black beans because pintos usually get all the refrying action.  Heavier than the pinto though.

Rice: Standard.  Was disappointed with my side since the garlic rice in the adobo burrito was way better!

Chips & Salsa: Pretty nice for free (with purchase of a meal).  The chips were standard, but the salsa was great!  Smoky and creamy.  No wonder why people rave about this compared to the more standard varieties all over the Mission.
author: Adam B.

description: Happened to catch the feature of Papalote on the Food Network so I thought I would give it a try.  I have to say I'm pretty disappointed in their burrito.  I ordered the carne asada super burrito.  The meat was so tough I had to spit it out into my napkin.  It was very difficult to chew.  Their chips were complementary but were stale. Their salsa was ok.  I probably will not be returning to this spot. I should have gone to El Farlito instead.
author: Leen B.

description:
My only complaint is I can't try anything else on the menu b/c the Carne Asada Super Burrito is so damn good.  That and I always forget my burrito club card.

But seriously, at the risk of losing my cred: best non Chipotle burrito I've had. And thats after 4 years in SD and 1 in the Mission in SF.
author: Phillip W.

description: Being from Vegas we wanted to ask the locals where we had to eat. The burritos here were amazing. Something about the flavors made the average food defiantly not average. The salsa was my favorite though. I have already been online to purchase a shipment for home!
author: Lauren W.

description: This place is not spectacular Mexican food. I don't understand its popularity. It's okay, but it's not great.
author: Will D.

description:
I've been ordering from Papalote since they first opened. They were one of the first to offer a burrito with tofu, and tasty grilled with their delicious salsa at that! It was a little more pricey than most places at that time, but it was exceptional quality. The Brothers who ran it were generally around and involved in the operation. As they expanded and became more successful, the quality slipped and the size of the burritos became more meager. To spend close to $10 for a vegetarian burrito was a little tough to take!

I'm happy to say that the last 2 burritos I've had are back to the quality they began with and are larger than ever!
author: Broach M.

description:
Ohhh Papalote! The burrito you serve is ahhh-mazing!  

I ordered a super steak burrito.. I mean cmon! A super determines if the burrito is good or not! Let me tell you, probably the BEST burrtio.. actually no, the 2nd BEST burrito I've tried in San Francisco. Like the comment below, it definitely is not as authentic as El Farlito but this places has their own bars! 

The sauce they have.. simply just makes the burrito even better! And the Salsa for their chips.. perfect. Definitely recommend this place if you love burritos!
author: Lianne D.

description: My first time at Papalote and it was soooo worth it!! The art, music and vibe was dope. I ordered the Mexipino Burrito and inhaled it..listen when you order this you will understand PLUS the salsa was so on point. Will make sure to always go back to eat at Papalote EVERY time i come to SF.
author: Matt K.

description:
I was a regular at Papalote for years - I came here specifically for the carne asada burrito (walking past numerous other burrito places) and gladly (well maybe gladly is a bit strong) handed over $12 for a burrito with actual steak in it. And I'm talking about a quality cut of meat, charred with epic flavor.

About a month or so ago they changed the cut they use and how they prepare it, so now it's just another typical burrito with questionable meat - very grizzly with mediocre  flavor. I can get the equivalent for $7 elsewhere. 

The change was immediately apparent but I continued to go there for my weekly burrito. After about month or so of this, no more I say.  I hoped they'd finally realize how inadequate  there carne asada now is, but no luck - the low-quality meat seems to be here to stay. So disappointing. I'll just have to find my new favorite elsewhere.

Also, on a side note: what's the deal with piling all the meat on one end of the burrito? I know they're really busy back there but spreading it out would take about 0.5 extra seconds per order.

Again, so disappointed to give up Papalote. I'm going to miss what it once was.
author: Jon C.

description:
Rocks in my burrito!  One was 1/4" in diameter.  Could/may have chipped a tooth.

Rocks aside, burrito was ok, but not great.   Accidents happen, so 2 instead of 1 star.
author: Geek F.

description:
Stopped in for a quick meal. This place is crowded! 

The food was good! Fresh! and it was quick despite the line and being crowded. The Guacamole was very good. I had the Chili Verde and it was yummy. Overall a good stop, friendly, happy staff, good fresh food, it's a winner.
author: Jill T.

description:
This place now tastes like a taco bell.....  nasty.  so sad as it used to be awesome.  barf on a bun (or burrito).

hugs

P
author: Pammy S.

description:
I wish this place was here in NJ. Another great place for vegetarians.
The best soy burrito, called soyrizo that I ever had and the salsa is so delicious. Chipotle and Qdoba do not stand a chance with this place.

Please open this place in Central NJ.
author: FoodCritic F.

description:
This review is a bit overdue.. Papalote was recommended by my sf soul-sister. (thanks Dez!)  
So we're in the city, starving for burritos...  what better place to be than in the Mission..?!?!  Super excited to taste the food here.

Paplote is conveniently located away from the super busy part of the Mission, so it's easy to find parking in the residential area surrounding it.  I ordered the grilled veggie burrito, and really enjoyed the fresh, juicy, kinda tangy onions, eggplant and zucchinis!  I've never had a burrito like this before... 

Talk about a great spot with lots of urban flavor!!
author: Jo D.

description:
Hey! Papalote!

Sorry about those things I said about before.  They were not that nice, though i did feel them at the time.  I have crossed your threshold again and partook in your masa wrapped fare.  By Jove!  Your tacos are good.  Your chips are more chip like than at other lesser taquerias.  And I might be able to drink your salsa.

Papalote, I think we can be friends!
author: Adrian L.

description: I liked that you could get your burrito in a bowl (on a salad) rather than in a Tortilla, but the food itself wasn't anything to remember or go back for. No idea why this place was so crowded, when there are so many more authentic Mexican places in the neighborhood.
author: Sam R.

description:
Eh... I think it's okay.  I fail to see the "wow factor" that so many other reviewers rave about.  I think there are a bunch of better burrito shops in the city- for example Little Chihuahua on Divisadero.  To me the salsa is bland and mushy.  Where is the texture?  It's just like... red glop.  

They get your order wrong quite a bit, seem ill-equipt to handle the crowds.  Also, sometimes harried and/or rude service.  

They'll charge you $7 for extra meat/shrimp in a burrito or taco- why so $$?  Might as well get a whole extra order in that case.  

If we didn't live almost right next door we would never go here.
author: Alex J.

description: Good mole sauce.  My burrito guru said they have every combo of meat/sauce/extra for your taco/burrito/etc. Interesting deco and reasonable price for the location. A good spot for hangout or a casual lunch date.
author: Alexa X.

description: I have never stepped foot into Paplote Mexican Grill, but their salsa is THE BEST! They sell their roasted tomato salsa, and I am obsessed with it. It's not chunky or anything, but it's mostly smooth, & slightly gritty. I can take spice, but this one is quite spicy. I could drnik it out of the bottle; it is that good! I wish I could win a life-time supply of this. mmmmmmmm
author: Leslie P.

description:
I usually go to Cancun when I feel like having a burrito in the Mission, but you can't beat Papalote's house salsa.

Love the Soyrizo super burrito. Beware of waits on the weekends (the place has limited seating).
author: Bianca G.

description:
Only been here once (so far) and it was two nights after the premiere of the Bobby Flay's Throwdown episode last week for their "Triple Threat" burrito, which I am waiting to devour in the near future.

My buddy and I both ordered the Vegan Adobo burrito (tofu substitute for chicken). I forgot to make it a super burrito, but later thankful for not doing so because I was able to enjoy the burrito in all its natural glory, adobo. 

We both engulfed our burritos in a matter of minutes, and their special sauce didn't help!!! IT'S SO GOOD. There's a hint of spice to it, which I enjoyed!

I haven't seen the one on Fulton yet, although it's not too far from my own place, versus this one on 24th Street. This place is a little on the small side, but if you're just going to order a burrito, you don't need a table. You might need a chair to hold you up after nearly dying from the deliciousness of the first bite. :D

The pricing is pretty "standard" especially around here in the mission.
author: Cipriano G.

description: It's like you can just walk into any taqueria in the Mission and get one of the best burritos of your life. I got a tofu burrito with mole sauce. It was bomb.
author: Ben E.

description:
I'll keep this simple and short but..

THEIR ADOBO CHICKEN BURRITO IS BOMB! =] 

I can't give this place a 5-star because I've had better burritos and quesadillas at other places in Mission, but I gotta give props for their adobo chicken burrito because it's damn delicious and unforgettable for sure. Who would've thought Filipino food and Mexican food is such a good match?
author: Arika I.

description:
Can I have that salsa with every meal I have? It's smoky, got a kick but not too much, full flavor on the tongue. The food doesn't come out right away, but that's because they're making your burrito fresh to go. Fish burrito is delicious, not fried or breaded.

I'm not sure about the 1 tortilla per taco as said by other reviewers but if so, I agree with the atrocity. 2 tortillas man!!
author: Daniel C.

description:
I know I know...it's supposed to be better. I've heard for years how great the food was. I (sadly) won't be going back.

MY GO-TO TAQUERIA
Zapata - 18th/Collingwood

I ordered two tacos and went for the Mole. Woman at the counter couldn't recommend because she doesn't like mole, well, I should have gone with her "no like". I LOVE mole, and this was bad; watery, thin, blach. The chicken that was covered by the mole was DRY DRY DRY. Biting into it wasn't soft and juicy, rather it was hard and chewy. Last thing was I asked for no lettuce (lettuce is a cheap way to 'fill'). Unfortunately lettuce was on my mole, which made it worse(r).

: - (

Chips & Salsa (*****)

I know, this place is supposed to be great.

Sorry...
author: Mark M.

description: Love love love this place! Terrific vegan options-mole, soyrizo, marinated tofu, grilled veggies. Can't go wrong!  Their homemade salsas are so good too.
author: Jessica G.

description:
The food is easily 5 stars , I've had tacos and burritos aplenty here, and the salsa they make is amazingly good. For any vegans all the bean options are safe (stated on the menu) and they even have tofu and soyrizo too. Matter of fact a soyrizo burrito is what skillfully defeated my hangover on Saturday. Thanks again huge burrito, I owe you.

I just can't quite go 5 stars because every time I'm here the employees seem so unhappy to be working. It's just kind of odd, like no one smiles, they don't really give a vibe like they're happy their lobby is bursting with customers. Like it's a hassle.

But even though they are not the most chipper bunch the food is fantastic, that's why the place is always so packed with customers. Just look happy I'm at your restaurant when I order like one time guys and I promise to go up to 5 stars.
author: Justin N.

description:
So I ordered the Mexipino Burrito because it sounded interesting but either they fucked up and gave me a regular chicken burrito or their Mexipino Burrito is just not that good.  I found no hint of adobo flavors or garlic rice but dousing the meal in their remarkable hot sauce made it edible.

I'll probably just stick with Taqueria Cancun or El Farolito next time.
author: RJ S.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I really love Papalote's food.  That's why this review even has a couple stars.  I usually go to the Masonic and Fulton location, but went to the Mission over the weekend to try it out.

The food is still delicious.  However, the staff was so incredibly rude that it almost ruined my experience.  The place was packed wall to wall, and my three friends and I were concerned about whether or not we would ever get a seat.  My friend suggested that we just get the burritos to go in case there were no seats, but snag some if they opened up.  

After we had waited a while for our food, lo and behold, a table of 4 opened up!  We walked over to grab it, and the waitress came over and told us we were not allowed to sit there because we were "to go" orders and other people were waiting to eat "for here."  We explained the dilemma about having been concerned that we would not find a seat, but really wanted to eat in the restaurant.  However, she insisted that we could not sit down, and gave the table to people who had come in after us.  Seriously??

We were pretty pissed, but when the next table opened up, we just sat down.  What was she going to do, kick us out?  She did not kick us out, but she did come over and start bitching about how it was our fault that we did not order "for here" and NEXT TIME we would have to do that to be seated.  Sorry, honey, there won't be a next time.  I'm going to stick with my tried and true happy Papalote employees over on Fulton.
author: Erin B.

description:
Go here with a mindset prepared to wait a little bit.  It's a pretty popular place and can get kinda crowded.  I always get my food to go because it seems hella cramped in there.  Now for the food.....

All the food here is good, BUT..... if you have 20 bucks in your pocket and aren't afraid to waste it all on one burrito... you MUST get the "Triple Threat Burrito"!!  Really though.  Dude, this thing is jam packed with carne asada, chicken AND shrimp!  Oh yeah, and this thing is drenched in Papalote's amazing salsa... (I'm not really a salsa person, but I must say...Papalote has got some BOMB ASS salsa.)

Although it's an almost guaranteed heart attack, this monstrous burrito is an amazingly delicious explosion that creates an unmatched tastebud utopia with every bite!

...wash it down with a Mexican Coke and call it a day.

Your welcome, Tim.
author: Tim L.

description:
I've been here once..... ordered over the phone and picked it up. It's in a good location, parking isn't too hard. 
The food: Is expensive!!! I got the steak nachos and a burrito...... It was bomb! I had food coma after all of this. I would def come back..... there are other places that are delish and don't put a dent in your pocket. But this place is good.
author: Irma R.

description: Delicious Mexican taqueria with - SURPRISE! - delicious VEGAN options!  I'm a fan though I don't get here as often as I used to when I lived in the neighborhood.  Definitely check out their mole - muy rico!
author: Jenn C.

description:
A bit overpriced and very bland.

I had wanted to go here for quite some time.  It's not too far from the house and has been feautured on multiple food channel shows.  I figured it would have to blow away the other local burrito shops.   I was sadly disappointed.  

Don't get me wrong.  The food is pretty good. It's fresh and tasty.  The burritos are smaller than most other places, which doesn't really bother me.  At my normal burrito place my favorite is a  baby super burrito.  In reality, it's just about the same size as the burrito I had here.  However, at my normal place it is only half the price, and comes with a bit of spice.

So they are known for their salsa here, but I'm not quite sure why.   If you like salsa try Taqueria Guadalajara  8 different kinds to choose from and it blows this place away.  Here, there was only one choice.. and with my 2 entrees I received 2 small containers of salsa with my order.  I asked for a third ..and was told that would cost .55 extra.   I took my entrees to go .. I have plenty of salsa at home.  The salsa which was rather orange in color, lacked spice.   It tasted good and  the first container was gone before I was halfway through my burrito. Did I mention it was a SMALL burrito.  At most places, I get the hot salsa... at really good places I'll take the 2nd or 3rd hottest salsa as my main salsa and have a few drops of the hot salsa on my main dish.  

Here I could drink the salsa like a milkshake. They sell it by the jar, but truthfully I'd rather have salsa that I can only take in small quantities.   

Then there's the prices,  This meal literally cost $8 more than my local place.  That's nearly double the price .. and if I had bought the proper amount of salsa definitely more than double the prices at my local place.  What amazed me is the place was packed... true, I don't think there was a single Central or South American in the place besides the wait staff. But there was a line of the whitest people you will find in the Mission at nearly 9pm on a Wednesday night. 

On the other hand, if you are a vegetarian.. the choices were good.  I'd still pick El Burrito Express over this place for the vegetarian options, but that's a long way to go from this neighborhood.  They had an eggplant burrito, a tofu burrito, and a few other options.  Far better than the bean and rice burritos vegetarians are stuck with at most places.
author: Cat C.

description:
OVERALL: 3.9

FOOD: 4
SERVICE: 4
AMBIANCE: 4
VALUE: 3.5

Got me a seat on the Throw-Down bandwagon, and it was glorious.

Didn't know about the Triple Threat bomb of a burrito--all I knew was Bobby got flayed, so I had to check it out for myself.  Definitely a more Americanized & polished taqueria...I'd say along the lines of In-n-Out of burritos, but edgier.  Cool urban artwork, bright walls, ornate kites strung up on the ceilings...fun & festive.

Menu is gringo-friendly with very standard and less adventurous options (i.e., no lengua or other head-parts)....and DELICIOUS.  Sure, it may not be so-called authentic, but it's definitely its own unique brand of Mexican flavor...your mouth and belly will know when it's Papalote, and they'll thank you.

FISH TACOS (2 for $6.75): Generous mound of grilled fish, chopped romaine, tomatoes, onions, & famous salsa--best grilled fish tacos so far!  Super fresh!

CHICKEN QUESADILLA ($7.25): Chicken reminded me of tandoori (vibrant red color, dry-ish but still moist & tender), and was the saving grace of an otherwise lopsided quesadilla....jicama salad/salsa was also a nice addition, though the portion was barely a biteful.

Next time I have food-baby pangs, I just might consider the $19.95 Triple Threat....til then, I'll stick to my fish tacos & salsa!
author: Amy K.

description: I visit the Papalote on Fulton every few weeks and it is great every time - usually order a carne asada burrito with everything and the sauce they make keeps me coming back. You can order over the phone for pick-up (usually 15 minutes) and they are pretty good with timing. They also deliver via Postmates and you can try the promo code "FRIENDS" or "GETPLUS" for free delivery.
author: H C.

description:
2.7 / 5 (Chips and Salsa rated separately would receive 4.5 / 5 star rating)

If you're a vegan or a vegetarian, I guess this place would suffice, but because I demand flavor, value and nourishment when I indulge in a burrito, Papalote goes a sad 0-3.

It's not all bad though, Papalote's salsa does provide diners with an exquisite way to spice up their otherwise lackluster food.  If their chips were a little saltier, I would have given their chips & salsa combo 'legend' status.  Still, the chips and salsa alone earned Papalote 2 of their 3 stars.

The real problem with Papalote is that it doesn't deliver the awesome burrito experience that one expects when spending $9 on a burrito IN THE MISSION!!  Taste is blah, care and attention to detail is minimal at best (my burrito completely fell apart after 2 bites), and the ambience is just a little too earthy / yuppy for it to be a true burrito joint.

Long story short, unless you're an herbivore, there is no reason to go to Papalote when El Farolito, La Taqueria and every other delicious Mission burrito is a minutes walk away.
author: Kyle S.

description: If I wanted a rice burrito I would've ordered a rice burrito. What's the point of ordering a veggie burrito if all you get is rice? Ps. Dont come in 40 minutes before they close, u wont get to eat there. Because no customer is worth any extra time.
author: ken p.

description:
Go to Papalote for their clean and spacious seating area, some seriously amazing salsa, and fresh made guacamole.  Their burritos are pretty standard, but once you add the salsa and guac, they shoot up into the realm of heavenly.  Also nice that you can choose what type of beans and tortilla you'd like in your burrito or quesadilla.  

Everything comes with a side of tortilla chips and salsa.  So as we found out today, it's not totally worth it to spend $5.75 for an smallish bowl of guacamole and more of the same chips.  Next time I'm going to just go ahead and order the guacamole as a side dish, or maybe even upgrade my burrito for $0.99.

No, not exactly the most authentically Mexican taqueria in the Mission, but who claimed that it was?  The food is still mighty tasty, especially with that salsa.
author: Joanne G.

description: I really don't understand the hype. This really is an average burrito with a fantastic salsa.  I highly recommend buying a couple jars of the salsa (also available in grocery stores) and using it at home.
author: Zoran L.

description: I come here quite a bit and love the food. I usually get the chile verde burrito and it's messy but amazing. The salsa is very addictive, it's no wonder they sell it by the jar.
author: Jared G.

description:
Ok, this is sad to write but here goes. 

Part of me wants to give three stars but this is more of a 2.5. However, when you miss the basics, you get dinged. 

Papalote had great reviews so we went for a burrito. The space is clean and comfortable. I liked the creamy salsa but had issues with our burrito. 

We ordered a prawn burrito to share. Now, I know prawn burritos are always more expensive than say Carne asada but at $11.25 for a prawn super, it should be pretty darn good. 

Papalote got right what many places don't - flavor.  The ingredients and recipes were good. What didn't work for me was composition. They were nice and offered to cut the burrito in half because the cashier realized we were sharing. When the burrito came out it looked great. 

It was the right size, had been toasted after rolled (good call!) but something was missing. Prawns for me, rice for my wife. 

In my half of the burrito, there were no prawns. I took it to the counter (after unrolling on a search for shrimp) and told them there was nothing there. My wife had found three inside her half. I asked them how many prawns come on a prawn burrito and the said 4. Now, if these were true jumbo prawns (8-10 count/lbs), that would have made sense. They seemed like regular size shrimp to me.  Plus they were put in whole instead of being cut in half which would have helped the composition. 

My wife's half had primarily beans and prawns but no rice. 

A burrito is like a sandwich - very simple. But simple foods require precision to be REALLY good. It was sad that they skimped on the prawns and that the ingredients weren't balanced. They had a 4 star burrito in the making. The staff was genuinely apologetic however there was no recovery. I didn't make a big stink about it but I certainly left rather disappointed. I'd try them again but would probably go for tacos where composition isn't an issue. If you want a burrito, don't get prawns.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I recommend this place to everyone in Miami! Amazingggg Service, Great Freaken foooodd!!

Kuddos guys!
author: Alex D.

description:
Pretty much your basic taqueria here in a colorful, playful setting. Portions are big so it's perfect if you want to share. The guacamole was so big too that we couldn't even finish it! 

You also get free chips and their famous salsa, which was really the best thing. It's a roasted flavor with the perfect amount of heat. Good thing you can buy an entire jar of salsa to go for about 6 bucks! Yummmm!!! I would just come back here soley for that!
author: Heidi L.

description: The Mexipino burrito is pretty damn good. Chicken adobo with garlic fried rice, avocado, cheese and sour cream. Yes, please.
author: Jay F.

description: Oh I have a secret sin to confess! I've been hiding this place from all my friends just to make sure I don't have to wait in the line to get my favorite fish salad. The salsa there is so delicious from day one that I have to get a bottle to keep at home from time to time! Great place to go if you just want to have something simple, fresh and tasty! A great place for budget eating!!
author: Yina M.

description:
THE CHIPS & SALSA - BOMB.COM!
When I first had it, I wasn't used to the fact that it wasn't chunky salsa but thennnn I tried it and the flavor just blew me away! It's SO good - I can't even describe it aside from the fact that it is spicy. Bottled sauce is available for purchase.

My go-to when I want a burrito WITHOUT feeling heavy/disgusting after
IE.) the "I should go and work out after eating this but really, I'm gonna take my lazy ass to sleep"

Anyways, on to the burritos -
Not the hugest I've seen (hahaha) but it's filling and ingredients taste fresh. Burritos avg around $7-9.

Chicken Adobo burrito is muy deliciouso - love the garlic rice in it that really adds a good hint of flavor. the adobo chicken is not as vinegary as authentic adobo but you can still taste it. 
Filipino inspire - It's a must try when ambitious to step outside of a carna asada burrito (there's nothing wrong because I like carna asada too!)

They also have variety of different burritos from tofu, veggie, shrimp, fish, beef, pork so you really do have A LOT to choose from. 

+Not your late night burrito joint - closes at 10pm!
+accepts credit card
+ small, colorful and clean eating area with cool local flyers for events around the Bay scattered everywhere
author: Tiffany N.

description:
CILANTRO HATERS: This one gets complicated since they have it in their salsa and guac. I usually go for the super shrimp burrito with avocado instead of guac, and with the roasted salsa instead of pico de gallo. Yeah, I'm that annoying dude in front of you with an order like that. But seriously, you need to try this, and this is your ticket to happiness.

Do yourself a favor and get the shrimp or fish burrito/quesadilla here. I'm sure their steak and chicken are great or whatever, but if you don't get shrimp or fish, you are totally blowing it. It's the best in the city, as far as I'm concerned. It's cooked in this white wine and butter sauce that is just unreal. That, and if you can swap the roasted salsa in for the pico, you have now elevated your meal to divine status.
author: Alex O.

description:
Papalote is the go-to spot for trendy conformists who want bland, overpriced nuevo Mexicano food. My wife and spent over $20 on chicken fajitas that were roughly equivalent in flavor to what one might get at Chevy's. Our previous experiences have been equally bad, and why we bothered to return is too long a story to bother with, but it's not a mistake we'll be making again.

Papalote's popularity is utterly incomprehensible given how many really good Mexican places exist a stone's throw away. I guess they've found their niche in the category of "Stuff White People Like," though, so good for them.
author: Bitter J.

description:
Home of the $10 burrito.  

Every time I come here -- which is not often -- I'm shocked at how expensive it is.  And then I stay away for a long while, until I forget.  

Yesterday was one of those days.  They'd remodeled since the last time.  I was taken aback.  Looked like a chain, felt like a chain.  Who knows, that could be the plan.

If they're gonna go that route, they need to resolve issues like the big jar of jalapenos with tongs and nothing to put the pickles in, with the sign on it saying "Do not use water glasses.  Ask cashier for container."   As if anybody's going to wait on line to ask for a plastic thing to put them in, instead of using one of the conveniently at-hand water cups.

They also ought to have a "salsa bar' because it appears they have only one kind, and it's weird.  (Should be called "salt-sa" because its apparent function is to make people thirsty and buy beer.)  Other places have a selection.  You know: red, green, etc.  But creamy?  That's weird.
author: Tom H.

description: Meh, is the best way to explain the food. The burrito was slightly below average in that it terribly wrapped and the insides were poorly distributed the flavor was ok and I really have no idea how this place has so many stars.  The fish tacos were ok, bland and nothing special. The best thing about this place was the salsa sauce and even that was only ok, in my mind 22 dollars is far to much for a one burrito and one order of fish tacos you can get better cheaper and more Mexican food pretty much anywhere in San Francisco. Skip this place entirely.
author: Charles W.

description:
I would given 1 star, but the house salsa bumped it up to 2 stars.

MANAGEMENT, did I really just wait 15 minutes for a  $9 CARNE ASADA burrito for it to have literally 4 PIECES of carne asada and a dash of salsa!?!?!?!?!
 If I wanted to eat rice and a cr@pload of beans, I could of made it myself.

A PRIMARILY rice and bean burrito for $9 dollars.!

CMON  Papalote.  GET IT TOGETHER, you will LOSE CUSTOMERS this way to other nearby authentic taquerias that dont SKIMP on the carne asada for the pricepoint!!!
author: Ferdinand B.

description:
The salsa was good.  So good that I wished I order more but I controlled myself.  

I shared a Triple Threat burrito with my lady.  The meats in the burrito were tasty.  Eating half of the burrito is pretty filling.
author: Pete C.

description:
The location for this restaurant is amazing, right off the 24th and Mission Bart stop. The food is fresh and there are always a few people waiting for their to-go orders. 

We got the carne asada burrito with black beans. It was delicious and there was plenty for my husband and I to split. The staff was helpful but not overbearing. Great place to catch a quick bite in the Mission!
author: Emily S.

description: Probably now one of my most favorite burrito places in the city. I got a chicken burrito, and it was flavored so well. The chicken was great. My brother got the adobo burrito, and I definitely want to get that next time! The adobo chicken was seasoned perfectly, and it was a great combination. Definitely coming back here!
author: Kae O.

description:
So dependable. 

Took my parents here last weekend and this was the first time I had to wait for a table when I got there. 

One of the employees rushed this table of chatty patrons to give us a place to sit (awesome in my book, probably not so awesome in theirs) so the wait was only about 10 minutes. Also awesome was that they timed the wait precisely and the burritos were piping hot when we sat down.

Also, got their horchata for the first time and it was delish!
author: Raina B.

description: Mmm! Got a chicken burrito with black beans and gauc to go. Call it in because it does take 10 minutes or so to make. I first tried the salsa and chips -- excellent queso/salsa mix and with a nice little kick to it. Tons of chips to go with it (standard, unsalted). My first bite into the burrito was heaven. Very high quality tortillas! It really give the tortilla a fresh, light taste. Guac was excellent. Ingredients were also very tasty spun together. Really nice salsa inside the burrito. There was maybe just a little something about the salsa that makes me prefer the guac to pull everything together. Is it pepper or peppercorn, perhaps? This is a meal and a half. Great value!
author: James C.

description:
My friend was watching the Throwdown Challenge on the Food Network and saw the Triple Threat being put on the spotlight. To make a long story short, I'm sitting there, watching two of my buddies take on the Triple Threat. Not wanting to shell out $20+ for a burrito, I'm munching on a normal carne asada burrito.

I was really happy with how the carne asada came out. The meat is so tender and juicy and the steak marinade is fantastic. I wish it wasn't $9 but the quality speaks for itself. 

From my friends' comments, I'd say that the chicken in the Triple Threat is not so great. A bit too dry and when compared to the steak, very plain. The shrimp is stir fried with garlic and is great. 

Great burritos but too pricey. I don't recommend the Triple Threat unless you're doing it for the sake of doing it. The normal burritos are sufficient.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Terrible quality of meat and food in general. I don't recommend it at all. I don't know where the high ratings are coming from.
author: Ssm M.

description: Super Burrito heaven!! you know you are central american when you love black refried beans in your burrito hahahah. This place sure does use their capital to make burritos con savor!! worth my 10 dollars hands down!! #Yum.com
author: Eli A.

description: Sometimes it's perfect and you get a delicious burrito made in clean conditions.  When it's off, the place is still clean but there's just something off about the food.  Not sure what.  It's a gamble.  Just when you decide this place sucks you get another perfect burrito and you get sucked right back in again.  Sigh.  If it was reliable, I would be here every night.
author: Amy M.

description:
Love me my papalote and have for years. Particularly good are the carne asada super burrito (of course), the chicken mole, and when you're not needing to eat flesh, the soyrizo burrito super is super tasty. 

On those rare times you have the space and minutes to sit down and dine in a civilized manner, the pollo al achiote and the fish tacos are the way to go.

The salsa is so good I buy it in the fresh jars in their fridge and have it as an after-work snack with some local casa sanchez chips. 

I just wish they had a bigger space so it wasn't always so crowded! And I suspect their burritos have gotten slightly smaller in the 8 years I've been coming here.
author: Tony B.

description: Good burritos, silly high prices. But I'm a sucker like just about everyone else for the excellent salsa,
author: Dustin W.

description: Gave this place a shot and I wasn't impressed. Their food was overpriced and lacked flavor & authenticity in my opinion. Experience wasn't that welcoming either, word of advice, don't order carnitas or they'll frown upon you! At least that's the impression given. Just an "Uppity Mexican Grill." Gave the place 2 stars as the ingredients do taste fresh.  If you want to feel as if the Mexican culture has been robbed out of your food to appeal more towards "American's" or our new found hipsters, you might as well go to chipotle.
author: Honest T.

description:
I spent half an hour online researching opinions on where to find the best mission district burrito, and Papalote wasn't mentioned all that often. Somehow it caught my eye though and I decided to check it out. I should have trusted popular opinion a bit more I think. The burrito was alright and the salsa was good, but I've definitely had better. 

Next time I'm in S.F. I'll hit up El Farolito.
author: Mike B.

description:
This is 2nd in my Vegan the Mission series.

Decided to brave the "overrated" reviews and give their vegan tofu mole burrito a try, since life without mole is not worth living. Happy to say it was yummy and filling and came with a nice, if skimpy, salsa on the side.

Go on a Sunday afternoon to avoid the lines.
author: Charles B.

description:
Do not get the chili verde burito. I got one yesterday and got a bad case of food poisoning, and reading older reviews it looks like I am not the only one.I had to stay home from work and spent all night violently vomiting. 
They need to make sure that the chilli verde is handled properly, last night was one of the worst nights of my life.
author: Julian M.

description:
Affordable, high quality mexican food. Ingredients were super fresh and possibly the best homemade salsa ever.

I had the carne asada tacos which I HIGHLY recommend, and spent the rest of dinner eyeing burritos at the next table.

A new regular, yay!
author: Annie L.

description:
I don't know what all the buzz is about.

I've come twice and both times I walked away disappointed. The space is cute but a bit cramped and gets very crowded if there are just a few people eating.  I ordered a chicken burrito both times. The portion was generous but the chicken lacked flavor. The whole burrito lacked kick and seemed very flat. I appreciate the complimentary chips and salsa. The prices aren't that cheap for food that isn't that good. For the same price/type of food I'd just go to Chipotle and leave the restaurant a happy camper.
author: Zachary S.

description:
This place is a little confusing, but good. I didn't understand the menu right away as I was standing in line to order so I got nervous that I would be holding up the line while deciding. No pressure or anything. There's just always a line. The menu on the wall has some options on the left side such as "Veggie," "Grilled Veggie," and "Soyrizo". The next few columns to the right then have prices for exactly what dish you would like your first choice to be and then you move on to picking additional ingredients. The additional($) ingredients are things like cheese and sour cream which come standard at most taquerias so the burritos that would be around $6 at those other places are $10 here.

I got the soyrizo burrito partly because I heard bad things about the "Veggie" burrito here (Potato, carrot, mushroom) and partly because I wanted more flavor than a bland veggie burrito I've had at way too many other places. I added cheese, sour cream and guacamole to my burrito and there was plenty of all three in it. The burrito itself was flavorful and filling so I definitely wasn't disappointed with my choice.

So..the sauce. The sauce is slightly spicy, smokey, and delicious. Just had to throw in my opinion about the sauce everyone mentions, I guess. I might even buy the jars they sell and use it when I get burritos at other places :p

Overall I like this place. It's impossible to park around Valencia/Mission most of the time but if you can make it to this location it's worth it
author: David O.

description: When it comes to (gringo style) burritos this is the place!  Also as a vegetarian they offer an amazing soyrizo burrito, this topped off with the papalote salsa ( I recommend ordering atleast an extra) makes it a favorite. Extra star for the cute and very personable staff taking the orders.
author: Kellen H.

description: Awesome carne asada - really tender, moist, and flavorful. We also had shrimp tacos... those were good but not as good as the burrito. The ingredients seem really fresh, so the only real criticism I can give is that the restaurant is a little small and it gets crowded around lunch.
author: Lily C.

description:
YELP. I am mad at you. 
Chips and dip, yeah okay.
Soyrizo Burrito, meh.
Fish tacos, +3. 
I was trying to go to La Taqueria but they were closed for winter cleaning. I should've went to El Farolito instead.
author: Spring L.

description:
"Good Friday" was definitely upgraded to "Amazing Friday" after I got my crack - I mean - Salsa fix at Papalate... but yo    it definitely didn't stop there!  Because of the Lenten season, (well I am assuming) they had a Dungeness Crab Enchilada special along with complimetary Sangria that I definitely could not turn down...

I spread the word and wether or not anyone wanted to tag along, I knew I was going to enjoy my lunch there REGARDLESS!  BUT I KNEW once I said FREE SANGRIA at least MONICA would be hooked! Monica, Stan, Thomas, and eventually Brian was sold on my advertisement and our Sunny Friday was set...

Stan ordered the Fish tacos, Thomas and I ordered the crab special, and Monica opted for the chicken burrito.  Everyone definitely agreed with me about the flavor, quality of fresh ingredients, and of course THE SALSA!

The sangria itself was delicious... being the "cheap date" that I am now, I was buzzing off of my first half glass... but it made my dining experience even better!

I really should have walked away with a bottle of salsa! ::kiking myself in the butt:: NOW!

There is nothing better than sharing amazing food with amazing friends!
author: Chrysantha C.

description: I got the carne asada burrito. The crispness of the tortilla was very nice, and the fillings were okay, but the steak tasted cheap cheap and it was just a little bland. It's a burrito, ok? Nothing more. Nothing less.
author: Jarrod S.

description:
The last time I came to SF I failed to eat a burrito and it's been killing me for more then a year. So, this time, hot off the plane, it was BART to Papalote and a burrito was in my system before I even checked in to the hotel.

I got the grilled veggie and it was HUGE, BF got meat. The loudly vegetarian girl sitting next to me got meat accidentally and was scandalized. 

Overall: a little pricey, but portions are worth it, and the quality is excellent. Would recommend.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Heard rave reviews about the burrito for years but just never have ended up there.  Finally did.  It's alright.  Not the best burrito I've had, and not the worst.  I have to knock off a star for the price though.  The basic carne asada for almost 9 bucks?  Sorry, but no.  

I know burrito alliances are borderline religious here in SF, but go to El Farolito and get a better burrito for less.  

The salsa at Papalote is good though.
author: Sean H.

description:
Been here a couple of times and
Problems:
1. First visit screwed up my order
2. Next visit screwed up my order
3. Tonight I had to get takeout bc my bf wanted to eat there, got home (dumb me) and for my shrimp super burrito there was no shrimp, no cheese, no guacamole, and no sour cream. 13 bucks for rice and beans?! FAIL

Done
author: Ali G.

description:
Seriously, people that don't know Mexican food rate this place as 4 stars and above but coming from the Central Valley and being raised in a Mexican household, I will tell you that this place is EXTREMELY overrated. 

I rejected the 20 something dollar burrito because I don't care what you put in a burrito, a 20 dollar price tag is insane and a no go for me! 

I went with the super Carne Asada burrito and it was NO BUENO. I actually put tasty under my 'quick tip' while checking in but that was only after the first bite. Their salsa is actually pretty good. When I got to the meat, OMG - no flavor! This thing needed to be knocked upside the head or tortilla with a pound of salt because it was so flavorless! 

The rice and beans were mediocre. 

After more than 4 years of living in the Bay Area, I am still not satisfied with the Mexican food joints in the area. This is just another Mexican food joint that is seriously over-hyped by people.

If your taste buds are satisfied because you're paying a fortune for your food, then kudos to you but some of the best burrito's I have had costed me no more than 6 dollars. 

1 star for the service and the decor but that's all this place will get from me (actually Yelp does not allow me to assign 0 stars). 

If you want great Mexican food, hit the Central Valley for it. Hell, I will make you something if you wish! Haha.
author: Augusto L.

description:
OMG! 71$ for lunch! are you kidding me!

Now, when you have a glass of wine with your food I understand the elevated price. But when your server comes over and asks you if you want Guacamole and ceviche with your chips but doesn't tell you the PRICE, I wasn't expecting $17 dollars for some avocados and shrimp!! Outrageous! I wouldn't have minded if i was WARNED ahead of time!

The portions are fine but WAY expensive for what it is. $9 for carne asado tacos....really?!?!? You can dress up Mexican all you want, but it is still street food! And this wasn't even dressed to impress. Come on!!!
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
Just tried the chicken tacos here - delicious! The chicken was soft, juicy and flavorful. My friend tried the chicken burrito and declared it the "best in the city". I like their decor too. 
Highly recommended.
author: ubaid d.

description: The quality of food was so so (fish taco too salty )  but the ladies at the front desk taking your order were far from being friendly,  borderline arrogant and rude
author: M S.

description:
A man who was trying to woo me said, " No way!  You work in the Mission?  I know the BEST place to get authentic Mexican food."

I was all ears.  "Papalote!" He was so enthusiastic I figured he must've owned the place.

"Really? Seen it, just never tried it.  Is is better than La ____?"

"Oh hell ya! Promise you!"

His confidence was charming.  The place, not so much.  

It's a great spot if you want to pretend to be in the Mission. It's clean, at least and perfect if you like spending about $10 on a dry prawn burrito and wait 20 minutes to receive it. 
Better ones can be found at Whole foods if you're too afraid to go to a real taqueria in the Mission - you know, the ones Mexican people actually eat at.

2 burittos, 2 beers & some guac he insisted on ordering because it was 'awesome' - $43. Really?
author: Athena S.

description:
A friend of mine totally hyped this place up to me.  Honestly, it wasn't much better than a lot of other mexican food I've had in SF, however, the bar is pretty high around here and Papalote surely meets it.

The service is a little strange - you have to order your food before they'll put you on the list for a table, and the place is relatively small.  In retrospect, not really the place to go when you're a group of 7 and half of you are 45 minutes late due to cab difficulty.

But, I digress.  The super steak burrito was ginormous and delicious, and the man who took my order was quite friendly for how busy they were.  The horchata was great, and yes - just as everyone says - the salsa is pretty amazing.  Mainly, though, because it's such an original flavor (oh, and it's spicy!  yay!) - I doubt you've had a salsa with chips anything like this.

So, a good place to grab some grub, perhaps on a regular basis if you live in the area.  Not so great for large groups - max it at 4 and you'll be happy indeed.
author: Sarah C.

description:
If you take all of the Twitter and Food Network hype away, this place is an ok Mexican spot. No doubt that the salsa is what makes it. A little pricey for the burrito, but I attribute this to the organic ingredients they use and a couple dollars for the street cred. The last two tortillas I had were crumbly and felt like they were at the bottom of the pack. I've read other reviews that talk about the same problem so I'm assuming this is due to the high demand and rush in service.

The ingredients are very tasty, especially the Mexipino burrito. But without the salsa, I'd say it's an average burrito at best.

I'm not giving up! I know there is a lot more to try and given the street hype, I may need to visit during one of their sisig/burrito days.
author: Jorge H.

description:
Someone brought Papalote's salsa into my husband's work, and it was so good my husband wanted to seek out the mythical land of milk and honey, or rather, *salsa*, from which it came.

We arrived at Papalote at 2:30 on a Saturday afternoon and were lucky enough to only have to wait 3 minutes for a table. There was a line afterwards. The place is on the small side, and it's unclear if you're supposed to claim your own table or follow the "please wait to be seated" sign. There are pretty dragonfly artworks on the ceiling.

We started with the $1.50 chips and salsa. Unlike other places these aren't bottomless. The amount we were given was just under what we needed, especially given how great the salsa was. (The chips are pretty standard issue.) 

The salsa had a nice roasted flavor and was unlike any other salsa I've ever had. It was a light orange color and looked slightly creamy, though I can't imagine them adding cream to it. (Do they?) It was so good we went back a few hours later for some salsa to take home. For $6.50 you can get a full jar. Even though it's in a jar it's fresh salsa and it'll only last a few days.

We each got a pair of tacos for $4.95. One set had pollo (grilled chicken breast), the other carne asada (grilled steak). For some reason they don't let you mix and match your meats. The carne asada was a little chewy but had good flavor - did I detect lime and garlic? The chicken on the other hand looked like it was good quality, but it was bland. I regretted not paying the extra 99 cents to make it a "super" with guac, sour cream, and cheese. I asked at the counter if I could have the super accoutrements on the side. Initially they balked and wanted me to pay the $2.99 for a whole side of guacamole, but I talked them into giving me just a small side of guac for the 99 cents. Guac makes everything better.

Epilogue: The salsa was just as good at home. Still eating it...
author: Kathleen M.

description:
One Word: MEXIPINO.

This burrito is made from Mayan Gods, I swear.
Grilled chicken - fresh tomatoes and garlic rice.

HEAVEN IN MY MOUTH.
So much so...I've convinced my coworkers and we're going today!!
author: Sara D.

description:
Back here after a while.

I give a star for the salsa.

For the rest:

Flavourless beans. skudgy rice. über prices. bland meat. surly service. 

You want clean? Head to La Taquería or Pancho Villa or El Toro.

You want real? Cancun or San Jose or El Farolito.

This place was OK - pretty good even Then it got bad. .
author: Glen M.

description:
Great place for burritos and fish tacos. Of course, the sauce is amazing along with the service.

The only knock against the place are the Prawn tacos. Unfortunately you get only two prawn per taco, so it's not going to take care of your hunger. Better off ordering the prawn burrito since the other fillings will ensure you're satisfied.
author: Pico S.

description:
Overpriced burritos
bad service
okay-burritos
Well, i actually didn't like the salsa

for me, this place failed, miserably! I would give it negative one star if I could.
author: Evan L.

description:
My chicken looked like cat food. It had rounded edges similar to that of pre-cooked bulk meat that had been soaking in some sort of gravy. It reminded me of a burrito I once ate in Amsterdam cooked by a Spanish guy who poured velveeta all over it. I had a stomach ache half way into my burrito and it lasted well into the next day. 

With all the amazing Mexican food in the Mission, there is absolutely no reason to go here again.
author: Julie H.

description: Went here one evening and I had their guacamole and chips while my friend had their veggie burrito.  Their guacamole was delicious but disappointed with the bland flavor and very little portions of their chips.  I liked the pickled Jalapeños they give for free which you can find beside the counter.  Had a portion of my friend's veggie burrito and it was tasteless to me.  There are other burrito places within that neighborhood I'd rather go to to be honest.  Their prices were even too high for me.  $8 for guacamole and chips?  Too much.
author: Janis P.

description:
Dinner 02/04/2012

Mexipino Burrito = Adobo chicken with garlic rice. Slammin! Much better than I would have though. Garlicky sauce, chicken adobo good, everything else mixed in really well. 

VERDICT = Would order again next time here, although that won't be for a while.
author: David G.

description: Their salsas are the best- have been wanting to try the restaurant. It does not disappoint. I got the chicken mole- so good! Fresh and plenty of food!
author: Laura D.

description:
AH. SO GOOD!

I don't live in SF anymore, but when I come to visit, I love coming here. I got the fish burrito most recently, and it was amazing. Stuffed to the gills with guac, cheese, rice, and beans. Not only are their burritos enormous and filling, but they each come with an order of chips and salsa. And this salsa is some of the best salsa I've ever had: almost creamy in its texture, with a nice kick. 

And since Papalote's is located walking distance from Dolores Park, you  can grab your burrito, and then stroll over to Dolores Park and lounge in the (hopefully) sunny weather, watching the kids tumble on the newly-built jungle gym fantasy world, amidst the sunbathers and hipster locals. And then when you're done, (if you managed to finish this feast!) you can end your meal with a fresh ice cream cone from BiRite Creamery nearby. (I didn't finish my burrito, but it made a nice dinner for me later that day).
author: Anna K.

description:
The salsa is the bomb!  and you can get jars to go!  I've been twice. yup I'm goin back! community table seating is only ok and the bathroom is right at the dining room's edge... But other than that they run a tight ship! Food is good it's clean and fresh!  Popular place i gather but had to write a review and say hey I like this place!
Did I mention the salsa...?  Yea it's that good! bring it home!!!
author: Paris P.

description: Best burrito ever! Get the chicken adobo. Yum! The sauce is amazing too. Big fan!
author: Eme C.

description:
I was so excited for a burrito. Oh si, que rico me voy a tragar un burrito. The menu is pretty plain, choice of meat and 99 cents extra for "super" which seems worth it.  It adds cheese, sour cream and guac. I would get slapped if my mother heard me say "guac" she'd thing "guacala" and that don't sound too appetizing. I was eager and saw they bottled and sold their own tomato salse, hmmm must be guud. Chips and salsa was good, crunchy chips and mildly spiced sauce. Then the burrito came.. dun dun dun. 

Ay caramba, guacala!

The rice was dry as hell, ni de fiesta. "Arroz de fiesta" is spanish for party rice. Where people make big batches of tasteless, dry packed rice to serve at weddings and quincianeras. This wasn't even at their level. My carne asada was dry but my tortilla was hella on hit. I ran out of hot sauce, I requested more they charged me $1.10 for two small ass portions. WTF?! lol oh ya and the decor is awesome, the atmosphere feels mexican. There is mexican music blaring and dragon kites to match their red walls. I bet this place was one a chinese food take out and all they did was keep the loud red feng shui walls and flying dragon kites and call it tex mex. My horchata was ok a little sweet. They charged me for fucking salsa it's a spiced up taco bell trying to be a La Vics and a La Vics, it is not. Eh... In ADDITION the $22.50 was not worth the two burritos and one drink we purchased.
author: Julie N.

description: Came to visit SF and had to try the triple threat burrito. So disappointed. It was so salty I took two bites, could not finish it.
author: Donniel L.

description: This is the best place in the Mission for burritos.  I bet the rest of the menu is amazing, but I've only had the burritos because they're so good!  The soy burrito is good because of the sauce/marinade they have it in, makes a great 'rito!  And the carne asada if my favorite meat burrito, great stuff!  Sitting there with a  beer and a burrito...can't be beat.
author: Joel S.

description:
Once you try a Burrito from Papalote it's hard to have one anywhere else! I didn't try the "Triple Threat Burrito" yet but the Carne Asada Burrito made me forget about how hard it is to find parking in the City let alone the shortage of seats they have... I'll be happy to stand up and eat it on the sidewalk!

The steak portions are thick and meaty as hell with chunky, flavorful slices spread all out the burrito. Portion wise... man, it's just right with an even amount of rice beans and all the good stuff that makes a Burrito taste so heavenly! I walked out feeling satisfied! Not lazy and bloated like other Burrito joints! Their orange sauce is great! I've only had the pleasure of trying one similar in San Jose. (La Vics) 

Overall, it was a great 1st experience I am willing to try again! (this time the Triple Threat is on my hit list!)
author: Tony R.

description:
Amazing food!!! I used to work her for a couple of years and years later I'm still a fan and a regular. 

Everything is super yummy here... their shrimp quesadillas are the best in the city. 

But let's not leave the salsa behind, the salsa is amazing too!! 

Family owned... owners are great and so is the staff. 

Love my Papalote...
author: Liliana C.

description: Large selection of vegetarian and vegan options. The tofu mole tacos (although a bit spicy) are really, really good. I've become obsessed with their roasted tomatillo salsa which I buy at Rainbow Grocery and put on everything.
author: Priscilla M.

description: Only thing I get here are the burritos, I always call in a head of time as the lines can get pretty long. The salsa here is some of the best i've had.
author: Eric R.

description:
Papalote Salsa runs into burning buildings and saves kittens.

Papalote Salsa ruthlessly mocks libertarians until they cry out in anguish and promise to never recite another feeble Randism ever again.

Papalote Salsa seals windows and doorways tight, reducing monthly utility bills during winter months.

Papalote Salsa, when poured directly into your vehicle's engine, will enable a 35 year old ford pickup to pass a gold-star certified California SMOG check.

Papalote Salsa also tastes really damn good.

I have never been to the restaurant, never eaten the burrito, and need not try, for the salsa provides all a man needs.

Tomorrow I'm climbing El Capitan, having trained on nothing but a diet of Papalote Salsa for six months.
author: Scott F.

description: I was speeding to work and backtracked just to get Papalote. I eat it from time to time, and it's always good time to time lol. It isn't greasy, I don't feel extremely tired from eating it but I feel full. The sauce, YUM. I realized that they carry it in Whole Foods now. 4 stars on a solid burrito.
author: Sweets N.

description:
salsa is good. everything else is overrated and their prices are out of control. they charge you for extra salsa (lame), and without the salsa, their food is super bland, and...I've tried MOST things on the menu and nothing ever sticks out as "I want that again"

 it's the name and the salsa.
author: Osh J.

description:
The closest thing to La Victoria's orange sauce! Although I think they call it a chipotle salsa, every time I take a bite, it still reminds me of the orange goodness from SJ.

Parking at both locations can be rather difficult but the proximity of bars makes this location my favorite of the two. Seating can be limited, but customer turnover is fast so you can usually count on having a seat by the time you've ordered and your food is ready. The tables are stacked next to each other so different combinations of group sizes feel like a game of Diner Dash. Occasionally, other diners may overhear or eavesdrop your conversation and chime in. 

Usually, I go with the Pollo Asado Super Burrito. Although a little bland on its own, but the salsa definitely kicks it up a notch. Combine that with Reed's ginger ale and that's a wonderful meal. For the really adventurous ones, you can opt for the chicken/beef/shrimp super burrito. That shit cray!
author: Dennis L.

description: Pretty dissapointing entrees after enjoying the one-of-a-kind chips and salsa.  My chicken burrito was really dry-the beans were a bit undercooked and had no sauce--they must have just rinsed them off in water after cooking.
