There was a small pile of pico de gallo at the very END of my burrito!  Clearly this place doesn't care and seem to just be trying to ride out their past glory with bare minimum effort.
author: Tom H.

description:
I love you and your food is amazing but I am giving you 2 stars b/c you are so damn stingy with your salsa..

it is amazing but here's my 2 cents.. give enough of it for the amount of chips you give us!! i mean there isn't enough salsa for the bowl of chips let alone the burrito.. and unlike most places that give you free extra salsa you charge a dollar??

lame...
author: Christopher H.

description: Our seven year old (raised on Mission burritos) refused to eat the carne asada from Papalote. "This tastes Americano," he said.
author: Franz T.

description:
A "Whole Foods" take on a Mission burrito.

By "Whole Foods" I mean it's expensive, has premium ingredients, and is served to you in a relatively non-dingy space. So yeah it's probably a little sad that uppity folks like myself come to the Mission and get a fancy pants burrito instead of patronizing a more Mission-y hole-in-the-wall joint, but what can I do... I freaking love their burritos.

Cost per B (burrito) is north of $7 bucks. It's almost always crowded, which is annoying, but you can call ahead for take out, which is my default move. 

Power tip: If you do take out, you have to go to the right register not the left.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Papalote has won SF Weekly's 'Best Burrito' in 07, 08, 09, and 10.  

And I can't disagree.

The flavor. The quality. The quality. The freshness. The flavor. The flavor in these burritos truly stands alone. True flavor. Real quality flavor. There are millions of burrito spots in the Bay Area, taco trucks, taquerias, restaurants; I've honestly never had such a uniquely flavored burrito that you can truly, TRULY taste the quality in- maybe in all of my 'foodie' experiences. 

The meat. The rice. The salsa. None of these ingredients get lost in the burrito- you can clearly taste distinct flavors in every bite. No flavor is hidden. Everything tastes fresh. Everything tastes well seasoned. Everything has pop. The veggies. The meat. The beans. The meat. The salsa. The veggies. I'm rambling. I'm drooling. I'm hungry.

The tacos are good, but they're a bit sloppy. If you're eating here, swoop on the first available seat that opens up. Most importantly, whatever you do, get the burrito.
author: Greg G.

description:
Papalote, the Spanish word for kite, explains why these folks' culinary style is not well grounded. In fact it is an overly hyped mess. Maybe I had the bad chef or maybe San Franciscans are high as a Papalote when they come here so their memory is in the clouds as to whether it really was so great *staring into distance scratching head* or was it even this place at all *nodding in recollection* maybe it was that other Mexican place you know in the Mission full of gringos you know that one...Freaking Mission you've failed this Tejano again. 

3 reasons that had me saying Mehhhhhhh: 

3) I ordered a steak taco and it came out cold and with huge chunks of lettuce and tomatoes on top like a salad. I was like where is my taco oh wait it's under this pile of poorly chopped lettuce that was hurried and thrown on top of my steak taco. Mind boggling to me is why was there signs of hurrying the lettuce (the easiest part) and my steak is cold?

2) Beans were so runny wet and thin that they could have been mistaken for Montezuma's revenge. Safeway brand tin can beans could put these to shame. 

1) Corn tortilla was store bought and still COLD!! It cracked when I folded it. WTF Come On Man, my 5yr old Mexican niece can throw down a better tortilla on top of her easy bake grill.

Papalote No Gracias Guey.
author: R J.

description:
El Farolito, move out the way.  Your PAPA is here to give you a smackdown on your burrito and show you how it is done.  People say this is one the best burrito place in northern california. i think so. 

free Chips and and homemade salsa=descent chips and AMAZING salsa.
Burrito=smoky/juicy chunks of carne asada. super flavorful.  all the ingredients are fresh.
I think I just had the best fish burrito ever here.....oh man.

it's a bit pricier than most burrito joints but huge portions make up for it.  4.5 stars for sure.

it's so good that sometimes, after a bite, i just want to get up and start shaking my body.  but then again, it may traumatize the people i'm eating with.
author: Jang David K.

description:
Ok, this review is for the mole chicken burrito. Straight up edible crack rocks. Delicious. Easily the best burrito I've ever had. The mole sauce is perfectly seasoned and it just rocks. It's the downfall of my near-vegetarianism. They do have a tofu mole burrito but I just can't imagine it being as scrumptious.

The salsa is also extremely fresh-tasting and delicious. Love, love Papalote.
author: Faith S.

description: Gone way downhill. The previous time I had guacamole which had gone bad (they reimbursed me the $1 for the guac, with bad grace--they should've reimbursed me for the whole ruined meal) this time I had stale and rancid-tasting chips. And the prices seem to have gone up-$12 for two small tacos containing precisely 2 prawns each? Covered up with lots of dry lettuce to minimise the lack of actual food. I'm not going there again.
author: l x.

description: Food is over rated. Lacks seasoning and flavor in general. It is amazing what TV publicity can get you.
author: Ray S.

description:
I went to this place expecting really great authentic Mexican food. 
The first attempt was thwarted when they were closed for a special event, so I went to La Taqueria instead..

I came back the following day and what I found disappointed me.
I ordered a carne asada burrito and a ginger beer.
I really wanted a horchata instead, but didn't see it on the menu until I looked behind the counter and noticed they DID have it. I asked to switch my unopened bottle of ginger beer for the horchata but I was denied because I had already paid.. what sort of crap is that?

Obviously off to a bad start, I hoped my burrito would make up for it.
It didn't. I was unimpressed. I should have realized it after noticing that there were no locals in the joint.. just nicely dressed white people (like myself) and prices that were a little high for the area to boot.

It wasn't taco bell quality, but it definitely not worth the praise I read about in reviews like Citysearch. I only put 1 star because I think the ratings need to drop on this place to help ward off any would-be explorers like myself who are expecting real flavor in the mission district.

My only consolation: finally a place worse than stuff I find in Miami! YAY!
author: Jeff G.

description:
Paplote is the kind of place that seriously contributes to the Mission's legendary status of home of the ultra-bombastic burrito.  Known far and wide, well beyond the walls of The City, the Mission is always a must-visit for me every time I come to town, and this is precisely why.  

Fresh, made to order, quality ingredients, and so very  delicious, these little wrapped logs of heaven are just so, so good. Not too greasy, not too heavy, and not too huge, they form the perfect meal.  I think if I were drunk, I would want something bigger, greasier, more insurmountable - we all like a challenge when inebriated. But when hopping off BART on my way to the airport and for my quick Mission fix, Paplote delivered in a major way.

Thanks Susan for the rec, and gracias Paplote for a little taste of divinity.
author: Don B.

description:
2 words - THAT SAUCE. The salsa provided with your meal has a taste you will not find anywhere else - makes anything taste good. 

Being a vegetarian I had the Tofu Burrito and absolutely loved it. Definitely recommend lunch with a small crowd not a lot of space for seating. My friends also enjoyed the Chicken Burritos.
author: Anurag S.

description: Salsa here is a little creamy, so delicious so different!   The triple threat is huge and soooooooooooo good but a bit expensive,  almost $20 for a burrito!   I always get the prawn burrito with grilled veggies and its amazing!  Writing this review is making me want to drive there right now and get one!   2 hr drive for a burrito!  Haha
author: Michaela T.

description:
I waited THIRTY frickin minutes for my ONE order of veggie nachos last night.  

Granted it was the night before Veterans Day and people were probably more inclined to eat out on a Monday night (damn all of you who got the day off today), and it was smack dab during the peak of the dinner rush when I came, I still think waiting 30 minutes is outrageous.  I'm a pretty patient person when it comes to food, but I completely lost my patience when I saw that others who ordered after me were receiving their food before me!  When I went up to the cashier with my receipt, it's as if she already knew what I was going to ask her, and she just gave me a shoulder shrug to blow me off.  And much to my dismay, there was no "Thanks for waiting" or "Sorry for the long wait" or even anything free!  

But damn it, those veggie nachoes doused with extra hot sauce are still delicious!  I will never walk in here with a craving, I know now to call in my order next time.
author: Diane L.

description: It's billed as the having the best burrito the the United States, and being a Bay Area native and Mexican food connoisseur, I had to check it out.  I ordered the steak burrito and I must say, overall, it was very good.  Fresh ingredients and made with love I'd give the burrito an overall 8.5 out if 10.  Have I had better?  Probably.  But the burrito was great and I would highly recommend it, at least so you can say you had the best burrito America has to offer.
author: Edgar D.

description:
duh. its DELICIOUS. 

BUT tonight i learned that ALL OF their beans are VEGAN!! 
...not that i am a vegan. but i do appreciate the fact that i can have ANY kinds of beans i want, no animal fat included.
author: Kaylan S.

description: Amazing rice and beans burrito. We are visiting SF from Vancouver, where Mexican food is really hard to find, and this place totally hit the spot. The salsa was also fantastic! FYI that the bathroom is kind of dark/gross, but hey, at least they have one!
author: Sarah V.

description:
sadness...

I used to love you Papalote...you were cute, better than your average taqueria...your fish and prawn tacos, your mole sauce, your burritos...all had a little something extra, an attention to detail, maybe the fresh greens on the taco, the slices of radish, it was worth a couple extra bux.

But just like a good TV show, success has robbed you of everything that made you special.  Now all I see is:
-- OK Food, still good, but seems to have lost that something extra...no longer better than the cheaper taquerias one block away
--Crowded/long lines/noisy, people constantly standing around waiting, staring at you to finish so they can have your seat
--$$$ - No longer worth the extra few bucks

OH, and my tacos fell apart, they now use one corn tortilla instead of two - did that 2 cents per tortilla really save you that much money  Papalote? 
It pains me to see how success has ruined a formerly great little place.  I'll always remember you the way you were....sadness
author: Peter S.

description:
Being single and poor, niece snuck up at Matt's worksite to gain access to his uncle's wallet and have a decent meal. Matt needs a niece-repellant spray or something.

We had a craving for a burrito, and many of the taquerias in the Mission district is crowded, in which it's no-brainer to figure out during noon. 

We landed at yuppie-like Papalote, and thank goodness, there wasn't much of a line. As we're waiting in line, Matt went to the beverage, which is located on the right side, and grabbed 2 glass bottles of Coke, this jerk right behind me and say,

"Hey buddy, you lost your space in the line. Go back to the very end." 

After the unnecessary remark, Matt retaliated and returned back with a dirty look at him. You can tell easily that the Yuppie neighborhood didn't favor us. 

Matt ordered the Chili Verde (pork w/ green Serrano Sauce) Super Burrito. The $6.50 Super silver-bullet had choice of beans, sour-cream, cheese, salsa and guacamole. Most of the burritos are wrapped in aluminum foil, but since we ate in, the burrito was loose and placed on a plate. So Matt had to eat the wrapped boy with a fork and knife, like a sophisticated yuppie. 

Niece had a pair of delicate Pescado (fish) taco. The $5.95 meal comes delicate piece of buttered fish and salsa blanketed with a corn tortilla. She was so hungry, that she devoured the pair in record time and beating his uncle.

Our meal comes with complimentary Tortilla chip, which tasted exactly like Doritos.  

We were seated at bar-stool near the public lavatory on the left of the restaurant. As we're resting after a hearty meal, a lady finished her #2 and left her massive stench of odor over the entire restaurant and ruining ours and most of the patron's appetite.  

We had a good meal, depsite overcoming what happened in the beginning and the end.
author: Matt G.

description:
I'm torn over how exactly to solve the Papalote Conundrum.

The burritos are top notch.  Even if you're going for the somewhat generic sounding "Chicken Burrito", the result is pretty amazing.  Beyond tasting fresh, you can actually taste all of the ingredients in the burrito and they're big enough to satisfy the hungriest kids (me).  I think this alone merits a fairly high rating.

The bad is that the cost of coming here is high.  Between walking in and waiting (seriously about 15-20 minutes from order to walk out) and dropping nearly $10 for a super burrito, I figured I should've just taken myself to brunch somewhere.  

If the dedicated "Phone Order" register isn't a clue, I'd definitely make calling ahead part of your plan if you are coming here to grab a burrito to go.
author: Steven R.

description:
Came here for lunch with some friends since this was one of my friend's proclaimed "Favorite burrito place in all of San Francisco". The food was fresh and tasty, service was quick, but this wasn't a great place for a group of 5 to meet. There place is tiny and only had about 5 small tables that sat 2 or 3 people, maybe 4 .. but to fit 5 we had to put two tables together and be "that group" of annoying people clogging up the area.

For a quick bite to go or a lunch date with a friend, this is a definite must try.
author: Monika C.

description:
Came here while visiting SF during Memorial Day weekend.  Been hearing a lot of hype about this place so since I was in the Mission, we decided to give this place a try.

Ordered the super chicken quesadilla.  It was just OK.  There wasn't a whole lot of chicken in it.  I can't really explain but it was really just OK.  In my own opinion, I've had better.

I've heard a lot of rave about the salsa, so much that I was even thinking of buying a bottle of it.  Tried it when it came out with my meal, and it was spicy.  Spicier than usual (is what the people next to us said).  

I'm willing to give this place another try next time I'm in town, and maybe split a triple threat with someone!
author: Sandy B.

description:
I really don't understand why ppl are going on and on about this place. In a town like SF where there are plenty of Mexican/burrito joints, methinks this place is totally overrated. But I just had to try it and experience it for myself, esp if they threw down Bobby Flay...

The place is a little small but the tables turn pretty quick, as it's not really a place where you stick around and chit chat with your friends without getting dirty looks from ppl waiting for a table. Props for having an effective system waiting for a table which allows you to preorder your food and having it arrive shortly after being seated.

Overall, the meal was pretty disappointing. The only good thing really, were the loaded nachos.  

The chips that came with the burritos tasted dry and stale. The touted salsa, was underwhelming. That's what I really didn't understand. There was no real taste, except a somewhat mild lingering taste. Sad to say, all of us added a little salt to enhance the flavor. I guess we all expected a little more. 

Chile Verde burrito was not at all what I expected. It had no heat at all, but rather sweet. The rice had a weird texture, it felt almost al dente?? Palatable by me given that I added the slime colored habanero sauce they had on the table (i thought habaneros were orange??), but a total thumbs down by the hubby, who usually eats most everything.

We've had better burritos, both in size and taste, elsewhere in the city and for a better value as well. Who knows? Maybe they were having an off night? Sorry Papalote, I guess you're not meant for us.
author: Ly T.

description:
OK. so the only thing you have to know about papalote is...the SALSA! man o man, this salsa is quite possibly the best creation to be married with a burrito...chips...quesadilla..wait, actually i could eat this salsa on anything. rice..pizza..hot dog. yea, its that good. 

After seeing this place on throw down with bobby flay, i've always wanted to hit this place up. unfortunately, the TRIPLE THREAT burrito is TWENTY bucks? yea insane...but still might get it some day (shrimp, carne asada, chicken, in a giant burrito). 

I ended up getting a regular pollo asada burrito in a spinach tortilla, made it super (guac, sour cream). After waiting for about 10 minutes, the burrito had arrived! The burrito was well sized...and piping hot. Bite after bite, i enjoyed the burrito until it was no more. I found the flavors to be great, ingredients fresh, and with the AMAZING salsa - it was almost the perfect burrito. I would have liked the avocados to be sliced freshly (taqueria cancun!), and perhaps a something else to mix up the burrito texturally (fresh salsa..onions?). 

Overall, i thoroughly enjoyed the burrito - the price was fair at about $9 (not cheap but great quality). Lastly, I would consider buying the salsa by the jar, which they sell at the shop also. I can see why bobby flay lost his throw down to the Papalote bros!
author: Truman S.

description:
The food is actually pretty good. However, their seating policy is like nothing I've ever encountered at any other restaurant.

At any other restaurant, you can walk in, grab a table and put your stuff down to guarantee yourself a seat, then get in line to order. At this place, you may NOT get a table until after your order. If you do and they catch you, you'll be asked to give up the table.

The problem with that is that the place isn't that big and there is often a line, so by the time you've placed your order, there may not be any available tables.  So then what are you supposed to do if you've placed your order for "here" (as opposed to "to go")?  Just stand there waiting while your food gets cold?

Not customer-friendly.
author: Paul L.

description:
one word : Overrated!!

I know the many folks love this place, but i feel that the service was awful!!! not too add that there are plenty of place on mission that offer the same quality of food for half the price.!!


1-* for the salsa!! it was amazing..

-1 * for charging $ 4.50 for small amount guacamole!! 
-1 * for the bad service from the Cashier, after asking why it was so expensive.
-1 * for not getting enough chicken on my burrito
-1 * for the nasty messy tables they had with gross food that you know had to be seating out for a while.
author: Char K.

description:
Excellent salsa. Really tasty chilaquiles. Heavenly black refried beans.

My only complaint? The too-tall tables paired with the too-short chairs in the back. Translation- you can't reach your food. So, if the chair looks like a bar stool, don't sit there otherwise you'll have trouble dipping your chips into their lovely salsa.
author: Miriam W.

description:
As much as I love getting an al pastor super burrito dripping with fat at Cancun, sometimes you just want something a little lighter and fresher - and Papalote hits the spot. The marinated tofu is surprisingly delicious. I think I was a lion in a past life (...rawr) and almost never go for the vegetarian option, but I was talked into the tofu and it was really, really flavorful. 

Come here for tasty burritos that won't make you feel like you're pregnant with food triplets, and make sure you grab a couple of crunchy pickled jalapenos (you can wrap them in the foil on the counter if you're getting your food to go). And even if you're not that hungry, get the super burrito - the regular burrito is pretty bland.

They sell their famous salsa in jars, too!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Amazing Healthy Mexican

Best Mole I have had. Salsa and Chips is also very famous, and for good reason.

Very, very, good food at a very reasonable price.
author: Ethan K.

description:
I've been to Papalote twice, and both times were fantastic. Their veggie burrito is great, with the tortilla expertly grilled and stuffed with goodness. Like most people who've tried their house salsa, I love it,. It tastes vaguely like Doritos chip seasoning (and I mean that in the best way possible). 

They have a big jar of picked peppers and veggies as a nice condiment, and they stock every table with Yucateca green habanero hot sauce.
author: Jordan Z.

description:
Before going to Papalote for the first time we checked out the Yelp! review and my husband (who isn't a fan of Mexican food) said "how can salsa be so great?!"  We now purchase a homemade jar of the salsa EVERY TIME we go!  It's the best.  You even get $1 back for your empty jar - homemade jar only. 

My meat of choice at Papalote is their beef.  You can build an entire entree just around the beef!  It has so much flavor!! 

Don't forget to ask for your "burrito card" when you're there.  If you're taking it to-go call in your order, the line can be out the door (literally). 

Enjoy!
author: Lisa C.

description: Delicious! This place has the tastiest salsa I've ever had. Also tried the carne asada salad, which was easily the best Mexican salad I've had as well. I'll definitely be back!
author: Rajesh S.

description:
Just go.

Seriously.

So, if you like delicious tacos and burritos and oh, fresh salsa, then Papalote is your kind of place. The first time I came here for lunch I had the soyrizo tacos which were fantastic. They serve it fresh with a side of your own chips and salsa. 

After going there for lunch this afternoon with some friends, I decided it was time to write a review. Today I went with the grilled veggie burrito, which was delicious. My only complaint is that it was loaded with black beans, which I requested, I just wish there had been more of the grilled zucchini and eggplant. Oh well, it was still deliciously satisfying. We all shared an order of chips and salsa, on top of the side of chips and salsa that they already give each individual order. The salsa is SO good. My friend talked me into buying a jar of it on my way home, one of the best decisions I made all day. It's fresh with a definite kick, so beware if you're sensitive to spice. Also, highly recommend getting your burrito/taco to-go and enjoying it in Dolores Park when the weather's nice.

Side note, they also serve Mexican cokes (pure cane sugar=the real stuff) as well as a wide range of cold beers to enjoy with your delicious Mexican entree of choice.
author: Emily S.

description:
It's amazing to me when you cross Mission street to Valencia it's like going to another world. 

Enter the world of high-end burritos... 
If you want pretty amazing burritos (this is coming from a 2 year mission citizen) this is place for you. Their pescado burritos were quite amazing. Their salsa is definitely different than your standard fare. The chips were crisp and quality. The sit down experience here was quite nice, you order your food and they bring you chips/salsa then your food. There was a nice amount of space in the restaurant. 

This place is delivering burritos to the crowd that's willing to spend more than 7$ per burrito. If you're looking the cadallic experience of burritos this is place.  

Bathroom experience:
Didn't get a chance to use it.

Take out experience:
Quite slow to get 3 burritos, we waited a good 10 minutes. Way too much for a quick in/out. Tip: call in your order for pickup!
author: Michael S.

description: I got food poisoning from a burrito here on my birthday. Didn't eat anything else all day, had a chicken mole burrito then later that night had to leave my own birthday party to go home and hang out in the bathroom all night. I'll never live down having friends show up to my party and I not be there. Thankfully it passed (ahem) within 24 hrs but the timing could not be worse. I urge you to pass as well on Papalote.
author: Alex A.

description:
This storefront could be mistaken for a dive...delightfully, it is anything but.  Wonderful burritos, tacos and quesadillas with fresh, fresh, fresh ingredients are here in a simple store front with limited seating in the middle of a neighborhood where only authentic Mexican food can survive.  Grilled fish, shrimp and chicken were our choice and we were delighted with the results. I was sorry the salsa wasn't filled with tomato pieces instead of  simply a thick sauce, but nonetheless it was spicy and tasty.

This is another example of what the Mission does best, present ethnic cuisine without frills or fuss at a reasonable price.

Order at the front counter and they will bring your food  to the table when it is ready. (Try not to notice that no one wiped down the table after the last customer....he didn't leave any crumbs anyway). Think of  a visit here as a cultural immersion experience and take note of the colorful photographs on the cheerful, red walls.
author: Lynn S.

description: Really don't understand why people dig this place.  My friend digs the fish burrito so I tried it and it was pretty less than average.   Lack of flavor for me doesn't designate good food..
author: Mitch A.

description:
I got the chile verde pork tacos, and I made them super for 99 cents more. The plate was definitely larger than I thought it would be, and I think the super-ness made it too hard to actually eat the tacos by hand. I had to use a fork to pare them down a bit before I could even get them to the point where I could pick one up to eat it. That said, the chile verde was good, but felt like the rest of the toppings weren't awesome.

I ate at the restaurant, and after a short wait, we got a table. The server brought each person a small bowl of chips and a small container of salsa. The salsa was great, spicy and a good appetizer.
author: C S.

description:
This is what me and my friend affectionately refer to as "white people food"  Tasteless and pretty much flavorless food...cooked for the masses who don't know better.  I have never had anything from this place that even remotely touched on what I would consider spicy.  The prices are through the roof for me and its usually packed, service varies, but typically they are rushed,stressed out and too busy to care. 

So sad..really.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Two words: Mole Tofu. This place is the answer to every vegetarian's dreams. I know nothing of the chicken adobo, or whether the carnitas (if they even have it) stacks up against El Farolito's or Taquieria Cancun's. That can't matter to me cause I'm stuck with the veggie (really beans, or at best chile relleno) options over there. Papalote gives the treatment veggie options deserve. 
Also, there salsa is not only better than any other, it is a redefinition of the category 'salsa'. It's more like a mole or adobo, but creamier, that decided it wanted to be served cold on chips instead of used as a marinage/grilling sauce on proteins.
Another place there game is on another level are the prints of famous singers (done as two-tones that make them surreal and pop) covering the walls. Go there because Prince (and apparently the Mexican National Team:http://sfist.com/2014/07/07/mexican_world_cup_players_return_fr.php) sent you.
author: Ory P.

description:
The salsa at this restaurant is DYNAMITE! I could out it on just about anything . I ordered the Triple Threat which is a burrito filled with grilled shrimp, chicken, steak and also loaded with sour cream, guacamole, rice and black beans, absolutely FANTASTIC!
The chicken, steak and shrimp were seasoned just right, full of flavor and juicy. 
 I can't wait to go back :)
author: Shawn S.

description:
This place was interesting as it seems to make a slightly healthier cuisine than most Mission Mexican restaurants.  It is on the Valencia side, I suppose.

Tried a marinated tofu burrito.  I've always been a skeptic of Tofu in burritos, I usually just opt for extra beans.  I should have done the same here.  No discredit to the preparation, it was delicious, but tofu and burritos just dont mix easily in my book.

The best thing they have going is their salsa.  It is highly addictive.  I am planning to buy a jar next time I swing by.  Its legit.
author: Raman S.

description:
As is tradition with my European travels these days, the first thing I do upon returning to my beloved San Francisco (don't worry babe, I may be cheating on you with Berlin, Madrid and London but I'm always coming home) is get something you can't find anywhere else: a massive burrito. I was thinking Papalote from the minute I stepped on my flight home, and I was still thinking about it the minute I stepped off. Next stop: 24th Street Mission BART / i.e. burrito mecca.

Such a hyped member of our Mexican food scene, but I can't say I share your enthusiasm. My marinated tofu burrito was great. Plenty of soy, plenty of black beans and plenty of salsa, all wrapped up nicely in a wheat tortilla. But the cost. Did I bring London prices back with me? No burrito should be over $7. Or $8 plus change, as is the case here.

A reluctant three stars. Quality and portions were great, earning them a third star, but I can't go higher at these prices.
author: Jason B.

description:
You were right, the salsa is peerless.

I saw an ex-coworker from Palo Alto and her surgeon fiancee. We hugged. Then I returned to my date. We sipped from the same bottle of Mexican Coke between bites of notable fish tacos.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Look. I love Mexican food. I'm from Southern California, it's part of the culture here. So my cousin and I couldn't help but eat some more mexican food while we were up in SF, especially as our last meal.  We were dragging our luggage all over the streets of Mission looking for this restaurant, which is some what difficult to find when you are obviously not familiar with the area and when its kind off the street without a large sign. But we found it finally and when I walked in I knew we were in a good place. 

Lots of sizzling and delicious smells and lots of people grubbing, those are always good signs. I didn't feel like eating tacos (I always eat them in LA so I wanted something a little different) and I saw the mole and I knew I wanted it immediately. I love mole, I love the sauce, sweet, salty and delicious. And I got a nice hochata, I love horchata (although I wish they gave me a little more ice since it was pretty hot in the restaurant!). My cousin got the carnitas verde (I think- well it certainly had the verde sauce). 

I didn't realize how big the portions were until they gave us the plates, but it was huge and it came with rice and beans, mmmmm. They also gave us generous portions of warm tortillas. My cousin and I immediately dug in, things were bursting out of our tacos and the couple who just sat down next to us, waiting for their food were staring at us. I have to say I liked my cousin dish because it had a little heat to it, some spice, but the chicken mole was pretty good too. I wish I had more room in my stomach to finish it all or could take it to go if I was staying longer, but unfortunately I couldn't finish it all (yes I was disappointed in myself).

I highly recommend people to grub here if they get a chance. I do have a warning about the bathroom, it was a little frightening in there (and quite nesty) so I would use it for washing up. But nonetheless I loved the food and that was the most important part of the experience!
author: Helen P.

description: Best burrito place ever!!!  I drive from Oakland just to get takeout from here. They make my special order with a smile and even remember it since I have been eating here for so long. I get a jar of salsa almost every time I'm there too. Could not recommend more. Great food, nice people, what else could you want?  Six stars!!!!!!
author: Kevin C.

description: Very fresh + fast Mexican food. Usually that's an oxymoron, not when it comes to Papalote. Took my nephews yesterday and was pleased we could dabble in the menu (bean and cheese burritos for the adventurous nephews, chicken al achiote with jicama salad for me). And yes, the salsa is amazing! Just spicy enough and clearly NOT from a jar. So yes, will be going back to Papalote now that it's on my radar...also while the place looks packed upon approach, there is someone helping seat people so even with our group of 5, it didn't take more than 5 minutes to get a table. A good thing to remember...
author: Erin W.

description:
Okay honestly, Papalote is not really a 1 star but I had to give it a 1 star review because I need to bring the average down.

I went to Papalote because I originally saw it on Throw Down with Bobby Flay on Food Network and they hyped it up to this amazing burrito that I thought would blow my mind. 

DISAPPOINTED! At best, Papalote was okay. Other than their salsa, their burrito is not much better than Chipotle.

This is the reason for my campaign against Paplote. I just want to warn other foodies from traveling long distances expecting something amazing and being let down.

ENJOY.
author: Danny S.

description:
Papalote has "Mexican Grill" in the name, and that's basically what it is. It's more than just a burrito joint, although that's what they're famous for, and it's not a full-scale Mexican restaurant either--something in-between. They have plenty of options on the menu for meats, sauces, etc... and of course their world famous salsa! You can get it at a Whole Foods near you, but the freshly bottled salsa you get from their refridgerator at the restaurant is the way to go if you have the opportunity.

Plus you gotta love that the owner beat Bobby Flay on Food Network's "Throwdown" show, and he'll also be appearing on an upcoming episode of "Chopped." Pretty brilliant that they have collabo swag like the FTC skate decks and New Era fitteds.

If you live in the Bay and haven't eaten at either of the two Papalote locations yet, get familiar!
author: Patrick L.

description:
The sauce/salsa is great.  Everything else in my Carne Asada Super Burrito was just ok.  One thing was that the avocado and sour cream was not evenly spread out in the burrito.  Also, not enough sour cream.. tsk tsk.. 

Anyway, the wait for a table can get quite long.   Not sure if it's worth the wait and price.  
Also tried their fish taco and that was not bad, but not awesome either. Think I'll stick to El Farolito to supply my burrito fix.
author: AhLin C.

description: Have to say, we went through a love - hate - like relationship with Papalote.  Had some visitors recently from out of town and after a few foiled attempts at some other places in the Mission, ended back here and was impressed.  Have the usual (rice and bean super burrito) and it was quite tasty.  The burrito was made very well and everything had good flavor.  The price is still a little on the high side, but would come back if I was in the  neighborhood.
author: Sheetal P.

description: Most recently had a carne asada burrito that was flavorful, but incredibly salty. Papalote is usually pretty decent, but given that it's pricier than its neighbors (La Taqueria and el Farolito), probably won't be rushing back anytime soon.
author: Andrew C.

description:
The hype monster lives.

Hubs and I first heard about this place on the Bobby Flay showdown show. Hubs thinks that Bobby Flay is the biggest douche-bag that ever walked the earth so he definitely wanted to try the Triple Threat burrito since it beat Bobby Flay's green burrito.

After tasting for myself Papalote's famed Triple Threat burrito, I seriously doubt either:

Bobby Flay's cred as an Iron Chef 

or 

the crediblity of the judges

because that burrito was hella average.

The meats were nicely grilled but as a total burrito, it was average

AND

at $20, I expect to pay for quality, not quantity. The burrito is huge but if I wanted a large amount of average tasting burrito, I'd order 2 regular sized burritos.

The salsa is really good. The burrito is not worth a 2nd visit.

Oh and I saw unmelted shredded cheese on a shrimp burrito - questionable.

What the hell Bobby Flay?
author: Kiristen R.

description:
Favorite burrito in SF, hands down.  I take friends here all the time when visiting.  A cross between legit Mexican and Mission hipster/funk.

Veggie burritos are great.  Recommend the classic vegetarian (with potatoes) with cheese, no rice, add guac, whole wheat tortilla
author: Michael O.

description:
Probably the best carne asada around. They grill it up right there and then with fresh ingredients and of course you gotta get it super!!! Burrito or taco = yum yum... Add a little of that amazing orange sauce and OMG goodness!!!

Pending on time of day, parking is a biatch...  and good luck getting a table...
author: Minh V.

description:
I have always really loved this place, but the last several times I've gone in, the quality and level of service has gone down significantly.  I always order the same thing-- the tofu mole, and twice recently I was served regular grilled tofu with no mole sauce.  When they did get my order right, there hasn't been as much mole sauce as there used to be.  Moreover, the people at the registers always are rude, act annoyed and seem like they really hate their jobs. 

I hope this place starts paying more attention to quality and customer service.
author: V M.

description:
The line seems infinite.  

I am finally at Papalote.  It is late at night.  The line seems infinite. She is on my mind. I am alone. 

The cool San Francisco night breezes in through the open door.  The line out the door.  The line seems infinite. 

There are few burritos that show you your soul.  That is Papalote.  The line seems infinite, sure.  But here I wait.  Waiting at Papalote.  She is on my mind. 

Too many minutes pass, and finally I am placing my order.  Goddamn.  The line seems infinite. The tiny radio behind the counter plays some kind of Mexican music.  I daydream that it is the story of a drug courier, lamenting the woman he left behind.  Maybe I'm right. I do not speak the language, so I will never know.  For now, she is on my mind. I take a red number, number 32 and walk to the dining area, hoping to find a table. 

I luck out and find a table near the window, just being cleared. I sit. I smile at the waitress.  She smiles back, a crooked smile, but a real one it seems to me.

I look out the window. I see a man with an acoustic guitar under his arm.   The acoustic guitar is blue. The man is old, with long hair.  He looks like a broken glam star from the seventies.  He looks like David Johansen.  She is on my mind.   

Number 32 is called and I walk to the counter, take my burrito.  I walk back to my table and sit down.  I begin to eat.  I feel my soul in the burrito.  The stars melt together.  The moon sinks below the horizon of Valencia Street.  Tomorrow is already here.  Tomorrow will never arrive.
author: P. William G.

description:
WOW
I just dont get it.
The salsa was a weird creamy-esque mess, full of smoke, no heat or flavor

Burrito- I have truly had better at taco bell, truly- carne asada- seco (dry). no flavor, chewy because they did not cut against grain.  Beans, no salt?

Wife has chorizo- no bueno, no spice, no flavor no nada

I do not get it.  This food is not good AT ALL.  whosoever thinks different has not had good mexican taqueria food.
author: Hung L.

description:
What a Burrito... As a vegan, this is the best burrito I have had since I have lived in San Francisco. Really close to 5 stars, but I need something to push me over that edge that was missing a little. 

The standard mission vegetarian burrito tends to be pretty tasteless and disappointing. The proprietors here seem to have actually put some creativity and effort into the vegan options which makes me know that I will be back many times. General rule: If you love the vegans, the vegans will love you.

I had the Soyrizo burrito. This burrito is chocked full of delicious Soyrizo, rice, ad beans. Toward the end though, the saltyness caught up with me. Soyrizo is pretty salty, so it is understandable. Next time, I will be consuming the tofu mole burrito. I have high hopes.

As for the salsa, It was good. I wouldn't cross into the great department because I didn't find it as spicy as I would like for a GREAT salsa. They do provide 2 hot sauces that you can douse your burrito in.
author: Peter V.

description:
I guess I can see why people would like soyrizo burritos, but it's not the type of burrito I would crave for. It is better than other vegetarian burritos at other tacquerias, but it wasn't not enough to thrill me. I'm not a vegetarian, but every now and then I'll try the vegetarian menu. Maybe I should have stuck to a pollo burrito like I always get. But I did try the carne asado burrito my friend got, and it was good, but again not enough to thrill me. And I actually didn't like the tomato salsa too much. I don't understand the hype, but I guess everyone has different taste buds... 

I mean don't get me wrong, it wasn't gross, but I have had just as good or even better burritos.
author: April D.

description:
HOLY FRICKIN COW!  Chicken mole burrito, no rice, black beans, tomato tortilla - outta sight!  The best burrito EVER.  Homemade roasted red pepper salsa is undeniably the best salsa I have ever, ever, ever, ever, ever had.  And the homemade chips are delicious.

I can't even tell you how many "Buy 10 Burritos, get the 11th free" cards I've filled up here.  

Usually best to call ahead if you want something for take-away, as the line (and the wait) can be a bit long.  And it's not really that the wait is that long, it's just that there's not a lot of space to wait.  

Fresh ingredients, and I like the respectful menu options for vegetarians and vegans.
author: Evan G.

description: Probably the best burritos I've had in the city ever. Taste so good makes you wanna slap yo mama.
author: Christopher R.

description: Such good food. Reasonably priced, fast and yummy. Also, amazing salsa!! If you're in the mood for a delicious burrito, this is definitely the place to go.
author: Stef S.

description:
I'm teetering between a 3 and a 4.....I feel like I only review Mexican places and liquor holes (bars. get your mind out of the gutter), but I guess that means those two things are what I know best. Coming from South Bay, I admit I'm kind of a Mexi-snob. Well Papalote...I gave you a chance with the hype, salsa, and big burrito on my plate ready to take in bite by bite.

I got the Carne Asada super burrito, and I'd say the burrito itself was a 3. The burrito was as flat as a pancake, and it was empty and soft inside. I like my burritos dense, not sagging in my hands like its a chore to feed me. The only thing that redeems this place to a 4 star rating is their salsa. I wouldn't call it salsa, I'd call it sauce. The flavor completes any burrito, just try it to understand how they can get away with charging several dollars for a mason jar full.

NOTE: for those of you out there who know what 'Orange Sauce' is from San Jose, this is the closest thing you're gonna get in the city. Hell, I think this sauce might even be better than La Vic.

Anyway, props to Papalote for keeping the Mission charm. Dig the vibes from the art in there. Nice location in the Mission near BART. I'd go back after drinking. But if it were up to me for getting Mexican in the Mission, I'd hit up El Farolito for a suiza instead.
author: Samantha R.

description:
I got the Triple Threat Burrito for $20. Yes, I spent $20 on a burrito, please don't make the same mistake I did. The burrito wasn't horrible, but it wasn't good enough to justify the cost of being two to three times more expensive then other burritos in the Mission or anywhere else in SF. 

Food: Maybe a little better for comparable Mexican food, but not good enough to justify the higher cost and longer wait. The chips and creamy salsa were different and good in it's own way. I also enjoyed the small side of pickled beets or daikon or whatever it is they serve with the burrito. 

Ambiance: Small clean restaurant but can get very crowded. And if you have a large party, five or more, be ready to wait an extra 10 to 15 minutes to get seated.

Service: Everyone is nice, but not overly friendly and do their job well.

Price: Like most other people said, a few dollars more expensive then other Mexican places.

Overall: Check it out if you're in the area or if you're curious enough to try the burrito that supposedly beat Bobby Flay, but in all honesty you probably already have a neighborhood Taqueria in your own area that will make you more happy.
author: Binh D.

description:
Wow!!!! The freshest and tastiest fish taco that I've had in my life! Don't bother with the rest of the stuff. F-I-S-H T-A-C-O

Got it :) ???
author: Javi V.

description: Pretty hyped up but the food is good. It's one of those taquerias where you could eat the food blindfolded and be able to guess it correctly. My fiance claims it's the best carne asada she's ever had. The sauce is good too but they shouldn't charge for extra. If you buy a bottle tho, get the home made stuff in the mason jar, not the factory jars as they do not even compare.
author: Mike T.

description:
Maybe one of the best burritos in sf gotta love the triple threat!! 
 oo and man the salsa is always different but always good!!
author: Joe A.

description: I had my first trip here which was long awaited after hearing about it for so long.  The salsa is just amazing.  The meats and entrees were made fresh and to order.  I'm torn.  I think La Taqueria's tortillas and Carnitas still win out but should the families of La Taqueria and Papalote marry, no one could stop them from world domination.  Don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Darin E.

description: On my quest from Portland I managed to stop by Papalote to try some of what I heard to be pretty awesome veg burritos. I was impressed by the sauce that came with the chips and the burritos themselves were great. It would be nice to have that rad sauce or another house made sauce for the burritos. Next time I am in the Bay I will make sure to stop by this joint again.
author: Tommy T.

description: tasty burrito...food tends to be overpriced. good sauce, tho
author: Ericha F.

description: This is literally the best Mexican restaurant in San Francisco. The flavor, freshness and overall experience cannot be topped. The salsa is spicy and can be bought in jars. I'd highly recommend the Valencia St location although the lines can get a bit long at times. The staff is friendly and helpful.
author: Hilary S.

description:
I'm gonna go ahead and say I hate this place.  A lot of The City dwellers might cry, but it is what it is.

Now let me start by saying that the food is not bad.  It's actually pretty good.  Solid.  Definitely not life-changing though.  That said, $20 for that triple threat is grand larceny.  It's obnoxious.  If I'm dropping over a dub on a burrito, then it had better be gigantic or mind-blowingly delicious... ideally, both.  The triple threat was neither.  It was merely hefty and good.  Worth $21?  Hell no.  

And don't think the regular prawn burrito will give you any more bang for your buck.  For $11 (w/ sour cream & guac), you can expect a grand total of 3 prawns.  Worth it?  Another emphatic, hell no.   

Papalote's food is not bad.  Really.  But their prices are insulting.  For that kind of money, I would much rather go to Chipotle.  Yup, McDonald's-owned, quasi-Mexican, burrito-bowl-serving Chipotle.  Definitely a better value.
author: Jaymar C.

description: I dunno -- I get the upscale take on burritos.  But given the price, my mole burrito wasn't really cutting it.  The food was satisfactory, and the decor and service reflected the higher prices.  However,  with alternatives nearby I'd be hard-pressed to come back to Papalote for delicious burritos.
author: Bill H.

description:
Absolutely awful...the most overrated burrito joint i have ever been to...talk about neutralizing Mexican food!...

I had the soyrizo super burrito and it was a mess...my girlfriend had the chicken burrito and she compared the fowl niblets to dog food...

overpriced and generally disgusting....

imagine the cuisine at Chevy's accompanied by PBR guzzling hipsters and you have a fraction of an idea of what this place is like...

with a plethora of great burrito joints within a five block radius, who would eat here?
author: Sgtslut F.

description: Came in here with my boy AA and ordered a Carne Asada Quesadilla for $7.25. It had jicama, guacamole, salsa, and pico de gallo. The meat was freshly grilled and the cheese was melted perfectly. High quality stuff. It was served to us on our table but previous to that there was a legit orange sauce and chips. I say legit because you could see the crushed tomatoes and pimentos in there. Did I say this place was ZAGAT rated? now it's BRIAN rated as well.
author: Brian C.

description: Mexipino buritto- best burrito in the city, period.  Add some House Salsa, and you're done.
author: Raza U.

description:
I almost feel spoiled going to all these establishments worthy of 5 stars. My buddy from work keeps taking me to hit up these places and every time, I leave there wanting more. Fortunately with Papalote, I got to take some of that goodness home with me.

Let me start by saying their food is great. I had the Chicken Adobo Burrito and that was just delicious. But what truly made it taste so much better was their special sauce they give you with your chips. I poured some of that on my burrito and it was....OMG...AMAZING! I can honestly say, you can go anywhere, make anything, pick something off the ground, whatever. You pour that sauce on it and it will taste PHENOMENAL!!! La Vic's sauce in SJ was once my favorite but it has just been officially replaced by Papalote!

For the sauce alone, I give this place 5 stars. Then when you add awesome service, great atmosphere, and great people, this place deserves even higher than that.
author: Gajan K.

description:
I had their burrito with the asada,chicken, shrimp, and chile sauce. It was not worth the $20. The Chile sauce is good but i think they took
a page from La victoria in San Jose. I would take La victoria Chile Sauce over Papalotes any day.
author: Mario M.

description:
The food network combined with the 7x7 list almost forced me to come here on my last SF visit.  After ordering a burrito, chips and salsa and a couple of tacos, I decided to take a seat.  It was amusing that even the lady behind the counter noticed the feast that I ordered and told the food runner how the number of people at our table was less than the number of entrees ordered in Spanish.  

The rice and bean burrito was excellent, as were the chips and salsa (the 7x7 item).  The marinated tofu tacos lacked taste.  I really wish I had opted for the soyrizo, but my stomach was recovering still and I did not feel the need to risk it.  Next time, soyrizo will be my taco filling of choice!
author: Jason P.

description: All the hype wasn't really substantiated. But that said, it was still a delicious burrito! Don't recommend the guac b/c it's overpriced at $8. But what I do recommend is the fresh salsa they give you free with your chips! That alone made this place a 4 star vs. 3 star joint. Not sure what goes into it but it's more than just normal tomato salsa. They were even charging $0.50 extra for refills. We noticed customers buying jars of it to go... and they recommended we buy the fresh ones and not the ones on the shelf because they have preservatives in them that changes the flavor. Overall it's a solid joint, but I wouldn't make the effort to go here unless it was on the way or nearby.
author: Steph W.

description:
I was thrilled to try a burrito in the Mission district. The burrito itself didn't thrill me but it was good probably better than I have had anywhere else.  I am not a huge burrito fan but can enjoy them from time to time. 
I think I had a fish burrito and he had pork. 
In general I don't have chips when I go to a cheap Mexican place because most of the chips are recycled and other people might have touched them. I know it's weird but unless I am starving I do not go for the chips. So my husband said the chips and salsa were good. 
Fortunately for us there was no wait. None at all. We were the first people there when they opened. We actually got there before the place opened. So no complaints on a wait from me. 
I think it's one of those things you have to do when in San Fransisco go to the Mission district for  a burrito. I did so I can take it off my bucket list now. :)
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
Papalote is slightly miraculous in that I never even feel the need to eat their meat options.  I freaking LOVE meat, particularly chicken (when it comes to burritos), but I never need to even go there at Papalote.  The soyrizo burrito will cure all meat-cravings.

Soyrizo! Soyrizooooooooo! I love you SO! It is so perfectly spicy, and the burritos here are huge! I'm talking the size of my face.  Face-sized burritos for the win!

Sorry, got a little excited there.  I'm trying to say that Papalote's vegetarian options are amazing (this coming from a girl that doesn't even like vegetables, haaa).  And then there's the salsa.  Is there cream in that salsa? I can't figure it out.  At any rate, the salsa is the crack.  Crackalacking salsa.  I need you all the time. Like right now.  Salsa.  I NEED YOU.
author: Jessie H.

description:
As a San Francisco native, their burrito is on point.  Especially that orange sauce that they give you with your chips!  Drizzle that all over your burrito and call it a day.  

I come here often with friends and family.  Once, my friend ordered two fish tacos and another friend ordered the nachos supreme.  The tacos were soggy so it was difficult for my friend to enjoy them the way that is normally enjoyed, but the nachos were great!  They do not serve the agua fresca that I love, but their Horchata is still comparable. 

Seating here is given to those who order first on a busy night.  I noticed that someone was kicked off their table before they had ordered, so definitely take note of that!
author: Reb R.

description: Not worth it.  Friendly and fast service, for sure, but the food is bland and stale-tasting.  The veggie taco had ingredients that just didn't work well together, the chips were tough, the salsa was weird, and the guac didn't help.  You could do better in your own kitchen, even if you're not a cook.
author: Anna S.

description:
2.5 stars

The pollo asado burrito remains delicious on account of their special marinade and the grill flavor.  Every bite yum.  
But what if I came in one day with the family and we tried something different... perhaps one of their plates?

Pork chile verde:  should've been named Green Pork in Garlic Sauce cause that's all we could taste.  Not the tangy, intangible yum of tomatillos. Not the zing of chili.  Hell, not even pork-flavored. Care to guess what you COULD taste?  Fail.

Chicken Mole:  was rich as mole negro should be.  The sauce is deeply flavored BUT way over-chocolate-y, covering up practically all the chili pepper flavors.  The chicken breast was tough, overcooked to the point in which it required earnest effort to cut with a fork. 

Spanish omelet:  good cheesy goodness with mushrooms and bell peppers throughout but it suffered from overcooked eggs.  Browned scrambled egg has a particularly strong flavor and if you dig it, you'll be pleased.  I find it just short of revolting.

Conclusion:  stick with the burrito at $7.50 and pass on the $13 plates.
author: Ben S.

description: This place is way overrated, over priced and most importantly their food sucks. A lot of people, mostly hipsters and college students, seem to love this place but I'm just not on the band wagon. It's nice to try for the novelty since it was featured on the Food Network but be prepared to be underwhelmed and dissatisfied.
author: Ruperto F.

description: Wow! My very first Yelp review and I am very excited to write about this place. I love Mexican food and this place is authentic and legit as it gets. Food/Ingredients were fresh, service was fast and they have THE BEST salsa in the world. So good that I had to go back to the counter to ask for one more cup and the cashier gave me a stink-eyed attitude about the cost being $0.50 more if I wanted it. I walked away because I didn't have cash on me and didn't feel like pulling out my debit card just for a $0.50 transaction, even though I kind of thought about doing it. Then 30 seconds later here comes the server (who overheard our conversation) with a complimentary cup of salsa in hand just for me. He made my night and became part of the reason why I am going to go back. If there was a 1/2 star rating I'd give this place 4 1/2 stars. Unfortunately I had to deduct 1/2 a star because of the rude cashier. Thanks for making me feel stupid for not knowing it cost $0.50 for extra salsa. Next time I will buy my own jar so that I wouldn't have to bother you again.
author: Sop S.

description: Had never had a mission burrito before coming here and holy cow it was next level. While I still have love for chipotle, 9 times out of 10 I'll head to papalote to get a burrito. I went with the steak burrito "super" with an extra salsa.
author: Jeff M.

description:
I now know why this place put the smackdown on Bobby Flay -- it's that salsa that's so damn good you want to lick it off just about anything.  I'm not sure if the secret ingredient is something as simple as creme fraiche or as addictive as crack, but I don't care just as long as they keep serving it. 

I've ordered the camarones taco and burrito as well as the queso dip with meat.  The camarones are in a light white wine and butter sauce which doesn't overpower the taco and compliments the seafood.  The queso with meat is baked and has a slightly crispy top which when broken by a chip or a fork, unveils a delightful stringy cheesiness and spicy chorizo that is great alone or with chips/tortillas.  If you are looking for a taqueria that's reasonably priced with fresh ingredients and is a step up from the likes of Cancun and El Farolito, this is your new spot.
author: Yea A.

description:
So for the longest time, the ONLY burrito I would get in the Mission (or Mexican food, for that matter) was at El Farolito. You couldn't even convince me to try another restaurant due to my traumatic "taqueria" experiences in the East Bay. Why not just stick to what works, right?

So I went with 2 friends for lunch last Sunday by one of their recommendations. You go into a small, cramped area with registers, order your food, pay and then sit down. The whole restaurant is encased in a small square room packed with tables and chairs. In the corner they have a roll of aluminum foil for your leftovers, and a self-serve water thingy (? brain isn't working well today) and a stack of cups for the cheapskates.  My friend (who made the recommendation) bought a whole jar of salsa that she started raving about. Now, I'm from Texas, and salsa means watery, tomato-y and pico-de-gallo-y. What she was holding in a jar was thick, almost creamy-looking red sauce... kinda like marinara. Honestly I was a little put off and couldn't imagine it being THAT good.

We sat down to small bowls of thick, crunchy tortilla chips and tiny ramekins of said salsa. Peeps, this salsa's legit. I'm not too picky when it comes to salsas (though I'm used to the Tex-Mex kind)... but it was amazing. And spicy!! Just the flavor that they pack into every bite! I should've written this review when the flavors were fresher on my mind, but it's been almost a week and I've forgotten, sorry! Just know that it's legit.

I ordered a tofu burrito (because I've been on a vegetarian kick lately), and I gotta say that I really didn't miss the absence of meat. The tofu was flavored well, the beans were awesome (I ordered the refried black beans, and they tasted lard-i-licious even though they were vegetarian, too). I could only finish half of the burrito, but I took the other half home. It was the perfect, filling meal on that cold, rainy day. Just wished I could've taken a burrito-food-coma nap, and it would've been a perfect Sunday.

It just seems like a higher-class, healthier burrito than El Farolito. When I want something dirty and satisfying, El Farolito is still my #1 choice. But when I want something without feeling guilty, or feel like I'm eating for a cause, I'll mosey on over here.
author: Becky K.

description:
I just discovered the chicken mole burrito. If you need a change from the classics, this is it.

Papalote ingredients are definitely above average quality. Salsa, obviously quite outstanding as many before have stated. They are really milking the Bobby Flay throwdown thing these days, but I guess who can blame them.

Call in your order or be prepared to wait.
author: Julia G.

description:
Yes, I took friends here just because I saw it on Throwdown.  I knew I had to get the salsa here, but we also tried some of their various dishes.  This place is cool for not over-advertising their fame, and also keeping their restaurant very local and quaint.  We had to wait a few minutes to even sit down for some quick-paced Mexican grub.

The food here is served in large portions, but the prices are quite up there.  They are known for their sun-dried tomato salsa, but it is somewhat one-dimensional in my opinion.  It lacks the freshness of salsa (they sell it by the bottle), and it has too much American jazziness to it.

The best thing by far is the fish, in any form.  The white wine and butter sauce is exquisite, and the fish is extremely moist and tender.  The quesadilla option is a bit pricey, though.

The chicken mole kind of stunk.  The sauce was pretty heavy on the sweetness; it could have used more chiles.  The chicken was not super moist, and it was $13.  The chicken burrito was a bit dry, but the chile verde pork was better.  The CV had a tangy, hearty sauce that paired well with the tender pork.

There is nothing to really rave about here, but I guess it is worth a shot if you are into unique salsas and stuff.  The food is a little pricier than normal, but it does the job, and there are offerings to satisfy everyone.
author: Solomon W.

description:
We decided to give this place a try after watching the show on Food Network Bobby Flay's Throwdown. He competed on who can make the best burrito against the 2 owners of the restaurant and at the end Papalote won with its Triple Threat Burrito which has chicken, prawns, carne asada and the usual rice, beans, Etc. So after watching the show a few days later we decide to give it a try so my husband hops on Bart and takes off for S.F. When he gets there he calls me and tells me that the Triple Threat Burrito is $ 20 buckz each...I said fuck it you went all the way out there we might as well get it! When he gets back I couldnt wait to tear it up...lol OMG it was so fuckn gooooood! The tortilla was not steamed but kinda crunchy but not hard at all it was just perfect and their salsa was delish too!  

I still haven't gone back till this day to try anything else but pics I've seen on here look delish I will have to go back n try something different....I hope cuz I might just end up with another Triple Threat lol
author: Johanna G.

description:
+ Their house salsa is tasty

- The service is terribly slow. I've not gotten out of there without spending 10 minutes waiting for my food. The last time I was there, it was before a shift change at the cashier, and they forgot about our order. Even though the restaurant was empty, it took over 20 minutes. No apology.
- When we got home we discovered that they had forgotten a portion of our order (but still managed to charge us for it). I complained via their website. It's been 4 days, and I've not received a response.
- They have numerous vegetarian options, and with my last visit I've now tried them all. They sound interesting, but they taste the same: salty, beany, and dull. Nothing fresh and bright. Just lots of carbs. At these prices, I expect more than food for drunks.

I went here (1) because of the illusion of lots of choices, and (2) because it was close to where I live. But there are hundreds of taquerias in the Mission, and I'm done with them. What's your excuse?
author: Andrew B.

description:
I admit, I'm not a big fan of Mexican food, Tex mex is probably the best I've had and that's in Austin. So when clients suggest Mexican I'm not too adventuress. I usually do fajitas or if it's grab and go, just a burrito with no sour cream and maybe no guacamole.

This is the best burrito I have ever gotten hands down. It's so dense  that I feel like I need a nap after though. Which is it's only negative, but that's a positive if you want great tasting and filling.

This is the only Mexican place I put on my come back places in San Francisco.
author: Brandon M.

description: The burritos are definitely good, if overpriced and uninspiring. The salsa is really noteworthy, though, and the ambiance is charming, with lots of nods to Frida Kahlo, for no discernable reason.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Mmm

I heard about Papalote because they beat douchebag bobby flay in the throwdown show and was surprised at how many veggie options they have.

Highly suggest the Soyrizo or the grilled veggie if your a vegetarian.  Also, the salsa that comes with every buritto is awesome.  Its a little on the spicy side but is one of the best salsas I've had.

Highly recommend calling in to place your order, its usually ready in 10 minutes and beats having to wait in the long line.
author: Kameron K.

description: Best burritos. Great meat. Though it tends to be crowded and they will literally ask you to leave right when you finish your burrito
author: Daniel Z.

description:
With this many reviews of this place, it's no wonder why Papalote is such a popular spot! Even when he's doing street vending, he's still the one customers rush to. Though I didn't have it at the actual restaurant, I did have an adobo burrito while he was at the MINK LOUNGE in Daly City for Inside/Out 3, and that was bomb!

At the restaurant, I was with my wife and kids. We ordered some tacos and the Triple Threat burrito. I didn't see the price at the time, but had to notice the homely decor of the place. It was set against a red-painted wall. There was a 3-D representation of what I think was a "chupacabra" in the back, and there were paintings by various artists (some of which were for sale).

Upon tasting the Triple Threat, I realized why it was such a hit among Bay Area folks: it had THREE types of meat in it, the sauteeing was perfect, there wasn't too much of anything (except the meat, which was a plus!) and it was HUGE! My wife and I took turns putting a dent on the tasty-ass burrito!

What prevents me from giving it a full-on FIVE STARS is that it was kinda out of the way, and good luck finding parking on a busy day! You can probably already tell we're not from the city part of the City, and when you're hungry, you gotta get it when you want it lol. Otherwise, Papalote's is ON POINT!
author: Geric O.

description:
Overrated, much? Their famous salsa was a good surprise, but it was nothing extraordinary. The chicken in the chicken mole was overcooked and dry; a waste of good mole sauce. The burrito was nothing special (again, the meat was overcooked and very dry), and neither were the rice and beans.

Oh well.
author: Elben S.

description:
Best burrito ever. TONS of delicious vegan options. Soyrizo? Tofu mole? grilled veggies? 

I nearly always get the soyrizo, sometimes with guacamole. Always AMAZING. And enormous for super-cheap. I work in the Financial District and have spent entire lunch breaks trekking to and from papalote to get an excellent burrito and get back in time to sit at my desk and eat while working -it's totally worth it. 

And the salsa. Did I mention the salsa? SO DELICIOUS. You can buy it by the jar at the store, or you can now buy it on-line for delivery. When I found this out, I sent the link to everyone I know, and they all reacted "This is the best day of my life". It's that good. 

While i've only ever gotten vegan burritos here, I've been told the non-vegan ones are also good. But can't really comment. 

Their other location is also good. So good that when our office was in the Presidio, we would regularly drive over and get burritos for the whole office (~25 people). 

Go here!!
author: Sue A.

description: Came here on a sunny Saturday afternoon to the amazing sight of no line. I had a bit of confusion with the menu setup (they really could make that easier to read with little changes), but the girls behind the counter were helpful and friendly and pushed me in the right direction. I ended up getting a naked rice & beans burrito bowl and my companion got herself super nachos, both to go. The food came out less than five minutes later, and realizing we had far more to carry than we envisioned (with those bags of amazing chips tossed in on top) the counter-girls handed us a bag without charging us the silly ten cents. My only complaint is that I wish their packaging held up a little stronger. By the time we reached the park less than ten minutes later the beans of my bowl had soaked through part of their container and made for a pretty sloppy dish. Overall, both orders had a nicely balanced flavor to them though and no one aspect of the dish overpowered another. I'll be back again, even if it means getting stuck in the supposed line every one else seems to encounter there.
author: Amy S.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF and lucky me it is down the street from where I live. Their salsa is incredible and I cannot say better things about the taco's they are yummy. 

The place is very clean and always busy with frequent repeat visitors. You will see everything from families, urban hipsters and guys right from the job site here. The prices are very reasonable and the staff is incredibly nice. This is one of those place for me if some one had not recommended it I might have never known it existed!
author: Ryan B.

description: The salsa IS a amazing. The burrito is good too and wet... but they got me wondering why they didn't put the salsa in the burrito also (the burrito isn't spicy in the slightest). This is like a more upscale version of all the other Mexican places deeper in the mission.
author: Grant M.

description:
Sad to witness the demise of the once-almighty Papalote. We used to eat here several times a month.

Then they got on TV and lost their way. The salsa is different and not as good. The always-brisk service is even more so. The prices went up. Orders have been wrong and not corrected with grace.

It's sad, really... I'm looking for a new taqueria to call home...
author: Shal J.

description:
Papalote is great! This is the kind of Mexican food that doesn't make you feel gross for hours after you eat it. The ingredients are fresh and flavorful, and not greasy like many/most Mexican restaurants. It's not the most traditional I've ever had, but who cares if it tastes good!

My recommendations: The Veggie burrito (trust me) doused in their ridiculously delicious salsa, and a big glass of horchata.
author: Amanda P.

description: I like Papalote a lot because of its convenience, but it is on the expensive side.  I get the "naked burrito", and have had chicken, carne asada, and prawn.  The carne asada was the best, with lots of steak and a generous portion of guacamole (but they charge quite a bit to add it).  Their signature salsa is fantastic, spicy, and unique.  I was disappointed that the prawn only had 4 pieces of shrimp, but it was delicious.  I'm somewhere between 3 and 4 stars on this one, but I'm giving them an extra for good service.  Everyone who works there is really nice!
author: Rachel A.

description:
My husband moved to SF to pave the way for us to live out our California dreams, and when I finally got to town he went out of his way to take me to Papalote. It was across town from our apartment, but he assured me the Zipcar trip was completely justified. This coming from a man who didn't touch Mexican food with a 10-ft pole before we met. Luckily my years of quesadilla indoctrinations worked, and now I love it here as much as he does.

The salsa rocks. I demolished a bowl without really noticing. Then we shared both a prawn and a steak quesadilla. Again, simple, and delicious.

The bathroom... it looks like it would be disgusting thanks to the dark paint ahd the insane asylum looking scrawls on the walls, but its actually quite clean.
author: Lesly S.

description:
We tried the triple threat.
Good but wow!  expensive burritto!  It had everything in there but I'm not sure its worth $20.  It was good for sharing though.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Simple spot to eat, nothing fancy, just a killer Carne Asada and Salsa!
by far my favorite Burrito in Mission!
author: David W.

description:
Ok, I'm gonna preface this review by saying I came here FAMISHED (since it was way past my dinnertime), and diverted since my first choice of taqueria was closed. Needless to say, I was already a little annoyed when I arrived...though it was nice to meet up with some of my friends (I digress).

I walk in and WHOA...ok...the counter is now on the right, vs right in front of you when you walk in. I didn't see a menu on the wall (they actually hung it up when I sat down to eat), so I ordered from a printed post card looking thing that they had a stack of.

I ordered a super prawn burrito and a horchata. Wait...what? No horchata? I had one last time I was...ok...nevermind. Give me an Orangina.

It was about 8:30 at this time, and the dining room was popping. There were open seats strewn about, but nothing really available to have three people (me and my two friends) sitting together. And what's this "Please Wait to be Seated" sign have to do with anything? That's weird. I don't see any staff seating anyone.

So, I saw some built-into-the-wall countertops and we decide to pull some chairs up to it. "I'm sorry, but you can't eat there." Says an employee of the place. So....hrm....maybe there should have been a sign. I'll admit I was thoroughly confused. We eventually waited for some other seats to open up (oddly, like 8 people left at the same time), and sit down. The table was still kinda dirty even though it was wiped down (food debris and what looked like some hair). I'm too hungry to care and brush stuff off with the number tag they give you with the order and I sit down.

A few minutes later, they bring the food out. I eat, chat with my friends, then bail.

Experience: 2 ("Ermm....hurhmm)
I would normally give a 3 to taquerias with their functional decor and spartan surroundings. But, the dirty tabletop, and counters that you can't eat on just didn't mesh well with my already annoyed mood. Yes, I'm sure my mood is influencing my rating here. But then again, even El Farlito with their plastic/cafeteria-style seating has clean table surfaces (every time I've been there). The bathroom, for the most part, is clean; save for all the patron-contributed art from pretty much floor to ceiling.

Value: 2 (A little steep for what you get...)
A prawn (all right, that's normally pricier) super burrito and an Orangina for $13-something? Really?

Food: 3 (It's fine)
The prawns tasted a bit toasty/overcooked. But, I give them bonus points for having black beans. The portion is pretty on par with your standard Mission District burritos (read: big enough that a fork and knife are standard issue...though it's hand-holdable, still).

Overall: 2.33 (Ugh...down to 2)
I don't want to give this place a 2...as I had an okay experience here last time. But, when you go into an establishment, you don't want to feel worse than you did when you walked in. Granted I was already annoyed, but this experience made me more annoyed tonight. Maybe just my luck of the cards and perfect storm alignment of mistakes by the establishment. Yes, in Yelp terms "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Ellis A.

description:
Definitely a departure from the usual Mission taqueria... colorful, clean dining area, bussed tables, skillfully wrapped silverware, etc.  But I came in expecting superior Mission Mexican and was underwhelmed.  

It's a slightly unfair comparison - I had the soy chorizo tacos instead of the usual veggie burrito (b/c their veggie burritos had weird shit like zucchini in them) - but the soy-rizo was too salty.  And while I like that they have their own style of salsa (bottled, trademarked, and sold), I prefer two distinct offerings: red and green, or hot and hotter.  If El Castillito bottled their green salsa I would chug it for breakfast.
author: seema s.

description: I'll probably miss their salsa forever. Expensive for the area but the place is far nicer to eat at than most burrito places.
author: Oscar H.

description:
Papalote in the heart of the Mission on 24th near the Bart station is a small place.  They do a pretty big takeout business because of their small dine in space and their dedicated register for those takeout customers.  Menu is pretty straightforward, either burrito, taco, quesadilla, all with a healthy choice of different meats, tortillas and sides.

I had the Carne asada that was voted and rated highly on 7 x 7 list of best Carne asada burritos in the city.  K had the shrimp burrito.  When we sat down, they brought us chips and salsa.  The salsa is this creamy roasted tomato salsa with a kick.  It was very different than I've tasted and was def a fan.  The burrito was a large size, mine was the "super" with guacamole, sour cream and cheese.  The Carne asada was actually very good, tender and tasty but the mush that they called rice ruined the burrito for me.  It just became this mix of poor textures. K was happy with her shrimp burrito and said it was flavorful, she didn't mind the rice as much as I did.

If I could take the Carne asada from papalote and put it into a el farolito burrito, I would be in heaven.  Since I can't, I'll have to settle for the dry meat at el farrolito because I definitely can't deal with the mushy rice at papalote
author: Brian C.

description: Sometimes I wish you weren't SO delicious, because you're constantly full and even the wait for take out can get long.  You're food always make me feel good (and healthy) and puts a smile on my face.  I'll also never forget to order an extra side of salsa because you know it's my favorite!  Mmmm...
author: Vicente G.

description:
Hmmm... how the hell did I live in the Mission area and never been to this place up until now? I guess this is my wake up call to go out and explore more...
