So, we had a craving for tacos and decided that we are going to try a new place. After some yelping, we decided to try this one. Why? Because I live like 4 blocks away. 

We got kind of confused at first because we saw that in the Yelp pictures, the logo is pretty colorful, but we saw no sign when we got to Poplar st. 
But no worries, we quickly found it because people were lining up! 

I decided I am going to try the Soyrizo taco(my experience with soy stuff before hasn't been good but, eh) 

As we sat down, they gave us a complimentary chips (1 bowl for each person!) and the BEST salsa my tongue has ever sampled! EVER! Omg, it has the right amount of spicyness and zestiness! Then my soyrizo taco came. I poked it a little bit and CHOMP! it did not taste like soy at all! it actually kinda taste like meat! I love it! It was gone in like less than 10min.... fatty me. lol. 

All in all I would totally come back! :)
author: Miss C.

description:
So me and my coworkers were on our way back to Bart from the SF Carnaval (congrats Carmen for winning the Queen title by the way) and we were starving. I wasn't trying to pay 10 dollars for street vendor food that was cooked in the scorching sun plus the fact that I didnt have cash anyways.

So we headed here. Wasn't as crowded as I expected it to be. So I ordered the carne asada burrito. It was pretty good. All meat and no fat. (which is what i love). The salsa was really tasty but they barely gave any chips. 

The DOWNSIDE - the customer service is AWFUL. The asian girl behind the register was really straightfaced. I ordered my food and sat down. When I got my burrito, I asked the person who served us if they can give me a fork and knife (which they should have gave in the first place) he says "what?" and i go "can i have a FORK!" and gives me a weird look. 5 mins later, still no utensils. So I go up to the cashier and ask for one, (same girl from earlier) and she just hands me the fork in a rude manner even tho I said "thank you."

ANOTHER THING - i also ordered horchata. I thought they would have given it to me along with the burrito or when i paid but NOPE, nothing. So i went to the register AGAIN and asked the same server guy who DIDNT give me the fork for my horchata and he gave me the same weird look and spoke to other girl in spanish. The other server girl goes "what do you want?" and i said "i ordered horchata and i never got it." So she leaves randomnly and the guy just hands it to me as if its the worst thing in the world. 

All in all, TERRIBLE customer service. I dont know if the servers understood english or not but c'mon, I'm a paying customer. Have some effin decency.

Good food, bad service. Might as well go to Chipotle. Or the other Papalote location.
author: Fran N.

description: The salsa alone is worth a trip (I'm wary of superlatives, but I will tentatively state that it is the best salsa I have ever had). I don't know what it is about it that makes it so unique, but it is, and it's delicious. The burritos are perfect; yes, they are more expensive than other options around the Mission, but I think they are worth it. I would probably subsist on them if I could; the rice and beans are always fresh and the meat is perfectly cooked. The dining space is cramped and gets crowded, so I prefer doing takeout. The line can be crazy and the waiting area is small, but I don't think I've ever waited more than 10 minutes or so.
author: Katie M.

description:
This used to be my most frequent stop in the Mission for burritos, before the recent renovation.  I don't know if someone else bought the place or what but the changes are not good.

The new counter help isn't very helpful.  They've always been brusque, which is fine but we had to stand there, in front of three employees who wouldn't make eye contact, for a full minute before anyone would say anything.  Then the young man was bothered that he had to help us.

They have significantly reduced their beverage offering and my beloved pear cider will not be returning.  

The interior decor is stripped of some of the old art and in over a week nothing has been found to replace it.  

My chicken burrito was filled with lots of rice and a hint of chicken.

I hope the online salsa sales will sustain them because the customer service and quality of their storefront isn't going to win them many fans.
author: Jak K.

description:
The salsa here is quite good - its more like a creamy spicy sauce that you eat with your chips, very unique and tasty.
 
Otherwise, I don't really feel like it's anything special. I've definitely had better mexican food. I had the carne asada and chili verde tacos. They come in litle corn tortillas with pico de gallo, lettuce, and meat. Both were OK... I just felt like something was missing. Adding the salsa made it better, but maybe I wanted cheese or something. My friends ordered their chicken and carne asada burritos. Again, nothing special. I tasted it and it didn't really have any outstanding flavor. 

I think the reason why its so liked is because it has interesting vegan options like soy chorizo and eggplant quesadillas. They also offer wheat tortillas.
author: Tim B.

description: Don't know what the hype is all about. Paid a ridiculous amount for a less than mediocre burrito. Surf and turf for 20 bucks?!? I could get a much better tasting burrito for half the price elsewhere. Two stars for the house salsa.
author: Daniel K.

description: In a city with such a rich tradition of great mexican and latin food I am shocked at how highly rated this place comes. The food is not bad but to say its has the best burrito in the city is pretty hilarious. Being overpriced and having a crappy seating system doesnt help either.
author: Ryan M.

description: I had a fish burrito. It was tasty but not enough fish. Had to take several bites to find the fish. The biggest set back for me was the price. $14 for a burrito with just a little fish is waaay too much for me. They also need to work on a better system to take orders and deliver better service.
author: sumaya g.

description: My boyfriend and I went here because it was rated the "best burrito in America". Umm what? Like most of the other reviews said, the burrito was BLAND and overpriced. My pollo asada super burrito came cold. The chile verde super burrito my boyfriend got did come hot, but was very unoriginal and bland as well. You would think the place acclaimed as the "best burrito in America" would have more to offer than overpriced, everyday burritos. Overall, we thought this place was hugely overrated and overpriced. DO NOT go here if you are expecting a world class burrito, plenty of other taquerias in the mission offer much more and at a better price point.
author: Ainslee S.

description:
Been here a million times and it gets better and better. But since everyone loves this place for the burritos, I wanted to comment on two things:

Pechuga al Achiote: SUPER healthy and great. I would recommend this if you're looking for a non-burrito option.

Mole Burrito - I would not recommend this one. Maybe its because I'm used to the freshness of the grilled pollo burrito but I was disappointed I chose this.
author: Preetesh B.

description: been a mission resident my whole life tried papalote for the first time yesterday. this is by far the worst place to get Mexican food, my burrito was 10$ it looked like someone drop it from a roof I'm disgusted by this place F U papalote keep serving that to the geeks
author: Luis A.

description:
My friend enjoyed her grilled  veggie burrito. For about 5 bucks, it was a good size and had nice presentation.

My grilled veggies were cut up in tiny pieces like baby food. That was odd. It tasted fresh and nicely grilled but a little bland. I added their salsa and that made it better.

Papolotte has excellent salsa. 

The downsides: LOUD music blasting from two speakers at their highest volume in a small dining room (this isn't a club!) It was hard to hear my friend talk and the loud music was hurting my ears.

The cashier was rude to me. I asked her to lower the volume of the music since I was the only person there waiting for my friend, she didn't do anything about it. The second time I asked her to turn down the music, she finally did something. When I tried to order food, she pretended not to see me and basicly had trouble hiding her dislike of me.  She ruined the ambience of the place.  What happened to good customer service?
author: Lorissa W.

description: Don't waste your time and $ on an over hyped and super over priced taqueria.  Go here if you like paying $10 for 2 shrimp tacos that had 2 shrimp in each taco...Rip off!!!!!  My $10 salad was tasty but not worth $10.  Somewhere down the line the owners got high on their briches, they are  getting away with over charging unknowing gringos and hipsters that do not know any better! A whole lotta moola is being wasted for food you can get down the street for less.  I am an S.F. native born and raised in the Mission district. (I am also 100% El Salvadorean)  Go to Pancho Villa on 16th or La Coroneta on Mission St instead!  The portions and salsas are bigger and better!!!!!
author: ada l.

description:
I recently went here for the first time and I fell in LOVE with the salsa. I am pretty I would drink a large glass of it if I could. 

This place is super vegan friendly, they have quite a few different options. I had the soyrizo burrito (husband had the carne asada and he was it was absolutely delicious). I love that you can have a choice of beans at this place (all of which are vegan). I had the black refried. 

I think I could say this is the BEST burrito I have EVER had. 

The reason for four stars instead of five: Our burritos came with chips and salsa, and while the salsa is heaven, I thought the chips were just "okay."  Also, this location is pretty tiny with limited seating and customers were packed in there like sardines. We arrived just in time to grab the last two seats. 

I'm still dreaming about that salsa.
author: Carrie T.

description: I don't get what all of the fuss is about.  It is a burrito place with decent if not kind of bland food.  It is really over priced too.
author: Andy Z.

description: Every time I drive by this restaurant there is a line out the door, so this past week we decided to give it a try.  It's a very casual environment, good for a weeknight dinner or lunch.  The food was very flavorful (we had the vegetarian options with tofu, but still great in taste).  I had mine without the guacamole, cheese, and sour cream, but those options definitely add some flavor enhancements (and maybe a few calories).  Portions were very generous and service was friendly.  The housemade salsa was also excellent (think they charge $0.50 if you want extra).
author: Kent W.

description:
My favorite thing about this place would have to be their salsa.... i keep going back because of it. 
You can even buy some in jars so you can take home! It's so good you will want to! 

Their known for their awesome burritos which I think are really good when they don't overcook the meet. And if it's your first time you should get a burrito! 

My favorite item to get is the nachos with carne asada and I get an extra salsa cup ...so good! one time I even shared with this guy sitting near me. He thought it looked so good and dam right it was!
author: Crystel A.

description:
Man...... Bobby Flay jacked up the hype and the prices! It was such a crazy wait to get a table, and paying 20 bucks for a burrito is just cruel and unusual punishment. 

It was a plus that I could drink my chilly Red Stripe in line, but once I finally got the triple threat burrito, I did not get the heartbubbles. It tasted like any other burrito in the MIssion just ten times the price. 

The adobo burrito however, was just a perfect cross cultural combo. The chicken adobo was soooo tendah! Hands down I had plate envy as my best friend got to enjoy that perfect tortilla pillow of awesome. 

I would definitely go back just for the adobo burrito, but the triple threat is not worth the ridiculous price. Unless the animals in this burrito were massaged by golden hands there is no reason why it should cost twenty dollars.
author: Christina Y.

description:
4 stars for the prawn burrito. 
3 stars for the prices.
2 stars for the wait. 

suggestion regarding the wait: get a digital sign which shows which orders are ready. clearly the owners are rich by now, so they can do a little research and figure that out. 

prices: $11.30 for a prawn burrito with avocado (to go) is expensive. It should be $9 total. (of course if you're on route to your 2.5 million noe valley house, not having to walk 2 blocks out of your way is worth $11.30, but for the rest of us please bring the prices down). None of the ingredients are organic, or pesticide free, thus the cost of that burrito is probably $4.50 thus at least a 5 dollar profit (after labor)! whoa. 

food: they do make a good burrito, the salsa is key. it's filling but not too filling. the chips are cheap fried chips, could be of better quality. 

I also recommend la corneta's super baby prawn burrito, and the seitan burrito at herbivoire, both of which are less expensive, and you will not wait as long.
author: Nip B.

description:
Oh Papalote, if you weren't so flawed I'd go with a higher score. I finally got to try the much-hyped chicken adobo burrito, but the overall experience I had could have been waaaaay better.

Let's get the bad out of the way. What the hell was up with the wait? I think I easily spent over half an hour waiting for just one burrito. Then again, others that ordered ahead of us experienced just as long of a wait. I'm guessing they do put a genuine effort into their burritos, but takes a little too much time. With that said, called way ahead, like you would do when ordering a sandwich at Ike's Place. 

Another thing is the price. It's more expensive than La Cumbre or el Farolito, which is a couple blocks away. The burrito itself was 7.50, then when I got rung up it jumps to a little over 9 bucks? Fine whatever, I just want to try the damn burrito at this point.This place could also benefit from being open later, but I'm guessing all the drunken crowds will flock thus causing a wait until the sun comes back up. 

Now the burrito itself is pretty good. You can definitely taste the adobo flavor, but its not as strong as I had hoped it would be. I guess thats the beauty of the burrito by not overwhelming the consumer with the flavor. The burrito wasn't dry or anything either, I just expected a little more taste. 

I'll come back to give it another try. I need to go here anyway because my parents want to try it themselves. Not bad, but I think I'll be going back to my regular options.
author: Loren John B.

description: I understand that a good burrito should cost more but not double the price of a regular burrito. it is good don't get me wrong you'll probably enjoy it especially if you use that orange salsa that they give you. This reminds me of a High Class Chipotle Burrito and there is always a crowd here. It is in my opinion just a little bit overhyped. They could also spare a few more chips.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Hands down my favorite burrito joint in the city, and I have eaten my fair share of bean, rice, and meat in a tortilla.

Employing the golden ratio of guacamole to sour cream, Papalote combines fresh ingredients to create a superior taste experience. Unlike other taquerias whose burritos flavors are mushy and muddled, Papalote's burritos are flavorful and delicious - each ingredient stands out on it's own. 

A few tips:

1) My fav is the prawn burrito. Get it super with cheese, guac, and sour cream. 

2) The salsa is totes amazeballs. You can even buy a jar of it to take home. 

3) Call in your order 10 minutes in advance to have your order ready when you get there!

4) Even though it sounds enticing and delicious, forget the Triple Threat burrito on the menu.  It's $20 and has carne asade, prawns, and chicken, but is no larger than a normal burrito and not worth the premium price.  I suppose I'd pay a few bucks extra for the combination of meats, but it doesn't make sense to charge a ridiculous amount of money for a regular-sized burrito.  Maybe I ordered it on an off day, but it was the one and only time I've been disappointed with Papalote.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Being an out-of-towner, a local recommended we check out the Mission district of San Francisco. Taking the BART was a convenient way to get there. We happen to be in town during Cinco de Mayo so it was quite packed.

After you order your food, you're given a number and they eventually find a table for you and your food comes out soon after.

Seating is quite cramped but it's nothing too crazy.Being from LA, I didn't find this place spectacularly different or extremely to-die-for but the chicken molé quesadilla was pretty good but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Alyssa A.

description:
Ok - so I gave Papalote one more chance.  This time, I tried the Triple threat burrito, while my friend ordered the machaca.

I had recalled on Food Network that the brothers who own Papalote entered their Triple Threat burrito into some competition and it won, so I figured - if I am going to give them one more shot, I might as well give them their best chance.

For $20, the burrito was ok.  It kind of laid there and acted bored.  For $20 for a burrito, I want a little more action - I just need a little more lovin' for that price ... for a burrito.

I don't think they sell very many of them, because the shrimp actually had no flavor.  Yes - it was large - but size isn't everything in this case.
Interestingly, my friend's machaca wasn't actually machaca at all, but chopped up carne asada.

His theory (he's Mexican) is that Papalote is for people who don't know what Mexican food is.  Frankly, I see the line outside the restaurant every day, and I am still perplexed why these folks don't go down one street to Taqueria or a place where you can get much better Mexican food a lot cheaper.
author: Joe S.

description: My first real Mission burrito. I went with the marinated tofu (with black beans) on the recommendation of the Burrito Eater, I got it super (with sour cream, cheese and guacamole). I was delicious, but honestly not much different than Chipotle, except more expensive. It comes with (warm) chips and salsa, but I didn't eat very many since I knew the burrito was going to be big, so it was kind of a waste. I would have rather paid extra for chips if I wanted them. I would be happy to eat here again, but there are so many other places I have to try, I wouldn't make a special trip to go here.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down because of how long it takes to get a burrito to go on a Tuesday night.  Apparently, you can call ahead and pick it up right away, which is what I should have done.  It's pretty tiny, you have to wait even longer for a table.

My theory about Papalote's excellent ratings:  Roughly half of San Francisco is vegetarian, if not vegan.  The vast majority of burrito places, even here, seem to think that a vegetarian burrito means "beans and cheese only" (recipe for an evening of stink if I ever heard one).  Therefore, Papalote gets amazing ratings from half of the city purely for using vegetables.  Like, real, fresh vegetables, which is nice, but not as nice as the reviews make it out to be.

That said, their mole burrito is delicious, and it was almost worth the wait.  Since I wanted both meat and veggies in it, they charged me close to $13.  It was enough for two meals, but still...$13 for a burrito of any sort seems a bit excessive, no matter how delicious.
author: Sydney H.

description: I was shocked that my side of chicken cost $7 when it arrived it was about 2 thirds of a cup of cold meat. What a rip off
author: Brian S.

description:
I don't get the high reviews.  Are they getting YOUR orders right?  

Love the idea of fresh avocado on your burrito?  Me too, and Papalote will certainly charge me for it, which is a good sign that they heard me, but so rarely actually put it in my burrito.  Are you a pescaterian who likes the idea of vegan refried beans?  I unwrapped the foil, on which someone had written "shrimp," and took a nice big bite of CHICKEN!  I HATE chicken.  (I have a video of this burrito, and wonder if I can upload it here.)  I told the manager, Cecilia, about it, and she was NOT gracious about it at all.  She had the cashier take my order again, which came out on a white instead of wheat tortilla.  

These people obviously don't need my business, or yours, not that I am telling you what to do.  But have you heard of Taqueria San Jose?  Those people are nice, their food is fabulous, and while they don't have wheat tortillas, at least they won't promise you one.  

Had their $8.50 nachos.  They were SO stingy with the beans.  It was a plate of burnt chips with no salsa even though we requested hot.  

I'm done here.
author: Amy D.

description:
This is more of a 3 1/2 star place. As a Los Angeles native, I have been on a constant search for a burrito reminiscent of home. Their tofu burrito is comparable to Sharkey's in So Cal. It's delicious, but like Sharkey's, it's totally gringo Mexican food. Though, what do you expect when you order tofu in a burrito? Still one of the best burritos in SF. Though that isn't saying much. 

Oh yeah, their orange-ish salsa is the bomb!
author: Amber G.

description:
The best burrito in SF. As a native San Franciscan I pride myself in burrito knowledge. The camarones is my favorite and whenever I leave home for more than 2 months, I always make sure to have a tasty burrito waiting for me!

Don't forget the hot sauce - my friend from San Diego takes back bottles of it!
author: Francesca F.

description:
I went here after it was ranked the #2 burrito joint in SF by the 7x7 magazine.  (El Farolito was first.)  The burrito was gigantic, and tasty, and a good half of it is still around for dinner.

Overall, this isn't really a place you go to for ambience--even though it has it, and beer--but moreso for awesome food:
Food: 5
Service: 4
Price: 4

Clearly, food carries the day.  I ordered a chile verde (pork) burrito, with guacamole and sour cream, on a spinach tortilla.  It was delicious, with the ingredients well mixed in the burrito (a big selling point).  I added a little of the well-spiced salsa provided with my chips to the burrito and it really hit the spot.  The pork was cooked that day, and fairly tender.  The guacamole wasn't spectacular in its own right, but mixed well with the flavors of the burrito.  And there was some form of pickled vegetable in the burrito that was just the right touch.  The burrito was gargantuan, though, so I brought most of it home.

The only detractors are as follows.  There isn't enough salsa to go around, and according to another review, you have to pay for extra.  Also, it may be that I was unreasonably hungry, but I felt the 10+ minutes I waited for my burrito was a bit more than needed, even for fresh ingredients.  Lastly, at $9.30 for a super burrito, there are cheaper places with quality that's just as good.

Nonetheless, it's scrumptious, plain and simple.  Worth going, worth the price.  Word to the wise: from the look of the place, you'll have to wait for a while to find a table during peak times.
author: Naveen A.

description: The soyrizo is so good. Making your taco order "super" will totally fill you up if you don't want a burrito. But if you do, my go-to burrito is a super carne asada burrito. The salsa is AMAZING. Calling ahead and picking up is also great if you don't want to wait in line.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Seating is very limited but once you get a seat, they bring you a bowl of chips and salsa. The salsa is addictive. So good. So very good.

And I must say, sometimes I have cravings for nachos and this place really hits the spot. I highly recommend the nachos - it's flavorful, the chips have a great texture, and did I mention the salsa? I did? OK, yeah, it's great!
author: Chung N.

description: Definitely lived up to the hype! Wasn't expecting to be blown away, I'm pretty jaded, but this restored my faith in burrito.
author: John J.

description:
We saw this place, as many others have, on Throwdown With Bobby Flay. Seriously, how did he lose to the WAY OVERPRICED triple threat burrito? It's $20 fucking dollars, and I'm still pissed that I threw my money away there.  Over $40 for 3 people to eat at a glorified taqueria? UNFUCKINGBELIEVABLE. Fuck YOU papalote.  

Back to the triple threat burrito: it's big, but not even CLOSE to worth $20. It was dry, and totally unremarkable. And they want MORE money to make it palatable? (extra $1 for cheese/guacamole/sour cream). Best part about the food here is their house salsa.

The ONLY way I would ever come back here is if I somehow got addicted to burritos, went on a bender, and woke up in the dumpster in the alley next to Papalote with a burrito withdrawal. ONLY fucking way.
author: Damon K.

description:
Disclaimer:  This review is for the Adobo burrito ONLY!  

So some of my coworkers had been hyping up this Adobo burrito for awhile, and one day I decided to get one for myself because I love the 'idea' of it.

Well, let's just say it left many things to be desired, namely the adobo flavor.  It really tasted like bland adobo.  Plus it really would have been better with Filipino-style garlic rice.  I also think pork, like shredded carnitas-type meat would have worked better.  

I'm not writing Papalote off completely, I just had such high hopes for the adobo burrito.  I will be back to try their 'regular' food and their chips and salsa.
author: Eileen H.

description:
excited to check this place out after finding out it beat out bobby flaw on throwdown, i made the journey to experience 'the best burrito' in san francisco last sunday. BAD IDEA!

what a waste of time and hype. First off, the 'triple threat' cost $20, seriously, 20 bucks for a damn burrito, not in this life time. 

So, instead i was torn between the mole burrito or the chile verde. Per the cashiers recommendation, i chose the chili verde. While waiting i was brought some chips and salsa. 

Heard the salsa was great, what a disappointment. It is the better type, i think habanero; however, it just wasnt anything special. If you want a real good orange salsa, try Iguana in SJ, definitely the best. I mean my friends mom could make a better one in her sleep, and she probably has.

Back to the point. well i was given the salsa with some chips, which were store bought (not the great house made ones at REAL mexican restaurants). Once my burrito arrived I asked for some more salsa, since I used the other on the chips they gave me. The worker told me I only get 1 salsa per order and I would have to pay if I wanted any more!! ARE YOU SERIOUS?!? Youre telling me the salsa that came with my chips was the only salsa I got to use for both my super burrito and my dipping my chips? WAT A JOKE! 

any other legitimate mexican restaurant usually hands salsa out like its halloween or even keeps them in self serve so you can basically dip your burrito in before you eat, lol. Not this place, their are like the salsa nazis for some bland lame duck salsa. 

Havent even gotten to the burrito. So, i could barely even taste the green chili and the pork was rather dry and cut too large. I mean i have had chili verde cut that large before but usually its been simmered in sauce so long that it just melts in your mouth, not this one. Felt like I was eating over cooked chicken. 

Only good marking this place gets is they allow the option of getting spinach tortillas and whole black beans. Although, DEFINITELY NOT worth $9 PLUS, the extra cost of salsa!!

BOOOO!
author: Anthony D.

description:
When I was told that Papalote was the best place in the area for Vegetarian friendly food, I set my hopes high.  I admit, and I know I've said this before, my standards for Mexican food are slightly lowered when I am in San Francisco.  Being from San Diego, we have some of the finest Mexican food you can find, besides of course, Mexico.

The line, out the door, but not too long of a wait.  The space is small so of course getting a table can be a hassle at times.  The guy at the counter was extremely helpful, making jokes as I ordered and paid for numerous beers, for just myself.  

The food, just like three stars A-OK. The burrito I got didn't leave a lasting impression which turned me off even more considering that I paid almost $30 for just myself.  To be honest, I was expecting a lot more.

None the less, I wouldn't mind coming back here, if I was in the area even if to grab a few drinks.  I like the atmosphere and the staff is great.
author: Madison B.

description: The carne asada burrito definitely lives up to the hype. We're talking good sized chunks of steak (NOT ground beef), good ratio of rice/beans/meat/, and a smoky, flavorful salsa to pour on top. I'm not a fan of the jicama salad that comes on the side, mostly cause I'm not a fan of jicama, but the burrito does not disappoint!
author: Caroline W.

description:
Give me a break!

On a perfectly nice Sunday - we were chilling out at Revolution Cafe w/ some beers indulging in nice conversation, a great live band, and "people-watching" the most interesting, odd folks who thought it normal to shush people at a cafe.  The three of us all being foodies - talk of food was inevitable as dinner time approached us.

JB mentioned a burrito place that had recently been featured on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay".  Now, I like Bobby as a person more than a chef, and I do enjoy this show from time to time but I had missed this episode.  But my interest was piqued in learning that Bobby had lost to the "triple threat burrito" at Papalote, so we started walking to check the place out for dinner.

Well, as we expected, there was a massive line of people wanting to try the place that had beaten the Iron Chef.  As it turned out, there were more people waiting for their placed order than wanting to order, so we were able to squeeze right through to the counter.

All three of us wanted the Triple Threat.  
All three of us gawked at the price: $20.

TWENTY DOLLARS?
The first natural question was: how big is it?
Answer:  same size as the other burritos... that average out at about $7.50 in cost.

*(looking around the room to make sure I'm on earth)*

ON WHAT PLANET DOES THAT MAKE SENSE?????????

Same size - 1/3 portion of beef, chicken and shrimp....
Almost 3X in cost.

FOR WHAT?

Forget that!  Do I have "IDIOT" written on my forehead?

We scored seating in the restaurant within 10 minutes, and that was good since our wait for the regular burritos would be over 30 minutes.

Once seated, we just paid $30 for a plate of fish tacos and a beef/chicken burrito, with a beer and a diet coke.  Examining the receipt, it became clear that we had been charged for fish tacos, a beef burrito AND a chicken burrito.

(Annoying.)

The chips were decent, and their "special secret sauce" (salsa) was pretty good in concept but overly salted, and not quite what *I* want from "salsa".  Nonetheless, it was tasty.

The burritos arrive.
Regular size.
I was SO not a fan of the Monterey Jack cheese - in cold state, not melted - that they sprinkle on everything.  Yuck.  Took a bite of the chicken/beef burrito - and the only noteworthy thing was the chicken was well marinaded/seasoned.  The rest?  Unimpressive.  Overall, for the burrito, I'd have given it three stars.

I tried the fish taco - and the fish was fresh and not deep-fried, the lettuce was crisp - but the cheese, as much as I tried to take it all off, ruined it for me.  If I had asked for no cheese - I would have given it three stars too.

There's a MUCH better burrito to be had at El Metate for a fraction of the cost and even better ambiance with better drinks and service, too.  ($5 for a burrito there - try it!)

The experience of eating at Papalote, due to the hype, was worth it.  The company made the whole night fun.  Perhaps, if we had been insane enough to splurge $20 to eat a burrito - my assessment would be higher.  But for a $20 burrito, I expect it to give me wings, and based on other reviews - nobody sprouted wings and took off.  It's unfortunate for the owners as they'd be making a WHOLE lot more money off the recent coverage if they charged $10 for the Triple Threat instead of attempting to price gouge their customers for $20.  Whatever number of Triple Threats they are selling right now for $20, they could sell 10X that amount had they charged $10.  Do the math.

Coincidentally - upon arriving home later in the evening, the very episode of "Throwdown w/ Bobby Flay" came on TV and I watched it with the remnants of Papalote's burrito and fish taco in my stomach.

Bobby was as cute as ever, and based on ingredients alone, I'd have preferred his "green burrito".  That said, the two brothers were funny and seemed like nice guys.

They just happen to be out of their freakin' minds.

$20 for a BURRITO?
That's just insulting.
author: Grace K.

description:
I walked more than two miles in the pouring rain to enjoy the triple threat burrito here. I was sadly disappointed. I've had the super carne asada burrito here before and it was pretty good. The triple threat was a complete dud. It was relatively small considering the amount of meat it contained. A normal El Faralito burrito is bigger. Also the triple threat is WAY overpriced, $19.95 and that is without the super upgrade. RIP OFF. 

Finally the biggest rip is the .55 you have to pay for extra salsa. 

El Faralito is better if you eat meat. If you want a soyrizo tofu bastardized burrito papalote is still your spot.
author: Mike I.

description:
This place just makes me angry. 

It has also made me lose respect for Bobby Flay as a chef, how on earth could he lose to the triple threat burrito. It is dry and sub-par (I might even say bad). And don't even get me started on being duped into paying $20 for a burrito. 

The triple threat is exactly that ( a threat to your wallet, your dignity, and your tastebuds). Papalote needs to get off its high horse. 

I only gave this place 2 stars because I thought the salsa was excellent. Otherwise, 1 star for sure.
author: Alixandria F.

description:
wow overrated much?
Don't get me wrong, it was an OK burrito
and if this place was outside of San Francisco, I would say they would be the best burrito joint in whatever city they were in

but i mean, there is el farolito down the street.  you get a burrito twice the size with way more flavor for half the f'n price.

I would not go back here, even though i live down the street, i was just shocked at the $10 price for a super burrito.  And it was just meh

Not bad by any means, but there is better up the street
author: Jason W.

description:
Of COURSE my friends and I went here after hearing about that throwndown bobby flay thing triple threat burrito thing. Sooo... we waddled down to the mission and found parking right away which, according to my friend, was probably the most positive thing about this whole experience. 
I tried the mole chicken burrito which was delicious. My two other friends had the $20 burrito (I had a small taste). Nothing spectacular, just lots of different types of meat but the exact same size as mine which I didn't expect--- thought it was going to be huge. 
Yes, their salsa is unique and yummy, but nothing to go ga-ga over. And it was nice that the owner was out to mingle, but I'm sure he's just ride out the 15-minute fame wave as long as possible. 
I couldn't have phrased it better than yelp does with my two-star rating: "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Christine Y.

description:
I can't believe i fell for the hype......$20 for a freakin burrito!!!! Are u kidding me!?!??!?!?! Totally not worth it.  My sister and I ordered it thinking for $20, we'd get a big-ass burrito but it was just a regular size burrito.  Everything was way too salty even their famous orange sauce (which was good but nothing spectacular).  There was no distinct flavor for them to justify a $20 burrito.  Even if I paid $5 for this burrito it would just a another ordinary burrito. The 1 star is for their yummy chips.

Listen here people. Take your money and walk 2 blocks down to El Farolito.....It's waaaaaay better.
author: Michelle T.

description:
i couldnt bring myself to give more than 2 stars. HOW DID THIS PLACE EVER BEAT BOBBY FLAY? like many others, i was interested in trying this place out when i found out that this place beat bobby flay's throwdown. 

my boyfriend and i shared the triple threat burrito which has steak, chicken, and shrimp for $19.95 and boy do i feel cheated! i've had much better burritos elsewhere for less than half of that. the shrimp was overcooked so it was a little tough and rubbery but i did like that it tasted grilled. i didnt have any chicken in my half of the burrito. and the steak had me feeling a bit greasy. i appreciate good carne asada in a burrito but the beef was a bit chewy and too greasy for my taste. (boyfriend agrees with all this by the way)

however, i do like that the chips and salsa came free with the burrito. and i appreciate the cashier for telling me they come with the burrito so i didnt have to pay for an extra one. the salsa was delicious too. if it wasnt for the chips and salsa, i dont think i would even give 2 stars.
author: L M.

description:
Came here after my husband saw Throw Down With Bobby Flay.  I'm a Bobby Flay fan and we were kind of having a fun "food network" adventure during our weekend in SF.

How did my Bobby Flay lose, I'll never know...

My husband got the triple threat burrito.  Most of the carne asada had to be spit out due to the gristle and the 3 prawns inside were over cooked and chewy.  The chicken, however, had a great flavor and left us wishing we'd just gotten the chicken burrito.  However, we were essentially there to try this particular burrito.

I ordered the fish tacos and they were alright.  Nothing special.  Oh well.

The chips were good and the salsa was fantastic.  The salsa was the only impressive thing about the place.  

If you decide to try Papalote, don't waste your time with the triple threat.  It's over-priced and over-rated.
author: Stacey B.

description:
I am upgrading my review to a 4 1/2 for Papalote!

I've been back to Papalote a number of times since my first review.  And when I say a number of times, I mean like once a week.  I seriously crave the stuff.  

My favorites are the soy chorizo burrito (don't forget to make it a super burrito!) and the soy chorizo tacos.  I LOVE soy chorizo and Papalote incorporates it so well into its food.  The soy chorizo burrito and the soy chorizo tacos are positively bursting with flavor and I savor every last bite every time I go.  

The boy toy and I  tried the fish tacos once and I recommend NOT getting them.  They were not good.  Totally bland.

Other friends I have been with have tried the tofu in their tacos and burritos and really like it.  I've had a bite and it tastes like paneer.  Pretty damn good, but I'm not willing to cheat on soy chorizo for a cheap fling with the tofu.  I would love to try some of the other vegetarian options as well - Papalote has a ton!

Definitely come to Papalote if you want some delicious Mex food in the Mission.
author: Julie S.

description:
Whats there to say.. First.  I love there salsa.  I don't know what it is, but the stuff is amazing.  I bought a jar last time I was there and so should you.

Second.  I can't speak for anything else on the menu since all I ever get is the chilaquiles with fried eggs.  If everything else is like that, than I'm sure its f'ing FANTASTIC!!  It was so good, I can't even remember what my most loving and beautiful wife had.  I believe it was something lo-carb.  Everyone there has always been very friendly every time I've been there.

Third, it was always a little chaotic when I would go there, but in the past 4 months they remodeled a bit and it's really really nice inside.  I love this place.  Done.
author: Joe K.

description:
I had the chili verde super burrito. The pork was really good.  I usually get carnitas but they didn't have it on their menu, but this was definitely better than any chili verde I've had...moist and juicy without being saucy.  And OMG the salsa with chips!!  I usually don't eat chips and salsa but this salsa was to die for! And they sure do give you a lot of guacamole. 

All in all I say it's good food, a little bit pricey for Mexican, and barely any seating so take out is probably best.
author: Nikkie P.

description: Really good food! Great selection to eat! A bit on the expensive side for quick Mexican food. But well worth it.  Get your burrito super and make sure you get the guacamole too!
author: Alex Z.

description:
This review will be short.

Two words in fact-- one of them doesn't even count.

The salsa. 

That's all.  Enjoy :)
author: Kristin P.

description:
I have a theory that when the food network visits a restaurant, they inevitably ruin the experience for everyone else because not only are your expectations higher, the restaurant gets a bloated ego and goes downhill.  

The food was overpriced.  I got a less than desirable plate of nachos with nothing but some cheese melted on top, a scattering of tomatoes, a smear of beans and overcooked shabby looking chicken pieces on top.  Oh, the triple-threat burrito, the one that was featured on the show, $20.  I asked how big it was because I was considering getting it.  It's the same size as a regular burrito.  Can anyone tell me if ANY regular sized burrito is worth that much money?  Me thinks not!

The wait staff left a sour taste in my mouth.  Apparently they've become so crowded a hostess needs to seat you.  Fast food or restaurant, they can't decide.  Someone brings out chips and salsa and the food to your table.  The salsa wasn't very fresh tasting.  The worst part, the food took about a half hour to come out.  I get faster service at legitimate sit down restaurants.  What's going on back there in the kitchen?

For an actual burrito experience, go to Farolito, or even Pancho Villa for crying out loud.  You'll spend half as much as come out with a feeling of satisfaction!
author: Blu n.

description:
THREE reasons why I walked into Papalote:
(1) The SF 7x7 listed their "chips and salsa" as a place to try before you die. Hmmmmm!!???!
(2) According to the Food Network, their "Triple Threat" burrito beat out Bobby Flay's burrito.  Bobby Flay??? Quite impressive!!!  
(3) They serve "Chicken Adobo" burritos. Huh, really???!!!!

How do they measure up???
(1) Chips and salsa- BIG THUMBS UP!!!  I really liked it. I couldn't stop munchin' on them.  The salsa was fresh & chunky, and the orange color reminded me of La Vic's delicious salsa. (Try La Vic's orange sauce; buy the bottle even!)
(2) The "Triple Threat" burrito was jam packed w/ flavorful shrimp, chicken, and steak. It was really good, but I have to question it costing $20!!??  For that price, it should have been GYYY-normous, but wasn't.  
(3) I give it up to them for having a mix-breed type of BURRITO: half Filipino/half Mexican. Was it good? Sure it was, but I wonder why it appeared "off-menu". (I'm glad my girlfriend told me about it.)

TIP for those doing the 7x7 list: Anthony's cookies & Mitchell's Ice Cream are a hop, skip, jump away. =)
author: Joy A.

description: The food is incredible in  this place is on  my favorite list I love Achiote chicken plate Simply superb.!!!!!!
author: Claudia Q.

description: Papalote used to be one of my favorite white-ican restaurants (yup, Mexican food for white people). I still think it's really good, but the last time I visited I noticed the veggies in my veggie tacos were drenched in butter, and the salsa I usually love just felt thick and heavy. And I just have to say... it was kind of too much.  Obviously I'll give it another try; but for now I'm going to have to take off a star. :(
author: Amber K.

description:
It's obvious that the 'comedian' brother came up with the price for the Triple Threat because that was funny as hell!  But hey, I'll go along with the absurd price and fall into the tourist trap.  Turns out it's the customers who are the joke since it's not even that good...

Like many others, I came to this place after watching Throwdown a couple days ago.  For those who want to come here for the Triple Threat burrito, the 1st thing you will notice is the $19.95 price which might be worth it if it used Kobe beef though I just wanted to try it once.  I think it might be less to just buy a prawn burrito, add chicken & carne asada, and make it a super though I'm not sure.

I really do think this Triple Threat burrito is overrated, especially because of its price.  I found myself eating each of the meat separately because together it is over-seasoned with each of the marinade and sauce getting lost within each other.  Individually, the meat tastes great: perfectly grilled and marinated so well.  But together, there is just too much going on.  The secret sauce is good (maybe a rip off of La Vic's orange sauce) though, with some heat and tangy.  So it may be that it's better to just get a burrito with just 1 type of meat and hope it's not bland.  The food here is fresh though.

There are other places in the Mission where you can get just as good of a tasting, fresh burrito that's more authentic for half the price.. so I won't be coming back here.

small dining area, so might not get a seat
service is good, but phone your order in so you don't have to wait a while
parking isn't too hard to find, metered
author: John D.

description: I LOVE papalote burritos! Have to admit, for the many visits I've had to Papalote's I can't seem to get past the 2 most delicious burritos I have had in my lifetime. The 'mexapino' and steak and shrimp! Both are equally amazing to the point that my roommate and I like to get both and split them because deciding on one is too difficult. Aside from that, I'm stuck on their sauce which you can purchase by the jar if you love it as much as I do. Really if you've never been here you need to... 5 stars is not an exaggeration.
author: Michelle D.

description: The food is undoubtedly great here! Tried the Triple Threat burrito and, on a another occasion, the chicken mole. Would come back for take out. Seats are hard to get to dine in and so is parking.
author: November C.

description:
Cheesy cheesy goodness...

The cheesy fish quesadilla revisits me in my dreams sometimes and I'm a fan of the sauce. Although I don't see what all the fuss is about it is still really good. 

The burritos were pleasing, not too fancy. 
The chicken mole was whack... avoid it. 

If you're going to Papalote, send me a fish quesadilla please.
author: Ricky H.

description:
There are a lot of burrito places in the Mission but I generally wish I would've saved my money and just made a burrito at home rather than spending my money on such an underwhelming meal.  Papalote was the first place so far that hasn't left me feeling like that and I intend to go back frequently.  Reasons it was different than the others: 
1. HUGE menu that encompasses vegans, vegetarians (GREAT tofu!), and people who love lots of meat.
2. Awesome mole- not spicy, so it might not satisfy some people, but it is so creamy and rich I don't see how anyone could complain. 
3. Free chips and salsa when you sit down but the salsa isn't just your ordinary tomatoes and spices- instead it's more creamy and bursting with flavors (though pretty spicy). 
4. Huge burritos overflowing with ingredients. !!! (I just got really hungry writing this and want to go now)

I'd probably go for 5 stars except that I wish there was more seating (though we only waited for less than 10 minutes for a seat, I felt like we were rushed towards the end when they clearly needed our table) and to add sour cream to a burrito is $2.25 (probably the only expensive thing on the menu but i really love my sour cream).
author: Luthien N.

description: This review is long overdue. Not sure what all the hype is about over this place. Went in ordered a steak burrito and left. It was mediocre.The restaurant is actually quite small, and attempting to seat a large group would be difficult. Nor were the employees very friendly.
author: J K.

description:
I still don't know understand the hype of this place. I had tried this place a while ago for their chicken mole tacos and found it alright. Then I saw Papalote beat Bobby Flay with their Triple Threat Burrito. Since I couldn't find the bakery I was looking for I decided to give it another shot.

I didn't realize that the Triple Threat Burrito is $20! Instead I got the carne asada burrito to-go. The burrito is good. Big chunks of meat and a good balance of ingredients. They also pack your bag with chips and some killer good orange hot sauce. For some reason the sauce tastes better this time around. I think the sauce is better suited for hefty savory burritos.

Considering that Papalote is as busy as a liquor store on New Year's Eve, I would rather go somewhere less congested, cheaper, and just as good. The wait isn't worth the food. If it's not that crazy packed, give it a shot.
author: Michael H.

description:
overrated! I was not impressed... 

I thought their chicken was dry, prices high, and tortilla not fresh. I was also shocked that there were no mexican customers. ( i think a good taquería should have mexican customers... have you ever seen a good asian restaurant without asian customers? didnt think so..) 

i'll be going to the taquería's on mission street next time...
author: Dave N.

description:
The last three burritos I ordered here were absolutely awful.  Today, I ordered a super prawn burrito and after the first 4 large bites, I returned to the store thinking I had recieved someone else's order.  Why?  Because all I got in each bite were BEANS.  Where were the prawns, the sour cream, the guacamole and cheese that comes with the "super?".
Turns out there were a few over cooked dried prawns in there.  But I never found the sour cream.  And I found a bit of mushy guacamole and cheese clumped at the bottom.  But mostly beans, and blandness.  Don't burritos usually have a tasty salsa as well?

Yuch.  I was truly disappointed, for the third time in a row.  Not sure what people like, maybe it's because it's kinda "granola" and that's what a certain mission crowd likes...
author: Avi S.

description:
I came to Papalote specifically because I'd never had mole negro before, and a friend recommended the chicken mole at this place. After hearing how crowded and crazy it is, we almost didn't go -- but I'm glad we tried it. Despite the crowds, we were able to sit down at a table and (semi) enjoy our meal, although we were crammed in close with other diners and the servers kept banging into my chair. 

Anyway, where was I? Oh yes. The food. 

The salsa, as others have said, is unique and tasty. It's on the spicy side, blended, and a little bit creamy. I almost ate all of it with chips while waiting for my meal, but saved some. That turned out to be a good thing. 

My portion was huge. It came with more chicken that I could eat at one sitting, partly because it was pieces of white meat that had gotten very dried out during the cooking process. The mole sauce was amazing -- rich, complexly flavored, chocolaty and just slightly sweet. However, it wasn't enough to moisten the chicken, and the dry meat combined with the uber-rich sauce made the dish hard to finish (and I didn't). 

The house-made pinto beans were very bland -- and adding the leftover salsa helped, but only a little bit. Their tortillas are store-bought; I was a little disappointed by that. And the jicama salad was teeny-tiny. I could have used a lot more greens on my plate to offset the rich/dryness of the mole. 

My date had the pork salsa verde; he said it was "just OK" and had similar blandness issues with his black beans. 

The service was friendly and fast. 

So, a few stars for tasty sauces, but several stars taken away for crowds, dry meat, and bland beans. We probably won't be back.
author: Beth W.

description: Triple Threat Burrito is the bomb. Some times you finish sometimes you don't . But if you want something a bit smaller you can go with any of the plates chili verde , Carne and even chicken. Can't go wrong here
author: John J.

description:
Ever eat a $20 burrito? That's what the the Triple Threat burrito will cost you. Shrimp, chicken and carne asada in a single burrito that's no bigger than a regular burrito. I normally get the Chile Verde burrito which is excellent ($7.50) until I saw an episode of Throwdown with Bobby Flay. Now I've been eating here for awhile and was never aware of the Triple Threat until the episode with Flay. Told myself that I was gonna try it next time around instead of my usual Chile Verde. Looked at the online menu and there was no Triple Threat. Had the little lady call in an order for us. One TT and one Chile Verde. 25 mins later, I show up to pick up my order and the nice young lady at the counter tells me the total is $32. I looked up at the menu board and there's a small plastic sign taped to it that reads Triple Threat Burrito $19.99. WTF? 

It was a Wednesday night and the place was unusually packed...alot more than usual. All of the staff members were wearing Throwndown shirts and they looked really overwhelmed by the crowds of people coming in and the telephone ringing off the hook. Even after calling the order in 25 minutes ago, I still had to wait another 15 minutes to get my food. 

The TT was good and the different meats in it had a nice balance that worked together. Maybe $10-$12 would have been a reasonable price. But $20...gonna stay with the Chile Verde. 

My beloved Papalote is now a rerun on the Food Network. Great for the owners (well deserved) but sucks for the regulars who now have to deal with the crazy crowds (not that it wasn't crowded before). At least, I can tell people I had a $20 burrito...once.
author: Rick C.

description:
Good - not great - but certainly not "the best".

I ordered the carne asada super burrito and came away full but not completely satisfied.  The steak was very good, but the rest of the ingredients (Rice, beans, pico, guacamole) were bland by comparison.  I found that I had to load the salsa up on the burrito to compensate for the generic taste.  I'm glad to have tried a new place, but will stick to La Taqueria for a more authentic and flavorful experience.
author: Greg G.

description:
Something's happening at Papalote, and it's not good. Seems like things are going on a downhill slide. I used to love, love their burritos and their salsa. The last time I ordered a veggie burrito, the potatoes weren't cooked enough.

Today, I tried again - my friend's veggie taco was inedible, she said the potatoes tasted bad and she threw it out. My "super" burrito with pintos was actually not a super, and they put in black beans. (this was a pickup order, so I didn't realize this til I was back home).

I hope things turn around soon, or I may just stop trying. Two strikes so far for two visits in a row...
author: judah m.

description:
I was reading over some of my old reviews and I'm still taken aback by this place. Whenever I go for a good burrito I go to Chipotle now. 6 bucks for a huge burrito where i know for a fact that everything is made fresh (cause I can see it being made). But what really floors me about Papalote's is that it takes sooo long to make an average burrito. These guys needs to take some hints from Chipotle. I have never spend more than 10 minutes from getting in line to leaving out the door.

One time i spent like 3-4 minutes (the cashier was tied up in the back) waiting for my order to be rung up. When the cashier finally came she said the burrito was comped (on the house). This has happened twice now. Chipotle will forever earn my burrito dollars. Get a clue Papalote and learn how to serve great tasting food for cheap in less than 10 minutes. It all happens in front of you so its not some trade secret.
author: Daniel D.

description:
I just had Papalote takeout for dinner and the experience was great.

Price: Reasonable
Service: Quick and Friendly
Food: Super Chicken Burrito was fantastic! 

I'm definitely a fan and will come here again!
author: SF M.

description:
I was set to write a real hater review of this place because I'd locked my bike up and ordered a burrito only to wait in an alley for 30 minutes with my number because the line was so long...I even had my iphone out, ruminating on how I'd throw my daggers...

but when I got home and finally tore the tinfoil off, it was bliss. Pure Mouthhole™ bliss.

I knocked off a star because their burritos are more expensive than the surroundings (I live in the mission, the going rate is like 6 bucks for a super burrito) but nonetheless I'll be back...and next time I won't wait till 8:30 at night to try and get dinner.
author: B C.

description:
The Mexican fare here definitely feels different, maybe more upscale? Well it's definitely more expensive, but the food is delicious. I recently got one of their breakfast plates and it was huge, reminded me of Chevy's/Tex-Mex almost, and delicious. Their fish quesadilla is pretty delicious, insanely buttery and cheesy, i.e. kinda greasy if you're into health (but why are you having a quesadilla in the first place then?). The fish reminded me of French food with all that butter-y tenderness.  

As for minuses, again price-y, but it seems like most Mexican places in the Mission have raised their prices. Their tacos and burritos are so-so, a bit bland. They are stingy with their chips and especially their tasty salsa now that they've started selling it in jars.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Beware of the crack salsa. Once the orange stuff hits your mouth, you'll be lost forever. A little bit of smoke, a good amount of heat, some tang, and a rich creamy feel. I don't know what's in it. I know many have tried to duplicate it and they have failed. Frankly I don't care. I just want more. More!!!

Since I can't inject the stuff intravenously (or can I?), I ordered a chile verde burrito with black beans to serve as my salsa delivery mechanism. It was pretty decent - well proportioned and plump with freshness. The meat was tender and juicy, and the beans were solid by my book. The burrito lacked the sinful greasy qualities of traditional Mexican, but I still enjoyed it (and my heart thanks me).

You'll like the food as long as you're not holding it to traditional expectations, but seriously it's all about the salsa here. It's damn good!
author: Mike W.

description:
Papalote's was featured on the Food Network on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay," me and the boyfriend wanted to check it out because it was local. We went there with his family and it's a small restaurant, it was the weekend, so it was really crowded but we waited for a table.

When we sat down they served chips and salsa. OMG that salsa. It's not the kind of salsa you're used to with chopped tomatoes, cilantro, and what not. The salsa at papalote's is more like a sauce, but a HELLA good sauce. We spent like 20 minutes tasting it and trying to figure out what was in it. The way I describe it is: it tastes like spicy nacho cheese doritos but in liquid form. Haha.

Anyway, I got the carne asada burrito and it was full of flavor. I'm not sure how else to describe it. Everything is made to order and it tastes like all the ingredients are fresh.

One time I came here with my co-worker and I got nachos with carne asada, cheese, guacamole, and sour cream. They had the perfect cheese to nachos ratio. They didn't put too much cheese and the chips stayed crunchy. It was a huge plate though, so if you get the nachos make sure you're with a friend. =)

What sucks is that after you finish the free chips and salsa, you have to pay for more. It's not much, but I usually think that chips and salsa are free.
author: Therese M.

description:
I went to Papalote in the Mission District on a recent weekend visit.  It was recommended by the owner of the B&B where I was staying.  As this is San Francisco, I expected the food to be a bit more authentic and I was sorely disappointed.

The staff was friendly enough and the menu was readable.  My complaint?  First, we ordered taquitos and a side of rice and beans.  My partner ordered the carne asada (beef) taquitos and I ordered the chicken.  What we received were huge chunks of meat (we are used to shredded meat) and long strands of lettuce and huge chunks of tomato.  There was no flavor at all in the meat or chicken and the abundance of watery tomato and lettuce made the taquitos so watery that they dissolved the tortilla.

The horchata and strawberry drinks were watery and not at all flavorful.  I am used to taquitos that have double tortillas with shredded chicken or beef and topped with salsa and chopped cilantro and onion.  Not here.

I would not recommend this place, and when I told my friend who we were visiting, she said that the place was always full and that there were way better taquerias to be had along Mission Street.

So, to not be too mean, I gave this place two stars, but really would have given it one.  Oh, and the huge burrito (which by the way, is an American invention) at the table next to me was burried under a mountain of mozzarella cheese.  Yech.
author: Deb J.

description:
I heard about this place from the food network and I thought i'd check it out.  I tried their signature dish, which was the triple threat burrito.  It wasn't bad.  It wasn't traditional but it was good.  They added too many spices in there and it was a bit overwhelming for the taste buds but I do like the meat.  For 20 bucks, I could've probably gotten 200 some good tacos in mexico but the food here was worth exploring.  
I wish I could say the same about the restaurant itself.  WIth the business it gets, you'd think they can afford a bigger place.  The graffiti in the bathroom is not art, its graffiti.  You can see that on the 101 when you pass downtown LA.  Be more creative or neater... or both.  
Overall, 3 stars for portion.
author: Kai H.

description:
I waltzed in with a friend early one Sunday evening. We went for a walk, saw Papalote, and thought sure, let's try it. 

AND WE DID. 

I had the grilled veggie burrito. I LOVE zucchini in my mexican food and this included it....And not just a few slices but it was STUFFED with zucchini...and a side of pinto beans, rice, eggplant, sourcream and cheese. My friend had the Mole/chicken burrito and she also enjoyed it...Although I think she enjoyed the strangely orange free salsa more. It WAS good after all. We left stuffed and pleased. Especially since when we arrived at 4 we walked right in and up to the cashier. Then when we left at 5ish there was a line out the door. We had the right burritos at the right time...with drinks for the right price...20 bucks. 

(By the way, this story took place approximately 5 hours ago. I decided to write this review promptly bc I also decided to promptly eat my burrito leftovers as soon as I got home....which is now....Also, it's even better cold. Yesssssss)

Go here and go early.
author: L P.

description:
Need to spice it up a bit?  Who said you can't find love on the cheap?  No better way to win her heart, or even his for that matter, than over a fabulous Triple Threat burrito at Papalote's.  Fresh mexican food with a San Fran twist, they serve it up fast and serve it up good.  Hey, they even won over Bobby Flay's affections on his show!  With award-winning salsa that is to-die-for (literally you want to drink the stuff!), lean meats, great spice, and a wide expanse of vegetarian options, this Mission staple is guaranteed to add heat to any relationship. 
Let me repeat:  By far the best salsa is San Fran!
author: Brittany T.

description:
Had to come here after seeing the restaurant on Throw Down w/ Bobby Flay!

It was crowded, and the wait was a little long, but the food was fab.  Purchased the Triple Threat Burrito and it was good.  I'm an uber carnivore, so I thought the steak would be my favorite, but the shrimp was major yummers!

Love it!
author: Roselina R.

description:
About a week ago I was flipping through the channels and stopped on the Food Network like I always seem to.  I was enthralled to see that Throwdown with Bobby Flay was on and it was a restaurant near my house!  I quickly decided after seeing their triple threat the next time I am in San Francisco I have to go out of my way to try this out.

Today was the day I was finally making a trip to San Francisco and HAD to get down to the Mission District and try that burrito I saw only a few days later that had me eating half of my pantry.  Right when I walked up I knew this was going to be the real deal.  It had all the signs of a good local place; small "hole in the wall" vibe, local art on the walls  and most importantly a line out the door in the pouring rain!

Now to get to the point, I sat through the line and got to the register and realized the triple threat was $19.95 and thought to myself, "that sounds like a lot of money, it must be huge!".  After about waiting for 20 minutes I got my food and was a little underwhelmed at the size.  Yes it was big, but not "wow I spent $20 on a burrito big".  However, I was starving so I dove in and was immediately impressed with the quality of food that was in front of me.  My meat was juicy and very well seasoned and the salsa they put on it, as well as give you with chips, was addicting!

Basically this is a must go for any fan of a good burrito, the only reason I gave it a 4 out of 5 was because the service was a little slow, they put cheese on my burrito when I asked them not too and I spent $20 on a burrito that only had two prawns in it!
author: Nate J.

description: Orange sauce and carne asada is what makes this place. The decor is cute and clean. I got the carne asada tacos and my friend got the carne asada burrito. Fresh ingredients with the super. It's a little more expensive then your average taqueria. Expect to be lined out the door if you come during the prime time.
author: Jennifer B.

description: I didn't get it. Why did everybody say they love this place?  Marketing maybe?  I understand they head to the playa and cover burners in their house salsa. It might be great if your tripping balls in Black Rock but for my money there's tastier burritos, salsa, and clientele in a bunch of other places.
author: Ivan L.

description:
Whoever reviewed Papalote and gave it 2 stars, noted bad service and incorrect orders probably only went there once and had an off night. The salsa alone is a reason to eat there or take out. The super chicken burrito is my taqueria control food and they blew the competition out of the water. With all the fresh ingredients (and yes, really fresh and good quality - there's no "mystery chicken" in there!) and the salsa.... oh, the salsa... likened to crack cocaine, mixed dangerously with those fresh chips.... oh my. I think i am beginning to blush.
Go and order whatever you normally order from your local greaseria and it will be infinitely better at Papalote. I promise!
author: Holly C.

description:
Oh, yeah, come to papa...  

I'd heard a ton about Paplote and how great it is....and it is great.  Where else can you get a great, 3 lb. super burrito for so little?  I had the carne asada...yum...love the carne asada.  I was surprised by the Noe Valley weekday dinner rush last week, but I guess if I lived in Noe, I'd be there all the time too....  I was a little disappointed with the amount of guacamole you get with a side order, but otherwise, fantastic!

It was so tasty that I may even consider the tofu mole...
author: Wendy L.

description:
Papalote serves killer papas and O.K. tofu. The vegetarian selection ranges from quirky potato tacos to the common spicy tofu fare. Their $4 vegetarian burritos and tacos are a motley mix of warm potatoes with carrots and mushrooms over a soft tortilla. The burrito is filling and the taco makes for a delicious snack. They're also one of very few taquerias that offer potatoes in their food.

Their tofu entree is disappointing in comparison. I am a lot more ambivalent about their spicy tofu because I've had just as good at other taquerias in the city. Why settle for average? All entrees come with chips and their famous salsa. I never tried a more thick and savory salsa before. 

The lack of a lunchtime crowd and the colorful ambience made the whole experience enjoyable. Come before noon for ample seating and a more easygoing staff. Easygoing implies genial! Maybe.
author: Chris G.

description: Great Mexican - yes, the salsa is really good!  My 7-year old son would be happy to have dinner here every night, and I wouldn't mind a bit...
author: Steve H.

description:
The BEST burrito in CA in my experience.  I've had a lot of burritos in TX and CA and everyone is entitled to their opinion.  IMHO this is the #1.  

I always get the Fish Burrito with everything.  Hello!  Sauted in Wine?  How tasty is that?  

And REAL HOMEMADE Horchata!!!!!  Gotta love it.  

Finally, the salsa with the chips is worth coming in for alone.  Creamy!  Who whudda thunk?  So tasty.
author: Mark B.

description: Really great burritos! What makes them stand out is the Papalote sauce.
author: Amy N.

description:
Always consistent and the food is fresh! The only food item that I think can be improved upon is their rice; a little bit bland and dry.

Everything else about Papalotes makes me smile! I love their vegetarian tacos and burritos (with carrots, potatoes and mushrooms!)! Nice casual vibe and friendly servers.
author: Terri M.

description:
Average. I know that they beat Bobby Flay in a throwdown but I am really not sure how. The veggie burrito I ordered was almost identical to the shrimp burrito my friend got. She really didn't get many shrimp for the price.

Maybe it was an off day. I will say the play was packed so maybe what they ordered was better.
author: Leeann M.

description:
I'm gonna side more with the overrated comments. Burrito was big, meat was kinda tasty, but it didn't blow me away as I had expected. Also, my burrito was lacking in the amount of sour cream and guac i had added to my order. I've had better in the Bay Area and most definitely in all of CA.

Salsa was pretty good though. 

Place was pretty busy on a Wednesday night when I went. Expect to wait a bit if you want to sit down.

3 stars for salsa and effort.
author: Norwin E.

description:
I came for a burrito and I left happy. It sounds as though other reviewers may have come looking for something else - a religious experience, a revelation, a culinary come-to-Jesus moment. I did not have one of them. But I did have a seriously good burrito. 

I was in a rush so I got my burrito to-go, so I may not have had the full Papalote experience. The place was very crowded, even at 2 in the afternoon. It's a small space. If you're going for a sit-down meal, my guess is that you could have a wait, and you're going to be in a small room at a little table. If you're getting your order to go, you'll do some shuffling as people move past you carrying food and trying to pay for their orders. These things should not surprise anybody, you went out in search of a tiny delicious burrito place, right?

As this was my second lunch, I didn't have room to try more than one burrito. I went for the chili verde (pork). I am lame and do not like sour cream or guac, so I did not go super. If you are not lame, I hear you should do so. I was pleasantly surprised to find some wicked good salsa and tortilla chips in the bottom of my bag when I got on the BART. The price for the burrito was absolutely reasonable, throw in the chips and salsa and I'm a happy tourist!

Make sure to hit one of the bakeries in the area on your way home to complete the experience.
author: Laura S.

description:
Rub-A-Dub-Dub thanks for the grub!

Adobo Burrito is now available all day, every day! Holla!!

Parking can be a bit of a b*tch, but if anything you can call ahead for an order and leave someone in the car with the hazards on.

If you insist on eating there, you'll have to be willing to wait. Fortunately for us, we didn't have to wait very long at all. The line was long itself, but the seating process went smooth because they actually seat you! Unlike many other places that make you fight for seats and don't even wipe down the tables!

Anyways, the owner was there the night we came and I think he was doing more interviews, especially because the Throwdown with Bobby Flay will be airing soon.

On to the food, the chips and salsa are addictive. I don't usually go for spicy anything, but these are addictive. Unfortunately, they don't have bottomless chips and kind of give a dinky serving, but that's OK, I didn't want to fill up on chips anyway....

We waited maybe 15 minutes after ordering to finally get our Adobo Burrito. 1. I love adobo...chicken, pork, whatever. I love adobo and my mom's adobo is hard to match. 2. I love Mexican rice...but I only love it when it has the right amount of flavor to it.

So what does that mean? This burrito is delicious! It's neither overwhelming in each category and they compliment each other well. Then again I could have scorched my tongue from not being able to wait to bite in and the meat was still freshly hot-tot-tot.

The rice is flavorful, I half expected it to be straight up white garlic rice for some reason. The chunks of meat aren't too adobo-ey, but still taste good. If anything, it can have more flavor.

I took half of my burrito home, although they aren't too big in size, but I ended up eating it as soon as I got home and it tasted a bit better because I let the juices soak in.

There's not a doubt in my mind that the other burritos/dishes here are really good.

Sidenote: This is not a drunk food establishment, they close @ 9 or 10.
author: Clarisse C.

description:
Been wanting to try their triple threat for quite some time now and was able to do so the other night on a spur of the moment decision for dinner.

The boyfriend and I were driving down Potrero and I said, "Hey! Let's try Papalote tonight!" Of course, he agreed.

We got there thinking we'd just grab our burrito to go and cut out, but we were invited to sit and eat inside the restaurant since there were a couple open tables.

We ordered the triple threat burrito and horchata. I was a little taken aback by the price! But, alas, that's what you get for paying for a good burrito. My boyfriend even commended them. He used to work at SF General and tried a bunch of places in The Mission, but said Papalote was the best.

We got our burrito pretty quickly and we split it. Oh! I forgot to mention! The salsa that came with the chips was good! Albeit, spicy for my liking, but still good! Anyway, back to the burrito. It was filled with a good amount of chicken, steak, and shrimp, so I definitely feel like they didn't cheat us out of the good stuff. Miguel also came by to say hi and dropped off a plate of the adobo burrito filling, which is more down my ally! OMG, it was so tender and delicious. Better than most Filipino adobo I have tried!!!

I will definitely get the chicken adobo burrito next time. I liked the triple threat, but I don't wanna fight big pieces to eat my way through the burrito, which makes the adobo one perfect because the chicken is so tender that you don't need a fork and knife to eat it!

Mmm...just thinking about it makes me wanna go back and have one RIGHT NOW!
author: Diana Lyn Z.

description: nice chipolte burrito in price and no flavor.  with the white hipster takeover of the Mission there went the barrio and now it's all wait in line bland food in an anglo neighborhood.  seriously no meat in the burrito and had no taste what so ever.  I remember back in the day when every other doorway was a real mexican taqueria.  this is not at all the case now. Hipsters not only gentrify they destroy.  I don't trust any restaurant that touts vegan/vegetarian food and this place is one of them. ....oh yeah and the tortilla on the burrito....crap.
author: Michael S.

description: This was my favorite.  Sadly, I'm thinking we're in the denouement phase of Papalote's reign of awesome.  Still better than most.  I'll forever shell out the six bucks for a jar of that salsa at Rainbow/Safeway.
author: Nick D.

description:
The sibbies were in town and had seen the episode of Throwdown, of course.  I'd been curious to try out the famous burrito also, but knew I wasn't going to spend the $ on it on my own.  Cue Papalote for dinner tonight.  

First off, the place is tiny.  Not in a bad way, but just in the way that you need to know before going there assuming you can just sit down.  Even fewer seats than El Farolito around the corner.  

Foodwise, first we got the chips and salsa.  Off to a great start.  Good chips, tasty and complex salsa.  Nice and spicy, too, but maybe a touch too much for the average person.  Also not impressed they charge for another bowl of corn chips.  Boo for that one.

Next up: the Triple Threat.  Of course that's what we had to try.  It arrives taking up more of a plate than is reasonable for a burrito.  But that's what it should do for $20.  And yes, it did take ~15 minutes to arrive, but that's ok in my book, since it was clear everything was freshly cooked.  Again, not your average burrito.  We had to taste each element independently, and each was fantastic on its own.  The shrimp were nicely spiced and well cooked.  The chicken was not too salty (a frequent problem I've noticed with seasoned chicken), and the steak was simple but awesome.  Guacamole was also very good, as were the refried beans.

So on the whole, we enjoyed the food, were astounded at the size of the portion, and would likely come back again.  We would likely not be getting the Triple Threat, though...especially not for $20.  Carne Asada burritos, on the other hand....
author: Adam G.

description: I should Preface this by saying that i really sont mind paying for good food. this place is so overpriced!  Ordered two burritos and 1 beer for 25$. The salsa is great- ill give you that. Otherwise, everything was pretty standard burrito fare. Chips were stale. If it was a 7$ burrito I'd totally go back. For what it costs, no way. Over it!
author: Lindsay K.

description:
Their SALSA is awesome. I just wish I could get it at a store or something.

I had the Triple Threat Burrito. Pretty good. I doubt they really beat Bobby Flay, but it was still very good.
author: James S.

description:
They have greatly stepped up their game on the Adobo Burrito. The chicken is much more flavorful, giving you a full blast of the adobo flavor you've come to know and love. Not like the first time when I went, the chicken was dry and it only had a little hint of adobo flavor. Definitely check it out and only try it at the 24th street location.

They also include chips and salsa now with the burrito so that's a double win!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: Good food, great salsa and chips.  The price seemed a little high considering there are about a thousand great taco/burrito places within a mile of here.  I enjoyed my fish taco but I have a hard time giving it 4 stars.  My boyfriend said his carne asada burrito was good but he liked El Faro/El Farolito better and its $3 cheaper.
