Overall a good place to eat but I think there are other places just as good and a little cheaper just down 24th.
author: Nicole W.

description:
I ordered the Adobo burrito (off menu). It's mildly-spiced chicken, rice, and tomatoes (no beans). I was expecting something more vinegar-y, more reminiscent of Filipino food, but it was just OK. I wanted the flavor to be more pronounced.

The mole burrito was pretty tasty, but somehow I thought it would taste stronger. It wasn't bland, just milder than I expected.

The salsa was excellent, though.

I wanted to get the triple threat burrito (with shrimp, chicken, and steak), but $20 for a burrito was more than I was willing to spend.

One day I'll return to try their fish burrito. Sauteed in white wine and butter? In a burrito? I am skeptical as to the taste (white wine flavor in a burrito?) but intrigued.
author: Amy N.

description: This place is good. Its a tad small, but it packs quality. Fair price as well and the food is great. Nothing much more to say, just overall a great place and worth a try.
author: Don S.

description:
YUUUUUMMM!!

We made the trek out to the Mission during our recent visit to SF for the tofu tacos and they did not disappoint!  Everything we had was delicious but the tofu tacos were my favorite! It's hard to find good Mexican vegetarian food that goes beyond beans and fajita style peppers so I was super excited given their plentiful vegetarian menu.  The horchata was also one of the best I've ever had, and I'm a big horchata fan!

The best part of the meal though for me was the salsa, it is so delicious, I wanted to drink it!  The only downfall was the limited seating, but I like that they enforce the "wait til you order to sit down" rule because there were definitely some people trying to snake seats.  We were able to sit pretty quickly but had to split our party up, but it was worth it for the food!

Also the location is super convenient from the Bart station for those traveling visitors who find themselves without a car and tired feet.
author: Ana H.

description:
I will preface this review by noting that we should have called ahead and asked about the amount of garlic in their food. My husband has an allergy, & there were a lot of items on the menu he couldn't eat. That being said, we decided to share the grilled veggie fajitas. We received a small bowl of chips and a tiny amount of salsa when we were seated--it is nice to provide that complimentary appetizer, although visually it's perplexing to see the salsa served in the same size metal container that mayonnaise or ketchup usually come in. If my husband had been able to eat the salsa, it certainly wouldn't have been enough. 

The fajitas came out pretty quickly. The eggplant, zucchini & carrots were cooked a pleasant amount--not mushy. Lettuce, diced toms, and jicama (I think) all tasted fresh. The refried beans were good (though on the runnier end of the spectrum, just fyi) and the avocado slices were ripe and there were a good number of them. Wish the same had been true of  the tortillas! The order came with 3 clearly mass-produced, traditional-sized (i.e. taco, not burrito), flour tortillas--not enough to deal with even half of the food on the plate. Though they did not charge us extra when we asked for more, this just reinforced the impression created by the salsa--that they were trying to give us as little as possible. I suppose this could be a considered strategy to reduce food waste (which we would support!), though, if that's their rationale, it would help to explain that, and advise customers they need only ask for more. 

Overall, the food was fine, but not what I expected after hearing my sis talk about having seen this joint on TV, and seeing it mentioned in The Rough Guide to Cali. Could not shake the impression that you're not quite getting your money's worth. I may go back for the tofu mole everyone raves about, but probably only if I'm already in the neighborhood. I'll give 3 stars--because I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt that the absence of garlic really impacted the flavor of the food.
author: S H.

description:
loved the soyrizo tacos

lots of options for veggies and vegans

chips were a lil hard

staff was super friendly, okay prices.

I'd like to go back and try more , mmmmm
author: Coco J.

description:
Like what others have said, don't believe the hype.

After waiting 15 minutes for my carne asada burrito + the 99 cent extras, I was disappointed with the lack of flavor from this 'Mission' burrito.  The meat was tough, the tortilla seemed a bit off, and there just wasn't any flavor in there.  

El Farolito is miles better, and is just down the street.
author: shaun l.

description:
I recently moved to Bernal Heights and walk through the Mission everyday to get to and from BART.  The smell of grilled meats is enough to make me want to try every single mexican restaurant in the mission.  

I had the chicken mole tacos and fish tacos here.  YUMMMY fish!  Fresh and in my opinion, even better than Maya's.  Ok on the chicken mole. I love that place.  Looking forward to going back to try their carne asada and others.
author: Anna C.

description:
This place is kinda small and always packed with hipsters. I've usually gotten stuff to-go, and always the super tofu burrito. 

You wouldn't think that a burrito with tofu can be better than a burrito with MEAT. But it is surprisingly good. And huge. I've had it for days in a row and not gotten tired of it. Add the dip/sauce they provide, and it becomes even more amazing. 

Their chips are really good too - freshly made. With the burrito it usually comes to ~$10 - but lasts me almost two meals!
author: Connie C.

description:
My friend and I stopped by here for a late lunch on a Sunday afternoon after perusing the vintage shops in the mission. I ordered the beef fajitas and they were very tasty. It was a huge portion, so huge that I took it to go and ate it for lunch the next day. My friend ordered the fajitas with shrimp and though she said it was tasty, they only gave her three shrimps and it was the most expensive fajita option. 

The place is small so at any given time, there could be a long wait. And I must comment on the bathroom-it was DISGUSTING. In fact, that is why I only gave this place three stars. 

All in all, I if I lived close by this would be a great place to order take out from ...but I don't so that's not an option for me. If I was in the neighborhood, I'd maybe eat here again. But I wouldn't step foot in that bathroom.
author: Casf K.

description:
Papalote is one of the best Mexican joints in the Mission - fresh ingredients, creative recipes, and just the right amount of food. The place is ripe with delicious vegetarian/pescatarian options (the soyrizo burrito is pretty damned amazing) but there are a few drawbacks as well. 

Hipsters. Skinny jeans, Buddy Holly glasses, kafais, Che hats, and an overall  smuggness of being part of a large group of ironic looking non-conformist conformists are unfortunate elements of getting food at Papalote. When you order, try to curb your urge to kick the guy behind you in the shins while he waxes on about how The Faint was heavily influenced by Black Flag's early albums.

Also, make sure to call ahead to place your order so you don't have to wait forever for your food. 

Overall: great place, great options, slightly pricey for a burrito joint, and enough misanthropic trust fund babies to fill an entire screening of Nick & Nora's Ultimate Playlist.
author: Victor W.

description: San Francisco's best Mexican restaurant. The next la boulange, watch for it...
author: Soren D.

description:
Believe the hype - the chips and salsa are both amazing.  

I got the carne asada burrito and it's everything a burrito should be - meaty, hearty, devilishly delicious, and messy (if not eaten with a fork).  arrived at around 7pm on a Saturday night.  It was busy, but we were able to get a small table for two.  

The place is small but fun (and pretty clean), and the music was hip and upbeat.  There were some pretty cool artwork that hung around as well.  

Definitely worth a second visit.  If I can get someone to split with me, I'd like to try the triple threat burrito.
author: valerie t.

description:
I wanted to try this place badly after seeing it on Throwdown with Bobby Flay. The burrito featured on the show was the Triple Threat. The night that the episode originally aired, we tried to place a phone order to pick it up. After ordering 2 of these burritos with a couple minor add-ons, the lady said "it'll be ready in 45 minutes and it'll be $45." What?!?! Seriously? We thought she heard our order wrong, like we ordered 5-10 burritos. But no, she was serious; that was the price for 2. We were so shocked that we ended up cancelling the order.

After doing some research on Yelp, we found out that as soon as the show aired, they jacked the price up by $5. Pretty messed up, but apparently there was high enough demand.

A few months later, we finally decided to give it a try. My girlfriend and I split one of the Triple Threat burritos. I must say, it was pretty good. It's not often that you get shrimp, chicken, and carne asada all on one burrito. The orange sauce was excellent as well. Lots of flavor, and we also had some with our chips.

But in the end, I cannot justify paying $20+ for a burrito, especially in the Mission, where there is seemingly a taqueria every other store. I'm glad that you guys got the publicity that Bobby Flay gave you, but how do you plan to have repeat customers? Sure, people will try it once out of curiosity, but I don't imagine many returning for the same $20 burrito.
author: John C.

description:
Came here for a couple of reasons: (1) I was told that this is a place for Filipino-style Mexican food and I was eager to learn about Filipino food, and (2) this place had been featured on the Food Network (Throwdown with Bobby Flay).  I decided to order something different this time, the Prawn Burrito under the specialty burrito section, thinking that would give be more Filipino-like.

The prawns were coated with lime juice and grilled.  Upon first bite into the prawn I was thinking.. this is really special, great taste with great grilled aroma.  However, as I continued I found out the rest of the prawns were overcooked and tasted a bit bitter, probably from over-charring on the outside.  In the end, I didn't get either of the two things that I came here for - not feeling any Filipino side of it and not sure what made this place so special to be featured on the Food Network.

P.S. I did really enjoy the spicy and creamy saucer that came with the free chips.
author: Chad S.

description:
Finally a mexican joint that does fish burritos in the City. 

Seriously,i've searched high and low throughout SF to find a place that can make fish burritos decently. Nick's tacos off of irving? Forget it. Dry, puny burritos there. I've had to drive to San Carlos to Baja Fresh for my fix.  

Parking is iffy in that crowded neighborhood. Soon as you walk in you're at the cashier/order taker. Smiles and greetings. Gf ordered the pork burrito and myself pescado burrito with sour cream, guac and rice on. 

Seating's a bitch if it's rush hour so plan on coming right as they open or after lunch rush. We sat and immediately served chips with their famous salsa. Really good and the right heat to it. GF said it was too spicy. 

The fish burrito is what I loved tho they lose 1 star because they overpacked it and the burrito fell apart after 2 bites needing fork and knife. A burrito is a handheld affair. Giant though with the flour tortilla nice and warm. Big chunks of fish which I dunno why, is sauteed in butter and wine per their menu. Grilled would've been tastier and added an extra dimension. 

Finally found my fish burriot go to place. And open 7 days a week! nice.
author: Bill N.

description:
Wow, World class burritos, Fish tacos are old of this world.
  I highly reccomend
author: Candi G.

description: Papolote was my first taqueria when I moved to San Francisco and I still use as the REFERENCE for mexican food!
author: Khaloud D.

description:
I've enjoyed Papalote's food very often since moving to the Bay Area. They just recently raised their prices though.  $5 for a rice and bean burrito is kind of steep!  The marinated tofu is now $7.50. Add a dollar for guac and tax and it's around $9.35... for ONE burrito... during a pretty harsh economic downturn.

Congrats, I do realize you were voted best burrito in some local rag and the line got 50x longer, but this is just really milking it. Congrats on your Food Network show, too. I'll be over at Mariachi's (with enough change from my $10 to take the Muni home) if you need me.
author: aaron f.

description:
So I have been back twice (for take out) since my last review.  I was right the first time - Papalote is best enjoyed in the comfort of your home (or in my case, the home of a fellow fatty) :)

The first two times I had the soyrizo SUPER burrito (hey, go big or go home, right?!) and they were amazing both times, except that it can be a bit salty.  I would still highly recommend it though, especially because soyrizo burritos aren't something often offered at other places.

Tonight I tried the tofu w/ achiote burrito, which I could have sworn I had the first time I went...but alas, my burrito buddy proved me wrong with her detailed review documenting exactly what I ate (shout out to Ms. Julie S. who I'm sure is reading this review) ;)

I would highly recommend the tofu super burrito.  The tofu tastes more like paneer - and since I was craving Indian food also, it really hit the spot!  The tofu wasn't dry and went really well with the other fixings.  My only complaint was that the tofu wasn't really well dispersed...I had to eat almost half of my burrito to find the tofu...but when I did, it was DEE-LISH!

I definitely will be back.  Tip: call ahead!!! You don't want to get stuck in line!
author: Alvina W.

description:
I don't want to get hung up on money, but we went to Papalote for dinner last night and spent $30!  That's a ton of money at a Mexican joint.  I was shocked when the guy at the cash register told me the amount we owed.  We had a super fish burrito, two carne asada tacos, and two beers.  It should be noted that the menu prices listed on the photo at this time on Yelp are really out of date.

As for the food, it was really good.  Unique, tasty sauce for the chips is a great way to start the dinner and everyone gets their own bowl of chips.  Because it's a smaller space, it can get packed quickly.
author: Lucius M.

description: A friend recommended this place as a must-have during our girls' weekend in San Francisco, and we were not disappointed! The burritos and quesadillas were absolutely to die for - fresh and with wonderful ingredients. The employees were polite... and the chips and salsa? No words. My only regret is the salsa they sell is too big to be a carry on liquid!
author: Jessi L.

description:
I'm seriously pretty upset right now that I do not live in the city. I was hungover at my friends apartment and was way too lazy to even get up off the couch let alone leave the apartment to get food. 

We were watching Throwdown with Bobby Flay and this delicious looking burrito came up on the TV--The Triple Threat. I was hooked. I watched the entire show and was pumped when I found out these guys were based in San Francisco. 

I left the apartment immediately to find this place. The Triple Threat is HUGE (I think it should have been split among 3-4 people) and is $19.95. Sad. $20 burritos are always disappointing, but I couldn't not order it. It has prawns, chicken and beef in it. I was hesitant when I saw the chicken and I assumed it would be dry. It was not dry -- it was amazing instead.  

The salsa is amazing and I had to ask for my own because I didn't want to share anymore. It's spicy and is great on chips, the burrito, a plain flour tortilla....by the end I was just spooning it into my mouth. 

Their other burritos are very reasonably priced ($6-8) and the portions are also very large. And it's only 99 cents to add sour cream, guacamole, and cheese!  The staff is really friendly despite how busy they are and always wipe down the tables between guests. yay. 

Bobby Flay definitely has nothing on this place. I'm excited to go back.
author: Desiree L.

description:
The ingredients are fresh, and the options come by the dozen. Meat options are plentiful and unique. The menu has so many different options for any vegan, vegetarian, or good 'ole meat eater like myself. I personally loved the whole wheat tortilla option for no extra charge. It was the first time I had heard of a Chicken Mole option for a burrito - and it did not disappoint! 

However, the best part of the meal cannot be overlooked. The chips and salsa, which is served by the bowl to each person, is unmissable. Easily one of the best salsas I've had. It's smokey, garlicy and has enough kick to leave a little warmth in the back of the throat. So good.

The only downside I saw was the Triple Threat's price. Why, El Papalote, do you have a $20 burrito on your menu if it is roughly the same size as your other normal priced ones? I get that is filled with good meat, but damn! You better get a whole pound of shrimp in there for that price. 

I'd def. come back to El Papalote! Especially after beating Bobby Flay.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Soyrizo burrito is vegetarian perfection.  The salsa is amazing, very amazing.  It is always busy it seems and getting stuffed into a long table surrounded by couples on dates is kind of awkward, but the food is so good I cannot remove a star for this.  

Well worth the wait and the price (nearly twice that of my usual $5 burrito).
author: Jonathan T.

description: I got a regular soyrizo burrito with pinto beans, but it had the texture of a refried bean sandwich. The flavors were decent, but burrito was just a soft mesh of mexican tastes. The salsa is admittedly good, but you can get that at the grocery store and put it on a burrito from any other location in the city and you will likely have a better experience.
author: Ben M.

description:
Best veg burrito on the planet, with big chunks of potato, tender carrot medallions, and sauteed mushrooms. Plus, all of their beans are vegan (even the pinto beans are made without lard). I've had the veg tacos, the mole, and the veg quesadilla too. All are good, but I crave the veggie burrito. Oh, and the salsa is perfect: spicy and flavorful. It's so perfect that I buy it by the jar for home.

My husband jokes at me because whenever he asks where I feel like eating lunch, the answer is always Papalote.
author: Heather T.

description:
¡Quiero comer toda la salsa!

The food gets three stars, but the salsa gets ten. Take my advice: grab a jar of their $6 salsa, pick up a couple bags of hint-of-lime tortilla chips on your way home, and you're set. But be prepared for withdrawals once that jar runs out.
author: Adam M.

description: This is the closest restaurant to my house. The salsa here is very good and very different from other mexican restaurants. The chile verde is also great. One cool thing is that the cooks all speak in Mayan (I asked them). Somehow I didn't know that it was still spoken. I'm giving it three stars. I would probably give it four but I rarely feel like going there. One reason is that  50-80% of the customers at the other mexican restaurants are mexican or el salvadoran, but even though I pass Papalotes at least twice/day I don't think I have ever seen a latino customer.
author: John S.

description:
I used to frequent papalote and sing its praises to everyone I met. 
No more.
It's been almost 2 years and I have to say, other than the still excellent salsa, this place is no longer worth the visit.  When you are paying 15$ for a plate there is no excuse for dry chewy chili verde or mole. The 9$ burrito is easily bested by cheaper offerings from pancho villa, gordo, la corneta, el faralote, chipotle etc. 
I'll shed a tear for what papalote used to be but I won't be coming back for anything but a jar of that salsa.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Meat eaters and vegans alike should enjoy the tasty, savory soyrizo burrito here.

Whenever I make it to the mission I grab an extra one to take home for the next day.

It rarely makes it that long.

P.S. Guacamole as a side or as an addon is expensive but it's tasty and you get plenty.
author: Jeff G.

description: The sauce! The sauce is worth writing a million words for. You can also buy the jar of sauce which makes it that much better. I usually get the carne asada burrito and it's never failed to impress. I have also tried the grilled veggie burrito (not that great as it had no guac, cheese, salsa or sour cream). You can't go wrong with the quesadillas either! Cute little spot
author: Niki V.

description: Prices have gone up, service is hit and miss and when we were there a couple weeks ago, we were charged $1.50 for an extra serving of salsa. Is this a joke?
author: Natalye R.

description:
After reading 40 million reviews, thought I'd give it a try. Went down with a friend of mine, and he had the carne asada quesadilla, while I had the carne asada burrito. We also shared some chorizo and melted cheese---all of it fantastic! The carne asada was well-cooked, and they didn't skimp like other places do. The cooks are working overtime and we could smell and see the other tables' dishes as they were brought out, with a lot of "What is that? I gotta get some of that!" comments. All of the other patrons were equally impressed. And if you're in the Mission, you better be authentic or you'll be exposed for the fraud you are. This place is the real deal.

If this is your first time there, on each table there is a bottle of salsa picante (the red) and salsa verde (the green). OMG. Warning: whatever drink you get, if you put the verde on your food, get two drinks. I put some serious water away washing that down. It was one of those types of meals where you know you'll pay for it later and you just don't care. It's that good. We'll definitely be back again.
author: Jerry M.

description:
After seeing the Bobby Flay Throwdown episode where he challenged these guys and lost, we went out of our way (on a road trip from Seattle to LA) to check this place out.  Boy am I glad we did!! 

I wanted to try the Triple Threat, but we had other places to try just down the street so I went with the Carne Asada burrito.  It was perfect, not too big, not too small...just right.  The meat was perfectly cooked and flavored, not loaded with gristle like so many carne asada burrito's can be.  My wife had the shrimp burrito which was also very good, although the shrimp was a little overcooked and over-blackened.

Where they really shine though is their salsa.  It's amazingly good.  Not super hot, just spicy enough.  We brought a jar home with us and it's getting dangerously close to empty.  Will they ship to Seattle?

Definetly will go again on our next Cali trip.
author: frederick a.

description:
my go-to mexican joint for the past 5 years. by far, the best mexican food within the 24th/Mission/Noe corridor. Try the nachos (drizzled w/ guac and sour cream), refried black bean dip, and the carne asada super tacos. 

papalote even sells their own homemade salsa; I think a bottle runs ~10 bucks. You can buy extra 'lil salsas for 50 cents/ea. 

if that doesn't convince you then how about this: this is the 1,000th review on yelp in a very crowded mexican market.

check out youtube for their foodtv appearance and various founder/co-founder sketch vids.
author: devo m.

description:
Everything I've had here is DELICIOUS, from the chilaquiles to the breakfast omelet burrito, to the shrimp tacos, etc!  And every once in a while they'll throw in a special/seasonal item, like the Adobo Burrito =) 

I also love that they're *green* about their yummy House Sauce (my fave salsa dip on the planet) ~ You can buy a refrigerated unlabeled one and bring it back for $1 off your next refill.  There are also labeled ones along the front of the cash register if you're a label whore like that  :) 

I usually walk here so can't complain about the parking.  But it's the Mission, so notorious for tricky parking.  Also have never had a problem with a long wait, except for once I had to stand in the doorjamb for a few minutes, no biggie.  Service is always fast and the tables are always cleaned pretty swiftly!
author: Michele Z.

description: My dream has come true: I now live around the corner from this place. The salsa is the best I've ever had. Now I buy the fresh (in the mason jar) salsa to put on everything in my fridge. If you bring your jar back, they'll refill it for $1!!!
author: Juls M.

description:
Check out the pork n shrimp burrito.  I was grumpy as usual at 11am on a Sunday when I don't eat (sorry love).  My GF went out on a trek to find me some food...and what a find!  It took a little while, but the wait was all worth it.  I eat lots and lots and lotsa Mexican food - sometimes my GF hates me for it ; ) hahaha - but this place seemed to stand out.  The taste was less typical and definitely unique.

If my FAVORITE burrito place wasn't in the same city - I might have even gave this place a 5.  lets count this one as a 4.5  Check em out!
author: Derik P.

description:
This place has a lot of hype. Honestly I think the only reason they would beat a famous chef in a throwdown is the gimmicky $20 burrito. I got a carnitas burrito, and it was pretty mediocre. The salsa was in way bigger chunks than I like, and there wasn't a whole lot of flavor. Only a notch above a Chipotle (blech) and too expensive. The chips may as well have been Tostitos, but the real gem is the hot sauce people keep calling salsa that comes with them. That stuff I saved. Probably wouldn't go back here for a burrito since there are so many cheaper and better options nearby.

Also, if you do go here, call your order in ahead. I waited about 30 minutes for one burrito which seemed absurd since they weren't that busy when I came in.
author: Beth D.

description: My daughter and I really looked forward to eating at this restaurant after seeing it featured on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay".  It was a BIG disappointment.  The prices were way too expensive for burritos which consisted of mostly beans and rice, with very little carne asada or shrimp.  We are from Southern California where a carne asada burrito is less expensive, just as big, and has plenty of flavorful beef.  Plus, the beans and rice are side items, not the main component of the burrito.  So, we now know not to eat Mexican food in Northern California.
author: Raquel A.

description: Came here once, tried the Chicken Adobo burrito, or Mexipino burrito. SO GOOD! Garlic rice (already "game over"), chicken adobo, tomatoes. you can also make it a "super" with sour cream and guacamole. You gotta try it!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Go for the salsa - it's AMAZING.
Anything that is cooked in it (especially tofu) is also amazing.
Unfortunately, the line sucks, so call your order in. 
Note: They cost more than they should.
author: Sarah T.

description:
ordered the chicken adobo burrito and split it with my boyprend. 

just ordering one burrito came out to $10, super pricey.  Overall, yeah the flavor was pretty good, chicken was juicy, and the chips weren't bad, but $10 for a burrito?? I think that you could find a better burrito for half the price somewhere else.  

not really feelin' the papalote hype.
author: Tiffany S.

description: This place does NOT have the best burritos in SF at all. I had a steak and shrimp burrito today. The rice was undercooked and hard....and the carne asada was not chopped very well. Big hunks of meat like a fajita. Meats should be chopped more finely....I wanted extra salsa for my chips and they charge u extra ? I actually have to pay the waiter at our table and do a seperate transaction for salsa ??? Doesn't that sound ridiculous to you ? I take my burritos very seriously...the burrito wasn't horrible, but not by any means the best in sf. I will not give into the hype.
author: Mario W.

description:
My favorite burrito in the city.  Other burritos from taqueria's in the mission manage to all taste the same to me.  

If you're looking for a tasty burrito that uses fresh ingredients and is just plain addicting - then Papalote all the way.
author: Derek M.

description: Awesome food and cool atmosphere. Saw Andy Sandberg there eating, so mildly funny people appreciate the food too.
author: Al H.

description: Split the Triple threat burrito w/the hubby and for me wasn't worth the $20. Just reminded me of Chipotle flavors. I guess I was expecting more than it was put out to be.
author: Camille S.

description:
I feel so fortunate that I live on the same block as this restaurant. 

Chicken mole tacos and chile verde burrito pleeeeeaaase!
author: Keika L.

description: They have great food, but I think their best dish is the chilaquiles. Add eggs to it and you'll be happy and full for a long long time. Just writing this review is making my mouth water!
author: Carlos E.

description: Papalote is a great place for a quick and delicious burrito.
author: Dan W.

description: The chips and salsa was on the list of 100 things to try before you die. And I am glad I am able to check this one off, there is something really good about the salsa. I know they make it with roasted tomatoes but there is something else there, that I can't put my finger on it. I guess I will just use it to lick the salsa container clean.
author: Eve C.

description: We ordered by phone and picked up soyrizo and a tofu taco. The soyrizo is awesome and so is the salsa that everyone talks about. I hear the tofu tastes like paneer, which makes it sound even tastier!! Wish I was in SF longer to try out their other veggie options. Two tacos to an order made for a filling meal without feeling overstuffed. Yum!!
author: Christina K.

description: The food is decent, but it is pricey. Lots of better taquerias in the area, but this place has atmosphere and super clean. Really easy to chat and mingle with strangers here because the tables/seats are very close.
author: Nam L.

description:
The salsa here is on point.  If you want a good burrito with some fresh meat and great salsa, come here.  Expect a crowd and very little seating.

Bobby Flay did a salsa throw down challenge against these guys so you know they're serious about their salsa!  Salsa is creamy and spicy and you can buy it by the jar.  You can also bring back their jars and refill at the restaurant for a cheaper price.  Recycle.  

There is a good selection of tortilla wrappers; spinach, regular, wheat, flour etc.  They also have a good variety of meats to fill your burrito.  I didn't get the super burrio and my burrito tasted just fine.  Slap on some of that good salsa and you'll be fine.  

My few complaints would be that they don't give enough salsa, it comes in a very very small cup, more please!  Can't really complain about the space because you are in the mission and most of these food places are on the small side.  Get it to go.  Second, they do charge a bit more for their burritos than other restaurants do but their salsa is better.  I guess you can always get their salsa to go and head to a cheaper burrito place for burritos.  Whatever floats your boat.  Third, parking sucks, but again you're in the mission so it's expected.

I think this place is OK and I'd go back if I was in the area.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Good food but overpriced and on the small side regarding quantity. Parking is  tricky to find, depending on the day and time.The place is small and can be tricky to find a table when packed. Excellent for takeout as you order just inside the door. I am not a fan of salsa so I did not try it. I did notice they have their salsa for sale in glass jars,

Papalote Super CarneAsada burrito definitely hit the spot and the taste buds. I like how their Carne Asada is grilled fresh and not chopped into little ity-bitty pieces. They grill the tortillas causing the outside to have a nice crunch. I like their rice and how cheesy the burrito was, the Pinto beans seemed standard. The Burrito price was high (@ $9.97 with chips and tax) especially compared to other establishments. The size was not what I consider a super burrito and was on the small side comparatively. However the burrito was fresh, tasty, and great!
author: Trev D.

description: Great salsa!  I ordered the chicken mole burrito.  I am a big fan of mole sauce and almost always order mole when eating Mexican food.  It is a legit mole sauce, rich and well balanced.  I was visiting from Seattle and this was my favorite burrito on my visit.
author: Joel W.

description:
An experience that has shaken my faith in the taste of my fellow San Franciscans. I just cannot understand the hype around this place. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd come back here- it's just not a good value.

I've tried Papalote's food before. I have vague memories of eating there before I lived in SF and I'd had their takeout at a friend's house before. I don't remember being blown away by it, but I don't remember hating it either. Then again, I'm from Socal, so Mexican food is one category in which SF tends to let me down.

Fast forward to last night. We get there and, though the wait was somewhat long, the staff was so friendly and attentive that it wasn't a bother at all. 

I ordered the soyrizo burrito (not particularly adventurous, but it's what I was in the mood for). It was just okay, not any better or worse than what I might make at home using store-bought soyrizo. I wasn't unhappy with my meal, but I wasn't impressed. I'd rate it 3 stars on its own. 

My girlfriend's burrito was a different story. She orded the lime-seasoned prawn burrito, but the seasoning was so bland that she actually thought they'd given her the wrong burrito! I asked the (very polite and attentive) waitress if perhaps they'd prepared her the shrimp burrito with the butter-wine sauce by mistake, but it turns out it was the right burrito, just not a very good one.*

The other problem, besides flavor, was the number of prawns. This was an $11 burrito that had 4 smallish prawns in it. I don't expect it to be loaded up like a shrimp burrito, but I eat a lot of Mexican food and I know what $11 should buy me. I am not a diner with a sense of entitlement, I just don't want to feel ripped off. 4 tiny prawns just isn't gonna cut it in a huge burrito. It was basically a beans, rice and cheese burrito w/ a cameo appearance by some prawns.

The biggest surprise though, was the salsa. Papalote is renowned for their salsa. So I found it surprising that a Mexican place famous for its salsa DOESN'T GIVE YOU ANY SALSA WITH YOUR FOOD.... YOU HAVE TO BUY IT. **

I am, as my obnoxious use of capital letters might indicate, dead serious: Salsa with your chips is free, but you have to pay to have salsa with your food. 

You get a small (maybe 2 oz) cup of salsa with your chips. The place is popular, so you wait with that basket of chips for quite a while before your food comes. When your food arrives, it does not come with salsa. As it turns out, if you want salsa with your food you have two choices:

(1) Eat your chips without salsa, so you can save the salsa for your food. C'mon son. This might not be objectively unreasonable, but it's unreasonable in light of custom: what Mexican restaurant expects you to eat chips without salsa?

(2) Purchase more salsa to go with your food, at the rate of $0.50 per small cup.

Admittedly, $0.50 is not a big deal, but the idea that the only way to enjoy salsa with your food at this Mexican restaurant is to either pay extra or eat your chips without salsa just reeks of, dare I say it, arrogance. It's like they're so gassed up over people telling them how dope their salsa is that they think they're doing us a favor by letting us eat there. 

I get it. You're world-famous for your salsa. You sell the salsa separately in a jar. People would probably consume insane amounts of the salsa if you didn't regulate it somehow.... but is it going to kill you to give me one cup of salsa with my chips and one cup of salsa with my food? I mean, seriously, that just comes off as really, really cheap. I purchase a $30 fast-Mexican meal for two and have to pay extra to get the salsa? How is that cost not built into my $10 burrito?? 

This is the kind of disregard for customer perspective that causes once-great businesses to fail. Not saying I see Papalote failing anytime soon, but it was a *huge* turnoff for me and I probably won't eat there again because of that last straw. Two people can eat at Rubio's (which actually has very good food for fast-Mexican), spend $20 and enjoy several cups of their delicious salsas or free! The mind boggles.

Also, the salsa is tasty, but not something I would have thought to rave about if Papalote wasn't already well-hyped for its salsa. Despite really wanting to love my dining experience at Papalote, I walked away not understanding what the fuss is about. So disappointed.

______________

* I love my girlfriend, but I'm not the type to give a place a shitty review just because she had a bad experience (see my review of Sushi Raw if you have any doubts). That being said, her burrito was so skimpy on prawns that I was disappointed just *watching* her eat it. It was like watching someone pick the wrong door on a game show over and over again: bite after bite with not a prawn in sight.

** I KNOW!!
author: Jay S.

description:
just went here for take-out friday night.  super popular place, but i'm personally not sure why.  i guess i like greasy taqueria style mexican food, while is on the healthier side.  no lard in the vegan(!) refried beans, no carnitas = sad aimee :(

good agua fresca and chips and salsa.

waited about 20 min for 2 burritos, which kinda sucked.
author: Aimee B.

description: This place is tasty! I'm not even a vegetarian and I love their soyrizo! Can take a while so plan ahead - or call ahead.
author: Mary W.

description:
5 stars for grilled veggies in my shrimp burrito and the charbroiled taste of the carne asada

-1 star for store bought chips

-1 star for powder made horchata

-1 star for unhappy, low energy staff who shrug their shoulders when you ask about your order 30 min. after you place it or reply 'i guess' when you ask for a cup of ice to go with your $3 soda

-1 for yelling 'HEY HEY HEY' when we stepped right outside the door with your plastic cup of ice b/c it was too darn hot to wait inside

+1 for the sauce you provide with the chips

2 stars, but I'll happily spend my $8 at a taqueria with the same quality of food, but less attitude.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Papalote rules the Mission burrito scene. Fresh, healthy, authentic and reasonably priced.  No lard, no hipster BS.  The salsa is the key.  Smooth and spicy with lots of different flavors.

 Bobby Flay is still hurting from the butt whipping the Escovebo brothers gave him on TV.
author: Gregory L.

description:
Prawn burrito  w/ black beans was AWESOME. Definitely order it "super."

Order extra salsa for sure...it has a smoked kick to it that makes it's very tasty!

I'm excited to try some of their other burritos & have heard the mole is killer.
author: Mel A.

description: Papalote is one of my favorites for Mexican food.  The ingredients are super fresh and the service is fast.  I think their salsa is really good - it's kind of creamy and a little smokey. I wish it were a little spicier (I'm only referring to the salsa they give you when your order your food to go).  Next time, I'm going to look through the salsas they sell.  I think they have a habanero one that is supposed to be pretty good!
author: Nadia S.

description:
Wednesday, 8:45PM.

To enter Mission's Mexican food market, folks best be bringing their A-game or find some way to distinguish themselves from the competition. 

Papalote does both and is establishing a spicy niche in the area. 

Stuffed our faces in:
1. Soyrizo
     +Spicy, chunky soy pieces won over this omnivore
2. Mole, tofu taco
     +Cocoa pepper and chili concoction goes great with the hard shell
3. Triple threat
     +Chicken? Carne asada? Shrimp? Dig the combo man!
     - Only four prawns? Put a little more than that, c'mon now!
4. Salsa
     +Spicy kick without overwhelming the rest of the mix
     - Staff is stingy with this goodness

And then...?
The Triple Threat wasn't enough for my raging hunger, which is a testament to me being a PHATTTTY. Still paying a return visit though, I've got the seafood burritos and nachos to try!
author: Chuck N.

description:
Somebody call 911 because I just murdered the chicken adobo burrito at Papalote. 

Seriously, I love the idea of putting chicken adobo into a burrito. Effing genius. 

The chicken was so damn tender and the adobo flavor was present but not overpowering. The whole time I was eating it, I felt confused. Tastes like Filipino food yet tastes like Mexican food. Either way, I ate the whole damn thing. 

The horchata was good but I prefer a little more cinnamon in mines. I love that they have soyrizo and tofu as meat options. 

Papalote was definitely worth the journey from Oakland. I just hop on BART and walk a few blocks and I'm in the Mission. I don't venture out here much, but I'd make the trip for Papalote again.

P.S. If you have room, Anthony's Cookies is a couple blocks away.

P.P.S. Their chips are not that great. Best tortilla chips in SF? Velvet Cantina. No question about it.
author: Joshua C.

description:
This place is great, friendly staff and delicious food. The super shrimp burritos are amazing. Nice spot for dine in but I usually phone ahead for my to go order, it's quick and easy.
Best Salsa ever!
Taking a  star off as my bf got sick last time we got take away from there.
author: Claire R.

description:
i dont know if i can call this place traditional mexican food, but their food is still pretty darn good!

their orange sauce or creamy salsa they have for the chips was delicious! my friend brought me here today and she kept telling me to save the sauce for the burrito. i will do that next time! haha. they also have interesting drinks too.. they have this non alcholic mint mojito energy drink thats really good! they have a good selection of bottled drinks that im addicted to!

nice people and good food... see you guys next time!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Papalote's has been on my list of places to try not just because it was recently on Throwdown with Bobby Flay but because Kat C. has been raving about this place.

Hot damn that salsa is good.  So good I bought a jar to bring home to the bf (big ol' jar for less than  $5!). It's creamy, thick, and not too spicy - what do they put in that stuff!?!

I decided to go with the prawn burrito and I'm so glad that I did.  The prawns were so flavorful and delicious.. I was craving some more after I had finished off my burrito.  My only problemo with my meal was that I felt like there could have been more stuffing in the burrito.  I kept taking bite fulls of folded tortilla on one of the sides because there was nothing inside!  Sad day...

Papalote's is a bit pricey but it was a nice treat.  I'd come back - sparingly though.
author: Kim-van T.

description:
Oh man it was warm last night even at 9PM in the Mission, but inside Papalote it was about 100°F. I don't know how the people were eating in the dining room. There were boxes of produce by the door and the poor bell peppers were suffering too.  I ordered a regular chicken mole burrito and since I don't like pico de gallo, I asked if there was another salsa they could put into the burrito but they did not offer to put the orange salsa in :(.  

And then I waited....and waited...it took 20-25 minutes to finally get my burrito.

The verdict? The burrito was pretty good and so was the orange salsa that comes w/ the side of chips. But for the above average price and the long wait, I'd try other tacquerias in the area before venturing back to Papalote. They could use a new location w/ a larger kitchen to help the orders go through more quickly, and so the cooks aren't stepping on each others' toes as much.

One last note...like buying yogurt, I like to order 2-3 tacos each w/ different meats, but they only come in pairs here.
author: Patrick H.

description:
The good: Their salsa is pretty good, although it seems to have lost some of its fire lately, and their chicken mole is delicious.  The veggie burritos are also pretty tasty.  The portions are quite large and a burrito will easily make two meals.  You can call ahead and order food to-go and avoid the ridiculous line that often develops. 

The bad: I think the food is overpriced, especially given the volume of sales and the fact that their service can be mediocre.  But, they keep a line out the door so the market seems to say otherwise.  I've had orders messed up repeatedly -- from getting the wrong dish entirely to minor things like missing salsa or not getting a whole wheat tortilla -- especially when I order to-go.

The bottom line: Worth checking out, but not my go-to taqueria.
author: Steve B.

description: My roommate brought me here after ranting and raving about it for a while and after all that hype I was a little disappointed. I ended up having a carne asada burrito.  It was good, but definitely not the best I've ever had. It just lacked a lot of flavor and authenticity, in my opinion. I thought it was just okay (aside from the salsa, the salsa was excellent).  It gets pretty crowded here, since the place is so small. Its cute though and they play good music, so I guess thats a plus. I'll come back again soon and if I have a better experience I'll update my review, but other than that, I think I'll stick to the hole in the wall burrito spots that are better priced and have tastier food.
author: Cat M.

description: My favorite Mexican restaurant to date!  The tacos, burritos and quesadillas are amazing not to mention their signature salsa!  I use their salsa on everything now, from eggs at breakfast to steaks at dinner, it's amazing.  You can buy fresh made salsa from them while your their but if you can't make it to the city, The Nugget sells their salsa too.
author: Phil H.

description:
I sifted through a bunch of hipster reviews during my SF research and noticed consistent high ratings for Papalote, adding it to my list of Mission Musts. After a rousing show at the Make-Out Room, my beau and I decided to grab a bite in the vicinity. And since it was dark, finding the San Buena Taco Truck was out of the question. So we booked it to Papalote and earned a spot as the last lucky party to score a table in the small dining area. A staff member brought us each our own handful of chips in two bowls, along with little containers of orange, creamy, spicy salsa--quite different from the tomato chunks I'm used to. 

I ordered a prawn burrito, making it a super for only 99 cents. I appreciated the tortilla choices (spinach, flour, whole wheat and Roma tomato), opting for the spinach, as well as the bean options (pinto, refried and black). I chose pinto, of course. 

I mean, the burrito was okay but not worth $10. The prawns, generously doled and flavorfully grilled, added a unique texture to the sour cream, guac and cheese. 

The atmosphere set Papalote apart. The artwork, a fuse between Picasso and Rivera, adorned the bright red walls. Flying frogs and dragons kept watch from the ceiling. The arched entryway between the ordering and dining area added architectural pizazz. Plus, the bathroom, covered in blue paint and graffiti, reminded me of a catwalk per its long, narrow shape and mirror in front of the commode above the sink. 

Because of the shrimp and tilapia filling options and unique decor, Papalote rises just a step above chains like Willy's.
author: Bobbin W.

description: Wicked burrito. Definitely met my expectations. Would like to come back and sample other items from the menu. I don't live in SF and am far from a burrito guru, but was quite pleased with my selection.
author: Katie E.

description:
I have been to both Papalote locations, on Fulton and in the Mission. Both are great. They are well known for their salsa, which is REALLY good. The salsa is what makes Papalote really special. Like most other Mexican restaurants in the Mission, you get chips and salsa with your food. So while chips and salsa are just a plus to the burritos normally, I personally think the salsa is just as awesome and special as the burrito. 

Onto the burritos... They have more veggie options than other Mexican places. I have had a regular veggie burrito, with potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots. It was really good, but I do wish there had been more mushrooms in there. The potatoes and carrots had been cooked nice and soft but not mushy and seasoned well. I also tried the soyrizo which was also awesome. 

If you want some guacamole, sour cream,, and cheese in your burrito, you got to pay an extra 99 cents to get it super. The burritos here are a little pricier than other places in the Mission (around $6.50 -$9 for a burrito) and they are not as big either... BUT they are delicious...
author: Angela T.

description:
Best Carne Asada in the Mission.  You basically get a steak in your burrito.  Amazing salsa.  Really high quality, fresh ingredients.

I think just loses out to Pancho Villa for best burrito in the Mission, but it's really close.  You can't go wrong here.
author: Quags M.

description:
My boyfriend's friend called me Skeletor the other day. Although I loved 80s cartoons, I'm a chick so He-Man is pretty much out of my reference zone. But I get it. I'm skinny. Scrawny. Gangly. It comes with the territory and there's very little I can do. 

Except, of course, for setting up camp at Papalote. I've been exactly twice - once after a hard workout in the pool, and once after a long night of boozing that ended with a straight male friend kissing a guy at the Mint. Both times I was starving, my body shaking from the lack of sustenance, and their food delivered. 

Between the complimentary chips and bomb salsa and the big ass super pollo burrito, I probably packed on a good five pounds that I had lost the night/workout before. I'm rather impatient (great trait for a teacher, right?) and waiting twenty minutes for a burrito is never fun, but I dig that they grill the meat to order rather than just scooping up a mound of lukewarm chicken from a serving tray. It's the sort of taqueria that I know I'll be returning to time and time again - and probably when my body REALLY doesn't need the calories. 

With Papalote, I can continue the transition from an awkward hungry baby giraffe to a jolly chubby bunny. Something tells me that I'm gonna hate being called Ms. Staypuft Marshmallow just as much as Skeletor, though.
author: Devon S.

description: I am in love with their salsa. I cannot get enough. I had to buy their bottled salsa to go to indulge my cravings at home.  Their burritos and quesadillas are also yummy.
author: Natalie S.

description: i am so addicted to the grilled chicken super burritos and grilled chicken nachos.  i came here a couple of months ago and going back last night brought back all the taste bud memory.  SO DELICIOUS!  the super is an additional 99 cents which includes sour cream and guacamole.  the boyfriend and i usually share one burrito and can tackle half of the nachos and leave completely full.  i think my favorite is the chipotle salsa.  it starts off sweet and then as it sits in your mouth you start to feel a slow burn and your taste buds go wild with yummy taste.  i basically pour it over everything!!!  all of their burrito has fresh ingredients and the food comes out hot and well prepared.  this is definitely a quick in and out joint so don't freak out if the second you twitch to get up and leave that someone is right behind you swooping in to take your seat.  they always have a full restaurant!
author: Sandy L.

description:
So this is one of those rare reviews that was held back until I had returned 5-10x for further research.  Here are my findings:

+1 for the delish salsa they bring while you wait at a table
+1 for the giant, tasty fish tacos.  They're all I ever get.
+1 for being pretty affordable
+1 for not being greasy like all the other burrito joints around here.
-2 for the crowds.  Sometimes you have to hover over (i.e. sit on)  people who are half-finished with their meal to ensure you get a table when your food is ready.  If you don't sit on them, someone else will.
+1 for having strangers sit on your lap while you eat your food.

Now I know what you're thinking:
"But Mari C, that math jus' don't add up... you gave em five stars but looks like they should only get three.  How does that work?"

Well you see, I have an art degree, not a math one.  It's open for interpretation.
author: Mari C.

description:
Ok, I understand why this place was packed last night due to their debut with Bobby Flay throwdown being aired that night via the food net work, that my friend decided to have a cute gathering at her place and order their burrito (not the Triple Threat Burrito that was the challenge!) but a burrito none the less. We ordered to go and waited 25 terrible cold minutes outside waiting for our food (hence one star less) but in fairness I loved their salsa (me being a salsa man myself) enjoyed their burritos.
Sorry Bobby Flay but the 2 brothers had this one!
author: Marco R.

description:
Ok, we need to get a few things straight.  Papalote won all those Best Salsa/Best Upscale Tacqueria/Best Burrito awards for a reason.  Some of these reviews have it ass backwards - it's not made for the masses, it's just that the masses have spoken, and the verdict is DELICIOUS.  There's always a line out the door for a reason.

I just moved away from SF, and this is one of the spots I am missing the most. It's not "white people food", ffs, it's just not the most authentic Mexican in the area....but so what?  It's not like you can't score that if you really want it - but you come here for a reason, and that reason is the bomb-ass burritos.

And they are far from "flavorless", trust me.  The cheese is good, the fresh salsa adds nice saltiness and acidity, the beans are tasty and the meat is cooked to order.  Quite simply, they are just awesome burritos.  *Awesome*.

Not to mention the customary free chips and salsa, and to reiterate what everyone else already said - it's almost worth visiting just for the salsa (which does have plenty of kick, contrary to someone's bogus assertion that it's lacking...if you really want *any* Mexican food to be spicy, you have to add hot sauce, so that is kind of irrelevant anyways).

*Note:  the salsa does not, I repeat NOT taste anything like "liquid Doritos".  Good God.  The unique consistency in the "orange sauce" salsas in California are due to the addition of sour cream.

I'd usually be a bit more judicious with the stars and give this 4, but the service is always friendly and they never messed up an order in 2 years of constant high-volume take out.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Ladies. Gentlemen. I have been defeated.

In one corner you've got B: A vertically challenged underweight, but with years of burrito-eating experience.

In the other corner you've got Papalote: A Mexican grill that packs an unassumingly heavy punch.

This was the talk of the group for my San Fran veteran friends*. Luckily, I have a really smart morning routine: I oversleep, shower eventually, and drink my breakfast in the form of coffee. So by the time Papalote rolled around, Papa was storving!

I went for a classic grilled chicken burrito. Did I make it SUPER for $0.99 and add sour cream, cheese, and guacamole inside? DUH. As if that was even a legitimate question.

But first they give everyone their own bowl of chips and salsa. Because everyone is obsessed with the salsa, I'm just going to reiterate the fanatic declarations and agree: It is probably the best salsa I've had yet. I wanted to pick-pocket it and douse a little on all of my meals. 

Then, the burrito the size of my torso was set in front of me. My eyes said, "YES. YES. YES. GO!" Halfway through my stomach said, "Boo, you've got to give it a rest." 

I got about 3/4ths of the way finished with the appearance of my coaches--fork and knife--but not even they could help me with the big win.

Yet it has never felt so good to lose. 
__________

* I was a newbie. But I really did leave my heart in San Francisco . . . My appetite too.
author: Brett W.

description:
This place was pretty delicious.  The Salsa alone is amazing, something really tasty.  But beware, it is diff than traditional salsa in my opinion.  

The burritos were reallly good, perfect size and they had a nice toasted crunch to them.  The steak was reallly good, but a little large (pieces).  Lack of guac is what kept me from giving them 5 stars, i need to ask for extra.  ALso it seemed a little light on the sour cream.  but overall a MUST TRY.
author: Shawn A.

description:
This is a review for the "secret" adobo chicken burrito. I agree with other Filipinos who grew up on chix adobo (and otherwise) that this specialty burrito us tasty and passable, but it needs a little help from Lolo to bring the magic. The burrito is served with chicken adobo, rice and tomato and you can even get beans or make it "super." The chix adobo itself is tender and has just enough tangy Filipino (not Mexican!) adobo flavor. However, one vital component that is a bit weak is garlic. As everyone says a garlic rice is mighty tasty with chix adobo... As well you could throw in some caramelized onion. Perhaps, they could lightly paint a hot, garlic oil on the inside of the tortilla? A previous reviewer substituted a garden tomato tortilla with this burrito and that hit the spot.

Overall this spot still gets 4 stars any day of the week. They're the "healthful" taqueria which means no mystery meat, inventive plates and fresh, fresh, fresh food--even if it's infrequently in the face of authenticity. This is now my first choice taqueria--even to take the out of towners. Papalote is now a San Francisco tradition!
author: E L.

description:
mmmmMMMMmmMMmmM

I dont think I can ask for anything more in a burrito, and the dip that comes with the tortilla chips is awesome. What makes this place stand out to me is the nice staff there. The burrito you get is quite large, but if you have a large appetite like myself than you are in good hands. Go for the upgrade and grab yourself some sour cream and guac, its only .99 more. Not much space inside but enough to do your thaaaang. eat it n believe it.
author: Vamsee K.

description: $16 dollars for 2 steak tacos?????I think absolutely not. I could of gotten 2 huge burritos. Nothing even remotely spectacular about this place. Ive definitely had better right up the street. I am a SF native. You can't fool me. It was a regular taco. The Food Network did me dirty on this one.
author: Sophie P.

description: This is by far my favorite mexican food place in the bay! I love the tofu mole burrito and of course, the fresh salsa is glorious! Great for vegetarians and vegans.
author: Regine M.

description: This place is busy but there's a high turnover rate.  When we ordered the food, we didn't have any seats but by the time we got it, we were seated promptly.  My friend and I both got the burritos, which are huge.  I got the grilled prawns with a spinach tortilla.  It  was good when I ate it but now that I'm thinking back on it, there was way too much rice and not enough prawns.  I was expecting a prawn in every bite but that big burrito was filled with other stuff. The insides were not evenly separated either because I ended up eating a ton of rice in the beginning and then all the wet ingredients at the tailend.  I was expecting the grilled prawn burrito to be like the shrimp burrito at Chronic Tacos, which is BOMB.  Alas, that burrito cannot be replicated.
author: Tori Q.

description:
Two things to note: This place has DELICIOUS fish burritos and phone in because the wait can be super long. 

Papalote is great high quality mexican food.  You can have your carne asada, chicken, and whatever other type of burrito. I love my fish burritos. And this place has them. They have the most delicious fish burritos I've had in a while, this is the place. Other places in the mission won't serve fish. 

While I myself love this place for the fish burritos, they have a wide selection of other delicious goods. The chips and salsa are pretty good.

Beware the wait. You can wait anywhere from 5 minutes to 45 minutes (dead serious, 45 minutes for a burrito is not acceptable) but I assumed that was a strange night.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Ok 2nd attempt at Triple Threat.  I now understand why they call it a Triple Threat.

Threat Numero Uno: It's a huge threat to your taste buds.  An assault of horrible flavors!

Threat Numero Dos: It's a threat to your wallet.  A whopping $20 for a 8 inch burrito you easily pay half for elsewhere with better quality.

Threat Numero Tres: It's a threat to your anus.  After ingesting one, the burrito is described the same exact way coming out....
author: Thien T.

description:
Had lunch with a friend visiting from the UK, who was continuing on to NYC after SF.  Given the Bobby Flay Throwdown, we decided to have lunch here. Had to walk by it a couple times, as there's no signage. Look for blue tiles. We ordered a Champion Burrito with black beans, guac, salsa, sour cream for each of us. My friend got a Negra Modelo and I got a water =$52 before tip.

The burrito was hugh, could easily feed 2-3 people, and it was loaded (e.g., packed full) with grilled beef, grilled chicken, & large grilled prawns. I loved their roasted tomato salsa, and really liked that the burrito wasn't filled with rice & beans like other places do. It was good, but nothing amazing. The meat, chicken, & fish wasn't seasoned, just grilled. The Champion Burrito would be a goner w/o the salsa.

We got there about 1:30p and the restaurant was full - and this place is tiny(!). You eat elbow-to-elbow with the next table, tables lined up next to one another. Pulling your chair out means bumping the people behind you. If you've got long legs or are a big person, good luck. The staff move things along fast b/c people are waiting to be seated. You're still eating and are asked if you'd like foil to take your food with you.

I can say that I've tried Papalote's - and am over it. Too expensive, okay food, and a really uncomfortable place to eat (on a several levels). If Bobby Flay couldn't beat this burrito in a Throwdown, there's no hope.
author: SFer O.

description:
I've tried most Mexican spots in the Mission, but had never tried this one, let alone even heard of the joint!!!  If I had to sum it up, I'd call it "healthy Mexican food in the Mission"....which is rare.

I had the pollo super burrito which was delicious but not very filling.  It also felt clean and healthy, as opposed to the typical sloppy style I like at my usual Mexican watering holes (El Farolito, Taqueria Cancun and Taqueria Vallarta....yum yum!!!!!)  They also offer multiple tortilla choices (spinach, tomato, flour or wheat) which I loved.

The salsa was awesome!  Definitely unique, like a variation of Pakistani chutney my mom makes. (Honestly, I could go back and eat the chips and salsa and be happy!)  If they bottled it, I'd buy it....unique and VERY spicy :-)....UPDATE....I guess they sell the salsa in bottles....so you CAN buy it!!!!!!!  My life is now complete....

The overall cleanliness was nice and the ambiance in general is welcoming and relaxing.  I'd go here again if I had the urge for "healthy" mexican and was in the area.  Can't eat lard-packed greasy burritos everyday...right????
author: sohail s.

description:
If anyone in Mission heard a loud asian girl squawking "I'm SO FULL!" yesterday afternoon, that was me.  And I apologize for any disturbance/annoyance I might have caused you on your peaceful Saturday. 

I was drunk off of mole.

My brother and I went, but didn't get the famed 20 dollar burrito. I was afraid a burrito that costs that much would never live up to expectations, although it is supposed to feed two.

We opted instead to get different things, so we could taste more of what Pa Pa Lo Te has to offer, and it definitely didn't disappoint.

My brother got the carne asada burrito, and the meat was thick, tender, well-seasoned, and ABUNDANT. I love a restaurant that can bowl over its customers with its portions and flavor. (Note: I think my family's stomachs are smaller when it comes to some things, so what I think is a huge portion may be normal for others.)

I got the chicken mole quesadilla, and I loved the flour tortilla. It was light and crisp, with an almost translucent, shiny quality. I don't know how, but it managed to contain the mass of mole and chicken that was inside. The meat was steeped in gooey goodness and kept me well-satisfied for the rest of the day.

The roasted tomato salsa actually didn't do much for me. The heat was nice, but otherwise all I tasted was salt and a bit of garlic. Guacamole was good, but nothing supreme.  Fresh tomato salsa had a bit of jicama in it, i think, which was a very thoughtful, refreshing touch - cooled off my mouth nicely. It was fun to get the Mexican bottled Coke, which does taste different from the American stuff.

Service was quick, polite and friendly.  The staff kept the small dining area clean and tidy.

All in all a delicious experience, though since I don't live in the area, I'll probably be trying out all of the surrounding taquerias. 

Suggestions, anyone?
author: Lucia C.

description:
Soyrizo burrito = best burrito I have ever had.  Mmmm.

Papalote's number is saved in my phone.
author: Anna S.

description: I absolutely love their soyrizo burrito! They have the best chips and salsa in the city! I did try their adobo burrito and it was a tad bit too salty for my liking, but other than that, I don't have any complaints about this place AT ALL!
author: Fallon P.

description:
AWESOME food.  I've had the carne asada super tacos, carne asada super burrito and the nachos.  All great.  Orchata isn't half bad--I've had it on multiple occassions.  The water melon drink is a little watery so I wouldn't recommend that.  The salsa is probably the best thing here.  Do yourself a favor and just purchase a jar of salsa.  The first time it's 6 bucks but bring back the jar and it'll be 5 bucks :)  Good to reuse.  

As for service, don't expect 5 star service with smile.  There's a lot of traffic in this little place so they work fast and do what they need to do.  The food is good so I don't mind the sass.  

Tip for those of you that like to order to go, please call ahead and plan to get there in 15 minutes otherwise you'll be waiting FOREVER.
author: Karen N.

description: Their orange sauce is the ingredient to a winning meal.  For under ten bucks this is an outstanding meal, the burritos can just barely be finished, and dousing that bad boy with some of the orange sauce makes it all the more memorable.  I also like the chips they serve with each order, and the service has been really friendly and accommodating every time I've been.
author: Kunal K.

description:
3.5 stars, but I'm rounding up for this baby because it was still quite tasty.  After spending 3 days in San Fran and hearing about how Cali's mexican was SO much better than anything you can find in the east coast, I was craving a burrito BIG TIME.  Specifically, one from the mission.  We were recommended to come here to Papalote Mexican Grill.  

I ordered the Carne Asada burrito with black beans, guac, salsa - the works.  We sat down in the dining area and they came out with chips and salsa for each of us.  The salsa was awesome and hot hot HOT - I started getting really excited about this burrito.  It came out, nicely on a plate.  I picked it up and sunk my teeth in for my first bite.  GOO-OOOD = 4 stars, but where are rest of the rice & beans, guac, sour cream?  I only got to taste some meat, lettuce, and a little rice, beans..  I soon found out where they were.. all at the bottom-end of my burrito, thus giving me a soggy bottom and tearing my burrito apart at the end :(  That's why I took half a star away, for my soggy bottom.  Rather than that, it was a solid tasting burrito!

I asked my brother (local in SF) what he thought.  He said that he prefers the burritos that you get from the trucks in the mission better, but this place was good.  All in all, I was happy with this burrito, but as the best I've had?  I can't honestly give you that.  I'm sure there are better burrito places in SF, I just haven't had time to take a whirl-wind tour of burritos in SF.. next time...
author: Thu V.

description:
On our weekend in the city, my friend Tron said we had to eat here. He said it was on the food network, I was in.

We waited 30 min for it to open, and to my surprise they did not serve Carnitas! Pork is a staple of mine, so I switched to the carne asada burrito.

The food was delicious, but what I really liked about the place was that you could get the 99 cent upgrade which loads the burrito with Guac, sour cream, and cheese. I have paid over two dollars for avocado at other places before.

The orange salsa was the other wild card - it was unique with a lot of different levels of flavors. Other early birds there were coming in just to buy orders of the salsa - check it out!
author: Mike H.

description:
First off, let me just say that the "salsa," or whatever their creamy hot sauce is called, was AMAZING.  It was spicy, creamy and loaded with flavor.  I damn near ate my whole basket of chips to get to the last drop of that sauce.  :-)

Second, while I DO eat meat, I was a vegetarian for 10 years.  That inspired me to try the soyrizo burrito (with cheese and grilled mushrooms).  I have one word for you..  DAMN.  That was THE best non-meat burrito I've ever had and I love Pancho Villa's tofu.

My girlfriend had a carne asada and grilled shrimp burrito which she devoured (all 100 pounds of her).  Needless to say, she enjoyed hers, too.

We met the owner, Miguel,  who also gave us a sample of his chicken adobo (over rice), which is a burrito meat option (and quite popular, I hear).  While I thought that to be somehow wrong, I have to admit that the adobo was absolutely delicious.   It was SO tender.

The eating area is small but the tables do clear quickly.  And while their prices may be on the high side, I'm definitely one who believes in getting what you pay for... and we certainly did.

Miguel, thank you for your hospitality.  You'll definitely be seeing me again.

P.S.  My 9-year old son proclaims Papalote to be his favorite  - and he's eaten a quite a few burritos, living in South City.  :-)
author: erica c.

description:
OK, so like really good mexican food. Its a little different than the traditional mexican that I was expecting. Its sort of like Cali-mex...really fresh ingredients, not super heavy, oh yeah...and muthafuckin soyrizo on the menu. Nice.

Whoop ass salsa fo' shizzle. They thankfully don't hold back too much on the hotness here...I'm a big fan, but this could peeve some. 

The place is flirting with 5 stars, but there is a wicked wait, pretty indifferent help, and seating is pretty much impossible. Be prepared to hover, pounce, and cry if needed to get a seat for your and your peeps. If you plan on going here with more than 4 people, you better not plan on staying if you arrive anywhere near a meal time. Some day, I'll head there when I'm wasted and try to turn it into a pickup scene. "Hey baby, want to nosh on my salsa?"...I predict 50% smack ratio.

Next time, I'm trying the Mari C. endorsed fish taco.
author: Sean C.

description: The Prawns are bomb, but service is terrible!!!!  Would it kill you to smile and pretend like you're happy to be at work?
author: M G.

description:
Dear Soyrizo burrito w/ refried black beans, 
I love you. I miss you. Thank goodness you haven't changed.  You are my favorite burrito in town. 

Satisfied my craving for this ol' fave when visiting last week.  It lived up to memory, as the did the famous secret-recipe orange-colored salsa.  Nom nom nom.  Yes they charge for extra servings of it, but I think it's worth it.  Prawn burritos & tacos are good too, but my heart belongs to the soyrizo burrito - seriously one of the best vegetarian items in San Francisco.

Chips are just ok & the 3 small chunks of jicama on the plate are just silly.

Papalote is quick, not too pricey & very tasty.  A no-fuss modern (not traditional) taqueria.

p.s. the reverse engineered Ersatz Papalote Salsa recipe on http://www.chow.com/recipes/10646 is yummy, but still fails at recreating the original.  I make it & enjoy it, but just don't compare it to the housemade anymore
author: Kimberly C.

description:
FIRE ASS BURRITOS. THE SALSA IS ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE. BEST I'VE EVER HAD. 

3 vegan options!!! really unique and delicious.
author: Samantha S.

description:
!SALSA! Yep, it's so good, it's incased in exclamation points! I've only had the carne asada burrito here and it's really good too. I'm sure anything else is good too and if it's not just pour !SALSA! all over it.

I bought a jar of their !SALSA! and took it to a little gathering I went to. I should of bought two more jars. It was gone in about ten minutes. 

oh ya...

!SALSA!
author: Wes K.

description:
As a vegetarian, good Mexican food is few and far between.  Papalote is a GREAT exception.  They have several delicious vegetarian options that are all amazing from grilled veggies to soyrizo meat substitutions.  

They also have plenty of real meat options if you are with a group of meat-eaters.  

They charge for extra salsa which is annoying but their house salsa is one of the best I've every had.
author: Phillip K.

description: I live next to Papalote and really wanted to like it. Tried several times over several years before writing this after one last attempt tonight. Their food is terrible - just really bland and stale. Even their over-hyped salsa is simply not tasty. With so many great authentic Mexican places around the Mission, it's really sad that so many people are not taking risks and staying with Papalote. As a long time resident of the Mission - trust me you can do better!
author: Mandy R.

description: Just...just awful. Where to start? The prices are crazy, the "salsa" tastes like spicy marinara, the tacos are more like a salad sitting on a tortilla, the shrimp are charred and dry. It's just bad. Really, really bad. How is this place so well reviewed? I blame the transplants. Yes, this is probably better than the Mexican food you have in Wisconsin. However, it's absolute crap compared to actual Mexican food. For god's sake, run screaming from this place.
author: Nick G.

description:
3 stars for....

1. Their secret house sauce/salsa that was so delicious I probably would've drank it if no one was looking.

2. Extremely friendly service and putting up with customers that I would punch in the nose if they talked to me like that.

3. The extra sides of pico de gallo for the free nachos.

BUT... 

-2 stars for..

1. A horrific meal. =( The carne asada was burnt. Not just bits and pieces, but the whole slab they threw into it. I could taste the residue from their grill, and every bite I took was crunchy from the meat. On the other hand, I've never had a crunchy burrito? It was very.... Different? Good thing they stocked us up pretty well on the house sauce because I used that stuff to drown out the taste of the burnt meat.

Did not enjoy my food at all, but this place still deserves 3 stars. I'll probably give it another go, but maybe consider a vegetarian burrito next time?

3 stars, and maybe a follow up review. =)
author: Charmaine A.

description:
After six years in Phoenix, it's a relief to find all the wonderful taquerias in the Mission.  I had the shrimp burrito with black beans, peppers and rice. It was very good. 

Pros:
Good Portions
Fast Take Out
Take Credit Cards

Cons
The only salsa option is Pico
Chips were a little stale
No dessert options
author: Marissa P.

description: Seating is a bit tight, and pricing is a bit high, but the food is delicious!  Yummy!  I hear it's organic too.  I ordered the super veggie burrito.  They have this really yummy vegan salsa.  I'm addicted to it!  Bought some to take home with me yesterday.
author: A T.

description:
My friend Irv kept bragging about this great Mexican restaurant near Hayes Valley and I found Papalote on Masonic and Fulton thinking it's the same place but decided to try the mission restaurant instead, still with me? there's a point to this.

I drag my friend Gil to Papalote to check this place out, it's a bit out of the way for me (Civic Center) and him (16th st) especially with plenty of good Taquerias around. We stood in a short line, ordered our food and waited at a table for two. We were given two bowls of warm tortilla chips and a very creamy and spicy sauce to dip them in. I liked it because it wasn't the typical "Pico de gallo" and it did have some kick but not enough so people that fear spice would cry like little babies.

Our meals were brought to us, I ordered the Chile Verde Burrito and Gil had the chile verde quesadilla. I have to say, the burrito was pretty good, was not bland, actual big pieces of pork in the burrito and there was that "creaminess" in the burrito that I tasted in the hot sauce. The only comment that Gil and I both had was we couldn't tell this was Chile verde. 

Would I come back? Yeah, if I was in the neighborhood.

So back to why I came to this place, I sent a text to my friend Irv and said, "I'm at Papalote, it's pretty good" he txts back with "Where?" Thinking he's having a senior moment, I explain it's the place he's been going on and on about. He replied, "That's Nopalito on Buchanan". DOH! I was at the wrong restaurant!!! So we had a good meal and a good laugh at my expense amongst friends!
author: David P.

description: Service was pretty slow. Prices are oh-kay. But, as Oleg H. said, "DAT SAUCE!" 4 stars. Carne asada and pork were yummy. Would come back if we were eating in. Wouldn't get take-out - though the burritos held well on the plane :) Would order jars of that sauce to Brooklyn.
author: Fede O.

description:
A little pricey but the burrito is big enough to share with your girl.

Carne asada is great and the salsa goes perfect with it.  Pretty good burrito.  

Wish they gave more salsa and you didn't have to pay so much for so little.  Oh well, c'est la vie.
author: Mark K.

description:
Amazing carne asada, sooooo frickin good!  Wow!
Too bad they charge 55 cents for salsa, wtf?
author: Chaz N.

description:
The wife and I went here after watching Throwdown With Bobby Flay. Delighted to find that it was a cute, cozy place and not at all pretentious. All food was moderately priced, but extraordinarily delicious. I had the triple threat burrito -- had to after the feature on TV. A massive MexAm masterpiece with carne asada steak, chicken and jumbo prawns. 

The best part is their secret Papalote salsa. It was all in the triple threat. But, I was surprised to see them selling it by the jar. YOU MUST BUY YOURSELF A JAR BEFORE LEAVING THIS PLACE. You will scoff at other salsas once you try it.
author: Francisco H S.

description:
