I had to check out Papalote because I saw them on Bobby Flay's throwdown. I ordered the Prawn, chicken adobo, and carne asada burritos for my family. Me and my family members all agreed they were dry - rice and meat.. The burritos were ok, but I've definitely had better, like Castillo's (civil center). Disappointed and not worth the $8 - $10 for each burrito. You can definitely do better elsewhere. 
However, I will say the salsa was very  good.

Sorry Papalote. Overpriced and over-rated.
author: Les Y.

description: Liked this little place alot! I had the marinated tofu burrito w/ guacamole and sour cream. Super veggie friendly. They have SOYRIZO here! OMG! :) Prices are good and getting a table isn't too hard. People come in and out pretty quickly. Service is fast, you order, sit down, and bam w/ minutes they bring your food to your table. The salsa and chips are yummy. Definitely would come back and try the other veggie dishes.
author: Irene L.

description:
Fabulous Mexican food with one of the best, most memorable house salsas I've ever had!  Great selection of meat/veggie/fake-meat to add to your burrito.  

Place is small - don't be deterred by the line out the door!  Also, make sure to pick up a jar of their salsa, which can be found in a drink cooler to the right...mmmmm!!
author: Dori S.

description:
Salsa was really good :)

Atmosphere is busy, and it could use some A/C, once you start eating, you'll be food sweating
author: Eric A.

description: A bit less traditional than the other taqueria's in the mission, but a nice variation. I always order the chicken mole burrito and it's unique and delicious. Where else can you find mole in a burrito in the mission? The grilled veggie burrito is great too-- not overseasoned or too greasy. Gotta love free chips and salsa, and the creamy spicy salsa is delicious.
author: Will A.

description:
I was just underwhelmed by Papalote's marinated tofu.  I was assured it would be amazing.  That feels like a trick bourne of ulterior motives.  What motives?  I'm not sure.

The rest of the burrito held up the slack for the tofu.  I will not sit back and call tofu in a burrito great simply because too few places want to put it in burritos - it has to be superior tofu.  Soyrizo stands the winner of vegan protein options here for me.

Be warned, the wait for food here is longer than you'd think for a taqueria.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
We had heard so much about Papalote and it has long been on the list. 

The service was really prompt and quick and helpful . The much talked about salsa was not a disappointment .The burrito and  fajita we ordered were fresh and the guacamole was fresh and light . 

Will go there again.
author: aditi g.

description:
Dear Papalote,

I miss you.  Asada burrito, super, refried black, on a tomato tortilla. At least once a week, maybe twice a week *wink* and sometimes more. Since you opened. When Mr. E. used to work the counter. 

See, you were only a half block a way.  On my way home from work.

I am now in the land of the taco.  No more burritos for me. None will compare to you.  Although I do have people fly in your delicious salsa when visiting.

I have some in my freezer now.


With love,

Brian
author: Brian P.

description: The glowing reviews about the Soyrizo burrito and salsa are spot-on, both are just that unique and delicious.
author: James G.

description:
Ever since i became a vegetarian it has been difficult to find a good legitimate burrito place, that is until i found this place! 
It has about 4 different burrito and taco options for vegans/vegetarians (grilled veggies, or marinated tofu, or tofu with a mole sauce, or soy chorizo). Their rice and beans are vegan so you dont have to worry about whether they use chicken broth or anything like that.
And the taste of their food is really top notch, and is legitimate mexican. Its a small place and may be difficult to spot on the street, but has great taste! worth the visit!
author: Danny S.

description: Carne Asada Tacos & the Chips & Salsa! The place is very clean and not too big so it gets filled up during lunch hours pretty quick! Their menu says  "fresh & healthy... and from scratch!" You can taste the cleanliness of their ingredients from your food. Their bathroom is also very interesting!
author: Yumi H.

description:
Had a carne asada burrito there, and honestly it wasn't anything earth-shattering. In fact, I would go as far as to say that it was a little dry and the meat a little too chewy.

BUT what I will rave about is the red salsa. Its a must-try. I can see why they have literally bottled that stuff up to sell. ITS FANTASTIC. Spicy, savory and just the right amount of smokiness from the chilies. YUM. I'd come back just for a big serving of chips in salsa the next time I'm in the Mission.
author: Kyonne I.

description: Yelp's photo album for this place show's an outdated menu with burritos priced at $4.25. Don't be mislead by this photo. The actual price of a burrito is $9.19 with toppings. So, after tax expect to pay $30 for two burritos and two beers. The above average salsa does not offset the average burrito and expensive prices.
author: Graeson N.

description: I am vegetarian, mostly vegan, so I am not the best person to rate authentic/traditional Mexican food, which in my experience, is generally not vegetarian or vegan friendly.  That said, I have tried dozens of mom+pop burrito places throughout CA, and Papalote is in a league of their own, light years ahead of the rest.  Today ordered a mole tofu burrito with brown rice, refried black beans, cheese, pico de gallo and whole wheat tortilla.  The ingredients blended perfectly.  The tofu was fresh and firm.  And the mole was homey, not overpowering, a rich but thin, hearty gravy that brought everything together.  My kids love the food here, but since we never make it here before sunset, I tend to just order take out for us to eat on the drive home.  The neighborhood isn't necessarily bad, just not family friendly.  And while the staff are fantastic, in the evenings, the customers tend to be grown ups having grown up conversations over alcohol.
author: Mark X.

description:
Dinner at Papalote for Cinco de Mayo.

We ordered the famous Triple Threat Burrito ($20!) and it did not disappoint.  It was delicious, all of the meat was tender (pollo, carne asada, prawns), flavorful and perfectly seasoned - a definite highlight, and the black bleans, rice, cheese and guacamole were extremely complementary.  I thought it was kind of expensive for a burrito, but this is a must try - at least once - especially since they whooped Booby Flay's ass at his own genre on Throwdown with this burrito.

We also ordered the chips and salsa - the salsa was REALLY good, very spicy, but the chips - meh, not so much.  I like my chips thick and bursting with roasted corn flavor,  these were thin and kinda pathetic, most were broken into small pieces by the time we got home with our meal.

By the way, one of the brother/owners was in the house while we were there and the guy really cares about customer service.  It was literally a madhouse inside and he was really diligent about keeping people calm and the line moving.

Tip: Order ahead on the phone and drop by for pickup, we ordered take out in the restaurant and ended up waiting 20-30 minutes before our food was ready.  Not sure if the crowd was due to Cinco d Mayo, or if it's normally like this.  In any case, they have a separate and shorter line for phone orders.
author: Burrito M.

description: Had both the pllo and carne regular burritos and both were decent but not great, a bit on the bland side. HOWEVER, believe all the hype about the salsa, it's phenomenal and deserves a whole extra star by itself. The actual space is much nicer and more inviting than your average mission taqueria. Not the best burrito you can have in the area but definitely worth a try for the salsa if nothing else.
author: Sefi K.

description:
Surprisingly let down by this colorful joint.

As I prefer my chips thin and my salsa chunky, I definitely could die happy without having sampled this version of weird liquid salsa and painfully thick chips. (Ref- 7x7- 100 eats b4 you die)

As I prefer my Mexican food greasy and my fish tacos not fishy, next time I want "healthy Mexican food," I'll opt for Annies frozen Mexican entrees.

All in all, not where I would recommend satiating a starving belly craving Mexican food greatness.
author: Gabrielle J.

description: Papalote is just a smaller, slower (it takes FOREVER to get your food here), more expensive (they charge 50 cents for extra salsa!) version of Chevy's ... minus the unreasonably large watered down margaritas and the birthday song/sombrero.
author: Lara O.

description: I loved the Adobo burritto! My friend told me about ti and totally hyped me up for it. It totally hit the spot. They are gracious with their servings of salsa and chips. The burritto is SUPER  huge but at the same time, it better be since you are paying almost $10 for a burritto. I enjoyed it becaue it was stuffed with yummy goodness and had a huge horchata to wash it down! :)
author: Jermel-Lynn Q.

description: I like black beans more than pinto beans, but refried pinto beans puts it above the black beans. If you have the same preferences as me, then refried black beans are certainly above the rest. I want to slap myself for not having thought to do that for my own nacho creations at home because that was one reason why the nachos here are so, so good. Even though they got cold halfway through my meal, it was still damn irresistible. I like the burritos too. Aside from all the meats and non-meats you can choose from, there is even a selection of tortillas including spinach and tomato. The chips are good too, fresh and thin. There is only salsa here and it is the only salsa you'll need. It's creamy and red. It looks intimidating, but pretty mild in spiciness, but a whole lot of flavor. Like barbecue places that sell jars of their own housemade barbecue sauce, Papalote sells jars of their signature salsa.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I was hanging out with a bunch of redditors in the Mission when I asked, "hey guys, what's a Mission-style burrito?"

Next minute, we're at Papalote. I had a shrimp burrito and a carne asada quesadilla. Everyone thought I was crazy, but I was so hungry that I devoured both of those items in the time everyone took to eat their burritos! The salsa in the bag is delicious too. Will recommend! Next time, I'll have to get some horchata to wash it all down.
author: Ralph N.

description:
I love Papalotes!  The chicken tacos are to Die for so its a good thing they serve the chips and salsa while you wait.... :)

Miguels smile makes it worth the drive to the city from San Jose-
author: Raeleen D.

description: Them chips and salsa be good.  That triple threat... wow.  I split it with my boyfriend... but sheeeeeeeesh I haven't had so much meat stuffed into a burrito like that before.  Delicious.  I would, someday, try another plate and not the triple threat.
author: Angelica D.

description:
I was very eager to eat my Super carne asada burrito, unfortunately it tasted more vegetarian than anything when I only tasted about 4 pieces of carne asada.
They are not as generous as when they first opened, I guess now that they have the attention it's different
author: Doris V.

description:
LOVE this PLACE! 

The homemade salsa is something I randomly will crave. It is good. 

I recommend the chile verde chicken burrito and the mole chicken burrito. I like the way the mole chicken is prepared here. It is not overpowering or too thick. The tacos are also nice because they come with a lot of lettuce and tomatoes--yay more veggies!

The Triple Threat, which won in Bobby Flay's recent throwdown, is close to $20. I personally don't like eating that much meat in a burrito--so I don't think it's worth it.
author: Joyce L.

description:
So I know this place has high reviews... and I did like it. 
But it's honestly not the best burrito in San Francisco. 

You will still injoy it for sure!!  
It's kind of like Chipolte Burritos..... if you have gone there. 
Same ingredients,  I do say it's better then Chipolte. 
But not the best burrito......But worth to check out! Tasty!
author: Joseph J.

description:
Don't be put off by the lack of latinos in this place because the mole chicken burrito is legit. 

Not the best burrito I've had but the healthiest burrio I've ever had because I didn't feel gross afterwards.
author: Roger H.

description: good food and kind service.. but i'm always shocked at the total.... if all the ingredients were organic and locally sourced, the price might be justified, but for a standard burrito in the bay, it's steep.  if you are getting it to-go, i highly recommend calling ahead - will often save you 10-20 min of wait time.
author: Vanessa V.

description:
Call me a purist but Mexican food and tofu should not go together. Now, I understand the desire to combine the two but in the words of Britney, "Shit ain't right."

If you can look pass the fact that tofu is on the menu (and in a normal size font) then you'll enjoy the food they serve. Everything we ordered was tasty and the salsa for the chips was worth writing home about.
author: Juan V.

description: I do not understand the cult following enjoyed by this place. As far as I can tell the only thing with any flavor whatsoever on the menu is their salsa, which is genuinely good. So good in fact, that I am pretty sure you could cover dog poop with it and it would be edible, though I am not willing to test this theory.
author: Claire B.

description:
$1.50 for chips and salsa (very much like orange sauce at La Victoria's in SJ). Awesome food, very fast, limited sitting space. Chips were not greasy like many Mexican places. The salsa was the best part, spicy and fiery. 

One of the few 7x7 dishes that lives up to the hype. Only giving it 3 stars pending eating there more try out other dishes.
author: Oliver L.

description:
Has anyone noticed that the salsa is just not as good as it used to be once they started commercial production of it? It's completely different. 

The food was never good but the salsa made it worth the price of admission. 

Two stars for the salsa
author: Jamie b.

description:
I feel really bad for the proprietors of other taquerias in the Mission because once I went to Papalote, I never went elsewhere. As a creature of habit, I usually find the best damn food selection anywhere and then repeat. With Papalote, I really only get one thing: the fish cooked in white wine and butter that they serve in their fish tacos or fish burritos. It is the bee's knees. It's not that the other menu items are bad, it's just that the fish in butter and wine is so good, I can't quite order anything else

And the salsa is all that. Exceeds the hype and now in bottles for sale.

Mmm, I'm hungry now
author: Matthew R.

description: I'm sure we weren't the only ones that hadn't heard too much about Papalote before they were on Throwdown and listed in 7x7 but I was so glad I checked both of those out as Papalote is legit.  We ordered the triple threat burrito and it was great.  I thought that the shrimp was the best part of the burrito although everything was delicious.  We also ordered chips and salsa to start and the salsa is definitely one of the best salsas I've ever had.  I was glad I had some extra to pour on my burrito as it made it that much more enjoyable.
author: Blake B.

description:
So I will admit, I only checked out this place because this place was featured on the Food Network: Throwdown: Bobby Flay!

I grow up in the Mission district and know where to get great Mexican food but I am always up for trying something new!
I am so glad I did because the food there is amazing! 
The prices are a little higher than a normal Taqueria but the food is well worth the price!

I have been here 3 times within the last month and love this place!
I keep coming back for the fresh and warm tortilla chips, homemade secret sauce (Which is a medium spice level) and whole wheat tortilla super burrito with carne asade!
The atmosphere is nice and casual, they are always playing great music but be prepared to wait a little during the rush hours of dinner! If you can, dropping by for lunch is much easier!

Also, forget driving because parking is challenge, just catch Bart and get off on 24th street or the 48 line! 

If you live in San Francisco and You still haven't been here, make it a priority to stop by because it's just delicious Mexican tacos and burritos!

Plus its the home of the triple threat burrito (which i have yet to try)!
author: Stephanie M.

description: Gag!! Either these folks are complete idiots or they were trying to insult me. I ordered a Soy Chorizo Burrito, and it took WAY too long. I was the ONLY person in line to order. They had at least 7 people in the kitchen!! They put my chips underneath my burrito in a paper bag. What kind of dumb people have we got here? The service is awful, and the burrito is terrible. I will never give this place money again. I despise you Papalote! I didn't like you four years ago, and I still hate you. Thanks for reconfirming.
author: Mei F.

description: Great tofu burrito.  Fresh and delicious albeit it expensive for a burrito.  Still cheaper than any sit down dinner and thus, worth it.  The beans had flavor and it's nice to have a place that uses veggie instead of chicken broth so vegetarians have more options.
author: Jackie K.

description: Dude, easily one of the top Mexican joints in the Mish'. No need to play cute Papa's comes straight at you with the Triple Threat & kick'n salsa. Yo**
author: Sean V.

description:
I don't ever recall seeing any Mexican customers eat here. But don't fret, the food is tasty and cooked to order.

I don't like to order chicken burritos as most places tend to have overcooked white chicken, but not this place. The chicken is juicy and flavorfull.

The food can take awhile to get to you and the price is expensive for Mexican.


The $20 dollar burrito is a rip off. You can buy two regular burritos for the same price but you won't have that 3rd meat selection.

Don't leave there without buying a jar of their tomato based salsa.
author: Evan W.

description:
Funny thing happened when I found this place. I happened to be working in the area and someone told me to try this place for lunch. I went and it was great.

I tried to go back to the place a week later and found a huge line out the door. Apparently, a Bobby Flay Throwdown episode involving Papalote had aired and everyone wanted to try the newest hip place.

Very long wait to get a table and a very long wait to get something to go. It was still worth it.

And I'll still drive out of my way for it.

New favorite burrito place for me.
author: Peter M.

description:
Had to check this place out after they won the thrown down with Bobbly Flay on the food network.

I've to say the burritos were pretty good but not the best I ever had. 

However I'll definitely return here for 2 things: their salsa and chips and their strawberry aqua fresca!

Their salsa is different from your standard salsa. It is creamier and I think it's because they added some cheese to it. It's also spicer and I love that.. Note that your order comes with a serving of chips n salsa but if you want more if that awesome salsa they'll charge you a dollar(I think) for it.. Worth it though! 

Yes I love their strawberry aqua fresca. It taste really fresh and I like how you can taste the strawberry bits and seeds in it!

At the end of the day it's worth checking out the place at least once. One word of warning. If you're driving here in a Friday night good luck. Parking is difficult to find so drop your friend off to go order (40 min wait on fri nights) while you find a parking spot
author: Jun Kang C.

description: that orange salsa and chicken mole!!! its so good i bought a jar of the salsa to take home... and you know what it's better than la vic's orange sauce!
author: Mara G.

description:
I'm glad I gave you another chance.
In my top five favorite burritos in the Bay Area,
Eating in was a much better experience.
Only gripe was the last third of my burrito was falling apart on me.  I had to knife n fork it.  
Nevertheless, the flavors were amazing.  Also.... post-consumption, I didn't feel how I'm used to feeling after slamming down a slab... which is usually that 'not-so-fresh' feeling.
I'll be back for a three-peat for sure.
author: Barry A.

description:
I went here on one of the few heat wave weekends with my boyfriend.  The food was great, salsa to die for!  Restaurant, hot as hell!

The only downside was that the restaurant gave me a severe case of food poisoning.

The 3 stars is because I desperately want to give it a try one more time, for the salsa and the triple threat burrito.  However, my BF, being the voice of reason, reminds me of the 24 hour of pain I endured the first time around.

Either way, I can see why it's on the 7x7 list!  I would say it's probably safe to go, just don't go on a super hot day.  Sweating and spicy = a lot of sweat and no fun.
author: Melissa L.

description: I found out about Papalote from tasting their salsa at Whole Foods. I was so happy to learn that it is a restaurant and that there are multiple locations in SF. Whenever I go, I always buy a jar of salsa to take home. They have large portions and I like the burritos. I usually get a carnitas one and it totally stuffs me up. It's a bit of a pain to find a seat when it is busy, but it's worth it.
author: Lawren B.

description: To be fair, I only came here to try the chips & salsa from the 7x7 list. The chips were kind of stale, but the salsa was really really good and a little reminiscent of doritos. I like how there is a decent amount of seating inside, but the wait to order is disorganized and long. There didn't seem to be a line, and if you took too long wondering what to get after getting to the cashier and asking your questions, they'd let you stand and think while they moved on to the person behind you. Which is fair, but also something unexpected for me.
author: Melody L.

description: damn good chicken burrito. I have to get one every time I'm in town! The house salsa (orange stuff) is amazing as well. I heard they sell it by the jar now which means next time I'm up in SF visiting friends I'll be picking a few up for home.
author: V N.

description: $13.29 (including tax) for a fish burrito makes this easily THE MOST EXPENSIVE FISH BURRITO IN THE CITY (or at least ONE of them).  Prices have probably been readjusted to account for the recent influx of Google/Facebook/Apple employees (and Papalote is laughing all the way to the bank, no doubt).  To be fair, the fish burrito is certainly GOOD, but is it $13 good?  In my opinion, no.  For $13, I can do a lot better than a burrito, to be sure.  I know I could have just walked away & not paid such an exorbitant price, but I must confess, I felt myself oddly curious what a $13 burrito might taste like: Maybe it was sprinkled with gold dust or saffron, or maybe it came with 20 GB free storage on DropBox or something (it didn't come with any of these things, unfortunately).  I'd probably give Papalote 4 stars if I restricted my criteria to just the QUALITY of the food.  But when you also take into account value for money, it begins to fall a bit flat (I'd prefer to give them 2 and a HALF stars, but that does not appear to be possible here, so I'm only giving them 2).  Perhaps we're just in a new economy, and Papalote's prices are simply reflective of the new standard, but I think we collectively need to take a step back & pay attention to what a fair price really is, and how much markup is really acceptable.  Consider that you can get a fish burrito (with grilled Salmon, no less) at the Little Chihuahua on Valencia for only $8.75, or a fish burrito with line-caught Mahi-Mahi at Tacobar, on California St & Fillmore (in Pacific Heights) for only $8.50, then it becomes harder & harder to justify Papalote's prices.  Their food is good, but they're absolutely taking the mick with the price.
author: Eric H.

description:
Five stars just for the salsa!  I just found out you can buy a jar for $5.95.  Why would I ever want to make salsa again?   It has the perfect combination and ratios of garlic, smoke, heat that makes my tongue tingle.  

However, I haven't found anything yet that I can't live without.  So far  the carne asada tacos are decent.  But without the salsa, they are nothing.
author: Monica L.

description:
I love it.  I love it!  

What's up with that salsa?  It is so addictive I got a to go jar of it.  This place was one of the first places I went when I first moved here and it's remained one of my favorites. 

Delicious.

By the way, they have lots of veg options.
author: Suzie R.

description:
Get the pescado tacos!!  Do it now!

So I've been here previously and found the mole chicken burrito to be meh.  Maybe mole isn't my thing.

Today I decided to be fair and give them another shot.  At $6.75 for two pescado tacos, I was a bit hesitant since I'm trying out that whole "staying on a budget" thing.  But it was SOOOOO worth it.  The fish was freshly sauteed in white wine, butter, and herbs and it had much more flavor than the grilled fish at Nick's.  They also gave a good 0.5 lb of fish split between the two tacos (or maybe I just got lucky).  The crisp lettuce, onions, and tomatoes topping the tacos also tasted fresh and gave a nice cool contrast relative to the warm, buttery fish.

Oh yea, and I've gotta agree with every salsa - it's probably the best I've ever had.
author: Bipasha M.

description:
You know it aint that bad.  

So why did I start the review this way, well the way that my friends described it, I thought it was going to taste like an orgasm on the plate.

It wasn't that, but it was certainly a step above taqueria quality.  

The stand out is their hot sauce.  The ingredients are fresh and of a good quality.

I would say if you are in the area, and the line is not crazy (which it can be), then check it out.
author: Ken p.

description:
Spectacular burritos that don't feel like they are missing anything.  All options I have tried at Papalote have been very good, though I think the Marinated Tofu (super) Burrito with the black refried beans stands as my top pick and the best burrito I have had in San Francisco during the limited 2 months I've lived in the city.

The salsa and chips that you get with every order are also top notch.  Can be very crowded though!
author: Sam D.

description:
This is NOT your hole in the wall burrito place. It is much nicer space and atmosphere, and the beans are vegan.
Meaning the beans are not soaked with lard like in most hole in the wall places.

The fact that they use better ingredients affects the price, but this space is more in-line with low-end Mission restaurants rather than hole in the wall taquerias. So prices accordingly.

They also use open flame grill for some meats, instead of the typical grease soaked griddle (yikes).

Most things are great, and the secret sauce is well, the sauce. Best Salsa in the Mission. 

I don't walk into taquerias in the mission anymore, mostly because of the quality of the food. Some taste great, but the quality is never there. When I want Mexican, its either this one, Gracias Madre or Oaxaquena (with seems to be going down unfortunately).

If you like Mexican but want better quality, this is the place. And quality unfortunately costs, so expect to pay 50% more than a hole in the wall burrito. Still a much better deal if you care about what goes into your body (which apparently many reviewers don't :)
author: Elija A.

description:
Bobby Flay lost for a reason!

I came here to eat lunch today after hearing that Bobby Flay had lost a "Throwdown" here. The Triple Threat Burrito was the challenge, and boy was it also a challenge to finish. 

First off, the free chips as an appetizer are delicious! I don't know what's so different about them but they have a natural crunch to them that make them irresistible to turn away. Also, the salsa served with the chips is probably as close to perfect salsa I have ever tasted in my life. The salsa is sweet, yet not too sweet, and spicy enough to have a kick in it but not too much where you can only eat a bit. There's also none of that burnt pepper taste in it. 

I also split an order of fish tacos with my brother. The fish tacos were a lot bigger than other taquerias I've been to and they are extremely hot (temperature wise) when they come out. The fish tacos were recommended to us by the staff as their best tacos, and they were correct!

Now on to the Triple Threat Burrito. This burrito is definitely not for the faint at heart. The sheer size of the burrito is comparable to other taquerias as maybe 1.2 to 1.5 times larger. They also recommend that the burrito be shared by two or more people, which I recommend as well. The shrimp inside is of the jumbo variety, and the chicken and steak are marinated to perfection in many spices. There is not too much rice in the burrito to mask any of the flavors, and for $0.99 more, they add in sour cream and guacamole to make the burrito perfect. The only downside to the burrito was the price, for $20 I could get 4 burritos at other taquerias, but I had to try this burrito at least once. 

On another note, this place is probably the closest thing to a temple for those with hangovers!
author: Langdon N.

description: The fresh salsa, only get the fresh salsa!! I love this place, top-notch burritos.
author: Dressing F.

description:
As a couple of vegetarians who still hanker for some tasty Mexican food (we come from New Mexico), Papalote was a great discovery. We ate at the restaurant the first time, but it's almost always packed -- a testament to their tasty menu -- so we've become devoted taker-outers.

Me, I always go for the Soyrizo burrito SUPER (with sour cream, guacamole and cheese, the only way to go!) and she always gets the marinated tofu (super, of course).

For us to-go fans, that the burritos come with a bag of chips and their awesome salsa is icing on the cake. And the nachos are bad-ass.

A few of their dishes aren't so super -- like the overly oily-cheesey queso dishes -- but on the whole, you can't go wrong. Parking ain't easy (is it ever in this city?), which makes take out an even better option.
author: Bill H.

description: I had the Carne Asada Burrito. The meat was really good but unfortunately it was the predominant flavor. To me, it tasted like the grilled steak stuffed burrito from taco bell only with quality ingredients (which is good but boring). I much prefer La Taqueria for a much more balanced and flavorful burrito.
author: Blake E.

description: I ordered the camarones (shrimp) super burrito. I had recently ate at el-ferrollito on mission street because of there $6 prices and 2200 reviews and i thought they had good burritos. But anyway i had the shrimp burrito with black beans. Talk about heaven this burrito (about $11.50) is hands down the BEST burrito I have ever had. The different tastes of it make my mouth water. It was perfectly cooked in every way. I was not impressed with my el-ferrolitto experience but I have no complaints about my papalote burrito. This burrito was superb. I highly recommend it. I cannot wait to go back and try their asada and chicken burritos. On top of all this you get free chips and salsa. There salsa is world class. If you near mission street and 24th do not pass this place up
author: Tmo457 W.

description:
re: Renovation

Paplote was closed over the holidays to renovate.  The counter is now on the right, and the biggest change is that the kitchen is now hidden (not that that means anything, just an observation.

I had many, many burrittos from Papalote and they've always been consistently, which is great when you have a quality product.

However, when I got my first burrito from Papalote after the renovation, there was much more of a rice prescence in the burrito.

Has anyone experienced this since the renovation?
author: jesse b.

description:
Definitely a fan of Papalote! Tried their fish tacos, which were scrumptious. If you're big on eating, well, be warned, the portions are fairly small but filled with flavor and fresh ingredients. Okay, this review is sounding way too commercial. 

Being a native San Franciscan, Papalote, certainly, caters to the palettes of the transplants but does it well, I must say. It's quite the hipster place to eat. How, you ask? Well, I'm sure soy and tofu don't enter the minds of cooks who make 'authentic' Mexican cuisine. However Papalote totally pulls off vegetarian and vegan options off well. It must if it wants to compete with the rest of the taquerias. I mean, this establishment is in the Mission, well, off Valencia, really. But, nevertheless, it has to compete. Yet, their food and service are certainly commendable. 

However, it's one of those places that gets really crowded on Friday and weekend evenings and, what do you know, it's filled with the cute boys and girls in glasses (probably transplants and college kids, whatever) and plaid with beat up converse or grimy Keds ordering some vegan burrito. No, no, no...not hatin' at all, just giving fair warning to those that may care or have a particular predilection towards a type of crowd.  Blah ba dee blah blah. Anyway, aside from the scene, it is a decent place and if you want the healthy option, Papalote will serve it up!
author: Dorothy S.

description: Drop whatever you are doing and run to Papalote. Eat large quantities of their fish tacos and salsa.
author: Karen R.

description:
Oh Papalote, I feel like I spend my whole life waiting for you...

...and waiting. and waiting.... in fact, I'm sitting in your lobby right now waiting.. am i waiting for Godot or for Papalote? I've lost track.

The first few times I came here were a miss. The tacos were not the kind I'm used to (ya know... like not skimpy) and the tofu burrito was pretty dry. The kind of of food I think the hipsters probs love. BUT I then I found my niche: The Fish Burrito with refried beans. Damn the fact that it's 8.50, it was just so delicious in my mouth. Plus the hot sauce! Not as good at La Vic's but not a bad 2nd place.

The wait was not delicious though and it's the only reason I have to take away the 2 stars. And it's always so unpredictable! Walking in, I waited 25 min. The second time walking in was 20 min. The third time walking in and taking it to go was 30 minutes. And the last time I called I was told 20 min and when I actually go there, it was another 25 min!! That's pretty redonkulous in my book. So consider this a 3.5 rating and make sure you call ahead and then lose track of time. Then I bet you'll leave this place super stoked.
author: Salina Z.

description: I don't understand why people rave about this place. The burrito was overpriced. It tasted exactly like your average Mexican diner style burrito and costs about the same. Really? $9 for their super burrito? I'll take El Faralito any day over this place.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
I've only been here once, but any Mexican restaurant that actually caters to vegetarians and vegans while maintaining some degree of "authenticity" is a winner in my book. The tofu mole is freaking delicious, if a little pricey ($11.50, I believe), and they have a wide variety of options for the meat lover.

The salsa was also freakin' delicious, although perhaps not the most "authentic." But, then, isn't the word authentic sometimes a little condescending--not to mention overrated? I think so. The salsa is delicious, the mole is delicious. What more do you need?

I'll be going back. They have tofu mole tacos too!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Saw them on TFC news segment. I was at my in-laws and had to have my wife translate. Apparently they have chicken adobo with garlic rice burritos (that's not on the menu). What?! I love burritos and love chicken adobo....so they put them together like a freak experiment. Gotta check it out. 

The verdict? It was pretty good. Wasn't sure if it was garlic rice (it was weak if it was) or just drippings from the adobo (mixed with their regular rice). The chicken was good but both my wife and myself agreed it was missing something: either more adobo sauce or onion/garlic pieces or even sour cream that could've kicked it up a notch. 

Regardless, it was good eats. Warrants another try. You can tell they put effort in their food. 

p.s. I hope you kicked Bobby Flay's ass in the throwdown challenge. He's full of sh*t and full of himself.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
I am totally dreaming of this place right now. Best ever mole chicken tacos in all of the bay area for sure. If you are searching mole on Yelp then I hope you opened this post!!!! They serve you warm chips and salsa at your table and you don't feel bad asking for refills. The staff is friendly and its fine with kids too. 

Its clean and doesnt have the greasy smell. Its seriously busy all the time and parking can be a bia but its so totally worth it.
author: Naureen H.

description:
I am in love with the buttery tasty goodness that is the chicken adobo with garlic fried rice burrito.  the first time my friend and I ordered it, we forgot to get super - this we thought would be a terrible mistake.  sour cream is one of my favorite things in the entire world.  turns out the burrito is just sooo delicious it didn't matter at all. 

I realllllly want to try the triple threat, but it just wouldn't feel right spending 20 bucks on a burrito. sad. at least I've got my adobo burrito!

oh also it's a very cute place.
author: Niki B.

description:
Date of Visit: 05/01/2010

Came here on a Saturday night around 9pm thinking it would be too crowded and hard to grab a seat but it was very easy to get a table because I guess many people just eat and go, so the turn around time is pretty quick.  
The food took about 15 minutes to get to us and we ordered 2 burritos: Carne Asada and their Adobo burrito.  I would have loved to try the triple threat, but I wasn't prepared to shell out $20, so maybe next time.  The burritos were just like any other you can get at the next taqueria but their adobo burrito was very flavorful.  I thought there would be more rice in it, but it was packed with flavorful meat.  

Aside from the burritos, I would definitely go back for that salsa.  I would give this place 3 stars, but that damn good ass salsa definitely bumps it up another star.  If there wasn't somebody sitting at the table next to us, I would have taken a shot of that salsa from that little silver cup they give it in.
author: Raymond L.

description: I love this place. Best salsa ever and really delicious food at affordable prices. Win, win, WIN!!!
author: Naomi T.

description:
Fantastic guacamole and salsa, the combination is killer. Love that they offer so many veg friendly options, the tofu is even high-protein wildwood brand. Texture on the tofu and soyrizo was spot-on, no soggy burritos here. This place is tiny and getting a seat can be very hectic, I was thankful to finally plop down with the chips, guac and salsa and dig in. 
Love me some refried black beans, that alone earns this place an additional star.
author: Cori W.

description:
If you're expecting big chunks of tomatoes, onions and cilantro in their famous salsa, you'll be disappointed.  In essence, the salsa is made with roasted tomatoes and pureed into a smooth consistence but packed with flavor.  Their salsa is different but I personally like my chunks of tomatoes in my salsa. However their avocado dip ($2.75) was chunky and delish!

At Papalote, you have the option of making your burrito as healthy as you'd like.  From your choice of wheat, spinach and tomato tortillas to tofu and veggie options, a burrito does not have to be heavy and give you food coma!!  Once you order food, you'll be seated by one of the friendly workers.

The bathroom is kinda cool. Almost every inch of the wall space and the ceiling is covered in graffiti.  They've used graffiti as an art and it brings in a cool vibe.  

Parking is kinda hard especially in the Mission but if you bike to Papalote, you can park your bike at the bike racks in front and watch

We tried the carne asada tacos ( 2 for $5.95) and Veggie grilled burrito ($6.50).  The carne asada tacos had huge cube chunks of marinated meat. The veggie burrito was definitely not as great as the burritos from El Farolito.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Awesome!

Great food. Not too expensive. Huge portions. Free chips and salsa. Limited seating. Coke made with cane sugar in a bottle. 

Verdict: Dankmunch
author: Sean M.

description:
Papalote hurts my soul. Deciding whether to go to Papalote is a dilemma that is probably experienced by many San Franciscans due to the fact that their burritos are damn tasty but getting one takes for-f*cking-EVER. 

Be warned, friends - if you are starving and need immediate gratification do NOT walk in to Papalote and order a burrito.  Your sorry ass will be waiting for at least 15 minutes.  I was there Tuesday and it took OVERa half an hour to get a standard chicken burrito (which was delicious - I ate the entire thing and would've eaten a second if I could).

Ordering by phone seems to be the smart way to go about getting your food fast.  It kind of takes the spontaneity out of the experience but it'll save you frustration.  Case in point: I was silently cussing out the 20-30 peeps that were able to saunter straight up up to the phone order line and get their burrito immediately while I sat there, stomach growling, drinking my saliva and chewing my tongue.

So, three stars - five stars for the quality of the food, one star for the time suck and physical anguish.
author: Veronica Y.

description: Only been here once because I live hours away. Had the adobo burrito. I died from it's greatness. Staff was friendly and nice. I like the chips too. I'll be visiting the bay area soon and I'm hoping to drag my family here for the first time.
author: Jason P.

description:
This place is good. A friend of mine who lives in San Fran (Warren, who plays drums for Tussle and probably a bunch of other lame bands - just kidding!) took me (and The Woman Who I'm Currently Married To) to this joint. The burritos were pretty damn good. TWWICMT suggested that I try some black beans in my carne asada burrito with beans and cheese only (#2) and ya know what, it was a wonderful suggestion. I think Warren had a veggie burrito because he's one of "those kind." You know what I mean: they don't eat meat because Jesus told him not to via a text message while he was watching Goonies on DVD three years ago. It wasn't even the special edition, just the crappy pan and scan version!

I'm hitting this place up when I come back. You hear that Warren?
author: Jason B.

description:
I don't know if eating an entire burrito filled with tofu and potatoes is a blessing or a curse.

Carb induced coma withstanding, it's quite amazing.

P.S.  Add guacamole.  Take nap afterwards.
author: Jen I.

description:
All day the bf and I have been messaging each other that we want to try this so called Best burrito in San Francisco...he is torn between the Triple Threat and Carne Asada burrito! Oh the choices...actually the choice was pretty easy...haha...considering we would never pay $20 for a burrito unless it was maybe stuffed with some top notch Kobe beef! :P

He settled for the super Carne Asada burrito and I had the Chicken Adobo burrito with whole black beans. So it takes me a while to actually start eating I like to cut my burrito in half...make sure I have a drink beside me...utensils too! I'm about to take a bite of of my burrito and realize that the bf has mine...he's already 3 bites into it! How rude! So we do the switch and I can tell his eyes are focused on mine now! Let's just say the Chicken was so moist and so flavorful! It was delicious just wish it was a little bigger...too bad the Carne Asada burrito that my bf ate wasn't all that tasty. 

I really wanted to try their Triple Threat but was not going to shell out the money for it. :( bummer!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Yep, that sauce and better quality ingredients.  It isn't a bargain place but most other burrito places with their identical, soggy-wet burritos and sad meat are pretty pricey on their own.  For a few bucks more you get the first class upgrade.  

One question.  Why do guacamole and avocados cost more than illegal drugs in this town?
author: Matt M.

description:
Pros: 
  * Vegan-friendly.  The soyrizo is overrated in my book, but their marinated tofu is just great.
  * Refried black beans!!

Cons:
  * Unless you call ahead (and who *plans* to want a burrito?!), you have to wait 20-30 minutes to get your order.  Minus 2 stars right there.

Conclusion: I'm sticking to Pancho Villa.
author: Nori H.

description:
You only get 2 tacos? That was my question to my friend upon arrival. 
As a petite girl - I do love Mexican food..and quantity is important. 

I was completely stuffed after eating the 2 overly stuffed carne asada tacos loaded with sour cream, cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, and avocado. The salsa was just hot enough and had a great creamy texture. yum.
author: Jackie L.

description: The best burrito in San Francisco.  Veggie options are plentiful and the quality of the experience has been exceptional every visit.  Easily my favorite spot so far for a quality mission burrito.
author: Cory H.

description: You like-eh the sauce-eh? great source for flavorful food, you cant beat mexican food with great ingredients.
author: Mario C.

description: I've been coming to Papalote for years because it is so consistent and delicious.  We ate there today...and it was not consistent this time because it was EVEN MORE DELICIOUS than usual.  Steak burrito = perfect consistency, slightly grilled, amazing.  Chicken tacos = fresh, crunchy, bright avocado.  And don't get me started on the salsa - I could eat it as soup.
author: May A.

description:
I have given Papalote my fair share of food trials. From the prawn tacos to the burritos, I've eaten enough now to say ENOUGH! Since my last visit, they have renovated the area at the cash register. As if it could not have gotten more awkwardly placed, the line now is forced out the door at a sharp angle. Papalote's blinding non-CFL lighting (which creates an unnecessary heatwave in the dead of winter) and glossy red walls create an anxiety in me that only rivals that of an interrogation. Because it is in close proximity to my friend's apartment, I reluctantly agreed to meet her there. (Any excuse to see her.) Miraculously, she was able to get 3 seats for all of us. Seating is at a premium.

Last night, I had the prawn burrito. I was not given chips or salsa or a napkin or cutlery or my drink. I asked for all of these things, seeing that everyone else had them, and was told that "extra" chips & salsa were 55 cents. Seriously? I can get all the chips I want elsewhere and for free. Once I explained to the guy that I never got my first round, he gave me some salsa. I walked out of there having paid $14 for a burrito and a horchata. I could have gone to El Farolito and bought dinner for both of us. My burrito was dry, pretty bland, and I only found the cheese  of the way through my meal (same goes for the guacamole). I slathered every bit of my tiny salsa cup on my burrito for flavor. The prawns were large... all (4?) of them. I spent the entire night in agony. I remebered now why I never go there: I get incredible stomach cramps from their food. I can't explain it - no one else seems to have this - but the amount of acid created is so painful that the last time I ate there, I needed to swallow Pepto with lidocaine just to get to sleep. 

I will now leave Papalote to the hipsters who frequent it. A guy who sat next to us was visiting from NY. I mentioned to him that this was not my favorite place and suggested that if he was here for any length of time, he should try the many other burrito places that the Mission has to offer. I suggested El Farolito and the couple next to us agreed and chimed in. The couple on the other side of us agreed as well. One thing could be said: Papalote brings people together.
author: Shelley T.

description:
I can't add much to what everyone else has said except that the Fish Tacos are probably my favorite item on the menu. Mmmm!

And I am grateful they are so close to me in my new 'hood!
author: N B.

description:
I live about a mile from here so I was waiting for a nice evening to take a walk over and for some reason I chose last night which made little to no sense considering I was debilitated by a lack of sleep and an out of character hangover that left my limbs drooping all day , but I guess I was inspired or I just really needed the sustenance provided by a burrito. 

And I'm glad I chose last night because the soyrizo burrito that I had was pretty-pretty brilliant AND HUGE! I almost ate the whole thing which is f'ed up just because.

 It was very busy inside and though I did have to wait, it wasn't an unreasonable amount of time. I am vegan and the fact that I could not make up my mind on what to get made me kind of happy, considering sometimes I'm just left to eat the one or two things available to tweak on the menu. I will absolutely go here again, especially to try that tofu mole burrito. Sounds like a win.

Cons: place is cramped (though I was there at dinner hour) and my scale told me I weighed 2 more pounds than normal this morning. Coincidence?
author: Natalie R.

description:
Years ago I went one to Papalote and since that day I have been dreaming of the salsa, ooohing over the burritos, dreaming about the grilled tortilla and gushing about the eclectic interior.
Last night put a stop to that.

Burrito Shangri-la it was not.  A solid place to get a burrito it was.

After being rushed through the ordering process we were asked to wait outside until a table opened up.  That wait was quick, but then it took seemingly forever for our burritos to arrive (about 15 min, but i was hungry and these are BURRITOS - usually a quick food)!

The burritos were tasty but my grilled tortilla was a really strange gummy/spongy texture that was nearly impossible to cut through.  Also, in my book, burritos should be wrapped in tinfoil so you can pick it up and eat it like a. . .  burrito.  I just don't get theknife and fork on a plate thing for finger food.

Interior decor is still eclectic.
author: Sarah L.

description:
The most veg-friendly taqueria I've been to. They have so many veg options, which is good, because we come here at least twice a month. 

The roasted salsa is amazing, as is their mole sauce, and their marinated tofu, and the soyrizo...

tags: vegetarian
author: Nithin R.

description: I'd been avoiding coming here because I thought it seemed too "trendy," but my carne asada burrito was pretty good.  I didn't like it as much as El Toro, it was a little blander than most burritos.  Super crowded and a small space, not always the best!
author: Julia D.

description:
Heh.  Not bad, but definitely one of the least authentic taquerias in the Mission (I mean really -- when you're at Valencia & 24th, and the place is full, and every single person in the joint is white...).

I like that they do refried black beans.  And that they have a pretty darn respectable beer selection.  And that I can have avocado on my burrito (no guac, though).  I had heard amazing things about the spicy orange sauce, but was disappointed.  Not as disappointed as the time I had the spicy orange mayonnaise at La Victoria in San Jose, but close.  (And that's the closest thing you'll get to salsa there.  There is no -- repeat, NO -- salsa at Papalote. *cry!*)

But the burritos are fine, the meat seems to be of reasonable quality, there is excellent and happy-making beer, and also, on the right night, boxes of avocados the size of your head.  For serious.  So I'll probably keep swingin' by when I don't feel like walking all the way to Pancho Villa.
author: Angela B.

description: Undercooked beans, underseasoned chicken, and don't think about lingering at your table for even a few minutes after they clear your plate or they'll ask you to leave. I understand turnover is important to their business, especially during lunch. But shuffling people out the door less than 5 minutes after they finish their meal is kind of rude. This is what I get for paying $9 for a burrito? Give me a break. If only La Taq weren't closed for remodeling.
author: Andrew K.

description: For years, people kept saying to me, "you've never been to Papalote?!?"  I didn't understand why this was so surprising...then I had their soyrizo burrito.  I can't believe it took me so long. I can guarantee you that it didn't take long for me to find my way back there...again and again and again.
author: Renee D.

description:
this place is an absolute FAIL.

i've tried this place before because of all the hype. the carne asada in my burrito was dryer than the arizona desert. i had sworn off this place forever because not every place this is buzzworthy is actually worthy.

then came the adobo burrito. interesting because i love filipino food and it has really come up in san francisco. so about a year later, we return to this establishment, to find it as usual--crowded--with a small makeover.

so i grab a table because we had intentions of eating there while my boyfriend ordered the burrito. shortly after, i was approached by one of the employees that works there. this is how the conversation unravels:

employee: did u order food?
me: not yet, he is still in line.
employee: are u sure?
me(with a confused look on my face): he is in line!

so she walks away only to return and tell me that the single man standing over there had a number already so he was ntitled to the table I was sitting at. (people and their entitlements. i thought it was first come, first serve.)

as i look over to see where my boyfriend is in line, he is about 4 people away from ordering. (is taking an order really that serious? he was in line for about 15 minutes.)

so after telling her that we had intentions of ordering food and i wasnt just sitting in here waiting for a bus, i decided to throw a wrench in the conversation. i asked her, "is it because he is white and i am Latina?
keeping in mind that i had never heard of such a policy unless it pertained to a standby seat on a plane or bus.
both times her response to the same question was, "Yes."

so I got up and went to line to tell me boyfriend. as she approached he asked her again about this store policy and I asked her my entitlement question again, this time in Spanish.
and sure enough, her answer was "yes."

while im not completely naive to think racism doesnt exist anymore, i am also not accustomed to hearing that people of one race have a priority over another in a restaurant, at least not in san francisco.
while she was probably a messenger for the coward that didnt want to fight his own battle, i think she made a huge mistake in getting involved.

usually when i go to a taqueria, one or two people stand in line while the rest of the people grab a table. whats the point of congesting an area when u dont need to? and a persons money that just bought something is just as valuable  as the person who will be buying something, maybe even more, because the person in line still has the opportunity of walking out and not spending money there. 

the food is crap and the service is tacky. stop pretending to be something you arent. the people at el farolito, cancun, el buen sabor, and la cumbre know how to treat their customers, while also making better tasting food.
author: Bee B.

description:
Well after a long beautiful day in the sun, this restaurant was perfect. My friend and I shared a plate of yummy nachos and quesadillas. The place is really colorful and lively. It is definitely a trendy spot. I love the decor.  Papalote means kite and they have very beautiful ones hanging from the ceiling. They also have paintings from local artists on the wall. The place is a little small but it is still comfortable. You can't miss it when you pass by. It's bright red inside!!!!!

I would go back in a heart beat!!! So much fun!

Denise
author: Denise C.

description:
When I want a real gourmet sit down burrito in a colorful place with Mexican bug kites on the ceiling, I'll put up with circling around a few times in the Mission to find parking when I come here. I don't know of any other place that basically grills up a fresh steak for you and chops it up for a really fresh and naturally juicy and chewy take on the average carne asada burrito.
 
The fresh and not too salty chipotle salsa, whole wheat tortilla options and ginger soft drinks are also a nice touch.

My buddy I brought who went for the first time had the chicken mole burrito and kept raving about it for days.
They have some interesting graffiti on the walls in the bathroom, let's leave it at that... some of that stuff was pretty funny to read.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Chilaquiles!

After walking by a few months ago and seeing someone chow down on a huge plate of nachos through the window, I knew I had to come back and check this place out sometime. I actually had no idea it was featured on Throwdown until the day before we went.

We arrived at 11:45am and it was totally dead. But our friends weren't here yet so we walked around the corner for a cup of coffee. 20 minutes later we walked back and there was a huge line out the door. 

So it's definitely not worth all the hype but the food is still pretty decent, and it's not your typical greasy Mexican joint like one would expect.

- Chips and Salsa - I thought the chips were just average - I've had better. The salsa is fantastic though - creamy and orange with a bit of kick.
- Chilaquiles - "breakfast nachos", great for sharing as I don't think I can handle an entire serving. A generous serving of chips topped w/ cheese, sauce, and egg and served w/ beans and rice on the side
- Chile Verde burrito - a fat burrito, enough for two people. Consisting of just meat, rice and beans, it was tasty, but nothing to go crazy over. I didn't bother with the Triple Threat, and don't see how an extra 10 bucks and three different types of meat would have made it that much better.
- Chicken tacos - the chicken had a good seasoning, but the rest of the taco was pretty plain. Served on two flour tortillas w/ lettuce and tomatoes.

I would come back for the salsa and chilaquiles alone, and at least I know next time I can definitely skip the burritos/tacos.

One last note - the service is great and the staff was so friendly. With crowded tables and a 20 minute line out the door they could have easily been stressed out. But they all had a great attitude, were attentive, and thanked us with smiles on our way out.
author: Amy H.

description:
I am only speaking from the quesadilla perspective... and yea their super quesadillas are very very delish. What really makes the quesadilla is the meat of choice (I get carne asada) and their special salsa.

The carne asada is cooked just right! Not chewy or tough, but juicy and tender. Plus, the amount they put in their quesadilla is good for the portion. Not too much (but would I really complain??) or too little.

I loved how the quesadilla wasn't too cheesy and the outside was nice and crisp. I like to load mine up with guacamole, sour cream, and salsa for every bite. I don't know how you can eat it any other way! The guacamole makes the meat not too smokey, the sour cream gives it a little tang, and the salsa brings out the juiciness of the meat.

That's right... the salsa is yummy! I just wish it had more of a kick or was spicy in some way. Tasting it alone I couldn't really pinpoint anything special about it, but I love how it tastes with my carne asada. I didn't actually enjoy eating it with the chips. It was too substantial for the chips, which were thin and kind of papery. Not a fan.

What I am really interested in... is their veggie options! I will drop in again and try something. It's just going to be difficult because once I find something good, I can't help ordering it. It's a good thing I work in this neighborhood....
author: Donna K.

description:
Staff lies on the phone and says 10 minutes when they mean thirty plus.  I'd take it as a one-off if this wasn't the third time in 2 weeks.  I don't understand how this is so hard -- look at the kitchen, see how many orders you have, and do a little math.  And they don't even apologize after you stand in their restaurant an extra 20 plus minutes.

Their burritos are decent but nothing special; they're just closest to my house.  I guess I'll be walking a block farther in the future to find a restaurant that cares about customer service.  Try Little Chihuahua for a far better burrito and dining experience, plus when they say your food will be ready, it is!  Amazing.
author: Earl H.

description:
On a friend's recommendation, my husband and I came here randomly one night. 
What a pleasant surprise! The fish tacos are made with white wine and are wonderful. The guacamole is juicy and thick and that's really all you need to know about a mexican restaurant to determine if it's good.
Will have to try the one on Fulton soon.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Their veggie burritos are good, but...

1. Don't get carne asada with no rice. It's 89% black beans, 10% steak, and 1% salsa.  Bleh.

2. The "Mkt Price" for a side of guac was $3.25 for about two tablespoons. That's insane.
author: L B.

description:
My friends rave about Papalote, lauding it as one of the best Mexican food restaurants in the Mission. 

Lemme tell ya something folks, it's very well known that the Mission District is rife with taquerias, good taquerias, and Papalote isn't one of them. I bullshit people for a living, and it's pretty hard to bullshit a bullshitter.

If you enjoy dry burritos and other mediocre Mexican food, Papalote's your spot. Papalote, like a number of ethnic restaurants in this city, has sacrificed flavor in the name of being "healthy". If you want to consume "healthy" food, go to Herbivore. Minorities have health problems for a reason: our food is greasy yet chalked full of flavor. Papalote, I beg of you, give the people what they want. I don't want an Amy's organic microwave burrito...I want sour cream, avocado, and lard...precious, delicious LARD!

Kick it up a few notches Papalote, then we'll talk about revising this review.
author: Rodney P.

description:
Sad... I used to like their food. Last few times I went back the grilled veggie burrito didn't taste very good (ended up taking a couple bites then throwing it away each time...), their guacamole was not very flavorful, and their salsa was NOT hella good...

Boo... Bring back the yum or I'm not gonna come (back)!
author: Miss C.

description:
Chips and Salsa? Yum
Burrito? Yum
Mexican Coca-Cola? YUM YUM! 

The food is great and the price is so right.
author: Liz M.

description:
Soyrizo burrito! Say no more.

Excellent menu. Vegan friendly is an understatement. The salsa might be the best I have EVER had.

The only complaint I can even think of is that it gets real crowded real quick. If Papalote opened a location in Oakland, I would be in heaven (hint hint).
author: shane s.

description: My favorite cheap burrito place in the city --- and also LOVE their awesome orange sauce.
author: Shivani S.

description:
In the interest of full disclosure, I went to high school with the owners more than two decades ago.  I'm in the city for a bit and I haven't been in the Mission in a long time and hey, what was that place those guys own?  That's when a Google told me about the Food Network thing so it must be pretty decent.

There were three of us.  I had chicken Mole tacos.  Really good mole. I haven't had good Mole since I moved from L.A.  One Chile Verde Burrito, also really good.  Juicy tender meat with tangy sauce.  The third was an order of chicken tacos. 

I see others on here have mentioned the Salsa.  That stuff may haunt me between visits to S.F. that will hopefully include time to swing by again.   Starts off tomato with roasty smoked flavor and finishes with a good chile spice.  Not a fire eater spice but not for "mild please" weenies either.  And somehow it manages to seem creamy.  I'd like to buy it by the gallon jar.

Congratulations Miguel.  I dig your place and wish you continued success.  And the beer geek in me likes that you have Chimay Rouge in the cooler.
author: Otis D.

description: Oh boy this place is so sweet.  The staff are helpful and courteous.  The food is amazing.  I have never had a bad time here both with the atmosphere, the food, the clientele.  I challenge anyone to go and not have a good time.  In fact I know what I am having for lunch.
author: Scardaddy S.

description:
Still the most amazing salsa, and I still love the black bean and cheese dip, and I still just generally think the place is awesome, but when I went last Saturday for lunch it was completely packed and the only empty table was next to Super Star Elite Yelper Stephan W.

Eating tasty Mexican food is always fun, but eating tasty Mexican food with Stephan is a 5-star experience every time.

[Equally entertaining was the psuedo-semi-hippy-neo-hipster dude on the other side of me who spent at least 35 minutes telling his friend (over, and over, and over) why his last relationship didn't work out because he thinks that talking and sharing and emotional intimacy are the essences of a relationship and his GF didn't share, and kept it all inside . . . dude, if you're reading this, I bet she would've shared endlessly with anybody else you annoying twit!  

I can just imagine the guy getting home every day and hounding the poor woman with questions about every stupid thing that happened during her day and -- drum roll -- how it made her **feel**, and then he'd look her longingly in the eyes and say "I love you so much!"  Excuse me while I go vomit some of the tastiest chips, salsa, and black-bean-and-cheese dip I've ever eaten.]
author: Joe C.

description:
I would like to know how many native Mission residents frequent this place? I am sick and tired of taquerias that claim to be restaurants. El Papolote has got to be one of the worse places I have been to in the Mission District! Being of Mexican heritage I take these places with a grain of salt. Through many other recomendations for this place I decided to give it a try. Now no Mexican household I have ever been in steams a flour tortilla?Tortillas are traditionally grilled or are fresh off the grill...Never Steamed??? the Chi
laquillas were the worse ever! the same dipping sauce was spread all over my dish! and the rice was spciy and the black refried beans were so watery and spicy. There was one flavor! spicy. I never tasted the beans or rice. It was a big mess!I looked around the taqueria and noticed that besides the workers, I was the only latino in the place!Nothing but young hipsters!....maybe the idea of a big sloppy undercooked tortilla is an someone's idea of reall mexican food? sadly these young people will never experience real mexican cooking.
author: bette r.

description:
The idea of tofu in my burrito used to weird me out super badly before I came to Papalote.
Now, it's my most favorite thing in the world, and good thing, too! I've been wanting a little extra oomf in my veggie selections!
Also, the salsa here is BOMB, the staff is super nice, and they play sweet, sweet dub all day on the stereo!
Absolute win!
author: Erin P.

description:
What? Five stars for the whitest Mexican food this side of Taco Bell?

You're goddamn right. I earned my Mission Merit Badge back when YOU had no idea what San Francisco looked like after midnight because BART stopped heading to El Cerrito at 11. I had bacon wrapped hot dogs back when you were first hearing about The Tamale Lady (they USED TO BE $2, kids). So don't get pissy with me.

And I love the flavor of lard mixed with unwashed hands as much as the next guy. I've written love notes to taco trucks, and I've gotten ring sting from overzealous jalapenos that've soaked in pepper brine since the Carter Administration. I am more than immune to salmonella. I use it  like a sorority girl uses ranch dressing. 

So I KNOW, see, I know. I know that when I order a chicken mole burrito sans rice, I should expect, essentially, pollo asada with a hint of earth. And when I get surprised by what tasted like God & chocolate got together and made roast chicken, I can't really be bothered to give a shit about authenticity. When the salsa tastes like concentrated Mexican bullion, I'd be a fool to eschew it in favor of the onion & tomato afterthought that comes with thick chips and a hateful attitude at many of the nearby tacotoriums.

These aren't food socks, these are food stockings.
author: jason l.

description:
Dolores Park is maddening on sunny weekends.  I feel that I would rather skin both knees than go to Dolores Park on a sunny Saturday with friends.  With that said, I have been known to give in to peer pressure when there is beer or hookers involved.  In this case, it involved beer and good friends with beards.  And if you know me, you know that I will do almost anything for a fine man with a beard and the chicken fajitas from Chili's. 

Dolores Park, Coors Lights, PBR, temperature drops 20 degrees, smoke something, and so begins my Saturday evening of mystery.  This included stopping in to Papalote - whose name just sincerely rrrrolls off the tongue - and ordering a Mole Chicken quesadilla.  I had heard of people liking this place immensely, saying GO, GO, GO!  But I was like "I've been to taquerias, ya'll.  Just chill."  But THIS taqueria IS different.  It gives you about 12 choices of meat and veggie combos and sorts them in a taco, quesadilla, and burrito menu, making it SUPER EASY to order if you're at all fucked up or stupid.  I cannot wait to go back - seriously the menu is so organized and beautiful it's plain disgusting.  But really, Papalote is plaing GO-OOO-OOD, mang.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Salsa is pureed and spicy - satisfying with lots of umami. Like a sauce at an Indian buffet. Not really Mexican, but fine. Not worth $7 per jar by any means.

Menu is absurdly, ridiculously, outlandishly overpriced. $9 plain burrito. Enough said.

Food itself never, ever rises above mediocre. Ever. Take the grilled chicken - tasteless and dry, except for the burnt bits. Really subpar. I've had better at airport Chilis.

For Marina tourists only.
author: Justin W.

description: Great place to get some mexican food. Staff is nice and friendly but parking is the hardest thing to find.
author: Anthony V.

description:
NEWS FLASH: Papalote unapologetically increases Guacamole to $5 per thimble after the California avocado crop is devastated by January's deep freeze.  

"Guacamole: A.Q."

That's what it says on the menu board at Papalote.  Because of the volatile global price of avocados, a lump of freeze-dried guac is available only at market rates.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
Favorite burrito joint in SF that I visit on a frequent basis. Not as authentic as El Farolito, but this Yuppified burrito is still tasty.

+Seafood options on top of normal meat choices (Get the fish)
+Tortilla chips and amazing salsa that comes with every burrito
+Ingredients are top notch compared to some other competitors
-Seating is quite difficult to come by if you come during rush hour.

A must-go.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
BIG price, SMALL burrito. not as good as expected, based on the 100s of reviews. we ordered: 

1. carne asada burrito 
2. fish taco. 

burrito- wrap to stuffing ratio was off- too much wrap. mid-sized burrito, not the juicy fat type with thin skin.
fish taco- plain, but the fish was marinated well.
chips and salsa- chips were the thick kind, and salsa was liquidy, quite tasty, but left me craving the usual fresh, chunky salsa im used to.
price- higher than others. ~7.15 burrito, $6.75 fish taco.

this place is above average, but i enjoy El Farolito much more, or El Gruyense in Redwood City
author: Lina C.

description:
Really can't figure out why this place is highly rated.
First, let's start with the food. We tried the chicken burrito and the carne asada burrito. It's really...Meh - not bad but very average burrito.  Definitely not a $9, 10 burrito though. Nothing compared to SoCal burritos.   
Second, the orange sauce - pretty good. It's different, it's spicy, and it's tiny. You only get one little cup of sauce for your your burrito and your chips. It costs you extra if you want more. Speaking of chips - not that great, had better.  
Third, the wait - probably got more popular after the tv show. but this place is pretty small, hence the wait is definitely long. I highly recommend trying other taquirias - esp if the wait is long. 
This place is over-rated.
author: MissJ J.

description:
Remember how Super Mario Brothers came out and you saved up your money for what felt like years (reality: 2 weeks) and your parents finally bought you Nintendo and you thought it was the coolest game ever? Then after you won it for the 94th time, you heard that Super Mario 2 was coming out and you were even more excited. You opened the package, you blew air down the edge of the cartridge to make sure it would work properly the first time, and you stuck it in. You began playing and noticed the differences immediately. The background pops out more. The characters MOVE differently. Yet it wasn't as enticing as the first one. 

Papalote is Super Mario Brothers 2. 

It's a great place, it fills the stomach and the salsa is everything you could hope for and more (finally, someone who makes something relatively spicy!) But after the build up over the past few years, it just didn't live up to my expectations. The products are super fresh, but something just felt missing. 

My heart still lies with El Taqueria, but I would never turn down a chance to come back here. I was full for at LEAST 45 minutes after eating here. That could be a record.
author: Jared S.

description:
If I ate food, which I don't, and I wanted some Mexican, which I rarely do, and I didn't want to gain 6,000lbs. for the impending winter, which I wouldn't -- well, then I would come to Papalote and order some Soyrizo in my burrito.

Hold the beans.  Hold the tortilla.  Hold the cheese.  Hold the sour cream.

Cause what's better and lower in fat than fake innards made of soy on a plate?

Delish.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I've been transitioning to a vegan diet (in other words, i eff up alot and catch myself with a cheesy slice o' pizza and a reg. latte every now and again), and its hard peoples, really HARD to eat out if you have a restrictive diet.  That being said, Papalote is making my life easier in oh so many ways - their soyrizo (taco, burrito, whatevs) is amazing as is the marinated tofu burrito.  I love the chips, I love the salsa, and they are even starting to recognize me when i go in, which makes me happy.  

I want to be clear on this - even if you are not a veg/vegan, this place is delicious.  hear me?  word.
author: Karen K.

description:
This food was amazing! I got the shrimp burrito and it was the most delicious shrimp burrito I've ever had. My friend got the chicken mole, and that was delicious too. They have amazingly fresh and tasty guac. And lots of Mexican drink choices to choose from.

They even messed up on my burrito and forgot to make it. So I was waiting for 30 minutes for no reason whatsoever. I told them about it, and they told me they'd make it right away, and I got it in 5 minutes, which was nice. They were super apologetic, apologized to me 3 times even as we were leaving, which was pretty nice. But it was well worth waiting 35 minutes because it tasted heavenly, haha. I kind of wish they gave me a free drink or something to make up for it, but oh well...
author: Xavier G.

description:
So my mission for today was to somehow take my stink-ass rotten-for-a-personal-day mood and turn it around.

First step: Retail therapy at H&M.
Second step: Burrito as big as my head from Papalote.
Third step: Drink until I can't remember my name at DYL.

Papalote is deliciosa. I miss living by it, because parking tends to be trying around there. But today I wanted, no NEEDED, a super chicken burrito from Papalote. And I didn't know it would be part of the deal, but the burrito maker was smiling and dancing as he one after another assembly-lined those delicious (and massive) bits of goodness. Watching him completely enjoying his job totally turned my stink-ass mood around. 

The chicken is grilled to perfection with I don't know what kinds of spices, but I'm not questioning, just keep up the good work. The guacamole actually tastes like avocados, so you know it's got to be fresh. The homemade chips never seem to make it home with me, I eat them all up in the car on the way back.

And the roasted red pepper salsa is better than sex.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I hate to be a pooh-pooher. I'm usually a positive person. But I just can't like Papalote as much as everyone says they do. I don't understand it. Despite all those cheery colored tiles, I've gotten mildly depressed the times I've eaten there because I felt like I wasted the opportunity to have really satisfying cheap Mexican food.

And I'm into healthy food. Healthful. Whatever. But healthful and tasty are not mutually exclusive. It was like a homework assignment swallowing the last bites of those two dry tortillas covered in soggy bland vegetables. I don't think salt adds calories or takes away PC points. If you think I'm being mean and unfair just skip to one of the hundreds of happy-times reviews about this place. And I haven't had the burritos, which could be a whole other story...
author: Katrina D.

description:
Chip Stingy!

So you know, each person gets 1 bowl of chips and 1 cup of their wildly delicious salsa per order. If you want more you have to pay $1.50. 

I love the super fish tacos (no sour cream) from Papalote. My husb and I share one order and are both full after. Yesterday I decided to try the bean and cheese dip which turns out to be refried black beans with melted cheese. I asked if it came with a large bowl of chips and the gal at the counter ensured it did. So by my calculations we ordered two items for two people, one of which was supposed to have lots of chips. We got one bowl before the tacos and another bowl, same size with the dip. I kept asking the busser for another bowl but he knows the rules so he ignored my pleas. When I went to the counter the gal said they only have one size bowl. I reminded her she had said it came with a large serving of chips but that went right past her. She gave me another bowl but I could see contempt in her eyes as she handed it to me. Here's the thing, what is dip for if not chips? Secondly, the price for beans and cheese with a small bowl of chips would be fair at $3.50, still a huge mark-up. The actual price of $6.50 is just dumb, especially considering you don't get any type of garnish or extra chips. It's literally a plate of beans with melted cheese. Don't bother with this menu item. 

I'm giving this place 4 stars because the tacos and salsa are so good. They loose a star for being stingy.
author: Maria G.

description:
