Second visit to Papalote and still happy with their quality and taste.   On my first try I had the Soyrizo Burrito per my bf's suggestion.  It was filling, tasty and I was surprised how Soyrizo tasted like Chorizo.  On this trip, I wanted to try something new and different.   I believe I had mole sauce before but not knowing that Chocolate was one of the main ingredients.   Thanks to all those food traveling shows I was anxious to test out their mole sauce with Tofu.  BTW, you can also order the mole sauce with chicken.  I know this is weird but I don't like to have rice or beans in my burrito (I guess I'm more of a fajita girl) so I usually add sour cream and guacamole instead. 

On my first bite i was pleasantly surprised by the sweet taste of the mole sauce.  You can taste the chocolate!   The sour cream and guacamole did not overwhelm the mole sauce at all.   I actually finished the burrito since I kept wanting the taste of the mole sauce.  Now I'm going to try mole sauce at different restaurant to see if what I had was the real thing.   

The homemade salsa was not too spicy but complimented the chips and burritos very well.   You can even buy a jar of the salsa for $5.99.   It's that good.
author: Morgan L.

description: Rip off, only popular due to the food channel, stingy on chips & salsa w/ no refills. Specialty burritos $20 and it's not big. Leave this place for the locals and tourist. For the rest, goto a REAL Taqueria!
author: Cee B.

description: Heard all the hype about this place, so we had to try it. For some reason I wasn't in the mood for a burrito so I ordered the quesadillas. They were very, very good...but nothing that blew my mind. Maybe I should have gone the burrito route? Either way, a way more than solid option for some good, quick grub when in the area.
author: Caroline G.

description:
I liked Papalote, but after some investigation, I learned that they use flour tortillas from Sonoma Valley Foods, Inc. that contain partially hydrogenated oil.  Partially hydrogenated oil is an unnatural substance created through a chemical process that is used because it is cheap and has very long shelf life.  It raises bad LDL cholesterol and lowers good HDL cholesterol.  it is the only substance on earth that does this.  Bacon grease raises LDL cholesterol, but it also raises or leaves flat HDL cholesterol.

Partially hydrogenated oil has been linked to heart disease, heart attacks, diabetes, liver disease, and other diseases.   One 2007 study found, each 2% increase in the intake of energy from trans unsaturated fats, as opposed to that from carbohydrates, was associated with a 73% greater risk of ovulatory infertility.

A Spanish study showed that Increased consumption of partially hydrogenated oil increased the risk of clinically diagnosed major depressive disorder by 48%.

Another study found that trans fat and partially hydrogenated oil increases weight gain and abdominal fat more than eating the same amount of calories in regular saturated fat like bacon, lard, butter, etc.  It is WORSE for you than just about anything.

Another study found that increased intake of partially hydrogenated oil increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

This restaurant has a $20 burrito.  It's not cheap for a hole in the wall place.  It is criminal that they charge a lot for their food and then use the cheapest possible ingredients.  If they use cheap ingredients like tortillas with partially hydrogenated oil and preservatives, then why not just go to Taco Bell where they use the same unnatural chemical ingredients, but give you a big break on the price.

Some people will eat food that contains chemicals that have been shown to cause health problems because it's cheaper and they want to get a cheap price and they are willing to take the chance.  But to pay high prices for such bad ingredients is just not right.
author: Sean O.

description: The home made salsa just hits the spot . I usually leave with a jar! The burrito is delicious and done right . Good and fresh ingredients . I also like that they have a frequency card ... Way to keep you coming back but I'm sure the main reason is going to be for their food !!
author: Judy C.

description:
I don't understand why my friends like this place.
Mediocre food.
Nasty, "you're lucky to be eating here" attitude & not worth the price.
There are TONS better within blocks.
author: Geordie E.

description:
After a year I came back. Friendly, well prepared, tasty. During a pickup, I saw a server disinfect her hands - nice touch!

previous 1-star review:

Phone Conversation:

Me: I would like to order fish taco's  with extra salsa.
Papalote: Anything else?
Me: Yes, I didn't get my extra salsa yesterday so I'd like you to not charge me for it today.
Papalote: We can't do that, sir.
Me: Wha? I still have the receipt from yesterday.
Papalote: You have to bring the bag back so we can check.
Me: Cancel my order, then.

In fact, cancel my next 100 orders. That is how many time's I've eaten there in the last couple years. There is a kid there who always - and I mean *always* comes up short on my orders. I guess he doesn't like me. Oh well. 

Papalote. Decent food. But, be on your best behavior, or they won't let you eat it
author: iko o.

description:
This place was off the hook.. I was sitting at home not knowing about this place until i seen the place on Throw Down With Bobby Flay. After kicking Bobby Flay's butt my girlfriend and I decided to hit this place up for some Burritos. When we got there we noticed the place was not that big inside but it wasn't a problem because i've eaten in smaller places. After ordering one "triple threat burrito" and one prawn burrito the kind lady sat us down at a table and gave us some chips with this very very good salsa.

While waiting for our food i looked over to the table next to us and noticed the guy sitting at the next table was one of the owners that was on Throw Down With Bobby Flay he was conversating with one of the customers and it made me feel good that he took time to just sit down with one of his cusomers to shoot the breeze...

Our food came and we start eating and i must say that the food was very good. I am so proud to be from San Francisco where the mexican food is great and this place takes the cake when it comes to taste.
author: DANNY B.

description:
Once upon a time I wrote a glowing review for Papalote.  You can read it.   I once gave Papalote 4 stars.  It's beneath the astrix.

Here is my updated review for Papalote.

I took a good friend of mine who lives in Oakland, has a kid and never gets out of the house to the Mission.  We had an erreand to run but she was craving a good Mission Burrito.  Said friend is vegan, so I suggested Papalote, since they have tofu options, soyrizo, and vegan mole. 

We get there and decide to split the veggie fajitas with a side of guac, a side of soyrizo (for her) and some shrimp for me.  So I order and the total comes to 22 BUCKS!  Without drinks.  But whatever.  I tell her it's really good and I fork over some money.  So the food is brought out and I get the shrip and I say FUCK--what I really wanted was Prawns.  
Maybe it's due to me being an unsophisticted Mid-westerner, but I ordered shrimp not expecting them to be those tiney nasty thing but the big jumbo ones.  

I went to the counter and told the manager and he said tough luck.  I was kind of incredulous.  You think if someone has just spent a shitload of money--22 BUCKS for ONE MEAL at a fucking taqueria you could throw three prawns at them.  he was just an asshole and said you ordered wrong too bad.  So I walked back and spit out my WINE AND BUTTER soaked nasty ass shrimp that had no flavor.  

Then they brought the fajitas out and they gave us ONE tortilla and I was so pissed by then I couldn't even complain for fear they guy would be like--"well it only comes with one tortilla--tough."

So I left the place so pissed because I really wanted my FAVORITE taqueria to be my friend's favorite new place and maybe she would like it enough to come into the city more.

I was so upset that I decided to call the manager--who was the rude guy to complain--and guess what he was a dick then too.  I even told him that it was my favorite taqueria and instead of eating near my school in Potrero Hill sometimes--there are porbably 20 taqueria between it and Papalote I truck there.  

I was a regular customer--but that's what shitty customer service can do.  I'll miss you Papalote--or at least your PRAWNS.

I

**************************************************************************



At Papalote i like to order a plate with shrimp (STRIKE THIS APPARANTLY THEY ARE PRAWNS), beans, rice and guac.

That's it.

It's really good and filling.  It ends up being more expensive than an acutal burrito which is annoying.    However I keep ordering it like that, because that's how I like to eat it.

Their beans are the best--and vegan too which pleases many of my picky picky friends.  I like to take out and eat on the steps of the scary church with the big neon cross across Valencia Street.
author: Biggie M.

description:
Papalote is the perfect joint for the hungry. The burrito is humongous! I got the marinated tofu burrito and it lasted for 2 days! It was good cold too ;). 

I was going to get the carne asada, just because I can roll my 'R' like nobody's business, but decided to go on the healthy's side. It was not disappointing let me tell u. Get the super burrito. It's worth it. 

They give u the chips and salsa for appetizer. The salsa was hot!! Really hot. Me likie long time ;).

The place a bit on the small size but it wasn't busy when I was there. Next time I'm totally gonna try the soyrizo. Oh, did I tell u the burrito is huuuge?! Or the fact I can say "I would like one caRne asada, please."
author: Perry S.

description:
ok, there's not much need for another review of this place, so this is short and vegetarian oriented:
1) soyrizo, yummy, but really really filling.  Watch out.
2) delicious salsa but yu get about a shot-glass's worth, and they charge you for more.  Booo
3) Grilled tofu:  Yummy,  not as filling as soyrizo.
4) Bathrooms:  Nasty!
author: Ali M.

description:
Yummy fresh and Delish Dishes!

Great ambiance at this wonderful! Mission spot - 
Food is fresh and light meaning you can down an entire burrito and not have to be rolled out the door.  You can walk, or even skip out, as I often do.

I had the Tacos with Prawns; crunchy lettuce and veggies with tasty sea friends.  Granted it can be quite difficult to find icky Mexican in the Mission, but if you are looking for fun, light and yummy place (with larger than life Dragonfly and Frog hanging from the Ceiling - dont see THAT every day) that check out popopole - i mean papeelite - wait its papa...just go there okay.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Although it's far too inconsistent to earn five stars, Papalote serves up some tasty food. This place is the heart of gringo Mexican food in SF -- the only Mexicans you'll find are the ones working behind the counter. Still, a lot of their food is very tasty provided they don't screw up your order or make it too sloppily. 

I recommend the fish burrito -- it's sautéed in butter and wine and tastes delicious. The fish really carries the flavor of the rest of the ingredients and doesn't leave you feeling lethargic afterwards. The orange salsa they serve with their chips is also excellent although the chips are usually stale :(
author: Aaron V.

description:
Consistently one of the best burrito places I go to. You can taste all the fresh ingredients in their burritos. I also like that they cook the meat to order, so it's always nice and tender. 

The wait after you order is kinda long, but the taste/quality of the food more than makes up for it.

I'll definitely keep coming back to this spot.
author: Ian C.

description:
They definitely lived up with the hype of Awesome Burrito and Salsa. It's no wonder this place is always crowded. Don't be fooled by the lack of Latino customers in the resto, because they will still please your craving. 

Burrito - The Carne Asada, Chile Verde, and Pollo were all very tasty. Put a dollop of the salsa and you'll be in purgatory. I love it! 

Shrimp Taco - the shrimp were not fresh and this taco creation with bell peppers just didn't please my palate at all. (the only turn off)

Salsa - You can taste the freshness of the roasted tomatoes and the spiciness of the pepper. It has a great kick. The only salsa that can top this is La Vics in San Jose. I love it! 

Chicken Adobo meat - one of the staff gave me a small sample taste of their secret choice of meat. It tasted more like Paksiw to my Filipino tongue than Adobo. It's still pretty tasty but I'd rather have white rice with it. 

Price - It's more expensive than other taquerias in the Mission but it's worth it. (They need to be more generous on their salsa!) 

Staff - The owners were mingling with the people in line and all the staff members were genuinely nice!
author: Hebert J.

description:
A white-washed tacqueria owned and run by Mexicans; go figure...it's still great.

If other taquerias in the city, like El Castillito, were home-slobs sporting a greasy wife-beater, then Papalote would be their alluring and demure cousin.  I remember the first time I stumbled upon this modern-looking, hipster tacqueria on a night roaming the Outer Mission.  Hipster places springing up in the Mission is akin to pissing on gremlins: I guess only children of the 80's may get this reference.  I was mildly surprised by the interesting 'Mexicant' menu, including healthy options like soyrizo and vegan mole. I was even more surprised after having a burrito there, that I not only liked it...I loved it.

Myself, being a carnivore, love all of the meaty servings that they have to offer.  I personally love their Carne Asada and Chile Verde Burritos.  They are very flavorful, and not heavy at all: A combination in a burrito that you would think would cause a paradox that would unravel space-time.  However, it all works to me, and it doesn't feel I ate a truck when I leave.  Also, their Salsa is deserving of all the accolodates that it receives.

Delicious and health-conscious food, reminds me of what I miss about the city the most.
author: Satoru Y.

description:
Ohhhh baby I had some delish fish tacos for dinner last night. Sauteed in butter and wine, wrapped in soft corn tortillas with salsa fresca, sour cream and guacamole on top... hmm... I think I'm ready for Round 2.

I've been meaning to hit up Papalote for a while now, because it looked so damn cute. Forget cute - this place is scrumptious! The food tastes fresh, not heavy and greasy. In addition to my fish tacos, I had bites of a quesadilla, burrito, and chicken taco, so I got pretty good sampling of the menu. Now I just need to try some of their veggie/vegan options like tofu tacos or a soyrizo burrito (how awesome is it that they offer these things!?). As a self-proclaimed breakfast burrito connoisseur, breakfast offerings all day are also highly appreciated.

A definite new favorite for Mexican food in San Francisco.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I hail from a city which borders East Los Angeles.  What does this mean?  It means I eat a shitload of Mexican food.  I like all of it, including the somewhat more obscure fare like menudo and lengua (tongue).  My best friend who is Mexican won't even eat lengua.  She claims I am browner than she is (I am yellow).

On a recent weekend jaunt to the bay area, the aforementioned friend and her bf asked me what I wanted for dinner Saturday night.  After a couple days of light meals, I was ready for something that would leave me full for the rest of the week.  Thus, I suggested Mexican food.  First we tried to get to some spot that supposedly features bomb ass carne asada burritos, but alas, they are only open for lunch.  So we traipsed on over to Papalote, which they assured would be just as good.

Upon arriving, the place was way packed.  Albeit a small space, that shit was pretty ridiculous.  The way it works is, you order at the counter.  As my friends and I were dining in, we proceeded to wait in the doorway, watching like hawks at people who are taking their sweet ass time eating, finally scrambling when a couple leave only to sit down at their dirty table.  Btw, it took us roughly 30 minutes after ordering to get a table.  And apparently, if you're dining in and aren't seated, they won't bring out your food (which means it was probably ready a while ago and is now getting cold).  However, this is hearsay, and as Lavar Burton would say, "you don't have to take my word for it".

Wow, I haven't even reviewed the food yet.  It's subpar and the best way to describe it is glorified Baja Fresh.  I'll even say that BF is tastier, and without the gaggle of hipsters and long ass wait.  I had shrimp marinated in butter and something else tacos and a side of rice.  The shrimp was so disappointing, lacking flavor and spice.  The side of rice could feed four people.  Too bad it was super dry and needed a load of lime and salsa to punch it up. 

I'll agree with everyone else that the salsa was good, but that was the only thing remotely noteworthy.
author: Karen T.

description:
Soyrizo!!!  & Tofu Mole! It is a vegetarian/vegan dream. It is not authentic Mexican food but it is the next best thing.  The salsa is wonderful & creamy, a nice change to the standard salsa. The downfall...I have seen a cockroach crawling around on the inside of the window, while I ate (but that is why 3 stars only). But lets get real for a  second,  aren't cockroaches everywhere? Also sometimes the line is long or there is a lack of seating.

in summary:
healthy,
tasty,
veg friendly,
cheap, 
and worth your visit (and sometimes wait)
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I hath my friends who go ape shit for this place. Flipping ape shit. They say "Braden you MUST go to Paplote- it's the best Mexican food in the Mission, the best Mexican food in the CITY!" So - I grab a foodie friend of mine who also hasn't tried this place and we bee-bop over there. It's conviently close to BART and it smells great when you walk in the door. 

So my foodie friend "foodgasms" over the fish tacos- she says- 4 stars- I say 3 because I don't do fish, and even though the food is cheap - for SF standards, my food was blah, bland, and just not impressive enough to rock the vote as the "Best Mexican" food in SF. 

Salsa was actually the best I have tasted in SF. We have an issue with salsa in the city folks. There IS NO GOOD SALSA here- ok, well, there's GOOD salsa, but is there AMAZING APE SHIT salsa!???? If you've found it PLEASE let me know!
author: Braden B.

description:
Papalote has several features that set it apart from other Mission burrito joints:
1) it seems very clean and seeing a cockroach is highly unlikely
2) the space is slightly modern and interesting
3) I get the distinct impression that roving mariachi bands never come in here (I could be wrong)
4) They just plonk the burrito down on a plate - no foil

I miss the foil (it keeps the burrito from exploding out the bottom), and I do like roving bands of mariachis. I also wish they had more meat options, and no, "soyrizo" does not count. I like the chile verde, but I want some carnitas and/or al pastor. I guess they are trying to do a lighter version of burritos, which is okay, but I'd still rather have the carnitas at La Taqueria or the pastor at El Toro. Still, they make good tasting food, the salsa is great, and the no cockroach thing is always a plus.
author: Andy M.

description:
5 stars for their amazing salsa and the freshness. 
Minus 2 stars for being soooooo stingy.
author: Kiera H.

description:
Insane waits sometimes. Cramped. Yeah, the food can be good. But here's my bitch: They are chip nazis. And salsa skinflints. 

Should you dine there by yourself you're served a smallish bowl of quite good home-made chips and a sidecar of their own salsa roja, which is delicious and tastes of creamy roasted pepper. If you want more of these inexpensive staples (and who eats mexican food without a liberal serving of both? Not me.) Should you dare go there with 2-3 friends, you'll get the same one piddle-fart of chips and salsa. Now if I go there with a group, we say nothing to each other in line and get seperate numbers. 

$7 for a burrito, I'm damn sure getting my own chips and salsa.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Wow. I guess I've got it kinda off compared to the majority of reviews, but when I want taqueria food, I want the flavorful, tasty, heavy, good stuff. If you want a healthy quality burrito then go to a tex-mex place like Rubios.

First off, they don't have AC! Which restaurant would do that in the mission? Their service is okay. They kept skipping our table and giving comp chips and salsa to people who walked in after us. When we finally got our order, they gave it to us in a to-go box when we ordered dine-in.  The serving was very meager: barely any carne asada. And what's with the no guacamole and sour cream? $7.75 Nachos would give me ALL the fixins at another taqueria AND it would taste better. Their water cups are TINY. 

Not impressed at all.
author: Geralyn Y.

description: Great burritos and lots of choices (salsa, tortilla, meat, etc.).  Haven't had good Mexican food for quite a while since I just relocated back to the US, but Papalote is a must!  Had the Carne Asada Super Burrito...and I would get it again!
author: Timothy G.

description: Great salsa but otherwise underwhelming. It took a pretty long time for a couple of burritos to come out, and the meat was not as tender and flavorful as compared to your average taqueria. Not sure what all the hype is about...other than the salsa...
author: Rudolph R.

description:
I think it's hard to balance Healthy Mexican with Soupy Zesty Rar Mexican, and Papalote I think is pretty dang good at it.  

Very fresh ingredients and yet still has that satisfying umph.

Lots of vegetarian choices, lean meats, succulent camarones, and that famous pureed salsa. Only downer today was the chips were fried in either ollllld veggie oil or else meat oil.  Bleh.

Hey, Matt Gonzalez was there today for lunch.  That means something, right?  :)
author: Melanie C.

description: Can you say AMAZING?! First off, I love love love their salsa! Though it is inconsistent with the texture and the level of spicyness, I still give it a two thumbs up because its perfect with my chips and burrito!  I had the super carnitas burrito with a tomato wrap and it was delicious. The pork was so juicy and tender and the cheese was melted with the sour cream and avocado (I hate places that serve it cold and not melted). Love papalote burritos!
author: Irene L.

description:
The best thing about this place - the salsa. It was spicy and very tasty. The rest of the food was average.

Ordered the gaucamole and marinated veggie fajitas. The guac was not that good - it needed more lime. 

As for the veggie fajitas, the eggplant was not completely cooked and the veggies being marinated in the salsa made no difference to the taste of the vegetables at all.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
I'm spoiled.  This shrine to all food Mexican is less than a block from my apartment.  But the reasons other than proximity for my praise are simple:
-The food is fresh and healthy, void of the "grease sheen" that accompanies other fast-serving Mexican eateries.
-Cheap!  
-Vegetarians, like myself, have more than a cheese quesadilla from which to choose.  In fact, we have a whole smorgasbord of choices!

mmmmmm.........
author: Christine M.

description:
On the recommendation of a local, we headed to Papalote to sample what I've always heard to be superior Mexican food to what we have here in Boston.  

Can I just interject and describe to you how completely obnoxious it is to live in Boston and, on a regular basis, hear San Fransisco transplants berate me about the low quality and in-authenticity of Mexican food in the Northeast?  It seems like every person who has ever even step foot within a 500 mile radius of the Mission district feels obligated to chime in and remind me that, yes, Mexican food in Boston sucks, and Mission burritos are tastier.  After years of this, I began to think that this was, in fact, a fact (yeah, intentional), and that my trip to San Fransisco would give me an epiphany and a fantastic culinary experience to boot.

Back to the task at hand.  I went to the Mission and chose Papalote for my field research, as it seemed to be widely accepted as the "best burrito."  

I should have known that something was awry when the guy at the counter told me they had just whooped Bobby Flay in a Throwdown.  I call this the Flay phenomenon - The inevitable inflow of traffic post-TV-debut brings crowds to a Throwdown winner's establishment that the restaurant perhaps wasn't ready for (or ill-equipped to handle).  I fear this, as a once-fabulous place could go downhill quickly, choosing to ride the popularity wave.

Needless to say, I did not have such a great experience here, and whether it's the show's fault or the restaurant's, I left a bit let down.

The prices are steep - $5.50 for an order of two tacos, and this "famous" burrito now costs $20. WHAT?  What do you put in a burrito to make it $20.  I will tell you this - this place charges extra for cheese, sour cream, and guac, so I'm not sure what's left.

We did not go for the $20 burrito, but we had a more modest $9 version, but did not opt to pay the extra for the dairy and guac.  The burrito (chicken) was, as a result, a bit bland and very dry.  If the burrito only tastes good with these extra-charge add-ons, then why bother making the burrito at all? 

We also had an order of fish tacos, an order of chicken, and an order of beef.  The fish tacos were the only ones that were double-wrapped with two tortillas each, and the other two orders were only single-wrapped.  Is this "authentic"?  I am not sure, as I am not well-versed in corn tortilla etiquette, but I thought the customary-two was the standard.

The sole-double-wrapped fish taco was really wet and drippy, but I enjoyed that the fish wasn't battered and deep fried to the point of nonrecognition.  Rather, the fish in the tacos was abundant, moist, and juicy.  The other two tacos tasted just like each other, and were both very dry.

The best thing about this place was definitely the creamy, spicy salsa that accompanied the chips.  Perhaps this has always been the practice, or maybe it was due to the new-found extreme popularity, but after the first complimentary order, the restaurant charges for refills.  I don't necessarily think that this is a bad practice, just an interesting one I'd not seen before.  Because we bought so much food, however, we were able to get 4 orders of these for free, and I opted to ditch the tacos and make a meal out of chips and salsa.

You can buy this salsa by the jar to go, and had we not been from out of town, I would certainly take advantage of that.

I will say that the employees are ALL extremely friendly.  Everyone is kind, courteous, and polite.  We must have gone at a bizarre hour, because there was no line whatsoever.   Food came out hot and prompt, and I was very pleased with the experience aside from the taste of the food.

I don't think I'd go back, but one great thing did come from the experience.  Now, back at home, when people launch a tirade about how much New England Mexican sucks compared to the beloved Mission Burritos, I am able to smile, nod, and smirk knowingly (and perhaps a bit judgmentally) as they ramble on, while silently thinking that Olecito is better Mexican food than what I found in SF.
author: Heather G.

description:
I was on the quest for an amazing burrito during my two days in SF, and I decided Papalote was the place to get it (based on my Yelp research, of course).

The burrito, while not my Platonic ideal of the perfect burrito, was quite good, especially for its price. I got the Marinated Tofu (it was supposed to be on a spinach tortilla, but it seems that burrito places often advertise burrito flavors they actually don't have). 

The burrito was heavy and warm, filled with tofu, beans, and rice. It was a little different than what I'm used to, but quite enjoyable nonetheless. The salsa was also unusual--rather than resembling pico, it was much smoother and creamier. And, in case people out there judge a burrito joint on its chips, I'd say they were above average. 

All that for $6.30, which is slightly less than the going rate in Atlanta (a much cheaper city overall). The only thing is (and it seems this is common in big cities) there's not much room to sit. So it's best to take it to go.
author: David Z.

description:
This place used to be one of my favorite Mission burrito joints. The salsa is amazing, but otherwise, they've really slipped in the level of quality and flavor of the food. 

Last time I had a fish burrito, there were bitter spots in almost every piece of fish. It's a burrito. Burritos are supposed to be cheap. This place isn't exactly cheap for being in the Mission, so I expect better quality in their ingredients!
author: Jen K.

description:
Hm. This is a tough one for me. The food is so fresh and tasty and the salsa insanely good, but the service, incomprehensibly long wait and nickel-and-diming are absurd.

We came here to grab some food  to-go before Dolores Park Movie Night. Little did we know that it would take 30 MINUTES for our order to be ready. Does it really take that long to make three quesadillas? Really? 

The lady at the cash register is also not friendly. She is the Mexican Food Nazi with scary eyebrows to match. We adore the salsa (shit, I could drink the stuff it's so freakin' good!) and asked for extra chips to go with the jar we were buying. She shook her head, "No extra chips," and told us each little scoop cost $1. $1!!! 

We stood around and watched order after order (by people who ordered AFTER us, by the way) go out the door. But our soyrizo, pollo asado, and chicken mole quesadillas were taking an eternity. 

When we finally got our food 30 minutes later, it was almost worth the wait. ALMOST. The soyrizo quesadilla was excellent. The chicken mole fantastic. But again, the wait cost us better seats for movie night. And let's not forget that the food is over-priced. 

I am going to have to try the one on Fulton. It's closer to where I live and I am hoping the service and wait are better than the Mission location.
author: Jenny K.

description: If you go here you are taking a big risk, as I'm pretty sure they out coke on the food. Once I had dinner here every day, for a week. It took for me to travel abroad to stop going, I'm afraid to go back now...but really want to
author: Diego E.

description:
This isn't just a review of Papalote, it is a  report for a class in Socioanthropolgy ( a dream class, where you wander at will and write a paper ...... THAT is what Yelp is!!!!
It was a perfect day for our biennale trip to the Mission District to investigate the gentrification of SF Distructs  and ti write an article for THe Yelp Anthro Journal.  NO smoke from forest fires was detected, but to make sure we re save from particulates, we took the BART in the morning before anyone burned down another forest.

Gentrification has continued,  This year all The Elderly were killed, or sent to nursing homes in San Leandro.  Coffee Houses now occupy every third shop.  Indian Restaurants, serving  the new drink, Marguerita Lhasi have proliferated.  Alll residential buildings have been repainted, non victorian colors.  However the paint was obviously applied in a very shoddy manner, perhaps sp further gentrification can take place.

The old Mexican Restaurants  have, of course been removed ( to San Leandro, no doubt)  , so the anthopologists went to a nouvelle MexRes, Papalote.

This new style eaterie is like the ubiquitous coffee house.  It is not a restaurant.  You place your order, eg 
 a fish taco  get a place number, find a seat and wait for someone to actually catch a fish ( it took that long.)  This place is great for the
the scientists in our expedition, as we had to share various tables, 
and could mingle with the locals.  They may all be droids, but we did not stay too long to investigate.

On the plus side   of the New Mission read reviews of  the Valencia Farmers Market
author: Elle C.

description:
I have one word to say about Papalote: SOYRIZO

I never knew they could make a fake meat product that actually drips bright orange grease when you eat it. The grease doesn't actually stain your clothes, but it comes close people, it comes close...

Paplote is my go-to place after yoga on Tues. and Thurs. in the Mission. If I am not feeling the soyrizo I can always feed the beast with their amazing marinated tofu tacos. And I love, love, love the salsa they serve with their chips.

There is also more traditional Mexican fare, including the obligatory dead animals for those who like to eat them. Prices are about the same as other Mexican joints in the Mission, maybe a buck or two higher.

Papalote loses two stars because:

1. They can be extremely agro about kicking you out about 10 seconds after they close.

2. They made fun of my white friend for being Whitey Whiterson, in Spanish, not knowing that Mr. Whiterson actually speaks Spanish. Not cool.
author: Angie R.

description:
I have gotten various food from them four times now.

The food is very fresh, and very good.  Portions are fair-sized/large, so you will most likely get enough to eat without having to order more sides than normal.  I think this is the best "taqueria" I get food from in SF--if you base best on the food quality/taste.

But, there are two not-so-pleasant things about this place.  First, their offerings are more expensive than the typical taqueria.  It is not 10X the price, but the percentage difference is substantial.  Second, *every time* I have been there, there was a long line.  And irritating people standing in it who do not take the time, while they are waiting in line, to figure out what they want.  So they get up to the register and . . .  You know who you are . . . And you are *not* cute enough for the rest of us not to be pissed at you.

The second is a big issue for me, as I am usually driving home and trying to pick something up along the way (the long wait combined with the bad parking in that area is no fun).  Do yourself a favor and call in your order (I did that the last two times).  Depending on what is going on, you still have to wait--but you will wait far less.  I have never even thought to do this for a taqueria, but I can learn new things.
author: Sir Y.

description:
mad props for feeding my department on e-day.
the food was yummy, and not to mention we had a huge variety of it!
it was like a plethora of quesdillas, i was so happy.
beef, chicken, soyrizo, veggie...

i liked the veggie the best.
i haven't actually been inside the restaurant itself, my co-worker picked up the food and brought it back to work.

Papalote's, I SALUTE YOU! Thank you for supporting our hardworking department. =)
author: Susy C.

description:
Prawn tacos were amazing.  This is the kind of food that tastes good and makes you feel good too.  No overdoing with the lard.  People were friendly, and there was a good vibe on a rainy Saturday afternoon.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Dina B.

description: 3 stars for the salsa and the service but 2 stars for the food. I was really disappointed in the food because I've been hearing how wonderful this place is for years, and the food is just average. How can you make a chili verde burrito so average? Basically it comes down to this: Salsa good. Food blah.
author: Sheila T.

description:
This is my first experience here and this is how it went:

Short wait in the cold. No problem though as it reminded me of home. Read the easy menu and went for it. A Chile Verde burrito and a Carne Asada quesadilla. The pork in the burrito was incredible! Seriously, not like shredded chicken at other places in town, but big tasty moist pieces that were fantastic for a $5 meal. The steak in the quesadilla (a little on the small side) was done extremely well. Typically, strips of steak tend to get overcooked and tough but these folks did it right with every piece. 

The salsa that was brought to the table was different. Incredibly tasty and just enough spice. I had never had anything like it and would buy the stuff by the jar...better yet, by the case! 

Can't wait to go back again.
author: Gabriel R.

description: Luv Papalote.. The quesadilla is the bomb!! Ohh., don't forget the salsa, to die for!! Luvv itt!! :))
author: Chrissy T.

description: This is my go-to Mexican restaurant. Always crowded and pretty small but worth it. I love the free chips and salsa and all the usual suspects (tacos, burritos and quesadillas) are very good. I try to get something new everytime as they have a nicely varied selection of ingredients. Wish they would open more stores.
author: Dave B.

description:
I was never thrilled with their mole, and their breakfast burrito was way too salty for my tastes--possibly worse than Chipotle, which says a lot.  Still, they're unique in their offerings; the chips are great, as is their in-house salsa; and not counting the usual beans, rice and salsa burrito, there are just too few mexican joints with such a large menu for the veggie crowd.  

I've always considered Mariachi's, just a BART stop away, the place to satiate any vegetarian burrito craving in the Mission.  But Papalote is a close second.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
This place is the bomb for all the right reasons. BUT how come  whether I show up alone or with 2 friends we get 1 salsa and 1 bowl of chips ?  If we ask for more we get charged. The only way around this is to order seperatly and pretend you are alone. Then you each get chips and salsa. Boom Boom Boom !!!

Leave some cash on the table for the fellas running food. They work their asses off.
author: Joe G.

description:
I miss you grilled Prawn Burrito!

And roasted Salsa... Come to LA, and I will give you a dollar!!!

Refried Black Beans, lets make out.
author: Ashley J.

description: There are so many options in this city for great burritos, but Papalote is the best!  Their amazing salsa sets them apart from every other place out there.  My favorite dish here is the chicken mole burrito, super.  I'm a fan of ordering ahead and taking a jar of their salsa back with me.  Enjoy!
author: Deborah E.

description: Dunno about the burritos, but the salsa is fucking delicious.
author: Bernard W.

description: The girl at the register had very bad attitudes. This needs the manager's attention!
author: Hieu P.

description:
As a vegetarian of ethics and not of revulsion, Papalote's soyrizo burrito hits my niche-taste with gusto. 

I have never tried anything else there, and probably will never care to. In this case, that's a compliment..
author: Fernando V.

description:
I had been told that Papalote is "food of the gods."

I finally checked it out, and cannot fully concur.

It IS tasty, and it ISN'T greasy (which I appreciate), but I'm not entirely sure that it was worth the half hour wait for take-out on a Wednesday night
author: Leslie F.

description:
P-lote is a good burrito, but by no means is it great.  For SF, this is definitely one of the top three burritos i have had (i made the two burritos that were better), but it is in no way worth the money you will spend on it.  I guess its normal for SF carne asada burritos to not come with guacamole, but where i come from, that is an integral part of the burrito!  To get a carne asada burrito with guacamole will cost you near 8 bucks... for that i would rather buy 15 frozen burritos at Lucky's, they're almost as good! P-lote does have very good salsa, congrats...

"Son of a bitch Riggs!"
Danny Glover
author: John B R.

description:
Some may disrespect Papalote 'cause it's "inauthentic" -- I don't care, nor do I even know what that means in the context of a bastardized hybrid such as the Burrito.  Papalote should offer a great burrito, it wins "burrito of the year" in the weeklies all the time, and there's a line out the door most nights.  Sadly though, it offers only a middling burrito, elements of which are excellent, but which overall fails to hold together (literally if you order in house and the unwrapped log is served to you on a plate).

What do I mean, how can I blaspheme so?  What I mean is that the rice is often clumpy and unspiced, the beans mediocre at best, there's sometimes odd "salt strata" in the filling, the lines are murder - cramped, endless murder, the prices are a bit dear, and worst of all, I've been given stale chips of several occasions [ the stale chip problem seems to have vanished as of 8/1/07].   As for the good, vegans can eat here (which seems to make them happy at least), they make a tasty mole chicken/tofu filling and the meat grilled to order is a fine touch(though marinating the beef would improve it greatly), the salsa is good (not the amazing miracle some claim, but tasty).

Thus, I approve on principle and like some touches (the owner is a nice guy as well), but since they don't really need my approval, or my burrito dollar, and there are some intolerable inconsistencies at Papalote, I'm going elsewhere these days.
author: Gustie L.

description: I have been to El Papalote a few times. If you order grilled chicken or beef burritos, this place is clearly a 4/5. I like that you can make it super for 99 cents, which includes guacamole, cheese, and sour cream. The complementary chips and salsa are great. I am not a fan of the chicken mole burrito. It lacks flavor. The time I had one, my beans were a bit under cooked, the rice mushy, and the mole flavor not present at all.
author: Angelica S.

description:
Everyone raves about the salsa and rightfully so.  Others bitch that  if you want extra, you pay extra.  Please, it's fifty cents more and worth every penny.  Unlike any other salsa I've tasted.  Hotness varies each visit.

I find the food hit or miss.  The carne asada is bland and tough.  Shrimp tacos are the same.  Tortillas are the stiff, packaged variety.

The chile verde is delicious and now my favorite item on the menu.  I've tasted the fish tacos and not a fishy taste or smell about them.  A friend gives raves to the veggie burrito.  The chilaquiles are divine.

Papalote is located in what I call N'mission -- on the edge of Noe and the Mission.  If you're not into kids, then beware of the Noe Stroller Set.  They can overtake the place with often times not so well-behaved children.  Or clueless parents.  And why oh why can't they leave their strollers on the sidewalk?  The place is tiny enough.

Only a few tables in the joint, so you usually have to hover over diners like a vulture and swoop in as soon as one is free.
author: Liz P.

description:
Dont buy into the hype. This place is straight up disgusting.. 

We got 2 orders of tacos with chicken and steak:

Extremely dry overcooked chewy meat ( yuck )
Tacos basically come with lettuce and tomatoes, whats mexican about that? Sounds more like Mexican McDonalds. Lettuce was wilted and wet. Tomatoes smelled like they were sitting for a couple of days in a half cool fridge..
 Ordered a side of beans, waited for about 10 min while tacos got cold. On top of that they put some watery red crap on the plate, which made tacos soggy and looking red ( double yuck !! )

I ate steak ( which was also very dry ) and beans, since I was very hungry and we already dropped $$ on the beer.

If you want good mexican food go to either Regalito, Napolito or Chilango.

 Papalote is putrid..
author: farid a.

description:
The healthier, fresher, 'whiter' alternative to a taqueria. Still delicious, but I must admit I prefer a little more grease in my tacos.  

They do have the best salsa in the city.
author: Shayna N.

description:
I have eaten approximately 300 burritos in my life.  These are consistently the best ones.

Salsa has been one of my top 5 favorite condiments of all time for about 15 years.  This is the best salsa I have ever had.

Mole sauce is the way to my heart.  I am waiting for Papalote to propose.

Also, they have beer.

I have nothing more to say, really.
author: Laura F.

description:
I started going to Papalote over a year ago and loved it so much I ate here once a week.  As a vegetarian burritos can be bland but even their bean and cheese burritos are far from bland.  My only complaint is that they grill the tortillas but maybe that's too much to ask.  Their salsa is extraordinary.  I think this place survives off of the sheer awesomeness of it's salsa(chips are good too).  I totally love that they have vegan options like their beans(all of which are vegan), soyrizo, and tofu.  The downside is waiting in line in the cold and their curmudgeonly staff.  

p.s.  I usually order it to go and they have always gotten my order right on.  But if you're eating there the burritos come unwrapped(no foil) so you eat them with a knife and fork.  I prefer a hand held burrito.
author: Joni S.

description:
Who your papa? 

Say what? 

Who your papa?

PAPALOTE!!!! 

No, I wasn't a cheerleader in my past (or current life), but if eating at Paplote's somehow came down to cheerleading for a burrito, I would do it. Somehow I don't think one will ever have to don short skirts to eat here, but just for the record, I would. In a heartbeat. But anyway...

This is my favorite spot in the Mission (SF, for that matter) for a burrito. When I have visitors seeking culinary delights I take 'em here. The veggie burrito, loaded with potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots, is ama-to-the-zing. Add a little Paplote original spicy sauce, and you've got yourself a tastebud explosion! I love, love the sauce. It's spicy and delightful, and whether you're putting it on chips, a veggie burrito, fish tacos, or carne asada, it's the bomb. 

Don't be put off by the line or the small size of the restaurant. I've never had to wait more than 10 minutes to place my order, and believe you me, it's worth it no matter how long you wait. A little insider advice: call ahead and place your order to go. They make call-in orders quick snap. Before you know it,  you'll be lickin your paws clean after scarfing that delicious Papalote's treat.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Papalote is killing me! The food is great, but the cooks and the cashiers are the slowest - dare I say - in the city. And their waiting area is painful. Today I thought I was smart and called ahead. They estimated 15-20 minutes, so I showed up in 15. Purest optimism. I had to wait another 25 minutes as I was repeatedly told "it's not ready." How long does it take to make one quesadilla?

And then it all made sense. The scent of weed suddenly flooded the restaurant. I looked around the restaurant - no customers were smoking joints. Looked outside - sidewalk was empty. But all the cooks were huddled in a hallway in the back. Ooooh! These guys are baked and think they're going super fast, when in reality they're in slow motion. Ooooh.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
I heard about this burrito joint by word of mouth. I stopped by after school one day around five o'clock. The line that I read about in other Yelpers' reviews was non-existant, probably owing to fact that I went around 'tain't time ('tain't lunch, 'tain't dinner).

The lady who greeted me and took my order was extremely friendly and patient while I made up my mind.

After perusing the menu board, I settled on the chicken mole burrito with black refried beans on a whole wheat tortilla. It was tasty but didn't have the distinct mole flavor I was expecting. I will say that their burritos are the perfect size. Not too small, and not too huge as to put one into an instant burrito coma.

The salsa is outstanding - creamy and packing a spicy kick. I only wish the chips were better. They tasted like mass market tortilla chips. I much prefer the freshly fried tortilla chips some other burrito joints serve.

I look forward to trying a different kind of burrito and ordering extra salsa on my next visit.
author: Z. M.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said about this place??? Good ass food!! Not to mention the latest and greatest idea:  CHICKEN ADOBO & GARLIC FRIED RICE burritos. This isn't officially on the menu as a regular item but if you're in the know, via Twitter, they announce at least a month in advance when they'll be serving it and at which location. The next one is jumpin' off February 6, 2010 at the Masonic restaurant. Don't sleep!

NEWSFLASH! Don't forget to watch 'Bobby Flay vs. Papalote' in a burrito throwdown on the Food Network on Wednesday, February 17, 2010. Check your local listings!
author: Ivan F.

description:
Yesterday our burritos were tightly wrapped and a bit thin.  So they were less messy to eat, but also less filling, than your average Mission burritos.  I also found Papalote's tortilla chips too hard, and the soyrizo's texture wasn't as meaty as Mariachi's.

But when it comes to flavor, Papalote might have the edge, for three reasons:
- the smokey red salsa, speckled with black chilis -- Its makes your heart skip a beat (from the joy as well as the spiciness).
- refried black beans. what's better than fried? refried!
- the brownish red soyrizo, which has an intense salty (almost bacony) flavor that I just lurrved.

My husband liked that his carne asada was freshly made and piping hot.  

Horchata was creamy and sweet.  I asked for no ice so as to get more horchata. Thumbs up.
author: angela n.

description:
It's nice sometimes to not feel like I just ate a tub of whale lard! 

With reasonable prices..roughly $6 for a burrito...the place wasn't bad! I wouldn't say it's to DIE for ...but definitely delicious and I will return! 

Most of the time I will shove my face with food, and walk out feeling gross from the grease, but after completing my entire burrito I felt very content. No greasiness, and an over sized belly! The salsa was good as well. I ordered the camarone burrito (which was quite yummy might I add,but maybe they left out a few shrimp that I feel it lacked). 
I'm not a huge fan of beans, but I found their black beans to be yummy! 

Not far from the bart station...a good place to stop in and eat on the way home. It cleaner than most mexican restaurants. Although I didn't find it appealing sitting near the bathroom door...so i veered away from it. I think I  smelled a whif of the delicious flavor of the bathroom..which probably wouldnt go well with my dish. 

I'll be coming back occasionally on my walk home from the bart.
author: Catherine O.

description:
God do I love Papalote. To the extent that I sometimes have to stop myself from flying to SFO to lunch. I was pointed here by a dear friend months ago, and her suggestion was bolstered - deservingly so - by the reviews here.  Boy am I glad that I made that trip!

 My favorite thing to order is the Chicken Mole. Now, I'm no mole-expert, but I enjoy the hell out of this one. The salsa is pretty much the best salsa I've ever had. I even tried to mail myself a few jars (Goddamn you, FedEx!). I am to understand that the soy-rizo is excellent, also, but I'm stuck on the mole. Add a mexican Coke to the mix, and it's perfect.

Atmosphere wise, I really dig the place, too. it's small, but clean and comfortable. It doesn't feel super-hip inside, nor is it some filthy shithole. It's also very conveniently located to my favorite mode of mass-transport, BART.

If you can't tell, I love Papalote. I think it's reputation is well-deserved, and you should at least check it out once.
author: Matt C.

description:
One ting I miss about living in San Francisco is the salsa from Papalote. The burritos are pretty good  and I can think of a half dozen or so other places with heat burritos, but the salsa is fantastic.

I've taken relatives in here and my sister thought it was the best quesadila she'd ever had. I can't vouch for it actually being the best quesadilla around. My sister lives in New York which has some of the worst Mexican food I've ever had. I've tasted what they call good Mexican food and it makes me glad I can go to places like this on a regular basis.
author: Jeremy O.

description:
After seeing the Triple Threat Burrito on Throw Down w/Bobby Flay...

The burrito is good but, I don't know if it's worth $19.95 + $.99 for sour cream, cheese, and guac.
author: Breanne B.

description:
One word. Soyrizo. It is SO good. Go try it. I prefer tacos to burritos because the soyrizo is very heavy and will make you feel really really full. If I eat a whole soyrizo burrito, I don't feel so hot. Tacos are the perfect amount of food for me.

Minus one star because you're liable to stand there for ten minutes with pretty much no line and the staff with still manage to not help you.

Oh, and the salsa makes me drool just thinking about it.
author: Penelope C.

description: I give 5 stars for the salsa alone.  The food is good, but not great, they are clearly saved by the awesome salsa which I could pour over dog crap and it would taste like heaven!  Load this stuff in a syringe and main line it into me!!!
author: Bobby S.

description:
I had to check out Papalote after hearing my friends rave and rave.

It was 7:30pm on a Thursday night and there was a line out the door.  The place is broken up into two sections - a dining room and the order line where you order to dine-in or take-out.

It's the same ingredients across the board that you can get in quesadilla, burrito and taco? form.  Some very tasty-sounding vegetarian options.

I ordered the super soyrizo burrito.  Super = $.99 = sour cream, guacamole, etc etc.

And I did not regret it one bit.  IT WAS SO GOOD.  Down to the last bite that I knew I shouldn't have had but couldn't help myself.

The wait was horrific as I had enough time to order, wait five minutes, leave the place to go to my friend's house to pick up some dishes, clean those dishes and come back and STILL wait another ten minutes.  But it was well worth it.

Papalote FTW!
author: Amanda C.

description:
When it comes to burritos, I can talk smack.  I used to live near "the mish" and ate burritos almost daily.

Papalote rocks the best combination of authentic Me-hee-can-o flava with the health food fresh-mex scene.  My burrito-loving friends are sometimes offended: "no self-respecting burrito place should have soy-rizo burritos".  Al contrario, the genius of Papalote is that they keep it real with carne asada while infusing new flavors into the mix.  And of course it's all from scratch!

Note that I'm not some vegetarian hippy-dude.  Still my burrito of choice: soyrizo, whole wheat tortilla, black beans, extra veggies.

If Mexico were alive today, this is how he'd be making burritos.

Always order an extra salsa or two.  Sure, they charge you $.50, but go half-sies with your amigos.  It's just that good.

I first learned about this place from a girl I met on a bus.  You first learned about this place from me.  Play it on the playa, player!
author: David K.

description:
Plusses:

- the salsa is awesome
- the food is good

Minuses:

- service. I know it's a taqueria and thus one should not expect service. But papalote markets itself as a bit more than a taqueria, and I think that's why it's so full of hipsters. As it turns out, the guys that work here are horribly rude, and your wait will reach 30 minutes at times. At the end of the day a good old Cancun, El farolito, or La corneta does it more for me.
author: Fred A.

description:
So looking through the reviews for this restaurant, I do realize that the food is ok, and most of the time the service is good.

I called papolote to order some food for my boyfriend and I.  I ordered, verbatim, 1 STEAK Fajitas and a Soyrizo SUPER Quesadilla.

We walked on down to the store a few minutes later to pick up the order.

"Hi, Im just here to pick up an Order for Cory"
"Oh Yes" she replies...
"1 Grilled VEggie Fajitas and a Soyrizo Super Quesadilla"

I explained to her that I ordered the Steak Fajitas.  On the Menu, the Steak Fajitas are $12.50, and the VEggie Fajitas are $10.50.

She begins to tell me that she didnt hear me on the phone say i wanted steak fajitas, and that now, because the order was already in the computer she would have to charge me 4.50 for a side of steak.  

I was extremely confused.  Because she couldnt hear that I wanted Steak over the phone, I have to pay more than what Steak Fajitas Cost?  She was extremely rude and unappologetic, all the while rolling her eyes and talking to me like i was the iddiot.  

I work in the service industry, and if the order comes out wrong, whether or not it was the customers fault, you get them a new order no questions asked.  

I explained to her that the price on the menu is 12.50 for Steak Fajitas, not 15.00 and that it didnt make sense to me that she couldnt fix this problem, and that she was making me feel like it was my fault,  

She turned to the woman working the other register and said something to her in Spanish, and the woman looked at her and said... JUST VOID IT.

I dont care about the price, it was all about principal.  ANd to top it off, my boyfriends Soyrizo Quesadilla didnt come with Guacamole and Sour Cream like we ordered, and all in all there were about 3 strips of steak in my order.  

Over all a bad experience.  Maybe the woman was having a bad day, but for some reason i got the impression that she always acts like that.

THe food wasnt that great.  Ive had better from El Farolito down the street on Mission and 24th.

Watch out for the woman who works the register and doesnt wear a uniform.  Shes Crazy!
author: Cory C.

description:
Best salsa everrrrrrrrrrr (*sings*)!

The fish tacos are a-ma-zing.  I went here with a friend and thought a burrito would be too much so I opted for the tacos instead... So.  Much.  Food.  So yummy!  The last time I had fish tacos this good was in San Felipe (apparently the home of the fish taco...)!

Nom-nom-nom-full-full-full.

The burritos are good too, although I got a chicken mole quesadilla a couple of weeks ago and I think it was a mistake.  I'm not sure if I just wasn't keen on the chicken mole in a quesadilla, or if I wasn't keen on the mole sauce, or the chicken, or if I was just a bit too hung over to be eating it in the first place.  Either way, I have liked everything else I have eaten here.

The prices are perhaps a couple of dollars more than I would want to pay in an ideal world, but it doesn't stop me going back again and again because I loves it!  Oh and remember, if you have some of that salsa left by the time your food comes, throw some of it on those fish tacos, it's too good to waste!
author: Melanie B.

description:
High quality food here. I enjoyed the fish burrito's. 

The salsa dip is delish even thought the chips themselves could have been more refined (just an idea) so that everything's in step with the Papalote reputation.

They also have the old skool version of Coke (not the really old version that contained an illegal substance) if you want to avoid all the high fructose corn syrup and taste the cane sugar original.

This one is in the top 3 for sure.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: The Super Mexipino is amazing. The orange sauce is fantastic.  If you bring in a mason jar they'll fill it up for you at a reasonable price.
author: Robert C.

description:
The food is tasty.  But the Aging Noe Valley hipsters that frequent this place are not.

Fresh, tasty Mexican food, and not greasy either, which is a rarity.  But I would take it to go, personally.
author: Steve S.

description:
Pescado tacos and an ice cold Pacifico beer.

Sabroso!
author: Jenn A.

description:
Best. burritos. in. SF. I've tried pretty much everything on the menu, but the chicken is still my favorite.

And I'm pretty sure the roasted tomato salsa is the closest thing to heaven on earth.
author: Samantha M.

description:
I heard a lot about this place and finally tried it myself and papalote did NOT disappoint. there's like almost 600 reviews so nothing I'm saying is probably new but,
-they take cards!!!!! hallefuckinglujah for ppl like me who dont carry cash 
-the salsa is seriously THE shit, looked a lil weird but tasted like it was handmade by jesus or something. def on the spicy side which I love
-the chicken was damn tasty.. this is why I can never go vegetarian
-whole wheat tortilla, so I can be somewhat healthy

needless to say, I destroyed the whole burrito in one sitting. whatever, it was too good to save for leftovers. papalote... you will be seeing a lot of me..
author: Jennie L.

description:
Papalote is a great place to go if you like overhyped "Mexican" food that's been whitewashed into something that's about as close to being authentic Mexican food as Lindsey Lohan is close to being a Nun.

Some of it's interesting, sure. Some of it even tastes pretty OK. But calling this stuff "Mexican" food is a bald-faced lie. Just because something is rolled up into a burrito dosn't make it Mexican food.

Take my advice and skip the long lines here for a cheaper and more authentic Mexican dining experience over at Taqueria Cancun (http://www.yelp.com/biz/g0VCHer2uE5NLOEdblZuSw).
author: James C.

description:
On a recommendation, we stopped in for a late lunch after a long day in the city.  

We managed to get a parking spot right in front, which proved to be an omen of even better fortune inside.

I had the chicken mole burrito, which was not only outstanding, but came to the table MAYBE ten minutes after we ordered at the counter.  The mole is chocolaty and fantastic, but the real discovery of the day was...ba ba ba baaaaa.....the roasted salsa.  wow.  Probably the best salsa I've ever had, and kids, I grew up here.  I've had a bazillion types of salsa.  I'm a fan, maybe an aficionado.  This wins, hands down, as most perfectly spiced / roasted / blended salsa this side of...well....anywhere.

We picked up an extra jar of it to take home and nibble with chips for dinner.
author: Emily H.

description: Seen it on TV and was hyped about going here (even walked 4 miles to get there) and it didn't disappoint. I had the carne asada burrito and my wife had the Chile Verde (pork). Excellent burrito, great size, perfect makeup of ingredients. I preferred my wife's to mine but both were of the highest order. Their salsa is so good I would eat it on a shoe.
author: Ross H.

description:
I go to Papalote for two reasons: Soyrizo and Salsa.

We'll start with the Soyrizo.  The first time I had the privilege of letting it pass my palate, it was in a taco.  More of a burrito woman myself, I think I went with the Tacos because they were cheaper and I was in a hurry.  But damn, the moment that luscious fake meat hit my taste buds I had the foodie equivalent of a full body orgasm, complete with yummy aftershocks hours later.  When fake meat is better than any real meat you've ever experienced, you know you have a winner.

Next: The Salsa.  I think the quality of the salsa speaks for itself when the menu says you can buy jars of the stuff and they have about 600 little mason jars waiting to be filled ... BUT, lemme tell you this shit is good.  You get a little taste of it free when you eat in-house.  After my taste I was hooked and bought a jar so I could mainline it at home.  It's so good that the little kick of spiciness it does have still does not deter me from eating it in great quantities (and I'm the type of person that cannot handle hot spicy at all.)  My eyes water and my nose runs as I eat it, and I love every delicious moment.

I'm sure there are other great things on the menu, but give me some soyrizo and salsa and I'm a satisfied lady.  Mmm...
author: Becca B.

description:
Bottled Coke? Check
Delicious and unique salsa? Check
Guacamole that can save a marriage? Check
Cool decor and cooler plates? Check

Did I mention Bottled Coke?????!

Oh yeah and this place makes mexican food! 

I cannot say enough about this place. I tell all my friends about it who think that mexican food has to be dingy and greasy. This place makes mexican food healthy (ish) with premium ingredients. 

I enjoy the carne asada burrito with refried black beans...
author: David L.

description:
Salsa was gooood.  Served a little warm and has a different kick and tang to it like I've never tasted before.  But when I asked for more chips, they wanted to charge me an extra $1.  Maybe I'm spoiled but at most Mexican restaurants where the burritos cost as much as they do here, it's FREE.

Ordered the adobo chicken burrito, not cuz I'm Filipino, but cuz all of my people were ranting and raving about it.  Chicken was good and juicy and flavored "ok."  Maybe they all just got excited b/c they got their country's dish in a mexican wrap and they thought it was neat.  Who knows.  On top of that, I ordered it super and they gave me plain.  When I told one of the owners about it, he brought me sour cream, guac, and cheese on a plate on the side.  I didn't know this was build your own burrito.  Would definitely check it out again and if it beat Bobby Flay, there must be something right about this place...I just haven't discovered it yet.
author: Emily L.

description:
There is a sharp, burning line dividing the standard and super carne asada burritos served here - the former tastes like a mouthful of vinegar served on bald cats, the latter has a brilliant balance of flavours and textures (mainly due to the slices of avocado). Neither is particularly firm, so be prepared for some sloppiness. Service can be a little slower than other places, but it's usually worth the wait.

Update: After having been here on and off over the past year, I've come to the realization that Papalote burritos get repetitive, very quickly - they have a very distinctive flavor, so if you have a burrito craving, it can't be sated by a Papalote burrito (and consequently, a Papalote Burrito craving can't be resolved by eating a normal burrito). Downgrading from four stars.
author: Glen M.

description:
I live pretty close  to  this spot.  I'm moving,  but let me tell you - I will be making as many trips here as I can afford. I always get the veggie  fajitas or just a side of beans (BLACK REFRIED YESSS) and tofu and I'm always happy and craving more. Luckilly, when my boyfriend isn't looking,  I steal bites from his burrito.  

The star off is for one of the counter girls.  She's so unpleasant and rude. Everyone  else is so  sweet  she really stands  out. If the beans weren't so good, I'd  throw them at her.
author: haley d.

description:
I go here at least 3 times a week and as Nish pointed out, probably much more than that. Papalote means kite, and the restaurant (you can sit down) is cheerfully painted and hung with beautiful elaborate handmade kits that look like frogs, bugs, etc... and a world class collection of Latin and other music is playing at all times.

Food: The fish tacos are fantastic, and I love the prawn quesadilla, rice and bean taco, fish quesadille (seriously the only time fish and cheese can be used together) and nachos. I recently tried the chile verde quesadilla and it was soooo good. It would be my new favorite except that it's pork, and I don't really eat pork. The pork pieces were tender and delicious though. Maybe next time I'll ask if they can leave out the pork pieces and just heap on that yummy green sauce.

For 99 cents, I always "super" my order because the guacamole rocks. You can't even get an avocado at the market for 99cents, and they give a generous portion. The salsa is smoky and just the right amount of kick to it. It's worth the 50 cent charge to get another helping! The chips are thin, crisp and always served warm. Yum. 

Service:  awesome. "Perdito", who flashes his ever cheerful silver accented smile, is already filling my "pepsi regular" when I walk in the door. When the owner Miguel is there he always takes a moment to say hello.  Update: the Pepsi machine is "out of order" apparently because of a tiff with an incompetent supplies. Miguel refuses to do business with the guy and as a result, I'm going through some kind of Pepsi withdrawal. The homemade horchata is good, but sometimes I want that chemical kick of Pepsi. Rrrrrrrrrrrrrrr. Judith, the girl at the counter is always friendly and polite and acts like it's totally normal that I eat there every day.
author: Darcy V.

description: Recommended by two people in the span of 2 days so I had to check it out while in town.   Loved the carne asada tacos.   The steak was cooked just perfect.   Very fresh tasty and good portion size.   As plenty of other reviewers mentioned the salsa is fantastic.  Will be back.
author: Sara G.

description: Yum! Papalote makes their own specialty salsa. It was sooo good, I purchase a bottle to take home. They sell it freshly made in mason jars, or in their branded bottle.
author: Michaela M.

description:
A Papalote Haiku:

Black beans and cheese, please,
Tomato, lettuce and rice - 
Organic delight!
author: Katelin H.

description: Great vegan/vegetarian options help make this an awesome taqueria - the chips and salsa are wonderful, although its an itty-bitty annoyance that you have to pay for additional servings of either items considering other places don't charge... But I will say its worth it! Cute interior make it cozy to dine in. The key is to get there early, it's not unusual to see a line out the door during peak hours...
author: Sean G.

description: Saw a huge crowd here so we had to try it. The best part of the meal is the reddish sauce they serve complimentary with the chips. Prawns for the taco were burned, super condiments were very sparse, chicken in burrito was dry.
author: Marina N.

description:
Crap! If you pay the extra to get a "super" and still end up with a rice and bean burrito and don't mind, go here! You can tell this is the type of place that used to be good and the got a little popular- simply put; it's popularity got to it's head, like a high school girl who finally made the varsity cheerleading team.

I ordered the prawn burrito- $10 of worthlessness for a rice and bean burrito that only had 4 prawns.

Red flag- a Mexican restaurant with no mexicans- not a good sign.

The only thing good about this place is the salsa.
author: Theresa P.

description: Cheers for the great salsa:) Veggie burrito is awesome with lots of taste. Prawn tacos was not bad.
author: Maitai N.

description:
Hate to burst this bubble, but housemate Kim D. (also a yelper) got severe food poisoning from here not that long ago.

I know, I know, it can happen anywhere and it's not necessarily cause for alarm. But that aside, I'm not the hugest fan of this joint. Sure, they throw some sauteed zucchini and an odd piece of eggplant (and by that I mean exactly one piece) into their tacos, but they charge you an arm and a leg for it.  

Apart from the amazing salsa (creamy, smoky and tasty, it is now available for purchase here), this place is average.
author: Kathleen G.

description: Here's the deal...if the service sucks, it doesn't matter how good the food is. Don't get me wrong, I think Papalote makes a quality product but two weeks in a row they've messed up the take out order. Week one, we ordered the regular veggie but got the grilled veggie burrito. Week two, the burrito labeled "VEGGIE" was actually the chicken burrito. Additionally, the chicken burrito was supposed to be super (which was on the receipt so we were charged) but was not. Sorry, Papalote, don't care if you beat Bobby Flay in throwdown. Tighten it up.
author: Sig N.

description:
I'm on a mexican food venue yelping binge. 

Haven't been to Papalote in a while but I recall that anything with grilled zucchinis (I'm partial to zucchinis) was delicious. And the bowl of salsa for the chips - dude, if you want spicy...that's what you're going to get. It's not pico de gallo. It's straight up, serious business salsa.

I would go back just for the salsa.
author: Cat T.

description:
So I keep coming back to this place, but I'm lowering my review to 4 stars.  The food is still fresh and excellent, but I can no longer agree with their pricing structure.  Two people can't get out of here spending less than $20 and really, the portions are rather small.  

Also, they have a normal sized burrito that they charge $20 for.  That's just ridiculous.

Anyway, the food is still great but if they want 5 stars, they need to reduce prices across the board by at least 15-20%.
author: Cyrus C.

description:
Tasted fresh, creative, and wonderful.  Fast service, fun atmosphere (bottle of the brightly colored walls), and decent prices.

Need I say more?
author: Alex C.

description:
So Papalote is literally the closest restaurant to my house.  I admit to eating here at least once a week.  The fish tacos are fantastic.  I love that there are lots of other non-lard/veggie options--that's the main reason to come here.  If you want a big fatty burrito, they are good here, but probably better elsewhere and you don't need to go far...

People rave about the salsa, I personally am not into it.  Does it have cream in it?  My friend visiting from New York thought it tasted like Doritios--I agree.
author: Amy G.

description:
As a Mission local and burrito snob, I was originally skeptical of Papalote's brightly-painted interiors and vanity windows, not to mention its location just west of the Valencia gentrification line.  However, the quality of the food has eventually won me over, and though it may not be as rich in primal satisfaction as a Farolito carnage asada super burrito, it provides a slightly healthier and tasty alternative, perhaps more suitable to frequent consumption.    

The high point of their fare is surely the salsa, probably the best complimentary sauce in the city, doled out in conservative portions along with fairly fresh tortilla chips.  Their burritos are smallish and lean, but ultimately a tasty combination of fresh, lard-less ingredients.  They are best filled with carne asada, though less tasty vegetable and fake meat options are available.  Their tacos, perhaps reflecting their proximity to Noe Valley, lack the guts of their greasier contemporaries on Mission street, and are filled with lettuce, of all things.

I've found the employees to be uniformly rude, and their attitude does not seem to improve with frequent patronage, friendliness or tipping, but given that it takes about 30 seconds of interaction to procure my food, I'm inclined to not care.
author: Mike H.

description:
once you've had Papalote's burritos, its hard to go elsewhere...

Its seriously good tasting burritos, you can taste that they use better quality ingredients

I love the vibe here; festive, fun, it makes for a really nice ambiance for a fun dinner out

but the real reason I keep coming back is for their salsa...
their burritos smothered in salsa - its the real deal!
author: Teresa T.

description:
Papalote is over rated and over priced. The small space, which otherwise is well decorated, quickly gets really loud. Also, for some odd reason I've been cold both time I've visited and kept my jacket on, which is always anti-relaxing to me. It enhances the in-and-out mode, but with those prices and the wait on the food we've had, it's seems like a paradox. Considering the decor too, I'd like to feel like sticking around and hanging out. 

The food is bland. We ordered the bean dip, shrimp quesadilla, and veggie fajita, and besides the servings being on the skimpy side, there was just not much seasoning to any of it.

It's the second time I'm back, and the second time I again got annoyed with the rushed service at the counter.

Next time, I'll remember to disagree on going to Papalote's...
author: Kirsten L.

description:
So nice to have a variety of vegan/vegetarian options. Menu looks great, wait was not too long, atmosphere was, er, I dunno, kinda friendly DTE Mission normal.

My burrito was, I hate to say, a little dull. Like, not stand out bad, just not very moist or flavourful or exciting, and judging by the way everyone leapt at the salsa to smear on their burrito, mine was not the only one. Proportions of wrapper to filling were in a ratio not tolerated at, say, Pancho Villa, and the effect was to make it a bit stodgy. I left most of it and was hungry again by the time I walked home.

I'm going to go back, as I suspect I fell into the n00b's trap of simply ordering badly. I suspect all the things I found missing are add-ons, and I missed that bit of the menu due to hunger-induced bad eyesight and a desire not to hold up the swelling queue behind me. 

Consider this version 1.0 of the review release schedule.
author: Alison M.

description:
I would like to give these guys a higher rating because I do frequent them but the wait just kills me. Granted it is on a weeknight as a last minute meal, more of a "holy crap I have not eaten yet and it's 8:30!" before I head out for the evening... but still. They could be a bit more efficient. I am usually waiting outside (because there are so many people waiting inside) for at least 20 minutes to get my shrimp burrito.

Food is not too bad. I like the fresh ingredients. What more can I say? Weeknight haunt perhaps, but that is it.
author: Ali K.

description:
I fucking hate vegetarian "wannabe" food with a passion.
Veggie Burgers, Veggie Dogs, Soy Bacon; you can go fuck yourselves.

So I see and hear people rave about the soyrizo, and I am forced to try it.

Holy. Shit.

Better than any chorizo I've ever had. 
The Camarones (Shrimp) is light, blends nicely with the spices and rice, and just feels enjoyable to eat, perfect for not feeling like a sweaty piece of shit afterwards like most other Mexican places, which will keep you on the toilet so long you'll get new honeycombs on your jeans.

In fact, none of these burritos is going to weigh you down. 

The Mole is overcooked and has a strong basic taste in it. Meh.

They sell salsa by the pint in mason jars for $5.95, and I keep it constantly stocked in my fridge. It varies in spice from day to day, but no matter how hot it is, it's a crazy, unique, amazing salsa that I can't figure out the contents of.  Perfect for snacking, and can hold up it's own as a condiment against sriricha.
author: Matthew F.

description: Papalote, my love!  This is the ONLY place that I know that serves soy chorizo tacos...and I love them for it.  As a vegetarian, this is the best mexican food I can get...and it's probably because of all the hipsters that hang out around here.  The salsa is ADDICTING to say the least.  Papalote was even on Bobby Flay's Throw Down show and I can say with a HUGE smile on my face that they BEAT him and put him back in his place.  He even bought their salsa because he had to admit that his food paled in comparison.  I dream of papalote...and I always try to get some when I'm in SF.  Oh and their horchata is pretty good too.  Prices are sooooo good!!!!  All in all, awesome mexican food...a must-eat place in SF.
author: Kristine N.

description: They are way over priced. They give u a large plate of 9 dollar bean dip and about 10 chips and won't give u extra. They give you a tiny portion of salsa no matter what you order.
author: Jennifer D.

description: This is a very busy and very popular restaurant. The crowd is fun sometimes but it can take a while to order and then wait for your food.
