Apparently the food here is either organic, sustainable or both. The food is good (if not somewhat bland).  The salsa is excellent. Can seem expensive if you compare it to a taqueria.
author: Oliver W.

description:
We both we were starving when we got to the city on Sunday so I went onto my Yelp! application on my iPhone, then to my bookmarks, sorted them to 'Distance from Me' and Papalote came up as the closet (so did Humphry's but that's another review.) I was telling him about the Triple Threat Burrito and how there's steak, chicken and shrimp inside and he said "What are you waiting for, let's go!" We pulled up, got a parking spot right in front and walked in knowing exactly what we wanted. Ordered the $20! burrito and took our seats. We got our burrito and started to chow down. Every bite say "Ohhh - Ahhh - Yummm - This is the best salsa - Yumm..." this went on for about 15 minutes and then we both were stuffed. Couldn't take one more bite. I think the best part on the burrito was the chicken, nice big chunks and very good seasoning. I'm not much of a red meat eater so I actually picked out some of the steak but that doesn't mean it was good. And the shrimps were big! 

We both agreed that this was the best burrito we have ever eaten but for $20 it better be.
author: Katie J.

description:
ummm, i'm gonna throw it out there. the burrito was seriously one of the worst burritos i've ever had. and i've eaten a lot of them!  i had the veggie burrito and the hubby had the shrimp burrito.  it lacked flavor and it was dry! the rice and beans were a bit crunchy. i mean c'mon....crunchy? dry? that's definitely how you f-up a burrito.

the only thing they have going for them is their sauces.  the salsa is super yummy and i can drink that stuff.  2 stars for the sauce....

i will say, 7x7 never lets me down, and they claim that the carne asada burrito here is one of the best. maybe i'll come back for the salsa and give papalote's another chance and try the carne asada burrito.

maybe it was an off day? either way, for now... thumbs down.
author: Sharon T.

description:
if it wasnt so pricey and they were more consistent about how many chips you get with take out orders i would give them 5 stars
the chicken mole burritos are out of this world
and i dont even really like chicken!!!!!!!!!
author: beth m.

description:
I've been meaning to drop in here but there's always a line and I'm always in a hurry.  Finally had lunch here. Mole chicken tacos are damn good. Great mole sauce that leaves the essence of chocolate in your mouth.  Wonderfully ripe produce in the tacos. 

Super pleased with the flavor, the quantity and the price. And it's so close to my flat.
author: Mona M.

description:
Very good. Efficient service, not a place you can linger but a pleasant environment in which to eat.
The bean dip, it's very good but it's 1. HUGE and 2. Really just a plate of (good) beans w/ cheese- hard to eat and very filling.
The burritos are HUGE and delicious, no need to order any sides.
I liked the salsa, but wasn't as amazing as I expected- it was fresh but a little on the sweet side.
Prices are a bit higher than average for the area.
Still = a very good bet.
author: AA A.

description:
So the food is tasty enough to warrant a 5th star, but the burritos cost $10.  Ten dollars, in case you were thinking I mistyped that because you assume that only an airport or Disneyland would even think of charging $10 for a burrito.  The burritos are average to small in size so, no, they aren't bigger to justify the price.

So yeah, if you have decided to tolerate the $10, the ingredients are simple but definitely delicious and good quality.  The salsa is an amazing pumpkin seed concoction with a mild, but noticeable bite and my friends and I often buy a jar with our food.  My favorite burrito is a super with chile verde pork and refried beans (the black beans are great but I grew up on refried).
author: Harlen W.

description:
Meh. 

One star for being healthy
One star for good prices
One star for the salsa

I wasn't particularly thrilled by my burrito. It was VERY salty, and I would have liked it to have cheese in it. But I appreciate that it's healthier without it, and I also dug the fact that they use boneless, skinless chicken breast. Salsa is definitely tasty, but the chips weren't that great, so it kinda ruined it for me.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
Definitely overrated.  I had high hopes for this place, but it came nowhere close to all the hype.  Even discounting the fact that it's not authentic Mexican food, just about every menu option sounded intriguing to me.  However, everything I've tried has turned out to be rather bland.  I think the last thing I got there was a camerones burrito, and I couldn't taste any of the butter or white wine in which the shrimp was supposedly sauteed.  I had to pour tablespoons of salsa on each bite to give it some flavor.  

It does get a couple of points, though, for being a  quasi-healthy-Cal-exican alternative -- if that's what you're after.  And I can definitely see why vegetarians and vegans are thrilled with it, which is maybe why SF loves it so much...?
author: daphne w.

description:
I used to think that Papalote was trying to be a slightly hipper, more upscale, maybe even somewhat trendy alternative to the ol' San Francisco taqueria, a true institution. And, to some extent, it is. It's got those papery dragon thingies -- those are hip. And the logo is a "P" inscribed inside a circle -- that's a totally hip and now move as far as graphic design is concerned. 

But there are not downsides here (unless you despise style, which you probably do). It's not wildly over priced (rice and bean super burrito , $4), and you won't get any barfy 'tude from the servers, or fellow patrons. You'll just get some damn good burritos. DAMN GOOD, I say. Splurge and get the fish burrito... IF YOU DARE. The fish is delish (say it out loud, please!). 

Last night I ate my entire burrito, minus the glops of filling that feel onto the place. This does not indicate that the burrito is small (it isn't ), it indicates that the burrito is magical. That it finds away to fit itself entirely inside my stomach (much like my Honda Fit does in SF parking spaces). And by magical, I guess I mean these burritos are f*king tasty.

A final plus: it's fun to watch the burrito men make their magic behind the glass (how sanitary!). I even saw one guy wash his hands after extensively handling raw meat. Do you think all burrito guys do this? I doubt it. Google it. Then let me know.
author: Beah B.

description: By far, my favorite burritos on earth!! The lean meat never leaves me feeling weighed down. The salsa is one of a kind!!! Papalote fan for life!!
author: Tania a.

description:
We've had great burritos at Papalote. Their grilled chicken and grilled veggies are so delicious. 

The salsa is great!
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
ok, so i didn't used to love them. I thought the service killed everything as they used to be so rude.  but something has changed, as my last 5 times (at least) the service has been nice, funny, and helpful. and i know service isn't all, but it makes a difference.

the food is GREAT.  good quality, fresh, nicely presented.  plus that salsa is RIDIC!
author: Andrew r.

description: Their chips and salsa really live up to the hype.  Not that many mexican places have this kind of salsa.  It's not pico de gallo (fresh salsa), but the fiery orange kind that doesn't have any chunks.  They bottle this stuff it's so good.  But yeah, it's kind of expensive, which sucks since the flavor is so addictive. I didn't even try anything else, I just ate the chips.
author: Anna T.

description:
There's not much to say about Papalote that hasn't already been said. However, I will say this: My boyfriend discovered this really bangin' combination: Have'a corn chips with Papalote salsa...I'm telling you, this is Latino-Asian fusion at it's finest, people! 

Sure, the chips they serve at Papalote are nice and fresh and good, but if you ever buy a jar of salsa to go from them, just go across the street to the Valencia Farmers Market grocery store, and pick up a bag of Have'a corn chips (they are basically very fresh, crispy tortilla chips infused with soy-sauce...as weird as it may sound, it works!) And with the Papalote Salsa, oh hells yeah!!!

As far as Papalote goes on its own, I have been a long-time eater of their mushroom quesadilla (simple and good), their soyrizo nachos (great for us non meat eaters!), and their fish tacos (which are the healthy, non-beer battered kind).
author: Shannon R.

description:
I should know by now that it's best to go with my gut (not my stomach, but my intuition).  Burritos at Papalote always satisfy, but for some reason on this particular visit, I went with the prawn quesadilla.  I was almost in shock at my plate: my quesadilla was cut up in four pieces, with one piece of shrimp for each slice.  It looked so sparse, I was ready to complain.  But instead I dug in, and I have to say I didn't think about complaining because there was so much flavor in that shrimp, anything else would've been a waste.

But I was hungry afterwards...  So maybe I should ask for a quesadilla w/ the works and extra shrimp?
author: Audrey E.

description:
The first time I came here, to the Mission location, I had kind of a bad experience.

I had ordered the grilled veggie burrito (great, by the way) and a side of chips and guacamole. My friend was already seated with his chips and salsa when I sat down. One of the waiters came out from the kitchen almost immediately afterward with some guacamole and a small bowl of chips, and when he got to my table he unloaded the guac but turned right around with my chips still on the tray! When I asked the cashier, she told me that it's restaurant policy. To only serve one bowl of chips regardless of the number of diners and what they've ordered, such as CHIPS and guacamole? They give way too few chips per table. 

The salsa's amazing, though. Kind of like enchilada sauce.

The burritos are great: moist yet not drippy.

I still come here, I just don't order side dishes.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Papalote's could have the best salsa ever.  But they only give you one thing for free, then you must buy more (like my crack dealer).

Don't compare this to every other burrito and taco joint in the mission.  It's a slightly nicer version, a few more bucks, cleaner inside, with fresher ingredients, smaller portions, and they bring the food to your table.  

Tacos fall apart too easily, i recommend the burro's or a plate.  
I usually get the carne asada here.
author: chad n.

description: Excellent burritos with grilled ingredients and fresh salsas on the side. Non-greasy feel to the food.  Nice warm chips.  We split the Triple Threat burrito and walked away satisfied.
author: John K.

description:
over priced and took way to long.

not sure which part of a rice and bean taco takes 30minutes to make but by the time they brought it out everyone else I was with had finished their food.

next time I'll stick to one of the 50 other taquerias in the mission that charge half as much taste way better.
author: danielle m.

description:
Burritos should not be vegan, but if your too stubborn to listen to reason, than go to Papalote.  The vegan re-fried beans make for the best veggie burrito in the city. 
Portions are small but the salsa is unusually satisfying. 
The mom with the super round face who works the register is an angel.
 
The place is so busy and the ordering area / pantry is so small, it's hard not to get annoyed. Bring an appetizer and a magazine; the long wait is especially unbearable if your nut and twig vegan diet has your stomach to craving meat so badly that it starts digesting itself.
author: Puffy P.

description: Best burritos known to mankind. Great service & the conscientious owners always find ways to give back to the community. A San Francisco classic.
author: Erick S.

description:
The roasted salsa is enough for the five star rating.  Then you get to gleefully dump it into your burrito, which is stuffed with juicy-fresh delicious ingredients.  Ooh, mmmmmm; oh, rrrrr--oh; I, nnngggggg---I mean, em......oh, man, it's good.

Order extra salsa.  It's worth the token charge.  And try to hit it on off-hours so you don't have to wait so long.  Burrito, beer, and tip for around 10.00; with extra salsa, 11.00.  !!Super-extra perfectisimo!!
author: Randy F.

description:
Delicious. 
Oh Papalote you so good I can't stop thinking about you. You don't make me feel too bad about myself when I have nachos for dinner bc my teeny tiny brain has decided you are health food. Any place with vegan menu items immediately becomes health food even if I ordered a double bacon cheese burger. 
Only complaint is last night I went to pick up my to go and the place was jammed with white people. Damn I hate crackers.
author: Melissa H.

description:
How much do I love Papalote?

A soyrizo burrito was my last meal in San Francisco.  

I had lived in the Mission for nearly 3 years and Papalote is what I wanted for my last meal.  I'll miss you, Papalote! 

PS I am a humongous carnivore but the soyrizo is so good, I rarely order anything else.
author: Adrienne W.

description:
To those who decry the lack of salsa choices at Papalote, I say why waste a bunch of little plastic cups on substandard sauces when you could have a single, stainless steel cup of the best?

This is truly the height of California-style Mexican fast food in the Mission. 

I can take vegans, dieters, and people that won't eat tacos from a truck in Fruitvale (my personal favorite) here and I still get to eat pretty well. I'm a little old-school with the Mexican food. I like a torta so greasy the bun's almost transparent and tacos loaded with pleasure-nubbed lengua. Even so, the relatively light and uber-fresh food at Papalote agrees with my belly, my wallet, and my more sensitive, less lard-loving friends.
author: Margaret F.

description:
Soyrizo.  SO AMAZING.  I remember the first time I had Papalote, it was like an epiphany in my mouth.  Why oh why don't more places have soyrizo?  It can't be hard to make, and I know I've seen it at my local Trader Joe's...

But I digress.  Papalote has some spotty service (particularly when dealing with drunk chicks who have spent the better part of the evening at the Mission Bar for happy hour), but I could care less.  As long as they have some piping hot soyrizo in the kitchen, I will be back for more.

Did I mention the soyrizo?
author: Shirin S.

description:
This place just didn't do it for me. 

The "7x7 Top 100" chips & salsa were just ok. The fish taco's were not that great and a little over priced. The carne asade burrito was average at best. 

Considering all the Mexican food options in the Mission, I don't think I will be going back to Papalote any time soon.
author: Blake W.

description:
Papalote is my favorite burrito place in the Bay Area by a long shot!  They have so many vegetarian options, including the phenomenal grilled veggie burrito (potatoes and carrots!) and the equally amazing soyrizo burrito (soy chorizo!).  Make sure to order things "super" so that they come with sour cream/guac/etc.  

They don't cook veggie stuff (beans, rice, vegetables) with lard, so all is fair game for vegetarians.  I love that the burritos are a bit healthier than the standard Mission taqueria, so I don't feel quite as terrible when I leave.

The salsa is fantastic--people come for the salsa alone!  The bean dip is yet another thing to rave about.  I love this place.  Best burritos ever.
author: Claire K.

description:
Holy Vegan Deliciousness Batman!  

I am a HUGE fan of the vegan mole burrito with guac.  Srsly.  Get it.  I don't care if you're vegan, you will LOVE it.  *wow*  

Reasonably priced, ridiculously tasty food, and generally friendly service.  The only downside?  It gets SUPER crowded at dinner time, and it's hard to find a place to stand to wait to get your food, and the dining room is so small the wait is quite a while for a table.  Still, I heart Papalote.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place is absolutely delicious and it bustles. If you aren't too hungry, it worth the time you spend in line (and quite possibly waiting for a table). The salsa is awsome and I enjoyed everything I tried (carnitas tacos, prawn quesadilla and a bit of my friend's veggie burrito). I will definitely go back.
author: Nicole M.

description: Love their salsa! I recommend to hold off on the salsa when they give you chips and salsa. Save it for your burrito. It is delish.
author: Sonlay V.

description: I just discovered their garlic fried rice, wow! this just shot back to being my favorite place for burritos.. will try the soyrizo today for the first time.
author: Ajesh S.

description: I came here because everyone on Yelp raves about Papalote's salsa, and they were RIGHT!!! It was the second most amazing salsa ever (after my grandma's of course). Their burritos are HUGEMONGOUS, I had to share one with my friend because I couldn't eat one by myself.
author: Juan F.

description:
The salsa here rocks!

A bit overpriced compared to other mission burrito places, and the food is comparable. You do have to pay extra for cheese which makes me sad, because cheese should be an essential part of a burrito. Otherwise the food itself was pretty good, not to die for, but nice and tasty with the right bit of spice.
author: Stephanie C.

description: When I go to the mission (or near Masonic) when I am in SF I HAVE TO GET A TOFU MOLE BURRITO. Miguel's mole has to be some of the best I have had outside of my friend's grandma in LA. The salsa is bomb! The service is quick and I have yet to try something on their menu that is not to my liking. Local artists hang their stuff here-- it is a must go to when in the mission (or near fullton)
author: Vicky T.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE their fish tacos.  The fish is light, fluffy and perfectly seasoned.  They are super generous with how much meat they give you.
author: Hm M.

description:
I had heard about this place on Yelp. I wanted to try a Mexican place with a number of vegetarian options and that had something different to offer. This was the first burrito in SF that I had found were they had a Soyrizo burrito and one Tofu burrito that was marinated and grilled. 

I really enjoyed the Soyrizo burrito; it had tons of flavor (although I only got a bite or two of it - I hear it can be filling). I had the tofu burrito... it was pretty good. I finished the whole thing. 

Will definitely go again! I loved their salsa and chips...
author: Vrinda S.

description:
Very fresh Mexican food with vegan beans and organic veggies and meat.  Word is already out about this place so the lines are super long.  Make sure to call ahead of time w/ your order and beat the crowd...

One time I forgot to make my veggie burrito "super" and it kinda sucked w/o the sour cream and guac.  They do always include good veggies like zucchini and eggplant tho!  And i LOOOOOOOVE their salsa.
author: Sid D.

description:
I love Papalote! It's right on my way home and it's pretty affordable to boot. I get the rice and beans super burrito with pinto beans and it's never steered me wrong. Except for last night when I ate an entire burrito in about 5 minutes. Note to self: never do that again. I could feel the little burrito climbing around in my belly for a good hour afterwards. Don't get me wrong, the burrito was happy in there, but making itself known just the same. All I can say is, "It hurt so good."

Did I mention that I had to unbutton my top button of the pants at the bar later that night? I had to give my burrito some more room to breathe!
author: Jen G.

description:
Papalote is not new, but it's new to me. My family has been going to Pancho Villa for so long, that's my Mexican default. My friend ordered fish tacos, and I ordered quesadillas; and we both just sat there repeating, "Yum!" after every bite.

The ingredients were so fresh, I had to wonder if they had a secret tunnel directly linking them to Whole Foods. Maybe they fit a secret garden behind their kitchen? I don't know, but their "fresh & healthy" menu drew a motley crew of customers, from the typical Mission artsy types to conservative men in suits. They will definitely be getting repeat visits from me.
author: jenn h.

description:
I'd have to say that this place isn't THE best Mexican ever, but i feel that it's one the best Mexican restaurants in San Fran.
my friend who lives in the hood took me there..i have to say i was impressed with the mole's. very good. I'd go back. the place itself was small and did think it was a tad pricey for the location/size/ambiance. sevice could've been better. our table was barely wiped before we sat down.  close quarters with your neighbors. all good.
i'd go back though, fo sho.
author: Nichole D.

description:
sometimes I get a little too adventurous when deep down I know sticking to the basics is the way to go. 
In this case, I went w/ the chicken mole. it was good, but I can't help but think I chose my own adventure and I chose wrong. mole is very difficult to pull off especially at $6.95. 

That being said the salsa is legit as most folks have pointed out and the other dishes that my dining companions ate where delicious. 
definitely coming back here for a 2nd chance.
author: Gabe b.

description:
The salsa is in fact fantastic (I thought of mole more than salsa) and almost worth the whole visit. Apparently the shrimp quesadillas are amazing (none for me, thank you!) and the carne asada was drool-worthy. I had no idea this place was so famous, and I'm glad I didn't, because I was able to relish my meal without the hype leering around the corner.

The 2nd grade class' architectural drawings decorating the walls like gallery art were also a highlight. AND they have Dos Equis on tap.
author: Arwen O.

description:
The place was packed and lines were out of the door.  I was lucky since my friends already got seats by the time I got there.

I had the tofu mole but I thought the mole sauce was a bit overbearing. However, I like how "light and healthy" I felt after eating the entire burrito.   Also, the chips and salsa were warm and spicy.

My friends had chicken quesadillas and loved it.

An eclectic Mexican joint for vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
When there are a couple hundred reviews, you question the effort, but here goes anyways.  Overall I like this place.  The food is good, affordable, and fun.  

That said, the service is comical.  I mean these guys are really slow.  Even when the place is only mildly busy they walk around like the living dead.  There are always a couple women working the counter, feet stuck to the floor taking money and chatting up the customers.  Then there is the expediter (not that this guy knows what that means). The chefs cook up the food and you wait.  Then you wait some more.  Then you wait a fuck of a lot longer.  

I would rather eat my dirty laundry rather than eat at El Faralito, but there, the expediter knows what he is doing.  Assemble the orders, get people out the door (it's really not that hard).  

Then, there is the door.  Fix the god dammed door.  The ghost opening and icy wind really makes you appreciate the fact that you're waiting way way too long for your order.  All that said, the food is good.  I really hate that I really should like blows it with inept service.
author: Anthony K.

description: I've been to Papalote a few times, and I haven't been impressed. First of all, the ordering experience is awful and they show little interest in good service. I understand they get busy, but slowing down on the ordering process and not yelling at customers would improve accuracy and make people less stressed. Ordering food should be a good experience. The burrito itself was medicore and without much flavor. I'm sure it was "better" and "more authentic" than going to Chipotle, but Chipotle's ingredients have a distinct flavor profile. The rice isn't just rice, it's cilantro-lime rice, for example. Everything at Papalote tastes bland to me, which could be fixed with better seasoned tofu or richer salsas -- which brings me back to the confusing, stressful order process and menu. I'd only get it if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Tony G.

description:
my must stop-by place in the bay.

i know they are famous for their triple threat, but my love is for their shrimp burrito. yum!!

i love how you can pick the flavor of the tortillas for the burrito. i go for sun dried tomatoes : D

o i miss papalote : (
author: Amy S.

description: BEST SALSA EVER.  They serve it with tortilla chips.  I can't remember what I ordered, but i remember it being delicious.
author: Sharon F.

description:
Hands down the best vegetarian tacos and burritos. 

The tofu is particularly amazing. Most tofu substitutions at restaurants end up tasting like crap--they haven't marinated the tofu or just don't know what to do with it, leaving you with a semi-bland hunk mussing up your dish (and this comes from a tofu lover). But ho-ho-ho, not Papalote's! They've cracked the code and know how to turn a chunk of firm tofu into a tasty grilled wonder.
author: W. T.

description:
How do you make fish really bad for you?  

Saute it in wine and butter, throw it in a tortilla with a bunch of cheese,  then add a little more grease to toast it up, that's how.  Papalote calls this a pescado quesadilla.  I call it evil.

Holy crap.   This thing is freaking delicious.  I'm usually more of a burrito kind of girl but my boyfriend brought one of these evil pescado thingys home recently. Soon he was annoyed with himself that he asked me if I wanted a bite because after that he couldn't' get rid of me.

Fortunately I live nowhere near this place and they don't deliver.  Because if either of those two realities existed, I would have quesadilla butt in about 2 weeks.

So... my advice: Give up the burrito for a meal and try some fish.  But do so with extreme caution.
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
I've only been here once and had their Fish Tacos and Watermelon horchata - good stuff. Oh and the chips and salsa are off the hook!

The decor is definitely hipper than most Taquerias in the Mission, but don't let that fool you.  This place is definitely a contender.

I can't wait to go back and try something else on the menu
author: eileen r.

description:
Papalote lives very close to me, and I'm so glad it's my neighbor!  Friendly people work there, and the burritos are so very, very tasty.  I've eaten there way too many times by now, and I actually don't think I've ever been disappointed by the food - so many veggie options!  Mmm soyrizo.  

Also wonderful are their 10 burrito cards - get ten punches and you are rewarded with a free burrito of any kind!  I typically keep at least three of these cards in my wallet at all times.
author: Angela P.

description:
man, i go here WAY too much. there are so many things i love about this place. their ingredients always seem fresh and delicious, and they'll put your burrito on a whole-wheat tortilla. i go here about once a week. that's how much i love it.

so why only 4 stars, you ask? because i wish they had organic options, TWICE now they've messed up my husband's burrito (rice and beans for the vegetarian) and pollo (for me, the carnivorous one), AND they are on the pricier side. but despite all of that? they still get 4.. maybe even 4.5 stars..
author: Bella S.

description:
Today, I ate the best burrito of my life.

My vegetarian girlfriend was happy that they had great options for her as well.
author: David C.

description:
Papalote is up there when it comes to delicious Mexican food.  It's definitely in the top three and funny, for the life of me, I don't know remember the names of the other two because I'm hazy from the glow of Papalote's deliciousness.  While the proximity of my next job location to Papalote wouldn't be the deciding factor in picking one job over the other, it would definitely be a perk.

Papalote is a restaurant where I don't miss meat as part of my meal.  Their vegan and vegetarian burritos are delicious.  I usually order my burrito with black beans, a whole wheat tortilla, and make it a super so I can have their delicious guacamole.  The cheese is nice too. I've eaten their grilled veggie burrito, chicken burrito, and grilled shrimp burrito (it's not on the menu anymore so maybe it was a special), but I always come back to my one true love.  The rice and bean burrito.  It's simple, tasty, and will keep you going for the day.  Their salsa is fantastic as well and unlike any I've ever tried before.  It's hard to describe; it's a bit smoky.  

I love me some Papalote!  If I was vegan or vegetarian, it wouldn't be hard because of Papalote.  I firmly believe the restaurant would get me through the hard times.
author: TeTeDaMouse C.

description:
We came to pick up our orders then go to my friend's house nearby for dinner. I'm not sure if it's normal, but after placing our order, we waited an hour for our take out food. I get that they make each order when ordered, but still, we were freaking starving. It didn't help that it was during that heat wave last month so it was freaking hot in there like summertime in Mexico.

Anyways, onto the food. I ordered the mole chicken burrito since it looked different. During my hour wait, I read articles talking about the fake chorizo which I would try next time I went, if I go again.

The chips and salsa were good, but not worth the hour wait. 

Since I don't live in the Mission, I probably wouldn't come back here next time since there are so many Mexican places to try. But there were lots of locals in there that day, so I can see how it can be a neighborhood favorite, just not mine.
author: Vivian L.

description: I don't feel as guilty bc I think the food is healthier than the traditional taco shacks. The salsa is yum; I wish I had purchased a few jars for home consumption.
author: Ava C.

description:
This place is so freaking good.  My mouth waters just thinking about it.  Their special salsa is to die for.  I saw someone buy a jar of it once and had a mild heart attack.  I had no idea they offered that!!!!

As a USF student this place is extremely convenient...so why the hell not?  The food is really good and it's decently priced.

Good job Papalote.
author: Jules G.

description:
Back when I was living in SF, this was probably the closest to SoCal Mexican food the Bay Area has to offer. Fortunately, I lived in Noe Valley so when the J is slow, I take the BART to 24th... then I always had an excuse to fall in line (yes sometimes they have a line that extends outside) and grab the craved burrito.

However, nothing can beat Southern California's Mexican food... so I want to see Papalote try harder.
author: Eunice B.

description:
Their salsa is like straight crack!  I could eat five baskets of their chips and salsa and be perfectly content with my accomplishments for the day.

I ordered a carne asada burrito.  Very fresh ingredients, flavorful, and prepared in a fairly short amount of time.  

Has a local hangout / neighborhood feel to it.  Great for a casual lunch or dinner.
author: Eric M.

description:
I love Papalote's!

A guy I dated turned me on to the one on 24th Street.  Doesn't it suck when you break up with someone because they are a lying cheating scumbag poopy face and you can't go to your favorite burrito place by their house??

Then Papalote's opened a new restaurant near my hood.  Now I can go all the time and I don't have to go incognito!!

I love Papalote's!
author: Sarah T.

description:
will power = living 1.5 blocks from Papalote and having it programmed into my phone

PROS:
-the best chips/salsa EVER
-affordable
-healthier than traditional taquerias
-friendly/attentive staff

CONS:
-crowded all the time
-cannot get seat until after you order
author: Em C.

description:
I was skeptical at first but now I'm really into this place! They make your food as you order it--That's right, when you order grilled chicken, they grill it right then. That means there are no metal tins of grilled chicken or carne just sitting there all day being heated. Good vegetarian options too (grilled, marinated tofu!). Good salsa. Free chips. They bring the food to your table too!
Sure it may take a little longer than most taquerias but its worth the wait knowing that what you ordered is fresh.
Oh, did I mention how good the prices are?!
author: Jackie O.

description:
Fresh. Clean. Tasty. What else? Well, it does these qualities so well that I've not patronized any other Mexican place since its opening (okay, maybe 6 months after its opening when I finally tried it when the line wasn't out the door). Seriously, I won't go anywhere else. Do you know how many places still cook their beans in lard? You'd be surprised. And it's not just the lard. I taste grease and sweat and BO in my regular Mission burritos.

Thank you, Papalote, for raising the bar. And giving me dinner without the aforementioned additives. 

I haven't mentioned the salsa yet. Its homemade salsa is the best I've ever tasted. It's also incredibly spicy, even for the spicy tolerant like me. I have to save mine and eat it separately from my meal. If I eat the salsa first the spice gets in the way of the flavor of the meal. This is sad. It could improve upon its salsa by taking the spice factor down a notch or two. 

Still not enough to dock points off my 5 rating. I've loved Papalote for 4 years now, and it's been deliciously consistent. And clean, fresh, and tasty. Thank you!
author: Stephanie P.

description: The burritos are really nothing special, but the salsa here is absolutely PHENOMENAL. They sell jars to take home, which I totally recommend.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Today is Thursday.  Tuesday was my first introduction of Papalote, and I've already gone back.  It's that good.  And that cheap.  Unsurprisingly, it's in the Mission, where you'll find some of the best culture and food of the city.  

Both times I have been it's been packed with hipsters.  The diversity here is sorely lacking, which is a polite way of saying that it was all white people being served by people who (I assume) are Hispanic.  Which bugs me, but the food is too good to pass up.

Both times the boyfriend and I shared a burrito and nachos.  The chips and salsa that come while you wait (and you do wait - it's packed), is so delicious.  I just want to eat that all day.  We shared a chicken burrito, where you could taste the freshness of all the ingredients.  We also had nachos.  The beans were amazing, the cheese was great, and the chips were crispy.  Oh goodness, it was so good.

The seating is limited, so don't bring a big crowd.  And if you have to wait for a table, well, you have to wait.  A lot of people do take-out, or order ahead.  But it's worth it.

While the price of a burrito is pretty average in SF, their prices are generally cheaper than most.  Sometimes only by about 30 cents, but sometimes by a few dollars.  A bean, rice, and salsa burrito is $3.75 (I believe).  Nachos & super chicken burrito was $14.
author: Margee B.

description:
I love this place! It is great for vegetarians, and offers Mexican cuisine that is not as greasy and fattening as somewhere like Puerto Alegre. This place has delicious food. I especially like the rice and bean tacos. They are relatively healthy and you get a lot of protein. Don't forget to get it "SUPER". for $1 extra you can get guac, sour cream, lettuce and yummy cheese. 

I usually get my orders to go from here, but they do have a dining area. 

This place gets crowded, so call your order ahead, and you can pick up and pay when you get there.
author: Anne K.

description:
Will start by saying I "grew up" loving Papalote. Been in the mission for 12 years. It was cool when the brothers were around more and caring for the place. I really like their food BUT they've gone too far. Went for a breakfast burrito...they have 4 choices, all pretty basic without anything special and they are all $9-10. So I asked for the Denver (onions, bell pepps, shrooms and cheese) and asked to add Soyrizo. Was going to be $4.50!! Sorry but I'm willing to pay for quality and for food I can't easily make at home. I can make a Soyrizo burrito at home easy. 

So I said no thanks and left. Funny how blatantly overcharging can put a bad taste in ur mouth. Had to run errands up in Noe, so stopped at a cool, sustainable little Mex place on 24th past Castro. Bfast burrito with roasted potatoes, poblanos, etc was $6.50 and added carnitas for $2.50. It was huge and delicious.

Not sure if I'm going back to papalote for reg burritos or not. Hope u guys are paying attention and adjust your pricing. I might pay $15 for a really interesting, more gourmet bfast burrito...but not your basic one.
author: Steven M.

description: The pink salsa has just the right amount of trailing spice. Fish taco is fresh and juicy. One of the best I've had.
author: Stacy T.

description:
A caveat in advance: this is NOT traditional Mexican fare, or even the traditional California interpretation of Mexican fare.  This is healthy and yupp-ified.  

Which, when you want it, and can appreciate it as something separate is AMAZING here.  Their salsa is really really good and I love to dump the stuff on the chicken burrito.  The pescado tacos are scrumptious and on the lighter side if you're not in the mood for a carbo coma.
author: James M.

description:
After hearing so many good things from friends, colleagues and even sources like Chow Magazine, I was excited to give Papalote a shot when my co-workers decided to head there for lunch. Finally, I would have a chance to sample their "practically-orgasmic" salsa!

Papalote is a taqueria with partial table service. You order your food at the counter, grab a drink, pay your way, take a number and head over to a table in the side room and eagerly await the server with your taco, burrito, quesadilla or other standard taqueria fare... which is exactly what I did. 

The chips (still warm) and salsa were brought almost immediately - and for all intents and purposes, they were the highlight of the meal. The rich orange salsa was spicy, sweet and had a complexity of flavor not commonly found in the condiment. The texture was smooth with black flecks - possibly from black pepper or from the skin of roasted pumpkin or peppers (yep - the secret ingredient, I have been told, is pumpkin seeds). This salsa's only competition for #1 in San Francisco is by Orale Orale.

The steak for the Carne Asada (which got very high marks from my co-workers), as well as the chicken, is cooked to order on a grill instead of scooped out of a steam table bin... and though I didn't sample it, the meat certainly looked good: appropriately charred and tender.

The pork Chile Verde was also quite good, with distinct flavors of tomatillo, cilantro and citrus in the sauce. Unfortunately, this filling, when combined with refried beans, cheese, rice and guacamole and wrapped in a tortilla, didn't meld into that cheesy-goopy goodness that makes an excellent burrito. It was good, but not great. Certainly not on par with Victor's or Mexico au Parc - which just goes to show you: even if every component of a dish is excellent, sometimes it doesn't come together properly to make something amazing. This time, the components were better than the sum of its parts.

$8.89 for a super burrito, chips, salsa and a bottle of grapefruit soda. 3 stars for now, but I will certainly be back to try a carne asada quesadilla.
author: Avery G.

description:
2 reasons to go here:
Triple Threat Burrito 
Home made Salsa (This is really good stuff and not your average tomato stuff!)

Fast service and they are definately friendly to the vegan crowd.  Warning: if you don't put the salsa on the burrito then it can be pretty dry and salty!  I also get a jar of that salsa when I do go.
author: Jason A.

description: After a long flight what is better than a burrito bigger than your head.  I ordered the pork burrito and was pleased.  The meat was distributed through out and every bite had a little bit of everything.  The salsa is delicious with a real kick.  The guacamole was tasty and definitely worth ordering.  Next time I get a hankering for a burrito I am stopping here.
author: Megan P.

description:
I went to try the Salsa that I've heard so much about. My personal preference is for fresh, chunky salsa. This one was more of a spicy, tomato soup consistency. 

Despite the disappointment with the salsa, I had a Chicken Super Burrito and absolutely loved it.   The chicken was grilled perfectly and the cheese was completely melted in the beans.  I also appreciated the option of Tortilla (wheat, white, spinach & one more I forgot) and also the choice of beans.

I will be back for sure.
author: Michelle L.

description: Did not like mole chicken :/ Was not happy about the hype of this place =(
author: Tiff W.

description: This place is okay. The burritos are large and filled. The salsa is a thick paste rather than a traditional salsa. The salsa has a smoky flavor but is not very spicy. I was disappointed by the Carne asada. It didn't have any seasoning on it and did not seem marinated. It was dry and had a burnt taste.
author: DTronics T.

description:
2.5 like a fancy chipotle in taste.  quintessential sf.  look at the menu.  vegan soyrizo, marinated tofu, etc.  no carnitas, al pastor, etc.
took away 2 carne asada tacos here, $7 topped with guac. and all the americanized toppings.  steak cooked to order at least, otherwise not my style.  as a side note, the salsa with the chips was very nice and hearty.
author: Rob C.

description: Had a great soyrizo burrito (and half of my friend's mole burrito) and it was really delicious! Loved the chips and salsa that's made from fire roasted tomatoes which comes with your burrito. It's a little pricier than your average taqueria but worth it since their vegan options are incredibly tasty.
author: Susan D.

description:
a solid four stars for the food and for trying their best to manage the crowds... the staff really tries to make sure everything's orderly. the only thing they can't always control is how long people decide to dilly-dally at the table after their food has been eaten and plates practically cleared away, oblivious to others who are waiting. come on now, people!

the food was very fulfilling with lots of meat and flavor. i had the chicken mole burrito and literally couldn't stop eating until it was all gone... and it's a big sucker! i liked the radish (i think?) condiment they and of course those famous chips and salsa... it's more along the lines of a creamy looking spicy sauce than a pico de gallo but so nice!

anyway, next time around i'll probably just do pick-up and go home.
author: Andrey C.

description:
The best burritos in SF and yes, the salsa rocks.

Call ahead if you go during lunch time, or you might have to wait.
author: Frank d.

description: Buy the fresh salsa in the mason jar it is in the trudge. A great gift.
author: Andy C.

description: 1 measly star for the minuscule dollop of guacamole they put in a little bitty cup that usually holds salsa or sauces at a taco bar... $1.50 for barely a tablespoon. I've had better made at table side for lots less $$. Really $1.50? Seriously?
author: Cydney B.

description:
Hnads down, Papalotes has the best salsa. Whenever I come here, I can't help but dip everything I order here in the salsa. The chips that come with your order are warm and delicious. A big plus!

Grilled chicken super burrito (sour cream, guac, rice, beans, cheese and salsa) is da bomb.

Call in your order ahead so you don't have to wait in the long line once you arrive. The dining room here looks cute, but I always get my food to go.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
1 star: It's colorful and well lite and a happening joint compared to many other taquerias in the mission. Line out the door...
1 star: Prawn Tacos...yes my friends, that's all I have to say!
1 star: My friends liked their dishes too, nachos, burrito.
1 star: The style and flavors aren't generic, must be the grillz!
author: Venatius P.

description: Still good after so many visits. Yes is does cost nearly double the price of el farlito.  You're paying for the differences, cleanliness, atmosphere vegan options. El farlito is a place you eat at with your boys, and don't mind the greasy food, greasy tables, cramp seating. Papalote you take a date, order the vegan dish to impress them you're health conscious. A lot cleaner. Being more health conscious, they don't have carnitas, and many good fried meats like many other places.
author: Robin L.

description: They used to have really good burritos but the last time I came here my carne asada was dry. I'm a bit disappointed but their chips and salsa is still the same. Maybe it's a hit or a miss with this place. Oh well there's more burrito places around.
author: Ruby O.

description: The salsa is insanity.  Don't let a single drop go to waste!   I'll keep this short  as review #661.  *DO* order the tacos camarones and *DO* order an aqua fresa to wash it down (fresh, small chunks of strawberry, and not too sweet).
author: Sarah G.

description:
This is my favorite Mexican restaurant ever.  The salsa is fabulous.  Too bad they give it to you in teeny tiny little containers and then charge you for more--  but hey, it's worth it.  I would probably sit there all day and eat chips and salsa if it was free.

I love the veggie tacos (potatoes, carrots, mushrooms in a corn tortilla).  Everything always tastes fresh.  I love that everything isn't smothered in cheese, either.  Lots of vegetarian options (tofu mole, soyrizo and tons of others.) I even brought my mom here and she loved it, too!

And parking sucks, but that's to be expected.
author: Sharon G.

description:
Upscale, yuppy burritos.  But totally worth it.  And the fire-roasted salsa is awesome.   I've gone here many times just for the salsa.

Recommended selection: Steak burrito, black beans, grilled mushrooms.  The mushrooms are a little extra, but worth every penny.

Only downside is that it's so popular that it's often difficult to find seating.  But I still love my 'lote.
author: Rusty S.

description:
The food is ok. I mean, it averages out to OK, overall. The salsa, like everyone says, is fantastic. The carne asada quesadilla I had way really, really salty. And then, I wanted more tortilla chips to munch, and when they charge $1.00 for more chips, it doesn't include more salsa. 

Which brings me to the last point I'll make: this place is really expensive for what you get.
author: dana l.

description: Great food Great people Crap! Price!  I have gone to you guy's for years the people who take orders over the phone knew me by name and I stood up for you guy's as my friends raced to el faralito.. I'm sorry but why should you get rich while we suffer in this horrible economy..3 years ago I would have given you 5 stars but your constant rate hikes have ruined your great food for me..change your price and ill change my review..You guy's can go to Manhattan and charge $50 for a burrito as amazing as yours but please don't reem the cats that got you started...I respect your food and understand this city is not cheap but I implore you E lean to the mission side don't go Noe Valley..keep it affordable or at least put out some taco trucks with the original price for the people still on the street..you'll make money we'll be happy..
author: Annie H.

description:
EXCELLENT burritos.  I had a mole which was delicious and my friend had a soy/veggie one which was spiced really well.  It was a decent price but a little more expensive then i am use to for a burrito.

Nice atmosphere, little space to sit and enjoy the meal.  It was PACKED when i was there.  I recommend this place especially if you like mexican food!
author: Michelle S.

description:
You have to wait here for your burrito on most nights, sometimes for quite awhile....but it's worth it for that flaky grilled tortilla filled with perfection!

Every bite of my tofu mole burrito was hot and delicious with those amazing Papalote black refried beans!

The salsa here will ROCK your world...there's something in it for everyone...heat, flavor, and spice!
author: Britt M.

description: One of the best taquerias in SF.  Their mole is awesome!  I just wish the place was bigger as it can get crowded and hard to find a seat.
author: J R.

description:
Well whatever I may as well toss my hat into the ring here. I've lived in the Mission for 20 years now, on and off (the 1989 quake celebrations reminded me of that - I moved here 2 months before it, god I got an earful from my freaked-out Midwestern relatives for years afterwards. As if a tornado hadn't wiped a town right off the map 10 miles away from where I grew up. Hell-o).

At first when Papalote came around, I snubbed it. I admit it. I thought it was a dumb-assed idea. Healthy, gourmet-esque, burritos? With roasted vegetables? Posers.

But then I got older and started to not really want to feel kinda sick every time I ate a burrito. I'm not knockin' the more traditional (yes, yes, I know, burritos are not really from Mexico - but there is a burrito standard nonetheless, at least here in SF) burrito joints. I still go to them, they're awesome, but sometimes I'm craving a burrito but still want to sleep at night without feeling like I'm about to explode.

So I went to Papalote, just a few years back. Yummy chips, very fresh. Definitely a plus. Tasty jicama salad - unusual. Roasted salsa - a bit cheeky, but I gotta admit, pretty damn good. And shrimp cooked in white wine burrito - niiiiiice.

So now I work Papalote into my burrito rotation. Everything is yummy and fresh, and the lettuce here (used on tacos, not burritos) is real green lettuce, not iceburg crap.

A nice addition to the neighborhood.
author: Dusty R.

description:
$20 for the triple threat burrito?  No thanks.  Bobby Flay or no Bobby Flay, that's just challenging our intelligence.

I used to be a semi-regular customer here, but I don't think I'm going back.  They were kinda rude to my friend RC too.  Boo.
author: Jon B.

description: Great chips and salsa, especially compared to a lot of the taquerias in San Francisco that, for some god awful reason do not make their chips fresh, or if they do, consistently end up stale (I'm looking at you, El Farolito). Delicious burrito as well, though not the best in town.
author: Richa A.

description:
Most amazing nachos EVER! If you are a vegetarian, this is the best mexican food. They have a ton of delicious options and everything tastes FRESH. 
They have the most amazing salsa!
author: Aidan K.

description:
The good: The salsa. The fish tacos. 
The awful: Crappy vegetarian options. Just a little eggplant here or some potato there. I had the worst quesadilla possible there, like a microwaved castrophe with barely any cheese and dried out tortilla, everything piled to one side. If you want to go veg, go to Little Chihuahua. Less money, better variety and fresher ingredients.
author: Katie R.

description: The salsa lives up to the hype. The triple threat is overpriced but still delicious. Overall, a solid burrito place, albeit a little more pricy than other equally scrumptious burrito establishments.
author: Lisa H.

description:
i admit that bobby flay bugs the sh*t outa me. pretentious and seems to do the same thing over and over... yawn. so when i heard this place beat him in a throwdown, i had to go and throwdown (pun intended) my money to taste their beatdown burrito.

bobby flay sucks more then i thought. the burrito was good, not great. my tortilla was dry. the flavors inside were nothing extraordinary and blended without any peaks. how bad bobby must be for this to have won???

the lone exception was the salsa... i wanted to take a bath in it. but amigos, charging me for a tiny refill was not nice, esp. as it was needed to moisten my superdry tortilla. (sigh) ultimately, not anywhere i need ever visit again unless craving the salsa solo.
author: Missy D.

description:
HEY DON'T JUST FOLLOW THE CROWD KIDS--

There is no Reason on Gods green earth that this place should be as popular as it seems to be.NONE. Seriously folks. Here a few of the reasons:

1. You have pay for extra chips or salsa. And pay ALOT

2. God awful to nonexistent customer service

3. Insane packed lines to wait for so so mexican food

Now I will say the one good thing about soyrizo. tasty no doubt. 

But come on--this is the mission in sf, it not like there not a thousand other taqueria all around you, be an individual man go to an actual good place.
author: Vasile S.

description:
The first time I went to Papalote's, I tried the Super Pollo burrito, and it was so good it made my toes curl.  

Okay, toe curling aside...this burrito was, by far, one of the best burritos here in the city that I had tasted.  The size was perfect, not Godzilla sized  and overflowing with rice and beans, and not too tiny to leave me wanting more.  It was like a perfect little package of burrito love that I could hold in my hands!

When I took my first bite, I was in heaven.  The flavors were savory and every bite contained an equal part of all the yummy ingredients.  Nothing is more annoying than biting into a burrito and eating all rice, then all beans then your meat and...oh, there's the cheese (you get the idea).  The tortilla was nicely grilled prior to being assembled, giving it a nice crispy texture.

The salsa is so friggin good you'll want more (and they take this into consideration because they charge you extra if you go back for more).  For those who just can't get enough, I believe you can purchase their salsa to take home.

The only reason I didn't give Papalote's 5 stars was because on a few recent occasions that I went in, the burrito just wasn't up to par.  I'm not sure if the burrito assembly line in the back was having an off day, but the taste and quality just wasn't there.  

All in all, a great burrito for a good price with salsa that'll knock your shoes off and curl your toes.
author: Christy L.

description: I'm not a big fan of Mexican food, never have been, but this place is pretty good.  Great grilled vegetable fajitas with grilled chicken.  I've had most of the quesadillas on the menu and liked them all.  The vegan mole with tofu is pretty good too.  The atmosphere is pretty much your typical Mission hole with a casual vibe.  The only thing I'd improve on is the order first and wait for something to open up style of self seating .  I don't like eating and watching a half dozen people stare me down in the hope of making me swallow my food faster.
author: P.J. D.

description: Scrum-didily-yum!  A little more expensive than other places in the mission, but totally worth it! The taco's are huge, and have tons of fresh ingredients.  Oh, and don't forget the chips and salsa!
author: Laura P.

description:
Delicioso! Wanted a good burrito place where we could sit down and not feel like we're in one of the in-n-out, i'm probably drunk, burrito places all over the mission. 

Got chicken mole tacos, churizo/cheese dipping appetizer thingy and guacamole. Highly recommend all 3! 

seating can be a pain, the whole stalking people eating and jumping on a table when they're getting up, but it's worth it.
author: Sarah G.

description:
The soyrizo is excellent: slightly sweet, perfectly mushy, and seasoned in heaven. The salsa is smoky and smooth. 

One of my favorite burrito places. I would move to the city to be closer to The Papa, but they had the genius to put themselves 3 minutes away from the 24th Street BART stop.

Sometimes I worry that I'm not going to get a table, and you can't save a table while your friend orders. Mercifully, the Gods of Vegan Mexican Food in the Mission always smile down on us and a table opens at just the right moment. Now I must sacrifice a tofu-shaped virgin to appease this cruel cruel god.
____________________________________________________
I once saw a "wanted" sign here posted by some girl who struck up a conversation with some guy while she waited for her order. It was a really cute sign about how they hit it off and she even went to the effort of taking out an email address so he could get in touch, something like "webothwaitedforburritos@something.com" which I thought was a cute touch. I hope they reconnected and got married. Does anyone have closure on this?
author: Ross G.

description:
This morning I woke up and knew that if I did not consume a burrito before the end of the day, all would not be right with the world.  But where should I procure said burrito?  Do I go with the tried and true El Farolito deliciousness, or do I try something new and branch out?  Felt a bit adventurous today, so figured I'd try something new.  I heard about Papalote from my sister and she couldn't stop raving about it, so bring it on.

As the other reviewers have noted, their food is definitely more fresh than your standard taqueria fare.  Bonus points for feeling good about eating "healthy" while indulging in my burrito.  The carne asada was really flavorful and I especially liked how they put the burrito on the grill so that it'd be toasty instead of the mushy tortilla you get at other taquerias that put their tortillas in that steam thingy.  

Last, but definitely not least, their salsa is insane good.  I've always been partial to Zona Rosa's red sauce, but this salsa could possibly be my new favorite.  The only negative about this place is that they know how good their salsa is and ration it out.  They only give you a set amount of salsa, and if you want more, they may charge you $0.50.  Seriously?  Charging for what amounts to be a condiment?  But honestly, I thought about paying up...it's THAT good.
author: Norm U.

description:
Best salsa! & you can take some home with you in a nifty mason jar...
Burritos are not the best, but their tacos are really very good.

But go for the salsa. It really is remarkable!
author: kristin n.

description:
Papalote is in my speed dial.

I am sure that there are many tasty tasty things that they make at Papalote.  But the Super Soyrizo Burrito is SO good that I can't bring myself to order anything else.  

I always have a really hard time because the salsa is also SO good... and I want to fill up on chips and salsa before the burrito comes and then it's even harder to finish the whole thing.  If I go alone next time, and no one's looking, perhaps I'll just drink the salsa and skip the chips... 

Seriously though, it is often distressing to me because I wish I could eat a whole super burrito without getting to the pants unbuttoning level of stuffed-ness.  Don't get me wrong, I still eat the whole thing, it's hard to stop, I just deal with the consequences.

I have also tried the vegan mole tacos which were a tad salty but super yummy and the mole burrito which was a little drippy but good also.

I wish it were open later than 10.
author: Linda L.

description: That triple threat burrito is a killer! I'm pretty sure it was made for male consumption but ladies if u are hungry, get that burrito because it is well worth the price! Just keep TUMS in your purse for later!
author: Samantha E.

description:
meh!  this is my second or third visit, and it was supposed to be the redemption visit, but i was disappointed in almost every way.

first, theres a HUGE line at this place now cause of some bobby flay throwdown smackdown WWE whatever.  who cares?  hipsters care apparently.

second, you cant just get a table here and enjoy your chips and salsa (and agua fresca) while you wait for your burrito.  by the time you sit down, they pretty much come out at the same time.  if you cant see a problem with this, dont speak to me.

third, the 7x7 list thinks very highly of the orange salsa, which is above average, but not stellar.  this might anger some, but rubio's smoky chili salsa is far superior.  also, whats with the little tiny shot of it?  not nearly enough.

fourth, i get my burrito and its pretty freakin small for a super that costs $8.50.  also, its not wrapped in foil WHICH IS A REQUIREMENT.  the tortilla itself is not very chewy, and there is barely a DROP of sour cream in the whole thing.  overall, pretty dry, and a little below average.  that's right, i said it.

fifth, there was some different salsa garnish on the plate...mine had barely any at all.  whats the point of putting any on?  this was seriously a joke.

sixth, still hungry, i want more salsa, but i was told this costs $.55.  are you freaking kidding me??  the tiniest amount of salsa to begin with, and a refill is $.55?  its not all that, mmkay?

seventh...naw thats it.  you are not that great, papalote.  i actually saw people in here eating the $20 burrito and looking very disappointed.  and i could see why!  its not big, and theres nothing special about it...it just has three kinds of meat.  what a freakin joke.

dont get suckered in!  gordos, el farolito, el toyanense, and CHIPOTLE are far superior.  believe me...i know burritos.
author: Robert S.

description:
This place is not worth the high rating it gets.  Is it good?  Yes.  And if I was in the neighborhood I might eat at it again, but it is nothing special.  As far as the salsa?  Not that big of a fan.  To me it tasted more like hot wing sauce than salsa.  It was spicy and had a good taste, but Salsa it is not.  

Very small place and we had to wait a little bit to squeeze into a table.  

So if you are in the Mission District try it out, if not don't make a trip over there just for it.
author: Adam F.

description:
Excellent choice for a 'higher-end' burrito, just one block down from the 24th Street BART station for about $5-6. On this particular occasion I chose the chicken mole, a nice blend of salt and spice, mixed in well with healthy black beans and really good rice, some of the best black rice I've had around the Bay Area and that says a lot. My buddy swears by the griilled chicken, and rates this as one of the top burrito places in the Mission.

I reserved inserting that '5th star' just because, I don't know, a 5-star place should be really really awesome, and this probably is a really awesome, but I can't say that I was blown away, but then again, I don't know how a burrito could blow me away.

The place is colorful and filled with young idealists, the type who read Kant and look like they want to make a difference in the world. Oh wait, that was me. S***.

The only thing that bothered me was the water cooler, whose knob you had to turn 10 times, only to get it to spout  water at a flow rate slower than the Mississippi, or perhaps like a guy who has a hard time peeing. Perhaps it's a ruse to get you to buy a drink there. Sorry, I'm a cheapo.
author: Hubert H.

description:
You shouldn't judge a book by its cover .....but you can definitely judge a Mexican place by its salsa, and Papalote definitely has some of the best that I've tasted in the city (so far).  Normally I'm not a hot salsa fan, but theirs has just the right (comfortable) amount of heat and you can't help but keep dipping chips and shoveling your face with food.

Overall, the prices aren't bad at all.  I'd be willing to pay the $7 or so dollars for the special fish burrito I ordered.  As other yelpers attested, the ingredients are fresh and the combination is deeeeelicious.

The seating area was a little limited, and we had to enact the "search and hover" method because we were a group of five.  Luckily, a table cleared away just as our food came.  

Definitely worth a trip out to the mission - especially if you have a slow work day!
author: Shay F.

description:
$12 burrito what a joke!!!!! Two years later I gave this place a second chance and it was more disappointing this time around. Before I go any furher....I must tell you I decided to become a member of Yelp just to post this review tonight. Last time, I ordered a Triple Threat Burrito and paid close to $30 and was still hungry. Triple Threat doesn't mean triple the size or triple the meat/shrimp. This time I purchased a Prawn Super Burrito for $12.50 and of course I was still hungry. Why? There was only 4 shrimp inside. The only reason this place is still in business is because it was featured on The Food Network with Bobby Flay's showdown. It was because the salsa is good and on that episode the burrito was much larger. Please if you don't believe me; look it up on the web. 

The employees have attitude like they work at Gary Danko's except they don't! The chips are horrible and they couldn't more frugal with the amount of salsa and chips they provide.  I will never go back again!!!!! 

If you want something good and filling even though not Mexican go to Phat Philly's around the corner. It was delicious although still pricey...worth the $12 for a large. 

If you want real Mexican food or for that matter a delicous  burrito; go to La Cumbre, La Morena or La Tapatia. The last  two options are in South San Francisco.

Please don't support this establishment unless you think a shrimp is worth $3. 

Good Luck in your search and don't believe the hype on the reviews. 

Jay
author: jay m.

description:
You know how you go somewhere to eat and the food is so good and you're so starving that you shove an entire burrito and platter of chips and salsa in your mouth and then 10 minutes later you like, totally HATE mexican food and the thought of a taco makes you feel like vomiting? Yes?  Well, that's how I feel right now at this exact moment.  

I am, however, an extremely sophisticated human being and am able to distinguish between the "hatred coma" and my "true feelings" about a restaurant, and my true feelings about Papalote are this, "HOLY CRAP THAT'S SOME GOOD SALSA."  I had a green chile verde burrito and I ATE THE ENTIRE BURRITO, auhghghahghghghg, blah blah blah...vomitous, etc.  The burrito was good, you know, like average for mexican food but holy crapola was that salsa that I drowned my slab of lard in tasty, mmmhhhh, my lunch date wasn't lying when she said she sometimes ponders slathering it all over her body to attract men....now, if you'll excuse me I need to go to the bathroom and throw up, and then apply this wonder tonic...
author: Claire C.

description:
chile verde super burrito ordered herr, bloods.

2 things stand head and shoulders above all other burritos:

1. the sauce: great spice, delicious flavors. try it.
2. the something-or-other spice in the burrito. there was some flavor in this bad boy that made other burritos bow down to it as other rappers do to ice cube, WC, and mack 10 from the westside connection.
author: Victor B.

description: I've been going to this place before it was featured on the Food Network.  This is one of my favorite taquerias in the city.  I go there for their awesome salsa and chile verde (which I never order anywhere else).  But, I had to take off two stars because it's been a nightmare to go there ever since the were featured on Bobby Flay, even calling in and picking up takes forever.  The phone line is always busy and I've had to redial, as if I was trying to win a prize on the radio.  Of course, I had to try the triple threat but save your money and get something else because it's definitely not worth $20!  It's good but not THAT good.
author: Marleen C.

description: Good Mexican food.  Didn't blow me away but I enjoyed everything I had.  Not sure it's as good as the hype.
author: Ben M.

description:
Food was actually really good, I ordered the veggie burrito and the tofu tacos (gotta love my vegetarian ass!) - and they were both fabulous, washed it down with a guiness.  

Problem?  Why only 2-stars?  The service was shitty.  We went in at around 9pm, and the lady with the slick back hair told us 4 times they were trying to close up so we needed to hurry. 

Bitch, let me eat my paid for food in peace, the place closes at 10.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
Salsa.
Salsa.
Salsa.
Chilaquiles made with THE salsa. 

I love the chilaquiles at Palalote, and I end up needing 2 agua frescas because they are so damn spicy...but I love 'em anyway. 

I can't stand the little jicama side salad. It looks good; it has the potential to be good, but it seems overseasoned with some chile lime powder stuff. Sometimes the cashier is impatient and not so friendly, but I can definitely see the wide appeal of this place.
author: Dora A.

description:
This place used to be a great little find. Now it's an institution in SF. All because of that magic salsa. I think they get that smokey flavor from using roasted tomatoes Or something! It's different, that's for sure and damn delicious! 
Shrimp Quesadillas, I'm missing you.
author: Macelle A.

description: I hope Papalote improves their technique for this Food Network challenge. (See my review below). The cut vegetables should look like someone actually took the time to cut them, not just throwing leftover carrot ends in a pot. Some attention should be paid to balance and flavor and texture in the proportions of ingredients.
author: E. M.

description:
I have no excuses your honor...

Gasps and gapping jaws aplenty when people find out I haven't been here yet and now I know why. Having lived within blocks of this place for the last 2 years I have no excuses - it's a pure and utter tragedy of epic proportions. This place offers fantastic vegetarian mexican options - many without eggplant (sorry, but this vegetarian likes eggs and plants, but not those purple spongy, mucus like things).

After a grueling morning of conference calls without my morning diet coke I hopped on the 48 (don't judge!) and zoomed down to papalote.

I've never had potatoes and carrots in a quesadilla before and I've been sorely missing out. Despite a Friday lunch rush at noon I was able to zoom in grab a table and enjoy my diet coke within 10 minutes of leaving the house (seriously - no judging...)

Meant to ask them what creamy deliciousness they served with my chips, but alas work calls - whatever it was it was pure delight!

They will be replacing my Noe Valley Casa Mexicana mainstay for their range of vegetarian options!
author: Ennis O.

description:
The food here is great.  I love the nachos and the burritos hit the spot every time.

Cons: 
- Waiting for your food can be a drag since they are always so busy here... 20-30 minutes for takeout.
- They have forgotten to upgrade burrito's to "super" 3 out of the 10 times I've ordered from there.
author: Matt H.

description: The salsa here is basically crack cocaine.  If you don't think you can handle that kind of addiction in your life, avoid this place at all costs.
author: Monica R.

description: Known within my household as Papa-slo-te, because they must be some kind of union at the rate they out put a burrito.  They do make fresh and comparatively healthier Mexican fare with interesting burrito options like chili verde and mole with chicken or tofu.  Also, pretty good fish tacos, a rarity of the Mission, but not Baja style. Helpful hints:  at lunch time the strollers descend from the hilltop of Noe Valley and fill up the room, it will take you about 20-30 min. after ordering to get your food, and they will charge you something crazy for a side of guacamole.  Lastly, I feel like you kind of deserve it if you feel ripped off after dropping $20 on a burrito, even if you saw it on the TV, so stick to the menu that doesn't sound crazy and you should be fine.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
I'm allergic to fish & kind of think sauteed vegetables in a tortilla is lame. 

Their salsa is good, but why do they got to Jew you out of it? If you sit alone, they give you ONE small thing. If you sit with a friend they also give you ONE small thing of salsa. At El Farolito I could walk up to the salsa bar with a trough, fill it up & come back 10 minutes later for more. 

Really? This is the place you're all creaming yourselves for?
author: Rebekah K.

description: Came here JUST for the chips and salsa ($1.50). The chips are just ok...taste store bought, not salty enough. But dude. the salsa. SPICY. Its pretty damn good. Totally addicting, each time you take a bite of it, your mouth burns just a bit more. Its pretty good. :)
author: Carol L.

description: It's good, but slightly over-hyped in my opinion. The girl below me is right on about the salsa: it's nice and spicy but the flavor is a little lacking or overpowered by salt. The burrito was fine, nice big serving and coke out of a glass bottle is nice. I like that you can "Super" anything for just 99 cents extra.
author: Brian B.

description:
Oh my god so good and so worth the wait!! My tofu taco was divine heaven in my mouth!!

Also, I loved how they literally had the produce stock in the front of the ordering area. Every now and then a dude from the back would come and grab an onion.
author: Larisa S.

description:
Honestly, the food was really good. I had the grilled veggie - eggplant and zucchini burrito, which was really yummy. Also, the salsa that they give you for your chips is amazing. I was just upset when I asked for a small side of sour cream and they charged me $1.50 - then I looked on the menu, and a side of sour cream, guacamole and Cheese was listed as $.99, WTF? Whatever, I'm sure I'll be back because it was healthy and tasty, but they need to get their prices in order!!! Oh yeah, and get some larger water cups while you're at it. 

Thank you.
author: meagan m.

description:
Hook me up with some tasty tacos y burritos! Oh, I can get an Orangina to go with that? Sweet. Now that I'm on the East Coast, this is the spot I'm SURE to hit up when I'm back in San Francisco. Don't skimp on the secret recipe salsa, which is to die for.

Burritos aren't as good a deal as La Taqueria, but yummy yummy...
author: Daniela F.

description:
FIRST! not.

The big debate in SF is of course where the best burrito is made. It ain't here.

But 'lote is good. My main problem is their fucked up salsa. I can't decide if I like it, or if it's so alarmingly weird that I should just hate on it for sheer principal. Let's go with "it's good salsa." But I'm deducting a star because I had to the think about it.

Also contributing to the loss of the star is that their chile verde, although good, is not nearly the best in the City. Try Taqueria Mana for that.
author: Josh B.

description: Yum! Chile Verde burrito, chips and salsa and a diet coke for under $10! But not sure is worth waiting 15 mins outside in the cold for a table...darn food network hype. kudos to papalote however! a must visit as a sampling of the mission for tourists or locals!
author: Michael K.

description: Well, I checked out this location. I told myself I would never come check out this location (parking and time dictated this decision).  trust me... this is the last nail on the coffin!    Their clientele is definately "unique"... I got a carne asada burrito plus a water... 11.00 bones.  This review is only for their carne asada burrito.... the meat was SUPER CHEWY and TOUGH!!!  At a place like this, that was the last thing I would expect.  I got a few laughs though.. a table next to me ordered a super threat burritto cut in half... they attempted to hold it and it fell all over the place!  They had to eat the thing with a fork.  All in all, Papalote is not my kind of taqueria.  I will say that it does a great job in attracting customers.
author: Demanding T.

description:
I love Papalote.

Tacos, burritos and fajitas are all very good.  Lots of items on the menu to chose from, plenty of vegetarian options if interested.

Salsa is good, not the typical pico de gallo.  It roasted and a little spicy.  

Breakfast burritos are served all day and VERY good.
author: Anna O.

description:
I love Papalote. Burritos, beer, jalepenos. Good combonations. If I had money to eat food and not starve, I would be there often, eating burritos....and drinking beer..... :(

EDIT: I ate one today. The entire burrito. It was delicious, the best. Yessss, I am so satisfied.
author: Kerry F.

description:
Papalote offers up yummy fresh food at reasonable prices. They make their own salsa that is AMAZING! Everyone I have been there with has wound up buying a jar to take home with them. They serve you chips with salsa while you wait for your food to arrive. The burritos are big enough that I always have leftovers. Talk about economical, not to mention a very happy stomach!
I just found out, thanks to Yelp, that there is another Papalote location nearer to where live at Fulton and Masonic. I am going to go check it out.
The location I have been to is on 24th @ Valencia in the Mission District. I recommend going to take one of The Yoga Tree's fabulous yoga classes (1234 Valencia @ 23rd) then cruising down the street to Papalote to get their super yummy fresh watermelon juice and a burrito.
author: Christine P.

description: I've pretty much only have had their Regular Veggie Burrito and gallons of their delicious & addicting house made salsa, but I love it! It's a little crowded, especially in the front where you have to order. That can be annoying sometimes, but once you eat the food you forget anyway.
author: Daffodil K.

description:
Were it in Pittsburgh
PMG would likely be
The best mex in town
author: Patrick T.

description:
As a burrito connoisseur I have to say that Papalote is sublime.

Now, Papalote is not a run of the mill burrito shop.  There's hundreds if not thousands of excellent burrito places in the Mission alone.  There's burrito shops next to burrito shops, burrito shops stacked on top of each other.  Burrito shops on wheels!

...But there's something unique about this place, starting with the salsa.

I have dreams about their delicious salsa and am thankful that you can buy it by the pint.

It's become a ritual to me whenever I go there not to eat the salsa with the chips right away, the secret is to use it on the burrito.

The salsa makes everything better.  Heavenly's the word.

Besides the salsa, which is a litmus test for any Mexican restaurant, there's the Marinated Tofu.

OMG!  Though I'm no longer a vegetarian I need Papalote's Marinated Tofu every once in a while or my life is just not complete.

It's hard for me to write about the cons when I love the little imperfections or nuances of this place and the food is this addictive.

The portions are not humongous, they're modest...

And it's way too far from my house.  I want a Papalote truck parked on the street where I live or better yet, following me around the city wherever I go.

But I can't have that and that's very painful to me.
author: Francisco G.

description: Hello, I must say that this is the first time that the Yelp reviews and the 7x7 magazine both disappointed me to such an extent. This place actually won out of 7 other places in 7x7 taste test??? really/?? crazy. we walked in expecting a super duper burrito. The place was very cute and the service was very nice and efficient. HOWEVER, the burrito was as far from Mexico as u can get. The ingredients were fresh, but pretty much, u got a Chipotle burrito. An American version of a burrito and not a really good. Sorry, living in San Francisco I got spoiled and prefer authentic Mexican food without the fluff :(
author: marina g.

description:
This would have been a 3 star rating had there not been bottles of Prohibition on the premises.  Although not terrible by any means the food is not exactly worth the price you pay.
