It was nacho day for me, a friend of mine recommended the joint and it was within jogging distance.    Re-fried black beans are always a nice surprise for me but I'm not sure if you get the lard options.  The chicken was grilled in some type of orange marinade which looked cool but did not do much for the flavor.  Taquerias are not worth a damn if they don't give large portions and for 8 dollars I better not be able to finish my plate.  I left full and satisfied so I'll go back but probably for something in the vegi category.

Conclusions: It definitely had the "we are catering to the gringos" vibe.
author: ray M.

description:
let's just talk about the real travesty here.

the thimble of amazing salsa they give you, but only a tiny thimble. 

the last time i went here me and my boyfriend decided to share the triple threat twenty dollar burrito and they would only give us the tiny thimble of salsa for the both of us even though we had just dropped twenty bucks on the thing.

completely bogus move. 

in the name of customer service make more salsa and quit with the scarcity tactics. salsa should be plentiful and included in the mexican restaurant experience at no extra cost like it is at any other place in the mission. plus everything is just a little more expensive then any other taqueria in the neighborhood and our triple threat burrito sucked. 

from me and my boyfriend two thumbs down. way down.
author: Deez N.

description: Completely overrated food. The burritos are bland and mushy.
author: Andrea B.

description:
i'm down like a clown with paplote -

i am huge fan of super burritos and i've gone all around the bay trying my share of carne asada super's. Papalote reached TOP on my list for the bay - but definitely not number one on my pallet.

Their meat is delicious and there's huge chunks, i almost wish they would chop them one more time to be more bite sized. Their super burrito was almost perfect - except that there wasn't any gauc ( or such a small amount that u couldnt even tell.
\
Salsa = awesome. - and adds a lot to the burrito - i was dipping the huge chunks of meat that were falling out in it - mmmmm

I will say however, that if El Farolito's burrito's were a little...a lot bigger, they'd give this place a run for their money.
author: Shadi N.

description: awesome food. I got the chicken mole burrito. Definitely go there again. My friend got the breakfast burrito and said it wasn't that good.
author: josh m.

description:
Kind of silly art and an overly clean space say C'MON WHITE KIDZ.
Chile Verde tacos - so so. Not worth $5.15 for two, at all. No service complaints, but no warmth either. Salsa obviously delicious. Should have spent $1.50 on chips+salsa and left it at that.
author: Will T.

description: $8 for a tiny vegetarian burrito that tastes like crap? no thanks. Their prices keep going up up up and their burritos get worse tasting and smaller by the day.. They get the extra star for their salsa being good, but they give you almost none..
author: jake l.

description: yum yum yummy.  Very good salsa, tacos, burritos and I love the refried black beans.
author: Bucky M.

description: After becoming Gluten Free (by choice).....I still have LOVE for my papalote! I got the grilled prawn burrito (on a plate without the tortilla).....with guac, sour cream and black beans.....absolutely HEAVENLY with their famous sauce.....and probably 1000 calories less without that tortilla! Also has the watermelon Agua Fresca.....and which I loved so much that I got it to go.......YUM!
author: Lee M.

description: I think everything about this place has already been said. Stick with the burritos and you'll be in good shape. The carne asada is great- tender and tasty chunks of meat. But have to say that the chile verde left much to be desired. Atmosphere is nothing great- your typical mission hole. often hard to get a table- with a weird system of having to order first- so you don't actually know if you're going to get a table. The service is quick enough, but not friendly, etc. Still worth checking out!
author: Steph C.

description: yesterday evening I had my first Tofu Super Nachos...accompanied by a Fat Tire... The Tofu was charboiled to perfection...of course I also had a taste of my friend's taco plate and it too was delicious. I think I'll need to try everything on the menu once.
author: Mimi T.

description: After trying many a burrito joint up and down this lovely state, I have to say that this has to be the best salsa ever. It really does have a smokey, yet creamy taste to it.  And they stuff  the burritos with so much it can be a bit intimidating but just take the rest home if you can't finish. The warm chips to go with that heavenly salsa (along with a tidy dining area) gives you more reason to stay and dine in.
author: Art O.

description: It saddens me greatly that I have moved further away from Papalote.   Good burritos - particularly the carne asada, shrimp and fish ones and great salsa and chips. You can get a  burrito card and receive your 11th burrito free!  Staff is super friendly, ingredients are super fresh and location is super close to Bart. Super!
author: Kamael S.

description: I LOVE Papalote!  The salsa is the BEST!  The nachos are out of this world.  I've never had anything that I didn't want to eat again and again and again!!!
author: Karen C.

description: My favorite burrito place in San Francisco.  Grilled chicken and grilled steak are both fabulous.  The best salsa ever.  I love going here.  The burritos are big- so I usually save half.  The second half is still good hours later.   They serve beer too.
author: Madhuri K.

description: My stomach hurt after the ginormous soyrizo burrito here, but it was sooooo worth it.  They also have delicious homemade salsa.
author: Kaye W.

description: So all the hype from Yelp reviews to the Throwdown Challenge and the Tripple Threat burrito. I try not to drive too far from where i live over on Ocean Ave. I can just drive down to mission and hit up some very descent taco/burrito joints. Well the GF wanted to try this place, and i felt like some mexican food. We get to the place and place our order and it comes out to 25$ for regular carne asada tacos,pollo quesadilla, and carne asada nachos. So far this is the most ive ever spent for a hole in the wall spot. Ok, whatever right. Its suppose to be amazing. We end up waiting about 30-40 minutes because all these damn phone orders are coming in. If we would have known we would have left. Well its suppose to be great and great food sometimes takes time. Get the food and go home. Definitely fresh, but wheres the flavor? The Tacos are just "ok", the chicken quesadilla is the worst ive had on the mission(never had a bad one yet), and the Carne Asada Nachos literally Suck besides the thick carne asada meat. I prefer smaller cuts of the meat but oh well. The nacho chips were less than spectacular and the salsa was bland and tasteless. Now i lived in San Diego for 7 years. And so far some mexican spots here in SF can come close. But Papalote's fails in taste/price and service.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Hey guys, love that you have vegan options on the menu. Not too jazzed about the fact that a burrito with rice beans, veggies, ad guac has to cost $10 when I can get the same thing at that groovy little place on Mission right around the corner for $5. Even worse is waiting twenty minutes for said vegan burrito. And the kicker is getting home and halfway through it and in my hasty hunger, realizing I just ate half a chicken breast and  there indeed are no veggies in my burrito....Not so cool. Will never risk that happening again. I just hope I don't get sick tonight...
author: Avi K.

description: Best burrito in SF? Like Obama winning the Nobel Peace Prize. Absurd. Tasteless tortilla, over salted, and frankly, just plain dull. I mean the burrito. I also waited 40mins for my take out burrito. Does that happen anywhere?
author: k m.

description: I've never been here before but we were in the area so we thought we would give it a try.  I must say the fish anything is pretty good. I thought they would fry the fish but it's not!  Not a place for groups larger than 3 or 4 but I would come out again.
author: Elvin T.

description: A bit pricey.  Burrito wasn't spectacular.  The wait for take out food was too long.  Cramped space... not really any place to stand and wait for your food to be ready.
author: Danny C.

description:
Review #300.

Local, good burritos, good chips, great salsa, basic service, people in and out as soon as they finish, and there are always a few people waiting to go in...
author: T L.

description:
I gotta be honest: the first time I came here, I wasn't that impressed.  I had a standard burrito with carne asada, nothing to write home about.  

However, as a USF student, it's damn close to campus, so I made a second trip.  And I wasn't in the mood for anything too heavy this time around, so I had the eggplant and zucchini tacos.  DAMN.  Tastiest thing I've ever had in a tortilla.  I had it to go, so when I finally sat down to eat, the juices had split my tacos in half, making it impossible to hold, and I had no fork available.  However, it was so flavorful that I very quickly forgave the cooks at Papalote.

(I'm not vegetarian, btw.  I was thinking that perhaps they were making the veggie stuff taste so good to make up for not having meat... you know, to sell it to the carnivores, too.)

I got a little wiser by visit #3.  I ordered the eggplant and zucchini BURRITO this time.  And damn, that was satisfying.  Lasted me two meals!  And I didn't need a fork this time. :)  

Prices range from about $3-$7 for various items (thank god they accommodate for students).  I'm planning to make regular trips out there between classes.  Trip #4 will involve the marinated tofu at my classmate's suggestion.  

Oh yeah, and parking might be a pain.  Recommend the 1-hour street parking on Masonic or the Albertson's parking across the street (but you'll have to buy something from Albertson's to get it validated there, I think).
author: Phuong T.

description:
Yum. Yum. YUM!!!

Hey you could probably find a more "authentic" taqueria in the mission, but they probably don't have delicious roasted habanero salsa. And Soyrizo tacos. And most importantly...TOFU MOLE TACOS!!!

2 taco's are 4 bucks, and you get the tortilla chips and habenero salsa gratis. Plus like most of the taqueria's in the mission they have other delicious things...like real sugar-cane coke in a glass bottle.

Love it.
author: JC R.

description:
One of the better places in SF to grab some decent mexican fare.

I still prefer other joints in the mission but if you are around 24th and Valencia, Papalote is an option.

Small dining area and typically crowded.

For what you get, Papalote is a bit pricey.  You do get a small bowl of chips and some good seemingly homemade salsa though.

Out of all the times I've been to Papalote, I have yet to see a latino patron.  So, take that for what it's worth.
author: Diego S.

description: The chips and salsa are everything they are hyped to be! Chicken mole burrito (super without sour cream)  with refried (vegetarian) beans is fresh, delicious and filling. You even have the option of plain, whole wheat or spinach tortillas. Make sure to order extra salsa!
author: Danielle M.

description:
went here for lunch yesterday and had chilaquiles which were pretty good. i made the mistake of getting my second favorite dish that my mom makes (chilaquiles) and david got my favorite (mole).. of course im always underwhelmed when i try these dishes cuz my moms is soooo bomb!

but still good, AMAZING salsa, would def go back.
author: Art A.

description: Sometimes I daydream about eating burritos. Papalote makes those dreams come true. Papalote has it all....spinach tortillas, guacamole OR regular avocado, soyrizo, marinated tofu, perfectly seasoned grilled veggies, and beer. Don't even get me started on the salsa. Fuck, my mouth is already watering.....no joke! The salsa is amazing and definitely what sets this place apart from other spots in the mission. Delicious and spicy in all the right ways [insert sexual joke here]. On the real though.....Papalote is on top of their flavor game. I always bring my out-of town guests here... everyone loves it. Thank you thank you thank you.
author: Emily S.

description:
maybe they forgot to put the crack in my burrito? not sure, but i was expecting more after many a friend ranted/raved about papalote. don't get me wrong...it was tasty, but I don't think it's anything to call home about. am i the only one that thinks $8 for a super veggie burrito is pricey? ok fine maybe it's not THAT pricey but factor in my 30+ minute wait time in the cold. (in fairness that was a rookie mistake since you can call ahead of time and wait in a shorter phone order only line).

i'd like to take this time to apologize to the taqueria around the corner from my house. after your affordable, no line, deliciousness, i'm so sorry i betrayed you.
author: Ami V.

description:
Carne Asada burrito was tasty, and the steak was not at all fatty or gristly, which is rare and fantastic, but the small quantity of meat in the burrito was entirely overwhelmed by the comparatively large quantities of beans & rice. This was very disappointing. The salsa (of which I think they only have one kind) is fantastic though. Horchata was pretty good. Nicely toasted tortilla on the burrito. They also have a couple beers on tap.
On a second visit, the steak quantity was larger, but the arrangement of ingredients was very poor, with the top half all rice, and the bottom half all beans, and little salsa to be found.
author: Don H.

description:
Not good, not bad, but average.  Average for 24th St & Valencia Mexican food, but a bit below average if you compare it to 16th and Mission\Valencia taquerias.   Ever have Mexican food in Burlingame, Walnut Creek, or Lafayette?  It's very similar, somewhat bland, and heavily Caucasiafied.

I see people on this board rave about the salsa.....  I went, I tried, It didn't create a lasting impression.

A good place to bring a date if you want decent, affordable Mex in an area with a low coefficient of seediness.  But if you're willing to brave a sketchier neighborhood, head East young man!  There's better places as you head out 24th Street towards Potrero.....
author: Mike W.

description:
The salsa rocks my socks off!

My friend turned me into a burrito explorer after introducing me to the steak burrito here, and I was impressed that the meat remained juicy. I had to do a double take to make sure the food was consistent before I wrote a review, and the steak burrito nailed the flavors again and again.

I kept raving about the wonderful kick in the tasty salsa, and my friend brings over this hilarious and informative Chow article written by Helena Echlin: http://www.chow.com/stories/10111. Max La Rivire-Hedrick reverse engineers the recipe. All the other ingredients  are likely, besides the secret controversial ingredient of pumpkin seeds. The author probably put out this one ingredient to lead people to believe that is the closest they could come to the Papalote's salsa: http://www.chow.com/recipes/10646. I think the author actually knows better and did not publish the true last ingredient. It is a conspiracy, I say!

So I brought my food connoisseur friend to challenge her to deconstruct the recipe from scratch. She thought that there was some cream for the thick texture. But online comments adamantly state the salsa is all vegan. Well process of elimination helps our cause, one major food group down, more to explore! We are on a mission to figure out the REAL recipe. 

Until then, I will have to savor every drop of the legendary salsa in the first tiny vat that comes with the meal. I feel robbed to have to pay an additional $0.50 for another tiny vat of salsa. Definitely taints the true burrito experience. But I won't dock stars because of that...
author: Cathy H.

description: I'm currently sitting at home battling a hideous sore throat/headache combo, and I am DEVASTATED because all I want to do right now is get myself a goddamn delicious chicken burrito with special Papalote secret salsa. I unfortunately don't think my current state of health will tolerate me waiting in line with all the other people who are copying my burrito idea. With that, I'm only willing to bump my rating up to 5 stars when the good people of Papalote are willing to pack up their grills and come feed me in my own kitchen.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Came here because I've been wanting to try their triple threat burrito since I saw it on TV.  Their triple threat burrito is good but definitely not worth the $20.  Probably will never go here again, but was worth the experience.

Their salsa is the very good.
author: Maxim L.

description:
Was turned on to Papalote a couple of years ago and keep finding my way back like a blindfolded crack baby. This place is freakishly good. 
Lines out the door all the time... even in the freezing (well freezing for San Francisco) cold. Salsa that must have ambrosia as a secret ingredient--full of smoky goodness that's neither bland nor too spicy. Their almost unique practice of cooking your burrito meat to order (versus the more common pre-cooked steam try variety) really does equal a better product. I get the grilled chicken and it's always fresh and never dried out. And those refried black beans are simply to die for. Not exactly convenient for me, but always worth the trip.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Good mexican food. Not fancy, but everything is very solid. The place isn't much to look at - you order at the counter and they deliver the food to your table.

We chose this place for our Cinco de Mayo dinner, and weren't disappointed. I ordered a grilled chicken burrito, which wasn't the cheapest in the Mission, but provided a lot of food for a decent price. I think that I still have half left in my fridge - maybe I'll eat it for dinner tonight. The chips were solid, and the hot sauce was definitely hot.

Some of the tables in the back have chairs that are too low for them, so you might want to avoid those.
author: Dana L.

description:
We headed out to Papalote to get a quick meal before my flight back to Vegas. Being the first customers to arrive right as the store was opening we got our food pretty quickly.

I'm always amazed at the number of vegan friendly places in the area and Papalote is no different. I had a plate of soyrizo tacos that were quite delectable.
author: Nader A.

description:
Their smokey tasting salsa really is the shit and I can never get enough.  It is, that good.

I'm a big fan of choosing seafood options when going out for Mexican dining.  This is definitely where Papalote is lacking.  There are a good two prawns in their prawn tacos and the rest of the pico de gallo and lettuce they use, while it's quality and I do like that, it's just that it is basically what you end up getting full on, not shrimp.

Don't get me wrong, I do like this place - a lot, it's very good.

My only other complaint is that they use enough garlic in their veggie and seafood dishes it's practically sacrilegious.

However, this could be a great arsenal against an unwanted admirer/stalker . . . 

The burritos are good and the quesadilla are also, ask for their house salsa on everything, it really takes it up a notch.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I had high hopes for this place because it was a mexcian place in the Mission. Anyway, there was a Triple Threat burrito with shrimp, chicken and steak. It was shaping up to be something big, but then it fell apart. After I had reconstructed the burrito, it had all the parts but I didn't think that all came together. 

I was told that this place was more of a vegetarian place. I'm willing to try this place again, but we'll see the end result next time. For now, 3 stars. 

Oh, we also had nachos, they were pretty good. I liked the cheese.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Really really good Chile Verde chicken burrito. Their  tortillas are great, thick, lovely pancakes of goodness. The chipolte salsa is addictive. Sure, its not the run down place that you expect from one of the best burritos in the mission, but then again... Why's that a bad thing?

-1 for the crowding, lack of table sitations, that can occur.
author: Matt C.

description:
Once upon a time, I was hungry and decided to stop into Papalote to pick up lunch. I ordered a chicken burrito with some extra goodness and paid up. I took the little numbered placard they gave me...and then I turned into Rip Van Winkle because it took SO FREAKING LONG to get my burrito. Over 15 minutes to get one burrito! (All while some tourist and his awful screaming kids inflicted holy terror on the waiting area, but that's neither here nor there. Well, actually, it *was* there. And it was obnoxious! And I had to endure 15 minute of it!!)

Ahem...where was I? Oh, yes. The burrito was good. The chips were "meh". My friend recommends phoning ahead the next time I'm in the mood for Papalote. Thanks, friend!
author: Ana C.

description: Great comida, interesting, tasty beers and bomb azz salsa.  What more do you need from a taqueria.  Yes, I guess the prices are a little more than your typical taqueria but its still just a taqueria you broke jokers.  If you can afford rent in SF, then you can afford a good taco.  Service is good and you should def buy the homemade salsa in the mason jar.
author: Brett H.

description: This place is a-maz-ing.  I go here about 2 times a week, although I place my order on the phone and pick up.  The wait can sometimes be a pain since the place is so small it's totally worth it.  Best tatsing salsa I have ever had and the burrito's are so fresh and delicious.
author: Stephanie M.

description: So many of my friends drool over this place that I'm inclined to try it again. But the first time, strike one. That burrito was all sorts of uninspired. I guess the salsa's good?
author: Guillermo K.

description: What's the hype with this place??? I guess maybe it's me, but when I go to taquerias, I intend to overeat or hear myself gain weight. I felt like the complete opposite here. I was glad to see that the overpriced carne asada burrito actually had nice grill marks on the carne, but it certainly lacked everywhere else. The rest of the burrito was just boring and they skimped on the guacamole, which makes for a somewhat dry and lonely burrito.
author: Wil M.

description:
I couldn't get enough of the salsa! Damn, I'm craving it right now. 

My friend and I were just walking around the neighborhood looking for eats when their colorful  dining area sucked us in... I got the marinated tofu, which was pretty good, but she got the chile verde, which was...wow. So tender, and flavor for days. It's a cute little place, but I could see it getting CROWDED on busy nights.
author: Ed M.

description:
usually a "dont beleive the hype" type, but the hype was spot on.
great veggie burrito, amazing salsa, great staff. 
i come as often as i can.
author: Ryan L.

description: Some friends and I were out shopping and decided that we were up for some Mexican food... We weren't really to sure of where to go, so one friend grabbed her crack-berry, the other grabbed her I-don't, and in seconds Yelp hooked us up with loads of choices.  Eventually we settled on Papalote, mainly because it had over 800 reviews and a 4 star rating.  After eating there, I have noooo idea how this place has such a high rating.  The salsa was great just like everyone said, but other than that, the food was just average (barely). I won't be going back to Papalote anytime soon...
author: Tiffani M.

description:
Not the best buritto in the Mission bust most likely the freshest.  All of the meat is raw when you order it.

You want chicken?

They get out a big piece of chicken breast and thow it on the grill.

Carne Asada?

Get that 12-hour marinated piece of steak out of that vat of flavor goodness and cook it up.

ect. ect.

The roasted salsa is great as everyone else has said.  There are more hipsters here becuase the food isn't as greasy.  In fact I think that I would call this place a "california" burrito place.  I know that sounds lame but, sometimes you want something that doesn't bomb your stomach like an El Farolito burrito.
Know what I mean?
author: Thadd L.

description:
Marinated Tofu with refried Black Beans !

Great Salsa, super fresh and the dude who runs the place is all about good vibes. 

Check it out.
author: Dave W.

description:
Their Salsa is legit...

People come here and just buy the salsa, which comes in a really cool jar. it's a bit pricey at 6.50 but worth every penny.  Also they are pretty stingy with the salsa that they give out for free. They serve it in one little cup at a time, but they will refill it over and over for you.

My roommate recommended the grilled veggie burrito with Tofu. Great suggestion. I'm a big meat lover but decided to go healthy and it paid off. 

Had a good dark bohemian beer to go with it. I prefer Modelo Negro, but they don't carry it. 
This was my first  Papalote experience, but I will deffintely return. 

Thank you Papalote.
author: Adam L.

description:
Oh gawd, this place was good.  Many have rated this place on yelp and very few have rated less than 4 stars.  They definitely deserve the high ratings.

The menu was a little pricey I thought at first until I took the first bite.  My girlfriend and I split a gigantic prawn burrito that was awesome.  Between that and the chips and salsa, it was a very filling, delicious meal.

I have not been back yet but I would definitely recommend this place to friends.  Very good stuff!!
author: Augie S.

description:
My roommates had been raving about it for a long time so I finally went. 

I ordered the very thing they raved about - the marinated tofu burrito. I was entirely dissapointed. The tofu was soggy and flavorless and the ingredients around it didn't seem to make up for it. 

I would give the place less stars for that burrito but they had a decent beer selection and the jicama salad on the side was a nice touch. They do bring you chips while you are waiting and they taste very fresh but the salsa that accompanies them leaves much to be desired for me. 

I am willing to think that other items on the menu are better but the tofu didn't do it for me.
author: Inna H.

description:
There are a ton of reviews that I don't need to rehash.  You walk in and, though the counter service is friendly, you should know pretty quickly what you want to order, as there is usually a line of hungry people behind you.  

There are many yummy filling options, e.g. carne asada, chile verde, pescado, vegetarian, gambas, etc., that you can apply towards burritos, tacos and quesadillas.  You can also order entrees that come on a plate and are accompanied by rice, beans and tortillas.  Today I had the carne asada entree plate for lunch.  It came with two good-sized pieces of steak that were grilled to order.  They were, in my opinion somewhat dry due to overcooking but were admittedly tasty.  They were accentuated by the guacamole that came with my lunch companion's super burrito that he did not want.  And said lunch companion was gleefully happy with his chile verde super burrito, which he said was one of the best burritos he'd ever had, due to the tasty and tender pork concoction that I regretably forewent.  

The place was pretty clean and comfy.  I'd come back, but I did not leave the place dreaming of my next venture in.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
I have finally found it! A REALLY good mexican place in SF. Not only that, but one that has good vegetarian food. I'll just jump to the food:
The soyrizo here is amazing. I have tried to cook it myself from one of those packaged things you get from the store and lets just say it wasnt so good. So I was a little skeptical when I ordered it. But based on some of the reviews here I had to try it. I have tried it as a burrito and a taco. Out of the two I would go with the taco. It the taco you can really appreciate the taste of the soyrizo. The burrito is good too. I got that route when I want something really fulfilling. I have also tried the tofu in a burrito. It was good. I was had already eaten some tacos so I was only able to eat half of the burrito. The burrito ingredients at times overpower the taste of the tofu so next time I might try it as a taco. 

The salsa is meh. It a bit above average from what I have experienced out here but I wasnt too excited by it. I have to attribute the hype of the salsa to the type of customers going here. (you know what Im talking about) 

The prices are excellent here. For the amount of people that come here and order the wait is within reason. And as usual for the area parking sucks. All in all I have found my burrito spot.
author: Richard C.

description:
Papalote serves fresh, consistent Mexican food basics in a comfortable, fun setting.  It's a great cheap, reliable fast food spot.  Although it's not the absolute best Mexican food in the city, it's very very very tasty.  Although it's not healthy health food, it's much fresher and healthier than most Mexican dining.

I just had the achiote chicken plate, it had a grilled, spiced flavor, so delicious.  The grilled vegetable quesadilla kicks ass- it has grilled eggplant and summer squash- full of flavor.  Also, the fresh hot sauce is so tasty, and sort of a unique style that I haven't seen at other places.
author: Professor H.

description:
I had the Chile Verde tacos, which is a marinated pork. 

As soon a I got it, I reached for the hot sauce but decided to take a bite first. We had just gotten back from Mexico and I don't think I could have handled a disappointing taco; it would have broken my heart. 

Luckily, I was not disappointed and it was the juiciest, most flavorful taco. I put the hotsauce down and didn't even look at the salt/pepper for extra flavor.  The food was absolutely delish and I'm a huge fan. Will definitely come back!
author: Tien H.

description: This place is a rip-off. I ordered a Carne Asada burrito. Had to wait about 20 minutes for my food - when the place wasn't even that full! When my burrito finally came, guess what? NO MEAT! WTF!? Are you kidding me? At first i just thought that the meat was in the middle and patiently worked my way to it, but was very disappointed to find nothing there. My now "veggie" burrito was very mediocre with all beans and rice, even though I ordered the "super" - which supposedly comes with cheese and guacamole. Very disappointed. And definitely NOT worth $10!! Don't see what all the fuss is about. Do yourself a favor and walk a few blocks to another Mexican joint. There are plenty of them!
author: Tallulah J.

description: Lots of options here, but the burritos are not too good (by Mission standards that is; compared to the rest of the United States they are above average.)  Tend to be dry and tasteless and their much-touted salsa that they sell in Mason jars is SOOOO wimpy.  It's also about twice the price of the more hardcore places, although it's a lot more comfortable and less dangerous if you're actually gonna eat there.  But on balance, not worth the trade-off...too precious for my taste
author: Mike B.

description: Expensive. No Mexicanos eating here.. what does that tell you? Even the "good" items seem white-i-fied- mushy, bland. Covenient, safe, boring Mexican food. Boring! Predictable! Yuck. Hey, you live in one of the best places on earth for amazing Mexican food- and a block or three from this place you will find SOME Mexican food with  a better taste, AND a lower cost... Take a risk... walk a block.
author: Carol L.

description:
solid burrito.. huge portion.. but i've had better.. my fiancee had their chicken burrito which was pretty good.. but nothing spectacular.. my pork burrito with salsa verde was not bad.. it would have been better if they deep fried their meat though (e.g. crispy carnitas).. 

the salsa that came with their chips is too salty..
author: Stan L.

description:
I wonder about adding to the review pile when it is above 600, but hell, this place is worth it. 

If you are in the hood, make it a stop. They have a really awesome selection of vegetarian and even vegan (soyrizo) ingredient options. The guac doesn't taste like the prepackaged bag kind. 

The salsa IS to die for and the chips are real -  thick and crunchy and not greasy. Plus, it is only .99cents to upgrade to a super on a burrito and it is money well spent. Depending on your order, a burrito is around $7 bucks and most definitely won't leave you hungry.

Not open late, and not a huge seating area. But they do take phone orders for pickup.
author: Miel H.

description:
I love the carne asada quesadilla! It's my favorite on the menu! The staff is very friendly and the atmosphere is just awesome! They have artwork that catches your eye all around the restaurant and the music is good!

It's also decently priced. It's so worth it to come here! It gets really crowded during dinner time, so arrive early!!! :)
author: Bernadette B.

description:
I'm a little bit of a Carne Asada snob. It's got to be juicy. Seared. Flavorful. Big enough pieces to taste it separately. Small enough that it's not a steak with a tortilla blanket. A little salty. 

Papalote delivers.

Their burritos are big and tasty, all of the ingredients are fresh and flavorful, their tortillas are just the right kind of crispy-soft, and they're not too full of rice.

I've now gone there twice, and it's for the best that it's just a few too many blocks out of my way, or else They'd know my name and I'd have a special seat by the window.

My gripes: 
-I know, I know, everyone wants their damned coke-in-a-bottle when they get their taqueria on, but I really love a good fountain coke with a burrito, because of all the sweet-fizzy with the salt.
-Not enough chips. For delicious, fresh, hot chips, there are simply not enough of them, *especially* with that salsa, that's too hot for me, but too tasty for me not to eat.
-Bathroom location. Sometimes, it stinks up the whole place. And if it's full, Murphy's law dictates you will be stuck in that seat right by the bathroom with the double punch of having to smell it every time the door's open AND having to move so people can walk by. I'd rather walk through the kitchen.
author: Rhiannon C.

description:
Apparently the secret to their good taste is fresh ingredients.  Kind of like In'n'Out Burger, I guess.

The burritos are a little on the small and simple side.  Their motto must be "less is more," which everyone knows is a bunch of crap, especially when it comes to burritos.

Last time I went there, there was a good looking lesbian couple sitting next to me.  Hot.
author: Jackson R.

description:
So my roommate went with out me tonight while I was at work, but I told her to bring me home a jar of their salsa.  I get home with high hopes, look through the fridge, heart sinks. Where is it? 
There it is! On the counter.  I pour myself a little bowl, grab some chips, and head off to my room to eat some and check my email, etc...  
I'm in heaven. One of my favorite flavor combinations I've tasted. 
Roasted tomatoes and peppers for sure, and lots of other good ingredients that you can't figure out because they puree the salsa.  
Last I heard, the recipe was worth a few hundred thousand dollars!

So good, I licked the bowl.
I licked the bowl! Can you believe it?!
author: Markell M.

description:
It's so painful to wait for my food here. I need to really start calling my orders in.

**************

UPDATE:

So, tonight I called my order in.  They quoted me ten minutes.

When I arrived at the restaurant, there was a long line. I was not in the mood for that. Combined with the fact that it was raining and I was hungry... well, all I have to say is that I was grumpy.

I stood there for a bout 20 seconds and then heard, "Did anyone call in for an order?"

I was stunned. So stunned, in fact, that I didn't know how to react. I slowly raised my hand. 

"Come up here," said the girl behind the second register.

Total round trip to Papalote from my house: 5 minutes.

I love you Papalote!

What lesson did we learn today? Always call your order in when planning on eating Papalote.
author: Mark G.

description:
I loved this place.  I was afraid of the idea of tofu or veggie burritos - and a mission food joint that uses No Lard....?  However, when I got to Papalote I decided to try it rather than going with the meat.  It was fabulous, filled with grilled spiced eggplant and zucchini!  So tasty!  I have to go back to try the fish tacos - I hear they're divine and maybe the fajitas...

It's crowded, there does always seem to be a line.  You can't sit until you've ordered, so by the time you get a seat your food is just about there and you don't have to deal with people squatting on tables who have not ordered yet - which I think is a good idea.

I was suprised by the price of the bottled beer, until I realized the beer was this gi-normous supersized bottle.

The price of the food is fair and the place is nice and clean especially for a place in the mission; )
author: E R.

description:
What the hell is in that salsa that makes it so good? 
I want to buy a 50 gallon drum of this stuff and slather it on everything I eat (including dessert). 

Papalote isgood mexican food in the higher end, low end kinda price range. You feel me? Basically, it's not the great East oakland spots that are delicious and super affordable, but, its also not the Mamcitas or the Tres Agaves kind of expensive, the $22 carne asada plate expensive. ya feel me? It's worth it just to go there for the salsa. which is completely unique and only given out in small quantities. yafeelme?The chicken was kinda dry, but the shrimp quesdilla was off the chain. yfelme? I will definitely be back, but only for take out becuase there aint no parking round there. yflme?
author: Lawrence A.

description:
My burrito Mecca.
I can't believe how consistent this place is.  Every bite is full of every ingredient.
Also the fact that they cook their meats fresh to order is key.
Anyone else slopping meat from a bucket into your burrito is doing you a dis-service.
Change your ways and kneel before Papalote.
author: Josepe M.

description:
Being a native San Diegan, I like to believe that I have Mexican food pulsing through my blood, and despite it not being my favorite cuisine, I'm entitled to a very bold opinion about it.  Anyway -- Papalote totally deserves high honors - this is the place we go when I'm in the Mexican food sort of mood.  Hmm, maybe I'm in the mood now actually . . .

And let's face it -- Pa-pa-low-tay is just fun to say.
author: Jenn K.

description:
Papalote's burritos are just okay, they are not incredible. But when you coat them in Papalote salsa they are the best damn burritos you will eat in your life!

Thank god you can buy a jar of their salsa. Whenever I do, my meals are centered around it. 'What can I eat with Papalote salsa?' Mostly everything, you'll be happy to know.
author: C P.

description:
Fish tacos were awesome. I went there for lunch today with some friends and everyone was extremely pleased with their seafoody selections: a shrimp quesadilla; fish burrito, and two of us ordered fish tacos. I actually split mine with a friend and one was totally satisfying. 

Salsa was great and we had a good time--I will definitely remember to stop by again and maybe bring some salsa home.
author: Deborah S.

description:
So I tell my friends and family they are the reasons why I came back to live in SF, but this place just might be the REAL reason.  What is the REAL reason, moist, spicy, firm burritos which I found to be darn near perfect at Papalote.

Oh ya, you all know where to get the best burrito, but do you know where to get the perfect burrito?  Oh ya, that is what I am talking about.  Pork roasted to perfection, Mole sauce which is both tangy and sweet.  Oh yes, my friend, we have here a culinary delight of epic perorations just around the corner from where I live and aint it sweet.

When love has failed me and the job is causing me to look fondly at my neglected Passport, I saunter down to Papalote for a feast that tantalizes the eye as well as the soul.

Oh, don't forget to try their Mexican sodas as they actually complement the burrito with its sweetness and over the top flavor.
author: Jai D.

description:
This place cranks out quality "San Francisco"-style burritos!  The menu is unique in some respects, and has all the usual ingredients to choose from.  I've had take out from here several times, so I can't comment on the dine-in environment.  The service has consistently been quick and good, with minimal wait time after ordering.  

I have to say that the cooks here do me right as far as making sure the sour cream and guacamole get spread evenly throughout the 'rito when I've ordered it as such.  I definitely appreciate it!  Check it out if you are in the neighborhood and are in the mood for a Mex-American dish.
author: TJ D.

description:
It's not the cheapest place for Mexican vittles, but the chicken mole burrito can totally get it.  

And the salsa.  

I'm not coming here again, though, to do take out.  Screw the 20 minute wait.  Dining with friends?  For sure.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
I had a quesadilla because I wasn't that hungry.  It was really good.

The salsa they give you is really unique and sooo yummy.

All my girls got burritos and they were soooooo good. (I made them let me taste them...) I need to come back and get one.  Seriously some of the best in the city...

And now that we've been in the FF I think I have pretty good taste in burritos
author: Angela S.

description: Cafeteria-style ordering. Large portions. Pretty good food. Mole was decent.
author: Blanco N.

description: oh my god, so good and so healthy. the salsa is amazing. Go for that alone. Go, eat, love.
author: Mary M.

description: I love papalote. Not only cuz Mr. E owns this great place but because the food is great. The secret sauce is ridiculously good! Triple threat burrito is awesome. I do have one gripe.... i recently tried the Chicken Adobo burrito and it was kinda blah. Needs work Mr. E. Perhaps some soy type sauce. Other than that this place rocks. I wish I lived closer. Big Ups Mr. E and Papalote.
author: Dave C.

description: Papalote... the $20 super Tripple Threat burrito (which is regular size btw)... maybe last night wasn't the right night, staff wise. The Triple Threat was disappointing... so much that I wonder how bad Flay's was.
author: Shane C.

description:
BOUTIQUE BURRITOS.  Seems like this place is trying to hop on the boutique bandwagon.  20 bucks for the triple threat burrito.  That's right, folks, 20 bucks for a relatively normal-sized burrito.  Just around 10 bucks for all other burritos.  Did the taste justify the 10 dollar price tag?  Hell nah.  Did it justify the 20 dollar price tag?  FUCK NAH. 

Sue me for being unreasonable, but when I walk into a Mexican restaurant, I like to see Mexican people eating there (same with any other ethnic restaurant).  This place had not a single Mexican person eating.  The entire place was filled with yuppy Asians and Whites.  I felt like i was at Chipotle...in the Financial District.  

I guess you could say it's authentic Mexican if you consider food being cooked by Mexicans authentic Mexican....but you could also say Japanese food from Japan Town is authentic Mexican.  Or Panda Express.  Or 75% of food served in San Francisco for that matter...

The four-star rating blows my mind.  Sure, the sauce is good, but for the $0.50 they charge for each additional ounce of it, it better be fucking good.  

2 stars because it was not a horrible burrito - just horribly overpriced.
author: Per C.

description:
food was tastless. i had shrimp and steak burritos on different days and it was really bad. how could you not know how to wrap a burrito??? i wouldn't go back.
   service was good though.
author: emukka y.

description:
From reading some of the other reviews I see that Papalote was on the Food Network or something. I didn't see the show and don't go there because of it.

I've been eating at Papalote for the past 1.5 years and eat there at least once every other week. 

Pros: 

1) The most amazing chicken mole burrito. (If you prefer you can get tofu mole instead.) I always get Super Chicken Mole burrito with black beans. It is my Go-To favorite burrito in the entire bay area. To me, this burrito is addictive as crack. I drive from Burlingame to San Francisco sometimes just to eat this burrito.

2) The orange salsa that comes with your chips. They are pretty famous for this salsa. It's pretty hot but not enough to be super uncomfortable. It almost tastes creamy but there are no dairy products in it. Just pumpkin seeds or something like that.

3) Well located, just a 2 block walk west on 24th Street from the 24th Street Bart, right across the street from the gas station at Valencia and 24th Street. Hard to miss since I think it is currently painted orange.

Cons: 

1) Really small and waits of around 30 minutes during busy times until you actually are eating your food. Hard to get a table. Best thing to do is order on the phone about 20 minutes ahead of time and then go 'cut' in line by picking up your food at the right-most register. It's so satisfying to pseudo cut in line and get your food to go.

2) Crowd seems a little too trendy for my tastes. 

3) Price is a little high for a burrito, but you get what you pay for. After tax, I think it ends up being around 9 bucks for a Super Mole Chicken Burrito.

4) AFAIK, no delivery, which would be awesome.
author: P. D.

description:
My boyfriend and I knew we had to get some Mexican food when we were visiting since it's the one culinary category we are really lacking good restaurants in in Boston. We trusted our friend from Palo Alto who had read good reviews about this place and she did not disappoint us. 

The place was crowded,  a good sign for 7 on a Saturday night. We ordered at the cash register and were seated rather quickly, though slightly awkwardly as we had to share table space with another group of 3. They had real Mexican Coke which the bf and friend were super hyped about. They brought us out yummy fresh chips and salsa to start. I got an aguas frescas which was pretty good, though a little too sweet. My friend got the mole chicken quesadilla which was super delicious. I got the amazing fish tacos which were too stuffed to pick up and eat, so I had to eat it with a fork and knife. The fish was sautéed with white wine and butter, a pleasant change from the fried I am used to. The bf got a fish burrito, probably the biggest burrito I have ever seen and it was delicious to boot. He definitely paid a little bit later for eating the whole thing.
author: Lindsay E.

description: I've probably gone here 4 or 5 times in the last month.  The food is fresh, the salsa yummy with a nice kick, and they have a lot of vegetarian options.  The number one attractant to me is that they grill their burritos.  People, grill your burritos!
author: Liza W.

description: 30 minutes to get my burrito. Screwed up my order. Burrito was solid, but not the best. I'm still looking for something better. Much better.
author: Ryan L.

description: Filled with hipsters and backpackers. Not sure if the service is slow or if the kitchen is just overwhelmed but it takes way too long to get any food here. The burrito is solid and a pretty good size, but as a visitor to SF, I was expecting a much more impressive burrito for what was supposed to be one of the best burritos in the land where the mission style burrito was invented. None of the ingredients really stood out. Everything seemed to depend on their sauces, which admittedly are good, but it was your typical heavily seasoned mash of ingredients rolled for easy consumption. Moreover, the place is sort of really dirty. Now, I'm all for eating in unmaintained, hole-in-the-wall places, but for a place where there's no discernible freshness or life changing deliciousness in the ingredients it does make you worry a little.
author: Manesh P.

description:
Very tasty! I got there on a Thursday around 11:30 just before the lunch-time madness; I worry that away from my flexible vacation schedule I wouldn't be able to take the rush. Love the area, though I do agree with other reviewers that it's not in the thick of the more authentic Mexican restaurants nearby. The restaurant is colorful and fun, and I like the neighborhood-hangout kind of feel.

Lots of food for your dollar here - I got two gigantic fish tacos and could barely finish one. Might not be the choice for the fried or grilled fish enthusiast, but I love their butter and wine-sautéed take on my favorite taco filling. My family got quesadillas, which are also fun and huge. I am not the biggest fan of their salsa since I'm more of a see-the-chunks-of-vegetables kind of girl, but it's a great flavor and excitingly spicy. I say go for it if you have a long lunch break!
author: Megan E.

description:
Great Mexican food. It's not the most authentic taqueria you can find, but it's way more authentic than Taco Bell, Del Taco or even Chipotle (which I love). 

The ingredients are fresh, great quality for the price, and everything I had tasted great! Also, the salsa that you get for free while you're waiting with some chips, is amazing. I seriously wanted to pour it all over the taco I ordered. in regards to size of portions, they're not huge and gluttonous but still a great value. Another thing I liked about the place is that it was really clean and I like it when you can get the classic, glass bottles of Coke rather than cans or plastic bottles. 2 thumbs up to Papalote!
author: Edison C.

description: I went to Papalote for the first time yesterday afternoon right off the bat I liked the music, art on the walls and the service was good but I was not impress by the $20 Triple Threat burrito. I was so excited too but it was such a let down nothing special, don't get me wrong I still ate half of it cause it was $20!!
author: Angelisimo G.

description: Gentrified but delicious burrito. Great salsa.
author: Jack K.

description: Not sure what all the fuss is about.  The place is cramped, not so clean, and devoid of personality.  I've heard people raving about the place, and finally had dinner there.  But wow...totally and completely underwhelmed.  I head out for Mex at least a couple times a week, but won't be revisiting Paplote.  Perhaps the buzz is because they offer vegan or soyrizo alternatives?  Even the much-vaunted salsa?  Meh. The food was okay, but way too much rice in the burrito, and perhaps three shrimp.  For a $11 burrito, I felt rooked.  I'll stick with Pancho Villa's Super Burrito, or head to San Jalisco for their awesome mole, and go to El Metate for some great fish tacos.
author: R.B. W.

description: If you want a good tasting burrito you have to go to the city. I got a triple threat burrito and it hit the spot. Thumbs up for Papalote.
author: Ron B.

description: Really love this place.  Like everyone else say's about the salsa , it's pretty awesome ! Tofu mole burritos are super yummy , and the Soyrizo is delicious !  Both are my fav's ! Yes it's a tiny place and can be pretty crowded , and yes you'll have to wait abit , they aren't the fastest around ! It's all about the taste ! A+ !  PS - you can buy that salsa to go to in a quart jar , supreme !
author: Michael B.

description:
I have been a fan of Papalotes bottled salsa for the last year.  I had never visited an actual restaurant and was very excited to bring family from out of town to enjoy your tasty variety of salsas at the 24th and Valencia location. 

We are disappointed that Papalote does not proudly serve more than one measly dixie sized cup of salsa to their PAYING customers.  You have to purchase each extra measly little cup.  When we asked for the habanero salsa the busboy said they only sold it by the jar and only the mild salsa was sold in .50 cent size. He then pointed to a non-papalote bottled salsa that is worth $2 at safeway as an option.   It is very strange for a business who is proud of their salsa to make it so inaccessible.  I could feel the employees discomfort in having to enforce this nickel and diming business strategy, and could see that they deal with constant confusion and frustration.  You could walk all 47 square miles of this amazing city and not find one other restaurant that serves "Mexican" food but limits the salsa distribution to one small dixie cup that our chips do not even fit into.  This experience made Papalote look amateurish and suggested that they cater only to the yuppie community who do not know good salsa and therefore do not complain about being served only enough salsa for two bites. I did not buy any extra salsa that night.  After having spent $70 on dinner, I wasn't going to be forced into buying a whole jar of salsa and perpetuate this ridiculous business strategy.


PAPALOTE, SET YOUR SALSA FREE!

Don't come between a Mexican and their salsa.
author: vanessa f.

description: Really good mexican food. Nice options for vegetarians.
author: Johanna W.

description: Went here  for the first time after watching a video on Twitter about the chicken adobo burrito....I heart chicken adobo!  And when I saw there was a chicken adobo burrito I HAD to have one.  And well no regrets.  It was flavorful, tasty and yummy!   It had  a hint of roasted chili flavor...so yummy!  And the salsa that they serve with the chips...OMG...a burst of yumminess in my mouth!!
author: Mao K.

description:
I always like the food whenever I come here, but for some reason that's not so often.

In fact, I only seem to go when someone else suggests it. 

Why? I'm not sure. Something about the place seems watered down compared to the other rough and ready Mission tacquerias. 

But c'mon, it's fancier and not more expensive, and the ingredients are very good quality.

So why don't I go there more often? 

Hm. maybe I will.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Sweet Mercy, I think this place is going to make me a fat ass.
I am a burrito whore and my post will read as such.

First off, the marinated tofu buritto is the shizzy. If you dine-in, be prepared for a burrito on a plate, unless you ask for foil.  Compared to farralito and  other nearby joints, the size of their log is a little smaller.  The tortilla is crispy on the outside but is still a little chewy,maybe too much on the chewy. I just like to unhinge my jaw, and drop a burrito straight down in one gulp with NO CHEWING.  That's how I like it, i don't chew, I just swallow.

 Jokes aside, how about their salsa. A brown and smooth liquid, that I haven't found anywhere else.  It's great.

FYI, I think their horchata is made with soy milk, which ROCKS!

Best of all, you can dine-in and not feel like a stabbing may occur.  I would bring my southern ass backwoods family here and not worry about giving them a heartattack.  Well, I dunno, it IS the Mission.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
This is the healthy, clean alternative to every other GD taqueria in the Mission.  They have soyrizo, which is my favorite.

Here's my advice, though.  Get a jar of the delicious salsa and take it home.  The salsa gets five stars.
author: Charlotte O.

description:
I like burrito's.  A lot actually.  So last night when I was meeting friends around the corner from the revered Papalote I thought "hey, dynamite, let's check that place out."

Was the burrito flavorful.  You bet.  There just wasn't much of it.  I really could have eaten two of them.  

And yes, the salsa was great.  Highlight of the meal.
author: Eamonn T.

description:
I LOVE their chicken mole. Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night craving it!

Best in the city by far. The owner is super nice and always remembers me.

Thanks!
author: Bethany C.

description:
Nice, but a bit overrated.

I have had three different burritos there  up to date (carne, veggie and something with fish) and they were good. Not great though.
author: Jorge B.

description:
The Salsa... to die for.  Must.go.there.soon.  all food is fresh and well prepared.  I will eat anything there as long as I can have that fresh, smoky flavored chipotle Salsa.

These guys have a good thing going on b/c they make a healthier version of Mexican food (than most of the mexican restaurants that I have reviewed) and they have been able to come up with a small franchise of their restaurants.  Totally cool as I am in support of more healthy food franchises popping up anywhere... anytime!
author: Leslie I.

description:
Good and healthy, but a little over-rated like everyone else has said.

But for me, it's all about the salsa. So amazingly delicious. I buy it by the jarful. Actually, I usually buy three one for now, one for later, and one for the guests who stop by out of the blue. You can never have enough.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Very cool Mex food in the Mission District. 

Great mainstream options, all made fresh. More interesting, however, is the non-traditional stuff like soy-rizo and tofu mole, put into quesadillas and burritos and other great foods.

A wide beer selection as well. Seating is limited, so better to get stuff to go. Chips and salsa are great...but the nachos are even better. Everything made to order, so expect some wait...but it's worth it.
author: G J J.

description:
Yeah, I know, they are just nachos, but damn! Papalote's veggie nachos are fantastic. 

When I recommend this place to my co-workers, I say it's Mexican with a "twist", Potatoes and carrots in my burrito, wtf? But it works and I love it! I just wish they would serve more chips and salsa = ( oh well, I can live with a small portion.
author: Anabelle B.

description:
Papalote is my neighbor.  We share the same corner store. 

Papalote rides a fixie.  Papalote has a pornstache.

If Papalote went to pick up TP at 1am, it would be at my corner store.  We might even run into each other there.  Both, picking up TP at 1am at our corner store.  

We'd laugh about how we really should catch up.  How it's been so long since we hung out.  Both knowing we would never really follow through.

Then I'd go run off to catch up with el metate.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Papalote has AWESOME salsa but they NEVER give you more chips to eat it with.

Papalote has THE BEST burritos for somewhere I've NEVER seen any latinos.

Papalote has EXPENSIVE food but ALWAYS a line out the door.
author: Maia B.

description:
Hello awesome good time food. I will put you in my face now.

This place serves as one of my SF staples.  I've eaten here well over 30 times and never, NEVER, left with less than a smile on my face and a happy belly.

We call it the "fresh mex" place because it's kind of a californian mexican... you know, less grease, probably less authentic too, but who cares?

Their salsa is amazing, their staff is always friendly, and their burritos and quesadillas divine.  

There's only 1 thing I haven't loved, and that's the mole. It's not the rich, dark, chocolately variety that I love. It's lighter and less intense.  Some people like that.
author: cindy p.

description:
Best burrito in the city? I think it might be. Apologies to Gordo's, El Farolito, and Taq Cancun.

Lets see...

I get a super burrito, tomato tortilla, and the grilled tofu. Grilled tofu is something I would only get here. I've had every version they have -- chicken carne asada, soyrizo, triple threat -- I have to say the grilled tofu is the best. Guac, sour cream, black beans. Ahh, the simple pleasures in life. 

That fucking salsa. Its not fair how good that shit is. Its not runny, you dip a chip, and it comes out covered, no drip. Yeah. Exactly. Ive bought it by the mason jar, put it on everything. 

The bottled salsa on the table is a, dare I say, GREAT change of pace. Habenero El Yucateco? Yes. 

The apps are good too. The black bean dip with some chips is the ultimate ice breaker. Or something.

If you want to have a delicious burrito that uses fresh ingredients, or if you just want to mingle with the hipster fixed-gear crowd, Papalote is the spot.
author: Jeff G.

description:
It doesn't get any better for vegetarians! My all-time favorite burrito and taco place. My meat-eating friends also love it! I have no complaints about this place except it gets crowded sometimes.

My fav: soyrizo tacos and the most kick ass roasted salsa anywhere!
author: max k.

description:
Being a fan of Farolito I can not give this a 5 star, for one the Burritos they serve are americanized (wait Burrito is American, no such thing as Burrito in Mexico, heck in any part of South America), vegetarianized, veganized. No wonder you hardly see latinos here.

The food is great dont get me wrong and so my brothers claim they are healthier and way cleaner than Farolitos. True, but I want my Burrito espsecially if its Carnitas or Al Pastor to be soaking in its own fat....LOL

They have a very good spicy sauce, so that's good, not the usual, cilantro, tomoatoes, jalapeno, onions kind of salsa that is being served at all taquerias so that's a plus and the chips are good and crunchy.

If you want a healthy Burrito check them out.
author: Malou C.

description: They really aren't kidding when they say the fish is marinated in butter. This really hit the spot after too many months on the East Coast.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Normally, I would be skeptical about a local burrito joint if 1) it's overrun by hipsters 2) it has a tofu burrito on the menu 3) It was featured in a Food Network show (Bobby Flay's Throwdown show) - not that I'm anti-Food Network, it's just that they don't always seem to choose the "best" places, just the ones that will accommodate for the tv cameras and crowd. 

Despite making the foolish attempt to order the burrito on site... what's up with all the places around here? It's like anyplace with some kind of buzz requires a 20 minute wait!  Ah yeah, anyhow, I ordered my standard test: the carne asada! Master that, and I'll come back and try more. Good cuts of meat, tasty rice and beans, solid coma inducing size, and great hot sauce! Just be sure to call in your order or prepare to eat at senior citizen friendly hours.
author: Erick K.

description: Bland, boring food, place filled to the brink with hipsters. Tofu burrito ?!? - whatever. And to add insult to injury they charge 55 cents for tiny cup of their salsa (which seems to be the only spicy thing on the menu).
author: Anna M.

description: The salsa alone deserves all the stars.  I ask for extra so I can bring it home and add it to my own dishes.  I've had the prawn tacos and the veggie burrito...both very good.  I've also tried the tofu and it was delicious (my beef eating friends order it!).  Be careful if ordering a side of beans....it's a whole plate! And their guacamole is dang good if you just add a lil salt.  Also, the prices are ridiculously affordable.  Makes me not feel so bad for eating out instead of making my own dinner!
author: Shantal M.

description: I love this place because everything is made fresh and the carne asada doesn't resemble sisig (Filipino dish of little Pork bits).  Nice big chunks of meat. And like everyone else says, the salsa is awesome!!!!!!!!!  I take a jar home every time I eat there.
author: Segue P.

description: it is true that the carne asada burrito with guacamole is very good, and it is true that their salsa is very good.  as one other reviewer mentioned, you order and pay when you first walk in,  and then they bring your food to you at your table. the male cashier who took my order was very sweet and cheerful. i liked this place lots.
author: barbara r.

description: The vegan tofu burritos are quite delicious. Both times I've gone to get take-out, however, the wait has been rather long, even when no one was in line at the register.
author: Pax G.

description: Very good! I love the vegan selections and I enjoyed my tofu mole burrito. Each meal comes with a small bowl of chips and their delicious salsa. The vegetarian burrito and carne asada were delicious as well. We will be back on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Hannah S.

description: Burritos are delicious (both the chicken and carne asada are prepared very well) but the real superstar here is the SALSA!! I would inject it into my veins if I could. They also sell jars at the front to take home, score!! The two brothers that own the place (also seen on Bobby Flay's Throwdown) can often be found at the register or in the kitchen which is cute. If you are ever looking for good mexican in the Mission, check this place out!!
author: Kadie B.

description: So my chips were not so fresh but the salsa was excellent. When my two (not so hot) carne asada tacos arrived, there was some diced tomatoes atop but I like salsa on my tacos so I headed back up to the counter for salsa and they wanted 55 cents (my pockets only held only 12 cents) they would not give me any salsa, if I had know about the salsa rations I would not of wasted my 1 ration on the stale chips. I left them holding the plate after only 1 bite headed to the ATM and went to get my favorite tacos at 25th and Mission.
author: Su E.

description:
Who: Double date.
What: I ordered the Veggie Super Burrito, they ordered chicken fajitas, veggie burrito, and fish tacos.
When: Friday night. Line was a little long and seating limited, but it went fast....Eat fast as well as people are waiting and watching you eat.
Why: I guess my expectations were a little high for this place, since Bobby Flay lost! I didnt expect it to be as fast food-ish and fast eating! I thought it was a sit down, and order type of place, but turned out to be order at the counter and if you want to eat there, wait for a seat. Besides that point, the food was great. The salsa was definitely worth talking about after as well as the size of the portions- huge! 4 stars only because ambiance was more of a to-go place, vs eat there place.
author: R P.

description:
Fresh ingredients, good solid menu, and reasonable price!!! I love this place.

The salsa is the bomb-diggity-bomb-bomb!!!! as for the chips.....they suck just like all chips in San Francisco.....I like homeade chips ok, not bagged! sorry. 

It is my favorite burrito in the city. 
The soyrizo burrito that is.....!!!! So good, don't forget to make it "super!"

When I was a meat eater, I loved the Chicken mole, it is pretty yumm. But as far as vegetarian/vegan options, this is a great place! They have fresh vegetables, and the black beans taste good. 

It is nice atmosphere too, and I know you gotta wait a little, but it's so worth it. Beside, they play reggae in there!! What's not to love?
author: Kimberly H.

description: I don't know about all this triple threat nonsense... sounds like a boy burrito to me... but, If you want a really kick ass fish burrito, this is the spot.  Now kick ass-itude don't come cheap... for a burrito that is.  This puppy will set you back like $10 ( I'm used to $5 burritos at El Metate)  but no other place comes anywhere close to being this good.  I have actually never ordered anything else... but my boyfriend really likes their Chile Verde (although El Metate's is better and cheaper).  Oh, I almost forgot, Awesome salsa!
author: Liz A.

description: All right, but I'd rather have a $3 taco truck veggie burrito than one of these. Yes, the salsa is great, so maybe I would go here and just get chips and salsa. We got the chile verde burrito and the soyrizo burrito. I suppose they deserve props for offering lots of vegetarian options to wean people off meat. The chile verde was just all right--big hunks of slightly dry and stringy meat in a not very flavorful sauce; the soyrizo spicy and as you might expect; both burritos running over with no structural integrity--the kind of SF burrito that ordinarily is wrapped in foil, but perhaps they are trying to avoid the foil here and so you eat it with knife and fork.
author: Ryan C.

description: Seriously better than La Taqueria - in food quality AND price. Solid, good quality beef (carne asada) - no fatty parts like El Farolito. And better meat than La Taqueria. Loved my 2 tacos, and cute ambiance to boot! Win, for sure.
author: Sally M.

description: $10 for a giant burrito and chips in a clean place. I will make this the place where I bring out-of-towners for something better than Mission tacos
author: Scott R.

description: Great food, but they raised their prices a few months ago and now to get a veggie burrito with tofu and made super (guacamole, sour cream & cheese-an additional $.99) it's $15 ! I'm sorry, but I can't pay that for a burrito. I used to get out the door for $11. and that was doable, but $15. for a medium sized burrito is just ridiculous. Haven't gone back since. If price is not an issue to you though, the food is very tasty.
author: Gaea W.

description: Love this place! The food is fresh and the people behind the counter are really nice! The sauce that they serve with the chips is TO DIE FOR!
author: Farien F.

description: I used to work a block from this place and would go here for lunch 2-3 times a week. Calling in the orders are definitely best because they are always busy. But the food is great, especially the homemade salsa!
author: Mallory M.

description: I don't know what all the hype is about this place!  The food was just ok.  Nothing really stood out to me. We had the tacos and quesadilla, and it was a disappointment. I didn't like the chips and salsa, they tasted like Doritos.  Also, the restroom here is disgusting! I'd rather go elsewhere.
author: H. A.

description: After all they hype about this place- and the fact that it is blocks from my apartment...I had to give it a shot. I was sorely disappointed: what am I missing here? I ordered the mole chicken tacos which were tough, dry and lacking in ANY flavor whatsoever. In addition, the chips were beyond stale- booo.
author: NaNa M.

description: Went for a quick lunch and left very satisfied. I had a chile verde (pork in green serrano sauce) burrito that was excellent -- large chunks of juicy, flavorful pork throughout, well spiced, moist and just really good. Plus excellent, smoky and slightly creamy salsa served with warm, freshly-fried chips. Only minor letdown was the horchata, which was lukewarm (despite the ice in the cup), on the watery side and a bit too sweet. But that's a quibble -- this place was a winner and I'd definitely go back.
author: J. P.

description: Maybe I just got the wrong thing here? I guess there was a lot of hype or something, because this was on the boyfriend's list of places to try during a recent bay trip. I got a chicken burrito, and all I can say is I've definitely had better. It was just kind of dry and plain-ish. It wasn't bad by any stretch of the imagination, but I expected spectacular from the birthplace of the mission-style burrito. I think we do burritos better down here in LA. If I ever go back maybe I'll try the carne asada- that would be harder to dry out. All in all, I think if there wasn't hype I wouldn't feel a kind of let-down from this burrito place.
author: Amanda B.

description:
My favorite taqueria. Sure, it's 50 steps from my door, but I'd go further for it. Excellent service, nice staff, nice decor (though it's noisy when they're full).

Their burritos have potato, carrots and other fried vegetables, giving them a very "fresh" taste. :-)
author: Lee S.

description:
I think that Papalote has the best quality meat and chicken in the mission.  

I just don't crave the burritos as much as La Taqueria.  Also, don't waste your time in that tiny place, order to go.
author: Justin C.

description:
Great salsa and quality burritos. 

Needs to facilitate more service because the lines can really wear on overall dining morale. For now, its worth it.
author: George M.

description:
Two stars is my personal opinion. YMMV.

Papalote seemed much lighter that most of the other taquerias in the mission area. While that's probably good for my arteries, it felt less flavorful and made the food seem somewhat bland, especially for the price I was paying.

The seating area is extremely crowded on a weekend. We had to wait for 5 or 6 minutes to get a spot, and even then it was only the middle column of a 6 person table (we had people on both sides of us, very close).

I wouldn't go back. The food was decent though, and you are concerned about the healthiness of your mexican food, it's worth a taste. My co-workers swear by it.
author: Ryan R.

description:
So after writing a review of Papalote in NOPA, I got a message from the owner telling me to give it another chance, I did and wasn't moved. 

Months later I was talking with a friend of mine who kept raving about Papalote in the mission and said he thought that the one in NOPA was sub-par too. So finally the other day I ventured forth from work to get some food and I thought "well hell, I go to the papalote down here" and off I went.

The mission location was less filled with hipster douches, but the food was about the same. I guess I don't get why its so popular, but they are, and you can't dispute it.
author: Tom S.

description:
The best salsa ever!

And their veggie burrito is simple but incredible.  I prefer it SUPER!
author: Heather E.

description:
If you don't mind witnessing the occasional stabbing, Papa Lote on 24th and Valencia is worth the visit.

Yes, there is a lot of room for improvement in terms of customer service, seating available, and location... but the salsa makes up for all of those.

and omfgmfgfmogmfgfmogmfgfgggggg the chilequiles are the closest thing to true love that I have ever experienced
author: Wayne F.

description:
This place is better than good.  Go here.  All the cool people go here.  Wanna be not cool?  Don't go here.

They didn't get five stars 'cuz giving five stars is for tools.  Giving four stars, on the other hand: cool.
author: Coleman K.

description:
oh my gosh. AMAZING! i have been asking people where their favorite taqueria is and majority have pointed me in this direction. 

okay, i'm not sure how the burritos are since i'm a taco girl [FYI, when you order tacos, you get two - no choice, so that's why they're only about $1 cheaper than a burrito]. BUT, i'm sure the burritos are as delicious. i'm salivating just writing this review! 

here's the 411. 
+ good vegan and veggie opinions 
+ chips are made fresh there
+ salsa = spicy goodness, bold, flavorful 
+ soy chirizo = AMAZING...tastes like meat 

- the wait can be a little long to order and getting your food [but SO worth it] 
+ you can call and order for pick-up to avoid lines 

the decor is actually nice and hip - i want to say. it's a great place to sit and catch up [when it's not so busy which is rare]. however, it's nice to be close your neighbors so you can see what they're having and usually cute folks are there! : ) so it's not so bad sitting close to them and their friends! haha. but seriously, it does seem filled with young hipster-ish folks. 

i can't wait to go back because i seriously want to try every filling off their menu for tacos/burritos [minus, the beef and pork stuff, of course].
author: Jocelyn T.

description: Large and glorious burritos on a variety of really delicious tortillas. The salsa is great, a slight drawback would be that seating in the restaurant is pretty limited, I think there are only about a dozen tables, all meant for two people. They also have PBR tall boys, for the hipster in you.
author: Matt F.

description: I find it a tad strange that anyone would expect a burrito, which is an anglo saxon American invention, to be "authenically Latino". With that said onto the review. The vegan soyrizos here are totally addictive, can never have just one. The salsa, I'm still trying to figure out what makes it so awesome. Seriously it's the best salsa I've had in a burrito joint. The two downsides in my humble opinion are the location and it's small seating area. It always appears to be packed to the brim by a predominantly hipster crowd, making this more of take out joint. As far as location well, parking is difficult and it's about a block away from 24th and mission which is a cesspool of violence and crime. All in all dudes and dudettes: call in your order, take it to go, and keep the engine running :-P
author: Ricardo M.

description:
Burrito was solid, juicy flavorful meat, fresh fillings and weighed about 2lbs. But we really came here for the chips n salsa to mark off a big eats item. Chips were good, crispy not too thick, just enough salt and warm. Also came complimentary as a side - i hate when having to pay extra for chips n salsa at a mexican joint. We ordered an extra side though since supposedly they're the best in the city. The salsa is really really good, spicy wild flavor and thick. Almost too thick though. Like it has some cream, possibly lard in it to thicken and flavor it up. I am suspect to it's fatty potential. Luckily the mission is a rare jaunt for me so i don't have to worry about becoming addicted to these chips. 
The hubbs really wanted to try their famous burrito, but he was waiting in the car and i just ran in to order and dash and saw it was $20 - nope, too bad he didn't get to try it. Maybe next time we come we can split it to see how amazing it is.
author: Audrey V.

description:
This is seriously the best burrito that I have ever had in my life. 

The chicken mole burrito was a heavenly experience. I came back to New York and told my bay area friends the places that I went on my recent trip to SF and they were like, "yeah, papalote is awesome." Why did I not know about this place before?!?! Indeed, it is awesome. I love it. 

The burritos are a little pricey for other local Mexican prices but the burritos are gigantic and completely worth it. 

I'm already dreaming of my next trip to San Francisco. Sigh.
author: Carlie D.

description: This Is my favorite taqueria in SF.. Their chips and salsa are awesome if you like a litte spice, Chicken adobo Burrito is my fav and tacos are great as well. You will not be disappointed if you go here! Only bad thing is the place is a little small and can get get crowded pretty fast. Besides that it's great!
author: Rio J.

description:
This place is legit.  I would like to think that I was one of the original people who found the amazing salsa (which apparently only 1 person knows how to make and is not sharing), but clearly after reading these reviews, I am just one of "those guys" (you know, Snobby SOB who thinks HE's better because HE found the special place.... That guy, but I digress)

For a "gringo-friendly" taqueria, the place is done well.  I have been to this place 10 or so times and have never had a bad experience, including some surprisingly fast service for some of the lines I have been it.  I think it's priced well, the burritos are great, and usually the service is great.

This is a place that you should try at least once.
author: Stephen R.

description: Average burrito, but a better than average selection of styles.  Maybe it is simply that they don't live up to the hype.  Either way, go here when HUNGRY, so food will taste AMAZING.
author: p w.

description: Since we didn't want to spend hella $$$ for bar food, we navigated the craziness that is SF traffic  (mind you, during pride weekend) to get a taste of their "ADOBO BURRITO," a part of their secret menu!
