It is not listed on their menu yet because they have only been experimenting with the recipe for just a couple of months. If you like Filipino food, you must try this! Although I didn't order the adobo burrito, my friends passed it around. A bit gross but I'd rather feel loved (sharing is caring). I ordered the mole quesadilla! It is really flavorful, I don't know what mole tastes like but I enjoyed munching on the quesadilla. Of course I'm gonna come back to order me some adobo burrito and I can't wait to try their other dishes!
author: Anette N.

description:
I came here in 2006 on a burrito crawl through the Mission (I know...it seemed like a good idea?!) and after stalking this place via Burritoeater.com and Burritophile.com for two years I was ready to try it again. Granted I had the regular chicken burrito -not the super- but the basic burrito should be able to stand on its own, right?  It had way too many rice and beans, not enough salsa, and was really dry. I would recommend adding the extras in to make it a little tastier.

I might be back to try something a little more adventurous but will have to concur with my burrito blogs for menu options :) Asfor the basic burrito...i've had better!
author: Heather P.

description:
i'm salivating just thinking about the fish tacos and that salsa.  if the gods eat mexican, i'll bet they throw that sauce on their tacos.

I wish it were closer, and that there was more room to sit down (it gets pretty crowded, apparently the deliciousness of their secret salsa is no secret)
i also wish the food were less salty, the chicken was a little less dry, that it was a little cleaner, and that i could buy just one taco at a time instead of having to buy 2.  

that being said, i'm sure we'll keep going, probably at least once a week.
author: J W.

description:
$9.30 now for a vegetarian burrito? you know we're in a recession, right? ok, the tofu is tasty, i'll give them that. but the burritos are small, and did i mention that it's now $9.30 for a super?

also, i'd say 4 out of 5 times requesting jalapenos, or simply to have it made spicy, they fail. how hard is it to read the ticket and add some damn spice to my order?

if it's going to take 40 minutes please just tell me "40 minutes". i know it takes longer than the average burrito joint, and i don't mind waiting. what i do mind is being told 15 minutes, arriving after 20 and waiting another 20 on top of that for my food. 

there's an old adage in the food services industry. if you want to know how clean the kitchen is, check the bathroom. if the managers can't keep the bathroom clean they probably aren't paying any special attention in the kitchen. now, i haven't used the bathroom here in a while, but how many years has that entrance door been busted? get it together papa lote. you're not paying attention to detail and charging too much for your food.
author: Rossa S.

description:
Excellent salsa and a wonderful cheese and chorizo dip to start.  Cleanse palate with Modelo.  Shrimp tacos, two times.  More beer.  

Gourmet Mexican, something lighter and fresher then your average Mission taco joint.  

This place is worth a trip.
author: Tony A.

description:
Best guacamole ever!  Their chicken quesadillas are also amazing...try the mole style.  I really enjoy the ambiance, the people, and graffiti art outside.  Papalote is just a chill place to hang out and eat some good (and inexpensive) food. 
My only tip is to eat there because the one time I did take my food to Muddy's Cafe a block or so down, my food just didn't taste as good :)... oh, and they're salsa is just muahhh!
author: Jany X.

description:
This is the taqueria at which I am always trying to answer the eternal question, "What vehicle shall I use this time to stuff more of their fire roasted salsa into my mouth at once?"

Everything else is good, but the salsa just f*cking rocks.
author: Carol S.

description:
++UPDATE 10/29: Last time I went in to pick up some food I spent some time reading their SF inspection report. Let's just say they failed the inspection - things like storing food on the floor, the refrigerator temperature was not low enough...basically they didn't get a score because they had to fix so many things. Should you be afraid? I haven't gotten sick, but it was a bit off putting so I am lowering my score to 3 stars.++

Why do I love Papalote in the Mission? A few good reasons. I am not a vegetarian but I have to admit that the soyrizo tacos are pretty tasty but my alltime favorite is the fish burrito - straight up, don't go super.

Why do I love the fish burrito? It's is sauted in white wine with your choice of beans. The usual garnishes of lettuce, tomatoes, cheese, guacamole are absent so as to preserve and highlight the flavor of the fish.  The burrito is hot (temperature) since there are no cold fillings. You can usually share a fish burrito, and maybe get a quesadilla in case one of you gets a bit hungry.

The chips and salsa are also acclaimed. I do like the salsa, but I have to say it is a touch too spice for my taste.

They also do a great takeout - they are on my speed dial.
author: Spoon G.

description:
I used to really love Papalote, but it's definitely been heading downhill lately. My guess is that it started when they opened the Fulton Street location. Now you don't see the owners anymore, who used to be around all the time when I first started going ~4 years ago. 
I think they're counting on all the mission hipsters to keep coming here, but I think they're treading on thin ice. I paid $8.25 for shrimp nachos, which for exceptional ingredients, I can handle. Their salsa, however, is the only thing exceptional left about this place. They skimped on the shrimp, and I forgot that if you want guacamole and sour cream, you gotta pay for it here. On nachos this seems pretty cheap. 
I really hope they get their act back together, this place used to be worth the extra money, but now it is definitely not.
author: Kaya d.

description:
Changed from 3 stars to 4.

I've been back a few times recently, and loved everything I tried. I don't know why I didn't think it was "all-that" before. 

The salsa is awesome, and I LOVE the CHICKEN MOLE and the FISH TACOS!
author: J K.

description:
I love these guys.  You can't say that about a lot of places but Papalote's definitely deserves it. 

Their super burritos are the best especially for the price. The carne asada is my favorite. The meat is always tender and juicy. The salsa is awesome. If you're vegetarian or not papalote has something for you. Their Tofu burrito is also very yummy. 

I highly recommend this place because you great service, great food, and a great atmosphere without burning a hole in your pocket. 

Cheers!
author: Jessica L.

description:
So I have decided to finally try this place out. I know that this plae was on the "THROW DOWN" food channel show with Bobby Flay. I thought the salsa was great! Out of all the places in the city I think this place has by far the best salsa. Unfortunately, I had a Burrito and shared a quesadilla and it did not blow me away at all. Plus I didn't like that the burrito was not in foil like what all the other taqueria places do. Burritos are meant to be eaten with your hands and not with a knife or a fork. 
So what it comes down to, here's what I would do if you guys go on 24th street to venture. Go here to have the Chips and Salsa and don't order anything else. Then walk a block to EL FAROLITO and then eat a super suiza Quesadilla. If you are still hungry (which I doubt you will be) then go get a Torta at TOrtas Los Picudos down the street on 24th or walk to 19th and Mission and get a Super Burrito at Cancuns. That will be my Mission Mexican food information for y'all.
author: Nir B.

description: I don't understand why so many people rave about this place. Every meal I've had there has been so bad that I could not finish it. I've tried it at least 4 times now. Seems geared to vegetarians.
author: Eater S.

description: Hands down...they have one of the best salsas I've ever tasted.  Now that deserves five stars.  Everyone keeps telling me to try the chicken adobo burrito, so I did.  Nice try but it was okay. I'd stick to the carne asada.
author: Ricky M.

description: Their salsa is fantastic ... Not to mention that all of their beans are vegetarian. Love it. That said ... It is a tad pricey for a burrito joint, and the wait for pick up can be a bit ridiculous. But that salsa ... I will be back for sure :)
author: Cassandra M.

description:
Okay, Bobby Flay and all the thousands of fans of this place can't be wrong.  It's small,  but the food is great and the salsa makes all dishes better.  The Triple Threat Burrito is great, but a bit TOO pricey (Can you say $20 bucks for a burrito?).    The good news is that all other burritos and dishes are much more reasonable and just as good and tasty.
Their main fault as I see it is their order taking (and the help) - I don't know if they are mainly family members, but the girl taking my order at the counter could have been less friendly or interested in taking my order.   AND, I waited well over 33 minutes for my order of a Chicken Burrito, this after, 6 minutes in line.    The worst part was seeing many people get their food before me even though they ordered well after I did!!!      They need to work on this - very unprofessional in my opinion.   I have eaten there 4 times - two times in and twice on take out...if Bob did a Throw Down and this; he'd win easily...
author: Spidey P.

description: simple.  straight to the point.  Good fresh mexican food.  Glad they served Mole because it's hard to find.  I had the mole tacos and enjoyed them.  I had a satifying and fulfilling meal.  can't complain.  It's a pick what you feel like kinda place and deceide how you want it dressed up as either tacos, burritos or quesadilla.
author: Daphne A.

description: Went here finally for the first time yesterday. I wasn't really super hungry but definitely knew I needed something to tide me over. I decided to the get the chorizo and cheese nacho deal. Well, we sat down at the table and were brought the most delicious chips and the salsa which is fucking divine. There's no other way to describe it. But I could drink the stuff. So, I got my nachos. Well apparently I was supposed to hold out and wait with my chips because it was just dip? Kind of irked me but oh well, now I know! I will definitely be back but I think I might go to the other location- it's a little more convenient for me!
author: Lauren S.

description: Seriously, this place is one of the best Mexican joints I've been to...I almost always get the prawn burrito or taco's and they are basically perfect...I've also had a quesadilla there too...but...what makes this place so uber delicious is their sauce/salsa or whatever you want to call it...it's sooo spicy...yet sooo good :)
author: Tony A.

description: I have to write a review for Papalote simply to recommend their salsa!!! It's so so incredible. I wish they bottled it, I would love to gift it to people or bring it to a get together. Almost has a chipotle-like infusion to it, definitely try it next time you are roaming the lovely mission district. It is right off 24th st. bart station.
author: Caitlin R.

description: I order the Chili Verde super burrito and it was yummy . It is in a different class of the standard mission burrito. They are bigger(yeah, i said bigger), made to order(which means it did take a little longer), and a nicer fun environment. just make sure not to fill up on the salsa, before you even get your meal.
author: Heather P.

description: OK, so I buy the Triple Threat Burrito from Taqueria El Papalote, since they won the Throwdown with Bobby Flay. The stupid Burrito costs $22.93. And it is not very good. So now I am thinking, how bad is Bobby Flay's burrito? Isn't he an Iron Chef????
author: Enrique M.

description:
I love this place.  I know it isn't really authenntic but itt s so satisfing.  The salsa is pretty addictive.  I always get their steak burrito with cheese.  Veyy  scrumptious.  And those radishes and melons along the side? not just for show.  They actually cool my mouth down a bit after the salsa.  Though not my thing, I was happily surprised to see how much they had for vegans.  Also they place may be trendy but the staff seem pretty cool. 

I have not gotten big crowds, since I have come close to opening time.   After the second time they seemed to know my order.  And I said no drink but they gave me a little water annyway.  Much much needed as the salsa has a kick.:)  A person in a wheelchair can get in but it is a bit cramped, so be aware. (I have eavesdropped on many interesting conversations, lol.)  Also I tend not to linger here as by the time I leave there are people waitng.
author: Sascha B.

description: Came here per suggestion of a friend and I had also heard that this place was on a "throw-down" with Bobby Flay.  Being a vegetarian myself, I chose a vegetarian burrito.  Not too bad, but nothing terribly special.  The burrito was super big, saved the other half for my breakfast the next morning.  Meat-eater friends thought of the place as a healthy Mexican food place.
author: Teresa C.

description: I love Papalote. I probably eat here at least once a week, if not more. The salsa is the best, and the burritos are pretty good too.
author: Kensey L.

description: We ordered the carne asada tacos, carne asade quesadilla, and chicken adobo burrito.  The carne asada is quality meat and tasted fresh.  The chicken adobo burrito was ok, but I usually judge mexican food by the carne asada.  I'd definitely go back for more.
author: Kathy and Mark D.

description: I love this place.  The food is always really good, the people are nice and the prices are affordable.
author: Freddy M.

description: Now I know why you kicked Bobby Flay's ass in Throwdown!
author: Christine P.

description:
You know you're in the Bay Area when you find a taqueria serving soyrizo and tofu burritos. At kind of ridiculous prices.

As everyone else has noted, the salsa here is awesome and definitely worth buying a jar of for later. I appreciate all the different options (chicken, steak, shrimp, tofu; tacos, burritos, fajitas, etc) and how vegetarian/vegan friendly they are- I am partial to the grilled veggie tacos myself. Have never had a burrito here but my friends love the chicken mole tacos and soyrizo burrito. However, the prices are a bit steep so it's not exactly the best bang for your buck.

I've been to the locations in the mission and on 24th and have to say, the one in the mission served tastier/more flavorful food and there's a little more going there (the chairs at both locations however are super uncomfortable).
author: Grace S.

description: I ate here a few months ago. Of course I had to order their 20 dollar burrito. A bit expensive but well worth it! Something about blending chicken, shrimp, and steak into one concoction did it for me.
author: Bijon R.

description: Overall a pretty good spot to get some inexpensive mexican food. There food is pretty good, but nothing really to spectacular about it. Their tacos and burritos taste pretty good and are fresh, but it's nothing you can't get from a good taco truck. They do have some special spicy orange dipping sauce that is really good. Haven't figured out what it is exactly but its great for chips and even on your tacos. The food does tend to take awhile to be prepared though. I've ordered take-out numerous times and waited around longer than I should have.
author: Ajay K.

description: Yummy! I love that Papalote shows love for all the vegetarians - there are multiple vegetarian options (rice & beans, vegetables, tofu, soy meat) and the refried beans are specifically called out as being vegetarian (awesome). Their red salsa is so freaking delicious, like I-can-eat-it-with-a-spoon-by-itself-good. I had the rice & bean taco's which were the perfect size for a satisfying yet light meal. However be warned, if you are starving, 2 taco's won't do (according to my stomach). The rice is flavorful, the beans are good, and the pico and lettuce is fresh. I think that "fresh" describes Papalote's food very well, and the prices are really low (under $5 for my taco's) for such fresh, quality, flavorful food. If I ever find myself in the Mission area, I will definitely be coming back again for more.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
All you need to know: get the fish tacos. Am I kidding myself or is this guilt-free Mexican food?

The ambiente is a bit on the funk-side, but that's as it should be. Can be a little chilly when it's cold out, but the tacos will do the warming.

The salsa is magically delicious, but in our experience, they're asking 50 cents for a refill of the tiny cup they serve with chips! That's ballsy, I gotta say, but we ended up choking up the two quarters for another cup. I wonder how Adam L gets it for free??
author: Liza T.

description:
The salsa is smokey and eveything always seems to be super fresh.  I always get the soyrizo burrito, it is one of my favorites - tastes like something I would actually make at home. Back in the day my mom would make soy "chorizo" for me, but she would mix it with eggs. It came in a box, it looked something like bacos - you had to add water and let it reconstitute. It was kind of icky if you think about it.  Thanks papalote, you remind me of my childhood. Also, the guy that owns this place is very good to the local community...what's not to like?

OK, that being said I need to go on a rant about some of the reviews here. WHY do non-Mexican pendejos feel like they have the knowledge to call vegetarian options "non traditional"?, or to say that by "adding" vegan options it creates some form of  hybrid "healty twist" to Mexican food? Mexican food *is* healthy...or it can be, if you know where to get it. Burritos are NOT authentic Mexican food, so when reviewers complain that Papalote doesn't serve "authentic Mexican burritos" I can't help to roll my eyes.

Newsflash - in Mexico we DO eat vegetables. As a matter of fact, in many parts of Mexico meat was such a commodity that 98% of the diet was comprised of vegetarian options - just adding a little bit of meat in the shape of local available animals.  Even in super crowded cement and iron Mexico City you can go to any marchanta making quesadillas and ask for Flor the Calabaza, calabacitas con elote, rajas, papa con queso, hongos and delicious huitlacoche. Ohhh...if I could only find that here in the US! 

:-(
author: Raul A.

description:
As a child growing up in San Diego (15 minutes north of the border), I was practically weaned on good Mexican food. I have to admit, I was definitely skeptical reading menu items like "Tofu Soy-Rizo", but my fears melted away when I dipped my first chip into the salsa - oh, that glorious salsa, as man has never made it before.

People will argue that this is Yuppified Mexican, and it probably is since there is no brain or head on the menu - in my mind though, this is actually a good thing. They only serve the freshest ingredients, the best cuts of meat in all of their dishes, and I could go there for every meal.

The Carne Asada and Chicken are great, but for a special treat, try their mole or Pork Chile Verde. Tres Bien.
author: Andy T.

description:
Consistent fresh, cooked to order (that is to say they don't cook all the meat in the morning, it's actually make up for you.)

Great salsa as well.

I have yet to meet the owner, but Hopefully I get the chance, after reading the other reviews.

Price: $7, for a super burrito w/ fresh guacamole
author: Luke G.

description:
I went to Papalote after reading the review in one of the free papers, which praised the healthy cooking and number of the veggie options. I was particularly intrigued by the 'soyrizo', as I used to love chorizo before I stopped eating sausages, burgers, and all those other products made with mashed up scrag ends of meat.

I ordered the soyrizo burrito to eat in. At least, I think I ordered the soyrizo burrito, but I'm not entirely sure that the server understood what I said, and the burrito I received didn't seem to contain anything immediately identifiable as soyrizo. It did contain a bland mixture of rice, beans, tomatoes and onions, but I was expecting that. At least the salsa that came with it was tasty, although it didn't make up for the burrito disappointment. If I go back, I might try ordering soyrizo as a side. If I get a plate with nothing on it, I'll know that they're just making it up!
author: Amelia I.

description:
The roasted red pepper-standard issue-house salsa is good enough for me to drink as a shot. Problem is, that's all you seem to get without paying for some more. I have a problem with that. It reminds me of paying for bread at restaurants in Lisbon, and I wasn't a fan of that either. If you're traveling in Portugal, beware of the bread hustle. It's placed on your table like it comp, but it's not. Back to P...

I agree with Pookie W. in that the mole sauce isn't made in the classic sense, so if you're expecting that, you might be disappointed. That said, their "mole" sauce is great. They might please more people if they called it something else though. Can't speak on the tofu mole, I've only had the pollo. 

It's great for pick -up orders, especially being a rider of the iron horse. Just 1 1/2 blocks from 24th st. BART. If your order isn't quite ready, you can always have a beer while you wait. Bottle or Draught.
author: Kyle P.

description:
This is not your average SF Mexican food restaurant, so if you like dirty greasy burritos this is not for you.  You can find that type at El Farolito or Can Cun which I also love.  

But this is a level above, it fresh and veg friendly.  So skip the regular burrito and try the mole its by far the best I have had.  The veggie burrito is also unique and tastes great with black beans.

And as everyone mentioned the salsa is great and they DO sell it by the jar.
author: Brian S.

description:
Burritos sabrosos!  Only a couple downfalls to this place:

1.  They do not give enough chips with the burritos;
2.  The call-in service seems to be unnecessarily slow (ie you go to pick up your food 20 mins later and still have to wait).

Overall, great and reliable burritos and tacos.  I would venture out to other Mission taquerias as well, though!
author: Timothy S.

description: Consistently great service since I wrote this review. This place has the best burritos in the city.
author: Margaret R.

description: If your stomach isn't used to eating artificial crap and low quality ingredients this is THE burrito place to eat at in the Mission.
author: Rich R.

description: Another over advertised/hyped place. We just got the steak burrito. If you don't "super" it you miss out on guac, sour cream and something else. The line was kind of ridiculous for this food item and it's because they are so slow there.  While the food was decent, I wouldn't come back to wait in line.  The steak buritto was slightly above Chipolte to me and a little more costly.  Too many beans as filler and they weren't that tasty/flavorful either.  I would only come back if the line was shorter and the services was faster.  It also seemed very loud in the dining area.
author: reviewer m.

description: There are few things I actually miss about San Francisco. Papalote is one of them. Their pork chili verde burrito is absolutely fantastic. The salsa is one of the biggest surprises as well.
author: Rob Z.

description: Fresh tasting healthy seeming upwardly scaling Tacos and more. Really delicious, with generous chunks of grilled chicken. I need to go get a burrito there since I've only had the Tacos!
author: Brent D.

description: Best "secret recipe" salsa I've tasted ever. The food is fresh and the fact that it is ALWAYS busy tells you they're more than alright.
author: Matt A.

description: Orange salsa was slightly off putting, but tasted alright once you got used to it.  Completely turned off by the barbaric girl sitting close to me...close your mouth when you eat chips so the remnants don't keep flying into my food biatch!  My roommate order the carne asada plate, her response - ehhh.  I had the prawn burriton...my fave, but here it was dry, bland, and not even remotely memorable.  Love me sum dirty,  hole in the wall "Mission" mexi place...this ain't it.
author: D C.

description: Distinctive and delicious salsa (buy a jar to take home) and many options to please vegetarians/vegans/omnivores.
author: Adrienne S.

description: Just like ms. dimps said below we finally ate at Papalote's.  We shared many dishes because sharing is caring.  Word.  Also, we had a couple of beers because it complimented all our spicey and flavorable dishes well.  We started off with the chips and secret weapon salsa which Miguel felt sorry for me and gave me more chips, since i was licking the bowl.  Then we scarfed down the Trip-T and our other yummy dishes.  Please check this joint out and see the hustle of hard work.  I love deBurrittos!!!
author: Deborah V.

description:
underwhelmed!

my fish tacos were muy bland. my gf's chicken burrito also meh. not sure what all the fuss is about this place, unless it's just that some folks would rather only dine with other white people? 

thankfully we didn't have to wait too long as it was raining last night. don't think i'll be headed back here anytime soon...
author: Ellen S.

description:
HOLY MOLE!!! 

sorry, I couldn't resist.

eat mole here and you will not be unhappy, quite the contrary.

DO IT!
author: Sean W.

description: After the won against Bobby Flay, we decided to check it out.  Parking is weak, but keep in mind that you're in the city & its like that just about EVERYWHERE!  Once we got inside, everyone was super friendly, chatting with customers & joking around, offer food suggestions & making you feel welcome.  The food was delicious!  I had the veggie, which I completely loved.  The triple threat wasnt my choice that day, but it looked monstrously delish as well.  The owner was nearby,  playing with daughter while we ate, making sure we were enjoying our meal, etc... def a must hit if you're in the area!  I can see why they won the throwdown!!
author: Mia A.

description: The price point on Yelp needs to be adjusted! This is not (any longer) a one $ place. We ordered food here the other day for pick up and the bill came to $29 for two people with nothing supersized or specially added, and two (non-alcoholic) drinks. For a Mexican joint in the Mission, this is wayyy above average. Yes, the burritos are fresh and often contain ingredients you wouldn't find in your typical Mission burrito. But at this price point it is not only competing with taquerias, it needs to be compared to the range of sit down restaurants in the area, Mexican and otherwise. When those are taken into account, Papalote ranks just ok. The salsa is fantastic, but that alone isn't a reason to give a place five stars.
author: A F.

description: Try the soyrizo burrito adding potatoes. Make sure the potatoes are cooked all the way through ask for them crispy. This is about as good as it gets when it comes to burritos. B.C. burrito in Hawaii is amazing as well. Also, for a cheap and healthy option Taqueria Cancun is amazing for a veggie burrito. However, if you're willing to spend the extra couple of dollars here you wont' be disappointed. This is absolutely delightful! I highly recommend it.
author: Sashy R.

description: Always an excellent fresh choice for Cal-Mex food. Go take yourself or meet here with a friend or two.
author: joolia f.

description: Aye Carumba! This spot is taaaaaasty! HUGE burritos packed with the good stuff, make sure you get a lot of the salsa - amazing!
author: Paul S.

description: Down street from my old house and I feel i was with them from the start....like a connection. Not so close anymore. Still yummy.
author: Barak K.

description:
Well I have just changed my review from 5 to 4 stars on account of soggy rice the last few times I have gone. The original review still stands but the attention to detail has declined as their popularity has increased.....

(original review... ) Such a great place.  They are cheap, fast, clean and delicious. I can't get enough. The guys in the back practically start making my burrito with extra avocado before I even order. Gotta love it.
author: P-nut K.

description:
it's totally a five for a taqueria--everything's really fresh and a lot of care is put into it.  And damn you love that salsa.  But they're too stingy with it, because they know they can sell it to us.  If they gave out more with the order, we'd be there for hours just drinking it and smearing it on ourselves.  I usually like a variety of salsas, but the one variety they have needs no siblings.

This place really stands out in the vast sea of San Francisco taquerias.  They have vegan mole--damn...  she's been looking for that her whole life.  It's really good, too.  And mole could be really bad.  But never get it in the quesadilla, because it just oozes all out the sides and onto everything around you, making it impossible to eat.

The chicken is marinated and grilled fresh, so you can avoid bin chickens.  I'll spend extra to get shrimp at other taquerias simply to have freshly cook meat, so it's nice to have some more options here.  The lettuce is fresh and green, the guacamole is brilliant, the beans are  perfectly textured and the options include refried black--good stuff.

About the only thing I could think to improve (other than giving MORE SALSA) is that the corn tortillas could be fresher instead of the standard packaged variety.

The price is good, too.
author: Nicole and Kayvon B.

description:
Papalote is awesome to the core.  They give you your choice of beans and tortillas for burritos, which I enjoy because I'm not partial to the typical, "flour tortilla brown pinto beans" burrito persuasion.  My friend says the vegetarian options are awesome, he likes soyrizo, and I guess some people look for that in their food, a vegetarian option that is.  
The chicken and beef are grilled fresh to order, its always tender without gristle or fat.  I love their burritos, yo.  
The best part is the Barbie size portion of chips and salsa they bring for you and and your four friends to share.  Its tiny, but the salsa is the best ever.  The first time I tasted it I was like, "Dang.  Thats a good salsa"  
Minus one star because seating here sucks ass, and pretentious assholes won't move their chairs over an inch to make room.
author: Devon L.

description:
Heavenly tacos for vegans.
I drool for the soyrizo and grilled veggies, even dream about them. (Pass on the tofu mole) Fresh ingredients and complex flavors.  And their salsa, don't get me started... it's delicious. However this is the reason I give them 4 stars and not 5: why do they have to be so darn skimpy about their chips and salsa. They give you a small bowl while you wait for your food, but if you want more it costs extra........ for chips? Are you kidding me?!?
The service is good. The line to order is generally the longest wait. They have good beer in the cooler (others on tap) and art in the dinning room is always changing.
author: Maria L.

description:
A local favorite, I find myself eating here about once a week or so. The food is always fresh and delicious, whether you eat in the dining room or take it home. The taqueria is clean, busy and cheerful. They also do a great job of advertising the local art/music scene.

I love the carne asada burritos and tacos (make it Super!), but everything I've tried has been fantastic. They offer lots of choices and it can be difficult to make up your mind. The food isn't greasy or overly heavy and you can make things even more healthy by choosing black beans, etc.

I'm also a sucker for their guacamole, and would eat it by the gallon if I could.

Be sure to take a menu home so you can call-ahead when a craving hits!
author: Leslie T.

description:
Delicious, fresh tasting and oh so delicious. The only negative was standing in the long line out the door, and the tiny space for dine-in. meh.

I had a chile verde burrito with black refried beans- super style, my friend had the soy-rizo burrito and they were both so unique in flavor. Really really uniquely different. (??)

Delicious.
author: Sean W.

description:
Papa made me fat what with all his yummy burritos and guac.

Even my man boobs don't make me quit eating my favorite Papa.

Maybe I'll pull my own plow one day a week so as to make smaller man boobs while still eating my favorite Papa brand Lote. NOT!

The spicy horse testicles with extra sour cream me like best.

Salsa I like next best. But I ask for more, they no give to me. No, they change policy and now make charge on me.  I say - "I don't pay" - think, I just take it. "Hey lady, Look! Your donkey gets loose and run away down Valencia!" I Grab Salsa for myself.

Success!

Jagshemash!
author: Jack K.

description:
Papalote is currently my favorite place for mexican food...mainly because of the salsa! 

It's best to call in your orders and eat at home though, because the dining area is teeny and there's been a line out the door every time I've been there.
author: Ezra C.

description:
I'm on the great burrito tour and stopped at Papalote for my second burrito (La Taqueria being the first).  Papalote is a little trendier place with a nice dining area and cool music in the background (which some old guy was actually dancing to whilst eating his burrito...free entertainment, I guess).  Service was friendly.  This place seems like more of a sit-down type place as opposed to the plain burrito joint of La Taqueria.

They bring you chips and salsa to start.  The salsa was amazing!  Somehow they mixed creamy into the salsa vernacular and it works!  The burrito came a little later (the wait was a little long, but it takes time for good food) looking delicious with a little side of fruit compote of some sort.

Comparing the actual burrito next to La Taqueria's is a little difficult....I would describe is as "nicer."  I'm not sure what that really means, but it is what it is.  I got the carne asada.  Overall, the burrito was delicious!  The carne asada was very flavorful and it was pretty "clean" to eat.  La Taqueria is  messier and felt a little more authentic and the flavors were just different.  I preferred La Taqueria's carnitas, but that's not to say Papalote isn't very good.

This is a great place to come with friends and enjoy a beer and burrito.  Or, as were 3 other customers, a great place to come and read a book and enjoy some tasty food.

I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Michael S.

description: The food is good and the salsa is especially amazing but the prices are totally outrageous, especially after this last hike.  Between the prices and the wait, I have to be really inspired to eat some mole before I head here over El Toro or El Metate.
author: Gabby G.

description:
looking through the less-than-stellar reviews, i see things like:
"papalote isn't authentic mexican food!!!!!"  (that's because it's a burrito joint.)
"i can't park nearby easily!"  (it's san francisco.)
"i feel like i'm eating at chipotle!!!!11111"  (you're not.)
"i can't get a table quickly because the restaurant is too popular!!!!"  (?)

please ignore these people.  papalote has the best burritos i've ever eaten, and i've eaten a lot of burritos.  if you don't believe me, believe the people at burritoeater.com.
author: Austin W.

description: I never complain or give a bad review in less it's highly deserved. A couple of weeks back I went to Papalote to get my typical vegan bean burrito and I must say it seemed like something went wrong. Not sure what the deal was. They were crowded as usal and normally their service is quick never had to wait long on my order. On this, day December the 8th around 1:00 pm, I ordered a burrito that took much longer than normal and quality was much lower than normal. I wanted to write a good review because normally my experience at Papalote has always been great. However this time it seemed that my Burrito had some sort of black sticky substance holding together. It seems like some type of residual from the grill. After eating the burrito I had a bad stomach issues, aches and pains after eating food out makes you question the sanitary quality of the food. The reason why ate the burrito is because I was in a hurry and didn't have the time and tried to remove all of the black stuff that I discovered. I should have complained and I should have taken back the burrito as much as I loved papalote over the past year. I am considering never going back to this location. However I will say that because this is my only negative experience with the restaurant I will refrain from giving them a 100% bad rating. It's just a shame that this had to happen. Maybe the cook staff was having a bad day, or highly disliked me and didn't think I would give them a bad rating!
author: Kendrick L.

description: Having lived in Los Angeles for many years I moved here with the expectation that you can get a great burrito anywhere, I was dead wrong. The team at Papalote makes a perfect burrito. The best thing about the burrito is that it's balanced. Not too much meat and it's not loaded down with cheap beans and rice. The sauces are authentic and teate great. I recommend the fish burrito, pescado for the gringos. They have a cooler stocked with corona and prohibition which compliment the food perfectly. Probably the best burrito in the city, enjoy.
author: bart b.

description: I am so enthused about this place, but I will temper my review: the chicken burrito is the best I've had in SF, and possibly ever! The salsa is noteworthy--excellent with chips, although I prefer a vinegar-based sauce like Tapatio on my burrito.
author: Mehul P.

description: Best freaking fish burrito. Hands down. I used to live around the corner from the Fulton/Masonic location and was introduced to Papalote by roommates after being away from SF for more than a year. The salsa is amazing. Its what draws you in. I started craving it. I started thinking about it during the day, dreaming of it. I started trying different things on the menu, just to see what it would taste like with the salsa. Then they started bottling it. Now I have jars of it around my house. Eventually, I found Papalote's fish burrito. It is sublime. I crave it. I dream about it during the day while at work. Best freaking fish burrito. I don't care much for the burrito wars in this city. I will not prosthelytize, but I have heard many say and I will agree: this is the city's best burrito.
author: christopher c.

description: I love Papalote and their salsa - do go during non-busy hours or it will be crazy. They accept phone orders, but don't expect them to be 100% correct, sadly. I've been going here since the brothers first opened it 10 years ago, and the food is still tasty.
author: Lis W.

description: We ordered the Triple Threat Burrito and Chicken Adobo Burrito.The Triple Threat was good but i think the Chicken Adobo Burrito is the Winner Burrito.I am pinay and his Adobo passed the Adobo test with flying colors, I should say the Adobo Burrito is a pretty good idea,i love it! My friend ordered the Veggie Burrito, which was okay. The owner is very nice.I am definitely coming back to this place : )
author: Ces T.

description: Fantastic!  This is one of my favorite mission spots.  I really love the guac here, I could eat bowls of it.  The fajitas are great if you're looking for something other than the standard, a burrito.  One thing, ask for extra tortillas, they only give you one.  The grilled prawn tacos are ridic, too, it's one of my faves.
author: Emily T.

description: I prefer these "less authentic" tacos because they come with plenty of tomatoes and you can stuff them with alternative ingredients like tofu, prawns, or soyrizo.  Great chips and a very spicy salsa complete the meal.
author: Sonia C.

description: This was a yummy mexican grill. We had the "cooked to order" grilled steak burritto and "cooked to order" grilled chicken tacos.  Both were fresh and the meats were tender and juicy.  The spot is small, when you walk in, you place your order and seat yourself in the small seating area... other than that, yumo!! Also, it is near bart which is a plus in my book!
author: Amy C.

description: Best fish tacos this side of the border. I love ordering mine with extra prawns. The salsa is to die for and I am thinking of reverse engineering it. Grab a Pacifico if you want to remember your surfing days in Sayulita!
author: Jasmine T.

description: Great chips and salsa.  I like their "plates" rather than burritos.  Great beans.  Nice spot before or after braving Lucky across the street, because there's parking.
author: Andrea R.

description: Casual place to grab dinner.  The chicken burrito is still my favorite (particularly when slathered with that amazing salsa!).  I wasn't as much a fan of the shrimp burrito (I didn't feel like there was enough shrimp there), but the guacamole is also a must-have.
author: Melinda C.

description: Papalote serves the best quality mexican food in the mission and flavor is up there too, great service and friendly staff , achiote chicken is amazing give it a try .
author: NAEL K.

description: Would have been three stars, but $10 for a burrito and then you're going to charge me for extra salsa. OK, but it had better blow my fuhking mind. And Papalote, you didn't. Your burrito was bland and your salsa sucks. Plenty of other places to get a better burrito (or two, for the same price).
author: jesus g.

description:
Three words:

Get the salsa.

The salsa is some of the best salsa you will have in The Mission by far and the mole burritos are the best. Top it all off with a mexican (sugar!) coke for all under $7. 

Count me in.
author: Jay B.

description:
Amazing salsa.
Oh, marinated tofu!
Yes, I'll stand in line.
author: Alana D.

description: Papalote's has ruined me for burritos anywhere else. Theirs are, by far, the best I've encountered in the Bay Area. I thought La Bamba in Mountain View did an awesome burrito; I was wrong. Papalote's super burrito is at least twice as tasty and all kinds of nommilicious. Their salsa is a little spicy by my standards (which are average-ish), but it's so delicious that you don't mind the burn. For the meats my personal favorites are the prawns (nice smokey addition to the burrito), chile verde (good size chunks of pork and tasty sauce) and chicken mole (I hate chicken breast, but the mole sauce is so nommiful that it covers the dryness of the chicken).
author: Kelly C.

description:
I do buy burritos here fairly frequently as some of the more authentic places don't have a fish option and the salsa really is great and the Fulton one is convenient for me. But I think the hype is way out of line. It's a good burrito and sure, it's probably the best TOFU burrito in the city but not the best in town. 

I had been eating here for about a year or so when I saw Papalote on Bobby Flay's Throwdown on the Food Network -- the next time I ordered the burrito that was featured on the show. Not only did I think it was kind of mediocre but it cost me almost $20. Gimme a break.
author: Rebecca P.

description: This place is fantastic!! I enjoy the veggie or shrimp burritos/ tacos. The salsa/chips are perfect. They serve beer. It;s usually crowded but worth the wait.
author: Heidi L.

description: The food in this place is very tasty indeed - why do the people who work there have to be so rude????They leave a bad taste in my mouth- not sure they are worth going back- The least they could do is be a little more thankful to their customers who helped make them successful. I don't get why it feels like you are inconveniencing them when you order a meal. Basically, they are saying get the hell out of here as you are not worthy of this lovely food. ouch- I get that they are very busy and want you to hustle your ass when you order- god forbid you order a burrito wrong - cuz by gosh if you live in the Mission,  you should know how and deserve the cashier chick to bite your head off. Anyway, love love love that soyrizo burrito - my favorite in the city. Thank for reading, hope this was helpful.
author: sue m.

description: Yum,this place is good. I had one of thier vegeterian quesadillas, it had squash and i forget what else. But they gave me some kind of salsa and lord, that salsa was bomb. Another time i got veggie fajitas and it did not dissapoint. the only thing that sucks is that the two times i've gone i've had to get it to go because its virtually IMPOSSIBLE to get seating here, a bunch of middle aged hipsters who think they are still young take up the enitre space.Shouldn't they be eating somewhere like a fancy steakhouse?
author: Peeta B.

description: One of the best burritos you'll find in the Mission (and that's saying a lot!). Their special sauce is worth it in and of itself.
author: Jonah R.

description:
Best salsa I've ever had in my life, and TRUST, I have had many a salsa to compare, being a San Diegan and a Mexican food enthusiast. 
Papalote is healthy, fresh, flavorful, and unique. They offer black beans and whole wheat tortillas for crying out loud! Plus their veggie burritos come with carrots and potatoes in replacement of sour cream and cheese. But of course you can add the fats if you want... just ask to "super" your meal. The prawn burrito is my favorite, but the veggie fajitas (eggplant, zucchini, carrots, etc.) are satisfying if you're really hungry.
The only downside about this place is the wait, because sometimes the lines are out- the- door, which really sucks when you make the commute and there's no where to sit. So plan accordingly if you go at night.
author: Leah E.

description: Used to go here regularly 4-5 years ago, moved away, came back - still amazing as always. Fresh guacamole, well seasoned ingredients, and killer salsa. Love this place!!!
author: Joe S.

description:
Unique selection of meats/fillings, above average burrito (although somewhat inconsistent quality).

Horrible service (rude staff, long waits). I will not be returning to papalote because of this, there are just so many other businesses I'd rather patronize.
author: Tom B.

description:
marinated tofu.  fresh grilled veggies.  vegetarian beans.  amazing salsa.  delicious rice.  crispy chips.  MOTHERFUCKING SOYRIZO.

it's like all my little vegan pig dreams came true.  i've always said that the only cusine that's hard to do vegan is the burrito (yes, i consider the burrito to be a cuisine) and papalote has revolutionized my burrito eating life.  if you are vegetarian or vegan, go here NOW!
author: Laura B.

description: First of all, when I lived right around the corner, Miguel used to sing "Brown Skin Lady" for me whenever I came in (I'm easily flattered - more so when Mos Def is involved).  Second of all, papi's salsa is tasty as hell (and, no, that is not a metaphor.  ew.  why are you so the way you are?)  Third of all, the nachos alone added 5 pounds to my ass (i like my lil' junk).  Fourth of all...um, fourth of all...dang...I don't remember what fourth of all is but I bet it was brilliant.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: Going to papalote is kind of like hooking up with a really pretty person who you've totally hit it off with, but who ends up being not so great in bed. You really wanted to like it, you were really excited when you started, but at the end, you wish you'd just called your regular old booty call. Maybe they weren't as pretty but you always left their place feeling satisfied.
author: Maria D.

description:
god damn sh@t hole!
bad food
horrible servise
and it smells like a garbage can on fire
author: jet b.

description: I LOVE Papalote and I have been coming here at least once a week for three years.  There really isn't much else to write.  I feel as if the restaurant offers traditional Mexican food minus some of the cuisine's more negative aspects (e.g., lard).  I think their burritos (my favorites are chile verde and soyrizo) are far superior to their tacos, which tend to have too much lettuce.  Their nachos are also great.  In fact, the only reasons I'm rating them four stars instead of five are the 1) recent 13% price increase; 2) long wait/table scarcity during peak times; and 3) small, close together tables that necessitate having to sit too close to greasy poser hipsters (though some of them are cute) when dining in.
author: Steven W.

description: Very vegan vegetarian friendly. This is by far my favorite mission burrito.  Their salsa is amazing and sold by the jar as well.  The marinated grilled tofu is excellent.
author: Joshua S.

description: Went back (driver of the car made me go).  Got the chicken fajitas - no onions or bell peppers, WTF?!  Not good.  Everyone at the table was unimpressed with what they got.  I will not be returning.
author: Brittney B.

description:
Papalote used to rock.

But now it sucks. Food sucks. Attitude sucks. People suck. Hell, most of the customers suck.

I'm pretty sure it started to massively suck when the ______ started getting heavily into _______ ... but, hey, shit happens....
author: Currently A.

description:
Always reluctant to give a 1 star review, but I walked away hungry and feeling totally ripped off.  Excited to have a Mexican joint within walking distance of my house, really wanted to like it.  Unfortunately, I was very disappointed.  The price of food here is ridiculous, which is okay if they deliver on flavor, fail.

I ordered vegetarian fajitas.  Essentially one zucchini cut into four large pieces (undercooked), carrots (what), and onion, tasted almost steamed, ZERO FLAVOR.    

The only perk was is was clean and the rice was decent and I imagine the food was fairly healthy, but $13 for 5 ozs of steamed vegetables, no thanks.
author: Carla K.

description: I got the chili verde plate.  Nothing special really not super good or bad at all.  Just average.   The beans were Refried blackbeans and were decent and so was the rice.  The chili verde was lacking in flavor but wasnt bad.  I think 3 stars is average.  Also for being in the heart of the mission where all the epic level mexican places were I was expecting more.  Oh well.
author: Shawn L.

description: The burritos are good, but the prices have gone way up. Too much for what the food is worth. Wait time can be long sometimes.
author: marcos j.

description: This place is super yummy and cheap. I am a big fan of fish tacos and the ones here are the best. the fish is super fresh and the portion is large. The salsa they give out with the chips is amazing, unless you don't like spicey, in that case it will make you cry. If you're looking for great, cheap mexican food in the mission this is the place to go!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Papalote, a hipsterized taqueria with colorful walls and an impressive array of veggie options (mmm...soyrizo), is clearly a darling of the Mission scene.  Even in the middle of the afternoon with half the tables empty, there was a takeout line going out the door.  But I have to go with Maria D on this one:    you're paying for this trendiness with small portions.  Like my prawn burrito with hardly any prawns in it.  And yes, that creamy orange salsa is awesome, but you have to pay extra for chips & salsa, and even then you only get a tiny bowl of chips.  I could get the same delicious sauce by ordering the fajitas at El Toreador in West Portal.  Otherwise, I'll stick to the authentic taquerias for my burrito fix--soyrizo or no.
author: Wes M.

description: Papalote is probably my favorite burrito joint in the Mission.  The staff is nice, quick and clean.  The food tastes fresh and I love the chicken mole super burrito. The chips and salsa that they drop by the table as you wait for your food are the best, and you rarely have to wait more than a couple of minutes.  Above all else, this is the cleanest taquera that I have found in the city.
author: Quinn S.

description: Service has greatly improved! I love you papalote!!!
author: Erin D.

description: The chilaquiles were awesome though a bit spicier than the dish I had at the Fulton Street location.  Chips were just ok, salsa awesome.  I'll definitely be back to try the burritos.
author: phil h.

description:
#46 on the "big eat sf" list - chips & salsa

pretty much your typical chips - home made, fried there, not silly tostitos pre-made junk

but holy hell, that salsa was SPICY. i don't do spicy. call me a whimp, i don't care...if you do spicy, go and try it and give it 10 stars!
author: S V.

description: Great food.  The sauce is yummy and the way they prepare the carne asada is authentic.  The service staff is not very helpful but it you place your order and stay out of their way you're fine- just enjoy the food.
author: Lissette R.

description:
*yeah, we fed into the hype and swung by to see what the hoopla was all about....... 
 
i used to live in the city. i have my good-n-trusty taquerias that I MUST have whenever i'm up in SF - Pancho Villa, Cancun, El Farolito, but i never cared to break in another spot and be disappointed that i wasted my time when i coulda had a great burrito.

yes, parking is tough in the mission.  that's nothing new, so be prepared to circle the block.

ordering was a breeze.  Getting a table looked like it was going to be tough, but were actually seated pretty quickly. they bring you chips and their homemade salsa to nosh on while you wait.  the salsa is very very good - unlike the red/green salsas you see everywhere else, this salsa was rich, smokey, and very very flavoful (for those from SJ, think La Victoria salsa, but less creamy, and the raw ingredients dont get lost in the whip)

The meats are grilled FRESH.  not pre-grilled, chopped, and thrown in a tin in advance.  and cuz of this - and the size of this place (small), getting your order will take a while.  this is what separates it from other taquerias (or is it a grill?), that they do this as you order, unlike other places that take less than 5 mins to throw your ingredients in a tortilla, wrap it, and get it to your hands/table.  so be prepared to wait about 15- 20 mins (this was when it was very busy, probably less when its not)

my GF ordered steak nachos: 
the plate came and you could see the steam coming off the carne asada.  its a flank cut, marinated and seasoned to perfection.  she's a bit particular when it comes to taquerias, so to impress her was a big win.  the plate was fresh, hot, and all ingredients were very tasty.  refried black beans, ftw!

i had the chicken burrito + cheese & guacamole: 
not your run-of-mill burrito.  great size, its not HUGE, nor is it wimpy either.  the chicken is marinated very nicely; smokey & spicy, and it doesnt over power everything else.  refried blackbeans were nice consistency, not runny at all.  the salsa is awesome and the rice was nice and steamed, not al dente, or mushy.

the service is great.  one of the owners made sure the dining area was in check and that you were attended in adequate time.  kudos.
author: Ruben G.

description: Everybody thinks I am crazy that i don't like paplote's.  I am a meat eater - but am fond of fake meat as well.  I ordered the soyrizo tacos and it tasted like the cook had forgotten to remove the plastic casing (literally super chemically plastic taste).  After that i have been weary of going back.
author: Greg M.

description: I must say that their veggie burritos are full of wrong (carrots in a burrito?) but everything else is jam-packed full of good.  They're not fast, but damn are they quality.  Fresh ingredients (take that like man-whore Baja Fresh) makes this a taqueria I'll keep coming back to.
author: Chris M.

description: I got food posioning here from the green pork burrito and had to cancel my trip to Vegas. I've been back here once since then, the food is not bad. I still prefer Faralitos. "Green Pork" sounds like food poisoning.
author: Pepé H.

description: This is my favorite Mexican eatery in SF. I tend to like Oaxacan style -- heavy on the veggies, mole, and cotija cheese. I'm not a burrito fan like my boyfriend (who initially rejected Papalote as being inauthentic, but has since come around.) If you order vegetable dishes here, they are full of lots of veggies, not just onions, lettuce, and tomato like most SF taquerias. This place is awesome for vegetarians- veggies and meatless meats abound. Flavors are awesome. Good drink selection, too.
author: Kely G.

description: of course, right? i make vegan selection, so rare to find such a vast array, i must therefore support, right? RIGHT. tofu mole, you yellow bellied land lubbers! such an odd concoction, so zesty. so, so right. and yes, their salsa is "ingest-fest" endorsed by me. i also really like the verde habanero salsa at the table, really exemplifies the desirable "my nose is a resevoir" pain that i crave at each and every meal. i mean, i have to use the 1/3 of the bottle in each bite for that effect. that merely makes me a jaded soul who should be fixating on other avenues in life. but i say HIJO DE SIETE CHIGANDAS! i hope i said that right..... anyway, the aloof hipster gringos love this place, if you like carcass you should venture down the road apiece. VIVA LA MUERTE elsewhere, id say.
author: Christopher J.

description: Authentic burittos, the chef is cool, he is a DJ. Great adobo buritto idea. I had the Mole burrito. My boyfriend was grossed out once he found out Mole is Chocolate.  Ive had better burritos tho. Sorry! This place was featured in a Food Network show called Throwdown with Bobby Flay
author: kate b.

description: Saw a chef from Papalote on "Chopped" (on the Food Network.) Decided to try it while vacationing in SF. Salsa is great and the nachos w/roasted veggies are delcious. Service was a bit slow for 3pm on a weekday, but we weren't in a rush.
author: Kristen S.

description: I almost gave 4 stars because this place is always busy and often you can not get a table, but it's not fair to punish them for being so delicious. I have never had a bad item here. Tacos- yum. Burritos- yum. Sorizo- yum. Salsa- Yum Yum Yum.
author: Cassandra C.

description: Best salsa around. Buy a glass jar of salsa and bring it back each time for discounted refills. It is sooo good.  My staple mexican place everytime.
author: Jen V.

description: 4-star burrito, minus one star for the long wait. I have no problems with waiting a long time for a good meal, but the wait didn't justify the final product. Chips were kinda stale too.
author: Mark A.

description:
horchata is GREAT
guac is bleh, chips are awesome
chicken is crazy dry and gross
shrimp tacos are good
chile verde ques is very good
carne asada super burrito is good
author: Christopher L.

description: One of my favorite burrito joints in the Mission, nice and clean, plenty of seating too! Run by two brothers, but not the flying ones.
author: Nish N.

description: skeptical because of the hype, but that super veggie burrito is on point. and that salsa... damn
author: Monika S.

description: This place was referred to me from a few people who live in the city, so of course I had to try it! They raved about how the chips and salsa, and burritos are bomb-diggity here. First time I came here, they closed the door on us because they were closing. That's my bad for not checking what time they close. So I went there again for dinner sometime this week, and ordered a vegetarian tofu burrito. This was my first time eating a burrito with tofu in it. It was aaaaaaal-right. My friend had the mole burrito and he said that it wasn't that great. But for being a vegetarian, they had a lot of options there. I would go again to try the other dishes. Oh yeah, and the infamous chips and salsa... Chips were good, but the salsa on the other hand tasted better with the burrito. I am not a fan of dipping chips in creamy sauce. I am more into pico de gallo when it comes to chips.
author: Janice D.

description: A dream.  A beaut.  I'm an out of towner and begged my sister to take me to an awesome taqueria during a recent trip to SF.  She took me here, and I died.  Mexican Coke (tee hee).  Some sort of smoky, pureed chipotle salsa with fresh chips.  And the burrito.  Words cannot describe my happiness.  Chicken mole with black beans, super style (cheese, guac, slip of sour cream), was a humongous newborn-baby-sized thing of creation.  Everything was perfectly balanced: not too sour cream-y, no skimping on cheese or chicken, fabulous taste.  I would gladly eat one of these once a week, every week...sigh...if I were local.  Gracias, Papalote.
author: Lauren J.

description:
i went there for the first time with my lady carrying heavy bags of books. while she was ordering, i went to one of the many empty tables and put my stuff down and the "waiter" came over to tell me that "i must" wait until i order to sit down while at the same time the cashier was telling my girlfriend the same thing. this happens every time we go there, which has made us not want to go there. the burritos kind of suck. the soyrizo tacos are pretty good, but the amount of guacamole and chips you get for the money is just pathetic. it is fairly cheap and fairly healthy, but that's no excuse. 
you won't find me waiting in line for this crap.
*a year later and they still get balls. yellow sweaty ones. i tried them again the other night. jeesus.
author: schitzen h.

description: Tofu Mole burrito rocks my world. Always order extra salsa on the side. It's amazing. This is one scenario where I never try other things on the menu because the first thing I tried was so awesome I crave it every time.  This is a Mexican heaven where everyone can be happy together. Good for vegans, good for everyone.
author: Brieana E.

description: Salsa is one word, ORGASMIC!!! I absolutely love this place. I have even bought a whole jar of that heavenly salsa. Love the fish tacos, fish burritos, super veggie burrito, and the breakfast is slammin too. Huevos rancheros, yum. If you don't like this place, something is wrong with you. Oh, they are sticklers about the salsa, you get one cup, and they will charge you extra for more, so be prepared, but it is totally worth it.
author: Brooke A.

description: Just wanted to add that the fish burrito is ridiculously good. And I suspect their salsa is laced with crack cocaine. So good! Wait still atrocious though...
author: Maximillian M.

description: When I went to college on the east coast I had my friends ship me jars and jars of this salsa. I always get the super prawn burrito with no pico de gallo and extra roasted salsa. The shrimp burrito is good too.
author: Nisha M.

description: WOWOW Super chicken mole burrito.......mmm!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It is so good. The mole is nice and not overly sweet. It has that nice cocoa taste with a bit of smoky flavor. OOO lala!! Their salsa is amazing. It's very creamy roasted tomato. I love it. Not unbearably spicy; just perfect. And, they serve it with warm chips.  YUMMY BURRITOS!! Better than my old favorite, Taqueria Cancun.
author: O K.

description: Um, hello?!  Soyrizo burrito... nuff said
author: Lindsay F.

description: I've been coming to Papalote for over 4 years and it's my favorite burrito in San Francisco, because of the salsa, the guacamole and the fact that they grill their tortillas rather than steaming them a la San Francisco style.  However, I hope they read this review because I want them to know that the recent upping of the prices (not that recent now I guess) means I don't go there much anymore.  I used to go once every week and a half or two weeks, and now it's like once a month, if that.  When I went today, at rush hour, 12:30 p.m. lunch, it wasn't packed like it used to be, and I genuinely think it's because of them raising their prices.  Before that, I remember not being able to get a table and waiting in a long line.  Their food rocks, but who wants to spend $9.50 on a super burrito?  I'd rather go to El Farolito and save a few bucks.  I'm bummed...
author: Ilona S.

description: I've been going here for over seven years and having lived in Mexico this is as good as it gets this far from the boarder!!!
author: Muhammad R.

description: This place is good because it's healthy mexican, not too greasy and not overly salty. Overseasoned Mexican is NOT good!  I really like their salsa but to me it's more like a sauce or sofrito.  Good and spicey.  I discovered today if you ask for a veggie burrito it comes with potatoes and carrots as well as rice and beans.  It was just too much and I won't order it again.  But for the most part I've had excellent luck here.  Their grilled chicken burrito is fantastic.  They are a couple of bucks more than your average taqueria but it's worth it.
author: anne m.

description: If Papalote were a celebrity, it might be Tobey Maguire.  You sort of hate it for not being something else and then grudgingly appreciate it for always being just what it is and nothing more.  You wish it weren't quite so clean-cut but are pleased with the crisp fresh vegetables and zesty mole, you feel a little ridiculous for eating soyrizo but then you remember that soyrizo is really nice and treats you well, you sort of feel bad for not going for Benicio Del Toro/La Tacqueria down the street and you know you like Benicio better but there's something both annoying and comforting about Toby.  The horchata ladle will always be sparkling like his semi-bovine smile and you'll get what you expect.  All I know is that I dream of soyrizo quesadillas, and if that makes me a frippie then I can stand that for an hour or so.
author: Tory S.

description: Great chicken burrito, simple and easy, fast service, they have Mexican coca-cola and beer also, we took our food to go and when we got home we were super stoked. My buddy got the $20 Triple Threat Burrito, a bit pricey but he loved it. I am a picky chicken eater and I was very happy with the quality of the chicken that they had in my burrito. Thanks. We will be back for sure....
author: Aaron L.

description:
at first, i really didn't want to like this place because of the lines and sometimes annoying customers (you know, the dudes with skinny jeans and 80s style haircuts). but they've never disappointed me.  my favorite is the prawn burrito.  also, i love their refried black beans and they have plenty of veggie options.  only four stars because my burritos could always use an extra prawn or two.  plus, i don't think they need to charge for an extra side of hot sauce- considering, its about 3 tablespoons of sauce. 

the best times to go are before or after the lunch/dinner rush.  you will easily find a place to sit and maybe your food will be prepared with an extra amount of tlc.
author: maggie m.

description: Another one of my frequent haunts. I started out with the Fish Tacos, but haven't been able to order anything other than the Carne Asada entree lately. The black refried beans and the jicama pico goes great with the with the thin cut steak. Also have to recommend the Machaca when you're feeling a bit partied-out the morning after. A bit hard to get into sometimes, but the staff is always on the ball getting tables ready.
author: Chris R.

description: I've eaten here before (I love their salsa) and recently ordered catering from here for an outdoor party with 25 - 30 people.  Catering included 30 burritos (each cut in half) (10 beef, 10 chicken, 10 veg), chicken nachos, cheese quesadillas, and chips & quacamole.  Food was great, more than enough was provided and at a great value.  My guests loved it!  Thank you Papalote!
author: Leah S.

description:
my bf and i have been sharing their humongous fish burritos once a week.  we're still not sick of them yet.  

i LOVE their spicy roasted salsa.  it's not easy on my back end the next day, but i'll pay the price for a taste of that spicy goodness.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Went here with my family after seeing this place on Throwdown on Food Network.

Ambiance:  Place was super packed, waited about 20 mins for a table, but was pretty good considering how busy it was.  Nothing fancy, but basically what you would expect.

Service: They were quick to clean and clear tables for people to sit, so sufficient.

Food:  I ordered the Chili Verde Burrito, it was good, but probably not the best burrito I have had.  My brother got the Triple Threat Burrito which was featured on TV, it ran for $20.  The burrito was excellent but I wouldn't say it was completely worth the price.  The orange salsa is what makes the burrtio soo good...w/o the burrito would be near average.
author: Bryan T.

description: ICKY!  Thank god this place was inexpensive.  The best thing about this place was the water bottle that I paid for.  The rice and bean taco that I had was not a taco at all and was just a bunch of lettuce and some beans thrown on the bottom of soggy tortilla.  Do not recommend at all and if you see it - keep on walking!  It was basically watered down Mexican food for yuppies.
author: Anjali K.

description: My bf got food poisoning from their pork burrito thereby canceling our trip to Vegas.  :*(   Actually I should give them 5 stars just for that...then again it's minus 3 stars  for having to clean up vomit all weekend.  So we're back to 2 stars.  So you see, my rating system, it's all very scientific.
author: Melissa S.

description: This is the best burrito, especially for thoseof us that don't eat meat.  Usually you might get a rice and beans, but at papalote you can get two kinds of grilled veges, soyrizo, tofu con achiote and tofu mole.  Amazing.  Everything is incredibly fresh and grilled to order - no vats of food cooked hours ago here.  Salsa is amazing, i could drink it i think.  you just can't go wrong - not a typical burrito, go to another one of the millions of burrito joints in the mission for that - but a damn good burrito...
author: amy b.

description: When I first spotted this place, i had to laugh. It was exactly what I should have expected to arrive in the Mission: a veggie/vegan friendly, catering to the non-latino population, hipster spot. Then one night my brother suggested we go there (who happens to fit into the above said catagory), and I figured what the hell. What the hell! This place is great! My husband was almost drinking the table salsa, and every dish we got was scrumptious. And hey, even vegan, white, hipsters need a place to eat too. Ive beenback a couple of times since, and it's consistantly been good.
author: Mollie M.

description: This is definately a SF gem. The food is authentic and the atmosphere is friendly. The super Prawn buritto really satisfied me. My wife and I likey likey.
author: William M.

description: Papalote is one of the reasons I miss living and working in the Mission. As a vegetarian I love all of the options, but I often end up going with a super rice and beans burrito simply because the flavors are so delicious on their own. The salsa is to die for and like nothing else I've tasted. Added bonus- the owner throws some of the best parties in the city (check out his monthly Da Joint) and spins great hip-hop. Pick up one of the several flyers on the counter as you head out the door.
author: Michie L.

description: Total yuppie burrito.  Think you can get Vegan Tofu Mole anywhere in Mexico?  But that's one more reason I love living in SF.  Their service is a little slow, but worth the wait.  The Chicken Mole burrito rocked my world and the salsa truly is the best I've ever had.
author: Jimmy C.

description: This restaurant is tiny, the clientele is rowdy, and service is sassy. But their AMAZING salsa makes up for it. I could drink the stuff;  I love it so much. Too bad it's served in these puny little bowls.
author: Jen L.

description: Tofu mole...  My first apartment in the city was on Haight between Fillmore and Webster, right above a club called The Top.  Every night my floor shook.  And there were drive by shootings on a pretty regular basis.  But the upside was a wonderful burrito joint called Botana.  Authentic?  Probably not.  But they had this AMAZING roasted veggie and tofu mole burrito that I still dream about 6 years later.  Botano is no longer, but Papalote is as close as I'll get until Cynthia and Tony open up a new place.
author: Lauren D.

description: I don't get the appeal of this place. I'm never impressed with the food. We ordered something to go because there were no tables, then a table opened up and they wouldn't let us eat there. The guy cleaning the floors was rude as was the cashier. The food is OK, but that's it.
author: Melissa A.

description: Had they're famous dish the triple threat but for $20 not impressed.  Super Nachos were good and mate mojito was refreshing and made the meal better.  Extra star for customer service.  Going to try again.
author: G A.

description: Great, fresh healthy mexican. And the roasted salsa is the shiznit. The mole is only passable but the burritos and tacos are fab.
author: Paul C.

description: A great lunch place!   The chorizo queso was really good.  Gooey and spicy.  We were disappointed that they only gave us one (large) tortilla to share for it, however.   The salsa they give you with the chips was fabulous, not your usual salsa - couldn't put my finger on it.  We orderd the carne asada tacos, and they didn't disappoint.  Meat was tender and juicy, and the "grande" version with cheese, sour cream and guacamole made it better.   Would go again.   We heard about the "Triple Threat" burrito on a food network show, but looking at it in real life doesn't seem worth the $20. I'm sure it's good, but for that much money, we'd expect to feed two easily - not that large.
author: Ann G.

description:
for five bux after yoga a mole tofu taco is all you need.
you do need the yoga before hand to put up with the long wait.
but it's all good, patience, right...?
author: Today Y.

description: Go for the vegan tofu mole burrito.  Stay for the best salsa in SF. This is a smooth, blended, just spicy enough orange colored thin salsa.  The above mentioned tofu mole burrito is sweet and delicious and doesn't ever leave me with that "oh god did I just eat that whole thing" feeling.  Friends swear by the fish tacos and burritos, but I prefer a classic deep-fried fish taco to Papalote's sauteed fish version.  There is beer in bottles and on tap here.  It is a tad (just a tad) more upscale than the average Mission burrito joint.  It is also very excellent to watch all the boys and girls walk by the large picture window on their way to and from BART.  Eye candy goes well with any meal.
author: Emily N.

description: Just had the best burrito here. ever. the tortilla was grilled, flaky, and amazing. The chicken was grilled and tasty. The rice, beans, and cheese, all got along swimmingly and never created any kind of ruckus. There were not as many annoying, skinny-jean-wearing, hoodied, trucker hat "hipsters" as others have indicated. The beer was cold. Life could be worse.
author: LosAngelenoguy L.

description: A must have in SF!! The soy chorizo burrito is the best
author: willma g.

description:
OK I've tried this place again and again and I can't find a single item that I couldn't get a better version of somewhere else.

If you like good Mexican food, go somewhere else, the only thing decent here is the salsa, which I'm actually growing tired of as it's becoming more and more spicy
author: Henry C.

description: Yeah! I love prawn tacos, I love hipsters, I love Reggae Djs, I love watermelon agua fresca, and I love the smokey delicious salsa. The mole tacos are pretty tasty as well. Go here, why not?
author: Roxane S.

description:
as a vegetarian for the month of march, i tried the veggie burrito, and it far exceeded any expectations i had. grilled zuccini, eggplant and mushroom (worth the extra $1) - delicious, i ate myself silly and regretted it after, but it was delicious. 

can't speak to the rest, but will def go back in april to try.
author: stephanie w.

description: Heard about the adobo burrito from a friend of mine and she was not lying! A delicious chicken rice tomato garlicy flavored burrito.  Literally the first bite into it gave me a Man Vs. Food reaction of joy! lol It's a must try if you visit the place.  Brought some of my friends there and they have to order that every time we visit now. Free chips and salsa and the salsa is tasty with a little spicy kick.
author: Dee R.

description: This place is the dankness for burritos. I go there all the time for chicken burritos. Also, note that you can call ahead to pick up if you're on the go.
author: Mark H.

description: beware....this papalote is not as good as the one on fulton. why, i do not know.
author: Wakako U.

description: I loved Mission taquerias, then, one expanded waistline later, I didn't so much. I've come to think of Pancho Villa and Taqueria Can-Cun as now-and-then treats, while Papalote is a place you can eat regularly and not feel like you just did yourself horribly wrong. Papalote earns most of its points for health, adding ample vegetables to accompany their well-cooked meats. The prices are also equivalent to our favorite taquerias, without the unhealthy extras, with two carne asada tacos coming in at $4.15. All in all pretty good, minus the unhappy woman at the cash register doling out helpings of attitude with everyone's tacos.
author: Tara R.

description: came to this place because of the Iron Chef....I must say that while the Burritos were very tasty, I think the Triple Threat is overpriced. And if you are a guy, its not big enough to share. For $19.00, I would suggest getting 3 Burritos with 3 different meat than one Triple Threat. An average price burrito is about $7.50. You get more burrito than a Triple Threat. I thought the triple threat was going to be at least twice the size of a regular burrito but its not. So my suggestion is to get 3 individual burritos instead.
author: Jay S.

description: Word up on the fish tacos which are better than most. And the veggie options are actually decent and extensive which is good if you have lots of whiny vegetarian friends like I do. But the meaty things? Try somewhere else.
author: patrick g.

description: I love me a good burrito, and Papalote delivers and then some! The husband and I were still full from Dynamo Donuts (health nuts we are not), so we decided to be good and split a prawn burrito. Yet again, I was amazed by how something that can be quite heavy seemed so light. Such a delicious burrito - shrimp were cooked to perfection, and the veggies inside were uber tasty! The tortilla chips could have used a wee bit more salt (and seemed a bit stale), but that phenomenal salsa that came with them (probably the best I've ever had) more than made up for that.
author: Rachel G.

description: This is one of my fav hole-in-wall Mexican place in the City.  I liked the soyrizo veg burrito.  Parking is always a problem in the area (best to take bart to 24th) and be ready for long lines. Free chips and salsa too.  Chips weren't that great but the salsa... Holy smokes...that was hot!
author: ITesh J.

description: I ordered the chili verde burrito and it was the best burrito I've had since I can't remember when (maybe El Farrilito).  It was bursting with flavor...I'll be back...many times I'm sure!
author: Sarah D.

description: Fresh ingredients, table service and good beer. This place can't be beat. They serve free chips and salsa too!
author: Shannon B.
