description: I go to Papalote when I want something that's kinda burrito-esque, but not quite a super authentic Mexican burrito. I get the veggie burrito which has potatoes and carrots with black beans. And I love it. Also, I am oddly obsessed with the small portion of cucumber citrus salad they serve on the side. I think it's because it's such a small amount and you don't seem to be able to order a large serving of it. I can only dream...
author: Sharon T.

description: Papalote is one of the few SF Mexican restaurants that offers customers the choice of substituting vegan/vegetarian options (soyrizo, marinated tofu) in their dishes.  The decor is punchy, the employees very friendly, and their tofu quesadilla is a light, delicious, and quick bite.  "So why give the place only 3 stars?", one may ask.  Well, for me, Pokez in San Diego still sets the bar in the "Best Vegan Mexican Restaurant" division.
author: Momo R.

description: It seemed like it was supposed to be a nicer joint, but the food did seem much different than what I would get at any other taqueria in the neighborhood. I had a chile verde burrito, which tasted okay, but was also really runny, so I ended up needing a fork and knife to eat it. I don't see any reason to go here over another place.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
The mighty have fallen!!

As a long time Paplote enthusiast it pains me to have to write this...but they've stumbled and it's not clear if they will be recovering.

Food: 
   The food is still good - above average...but it seems a bit down from the quality of prior years.

Service:
   Ouch!! What else can I say. Last night was the third time in a row I had a sub-par experience. When you are charging more than virtually all other burrito places - come on, get it together.
   I went in with some friends, we ordered...then had a crappy time waiting (they don't facilitate who gets what table much - which can be stressful, but not entirely their fault).  Once we were seated (remember, this is after a significant wait) - one of our party gets her food immediately...which seems "about right" timing-wise.  We wait a bit more, she starts eating...then the waiter comes out...and serves one person from the party that was behind us in line. Then he comes out again and serves another person - but from the party 3rd back in line.  So now he has 1/4-1/3 served 3 different groups & we're all sitting there wondering WTF.  I go up and mention that one person got their food 10 minutes ago (and order more beer so it's not like we're not giving them more $$).  They think I am asking for more chips or something (no idea why - I wasn't mumbling or anything).

  The food *finally* comes out after we've all finished 2 rounds of drinks & our first friend has completely finished her meal (and the remainder came out in several stages as well - but it's getting painful to detail all this).

  Anyway - the main point....sigh....Papolote is really starting to disappoint. If they are too busy they should hire someone to "facilitate" orders, seating, etc - they charge enough and are popular enough to not handle their customer base in such a crappy way.
author: J M.

description: Wow, the black refried beans, grilled chicken and salsa are unreal. This is my new favorite Mexican spot in the Mission.
author: A D.

description: When Papalote saw me walking towards him, he put up his hand to wave, but it looked like he wanted a high five. So I started to high five, but he got flustered and moved his hand away. *scratches her head* Oh well, I've had better burritos at El Farolito a block and a half away, anyway.
author: Cecilia A.

description: ummm.. not sure what the big deal is, but their chips and salsa aren't that great. i get it, it's tomato-saucy-heavy. yeah, so? and the carne asada burrito that cost $10 or close to it? wasn't that great either. nothing in that burrito was tasty. the meat tasted very meaty. and not in a good way. it was just bad! and so was everything else that accompanied it. it just seemed like a giant mess. i've had way better and for a lot less! yes, like el farolito a few blocks away on mission. but hey, if you feel like dropping $10 for a burrito that's not even that great (in my opinion at least), then sure, come here. otherwise, i suggest walking down a few blocks and get a giant oh-so-heavy-you-can use-it-as-weights super carne asada burrito from el farolito. trust me, you'll be so glad you did. ;)
author: mai c.

description: Want a darn good carne azada..well this is the place. Full of flavor and great portions.. man Im comin back. Just recently found out they beat out that Bobby Flay Chef.. (no wonder they got quality stuff) Next time im trying the triple threat burrito with chicken beef, and shrimp.  Everyone there is also super friendly and totally easy access to 24th bart station!
author: jorge d.

description:
I watched a repeat of the Bobby Flay burrito throw down on Saturday evening May 22. The only thing kept me from driving to the city after the throw down was the fact I was driving from 94538 all the way to 94110.

But on Sunday, It was on. I was going to hit it. I didn't expect to find parking so I took the first space available. Good thing too.. I didn't see any other spaces from 26th and Valencia. I also found Anthony's Cookies..but that's another story.

Okay. Papalote. I was disappointed. To win the thrown I was expecting a kick-a-- burrito. Don't get me wrong. It was tasty. But $9.30 for a super size burrito that would be a "chico" at La Constena in Mountain View? Come on. The flavor does not beat Pancho Villa or El Toro (same place if you didn't know that) La Taqueria on 25th and Mission.. El Tonayense, Zapata even LaCumbre can hang with Papalote. 

The wait of over 20 minutes for 1 burrito to go was unacceptable. 
Those with phone orders also had to wait.

After ordering, you're in this cramped area of restaurant stock and produce or forced to wait outside. 

For those of you who saw the burrito throw down,. $19.95 for a burrito which is the size of a regular at most places? I can't go for that. No can do! 

Papalote is NOT terrible. My expectations after winning the throw down were really high. 

- 1 STAR Value and wait
- 1 STAR Untidy waiting area
author: S S.

description:
let's start a burrito fight. i declare that papalote has the best burrito in the city! it's fresh, tasty, healthy and that sauce- what the heck is in that sauce? it's so yummy. i'm crazy about their chicken burrito, but my friends love the fish and vegan dishes. anyway, i'm so happy that papalote is in my hood...

the only caveat is that the traveling mariachi band doesn't make it down to papalote. perhaps it's too gringo for them? well, they're missing out.
author: frisco j.

description: This place is pretty much perfect. It's inauthentic enough to be healthy, clean and full of varied, quality ingredients but authentic enough to be really really freakin good and easy on the wallet. The salsa may be atypical, but it's seriously the best salsa-esque stuff in a cup I've ever had. The grilled chicken, cooked to order, is crazy delicious. If Papalote were a single entity instead of a combination of people, inventory, recipes and real estate, I'd high-five it.
author: jessica s.

description: Clean, cheap and decent looking indeed, but carne asada burrito was just no match to Pancho Villa's, for example: meat was clearly burnt (you could smell the burnt meat/dirty grill? - as soon as you walk in) and definitely worse quality (lots of non-chewable pieces), and it totally fell apart all over the plate midway through. It was also really lacking in sauces/moisture, despite being "super"!  Sticking with Pancho's for now.
author: Sasha M.

description:
I wanted to not like it, I really did. I heard about the elitist attitude the people who work here have. I walk by every day and see the ridiculously long lines and tons of people ALWAYS waiting, but in my quest to find the best burrito spot in the mission I had to try it. When I walked by and the front door wasn't overflowing with hungry San Franciscans I knew it was now or never. I ordered a Carne Asada Super Burrito. "Do you mind waiting 20 minutes?" she asks. What? For a burrito?! But they are supposed to be good... "Uhm, OK..." So I walked around the corner to my house and waited patiently for the 20 minutes to pass then went back, waited five minutes more, and headed home. I tried a chip on the way (the best tell tale sign of a good burrito spot!) and... god damn it. Fresh, crunchy, delicious. I get home and open up the fancy little salsa tub... oh no! It's delicious too. I intrepidly peel back the foil and take a bite of the burrito, and my worst fears are realized: hot, flavorful, juicy steak. Wonderfully grilled tortilla... tasty rice and beans. Its good... its really good. 

I don't think the attitude or ridiculously long wait time was excusable, but these people have a hot commodity on their hands and everybody wants some. I noticed a lot of people had called in their orders and didn't have to wait at all, which would be perfect for, oh I dunno, someone whos back door is about 40 yards away from Papalote? I'll be back. God damn it... I'll be back...
author: Jeff S.

description: This is one of the best spots to get Mexican food in the city.  All of the ingredients are as fresh as can be.  The only complaint i have about this spot is that they don't wrap your burritos in foil unless you tell them to.  It is difficult eating a burrito with a fork and knife.  Being a burrito specialist, i tend to be critical about these things.  The salsa is bomb too, don't forget to try some!
author: Lalo G.

description: I love the veggie burrito. The salsa is as great as everyone says. The service is great. Everything is always fresh.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
eh. maybe i ordered the wrong thing. i got a black bean burrito, "poco arroz," with cheese and guac. it was very beany, and very light on the guac. 

when my friend was up getting more water, i snuck a bite of his carne asada burrito (i'm a pseudo-vegetarian, shhh). it was average, too. 

i used to like papalote but i forgot why...
author: jean w.

description: The burritos are SO good, fresh, the salsa GREAT! and THE SAUCE IS THE BEST..... I RATED #1
author: P R.

description: I saw this place on the Food Network (along with 50 million other people) so i decided to check it out. A friend and I split the $20 (Yikes!) Triple Threat Burrito. The place is small but the line was not too long. The wait for the burrito was very long, though. When it came It was a little smaller than I thought it would be for a $20 burrito, but it was enough. The 3-threat is shrimp, chicken and beef. All burritos come with chips and their special hot sauce (which is good and hot!). I have to say that the burrito was pretty good. The beef was probably the best beef I have ever had in a burrito. If I went back I'd probably just get a super beef burrito for about ten bucks and be very happy. Worth checking out if only for the super yummy beef and the high quality ingredients. Gourmet meets burritos. Check it out.
author: Richard H.

description: Least authentic burrito in the Mission, but oh so good.  Vegetarian mole, soyrizo, and the famous Papalote salsa.
author: kellan e.

description: Living a 1/2 block from Papalote is dangerous, very dangerous. I've got my intake down to about twice a week.  My regulars are the soyrizo burrito and the tofu mole burrito.  It's awesome to finally have a good Mexican restaurant with some veggie food other than the ole "vegetarian burrito".  And of course, the salsa is amazing. It's like velvet.  The only downsides are (1) the soyrizo is super salty and makes me really freakin thirsty (2) they charge $1 for extra chips (3) $.50 for extra salsa (4) the long lines (5) the front door doesn't close and its always freezing.  But other than that !!!  its pretty amazing.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I don't understand the rave reviews. The roasted tomato salsa was good, although the 50 cent charge for extra was not appreciated. My soyrizo egg burrito and bf's carne asada burrito was just okay. Expensive for the mediocrity. We won't be back.
author: Presto G.

description:
There's something really off about this place for me. Maybe it's the soyrizo burrito on the menu, or maybe it's because the people who rave about it are usually vegetarians or hipsters. Those are two groups you generally can't trust in regards to good Mexican food. And yeah, I know, I know I'm not first generation, Lily, but I'm fairly certain that authentic Mexican food does not include shrimp sauteed in white wine and butter. And where do they get off charging three dollars for a plain taco? Maybe I'm being harsh because I think seafood tacos are a waste of time and stomach space, but white wine? Oh, and they have tofu on the menu. I like tofu as much as the next gal, but man... And I've only seen the place packed with white people, the kind with dreads or people who look like they just got out of yoga class.
Ok, so here's where I give credit; the salsa was good. It was nice and spicy. The chile verde pork was very tender. There was Yucatan hot sauce, which is always a plus. And there was spiced up jicama served as the side, which was deliciously refreshing.
Basically, overrated white washed Mexican food, which is fine as long as you know what you're in for.
author: Daniella C.

description:
I visited San Francisco to run the marathon in August.  A friend from Phoenix had recommended that I swing by Papalote to get some assuredly delicious vegan mole.  I ended up going here twice, and forgoing some of the other places that were recommended to me.  In other words, the food was so good that I skipped out on seeing some places that I may not ever get a chance to see again.

The first time I went, I got a veggie potato burro thing with soyrizo.  This was amazing.  Period.  Super delicious.

The second time, I had the vegan mole burro with a side of guacamole.  The burro was great (I liked the veggie burro with soyrizo more though), but the guacamole was kind of lame.  I mean, it wasn't bad, but it didn't taste freshly prepared.

So, the food was delicious, but the store itself sucks.  It was packed out the door both times we went, preventing any possibility of actually sitting down to eat.  The first time we went, it was like 3pm on a Saturday, and the second time was abour 1pm on a Monday.  Weird times to be so completely busy.  It was really loud as well, and I could barely hear the server girl who was very frustrating to work with anyways.  She was just sort of rude, and kept turning around and joking with the grill guys while I was trying to order, then gave me attitude when I corrected her inaccurate record of my order.  I don't know, it just added stress to something that should be delicious and stress free (mexican food).  Oh, also, the bathroom is sort of gross, and they keep all of their produce in the common area where a thousand dirty hipsters assuredly wipe their gross hands all over my delicious cucumbers and tomatoes.  It HAS to be against some sort of health code to store produce in the area where people stand in line to order.  Right?  

So, four stars because the food was excellent.  Would have been five if the girl wasn't such a biatch, or if the place was like one square foot larger.

Go here, but get take out.
author: Nathan M.

description: So, I was in town for a wedding and was on the hunt for the best burrito in the city. My host has lived in the area for years, and he said, Papalote, hands down. We went right around closing time, but they were happy to serve us. My friends kept pushing the soyrizo burrito, but I wanted MEAT, real meat. I got the pork verde burrito. It was pretty awesome. Salsa was great.
author: Suzanne P.

description: Best burritos in the mission.  This place is always busy and always has a line.  The salsa is the best. I get the shrimp burrito with wine sauce so good.
author: kristi g.

description: I used to eat here in my lazier days once almost every day. Chicken quesadilla and some amazing strawberry juice. That was my regular meal for the time I lived around the corner. Since moving to another area I now only have tacos when ever I make it up that way. I have never been let down here especially with the sauce they serve. Also, I picked up a great reggae mix here once possibly related to the triple threat affiliation they have. Still loyal to the Coyotes though:)
author: David H.

description:
do i really need to explain? 

they have a burrito named after world famous dj's... 

raekwon, cee-lo, and countless others have eaten there... the GOD's probably eating there now....
author: brian l.

description: I give Papalote 3.5 stars because it's the Chipotle of SF. Doesn't feel as authentic as other places in the Mission. But I will give them props for their fish burrito which was soaked in buttery goodness. I could have cared less for the mole burrito, but only because I don't really like my burrito to taste like chocolate. The fish burrito was almost $10 so it's not cheap. I would only go back if I were hungry and needed something to eat. But I will say the salsa and chips is amazing - wish I could take a big jar of it home. Never tasted anything like it.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Whoa, wait. I haven't reviewed Papalote? Oh man. It's been awhile but this place sure is tasty. It's a lot cleaner than a lot of the Mexican taqueria's in the Mission with organic veggies and meat to make you feel good. A buritto with black refried beans is so worth trying and the roasted tomato salsa is totally unique and a nice change from your average tortilla chip appetizer. The space is pretty funky as well and makes for a great dinner spot on a Sunday. Man, too bad I'm so lazy and don't hike down here near enough...
author: Michael E.

description: Never disappointed, yummy chips and salsa. If you're not a vegetarian, you should still try the quesadilla with carrots and potatos. Jeezus!
author: Kim G.

description: Yummy vegetarian tacos, even if you're not vegetarian. Fresh is the key word here, but the real star is their salsa! It's creamy, spicy and all around tasty. It really wowed me. The people watching went along well with the music being played in the background.
author: Farah S.

description: The grilled veggie tacos where delicious. I had never had grilled eggplant and zucchini in a taco before, but I will be coming back here for more! They also put cheese, sour cream, and guacamole on it if you'd like. It was so good, I can't wait to try other things on the menu. The wait for a table and food was pretty long, but it was cinco de mayo, so it was probably abnormally long. I have a feeling this place is generally pretty busy, and for good reason.
author: Julie F.

description: Best taco joint for vegans in the city in my opinion: the tofu and soyrizo options are fantastic.  Avoid Papalote during the time when everyone gets off work, the queue can get very long.
author: Olivia G.

description: DELISH! The burittos here are deceivingly filling. They seem small, but they are great. The best thing about papalote though is the salsa. IT'S ADDICTIVE! Despite being pretty spicy, you just can't stop! And each batch is different, so one day you may get something that is so hot you're sweating the next not so bad.  Overall, I fancy this place, hands down!
author: Douglas L.

description: this is no ordinary taqueria. SUPER amazing chips and salsa (not your typical chunky salsa, though i love that too), veggy options, and I love their fish tacos, mushroom quesadilla, and steak or shrimp burritos. my mouth is watering just thinking about it.
author: beth l.

description: I can drink buckets of their salsa.  Everything here is awesome.  Nuff said.
author: Christina L.

description: Papalote is a great taqueria for vegetarians and healthful eaters! You can order burritos, quesadillas, and tacos with grilled veggies or tofu.  I ordered the super veggie burritos which comes with potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots.  I thought putting potatoes in a burrito was unusual until I tried it.  There veggies are not bland at all! There was some serious garlic action in their veggies!  You also get free chips and salsa.  There salsa is super tasty too.
author: reena p.

description: Papalote tricks you into thinking that it is not as good as it is, because the food is so simply prepared.  However, after returning after being away for a few months, and ordering a plate of the tacos de pollo and a side of black beans, you just have to give praise to simple food done to perfection!
author: Nicholas E.

description:
I've always considered the burrito to be the perfect culinary invention: every food group delightfully wrapped in a tight, nutritional envelope. And even though Burritos and Tacos and Quesadillas don't really showcase the true sophistication of Mexican cuisine, sometimes you just want that massive hunk of goodness in your belly. That's why Papalote offers the best of both worlds: authentic Mexican standards like Chile Verde, Carne Asada, and Chicken Mole; but without the lard, and with veggie friendly options like Tofu and Soyrizo. I've always been a devotee of the Carnitas at La Taqueria on Mission and 25th, but I've only been back once since I discovered Papalote more than a year ago. That's how amazing the Chile Verde is. It's the perfect combination of spicy, simmered, and fresh. And unlike other "healthy" burrito options, like those found at Whole Foods, Papalote doesn't try to foist a dry tortilla sandwich off on you.

n.b. The atmosphere and Chile Verde are better at the Mission location.
author: Lawrence S.

description: thus far, my favorite burrito place in the city (maybe even the world!!). i had it  in february 2008 and it was amazing.. went back a few days ago and it was still amazing. i got the carne asada super burrito... it came loaded with avocado and the best flank steak ever! that salsa is amazing too! two beers, two super burritos, and chips and salsa came out to $23.
author: Kimberly S.

description: They make a five star mole, even when combined with grilled and marinated tofu. This sounded suspicioud but tasted surprisingly good. These guys also make a stellar salsa, hot and spicy, but so different from anything else I've tried. Minus one star for the veggie tacos which had no toppings save the vegetables. Later saw that the menu said we could add the sour cream and guac if we wanted. But you woulda thought the cashier would have mentioned this to us when we ordered? Will be back to try these again, and the nachos as well. But still not completely sold.
author: Purnima M.

description: I am here 2 to 3 times a week since it's right near my house. Miguel, the owner, is hilarious and sarcastic and really takes care of his customers. I've seen him shopping for the restaurant at Rainbow ... they use all organic ingredients and "No Microwaves!" as he likes to point out. It's getting more and more popular so hopefully they'll one day open another one so the lines can be shorter!  yay.
author: hafsa m.

description: I love the crispiness of the tortilla around my burrito!!  The chips and salsa is SOOOO good that I have a hard time not getting full off of it before my burrito even gets here.  But even still, I'd finish my burrito until I have to stand up so my stomach can expand some more.  Free water is a plus, walking distance from USF is a plus, fast and great service is a plus.  Only minus are the chairs. Not quite comfy.
author: Chrisy C.

description: Love their chile verde! Especially on the tacos--make it a super. Chicken mole is pretty good, though prone to "off" nights. Oh and get the chips with guacamole--ooohwhee. They've got freshness on lockdown yo.
author: Genevieve R.

description: Eat here when in the Mission during a rainy day. Like on a Monday, or a Saturday, or a Thursday. Any day is good here.
author: Sprout S.

description: Papalote so nice they gotta do it twice!  LOVE this location though Fulton is nice as well, depends on your mood really...same great food, two different spots!!  I absolutely adore the Chicken burritos, the quesadillas, and omg the MOLE!!  The owners are FANTABULOUS!!  So nice and friendly, Im blessed to have found such great food and friends!!
author: Keagan M.

description:
First, the salsa is legit, no lie.

Second, its burritos and tacos, expectations are not that its going to change my life.  But all and all, they were very good.  

Third, tacos are street food.  Its hard to dress it up and still give it the same rating.  But I will visit again.
author: James S.

description: Only is San Francisco can you go out and find a grilled tofu taco and have it be totally fantastic! I am a serious meat eater so when I looked at the menu I didn't even consider the tofu taco until one of my best friends told me how great it was so I decided to give it a whirl. It was fabulous, I honestly couldn't believe how good it was. They have a great selection of vegetarian meals which leave you feeling happy and healthy. I definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for vegetarian Mexican, its the best of its kind.
author: Sugey G.

description: Healthy and delcious taqueria food.  I could bathe in their salsa.  I've only ordered the chicken dishes, but it is succulent and tender.  The only sorta sucky thing is that tables are hard to come by sometimes, and the tables in the back have chairs that are too short.
author: A E.

description: Salas is incredible. Burrito completely fresh and all meats cooked to order. Totally get the hype for this one, would absolutely go back. You can tell that fresh product is really important here, which is not always the case. Also burritos were not gigantic which was also a refreshing change.
author: Tony C.

description:
this is my absolute favorite burrito place in the city. i never thought i'd like tofu in a burrito till i ate here. and, being a vegetarian, it's so nice to know that their isn't secret broth or animal parts in the rice or beans. 

their salsa is delicious. friends have found it slightly salty or spicy, but i would put it on everything if i could. 

i take every visitor to papalote and have never had a complaint. yummy!!!
author: Sam S.

description: I really love the vegetarian tacos at Paplote's.  Those with potatoes and carrots.  They bring an amazing salsa with chips to your table when you order.  The salsa is some of the best in the city.  I feel like I'm a connoisseur of taquerias in San Francisco--living here for the first five years on barely enough cash to pay rent and have a beer once or so a week, I learned to judge good cheap-er Taqueria food.  This place makes that list.
author: Jay S.

description: Great salsa, good mole, not to bad, and even better when you don't feel like cooking... to bad the cashier is sooo sassy! Also a little crowed since bofsf and all the scensters found out about it. And you have to fight with cases of beverages for standing room. Best bet, call in your order.
author: j s.
Nelle A.

description: I just absolutely love this place! Their burritos are so damn good, there are no words that can describe the ecstasy that my mouth goes through when I'm eating one. I started off getting their veggie burritos, which come with carrots, potatoes and mushrooms. I was a little indifferent about the thought of eating a burrito with carrots, but OMG!!! And since I can't give up the delicious seasoning in the soyrizo burrito, I order the soyrizo with all veggies. I get the best of both. And no, I am not a vegetarian by any means... I just don't do meat in my burritos. It's one of my many food oddities. I haven't tried anything else but the burritos, however, I know I don't need to to give them the 5 stars they deserve. They are always friendly and quick with my orders (I order to-go with my co-workers just about every other Sunday) and they always get them right. Their chips aren't greasy, like many other taqueria chips are, and although they don't have chunky salsa, their hot sauce is so delicious and has a great spice to it. They have a different style to how they make their food: Their menu is not as typical as most taquerias. It is very unique and special. Oh, and one more thing....they have refried black beans!
author: Amber Y.

description: I like the burritos better at a few places, but this place has my favorite salsa. I don't know how they make it, but it is awesome. And you can buy a jar of it to take home (and bring the jar back for a refill).
author: Pam D.

description: Papalote is my new favorite Mexican restaurant.  I've been eating there at least once a week for the past few weeks and intend to keep up the routine.  The salsa that they serve with their chips is so amazingly flavorful (and spicy) that I eat it with a spoon after I run out of chips...mmm.  The tacos are good and fresh, although I'm not sure how authentic the food is in general as I never see any Latinos eating there (unlike at other taquerias in the Mission).  Authentic or not, the food is delicious, so I will continue to dine at Papalote until I tire of the food from eating too much of it.
author: Grace W.

description: What I haven't reviewed this spot yet? Is it that I want all that crack they call salsa to myself? And those perfect chips. Or do I not want to share my pleasantly plump and buttery shrimp super burrito with black re-fried beans and all the love inside wrapped in a spinach tortilla perfectly paired with a fresh strawberry fresca? This IS my favorite Mexican taquoria. Everything here is fresh and believe it or not light. Here's a tip... Can't decide between shrimp, beef, or chicken? Try the Triple Threat Burrito. Also there are two choices of how they prepare the shrimp. Shrimp will be sauted in butter, prawns are kinds BBQish. Great service too!
author: sonia m.

description: Best burrito in SF....grilled chicken with black refried beans is the way to go!
author: Lisa D.

description: Decent burritos, but nothing special.  I thought the meat was dry, overcooked, and bland.  The salsa is tasty, but is more reminiscent of something I'd find at Baja Fresh than at a real taqueria.  I suppose this place is good if you're looking for a quality vegetarian burrito... otherwise, head for the more authentic places further down the hill.
author: Andrew E.

description: So DAMN good!  The salsa is incredible and unique.  It's a great place for a quick bite and is vegan/vegetarian friendly, which makes it easy for anyone.  The guacamole is always super fresh and the horchata is perfectly flavored.  I always find a way to incorporate the grilled veggies in my meal in one way or another.
author: Jessica L.

description: Ordered a mole burrito to go, so I can't really comment on the atmosphere of the restaurant, but I found the burrito itself to be quite tasty. The mole had a nice zing to it, and all the flavors came together nicely. Sure, it isn't an "authentic taqueria" in the true sense of the term, but sometimes I'm just a lazy SOB and I don't feel like driving halfway across town for a burrito that is only marginally better than one I could have eaten locally.
author: Chris B.

description: Excellent soyrizo burrito. I'd never had one till today, always opting for the basic rice and beans, instead. I was feeling celebratory since it's Chinese New Year, so I splurged and topped it all off with some guava soda. The salsa was tasty as ever, the burrito piping hot and so delectable. A bit salty however, but that's what the soda is for. The ingredients tasted very fresh, and the burrito was huge. I left very full. I deduct a star because the music in the dining area was just a bit too loud.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
Headed home from work I stopped off here to pick up some take out. Parking was surprisingly easy for the Mission and I quickly found a spot. The menu is very vegetarian friendly, with only two real meat options and a few fish choices to boot. I picked a grilled shrimp burrito for myself and a fish burrito for Abby. We both opted to make them "super" for an extra 99 cents, but my burrito especially had very little guacamole or sour cream (is there ever enough sour cream in a burrito anywhere? Please do tell). Both were super flavorful and had a very acceptable ratio of fillings, the shrimp were all nicely charred and the wine/butter sauce on the fish was pretty solid. The icing on the cake at this place is their roasted tomato salsa. While they don't have a salsa bar this one salsa makes up for it. It's pureed, almost more of a sauce really, and must have some kind of oil in it because it was too good not to have a fat content. We will definitely try this place again (plus they have tall cans of PBR!).

FYI - Try calling ahead if you are in a hurry as the wait is a bit longer than you might expect it too be.
author: Alex D.

description: Back in the day when I worked at Buffalo Exchange I would go here about twice a month. It's a favorite for two reasons- non greasy mex and great vegetarian menu. The soyrizo burrito is awesome! And tofu mole tacos are decent. I recommend the prawn burrito as well from when I was a carnivore. Nacho experiences here vary: I have had burned chips a few times. Also They must put crack in the salsa cuz I crave it baaaddd!! and the guac is good too. Always a line out the door so it helps to call ahead and they have great photography on the walls. Good for family, date, take out, and hangovers.
author: M K.

description: Quick service and great food.  This place got me through a rough December last year.  I love that you can call in your order and pick it up.  This place gets packed so I suggest calling ahead.  The Chile Verde Burrito is the best one in the city.
author: Nick L.

description:
yay!  i'm a fan!
good selection of burritos, tacos, quesadillas, etc.  
and for pretty good prices too!
my friend got the spanish omelet burrito that was huge (took it home to be a second meal) and looked delicious.  i went cheap (~$6) with the chicken quesadilla but it was just what i wanted and so tasty!
had to wait kind of a while for our food (although maybe that's a little tainted by how hungry i was) and there was an obnoxious trantrum-y child that ruined the atmosphere a little..  but nothing to keep me from coming back.
and i will!
author: Lily B.

description:
Like a lemming, i joined the masses checking out Papalote after their Throwdown win over Bobby Flay.  And I will say it more than lived up to the hype.

I ordered the triple threat burrito made famous on the show and a side of guacamole.  Hold up, $20 for a burrito!  This better be an amazing burrito especially since every other burrito on the menu is only $8 or so!  Needless to say, I was not disappointed.  A large delicious burrito filled with carne asada, chicken and shrimp arrived along with a side of hauntingly smoky yet perfectly spicy salsa.  The salsa is the perfect complement to the wonderfully grilled and marinated contents of the burrito.  Having three types of meat inside means each bite is a sublime combination of flavors and textures.  My only quibble is that a few pieces of the shrimp were noticeably saltier than the rest of the meats - though it wasn't inedible by any means.

And for those concerned about portion sizes, this was one of the biggest burrito's I've eaten in a long time.  Unless you're Adam Richman, this should be plenty of food for anyone.

Separately, the guacamole is good - though I wish it had a bit more of a kick and the fish tacos are also very tasty.  The fish is perfectly cooked and not dry like you typically find in fish tacos.
author: Jason M.

description:
I'd heard all the reviews and finally decided to try it for myself. 

I'm in love with Papalote!

 From the first delicious bite to the last. The salsa is amazing. Some kind of (tomato creamy) wonderful. Don't let my weird description deter you! It's good. And a delicious nutritious super veggie for under 5 bucks! With vegan refried beans! I'm going back tonight.  

To be fair, seating can be scarce. :/
author: Kiren K.

description: This restaurant reminds me so much of La Vic in San Jose.  OK their special sauce isn't as good as La Vic's infamous "orange sauce" but it's probably the closest thing you can find in SF.  Every order comes with a small cup of special sauce and tortilla chips which are so good as well.  The sauce is great with chips and over the burrito.  It was spicy but not overpowering to me.  I was also happy with the selection on the menu.  They have items that you don't normally find in a mexican restaurant in SF.  I had MOLE burrito (chicken) and while the chicken was a little dry, the creaminess of refried black beans made up for the dryness.  I also tried a burrito with marinated chicken breast --- grilled to order.  It was so juicy.  I highly recommend any SF locals and tourists to check out this place!  It won't disappoint.
author: Jessica N.

description: Best salsa *ever*! Killer fish tacos! Tastiest refried black beans (I still can't believe they're vegan)! You just can't lose with this place.
author: Donna A.

description:
on the house fire roasted thick sausy salsa with a kick.

***the super vegetarian nachos fall close second***
author: diana m.

description: They have awesome burritos and seriously addictive salsa. People come in there for the salsa alone, and their burritos are out-of-control good. Their popularity continues to swell and several months ago they decided to make a separate line for folks who are just picking up to go orders. This was a good idea as the line is literally out the door most evenings. Now they have one person who takes the walk in folks and another person who takes phone orders and rings up the to-go folks in the 2nd line. While they are still incredibly busy, nothing hits the spot like a Papalote's burrito!
author: kristen v.

description: The salsa and the grilled chicken are my favorites. It gets incredibly crowded after yoga tree lets out in the evening. Also I live dangerously close which has led suspicious bulging in key areas of my body, and I'm not saying a boner. Well maybe.
author: Jesse S.

description: Please remember to count your change; I was short changed $10 when it wasn't even busy. Food was okay.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: Went there for the first time today, and I'm sure I'll be back!  Good prices, and lots of vegan options.  On the downside: I think they put waaay too much soyrizo in my burrito -it has a really strong flavor and can easily overpower the veggies/beans/salsa/tortilla/etc.  Next time I go I'm going to ask them to keep the soyrizo to a minimum and put in more beans/other veggies.  I really like that salsa too, and fresh tortilla chip service, damn good! = )
author: Michael C.

description: I've eaten here about once a week for lunch since it opened.  They'd get 5 stars if all they served was the carne asada super burrito and their salsa.  Everything else is in the three to four stars range.  And they aren't greasy like most of the other gut-bomb factories in the Mission.  So if you're nursing a wicked hangover and all you can think of is grease to settle your stomach, you should probably go somewhere else.  Or you should just quit being a baby and work on bringing up your tolerance level.  I believe we're called "functional alcoholics".
author: mcmalaprop ..

description: The BEST salsa ever!  Yum!  The food here is great, in part because they use such fresh ingredients.  I used to live right up the street from here and couldn't help but stop in for dinner at least once a week.
author: Justin S.

description: Best dang burrito I've had in San Francisco... and I don't like burritos.
author: Lisa M.

description: Love the salsa and the always friendly service. Lots of vegetarian options. A neighborhood staple.
author: Scout S.

description: What do they put into that salsa of theirs?  I have never tasted it but it is SO good!  Their grilled fish tacos are my favorite.  It's a bit more then your typical tacqueria, but the quality is great.  The only drawback is they will charge you additional $.50 for their salsa for an eeny amount.
author: Jaemi S.

description: I love me the chapotole with chips and the chicken mole burrito. This is by far the best burrito/gourmet mexican food in the city.  Seriously. I shit you not.
author: Christopher C.

description: They have great shrimp tacos! Their ingredients taste fresh and yummy. The lines aren't usually TOO bad and there's a clean dining area for you to sit if you choose. They are a little pricey, considering all the other great & cheap Mexican places just a few yards away, but it's pretty damn good, so I'll pay. Oh and their salsa is spicy and delicious.
author: Pet O.

description: Just called to order in advance, ate my veggie burrito and many chips...it was easy, tasty, and I don't feel like I ate a heavy meal.  I did have higher expectations for the veggie burrito based on the reviews but wasn't blown away by it.  I will be back to try more!
author: Debbie Y.

description: i don't care how excited you are that you were on tv, papalote, but a $19 burrito in the mission is unconscionable. i love that you are jaring your amazing salsa but thats about it. your portions have gone down and your prices have gone up. thats just lame.
author: Lily S.

description: The best Mexican food in San Francisco. Period.  Their salsa is the best I've ever tasted. The prawn tacos are the absolute best. I could eat them everyday.  The decor is great although they could use a little more room. It's always crowded so get there when they open.
author: Molly W.

description: I live around the corner, so eat here at least once a week (and have also watched it evolve).  Agree with the salsa and fish taco assessment.  Did you know you can get all the different flavor flour tortillas with tacos too?  Plus they're bigger than the corn ones!  Another favorite is the shrimp quesadilla with sauteed mushrooms.  Best time to eat here is during lunch or weekend dinner - much calmer and better service too.  A testament to how fresh it is:  I walk by in the mornings and see crates of vegetables delivered that day, with the tireless employees chopping them well before they're open.  Hats off to Miguel, Victor and team!
author: Esther K.

description: Papalote is very good for certain things... the salsa being one of them. I do, however believe that it has gotten increasingly hotter over the last few years and therefore isn't as good to my taste. I too read the article in Chow and have been making that version of the salsa for years and actually prefer it. Nevertheless, I always get the shrimp (super) tacos and my husband always gets the chile verde tacos and those keep us perfectly satisfied, though the service can be somewhat cold. I don't care for the decor or the crowded atmosphere so we usually get it to go.
author: Terry M.

description: I thought the carne asada burrito was yum-my! Price was a bit pricey for the burrito and chicken tacos, I think it was about $13....a bit expensive for mexican take out....but i'd saw worth the price. the house salsa has a kick to it, but very good too!
author: Allison A.

description: A vegetarian's dream. I cant stop thinking about the SOYRIZO! My favorite place for mexican. Not authentic...but I am still in love.
author: Rosie M.

description: Went there for the first time with a coworker the other week. The food was quite yummy and the meats are much tastier than most of the other places I usually eat at. El Taco Loco just lost a star. The guac is pretty decent, but I think I make a better one! Overall, tasty. Food does take a bit longer than other places, but it's worth it.
author: Hans H.

description: I heart papalote! I used to live right around the corner and would dine on the fish tacos regularly. Their salsa is out of control good! And the sell it separately. Great gift. It's hard to stray from the fish tacos, but I also enjoy the steak entree. Lots of good memories.
author: Roxanne L.

description:
My favorite burrito ever. Hands down. Me and my girl come here about once a week, and it never lets us down. Its a great stand by, always on point and close by. Tofu burritos all day. Salsa is amazing as well, sometimes its really spicey but soo good. 
Gotta admit it is alittle pricey, but quality is worth it for sure. Would rather spend the extra few bucks on food i know is safe, and hasnt been sitting in a bin all day. Or whatever else goes on in a gross kitchen. Plus the tofu is organic, and its always good to know the beans are vegan etc. No thanks on the lard packed pinto beans. Lines arent too bad, look worse than they actually are. Always good Art hanging up, and some reggae is always bumping in there. Good vibes for sure.
author: John H.

description: Great place for snacking on shrimp tacos...
author: Jackie G.

description: The burritos definitely redeemed this place.  We had to wait forever after we ordered to get our food, but they give you free chips and salsa to tidy you over while you wait.  The salsa was a bit spicy for me but I'm not the best with spicy food.  The burrito was grubbing.  Not all sloppy either.  It's one that you can actually pick up and eat.  Certainly a good place, but I will most likely call ahead next time to avoid the wait.
author: Brian L.

description: There are so many good taquerias in the Mission. Unless you are a vegan, there's really no reason to wait 20 minutes for a taco. The food is good, not great.
author: Randi A.

description: what? bobby flay's burrito must have really sucked for this burrito to have beat it on food network's throwdown challenge. the carne asada meat was so tough and hard to chew. the chicken was dry. the shrimp was the only decent part of the burrito. beans were good too, but when are they not? the extra guacamole seemed non-existent under all the other ingredients, yet the flavors left me wanting... so i doused the burrito in hot sauce... not what i expected from all the hype.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: I've had better burritos from here, but this one, a regular tofu burrito, was super dry and the black beans didn't seem quite cooked. Ick!
author: Esther L.

description:
1st stop on my day of eating in the mission...

tasty tasty tacos! 2 per order. the corn tortillas are big for... well corn tortillas.  the carne asada is large, hearty chunks of steak and you won't regret super-ing it.

the salsa is so good, calling it salsa doesn't do it justice. 

my new favorite taco place. and it doesn't make me feel too unhealthy though it's drowned in sour cream, guac, and cheese.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
OK update, the last time I was here the place was really clean. The food wasn't great, it was okay, so I upped the joint a star. One of my burrito eating pleasures is the "roach", the last couple of bites, or often one huge bite that has all the lovely trickled down essence with a fair amount of tortilla softened and flavored by the lovely essence. The burritos here don't seem to have that. They offer a doughy unflavorful last bite, and that just leaves me kind of disappointed. End of update until the next time I venture in. 

Yeah, so what's all the chatter? This place is dirty and the food is okay, meaning it tastes good enough but there are issues. Like, why do they not have a tortilla steamer? (I'm guessing they throw it on the flat top to heat it up, thus the greasiness..and judging from the dirt sticking to the stainless above the grill, not a lot of cleaning goes on here). So all these publications, web writers, and other folks with now dubious taste say this place is"the place". Very wrong y'all, in my microbiologist/artist/burrito fanatic opinion. 
Have I ever met a burrito I won't eat? Well, apparently not yet. As I sat waiting for my food I had ample time to ponder this question as I played amateur health inspector. The waiting for yo' food chairs are next to the reach in (as opposed to walk in) reefer so you can see how dirty the food storage is. Then the eye is drawn to the hood, caked in grease immobilized dirt. I was beginning to think I should split, but, hey a burrito awaited me, a hyped burrito, so I decided to just get over it and "take the burrito". 
So it was okay, just. Kind of pasty. Tortilla was what? Grilled? Not good. Mediocre with bad cleanliness means I will be walking the extra block and a half from the basketball court to La Corneta. Delicous, clean, and has one of the crankiest looking burritistas in the city. Dang, I love the cranky ones, as long as food is good.
author: James T.

description: Really good fish tacos, and the most stylish taqueria interior. I love the blue floor and red wall combination, though, you might want to wear sunglasses if you are sporting a hangover.
author: Stellah D.

description: This salsa saved my life.  Really.  Mexican food is the best for that morning after, and this it top of the line.  The food is not quite spicy, though, and that cost a star.
author: Adam R.

description:
the food's tasty but if i'm craving taqueria food, somehow it doesn't really satisfy me..  maybe it's the lack of manteca in their beans or something.
if you're veggie, they have veggie food for you...
small dining area if you want to eat at the  place, but it's pretty full of young kids who don't seem to take showers often...
author: charlotte s.

description: Two random people I met on the N line recommended this place (hey, the N might be good for something after all). The carne asada quesadilla is amazing. The wait took FOREVER, but to be fair there were about a bazillion orders before mine. Chips and salsa were good. I might venture out to the Mission more often, now that I've been exposed to some decent Mexican food.
author: Liz L.

description: No carnita's? WTF? I was full don't get me wrong, but it left something to be desired in my tastebuds. It might have been because I had to choose a runner up burrito with the lack of carnitas. Went with the chile verde instead. not the same and not very tasty. I don't care if what I wanted was bad for me ... it's tasty badness.
author: Greg G.

description: If you want a marinated tofu burrito with fruit salsa on a Fiestaware plate to go with your all natural Izze soda, then this is the place for you!
author: Amy E.

description: I knew coming in here  that this wouldn't be a typical mission taqueria and it definitely wouldn't come close to san diego taquerias.   My pork chile verde was tangy and yummy but the best part was the jicama side salad was the bomb... i wanted to take a bowl home with me!   I believe it only comes with the entrees, so i would definitely recommend all you burrito and taco eaters to order it on the side and try it out.
author: Erick A.

description: Please Mr. E, spend more time at Papalote.  I'm sorry to say the experience, service and food has really gone downhill in the past year or so.  It is still extremely busy there, which is great for you, but I know how much pride you take in the place, and the folks taking the orders need a little help.  They are really overwhelmed with the volume, and are not very happy or friendly with the customers.  Plus, we all just miss your smiling face there.
author: Cami B.

description: The best part about this place is their salsa.  The salsa is both sweet and spicy at the time.  The tacos are good but a little too healthy tasting (bland) for me.  If you like doing the healthy thing or are a vegetarian, you'll like this place a lot but if you're looking to have a delicious greasy burrito, pack on a few pounds, and schedule in a nice nap afterwards, I would recommend looking elsewhere.
author: Josh K.

description: this is worse Mexican food then I got at the Houston airport on my layover to Miami,. Not only is the food way overpriced and sub par at best, but you have to deal with a cluster fuck of scrambling yuppies attempting to scrap up a table, not to mention the sweaty line you have to wait in to order. After  shelling out a hefty $14.50 for a shrimp quesadilla with rice and beans on the side, I was expecting a solid meal. I got the opposite, the quesadilla looked like an apple turnover, upon further inspection contained 4 shrimp? the rice and beans were portioned for an infant, and the "platter" itself represented nothing of a platter. the side of jicama and tomato salad I had mistaken as a garnish and the teaspoon of sour cream was only useful for adding some flavor to the beans.. which by the way cost $1.75 EACH rice AND beans totaling $ 3.50!.. oh and the waiter there wouldn't let us get another round of salsa.. 1.00 extra!  I'm not sure how this place gets away charging airport prices and serving Uno Mas quality Mexican food only 2 blocks away from Mission st, but next time I will stick to a place like Taqueria Cancun, get fresh authentic Mexican fare for half the price.. this place should check it out and take some notes....
author: Derek S.

description: Definitely not as authentic as most San Francisco Taqueria's but they do cook your meat or tofu to order. The super Nachos are yummy and you can't go wrong with the smokey chicken. The Carne Asada is hit or miss depending on the day. Sometimes they screw up orders and sometimes there's a long wait but overall nice people, great crowded atmosphere. If you want authentic SF slab experience head down one more block to Mission St. and hit up El Farlito or El Taco Loco.
author: Jeff C.

description: I didn't think that the food was that great.  It's clean and bright and the serivice is just fine.  I just fail to understand how there could be lines out the door of this place. Perhaps because it is veggie friendly?  Maybe I should have ordered something vegetarian?  MD and I each ordered a quesadilla.  MD got the prawn, I got the chicken mole.  The outstanding factor of our meal was how salty everything was.  Even the supposedly amazing red salsa was extra salty, and not all that spicy. There are so many other great (less crowded, cheaper) Mexican places in that 'hood that I see no reason to give Papalote a second chance.
author: Miss Information X.

description:
I would come here strictly for the salsa, but, the burritos are also super delicious! 
I can't pin down exactly what makes the salsa so addictive, but we've definitely bought mason jars of stuff to bring back to san diego. 
the menu offers a great range of options, such as tofu and soyrizo, as well as quality ingredients. also, try the refried black beans!
author: Lauren K.

description: oh how I love thee...  If you are one of the burrito as boat anchor people, this probably isn't your spot.  But if you value freshness and quality, this place is a must.  And then there is the salsa,
author: Eagan I.

description: I heard this place was gnarly and its just eh. Its not the best and the chick that takes you order didn't give a crump that I was in there. She was rude as crud. Its okay mexican food at best. But the salsa super good. Now days when I go in I normal just get a cold glass of their salsa and just sip it or if I'm in a rush I'll beer bong it. I'm pretty sure they have chilled beer bong for you there.
author: Mike L.

description: Awesome burrito's, no question.  Some of the best salse in the city.
author: Zachariah B.

description:
OK. So it's really crowded at peak times.  And it's annoying they now charge for extra salsa.  But frankly, the salsa is worth it.  And it's fairly expensive. But it is SO GOOD that I rarely remember the annoying things about the place.

I suggest you go there somewhat off hours.  And complain about how they charge extra for salsa.  And then just enjoy the food.

Because this is a fresh-mex gourmet taqueria. I hear the owner comes from a long line of bay-area restaurateurs so he knows how to create a good establishment.

Did I mention how deliciously original this taqueria is? Sure, it's the same tacos, burritos and quesadillas that 100 other places have on their menus in SF, but it's done so nicely.  You don't feel like you got a gut bomb after eating here.  The beans are delicious, the salsa incredible, the fish and prawns so so so tasty.

Man. I wish I went there today instead of letting my friends drag me to El Metate (which is OK but not great, but usually costs a couple bucks less).

I'll have to try their new location. I never see the owner/founder at the original location any more.
author: Rusty H.

description: After listening to my son as he watched the Bobby Flay Throwdown episode with Papalote he kept saying OMG mom you have to get me one of those!!!! Those he was talking about was a triple threat burrito with Carne Asada, Grilled Shrimp and Grilled chicken and then all the condiments of a burrito beans, rice etc.. OH and of course the secret sauce...Now mind you I had been to papalote's before and like their burritos they are good not too heavy  ebough to get you through the day and don't leave that depressed feeling after. I ordered by phone and by the time I got there the place was PACKED I couldn't find parking, but then again anywhere you go in the mission is a rubik's cube trying to find parking. I finally get  parking and my order which was simple because they have an area for phone pick ups... as the girl starts to ring me up I start to pull out a $20 I figured 2 burritos and all the hype this place has gotten... I was thrown back when she rang up $31. I asked how much each burrito costed my grilled chicken burrito costed  around $7 and change then she said the Triple Threat costed $ 19.95???????????? I could not believe it I ended up just takin it home could not think of my son not eating his burrito ahaha I thought for that price it HAS to be good and it HAS to have ton of SHRIMP and HUGE when I got home pulled it out and my burrito was small and his was big compared to mine I took a bite and thought ehh it's ok.... my son enjoyed it in the end I asked how many shrimp he said I counted 3...3 shrimp ??? For 3 SHRIMP they charged $20???? They have gone mad then I thought about t and realized I had been bamboozled NEVER again sad to say but this place is OVERRATED OVERPRICED... So what Bobby Flay did a show on this joint I should have known when I saw the episode the only latinos in the show was the 2 owners the crowd was not LATINO? AND it took place at the Mission Cultural Center in the Mission there were no native mission ppl BAMBOOZLED I tell you never again I will stick to El Zocalo, El Farolito and pay $30 for 2 ppl including drinks and maybe even a quesadilla suiza... this place needs to lower their prices didn't they get the memo RECESSION?
author: Ines F.

description: Yummy buritos that are great and vegetarian friendly.  however, the wait for the food to be ready can be really long- we waited ~20m for a single burrito.  They do bring chips with a spicy chipotle salsa that help pass the time, but it can take a while.  if it were a bit quicker, i would definitely give it 5 stars.
author: Jeff A.

description:
attention vegetarians & vegans: love burritos but tired of only getting rice, beans, & salsa?

attention hipsters: looking for a fusion of east & west mission?

enter: papalote. many many choices, many many vegan (tho you can add dairy, and there are some meats too), all freakishly funky. sweet mole tofu? grilled eggplant? fill your stomach as eclectically as you fill your wardrobe. 

natural & made from scratch. very nice pricing. & don't forget to enjoy the kites on the ceiling. wee!
author: Jade P.

description:
unimpressed.  flew into town from DC area and was told that i HAD TO HAVE a burrito in the mission area ... um.. I'm sorry, i was not impressed.

Now, the Nachos that someone else got looked really good.  But i've never met a plate of nachos i didnt like.

The burrito i had was just a ton of tortilla, beans and minimal chicken.

I even got the "super" side of cheese, guac and sour cream on the side.  thats what made it palatable.

Maybe others are better.. but this wasn't that special.

Sorry, not trying to hate!
not that cheap either.
author: Cyrus S.

description: My wife and I LOVE this place. We won't eat burritos anywhere else. 'Super' Chicken mole and grilled veggie burritos (pinto beans and spinach tortillas) to-go are our staple, and the salsa is to die for. The wonderful thing is that puppies aren't 80% rice and beans, so it's taste heaven. We live on the other side of the Mission, while there are many places closer than Papalote's, in 4 years we haven't yet found a replacement...
author: B V.

description: This is ridiculous - we ordered 2 triple threat burritos and the total was $45!!!! The price used to be $14.95 for the triple threat and now it's marked up just because of Bobby Flay. The wait was 30 minutes from ordering to getting your food too, plus the wait to get into the place. Not enough space in there to wait so you have to wait in the cold. Not recommended!
author: I. K.

description: One of the better burrito spots, some good veggie options. Going with a friend who can't eat a whole burrito, get the nachos and 1 burrito to share. The creamy salsa is fantastic.
author: annie s.

description: This is some of the best Mexican food that I've had. Everything tastes fresh, the sauces are great, and the portions are sizable. My only complaints are that the wait can be long (but that's easily remedied by calling in advance) and the prices are a little high for basic Mexican food (especially given the plethora of choices in the Mission). Nonetheless, definitely some good stuff.
author: Carter F.

description:
sorry to the papalote faithful out there, but i was pretty underwhelmed/disappointed.  we went to the fulton/masonic location.  super crowded but we ordered right away (plain quesadilla, triple threat burrito, guacamole, & chicken tacos).  I know that's alot of food, but we're a family of three and we shared everything.  $50 for dinner...seems a little much, especially since the triple threat was $20.  got a table fairly quick but we were then trapped there by all the people waiting for pickup.  Got our food after about 20 minutes.  It was good, but not great.  the triple threat burrito was again good, but not $20 good.  Plus it was missing the prawns/shrimp.  would have gotten up to complain but one i couldn't get up (again was trapped by everyone waiting) and two i didn't really want to wait another 20 minutes for a new burrito.

if we were in the area, might stop in and try the nachos...they did look good!  but all in all won't go out of my way for this one.  I'll stick with our close to home favorites:)
author: Theresa S.

description: I get the regular asada burrito every time. I love the salsa for the chips. It's spicy and tasty.
author: Diego V.

description: Amazing super veggie burrito. Amazing salsa. My favorite burrito in SF. This is a special place.
author: Dan M.

description: Granted I have not explored the city to its fullest...but my vote is #1 for this place! I love, did I say LOVE, their food. Fresh, flavorful, not greasy and relatively fast! I've frequented a couple other places that are supposed to be the best Mexican in the Mission but I was sadly led astray, this place is my favorite thus far. I can't say I've tried the vegetarian dishes but my carne asada super burrito always hits the spot. Yes you have to pay an extra .50 for extra salsa but when you are talking about a $6 burrito why complain.
author: Nikki W.

description: If you want quick, no frills Mexican food, this is the place to go! Tasty food, tasty salsa and a pretty good selection of bottled beers (love the Racer 5)!
author: Art D.

description: A healthy and Americanized, but still delicious, provider of yummy Mexican food. They have a variety of unique burritos, with fish, prawns, and grilled veggies among those offered. Their salsa is different (where is the brown tint from? beans?) but really yummy. A little expensive, but worth it.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: In order to not repeat what everyone else has already mentioned about their salsa, just believe the hype. It's that good. I am giving Papalote a three star rating based on the quality of their food but stay away from the Fulton St. location as it is nowhere near as good as the one here in the Mission. Having said this, I have been back on a few occasions and think Papalote is average at best. Their prices are high, the tortillas just don't taste authentic to me, and with Farrolito just a few minutes away, not worth battling the insane crowds that gather here.
author: Kenny G.

description: I was looking for a good burrito place with more variety and thanks to Yelp - I found one!  Papalote has the best menu for vegetarians and vegans that I have ever seen.  I'm neither and I really enjoyed their Soyrizzo burrito.  Their guacamole and salsa is the best I've ever had at a taqueria.  I'm definitely going back.
author: Cyan C.

description: This was my local regular burrito place for 6 months or so, and I really wanted to like it, but somehow I never was totally blown away. The Carne asada is fine but a little bland. The fish tacos are good though. Gets pretty jammed at times, it always makes me feel a little harried. I wish they wouldn't leave all those drinks pallettes blocking the doorway. There is never anywhere to stand while you are waiting for your food. If you live nearby it is best to call in your order and avoid the lines.
author: Stuart J.

description: The first few times I went here I really loved it.  In fact, it became a weekly regular thing with me and the then SO.  It was good different and not of the usual Mission vibe.  But then on subsequent visits at least one friend would have "stomach issues" after (unrelated to spiciness) and it killed it for me.
author: darla s.

description: I was really turned on by their large selection of vegetarian items, but turned off once I tasted them.  However, they do get 3 stars for having the most kick ass salsa I have ever had.
author: Paul W.

description: The salsa, chips, tacos, burritos, beer, bottled soda, art, and especially the owner.  Can't go wrong dining here.
author: Tracy A.

description: I got ya' hipster burito right here. If my pal Big E didn't love this place, it would get less stars. It's not your 'destination burrito', but they do make some lovely salsas.
author: Rene D.

description: Definitely one of my top 3 favorite burrito joints.  I enjoy the vegetarian options (tofu, soyrizo, mixed veggies) and I do find myself craving their salsa.  I've also tried their steak and chicken options and I'm subtracting a star for just a little something missing....not sure what it is....but I find their food lacks that extra flavor that makes it "out of this world."   And the fact that they cheap you on the salsa.  A shot-glass of salsa for multiple people and a $1 for a refill does NOT suffice.
author: Kerry D.

description:
yum, papalote!
eating here just confirms what i already knew: even burrito places that are considered so-so in san francisco beat the pants off of anything in boston!
there are a TON of veg options here, which obviously i can appreciate. the chips are like perfect too. 
thankfully i don't live in SF otherwise i would gain 21389012389012 burrito-related pounds.
author: Laura A.

description:
pretty bad experience. the only reason why it gets even 2 stars is b/c the guys outside were really cool and the food was ok.  note that i didn't say that the food was amazing.

it started with going in to find that they make you get up if you dont have a number in the seating area.  not a big deal but the girl was rude and could've just told us and let us sit anyway since it wasn't completely packed. now the price of the food: not worth it.  i was debating going to my alltime favorite joint (farolito) or trying this place.  papalote's is twice as much and not as good nor as big as the burritos at farolito.  true, it's a nicer looking place, but meh.  

here's the worst: it took about 30 mins to get our food after ordering.  i get my food faster at fine dining establishments. this place is a take out joint.  why does it take 30 mins?  i get that the meat is freshly made or whatever, but it was a bit ridiculous. i will not return.
author: shar d.

description: The best fish tacos ever!  Sauteed, not fried, vegan black beans.  Smoky salsa will entice you to easily down two baskets of chips.   Mmmm.
author: Amme P.

description: Super fresh casual Mexican food. Order from the counter and hope there's a table available.
author: Philip M.

description: Good. Fresh. Fast. Organic. I will say no more. Oh yeah - except this: don't drive here because you will never find parking. But you already know that, you live in San Francisco.
author: Anika K.

description:
welllll.... Papalote had come so highly recommended and so pumped up by Yelpers that me and my girl were fucking dying to eat it... and this shit is not all it's cracked up to be.

(-) No salsa bar. this is a crime in the Mission. and then they have the balls to charge you for another little tiny shot glass if you need more (they give you ONE tiny serving for two people with two meals and your chips). it's fucking good salsa, but being cheap with it is wack as hell.

(-) fuck up your order. make SURE you specify that you don't want the fucking "super" burrito when you only want the "regular". and i don't really know how to do this cuz when you specifically say "i would like the REGULAR" and they say "okay" and then still give you the super, you may have to make it yourself to get the regular.

(-) refried beans are black beans. look, i'm from the southwest. we rock PINTO beans. pinto beans taste better to us. if you are from southern mexico or central america, you go black. two different worlds. i don't want refried black beans dude.

(-) tofu mole is crap. not that it is inedible, but it is so fucking plain. the tofu seems like cubed tofu straight outta the box dumped into a vat of the sauce. and they give you way too much of this stuff. mole is too rich to eat a serving this big.. it makes you sick afterwards. this dish (which costs $10 by the way) needs a better combination of sides. perhaps some calabacitas, more jicama salad, some greens and maybe some fruit. 

(-) limited agua frescas. straight up: i need limonada available every fucking day.

(-) "please wait to be seated" in a burrito shop? puh-lease.

there are some good things too:
(+) vegan friendly.
(+) chips are top notch.

overall, i wouldn't complain if friends wanted to eat here and i was out-voted (i'd just stick to nachos or tacos), but otherwise i think i'm avoiding this modern bogosity.
author: Clarence B.

description: Everyone talks about the salsa, and it was indeed awesome.  But I have to stay, the carne asada in my burrito was absolutely sublime.  Maybe I hit them on a particularly good day, I dunno.  But I'm used to burrito joints having dry, marginally flavorless steak - Papalote's was juicy and flavorful and way more than just a vehicle for protein.  Yum.  Another visit is indicated for further research, clearly.
author: Jess L.

description: Fantastically overrated. Fresh, but bland and boring mexican food.  They do make a mean salsa, but by itself, it can't make up for the otherwise uninspired fare.  And why only one dollar-sign?  I just dropped $14 for a chicken burrito and one beer!
author: Aaron C.

description: I came to frequent Papalote because it was the only serviceable burrito in the entire Noe Valley area.  Their burritos are solid, though they only use black beans (I'm a pinto bean guy, myself) and charge you extra for cheese (not cool).  Their salsa is easily one of the tastiest I've been able to find.  It's not spicy, though, so if you're into the burning tongue thing, it's best to look elsewhere.  If you love it, you can buy it by the jar, just be sure to bring back your old jar for a discount off your next refill.
author: Aldo K.

description: youtube "the lonely island - jizz in my pants" if you want to know how i feel about their chicken burritos
author: Paran Y.

description: Yum.  I got a shrimp burrito  on a spinach tortilla.  Decent price and big burrito....very yum!  An added bonus is the fact that they have bottled coke.  mmm.....yummy!  My husband got the carne asada burrito which wasn't as good as the shrimp.
author: Wendy V.

description: I would say 2.5. Like many others, I saw this on Food Network and decided to go give it a try. I don't know if I went on an off day but it seriously did not live up to the hype I had built up in my mind about how amazing this burrito experience was going to be. I ordered the Triple Threat, mind you...a $20+ burrito...yes I agreed to pay this much because I believed it was going to be phenomenal. I've had $5 burritos that blew my mind, this $20+ one did not. Seriously disappointed. It was all meat, mind you, which wouldn't be a bad thing, except there was nothing in it to make it spectacular. A good burrito to me has a balance between the meat, cheese, salsa, rice, and beans. This was mainly just a tortilla of meat. the chicken was probably the best of the three types of meat in it. The carne asada, again, nothing to write home about, and the shrimp, totally lacking and overcooked, didn't taste very good at all, I picked them all out and set them aside.  I did enjoy the salsa that everyone is boasting about but the chips weren't great and that's half the experience when you're eating salsa. Overall, I don't think I'd go back. Bummer, I had such high hopes.
author: Jnzl D.

description: Salsa was really good. Had the shrimp burrito and managed to finish it! Really, really tasty. We ate around 6:45 on a Thursday night and didn't have to wait. The meal definitely hit the spot.
author: Lily Y.

description: A great Mexican joint and neighborhood hang-out.  I almost always go for the chicken mole burrito - it has just the right balance of heat and sweetness. Their roasted salsa is the best I have had anywhere.  Super-friendly owners, super-fresh ingredients, and rotating installations by local artists.
author: Tyler N.

description: I've eaten a lot of mexican food in this city, and I usually give places the benefit of the doubt. But I was really, really sick after eating here. Granted, it was only one time, but I don't think I'll be taking my chances again. Usually I'll eat myself sick, but this wasn't the same kind of thing... you get it.
author: Veronica B.

description: Oh yes .... tasty carne asada and service was quick too. Nice clean small space.
author: Teddy d.

description: Papalote is so devine!  The transfusion of soy products into mexican food is amazing.  The refried black beans are among the tastiest things in the world.  I even can stand the full feeling after scorfing down an entire burrito and a plate of their nachos.  Papalote rocks the house!
author: S. K.

description: My first visit was uninspiring, but a second visit changed my mind. Healthy for a tacqueria, if you can believe it.
author: Blaine C.

description: This place is a special treat, the veggie burrito is the best and the salsa is fantastic!
author: John W.

description: In this paradise of Mexican food establishments, Papalote still draws crowds every night for its veggie/vegan options and generally healthier menu. For delicious fattening burritos, I'll head down the block to El Farolito, but for my average weeknight the tofu or grilled veggie burrito is essential. Also - try phoning ahead for to-go orders, there's a shortage of standing-around room.
author: Emily B.

description: The sun-dried tomato salsa they make is fantastic. The steak and prawn burrito will go down as one of my favorite burritos in the history of me eating burritos. They've also got a great selection of beverages.
author: Kevin L.

description: I really needed this last night. My stomach was so mad at me and I wanted a yummy, filling burrito. Well, it was delicious and the salsa was incredible. A little spicy for me but still, incredible. I think I filled myself off the chips and salsa before I got to the burrito :) Good prices, fast and easy and tastes good...couldn't really ask for more.
author: shadi m.

description:
Looked forward to the advertised "flaky" tortilla -- which it was not. Ordered Prawn burrito which had waaaayyy too much garlic-but not enough prawns -that I couldn't taste anything else in the burrito.  Btw, size of burrito is smaller than other places. 

Chips are not memorable. Salsa was good. Thought it stingy when another customer asked for chips refill and was given a response of, "$1" (for a small bowl!!!).  Is it true they buy the chips hence the fee? With all the hype, in real life, it was a let down. Would rather go to Taqueria Cancun or Pancho Villa. 

p.s. yes, I agree with the lack of "energy" staff members had -- or didn't have. And also agree that I was additionally put off with the bathroom.
author: Chuck T.

description: Too expensive for what you get. The burrito was dry and the meat was too salty. You can do way better in the Mission!
author: R M.

description: I love this place!  Great chicken quesadilla and awesome burritos!  The prices are reasonable, the service is great and always comes with a smile, the chips and salsa are amazing, and the food is so fresh!  I love this place and of course I'll be back!
author: Jo M.

description: I use to live right next to Papalotes and come 2+ times per week. What I love is that you can get delicious soyrizo tacos with amazing vegan salsa for cheap. While I agree that some of their dishes are "drier" than other neighboring spots, in my opinion it's because this is one of few places that doesn't coat your food in sloppy sour cream and too much cheese. I love this place!
author: Sara W.

description:
fresh!!

chicken plate is breast, but not so flavorful

is it really organic???  I'm not so sure...

mole is good.

people are friendly ish   ( the non mission locale)  

the burritos do no seem so flavorful.. but i like them anyway  its ALL ABOUT THE SALSA
author: Nicholas C.

description:
Be advised: if you get take-out from Papalote's you should bring a gameboy or a newspaper or something because even if you call in advance you will still have to wait, guaranteed.

If you see a guy there playing Nintendo, that's me, and I will laugh at you as you wait twenty minutes with the boxes of tomatoes and the windy-swinging door as your only friends. I am playing Metroid Pinball, probably enjoying a gunship multiball round or something, and my food can take as long as it needs to. In fact, if you want to tell them to put your order ahead of mine, that's cool. I see you're getting a bit twitchy. It's my fault for taking the only perch space I suppose.

Just don't rush them - see, the thing is, I secretly suspect it's not a good idea to irritate these folks. Ever hung out on this block on Sunday nights? Creepiest thing - there's this weird buzzing noise comes from out back around nine or ten o'clock. It's the kind of sound you'd hear if they were carving up all the customer who pissed them off with a meatcutter. Maybe that's the secret ingredient that keeps winning them Best Burrito readers awards.

Anyway, it weirds me out, so I behave very nicely and if it takes half an hour for me to get some chicken mole tacos, that's cool. At least their food actually exists in three dimensions, unlike the invisible burritos they serve down the street at Farolito's. Damn, I hate invisible burritos.
author: Millie S.
