description: Papalote has the best salsa in the city.....  fresh, organic ingredients that's made to order!!  I'm glad they opened up another papalote in my hood!!
author: Dhoris P.

description: I decided to try Papalote's based on the reviews posted here.  If authentic is what you're looking for, skip this place and head down a couple blocks. However, if you're open to tex-mex style vegan-friendly burritos, this place is definitely tasty and inventive.  I enjoyed it greatly from that perspective! Refried beans are a must!
author: Kimberly C.

description: The raison d'etre of Papalote is their Fish Tacos.  Just remember, when you think of Fish Tacos, think of Papalote.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
dear papa,

i like you b.c. you have soy-rizo and i like it in your burritos even tho i eat meat.

love me
author: Erika Y.

description: I honestly wish I could bottle up that salsa and take it home, it is so damn good.  Had the carne asada burrito and the meat was so tender and tasty.  The decor is a bit kitschy but who the hell cares when the food is this good.  La Taq still has my vote for best carnitas but I must come back here a second time to see if they rival La Taq's.
author: Emily C.

description: This place is simply great!  Awesome veggie burritos.  They have a veggie SoyRIZO burrito that is too good for words.  They serve chicken that is grilled to perfection and among the best quality I could have hoped for.  The kicker here is the homemade salsa.  I know you're thinking Salsa?!  But, this is special and you have to try it to know how awesome it is.  They do charge a little more than your normal burrito shack.  But, it is worth every penny.  It is too bad that they do not deliver.  Other than the wait to order this place has no down sides.
author: Matthew T.

description: I tried the marinated soy and soyrizo burritos- both good, neither memorable.  The ingredients are fresh, the service is solid.  It's not your traditional taqueria where they make it in front of you, but it's good nonetheless.  Take your veg friends here...
author: Rohit G.

description: I love this place!  I have to control myself so that I only eat here once a week...YUM.
author: elana e.

description:
I used to walk by this place every day when I went to work and there was just something about it that repelled me from ever eating there.  Well, my sister decided to drag my dad and I there for lunch yesterday and I can't really say it was entirely worth it but it could be worse (like Chipotle, for example).  

The moment we got in, we ordered our food but guess what?  No seating.   I found this a little frustrating and sort of an unusual situation, since most taquerias I go to have at least some seating available.  Anyway, we finally got a table and sat down to some *delicious* salsa and chips.  I've never tasted anything like it and enjoyed it immensely.  Of course, I find out after I leave that they sell it behind the counter but oh well.  We finally got our meals.  My dad had the chilaquiles and seemed pretty satisfied about them.  I probably should have ordered that, because my shrimp tacos were shameful.  I got a measly four pieces of shrimp in each taco that I could barely see since it covered in a pile of lettuce and tomato.  I got a salad, basically, hugged inside a folded tortilla.  I grew up with TACOS: loaded with meat, dripping with pico de gallo and salsa.  These weren't tacos, not to me, at least.  

I am still not convinced this place is worth all the hullabaloo, but you never know.  I might have to make a second trip.  For now, I wish we had gone to La Santaneca or El Farolito instead.
author: Christine S.

description: All I can say is I love the Soyrizo burrito $5.15.  My GF and I usually split it.  + their salsa is the bomb.  My only wish is that it'd come with 2 salsas instead of one.  Also the service tends to suck.
author: Julie V.

description: This is the place to go when you want a good, healthy burrito, and still want to be able to walk with all pants buttons in place afterwards.  Great salsa for sure!  Yummy veggie options.
author: Leah P.

description:
(The following paragraph has nothing to do with "El Papalote," but I've decided to included it for  "context," as this seems to be a custom on Yelp.)  I recently moved to the city but I'm pretty sure I have already figured out a few prerequisites to being one of the cool kids.  I've bought two pairs of tight pants, I'm looking for a hip (preferably ethnic) girlfriend, and I'm seeking to buy a vintage, multi-geared road bike.   Of course, I know a nondescript mountain bike would do me just fine, and a single speed would definitely be better, but I'm hoping for some kind of balance between style and city-bike practicality.  

So last night I was in the Mission to pick up a cheap bike I'd found on Craigslist, on my way to La Taqueria for a quick bite, when I noticed a crowd of people stuffed into a humble Mexican restaurant called "El Papalote."  

Despite my previous plans and a lingering nausea I thought might be the stomach flu, I decided to trust the mob's judgement, step inside and order a fish burrito.  This was the best  San Francisco burrito decision I've ever made.  These guys have figured out a secret that few of the city's other burrito-makers have discovered: if you prepare the food to-order, it actually tastes better.  The cooks pan fried the fish, slapped my tortilla on the flat top, and assembled the whole thing right behind the counter, resulting in a piping hot, delicious burrito.  The ingredients tasted quality, and the prices were reasonable.  The chips tasted fresh, and the salsa, different, but good.  On top of that, the staff was super friendly despite the crowd and I noticed they had quite a drink (beer, bottled soda, aguas frescas) selection.  Other notes: dinner entrees available, 99 cent for "super" burrito, and decent indoor seating.  Best Burrito I've had in the city so far.
author: Charles C.

description: Yes, it's true about the salsa.  Quite delicious.  My four-year-old date very much enjoyed the yellow dragon hovering above our table.  I liked the grilled veggie burrito, for what it was... but it really wasn't "burrito-y" enough for me.  I don't really know what that means, but there you have it.    Good, clean atmosphere.
author: Tovah S.

description: Gotta give this place 5 stars for the awesome Marinated tofu burrito!! Yummy!! The hubby got the nachos and quesadia (sp?) and those were good as well. THe thing i liked the most is that the plates were not drenched with grease like some of the other mexican restaurants i have been to, esp. on the quesadia plate.  The nachos were good, not too much cheese, not too little just enough... good food, will definitely come back!!
author: Shelley N.

description:
So...I crave the marinated tofu burrito on a regular basis
The grilled vegetable burrito is crazy good-
But that freaking marinated tofu is just incredible
The chips are awesome and the salsa totally lives up to the hype
(oh and 50 cents for extra salsa is so not a big deal)
My husband works down the street from this location
And when I see him come home with that brown paper bag full o burrito and chips and salsa
I get a huge smile on my face 
 I'm not sure what this says about me 
(well, I guess I do know what it says but whatever- shove it!)
But when I returned from a trip to Austin last week-
 I was happy to find that instead of flowers...I was greeted with a familiar brown bag full chips and salsa and a marinated tofu burrito (tastes good even reheated!) 
such a nice welcome home
Soooooooooo goooooooood
  (oh and apparently the meat choices are also super awesome...tasty enough that the boy will gladly wait in line on a regular basis to bring home takeout)
author: Maxine M.

description: Excellent! Not authentic but very creative and fresh. Very good vegetarian options.
author: Emily A.

description: Papalote is my local burrito joint. It's healthier than your average Mexican joint and offers soyrizo, tofu, and fish and shrimp options in addition to the more pedestrain (but no less tasty) carne asada and chicken options. It's really great -- and the salsa is to die for - it's spicy and creamy and complex -- I get it in the large mason jars that they offer and lug it home along with my super burrito of choice. The only complaint I have is that the chips are not overly flavorful and are oftentimes overfried. I'm alson not a big fan of the guacamole - it's not chunky enough and isn't really "avocado-y" enough for me.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This is the best mexican place I've found. The side dishes are huge and the food is great.
author: Dina M.

description: After watching Bobby Flay lose to the owners of this restaurant in a throwdown, my wife and I plus two friends drove 35 miles from the East Bay to have lunch.   Although the service was friendly and timely, we were disappointed with their specialty  "Triple Threat Burrito".  The meat and shrimp were cooked dry and tasteless, and the item had no salsa or sauce to make it juicy or to give it some semblance of flavor.  We have tried a half dozen of the Mexican Restaurants in the Mission, and Papalote failed to impress (or even satisfy) us in any way.  We would suggest "Picante" in Berkeley as a better substitute.
author: Carl B.

description: I'm so NOT a vegetarian; but I'm  addicted to their soyrizo burritos.! Their food is really  filling but doesn't give you that comatose, must-lie-down-and-do -nothing -but -digest feeling that other burrito places do. Yes, the service can be slow- they are not spooning it up from a steam table! We always call ahead- I think they know our number now; the food is always ready. I think I need to buy their salsa by the jar...
author: Linda F.

description: Food here is generally good. Its no El Farolito but its the only place that has actually made a burrito with "vegetables" in it eatable. The only thing that sucked about my last experience here was that I ordered "extras" (guacomole and mole i think were $1 each) and the portions were WEAK. Whoever made these burritos was hella stingy and when the extras are a dollar that is f$cked up.
author: Matt B.

description: It's really good and healthy, but lately the tortillas for the tacos are falling apart as you eat them, so if I could give this 3 and a half stars, I would. In the past, the tacos were SO GOOD with the delicious lettuce and super tasty and not too spicy salsa. Nachos are delish as well. Burritos are good too. If you have a strong stomach you should try the soyrizo burrito, it's pretty good. I have foresaken that one, gave me gas. Their prawn tacos used to be two big prawns but now it's little shrimps...they should really bring back the prawns, they are so damn good. Also 2 tacos for under $5 is a pretty good deal considering how gentrified Valencia Street has become.
author: Gina R.

description: Okay.  Came back for their nachos and tacos and now I wish I had not written that other stellar review.  Their nachos were NOT very good.  They were bland and the chicken tasted dry.  I got the carne asada tacos and felt that it could have used some seasoning and maybe an extra corn tortilla underneath so that it wouldn't get all soppy when I had to squeeze lime on it to give it flavor.  I will probably be back to try more things, but yea, I wouldn't order the nachos ever again.
author: Trinh N.

description: Excellent food - emphasis on fresh wholesome ingredients.  It's the Ton Kiang / PF Chang's of Mexican food.  I tend to order the fish burrito and my wife loves their corn quesadillas.  Despite a busy kitchen, everything is cooked to order which means it takes longer than your average taqueria where the meat is prepared ahead of time and food is served within a minute.  We tend to phone in an order, add 10-20 more minutes than what they say, and then pick up the food to eat at home.  Everything is so delicious! Oh and their chips & salsa are amazing!
author: Michael S.

description: Delicious free chip & Salsa, The burrito was pretty good, but lacking carne asada. I expected more from the burrito for it to be considered a front runner in the Mission.
author: J. M.

description: This place takes the cake. Best Mexican food in SF. So fresh, cheap, AMAZING.
author: Clementine J.

description: This is the best burrito you will ever eat.  Meat (or tofu) grilled to order and the salsa is this whipped and almost creamy concoction of pure heaven.  There's also great beer on tap and the atmosphere is funky with rotating artwork and of course, kites.
author: Ellen O.

description: Had the Prawn burrito. The prawns tasted like they had been left in oil all day and never rinsed. The taste of oil was overwhelming! Not good. I had a bite of my wife's burrito pescado, and it was decent, but nothing to rave about. Asked for extra salsa (the salsa was good), and even though they only gave us one tiny cup for two people, another cost us 50 cents. Not good. No horchata, no melon drink. Not good. Overall, Papalote costs more on a pretension for being a high quality "mexican grill" when in reality it's just a so-so taqueria dressed up in bright colors.
author: Scott M.

description: Really good salsa but the food was a little disappointing.  I agree with another yelper and don't know what to do when my burrito isn't wrapped.  I'm not the "have your burrito with a knife and fork" kind a girl.  Seems a little hyped.
author: Dana C.

description: I *kinda* like this place, but not enough to justify how often I eat here. I know, weird, right? still, it's usually pretty good, the salsa is amazingly addictive, and it's close enough to my house that I just end up there... over, and over, and over... I think I need an intervention.
author: Jeremy H.

description: Soyrizzo! OH MY! This is the first place I had this fine fakey meat and Im addicted. It is super delicious and decently priced. They also have super yummie salsa that you can buy by the jar and take home with you.
author: Misty D.

description: One word: Soyrizo. The burritos here are amazing, which is hard to find being a vegetrian. Get the Soyrizo burrito with the whole wheat tortilla and make sure to ask for extra of that orange looking salsa they give you with your chips-- so good!
author: Ashe M.

description: This place has the best salsa of all taquerias in the city that I've been to.  Fresh ingredients and tons of vegetarian options.  It's dangerous this place is so close....
author: Anne B.

description: Not the cheapest or most authentic place, but excellent.  Not as good as all the hipsters standing in lines out the door would lead one to believe.  The nouveau hot salsa is amazing:  they'll put it on your orders if you ask, and you'll want to get extra for your table too as you only get a small cup of it with your chips.  They sell it in mason jars to go for $6.
author: Adam Z.

description:
i am not the first nor the last(according to yelp the 329th) for this location alone. 
just have to add my favorite parts

soyrizo
the same guy who is there no matter what time of day who buses the tables
bohemia

oh yeah and the food never disappoints or gives me burrito gut like so many of the straight up taquerias.

also pickled jalapeno's
author: Chris G.

description: This place is a tale of two cities.  I worked up the street for a while and I have certainly pledged my burrito allegiance to farolito....but I read about the awesome and award winning salsa y chips at this place so I thought I would give them a shot....The salsa is mind blowing!  and the chips are really f'ingood!  but the carne asada super burrito I ordered was damn good, but not up to the farolito level of excellence that I had grown accustomed to....Still a killer Taqueria in the mission....oh yeahhhhhhhhhh kool aid man!
author: Francis K.

description: This place is not about burritos sorry. This place is about I want to have lunch on Sunday morning maybe with a book maybe with a newspaper, maybe with my couple, maybe with the couple. Here's the thing, this place is about sitting and eating with a certain calm and comfort it is not about a burrito experience, food is just medium. This is why the only Latin Americans you'll find here are the waiters, no Latin Americans customers.
author: Alex A.

description:
yummo. a haven for vegetarians [who aren't afraid of the gluten!] soyrizo everything, tofu everything, papas everything. it all is delicious and well priced! the salsa [which comes to you while you wait with a side of chips] is absolutely amazing; spicy, smooth, orange. in a neighborhood where the norm is meat, meat, meat and mystery lipids and fried beans, this is a healthy, refreshing alternative. good in or to-go.

busy all the time and waiting room is at a premium, so I say order ahead!
author: Rachel W.

description:
i came back to s.f. for three weeks over the holidays, and the entire time, la taqueria was closed. heartbroken without my usual joint, i wandered the city and racked up a significant number of half eaten burritos.

that was until my friend, browski, also in from out of town shared with me his jar of papalote's salsa. he was taking it back to hawaii with him, and its one thing he looks forward to on his trips to the main land. he explained it as "blended fire-roasted peppers", and though not chunky, it had a good balance and weight on our chips.

went the next day and ordered a couple tacos; chips and the famous salsa came free to the table. back in the day when i had first tried papalote's, i didn't remember it making a lasting impression on me. this time i got a mission cafe vibe - quirky setting, hip people, reggae in the background, lap tops and books about. its not the mexican dive i'm used to, but can appreciate it all the same. the tacos were unconventional - fresh ingredients overstuffed into one large tortilla. i'll admit, right now, back in los angeles, i miss that salsa. i should've taken the lead from my friend and taken a jar back myself.
author: Alexia P.

description: One of the best vegetarian burritos I've ever had! Everything was delicious. The salsa kicked ass too.
author: Zach C.

description: Love the Grilled Veggie Burrito. Papalote's phone number is in my address book for a reason.
author: Kristen Y.

description:
not too sure if this place is as cracked up as people say it is. BUT i think i didn't order the right things though. it was my first time here on Sunday and my expectations were high - considering all of my friends rave about this place. first of all, i didn't know their burritos came with no cheese. however, that was probably more my fault considering i was a little slow and hungover to really read the fine print and ask any questions. anyways, i ordered the grilled veggie burrito. bad move on my part. the burrito was dry and had no flavour. to fix that problem i ran up to the cash with my mouth full of food and order a side of sour cream and she asks me if i want it for here or to go? i was very confused - considering i JUST ordered food "for here" from her a few minutes ago and i had a mouth full of food , which mean't i was eating inside the restaurant. so anyways, she charges me $2 for a side of sour cream. REALLY? 

so anyways my gf got soyrizo tacos and they were ok, but she actually makes a better one than they do. i enjoyed the "complimentary" side of chips and salsa, but i agree with some other reviewers on here, why are you so stingy on the salsa? if i go back and ask for more, are you gonna charge me $2? the salsa isn't your typical chunky tomato-wee cilantro type - it's more like a tomato-wee creamy kind. not much zip to it, but still good.

anyways, i'm thinking i didn't order the right thing from here because my friends seem to know good food. i'm thinking i need to quit being a pussy and order a burrito with meat in it - most probably carnitas! mmm ...
author: James J.

description: What kind of Mexican restaurant doesn't understand that an order for a breakfast burrito with chorizo and cheese means you do want EGG as well??? Seriously - a chorizo burrito? With super condiments added? DISGUSTING. I don't know why people go there. We got it to go so didn't realize until we were home. NEVER going back to this place. What in the world is all the hype about???
author: Andrea S.

description: Up a star cause I just had the fish burrito.  SO yummy!  Big enough to split.  Love this place.
author: Jessica I.

description: The burritos are great, and the salsa is incredible.  I would have rated it 5 stars.  But seriously, this place is WAY too expensive and WAY too crowded.   Therefore just three stars.
author: shannon a.

description: Try the super veggie with a spinach wrap!!! Best food, and fills you up!
author: Mel D.

description:
the horchata is excellent! chicken mole super burrito is bigger than my head, and it's quite tasty.  the salsa everyone has been raving about is pretty yummy, but it's a little reminiscent of Doritos.

be prepared to wait a while.  it's been crazy busy every time i've gone, and the seating is limited.  if it's a pretty day, take a walk to dolores park and enjoy your head-sized burrito in the sun!
author: Terri J.

description:
Delicious food that keeps us coming back once a week.  Great vegetarian options (grilled veggie burrito is a favorite).  Whole wheat tortillas are really good.  The salsa is one-of-a-kind and irresistible.

We normally phone ahead and give it an extra 5-10 minutes, because there's always a wait.  Recently, we got some salsa that was not even close to the normal stuff.  New cook? Out of ingredients? What gives?  Even still, this is our standby neighborhood restaurant, quite delicious but don't expect authentic Mexican.
author: John B.

description:
The best thing about this place is that it feels really good to be in there. I love Mexican food, but there aren't many Mexican restaurants in the Mission that I enjoy spending any real time in. The restaurant is cute and nicely designed. Its colorful and small, but feels more cozy then crammed. The place is clean and, though it has the elements of other burrito spots around here-- you order at the counter, no servers, small place with a community vibe, it doesn't feel thrown together like other places. Its more of a spot I would go with a date I wanted to impress or didn't know very well, then the place I seek out late night when I want to stuff my face with a group of also drunk friends. 

The food is good but, like a lot of Mexican restaurants, it lacks anything really distinguishing. EXCEPT, the salsa is super good. I feel the urge to repeat that last sentence. I live really close to Papalote and, on the day I moved in, two separate friends brought up the Mexican restaurant near by with the awesome salsa. The shrimp tacos were nice. The shrimp grilled in white wine and garlic. They are plated on a couple of open soft tacos with crunchy lettuce and pico de gallo, and taste very fresh. They were even better when I dumped the salsa all over them. The burritos are fine, Ive tried the carne asada, shrimp and the veggie. That's with pinto beans and guacamole. All were good, but not wet enough for my taste. 

The staff are friendly. I came in with a group of friends the other night, and one of the guys put himself out for a little bit trying to reorganize tables so we could sit. 

The place is pricier than its competitors, but you pay for the package. Or maybe you pay for the salsa (which, on a side note, I'm pretty sure you can buy on its own to carry out).
author: Roger W.

description: My favorite new quickie Mexican place.  Good burritos and amazing salsa.  The quesadilla's could be a bit larger though.
author: Chetan S.

description: This place has great salsa and it shows. It is always winning the award for the best Salsa in SF. Good food. Good ingredients. Good staff. Be sure to also check out Miguel aka Mr.E's parties. He DJ's everywhere in the city.
author: Sal B.

description: I just moved 2 blocks from Papalote, so it's now my official "neighborhood" burrito place.  I have to admit, I'm not thrilled.  I think the food is really pretty good, and I appreciate that they have veggie options.  However, I'm a little put off by the prices.  I think they're on the high side, and they charge you extra for a little tub of salsa.  I mean, come on.  I always grit my teeth when i'm picking up a to-go burrito from there and only get a couple of singles back from my $10 bill.  Since when is a burrito not around $5-6?
author: Ann F.

description: Organic meats and produce coupled with the best salsa in San Francisco.  The wait can be a bore, but ALWAYS well worth it.  One of my favorites for years.
author: Aaron G.

description: Always excellent, inexpensive food, with the best fish tacos.  This is hands down the best in the city.
author: marie m.

description: I can't get enough of the salsa, however, the tomato crisis was like, so last year - stop making us pay for extra!
author: Julia P.

description: Best quality for the price, hands down.  If you really love Pancho Villa or Cancun, you might find this up (or down?) to your usual standards.  I'm vegetarian, so I can't speak to the quality of their meat offerings.  The tofu mole is interesting and quite good, but the fish tacos are a home run every time.  Their guac is excellent, the chips are fresh and hot, they have a good horchata, and enough vegetarian and vegan options to keep things interesting for the food geeks.
author: A B.

description: I've been in SF for nearly two years now, and not one taqueria comes close to my hometown favorites in San Diego.  I understand now that the SF burritos and SD burritos are two different animals, not to be judged on the same scale.  One of the few places you can find me munching on a burrito here is Papalote.  (Almost) always fresh, the best roasted salsa and homemade chips, Prohibition Ale, and vegan-friendly... I can deal with no refried pinto beans, I guess.  This is way better than when I lived in New Hampshire and drove 45 minutes to eat at Taco Bell.  "Mmmm, mexican food!"
author: Mike A.

description: Amazing burritos and salsa.  The nachos and quesadillas are amazing and yummy!  I'm a huge fan.
author: Nick T.

description: A spinach super tofu quesadilla please... no, a spinach super carne asada quesadilla with grilled mushrooms... no, a super tofu burrito on spinach tortilla with no rice, grilled veggies, and a Negra Modelo... no, chicken mole dried tomato quesadilla with grilled veggies on the side and a vitamin water... I can never make up my mind because it's all so good!
author: Kevin D.

description: I can't believe I ate the whole thing...again. Hello burrito belly.
author: Jen S.

description:
This is the place for the best salsa in town! Oh wow, the stuff is excellent. Yeah, that's right you know what I'm talking about ... the red stuff! 

The meat is very high quality and succulent on all acounts. I really like what they do with their mole sauce as well as their variety of tortilla. 

For vegetarians, they have a very hearty veggie burrito that properly utilizes potatoes.
author: Rahul T.

description: I live across the street, so I am ALWAYS HERE! They have the best burritos, and great salsa. Fast and friendly service come with this good food. The place is small, so I usually do take-out.
author: Simmy S.

description:
Papalote- 
The chips are just ok, the salsa is very good. The salsa has a nice flavor, fluidity and color. You can pour it over anything! Oh yeah, it's served in little black containers opposed to the clear Solo cup every other Taqueira uses; it added a little piazzas. We had the Veggie Tacos..... with potato, carrot and mushroom. Very good, I give it 4 out of 5. Nice big corn tortillas filled to the gills with good stuff. Same goes for the Marinated Tofu Tacos....... Absolutely awesome! One of the best tasting achiote paste/sauces I've had in a long time. The Tofu was grilled then sauted with the achiote paste. Excellent blend! I'd go back just for this dish. Tofu gets my best rating of 5 out of 5. These guys set the bar on tofu. Tacos Mole with Chicken.....You can tell they didn't use the achiote paste here, the mole they used was in need of (never thought I'd say this) salt. The chicken was dry and not simmered in the mole to make it moist and yummy. I gave them 2 out of 5. Soyrizo tacos....were pretty good. They tasted like store bought Soyrizo with crispy chopped Romaine, tomato salsa with light onion and cilantro. Actually all the tacos had the same garnishes. I gave them 4 out of 5. Friend had a carne asada burrito.......Good Quality Meat but was tasting burnt. Beans and rice were okay, tortilla was good but a little flaky and tender, nothing to write home about. I gave the burrito 3 out of 5. 
The food was great overall, a little slow but worth the wait. It was an order as you pay type place. I really like the grates they use on their grills opposed the single direction grates everyone else uses. The chicken looks like it was cooked at a western BBQ because of the little square marks it left, really cool!
author: Miguel V.

description:
i had a black bean/JOOCY meat/cheese/sour cream/rice burrito.  yes, i made my own burrito (doesn't have a name on the menu) and yes, i made sure there were absolutely no veggies in it and yes...i gained 5 pounds.  

that tender meat will keep me coming back.
author: Adela K.

description:
i like it... it doesn't necessarily give off that "authentic" mexican food/taqueria vibe... in fact it doesn't at all, but it does serve up some good food. and they are conscious of vegetarian needs. 

i'm not a vegetarian, though, so i ordered the carne asada burrito with black beans. it was enjoyable and the steak was great. their salsa is quite unique. normally, i look for chunks and LOTS of spice in my salsa [i have still yet to find a winning salsa that meets those requirements in this city, if you have any tips, please let me know] and it met neither of these expectations but still managed to get my attention.

i would go back.
author: Kayla K.

description: Mole fried-tofu burrito  and a Speakeasy beer?  Yes please.
author: Jon B.

description:
Good breakfast burritos and you can't go wrong with their Chile Verde entree.  I would like them to have salted tortilla chips but i guess that's a personal preference.  Salsa is great.

I would give them 4 stars but they get an extra one for being right next to my apartment.
author: Casey W.

description:
My favourite Mexican restaurant bar none. A whole other class to every other burrito place in the Mission - fresh fresh vegetables, really great grilled meat, and the best salsa on the planet.

The burritos are excellent, although maybe a little dry if you don't get them made with cheese & sour cream, which I always do... It may be a crime against Mexican cuisine and deeply inauthentic but I LOVE the nachos there, especially with grilled steak. Dear lord I think I may have to go there right now and get some.

Downsides - noisy as hell but what do you expect in a Mexican restaurant that's about the size of your bathroom? It's always busy, but I've always been able to find a table when I needed to. OK, the lines out the door can be a bit of a pain and the kitchen staff seem overstretched, but that's popularity for you...
author: Jacob D.

description:
they have the best tortillas....they are so fresh. 

i love the grilled shrimp super burrito with black beans. it is delicious! and they have amazing hot sauce...one of a kind.
author: Jenny B.

description:
very good.
the food took a little while to come out, but it was well worth the wait. 
ample seating for a mexican place in the mission.
i had the chicken tacos and quesadillas. i would order both again.
author: Eli A.

description:
Do I look like a child? (Don't answer.) I ask because the portions they gave us looked to be about the right size for someone who would shop in the children's department. We can blame my perception of our portion size on America's obsession with food or we can blame it on consumer expectations for a Mexican grill serving burritos in San Francisco's Mission District. Either way, these servings are about the size of what you would feed a baby, not the size of an actual baby (see reviews for Gordito's in Seattle).

Papalote is admittedly decent and admittedly healthier. These truths do not change the fact that our request for additional toppings on our food was not met (so we are unable to confirm that the salsa is to unbelievable as no salsa was included with our food).

Also, still small.
author: Tina V.

description: Chips and salsa are brought to your table after you place your order and take a number at this fresh, organic and altogether amazing Mexican eatery on 24th street. It rivals El Farrolito for quality, location and price but the two destinations are seperate and unique.  El Farrolito is a superb traditional taqueria: you get fresh food made with whole avocados fast and efficiently. Your chips soak through the white paper bag but they are salted and delicious. Papalote is more like a cafe- the prices are slightly higher and the guacamole and sour cream aren't as authentic as EF but with warm chips, table service, and home made salsa you can purchase by the jar this is definately a destination to try. Be prepared to wait to order and to get a table but it goes by fast.
author: Jessica M.

description:
yummy food, servers weren't so nice.  though it could have been from the heat and the crowds or something.  and bugs everywhere.  kept jumping on my leg and in the water.  not sure what type of bugs they were.  one was fried onto a corn chip.  good salsa too.

p.s. i had the prawn burrito.  not many prawns in there, but they were tasty.
author: reza n.

description: Pretty yummy.  One of my favorites in the city.  The salsa is creamy smoky magic.  I would recommend this place to anyone who is looking for a great tasting, consistent, Mexican food experience!  This location can be very crowded, so take it to go!
author: cece S.

description: Nothing special here.  Wait, that's not true...the red wall and the logo are pretty special.  The food is pretty plain.  I wasn't impressed with what I got and I thought the price was a bit high.
author: Meghan B.

description: Papalotes is THE SHIT! Mmmmmm... Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. I would have to say that its a must to eat here! Its healthy, tasty, and like everybody knows... The salsa is deeee-licious!  My favorite thing to order are the Prawn Burritos ( They are so good ). Miguelito, ( El Jefe ) is also one of the sweetest men I know. He's also a fabulous D.J.! You'll be seeing me soon mister... =0) Anywho, before I get off track i wanna end this by saying... Your gonna fall in love with this place if you just try it.
author: Aurita U.

description: Been going to Papalote since 2007 and have yet to go to a burrito joint in SF as good as this one is. I have been challenged by a number of friends to try all sorts of Taquerias, Taco Trucks, and various home style burrito places.That all said, all have fallen short. Since I am mostly vegetarian, I think it all comes down to the greatness of their beans (black beans in particular) that makes the simplicity of the bean and cheese burrito super style unbeatable. I have since gotten my entire office on Papalote as we use the services of TCB courier to deliver to our office on a weekly basis.
author: Manan M.

description: The salsa is to die for as is the chicken tacos and the camerones super burrito.  The ambience is far better than most burrito spots in the Mission and the prices will definately not break the bank.  Best of all, it's easy to do take out.  Simply call in your order, double park and they'll whisk you straight to the front of the line to pick up your food.
author: Suzanne D.

description: Fresh Mexican food, not the greasy late night variety. The burrito of choice por moi, is the chicken mole burrito, the mole is fresh, a tad bit too salty, but perfect with una cerveza. The atmosphere is nice; small lively restaurant with indoor seating. There is usually very cool wall art that changes to feature different local artists. Its location is prime: a block from the 24th st. Mission bart station. You must eat here at least once. I would not say the best taqueria in the mission as there are many different types and styles of taquerias in the Mission, but I will say this place has some of the more healthy cusine for a mexican restaurant.
author: Michael M.

description:
love this place purely because of the fresh produce and quality.
the habenero sauce/salsa is the best.
author: wayne s.

description: I must admit, I've ONLY had the chicken mole burrito here. But Papalote has the best mole I've ever tasted. I ordered it the first time I visited Papalote a few years ago and I haven't ever wanted to try anything new. Also, be sure to get their guacamole and salsa. I normally get extra because they are both so yummy. There can often be a wait if you order in-person, but you can call your order in and it'll be ready when you arrive. Try the mole!
author: Gregory G.

description: Delicious enough to daydream about - the chicken mole and the veggie (potato & mushroom) burritos are highly recommended!
author: J R.

description: Best fresh burrito in the misson, I know you've heard it a millon times but this place is it. Veggie, Meaty, Seafood. It's all good. Lines are long which is weak but it's worth the wait. Fish Tacos and the salsa makes it even better.
author: T S.

description: Ok, ok, people love the  salsa. It is true that the salsa is good. I even bought a jar, but ya gotta have somethng worthy of putting it on. The carne asada burrito was the weakest example of mexican I had seen here outside of the hard shell tacos at the school lunchroom.  They had something on the menu called "soy-rizo" I guess a sub for chorizo? No people from south of the border in this place except behind the counter. Hipster crowd w/ ironic tee-shirt and unique shoes abound....
author: Ross J.

description: Healthy and delicious mexican food.  Quick , friendly service.  Low-key setting.  Reasonably priced.  Try the carne asada tacos.  Yum!
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description: I thank my lucky stars that this slice of heaven is on the walk home from the BART. Who even knew that a "healthy" burrito could taste so good?! Their salsa is the real reason to visit- is it bottled for resale? My recommendation is the Grilled Veggie Burrito with black beans in the spinach tortilla. And I'd have to say that after Bay to Breakers, the second location on Fulton provided exactly the burrito I needed to keep going. Tan delicioso!
author: Ezza S.

description: Taqueria serving fresh Mexican fare made w/ quality ingredients. Meat is grilled to order; no mushy steam table food here. The fish tacos are divine; so is the tofu and mushroom quesadilla. Not a sit and linger spot though, due to high volume of customers and small dining area.
author: Jon R.

description: I was sad when I moved out of the mission because I still crave Papalote's veggie burritos and their wonderful salsa. The lines always long, but it's worth the wait. Yum. I think I have to take the J Church there very soon to get my fix.
author: Katrina F.

description: That salsa they make is like nothing I've ever had before. They make everything fresh to order and the veggies have life and crunch. Yum.
author: Mer S.

description: Papalote manages to be something of a mild hipster joint without completely losing the character of an authentic taqueria. The mole is unique and makes for a delicious burrito [I've only tried the chicken, not the tofu], and the homemade salsa is an especially tasty surprise. Beer on tap and a cozy, clean seating area make it a good dine-in experience, too.
author: Jon W.

description: Hungry? Best Burrito Belly in the Mission sponsored by Papalote. Fresh, tasty, home-made salsa (smokey spicy delicious). FRESH FRESH FRESH and delicious. Not your typical Mission-style burrito somehow . . . BETTER.
author: Emmabelle S.

description:
frreeessssshhhhh. thats the version here. remixed with health conscious ingredients. no LARD. vegan friendly. 

nothing fancy (well except the triple threat burrito of course, chicken, steak and prawn. what!), food with integrity. fresh fresas and horchata made daily.

the salsa. if you know, then i need not go any further.
if you dont, well, thats your fault. 

soyrizo quesadilla with grilled veggies in a tomato tortilla. 
i mean c'mon, can you say that about another burrito joint? 

the staff is friendly, fast, and efficient.

party flyers, community events, and awards plaster the walls and counter, i mean does your burrito joint have a write up in the 
WALL ST JOURNAL? 
didnt think so.

but hey, dont take my word for it. peep game yo.
you wont be sad, unless the grease, lard, and oil is your thing.
author: mark c.

description: Excellent taqueria.  Takes a little while to get your food - not your usual takeout Pancho Villa experience.  But the ingredients all have a unique and delicious flavor.  The marinated chicken is especially good - I'll drive across town (now that I'm no longer local) to get a chicken quesadilla.
author: David G.

description: Man.... I can't believe this many people know about my secret/favorite mexican restaurant!!
author: Dominick S.

description:
Too good to be real !!

First, I begin by eating all the tortillas with the fabulous salsa. Then I torture my super pollo burrito with pinto beans....

Gnaaaaaaa !  *slobbering*

L.
author: Lewis G.

description: The salsa was definately exquisite.  My burrito...so so.  I requested and paid for sour cream but received none.  I may give it another go since I enjoyed the plentiful grilled veggies and black beans.
author: Celeste A.

description: Great place for cheap eats($5-6 bucks + free chips and spicy salsa). I love the quesadillas and the spicy salsa is yum.  I'm not a big fan of burritos but everyone seems to like theirs.  The bathroom has more graffiti on the walls than you can imagine yet somehow the bathroom is usually very clean.  This place is listed as a mission restaurant, but i like to think of it as a noe valley place.
author: Brian D.

description: I really hate to be a downer here, seriously, because I've been looking forward to trying this place.  Finally happened today.  I went for the "super" burrito because why even bother without the soar cream/cheese/guac?  The chicken burrito came with barely 1/4 oz of the extras combined.  I know the chicken is supposed to be fab, but I really prefer the regular taqueria style rather than a pounded out flattened breast.  I had to buy an extra salsa (which lived up to its rad reputation) to pour over the rest of my burrito just to make it interesting.  And 50c for more salsa?  Come on.
author: e w.

description: Wow. Great dining atmosphere, and menu! Not the best burrito place, but definitely the best Mexican place so far.
author: Scott F.

description: I didn't like it at first. Then I found the grilled veggie burrito. black beans. with only guacamole and their awesome (strange) salsa added. my favorite lunch nearby when I forget to pack one for work.
author: Katie R.

description: The food is good tasting and good quality.  Flavor abounds, but this place can get packed to the gills at various times.  I have had more than one mild anxiety attack while waiting to order  It's best to phone in your order.  If I didn't mind waiting multiple minutes in small enclosures with multiple people, then I may just give it 5 fat ones.
author: Alex W.

description: One of my favorite taquerias. Their salsa is amazing, the best I've ever had. I had a veggie burrito, and it was quite interesting. I've never had one with potato and carrot, but it was pretty good.
author: Tariq I.

description: This place is great. Your typical California Mexican burritos and other food BUT their homemade salsa is delicious! I just pour it over everything but it makes everything really good. My husband had the triple threat burrito (which he thought was well worth the $20, yes just on his burrito alone!) and I had the chile verde burrito! Delicious (and much cheaper, about $8). Love it!
author: julie q.

description: My first couple expriences with papalote were not bad. The food luckily is not the worst part. I have never had to endure such awful service and unprofessionalism in my life, and believe me i am well a well seasoned restaurant goer. The restaurant was very near closing but they let us in. The restaurant policy as i know it, as if your in your in. This was unknown to these rude and unprofessional workers, in the middle of ordering i was told abrubtly that they were going to closed. I thought this very rude since i was let in, in the first place. I ordered still feeling remains of distates for one of the employees. But this unforuatly was just the beginning. I took a seat to a few minutes later be given a brown bag with all my food in it lumped together, told that they were closing and i have to leave. At this point i was apalled and even noticed other people still eating in the restaurant. This, in my eyes, is completely unprofessional and violates the policies of proffesional establishments. I was then left to eat out of a brown bag in MY CAR. Still just thinking about it makes me angry. I urge people that there are many others eually or better places than papolote. I would hate for anyone else to have to endure such rude treatment. They obviously have no concern for appropiate treatment of their customers which is a dealbreaker for me. Just so everyone is aware.
author: India R.

description: This place changed my (vegan) mind about burritos!  I wish they would offer the jicama garnish as a salad. I was delighted to see their amazing salsa being sold at Whole Foods.
author: Penny F.

description: The super pollo burrito is absolutely killer! Another cool thing is it's located off Valencia, so you need not delve into Mission St. where parking can suck.
author: Jim M.

description: The salsa at Papalote will knock your socks off!  Yum...  The atmosphere is cheery and cozy, and you can get Orangina with your delicious soyrizo tacos, which is a special combo for a mission taqueria.  The table service is usually very quick and friendly, although the folks at the counter can be a little testy.  One of my favorites.
author: Teresa F.

description:
Nearly every time I come here, I get the same thing--a carne asada super burrito. Invariably, the burrito is so good that it makes me never want to eat any other burrito, and possibly never eat any other food.

The meat here is always cooked perfectly, and clearly starts out as pretty high-grade stuff, and everything in the burrito always tastes fresh--the flavors are all distinguishable from each other, all very good, always well-balanced. Plus they have refried black beans, which automatically earn them an extra star (can I give them 6?)
author: Steven W.

description:
Being a vegetarian, this is certainly my favorite taqueria.  Not a traditional one.  But healthier, tastier, and so many more options.  My only mild complaint is thats its a bit more expensive then other taquerias.

My meat eating friends dig it too.  But if you're looking for a traditional mission taqueria experience, go around the corner to El Farolito.
author: Jeff W.

description:
For some reason the steak always tastes like its burnt and like they've been grilling the meat over a super charred surface. However, I do like that they offer different types of tortillas (wheat, spinach,tomatoe,etc),which definitely helps the diet.

Not the best burrito place in the area,but what gives them an edge is that they offer different types of burritos to satisfy everyones taste buds.
author: fancy-schmancy S.

description: I love that the salsa they serve with chips does not have cilantro in it, which means I can eat it! The sorizo burrito was fantastic, and I'm looking forward to trying more of their abundant vegetarian options.
author: Jessica C.

description: San Francisco's best taqueria.  Now I can't eat burritos anywhere else.
author: E. L.

description: Very Good Burrito. Fresh. I had the grilled chicken burrito. They grill the chicken to order. It takes awhile if you are doing take out, but it is worth the wait. Very good guacamole and hot sauce.
author: Dave P.

description: Over priced and over rated. Totally not worth the $7 or so bucks for a burrito. If you're in the hood what you should do is buy a jar of their salsa, and then walk over to El Farolito, buy one of their yummy burritos, then add the Papalote sauce. Yum!
author: Monica H.

description: I miss living in the neighborhood and having Miguel and Victor greet me every time I had my burritos there. The best and most interesting salsa around which I always buy by the pint for parties. Prices have gone up a bit too much over the years but as a treat (rather than a twice weekly necessity), Papalote is the bomb!
author: Bob S.

description: Very unique mexican food. Pretty good too! Quesadilla with carrots and potatoes in it!
author: Ilana I.

description:
i've been there once & looking forward to going again soon b/c:
-the shrimp tacos are killer. very smokey grilled flavor w/ incredibly GREAT salsa - of the liquified variety - which sounds not that good,- but is like crack.
i can't do 5 stars b/c the lighting is so bad. i don't mind fluorescent even, but the spotlight thing isn't good for my skin. how it looks to others that is.
so i'll do takeout next time.
author: Kim Y.

description: This little hole in the wall gets a 1.25 thumbs up from me. Although Bobby McFlay wasn't able to throw down on this joint or burrito or whatever so maybe a 1.5 instead for it being pretty good but not perfect. The ambiance is very hip and chill, a bit packed but the walls are red and covered in dope art pieces. You order your food at the register and wait to be seated while you're order is being cooked up. My order was half of the triple threat burrito: full serving of tender grilled chicken, full serving of tangy carne asada, four succulent grilled prawns, rice, beans and cheese - made it into a super triple threat and it also included sour cream and guacamole! Sounds pretty hefty, aye? That's why I only had half and I was good for the night. The meat was a little chewy and the rice - dry, but the grilled chicken was juicy and the prawns were flavorful! I could've used a side of fresh salsa but all they offered was a reddish orange hot sauce that kind of reminded me of the orange sauce La Vic's is famous for but sure enough, it didn't taste anything like it. 1.5 thumbs out 2, ain't bad at all.
author: Ai Q.

description: In the past, I did enjoy the huge burritos and special salsa at Papalote.  Then, one unfortunate day, I was eating in and a cockroach crawled down the wall beside me while I was eating.  When I notified the staff, they didn't seem to care.  Needless to say, I couldn't finish eating anything after that.  Still, I gave Papalote a second chance after it appeared on Food Network.  I ordered a prawn burrito and the prawns were bad.  That was the last straw for me with Papalote.  Such a shame :(
author: Stephanie K.

description: i've given this place two chances because so many of the (white) people i know just RAVE about this place (the ones I know have good taste since they also rave about el farolito, a fave of mine) but MAN is this place soooooooooooooo overrated. so so so so so so so so so overrated.  someone please tell me one good thing about this place.  i will not believe you.
author: chris m.

description: Have you ever heard of a mexican place that sells burritos w/ no carnitas on the menu?  Papalote.  I don't even remember what I ordered instead...a chicken burrito maybe.  It was so one dimensional in flavors.  The salsa was AMAZING though, which they sell in mason jars.   I wont be back for their burritos but would be back to purchase a jar of their salsa.
author: LT B.

description: I had to come and see for myself what all the hype was about with this place. It's already been crazy busy way before they were featured in Throwdown. I had heard about their adobo burrito, but I was more curious to see if the Triple Threat lived up to its name. Based on a Bay Area DJ group, this is goodness X3 with the incorporation of carne asada, shrimp, and chicken. Only thing I couldn't believe was the price. It costs under $20. Holy shh..! My friend and I decided to split one, and also ordered some super nachos. That was already plenty, yet they threw in some chips and salsa with our order. I was able to get a bit of everything with each bite. The nachos were awesome as well. We barely got through half of it because of the Triple Threat. Once finished, I washed it all down with a horchata. I can honestly say that theirs is excellent; not watered down and has just the right amount of cinnamon. It was nice to taste a bit of history, but I think I'll try something different, and cheaper, next time.
author: Rhia R.

description: I used to live in San Francisco & I would get food from Papalote often. I have never gone there and had my correct order handed to me. Not once have they gotten it right, and I went there roughly 20+ times. I'm visiting now and my friend & I decided to get take out. We got home and both of our orders were wrong. I was meant to have two tacos and I only received one, and my friend didn't get her chips and guacamole. So I called to complain. The girl I spoke with reluctantly said she would give it to us next time we came in. I called ahead the following day and talked with the manager. She wasn't very nice & kept stating "it's not possible to only get one taco when it comes with two." She also wasn't really answering my questions. But she said she'd get it ready for us and give it to us. We drove back over there and picked it up & got home & my vegan tacos were COVERED in sour cream and cheese!!! I'm only visiting so I have no intention of ever returning. If you like getting your order correct and avoiding the waste of food by having to send it back I suggest going elsewhere. There are so many Mexican food places in SF that are capable of getting order correct and their food is equally as good, if not better. I suggest skipping Papalote unless you want to check your order thoroughly before heading home. But, like I said, they have never gotten my order correct the first time, and more than just this weekend have they gotten it wrong the second. Plus, most of the staff are VERY rude. The food is good, but not good enough to deal with this. As far as their salsa: it has always been gross to me so I never eat it. The location is good. I really wish they'd train the staff to be kind or fire everyone and hire nice people.
author: Marie F.

description: As many have said before, the salsa is crack in liquid form. About  I've tried to replicate it several times, by tweaking the Chow recipe. I never really came close and for all the work I put in, I'd rather bring my empty jar over to Papalote and have them fill it back up for five bucks. I recommend this highly. The only downside if that you have to consume the entire jar in a week or two, before it starts to lose its freshness.
author: Cor D.

description: I went here with my family after reading all the good reviews on yelp. sorry to say, the yelpers have let me down. this place is very popular with an endless supply of customers, but i am baffled to why. my experience was that the food was satisfactory at best. we ordered the pescado burrito, carne asada entree plate, carne asada burrito, chicken nachos and a couple of tacos. the burrito have a toasted flour tortilla that does not hold shape and fell apart all over the plate. the meats were decent with not much flavor. ive had way better at many other places. the fish was not very well seasoned and the beans were bland. too much rice was used as stuffing the burrito so they wouldnt have to complement it with as much meat/fish. the staff was nice but rushed and spread very thin. this place is probably so popular because of its appearance with bobby flays show throwdown and their awards. they probably lean on those credentials and with its high demand dont put out the quality they used to at one point. oh yeah, very expensive for taqueria food, even for san francisco!
author: Toby F.

description: Great food and the phone order service makes it very easy.
author: Stewart D.

description: The food is amazing, I'm not gonna lie, it's really good actually and it's clean! A clean mexican restaurant in the mission! But come on, do the people that work there have to be so rude... they literally hate everyone that buys food there. So if your willing to pay a few extra bucks for a cleaner mexican restaurant with some fresh food and a rude staff, it's totally worth the deliciousness that is the lote.
author: Thomas F.

description: I'm addicted to the chicken mole burrito, which I eat at least twice per week. I know the other items on the menu are good, but I can't tear myself away from my standard.
author: David M.

description: Best homemade salsa and fish tacos in the city in a warm, vibrant, colorful atmosphere.
author: Angela K.

description: Hands down the best salsa in San Francisco!
author: Kim M.

description: Good old Yuppie Burritto, probably one of the most visible indicia of the gentrificiation of the mission - but SO DAMN GOOD.
author: Jen A.

description:
muy muy bueno.
fresh, tasty mexican food, veggie quesadilla, great chips & salsa, very busy at times.
author: Damien J.

description: Papalote is a fine, fresh, authentic, fast (if you call ahead) burrito shop. Very simple review, but that's all you need to know.
author: Joe c.

description:
Papalote is the be-all, end-all of burritos in the Mission.  Fresh?  You bet.  Tasty?  Of course.  Salsa worthy of a pligrimage?  Absolutely.

You cannot go wrong with the plain old rice and bean burrito, but if you can have meat the chicken and carne asada burritos should be your choice.  They also have some other intriguing options like soyrizo, so make sure you schedule multiple visits.

The nachos are mediocre - pass on those.

I hate that they ration the salsa, but it's understandable.  That stuff is truly amazing.
author: Aamir V.

description:
Whoa. I've avoided this place for over a year because any place with so much hype (even by a vegetarian friend who lives next door) has to be crap, right?

Well, finally picked up a chicken burrito supreme here today, and my god it was good! Chicken was seasoned and cooked perfectly. Seemed a little small for $7 bucks, but was filling. First place I've seen with refried BLACK beans. Nice.

Had to kill a star for the guac (seemed like the frozen stuff from Costco) and the chips (far too oil-laden), but overall a mighty tasty and unique burrito. Also - delicious (and skimpy portion) salsa. Will definitely be back for more review research.
author: Zen T.

description:
This is great reasonably priced Mexican food and healthier/ lighter than most taquerias in the Mission.  I love the tofu or chicken mole burrito, and the chicken quesadillas.  
HOWEVER, I have one complaint.  On multiple occasions I have ordered take-out, and my dish has been missing guacamole even though I ordered it.  This is incredibly frustrating since by the time I get home there's no way I am going to walk back to get it.  Other than that, I love this place.
author: Amy M.

description:
I had eaten a most gigantic rice and beans burrito (super-style) before I even knew what was happening... it was that delicioso.  AND they serve you chips and salsa, which is right on in my broke book.

Definitely a great place for veggies and vegans.  Didn't try the vegan delights, but I sure will next time!  

Oh yes, there will be a next time.
author: Elizabeth J.

description: The camarones quesadilla is the only thing I get here because it's so damn good.  As is the salsa you get with the chips.  Can't vouch for the rest, but I'm hooked.
author: rerun w.

description: Not the intensity of my favorite tacos stands or the scrumptiousness of my favorite burrito places. Excellent salsa. Burrito was fresh and the chicken was very "roasted" tasting. I have eaten here a few times and it is always very good, sometimes great.
author: Webber B.

description: Always busy, but always great food and quick too! Burrito's to bar. I love the salsa - quite hot and spicy but just right! Perfect for a quick and cheap, great-tasting dinner in the Mission. I was a weekly (or more often) visitor. I'd say this is definitely a local's favorite spot and rightly so - it's yummy! Just be aware - they close somewhat early (8/9pm - ish) so don't be crushed when you stare inside the dark window and realize your late night shenanigans in the Mission are cut short and burrito-less.
author: Carin B.

description: this place rules, make sure you get extra salsa though because without it you are lost
author: Matthew R.

description:
Way more crowded and way slower that other places with much better food.

If you're getting off the 24th st. Bart, go to El Farolito.  Equally crowded, but much faster with much much much better food
author: Andrew G.

description: I have to confess Papalote has grown on me immensely.  Originally I was deterred by the price, noting that many taquerias in the area served similar products for several dollars less.  But over time I have come to realize that the old adage "you get what you pay for" is ever true with regards to Papalote.  Many of these aforementioned neighboring taquerias serve nothing more than diarrhea wrapped in foil.  The others are by and large nothing to write home about, sans a couple gems.  Most importantly, Papalote's salsa continues to be a crowd pleasing delight that I cannot get enough of.  Although the price tag for extras thereof, and for jars to take home (a must for orders to-go, which are my usual modus operandi) continues to hurt my wallet, I haven't found a more consistently delicious and unique salsa (although for those of you who can still stomach Farolito or Cancun, here's a protip: up the ante by slathering some Papalote salsa on one those suckers, your mouths will thank you).  Because they have no qualms gouging me for this salsa and I'm still a cheap bastard, I can't quite bump this to a five, but the three-star rating I previously gave is far too low.  And for the haters who still prefer the tortilla-ensconced grease bombs available elsewhere, I have only your toilets and stomachs to pity.
author: Alan R.

description: Worth all the hype...authentic burritos and nachos...really loved the food. portions are huge and food is amazing...
author: Vaneet W.

description: The line was long (a good sign?), and the service was friendly.  I was surprised by how much more expensive their burritos were than every other place I have ever been in the mission, but figured they were worth trying.  I sat down and ate some chips and salsa while I waited 15-20 minutes for my food to be prepared.  I was pleasantly surprised by the size of my chicken mole burrito, and it tasted fantastic.  I then asked if I could have some more of the salsa I had eaten with my chips and was told it would be an extra charge.  The food was good, but not good enough to justify the price and extra charge for salsa.  Clearly the owners are trying to milk as much money as possible out of their positive press.  It is too bad, because their food is worth buying again, just not at the current prices.
author: Lucas M.

description: The chicken mole burrito is superb and perfectly (who does mole better?) balanced, especially eaten with lots of the habanero sauce provided on the table. I ate a burrito a day in the mission for 10 years straight ( have approached about 5,000 recently) and have to say that these guys are consistent --which cannot be said about any other taqueria in the city. The salsa which is a blend of two different dried chiles and pumpkin seeds (guessing here) rocks and is only rivaled by Cancun's green (the remarkable landmark in salsa history).
author: chris r.

description: Vegetarian options are stellar here. I don't think I've had anything I didn't like. And the salsa is awesome, a spicy roasted pepper thing I don't dare try to emulate. Everyone I have brought here loves it except those Farolito-obsessed motherfuckers. Grow some tastebuds you guys!
author: Mercedes C.

description:
Oh man. I haven't tried much of the menu because as soon as I got to the Prawn burrito, I stopped right there and haven't moved. Mmmmm perfectly blackened, big ol shrimp, fresh vegetables, great beans etc.

Also, great secret-recipe salsa. Sort of smoky and creamy, their salsa is...
author: Rachelle M.

description: Had dinner with a friend recently. What a value! This place is great, we shared fish tacos and a chicken quesadilla. The tacos were huge, overflowing with fresh veggies and plenty of chunks of fish. The salsa was great, fairly spicy (be forewarned!), the chips were a little greasy for my taste, but obviously freshly fried in house. The crowd was a mixed group of people who clearly know this place has great food at budget prices. I'm definitely going to eat here again.
author: Zephyr A.

description: I eat lunch here about three days a week.  And that's saying something, cause the Mission has a few options.  Best burrito place for people on the veggie side of things that I know of.  They will make a believer out of you!
author: Aram D.

description: SO GOOD!  The salsa is amazing.  If they sold it to take home, it would be worth the trip and the search for parking just to pick up a bottle.  That being said, everything else I've tried is incredible as well!  The fish tacos are spectacular - I am a big cheese lover and usually have buyer's remorse if my plate of Mexican food doesn't include cheese but the flavors in the fish tacos were so good, I didn't feel like I missed out on a thing.  The grilled veggie burrito is to die for - I've been thinking about it all week.  My husband is wild for their nachos and is even starting to suggest going to Papalote himself - this, from a die hard La Taqueria fan!  Keep it up Papalote, and I'll keep coming back for more!
author: Catherine H.

description: I'm in love with Papalote.  The salsa is some of the most exquisite I've had.   Chile verde burrito smothered in the salsa is not only scrumptious but will last you a couple meals.  Love the horchata too, not too sweet or gritty at the bottom.  Dude, the fact that you can buy a jar of their salsa is enough to keep me coming back even though I live 3 hours away.
author: E. Alicia P.

description: Food is pretty good, lines/wait is reasonable considering the food but after going for two years fairly consistently, I'm just done with the counter staff.  Just not very nice or even mildly pleasant and most of the time really annoying arrogant and aloof (it seems to have gotten worse over the last year).  I will not bother going back anymore- sorry kids.
author: Boris L.

description: the salsa gets 4 stars for sure and the carne asada burrito wasn't bad either. i wasn't blown away by the burrito, but the salsa more than made up for it with just the right amount of heat.
author: Gordon F.

description: I tried it recently and it was okay...I will give it 3 star...not bad for a quick burrito fix.
author: Ringo L.

description: Quality ingredients are the foundation behind this excellent Mission burrito joint, including hormone-free meats (Niman Ranch) and fresh veggies. Salsa? Outtathisworld and without peer. My favorite's the chili verde pork--better on some days than others, but that only means the place has real personality. I could eat here every day but I try not to.
author: Geddy L.

description: This place is pretty damn good.  The soyrizo burrito is great (and I'm not veggie), the mole is great, and steak is good. The shrimp isn't as good as La Corneta, but this is a great place for burrito diversity if you're sick of the same old ricy overstuff in the mission. It 's also nice when you don't feel like falling into the mexi-coma before you even get home  (aka reasonable portions)...
author: Willy c.

description: i only go for the salsa.  everything else is... ok.
author: Clarissa P.

description: I was excited to try this place because a bunch of people have raved to me about how good it is.  I went there for lunch late friday afternoon.  I ordered a super quesadilla.  I waited 25 minutes.  Still not done.  I ask the cashier how long.  Another ten minutes she says.  Why the fuck does it take 35 minutes to make a quesadilla??  It was busy, there but not that busy and I counted 8 people in the kitchen.  I got my money back because I was going to be late for work if I waited another 10 minutes. So...thanks papalote for wasting 30 minutes and forcing me to eat chips and a power bar for lunch
author: Cody R.

description: I have eaten here so many times that I feel obliged to write a review. Any time I tell people where I live, they say "Oh you're so close to Papalote, I've always wanted to eat there". To which I reply, "Get the fish taco/burrito or the shrimp quesadilla or the grilled veggie burrito, or, preferably, all three". I like the fact that their staff is always cheerful and polite, both on the phone or in person, even though they are always super busy. I make it a point to call about 20 minutes in advance if I am picking up food because I don't want to wait in their little waiting area for a long time, hungry and watching other people devour their burritos and tacos. Their salsa is very different from other places - most people love it but I know a few people who said "what's the deal with that orange-sauce they call salsa". I think it's great and love having it with their warm, fresh chips. Great place and good value.
author: Abheek G.

description: This was my FAVORITE burrito place until a few months ago.  Seven months pregnant, I ordered the vegetarian burrito.  I ended up VERY sick for the next 24 hours.  99% sure it was the burrito.  delicious, but something wasn't right
author: Lyndsay L.

description: soyrizo heaven and inventive veggie burritos. love and love. many of the mission style burrito places leave the veggie option bland and basic. this place takes it up a notch and keeps the spice right for the veggies!
author: Liz S.

description: I used to be on the fence about this place. I was concerned about the Vegan and Vegetarian elements of the menu. I was afraid that the meat wasn't going to be good or that I was going to be stared down if I ordered Carne Asada...so I ordered fish. The fish tacos (white fish sauteed in white wine sauce) are fabulous-- make sure to add avocado for pep. They got me by for a while and then Papalote started to die on the vine for me. BUT THEN-- I decided to get some balls and order the meat. It's amazing. It's lean. It's flavorful. It's everything you want in a Mexican meal. The salsa is fresh and tastes so rich it's as though it has a stick of butter in every ounce. You should go to Papalote--really.
author: Megan K.

description: So good! I think this is a hidden little gem. My sister and her friend called me a few days ago -they were in The City on biz - and said they were near Cesar Chavez and 24th streets. I directed them to Papalote, and they haven't stopped raving!
author: Tobias M.

description: Biggest disappointment of our SF trip.   Nothing we ordered was good, from the guac to the mole sauce, i.e. the easy to the hard.  I mean it was bad enough that I don't think we just ordered the wrong things.    Worst mexican food I've ever had at a place authentic enough to serve Jarritos and have aqua fresca tanks.
author: A. W.

description: The lovely cuzzins treated us out here over the weekend after spending the afternoon exploring the De Young museum.  They've been wanting to try this place out after many recommendations by close friends who are what you would call "the usual customers".  Not to mention that they reminded me that this was the place that beat Bobby Flay for the ultimate burrito throw down.  The place was packed when we arrived but never the less we got seated after we ordered and paid at the counter.  They had a variety of beers so each of the 4 of us decided to get a taste of different ones.  Good selections! The owner Manuel was very friendly, chatted and joked with us as if he had known us before.  This was our first time here.  Now the food...we ordered a little of everything but the taco.  The popular $20 burrito, chicken dilla, and steak nacho.  I loved all of them!  Most especially the fresh grilled steaks and the smokiness and flavors of it.  Then lets not forget that special sauce...excellent and different!  This place is so close to my work...so Papalote...you shall see me again!
author: Dimps I.

description: While Papalote is probably one of the more gourmet Mexican cafes in the Mission, I am not sure I see what all the hype is about. I came here for an early dinner and the place was not terribly crowded- we were able to get a table without any wait. I ordered a quesadilla with grilled zucchini and eggplant. I also spent quite a bit extra ($2.75 to be exact) to have a side of guacamole with this quesadilla. Why so much  money for a little dollop of mashed avocado? Can't answer that one. The waitress was clearly confused when I placed my order, since the the overhead board said that additional sides were only a dollar. But then again I also asked her if the vegan quesadilla had cheese in it, and she said yes so I knew she was not completely with the program. After a few unsuccessful attempted inquiries as to why the guacamole was more expensive than advertised,  I decided to just let it go, as I was getting rather hungry. The food came relatively quickly- in the meantime we snacked on chips and some very spicy salsa. Again, I don't see what the hype is about. The salsa was just that- salsa. Nothing extraordinary. In fact, I prefer fresh salsa, if anything. In any event, when the much awaited quesadilla finally arrived I was very excited to see that it was chock full of roasted veggies and not overly greasy or soggy. The cheese was relatively light- a white cheese (quesa fresca perhaps?) and the roasted vegetables were a delicious compliment. I much enjoyed dipping the crispy cheesy confection in the oh so expensive guacamole. I'll probably visit this place again if I happen to be in the Mission, and look forward to trying their soy products.
author: Kate A.

description: I couldn't agree more with some of the folks on this page.  If you're in a hurry...skip it.  If you're really hungry...skip it.  If you don't like creamy salsa...skip it.  If you're really broke...SKIP it.  If you have time, money, post nasal drip, and an English PhD - then by all means, have a seat.  The one star is for tasty fish that isn't breaded.
author: Lily N.

description: this is certainly not my first choice for a 'lil south of the border. the food here is so average. the beans are flavorless and the meat is often mediocre. occasionally i'll go with friends who rave about their fav dishes, however i gotta say- there are many places i would rather go. and whats up with the fish??? it is drenched in butter (which takes away from the flavor of everything).
author: SF U.

description: Oh Papa Lote, the times we've shared.  "Yuppie Burrito" and I have had our ups and downs.  It was love, oh it had to be love, discovering your vegan beans, addictive salsa and mole with tofu and that glorious soyrizo.  Then there was my year long boycott because of "Blondie," who on more than one occasion hung up on me, yelled at me and just gave off a generally sour and bummed out vibe that I don't really want in my life.  But, apparently, after months of visits again, Blondie is gone and there is nothing but warm love and yumminess in my belly.  But I feel that it's a bittersweet reunion, you see, a reunion that reminds me of some of my less ruling characteristics--I've reached this new plateau in the banal and repetitive exercise that is my existence on this planet.  I walk in to Papa Lote, and the nice shorter girl smiles, says "Super Soyrizo?" I nod, and my food arrives a couple minutes later.  This means I'm probably mere weeks, maybe days, from going in and reaching the ultimate and ultimately revealing plateau--walking in and asking for, gulp, "The Usual."  Due to my work schedule, I've reached this plateau at Love N Haight, and this, I'm fine with.  But, alas, with Papa Lote, it's just sheer and utter laziness.  I mean, with food this good two blocks from your house, how often would you cook?
author: Ben V.

description: The food here is really pretty good - it seems fresh, tasty, and more or less reasonably price.  My only complaint is that the cooks are SUPER STONED, and therefore incredibly slow.  While the first few times were fine, my last 3 visits took over 30 minutes to get my food.  Lay of the weed guys and get me my burrito a little faster.
author: Gregorio S.

description: I go to this place often, as i live a block away.  ever heard of a taqueria where you're tacos, burritos and quesadillas are MADE TO ORDER?  Really.  I am not talking about a scoop of pre-cooked meat from a bucket and onto the grill.  We're talkin' about a fresh raw piece of carne asada or chicken put on the grill especially for your burrito.  That's what Papalote is about.   Some people prefer McDonalds french fries over real freshly sliced potato french fries.  So if you wan't McDonalds, go to the taqueria down the street.  They're food is clearly fresh and delicious and some people aren't used to that.  They're salsa is also incredible.  For those veggies and vegans out there, this place is also the spot.  The only down side is it can get pretty busy and the line can sometimes be out the door.    I've called a few times to place an order and they've screwed it up more than once.  But they're food is still damn good.
author: Adrian N.

description: Though I would love to love Papalote, I find myself feeling slightly disappointed with the food each time.  It's very exciting to look at the menu and try to decide what to get.  To me, though, most of the time, the food tastes like something a friend whipped up at the house.  There is something deadly ordinary about the flavors they coax out of the ingredients:  it never makes me groan in appreciation tinged with jealousy, wishing I could make something that tastes this good at home.  The salsa is great, but I wish they would serve it in a wide-mouthed container that would make it easier to dip chips.  And that tablespoonful of jicama thing they serve--I can't tell if it's a meager side dish or relish that lacks entirely in the zip department.  I wish they'd either drop it entirely, rework it, or come up with something else that adds excitement to the entree.  I do like that they serve good beers on tap here, in addition to the typical cerveza selection at a regular taqueria.  I'm all for fresh, healthy interpretations of Mexican food:  I really wish I could be completely enthusiastic about Papalote, not just the idea of it.
author: maiko h.

description: My old Spanish teacher owns this place. He didn't teach me any Spanish, but this place makes the best nachos in the city.
author: Bethany D.

description: Tasty vegan options (including a Soyrizo burrito and grilled veg burrito) and fantastic housemade salsa!
author: D. B.

description:
good but not great.  simple and healthy but won't rush back.
shrimp tacos were ok but not creative.
I am still looking for the best  taco/burrito place in SF.
